Alternative polyadenylation in human B-lymphoblastoid cells has been shown to play a significant role in the regulation of gene expression and its variation across genetically distinct human individuals. We conducted a genomic survey of transcript ends in lymphoblastoid cells from genetically distinct human individuals and found that transcript end positions did not fall randomly in untranslated regions, but rather preferentially flanked the locations of 3′ regulatory elements, including miRNA sites. The usage of these transcript length forms and motifs varied across human individuals, and polymorphisms in polyadenylation signals and other 3′ motifs were significant predictors of expression levels of the genes in which they lay. Independent single-gene experiments confirmed the effects of polyadenylation variants on steady-state expression of their respective genes, and validated the regulatory function of 3′ cis-regulatory sequence elements that mediated expression of these distinct RNA length forms. Focusing on the immune regulator IRF5, we established the effect of natural variation in RNA 3′-end processing on regulatory response to antigen stimulation. Our results underscore the importance of two mechanisms at play in the genetics of 3′-end variation: the usage of distinct 3′-end processing signals and the effects of 3′ sequence elements that determine transcript fate.
SIVΔnef, a live attenuated simian immunodeficiency virus vaccine, is one of the most effective vaccines in inducing protection against wild-type lentiviral challenge. However, little is known about the mechanisms underlying its remarkable protective efficacy. Here, we demonstrate that the initial CD8 T cell response in the acute phase of SIVΔnef infection is mounted predominantly against more variable epitopes, followed by widespread sequence evolution and viral escape. Furthermore, we show that epitope escape expands the CD8 T cell repertoire that targets highly conserved epitopes, defined as anentropic specificity, and generates de novo responses to the escaped epitope variants during the vaccination period. These results correlate SIVΔnef-induced protection with expanded anentropic specificity and increased response depth. Importantly, these findings render SIVΔnef, long the gold standard in HIV/SIV vaccine research, as a proof-of-concept vaccine that highlights the significance of the twin principles of anentropic specificity and repertoire depth in successful vaccine design.
Candida albicans is one of the most common causes of mucosal fungal infections. The immune response to C. albicans in the oral mucosa is primarily mediated by cellular immunity. However, the mechanisms underlying the induction of antifungal immunity are not well understood. In this study, we investigated the role of interleukin-1 receptor ( IL-1R ) signaling in the neutrophil response to C. albicans in the oral mucosa. Using a mouse model of oropharyngeal candidiasis ( OPC ), we show that IL-1R signaling is critical for fungal control at the onset of infection. We demonstrate that IL-1R signaling regulates the recruitment of circulating neutrophils to the site of infection and the mobilization of newly generated neutrophils from the bone marrow. We also show that IL-1R signaling regulates the production of neutrophil-recruiting chemokines and granulocyte colony-stimulating factor ( G-CSF ) in response to C. albicans. We identified endothelial cells as the primary cellular source of G-CSF during OPC, which responded to IL-1α released from keratinocytes in the infected tissue. Our data establish a new link between IL-1 and granulopoiesis in the context of fungal infection. Together, we identified two complementary mechanisms coordinating the neutrophil response in the oral mucosa, which is critical for preventing fungal growth and dissemination, and thus protects the host from disease.
Between 2000 and 2007, the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis ( GPELF ) delivered more than 1. 9 billion treatments to nearly 600 million individuals via annual mass drug administration ( MDA ) of albendazole, ivermectin, and diethylcarbamazine to all at-risk populations for 4–6 years. To quantify the economic benefits of this achievement, the number of clinical manifestations averted was estimated and the savings associated with this disease prevention were analyzed in the context of direct treatment costs, indirect costs of lost-labor, and costs to the health system to care for affected individuals. An estimated US$21. 8 billion of direct economic benefits will be gained over the lifetime of 31. 4 million individuals treated during the first 8 years of the GPELF. Of this total, over US$2. 3 billion is realized by the protection of nearly 3 million newborns and other individuals from acquiring lymphatic filariasis as a result of their being born into areas freed of LF transmission. Additionally, more than 28 million individuals already infected with LF benefit from GPELF's halting the progression of their disease, resulting in an associated lifetime economic benefit of approximately US$19. 5 billion.
Gaucher disease ( GD ) is the most common lysosomal storage disease caused by homozygous mutations in the glucocerebrosidase ( GBA ) gene, leading to decreased enzymatic activity of glucocerebrosidase ( GCase ) and accumulation of glucocerebroside and glucosylsphingosine. Mutations in GBA also confer a strong risk for sporadic Parkinson’s disease ( PD ). We generated GBA nonsense mutant ( GBA-/- ) medaka that are completely deficient in GCase activity and display pathological phenotypes resembling human neuronopathic GD, including infiltration of Gaucher cell-like cells into the brains, progressive neuronal loss, and microgliosis. Detailed pathological findings revealed lysosomal abnormalities in neurons and accumulation of alpha-synuclein ( α-syn ) in axonal swellings containing autophagosomes. Unexpectedly, disruption of α-syn did not improve the life span, formation of axonal swellings, neuronal loss, or neuroinflammation in GBA-/- medaka. Our data suggest that GCase deficiency causes lysosomal dysfunction in neurons and α-syn accumulation in axonal swellings containing autophagosomes, and that α-syn may play an important role in the mechanisms of GBA mutations leading to PD. Furthermore, we demonstrate the minimal contribution of α-syn to the pathogenesis of neuronopathic GD in medaka.
Listeria monocytogenes, a facultative intracellular pathogen, is capable of inducing a robust cell-mediated immune response to sub-lethal infection. However, we show that L. monocytogenes confined within a phagosome suppresses the adaptive immune response. This suppression is not merely a consequence of inefficient antigen presentation, but is the result of direct suppression of the adaptive response. The presence of phagosome-confined L. monocytogenes not only limits the adaptive response to vacuole-confined L. monocytogenes, but also negates the response to L. monocytogenes within the cytosol. Co-infection with phagosome-confined and cytosolic L. monocytogenes prevents the generation of acquired immunity and limits the expansion of antigen-specific T cells relative to the cytosolic L. monocytogenes strain alone. We show that phagosome-confined L. monocytogenes suppresses the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and leads to the rapid MyD88-dependent production of IL-10. Blockade of the IL-10 receptor or the absence of MyD88 during primary infection restores protective immunity. Our studies demonstrate that the presence of microbes within a phagosome can directly impact the innate and adaptive immune response by antagonizing the signaling pathways necessary for inflammation and the generation of protective CD8 T cells.
Primary open-angle glaucoma ( POAG ) is the most common type of glaucoma and a leading cause of blindness worldwide. Genome-wide association studies have previously identified a significant association between POAG and the SIX6 locus. We sequenced the SIX6 coding and regulatory regions in 262 POAG cases and 256 controls and identified six nonsynonymous coding variants, including five rare and one common variant, Asn141His ( rs33912345 ), which was associated significantly with POAG in the NEIGHBOR/GLAUGEN datasets. These variants were tested in an in vivo Danio rerio ( zebrafish ) complementation assay to evaluate ocular metrics such as eye size and optic nerve structure. Five variants, found primarily in POAG cases, were hypomorphic or null, while the sixth variant, found only in controls, was benign. One variant in the SIX6 enhancer increased expression of SIX6 and disrupted its regulation. We identified a clinical feature in POAG patients that appears to be dependent upon SIX6 genotype: patients who are homozygous for the SIX6 risk allele ( His141 ) have a statistically thinner retinal nerve fiber layer than patients homozygous for the SIX6 non-risk allele ( Asn141 ). Our results lead us to hypothesize that SIX6 risk variants disrupt the development of the neural retina, leading to a reduced number of retinal ganglion cells, thereby increasing the risk of glaucoma-associated vision loss.
Clostridium difficile, a human intestinal pathogen, produces flagella that promote adherence to intestinal epithelial cells and indirectly impact the production of glucosylating toxins, which are essential for diarrheal disease development. Here, we report the identification of a flagellar switch that controls the phase variable production of flagella and glucosylating toxins in C. difficile. The flagellar switch is a 154 bp invertible sequence flanked by 21 bp inverted repeats located upstream of the flgB operon containing the early stage flagellar genes. Bacteria with the flagellar switch in one orientation ( “flg phase ON” ) express flagellum and toxin genes, produce flagella, and secrete the toxins. In contrast, bacteria with the flagellar switch in the inverse orientation ( “flg phase OFF” ) are attenuated for flagellar and toxin gene expression, are aflagellate, and show decreased toxin secretion. The orientation of the flagellar switch is reversible during growth in vitro. We provide evidence that gene regulation via the flagellar switch occurs post-transcription initiation and requires a C. difficile-specific regulatory factor to destabilize or degrade the early flagellar gene mRNA when the flagellar switch is in the OFF orientation. The tyrosine recombinase RecV, which catalyzes inversion at the cwpV switch, is also responsible for inversion at the flagellar switch in both directions.
Clostridium difficile is an obligate anaerobic pathogen in which endospores play a central role in the infectious cycle. We have studied the function and regulation of the sporulation sigma factors in C. difficile, which are key regulators of the endosporulation pathway. The sporulation sigma factors in C. difficile are σF, σE, σG, and σK, which control gene expression in the forespore and mother cell during endospore development. Our results show that while the main periods of activity of the sigma factors are conserved, the activity of σE is partially independent of σF, σG activity is not dependent on σE, and the activity of σK does not require σG. We also show that σK is not strictly required for heat resistant spore formation. Our results indicate reduced temporal segregation between the activities of the early and late sigma factors, and reduced requirement for the σF-to-σE, σE-to-σG, and σG-to-σK cell-cell signaling pathways. The activity of σK does not require σG, but mutation of sigG reduces the activity of σK at late stages of spore morphogenesis. Our results support the view that the top level of the endosporulation network is conserved in evolution, with the sigma factors acting as the key regulators of the pathway, established some 2. 5 billion years ago upon its emergence at the base of the Firmicutes Phylum.
Multisite allosteric proteins can be difficult to model due to the large number of possible phosphoforms. We present a compact framework to model the dose response of allosteric multisite phosphorylation proteins using a single auxiliary variable. This reduction can closely replicate the steady state behavior of detailed multisite systems such as the Monod-Wyman-Changeux allosteric model or rule-based models. We show that optimal ultrasensitivity is obtained when the activation of an allosteric protein by its individual sites is concerted and redundant. This reduction makes the framework useful for modeling and analyzing biochemical systems in practical applications, where several multisite proteins may interact simultaneously. We apply this framework to a newly discovered checkpoint signaling pathway in budding yeast, which has been proposed to measure cell growth by monitoring signals generated at sites of plasma membrane growth. We show that the known components of this pathway can form a robust hysteretic switch. This system incorporates a signal proportional to bud growth or size, a mechanism to read the signal, and an all-or-none response triggered only when the signal reaches a threshold indicating that sufficient growth has occurred.
Quorum sensing ( QS ) is a mechanism by which bacteria communicate with each other to achieve multicellularity and gain a selective advantage. However, the mechanistic underpinnings of QS “switching” phenomena have remained elusive. In this study, we employed a combination of experimental work and mathematical models to decipher the network connectivity and signal transduction in the autoinducer-2 ( AI-2 ) QS system of Escherichia coli ( E. coli ). We separated the network architecture into sub-networks to examine negative and positive feedback mechanisms. A new unreported negative feedback interaction was hypothesized and tested via a simple mathematical model. We also revealed the importance of the LsrR regulator and its determinant role in the E. coli QS “switch”, which is normally masked by interfering regulatory loops. Our simple model allowed for a mechanistic understanding of the interplay among regulatory sub-structures and their contributions to the overall native functioning network. This “bottom-up” approach will serve to unravel complex QS network architectures and lead to the directed coordination of emergent behaviors.
Schistosoma haematobium infection has been shown to increase the risk of Plasmodium falciparum infection in school-age children living in rural areas of Gabon. In this longitudinal study, we investigated the effect of schistosomiasis and soil-transmitted helminths ( STH ) on the prevalence and incidence of P. falciparum infection in school-age children living in two rural communities in the vicinity of Lambaréné, Gabon. Our results show that schistosomiasis tends to increase the risk of P. falciparum infection, but when combined with Trichuris trichiura or hookworm infection, the risk is significantly increased ( aOR = 3. 9 [95%CI: 1. 7–9. 2] ). The incidence of malaria over time was 0. 51[95%CI: 0. 45–0. 57] per person-year and was higher in the Schistosoma-infected group compared to the non-infected group ( 0. 61 vs 0. 43, p = 0. 02 ), with a significant delay of time-to first-malaria event only in children aged from 6 to 10-years-old infected with Schistosoma haematobium. Our results suggest that STH enhance the risk for P. falciparum infection in schistosomiasis-positive children, and when infected, that schistosomiasis enhances susceptibility to developing malaria in young children but not in older children.
Leishmania donovani infection induces an inflammatory response mainly mediated by the transcription factor IRF-5. IRF-5 is responsible for the activation of genes encoding pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-6 and TNF. During L. donovani infection, the inflammatory response induced by IRF-5 limits CD8+ T cell expansion and induces HIF-1α expression in dendritic cells. Induction of HIF-1α in dendritic cells results in decreased IL-12 and increased IL-10 expression. Ablation of HIF-1α in CD11c+ cells leads to a higher frequency of short-lived effector CD8+ T cells, enhanced CD8+ T cell expansion, and increased IL-12 expression by splenic DCs. Moreover, mice with a targeted depletion of HIF-1α in CD11c+ cells have a significantly lower splenic parasite burden, suggesting that induction of HIF-1α may represent an immune evasive mechanism adopted by Leishmania parasites to establish persistent infections.
Visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) is a serious public health problem in endemic regions, especially in the Indian sub-continent, North and East Africa, and South America. VL is one of the most neglected diseases in the world, closely associated with poverty, for which effective and affordable chemotherapies remain scarce. In the context of high fatality rates associated with VL, the identification of prognostic factors to identify patients at higher risk of unfavorable outcomes represents a potential tool for clinical practice. This systematic review brings together information from 14 studies conducted in Latin America on the potential predictors of adverse prognosis and death from VL. The strongest predictors identified in this review were jaundice, thrombocytopenia, hemorrhage, HIV coinfection, diarrhea, age <5 and age >40–50 years, severe neutropenia, dyspnoea and bacterial infections. Edema and low hemoglobin concentration were also associated with unfavorable outcomes. The main limitation identified was the absence of validation procedures for the few prognostic models developed so far. Integration of the results from different investigations conducted over the last 10 years enabled the identification of consistent prognostic variables that could be useful in recognizing and handling VL patients at higher risk of unfavorable outcomes. The development of externally validated prognostic models must be prioritized in future investigations.
Leishmaniasis is a major public health problem in Algeria, where the treatment of visceral and cutaneous leishmaniasis ( VL and CL ) has been based on antimony-containing drugs for decades. However, high drug selective pressure may favor the emergence of chemoresistant parasites. We investigated the antimony susceptibility of Leishmania isolates collected over a 30-year period in Algeria. We analyzed 106 isolates collected between 1976 and 2013 from humans, dogs, rodents, and phlebotomines, as well as 18 isolates from dogs in France. We determined the 50% inhibitory concentrations ( IC50 ) of potassium antimony tartrate ( Sb ( III ) ) and sodium stibogluconate ( Sb ( V ) ) in promastigotes and intramacrophage amastigotes, respectively. We also determined the epidemiological cutoff ( ECOFF ) that allowed us to differentiate between Leishmania species causing cutaneous or visceral leishmaniasis that were susceptible ( S+ ) or insusceptible ( S- ) to the trivalent form of antimony. Our results show a trend of increasing antimony susceptibility in VL isolates during the 30-year period. In contrast, an increase in the frequency of S- phenotypes in isolates causing CL was observed during the same period. The emergence of S- phenotypes correlates with the inclusion of L. killicki ( syn: L. tropica ) isolates that cause cutaneous leishmaniasis and that have emerged in Algeria during the last decade. Our results provide insight into the spatiotemporal dynamics of Leishmania antimony susceptibility in Algeria and highlight the need for the future implementation of an effective methodology to determine the antimony susceptibility status of Leishmania isolates to detect the emergence of and prevent the dissemination of drug-resistant strains.
Crohn’s disease ( CD ) is a chronic inflammatory condition of diverse etiology. We investigated the link between acute infectious gastroenteritis and the onset of CD. We developed two novel models to study the comorbidity of acute gastroenteritis caused by Salmonella Typhimurium or Citrobacter rodentium in mice colonized with adherent-invasive Escherichia coli ( AIEC ), a bacterial pathobiont linked to CD. We show that disease activity in the post-infectious period after gastroenteritis is driven by the tissue-associated expansion of the resident AIEC pathobiont, with an attendant increase in immunopathology, barrier defects, and delays in mucosal restitution following pathogen clearance. These features required AIEC resistance to host defense peptides and a fulminant inflammatory response to the enteric pathogen. Our results suggest that individuals colonized by AIEC at the time of acute infectious gastroenteritis may be at greater risk for CD onset. Importantly, our data identify AIEC as a tractable disease modifier, a finding that could be exploited in the development of therapeutic interventions following infectious gastroenteritis in at-risk individuals. We show that AIEC-colonized mice that develop infectious gastroenteritis in response to either Salmonella Typhimurium or Citrobacter rodentium have a worsened outcome compared to AIEC-naïve animals exposed to the same infection stimuli.
In flowering plants, the female gametophyte of Arabidopsis consists of two gametic cells, the egg cell and the central cell, and five accessory cells. The mechanisms that underlie the formation of accessory versus gametic cell fate are unknown. In a screen for regulators of egg cell fate, we isolated the lachesis ( lis ) mutant which forms supernumerary egg cells. In lis mutants, accessory cells differentiate gametic cell fate, indicating that LIS is involved in a mechanism that prevents accessory cells from adopting gametic cell fate. The temporal and spatial pattern of LIS expression suggests that this mechanism is generated in gametic cells. LIS is homologous to the yeast splicing factor PRP4, indicating that components of the splice apparatus participate in cell fate decisions. Our results suggest that all cells in the female gametophyte are competent to differentiate gametic cell fate and that LIS is involved in a mechanism that represses gametic cell fate in the accessory cells. The lis-1 mutant phenotype reveals two levels of cell fate regulation, one between gametic and accessory cells, and one between egg and central cell. The late initiation of cell-specific marker genes indicates that in Arabidopsis distinct cell fates are only manifested after cellularization.
Neglected Tropical Diseases ( NTDs ) such as podoconiosis, triggered by exposure to irritant soils in the tropical highlands, can be prevented through the use of footwear. However, in a rural highland Ethiopian community endemic for podoconiosis, there are considerable barriers to consistent use of shoes. Using the PRECEDE-PROCEED model, we assessed the social, behavioral, environmental, educational, and ecological needs influencing whether and when children wear shoes in this community. We gathered information from 242 respondents using focus groups, semi-structured interviews, and extended case studies. We found that shoe-wearing norms are changing, with going barefoot increasingly seen as ‘shameful’. However, many practical and social barriers prevent the desire to wear shoes from being translated into practice. Limited financial resources mean that people are neither able to purchase more than one pair of shoes to ensure their longevity nor afford shoes of the preferred quality. As a result, shoes are typically preserved for special occasions and might not be provided for children until they reach a certain age. We identified several barriers to shoe wearing that are amenable to intervention and which we anticipate will be of benefit to those considering NTD prevention through shoe distribution. These barriers are likely to be relevant to a range of NTDs and include financial constraints, poor suitability of shoes for common activities, and low perceptions of disease risk.
Pseudorabies virus ( PRV ) Us9 is a viral protein that plays a central role in targeting viral capsids and glycoproteins to axons of infected neurons. We have shown that Us9 is associated with lipid rafts on the surface of infected cells, and that this association is critical for Us9-mediated sorting of viral structural proteins to axons. In this report, we demonstrate that Us9 is highly enriched in detergent-resistant membranes ( DRMs ) of non-polarized and polarized PC12 cells, a rat pheochromocytoma cell line that acquires many of the characteristics of sympathetic neurons in the presence of nerve growth factor ( NGF ). We also show that reducing the affinity of Us9 for lipid rafts inhibits anterograde transmission of infection from sympathetic neurons to epithelial cells in vitro. We conclude that association of Us9 with lipid rafts is key for efficient targeting of structural proteins to axons and, as a consequence, for directional spread of PRV from pre-synaptic to post-synaptic neurons and cells of the mammalian nervous system. Our findings are consistent with a model where viral capsids and membrane proteins traffic together in axons as mature virus particles.
Nongenetic heterogeneity is a phenomenon in which genetically identical cells exhibit extensive phenotypic variation even under constant and benign conditions. This phenomenon has important clinical implications, as cells within tumors and microbial infections show nongenetic heterogeneity in growth rate and in susceptibility to drugs or stress. Using the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae as a model, we show that heterogeneity in intracellular cyclic AMP ( cAMP ) levels acting through the Ras/cAMP/protein kinase A ( PKA ) pathway and its target transcription factors Msn2 and Msn4 underlies this nongenetic heterogeneity. Lower levels of cAMP correspond to slower growth, as shown by direct comparison of cAMP concentration in subpopulations enriched for slower vs. faster growing cells. The paralogs Msn2 and Msn4 differ in their roles in nongenetic heterogeneity in a way that demonstrates slow growth and stress tolerance are not inevitably linked. Heterogeneity in growth rate requires both Msn2 and Msn4, whereas only Msn2 is required for heterogeneity in expression of Tsl1, a subunit of trehalose synthase that contributes to acute-stress tolerance. Perturbing nongenetic heterogeneity by mutating genes in this pathway, or by culturing wild-type cells with the cell-permeable cAMP analog 8-bromo-cAMP or the PKA inhibitor H89, significantly impacts survival of acute heat stress. Our results shed light on the genetic control of nongenetic heterogeneity and suggest a possible means of defeating bet-hedging pathogens or tumor cells by making them more uniformly susceptible to treatment.
Chikungunya virus ( CHIKV ), an alphavirus and member of the Togaviridae family, is responsible for causing severe febrile disease in humans. In December 2013, the Asian Lineage of CHIKV spread from the Old World to the Americas and rapidly spread throughout the New World. To understand how CHIKV may have evolved during this outbreak, we studied the viral genetic diversity present in infected individuals from Guadeloupe and Martinique, two islands in the center of the epidemic. We used deep-sequencing technologies to characterize the minority variants and diversity present in CHIKV infected individuals. We observed changes in the consensus sequence as well as a diverse range of minority variants present at various levels in the population. Furthermore, we found that overall diversity was dramatically reduced after single passages in cell lines. We constructed an infectious clone from this outbreak and identified a novel 3’ untranslated region ( UTR ) structure, not previously found in nature, that led to increased replication in insect cells.
UBTOR, a previously unannotated gene, has been identified as a functional player in regulating cell growth and mTOR signaling. We show that reduction of UBTOR function in cultured hippocampal neurons and PC12 cells promotes neurite outgrowth, while UBTOR depletion activates mTOR signaling and promotes cell growth. In contrast, UBTOR overexpression suppresses colony formation in cancer cell lines. Mechanistic studies reveal that UBTOR inhibits mTOR signaling by stabilizing DEPTOR, a component of the mTOR complex. In zebrafish, disruption of the ubtor gene results in higher mTOR activity and aggravates HRAS ( G12V ) induced neoplasia. Furthermore, UBTOR depletion promotes tumor growth and mTOR signaling in a xenograft mouse model. These findings demonstrate how UBTOR regulates cell growth and neoplasia via mTOR signaling.
Trypanosoma brucei, the protozoan parasite responsible for human African trypanosomiasis, is a highly diverged organism from well-studied eukaryotes such as yeast and mammals. As a result, more than half of its proteins have unknown functions, hindering our understanding of its biology and pathogenesis. To address this knowledge gap, we systematically interrogated the co-complex interactions of more than 3354 protein groups in the procyclic life stage of T. brucei using biochemical fractionation. Our analysis led to the identification of 128 high-confidence complexes encompassing 716 protein groups, including 635 protein groups that lacked experimental annotation. These complexes correlate well with known pathways and proteins co-expressed across the T. brucei life cycle, and provide potential functions for a large number of previously uncharacterized proteins. We validated the functions of several novel proteins associated with the RNA-editing machinery, including a candidate potentially involved in the mitochondrial post-transcriptional regulation of T. brucei. Our results provide an unprecedented view of the protein complex map of T. brucei and serve as a reliable resource for further characterization of trypanosomatid proteins.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( Mtb ) is a bacterium that causes tuberculosis ( TB ), which is commonly considered a chronic lung disease. However, Mtb can also cause extrapulmonary infection in any organ, and lymph nodes ( LNs ) are among the most common sites of infection. Despite this, the dynamics of Mtb infection in LNs and its effect on LN structure and function are relatively unstudied. We analyzed thoracic LNs from Mtb-infected cynomolgus and rhesus macaques using PET CT scans, bacterial burden, LN structure, and immune function. We found that LNs in Mtb-infected macaques increased in PET-CT-measured metabolic activity early during infection, and at necropsy, almost all of the FDG-avid LNs contained viable Mtb or persistent Mtb DNA. We show that Mtb grows to the same level in LNs of both macaque species, but cynomolgus macaque LNs were better able to control the infection compared to rhesus macaque LNs. Notably, compared to lung granulomas, LNs are generally poor at killing Mtb, even with drug treatment. Granulomas that form in Mtb-infected LNs disrupt LN structure and are associated with higher Mtb burden. Our data support that LNs are not only sites of antigen presentation and immune activation during infection, but also serve as important sites for persistence of significant numbers of Mtb bacilli.
Microsporidia are obligate intracellular parasites that infect a wide range of animals, including nematodes. The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans has been used as a model host to study microsporidia, but little was known about the diversity and ubiquity of microsporidian infections in nematodes in the wild. Here, we describe the isolation and culture of 47 nematodes with microsporidian infections. We found that Nematocida parisii is the most common microsporidian infecting C. elegans in the wild. In addition, we describe and name six new species in the Nematocida genus, as well as two new genera, Enteropsectra and Pancytospora, which are genetically distinct from Nematocida and belong to the main clade of microsporidia that includes human pathogens. These microsporidia are horizontally transmitted and most specifically infect intestinal cells, except for Pancytospora epiphaga, which replicates mostly in the epidermis of its Caenorhabditis host. We also show that some microsporidia have broad host specificity, while others have narrow host specificity. For example, some microsporidia can infect Oscheius tipulae but not its sister species Oscheius sp. 3, and conversely some microsporidia found infecting Oscheius sp. 3 do not infect O. tipulae. Our results illustrate the diversity and ubiquity of microsporidian infections in nematodes and provide a rich resource to investigate host-parasite coevolution in tractable nematode hosts.
Chemokine receptors are a subclass of G protein coupled receptors that play a crucial role in the human immune system and are involved in cancer metastasis as well as HIV infection. Chemokine receptors can form homo- and heterodimers or higher order oligomers, which modulate receptor function. However, structural information about chemokine receptor homo- and heterodimers and their interaction with cholesterol is limited. Here, we report the homo- and heterodimerization patterns of the chemokine receptors CXCR4, CCR5, and CCR2 at an atomistic level using thousands of molecular dynamics simulations. Our results show that the closely related CC chemokine receptors CCR5 and CCR2 share common features with regard to dimerization and interactions with cholesterol that differ from the previously reported characteristics of CXCR4. Cholesterol modulates the CC homodimer interfaces in a subtype-specific manner. Chemokine receptor heterodimers display distinct dimerization patterns for CXCR4/CCR5 and CXCR4/CCR2. Furthermore, associations between CXCR4 and CCR5 reveal an increased cholesterol-sensitivity as compared to CXCR4/CCR2 heterodimerization patterns. This work provides a first comprehensive structural overview of the complex interaction network between chemokine receptors and indicates how heterodimerization and the interaction with the membrane environment diversifies the function of closely related GPCRs.
Systemic leishmaniasis, a disease caused by Leishmania parasites, has been found to present with a wider spectrum of signs and symptoms than previously suspected. In addition to the classical form of the disease, characterized by prolonged fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and wasting, a sub-clinical form and an atypical form have been identified. The atypical form presents with depressed immunity and symptoms masquerading as a condition in which the immune system is non-functional, leading to recurrent secondary infections and a variety of clinical signs and symptoms. This atypical form was identified in 19. 4% of 160 patients with depressed immunity who were referred to a specialized laboratory for further evaluation of their immune system function. Among these patients, 31 were adults, indicating that systemic leishmaniasis is not limited to the pediatric age group. The diagnosis of atypical systemic leishmaniasis should be entertained in any patient with an unexplained depressed immunity state and in whom no obvious immunologic defect can be identified. Our findings suggest that systemic leishmaniasis is far more common than diagnosed to date and that it presents with a much wider spectrum of signs and symptoms than previously suspected.
A genome-wide analysis of human disease alleles reveals that their locations are correlated in paralogous proteins. We have assembled a unique collection of known disease-causing variants from OMIM and the Human Genome Mutation Database ( HGMD ) and used them to identify and characterize pairs of sequence variants that occur at homologous positions within paralogous human proteins. Our analyses demonstrate that the locations of variants are correlated in paralogous proteins. Moreover, if one member of a variant-pair is disease-causing, its partner is likely to be disease-causing as well. We find that sequence variants co-occur at aligned amino acid pairs more frequently than expected by chance, suggesting that similar functional constraints on paralogous protein sequences result in coordinated distributions of both disease and non–disease-causing variants along their lengths. These data show how paralogous disease genes and their variant-pairs can be used for hypothesis generation and as points of departure for further clinical research. We have also assembled a collection of known disease-causing variations drawn from OMIM and HGMD and mapped each of these variations to their gene annotations and protein sequences.
Plasmodium falciparum, the parasite responsible for the deadliest form of malaria, is exposed to multiple selection pressures within the human host. However, the extent to which the parasite responds to or is selected by the host environment in severe malaria remains unclear. We used RNA sequencing ( RNAseq ) to analyse gene expression in 44 parasite isolates that caused severe and uncomplicated malaria in Papuan patients. The transcriptomes of 19 parasite isolates associated with severe malaria indicated that these parasites had decreased glycolysis without activation of compensatory pathways; altered chromatin structure and probably transcriptional regulation through decreased histone methylation; reduced surface expression of PfEMP1; and down-regulated expression of multiple chaperone proteins. We also identified novel associations between disease severity and PfEMP1 transcripts, domains, and smaller sequence segments, and confirmed all previously reported associations between expressed PfEMP1 sequences and severe disease. These findings will inform efforts to identify vaccine targets for severe malaria and indicate how parasites adapt to or are selected by the host environment in severe malaria.
HIV-1 infection is a major global health problem, and the development of effective prevention strategies is urgently needed. One promising approach is the delivery of broadly-neutralizing antibodies via adeno-associated virus ( AAV ) vectors. In this study, we investigated the protective effects of AAV-delivered anti-SIV monoclonal antibodies ( mAbs ) in rhesus monkeys against SIVmac239 challenge. We used an AAV vector to deliver the anti-SIV mAb 5L7 IgG1 intramuscularly to rhesus monkeys, achieving persisting levels of delivered mAb as high as 270 μg/ml. However, host antibody responses to the delivered mAb were observed in 9 of the 12 monkeys, limiting the concentration of delivered mAb that could be achieved. Despite the absence of detectable neutralizing activity against the challenge virus, the six monkeys in the AAV-5L7 IgG1 mAb group showed clear protective effects against SIVmac239 challenge. These effects included lowering of viral load at peak height, lowering of viral load at set point, and delay in the time to peak viral load from the time of the infectious virus exposure. The monkey with the highest level of delivered 5L7 mAb completely resisted six successive SIVmac239 i. v. challenges, including a final challenge with a dose of 10 i. v. infectious units. Our results demonstrate the continued promise of this approach for the prevention of HIV-1 infection in people. However, the problem of anti-antibody responses will need to be understood and overcome for the promise of this approach to be effectively realized.
Motor proteins, such as myosin V and kinesin KIF1A, have traditionally been studied under the assumption that they respond linearly to thermal noise or structural perturbations. However, we have found that this linearity assumption is deficient for ligand-induced conformational motions and can even be violated for characteristic thermal fluctuations. We have performed numerical investigations of the conformational relaxation properties of myosin V and kinesin KIF1A within the coarse-grained elastic network approximation. Our results indicate that neither a single normal mode nor a superposition of such modes yields an approximation of the strongly nonlinear dynamics of these motor proteins. While slow conformational relaxation motions in myosin V can still be qualitatively characterized in terms of normal modes, the normal mode description breaks down completely for kinesin KIF1A. We have found that ordered and robust mechanochemical motions are characteristic for both protein motors, even though they cannot be described in terms of the linear response. These motions, which follow after an energetic activation, are conformational relaxation processes. Large-scale conformational changes may take place in proteins as a result of ligand binding. Our results indicate that important assumptions of the theory of protein dynamics may need to be reconsidered.
Clathrin-independent ( CI ) endocytic pathways, such as the clathrin-independent carriers/GPI-AP enriched early endosomal compartment ( CLIC/GEEC ) pathway, have been difficult to study due to the lack of specific cargo or regulators. Here, we show that specific caveolar proteins, including caveolins and cavins, are negative regulators of the CLIC/GEEC pathway. Cavin-1 and Cavin-3, but not Cavin-2 or Cavin-4, inhibit the CLIC/GEEC pathway in a process independent of caveola formation. Caveolin-1 ( CAV1 ) and CAV3 also inhibit the CLIC/GEEC pathway upon over-expression. Expression of caveolar proteins leads to a reduction in the formation of early CLIC/GEEC carriers, as detected by quantitative electron microscopy analysis. Furthermore, the CLIC/GEEC pathway is upregulated in cells lacking CAV1/Cavin-1 or with reduced expression of Cavin-1 and Cavin-3. Inhibition by caveolins can be mimicked by the isolated caveolin scaffolding domain and is associated with perturbed diffusion of lipid microdomain components. In the absence of cavins, CAV1 is itself endocytosed preferentially through the CLIC/GEEC pathway, but the pathway loses polarization and sorting attributes with consequences for membrane dynamics and endocytic polarization in migrating cells and adult muscle tissue. We also found that noncaveolar Cavin-1 can act as a modulator for the activity of the key regulator of the CLIC/GEEC pathway, Cdc42.
Aspartate-Less Receiver ( ALR ) domains are an atypical subclass of Receiver ( REC ) domains that lack the conserved aspartate ( Asp ) residue required for phosphorylation by sensory histidine kinases in typical two-component signaling systems. We have compiled a dataset of 2, 976 REC domains that are missing or have substitutions at the conserved Asp position, which we have renamed as Aspartate-Less Receivers ( ALRs ). Our data show that ALRs are surprisingly common, comprising ~4% of all REC domains and ~2 per completed genome in bacteria. ALRs are enriched for when attached to more rare effector outputs and have diversified to accommodate signaling inputs other than Asp phosphorylation, such as binding small molecules and Ser-Thr phosphorylation through bacterial eukaryotic-like Ser-Thr kinases and their cognate PP2C phosphatases. Our analysis of ALR atomic structures, combined with structural, biochemical and genetic data of the ALR archetype RitR from Streptococcus pneumoniae, suggests that ALRs have reorganized their active pockets to take on a constitutive regulatory role or accommodate input signals other than Asp phosphorylation, while largely retaining the canonical post-phosphorylation mechanisms and dimeric interface.
Oncolytic herpes simplex viruses ( oHSVs ) have shown efficacy in clinical trials, but most of them are attenuated or over-attenuated due to deletions/mutations in genes that counteract the host response. We have developed next-generation oHSVs that carry no deletions/mutations and gain cancer-specificity from specific retargeting to tumor cell receptors, such as HER2. These viruses are fully virulent in targeted cancer cells, but spare other cells in the tumor. We report on the first efficacy study of HER2-retargeted, fully-virulent oHSVs in immunocompetent mice. Both the unarmed R-LM113 and the IL-12-armed R-115 inhibited the growth of the primary HER2-Lewis lung carcinoma-1 ( HER2-LLC1 ) tumor, with R-115 being more efficacious. Mice that survived the primary tumor were protected from the growth of contralateral untreated tumors, providing evidence for an abscopal immunotherapeutic effect. Analysis of the local response showed that R-115 unleashed the immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment, inducing immunomodulatory cytokines, including IFNγ and T-bet, which promoted Th1 polarization. Tumor-infiltrating cells, such as CD4+, CD335+, CD8+, Foxp3+, CD141+, and CD11b+ cells, were increased in the tumors of all responders, with R-115-treated mice showing preferential increases in CD8+, Foxp3+, CD141+ cells and decreases in CD11b+ cells. The durable response included a breakage of tolerance towards both HER2 and wild-type tumor cells, and underscored a systemic immunotherapeutic vaccine response.
HIV vaccine vector-induced CD4 T cells manifest marked differences in their susceptibility to HIV infection. While Ad5 vector-specific CD4 T cells are readily susceptible to HIV, ALVAC vector-specific CD4 T cells are substantially less susceptible to both R5 and X4 HIV infection in vitro. The lower HIV susceptibility of ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells is associated with the reduced surface expression of HIV entry co-receptors CCR5 and CXCR4 on these cells. Phenotypic analyses show that ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells display a strong Th1 phenotype, producing higher levels of IFN-γ and CCL4 ( MIP-β ) but little IL-17. In contrast, Ad5 vector-specific CD4 T cells are highly susceptible to R5 HIV infection, with a mean p24+% of 26. 9%. In contrast, ALVAC-induced CD4 T cells in RV144 PBMC are markedly less susceptible to R5 HIV, with a mean p24+% of 1. 1%. These data suggest that the vector-specific CD4 T cells induced by different HIV vaccine vectors manifest marked differences in their susceptibility to both R5 and X4 HIV infection in vitro, with ALVAC-specific CD4 T cells being less susceptible than Ad5 vector-specific CD4 T cells. Our data provide strong evidence for distinct HIV susceptibility of CD4 T cells induced by different vaccine vectors and highlight the importance of better evaluating anti-vector responses in HIV vaccination.
The evolution of X inactivation strategies among therian mammals exhibits considerable diversity, ranging from strict paternally inherited X inactivation ( PXI ) to unbiased random X inactivation ( RXI ). PXI renders females haploid for all maternally inherited alleles, while RXI equalizes expression of maternally and paternally inherited alleles in each female tissue. We present a theoretical population genetic analysis of X inactivation evolution and examine how conditions of dominance, linkage, recombination, and sex-differential selection influence evolutionary trajectories of X inactivation. Our results indicate that a single interaction between allelic dominance and sex-differential selection can select for a broad and continuous range of X inactivation strategies, including unequal rates of inactivation between maternally and paternally inherited X chromosomes. RXI is favored over complete PXI as long as alleles deleterious to female fitness are sufficiently recessive, and the criteria for RXI evolution is more restrictive when fitness variation is sexually antagonistic relative to variation that is deleterious to both sexes. Evolutionary transitions from PXI to RXI generally increase mean relative female fitness at the expense of decreased male fitness.
Japanese encephalitis virus ( JEV ) is the first flavivirus found to be sensitive to the antiviral activity of human zinc-finger antiviral protein ( ZAP ). ZAP is a host factor that restricts the infection of many viruses through RNA degradation, translation inhibition, and innate immune responses. We investigated the antiviral potential of human ZAP ( isoforms ZAP-L and ZAP-S ) against three flaviviruses: JEV, dengue virus ( DENV ), and Zika virus ( ZIKV ). Overexpression of ZAP blocked JEV infection but not DENV or ZIKV infection, and depletion of endogenous ZAP enhanced JEV replication. ZAP hampered JEV translation and targeted viral RNA for 3′-5′ RNA exosome-mediated degradation. The zinc-finger motifs of ZAP were essential for RNA targeting and anti-JEV activity. JEV 3′-untranslated region ( UTR ), especially in the region with dumbbell structures and high content of CG dinucleotide, was mapped to bind ZAP and confer sensitivity to ZAP. Our data suggest that 3′-5′ RNA degradation by the exosome complex is involved in the antiviral mechanism of ZAP against JEV infection.
Rift Valley fever virus ( RVFV ) is a major human and animal pathogen that causes severe disease including hemorrhagic fever or encephalitis. The virus is endemic to parts of Africa and the Arabian Peninsula, but there is significant concern regarding its introduction into non-endemic regions and the potentially devastating effect on livestock populations with concurrent infections of humans. To date, there is little detailed data directly comparing the host response to infection with wild-type or vaccine strains of RVFV and correlation with viral pathogenesis. Here, we characterized clinical and systemic immune responses to infection with wild-type strain ZH501 or vaccine strain MP-12 in the C57BL/6 mouse. Animals infected with live-attenuated MP-12 survived productive viral infection with little evidence of clinical disease and minimal cytokine response in evaluated tissues. In contrast, ZH501 infection was lethal, caused depletion of lymphocytes and platelets and elicited a strong, systemic cytokine response which correlated with high virus titers and significant tissue pathology.
Chemotherapy-induced chemoresistance in triple-negative breast cancer ( TNBC ) is a major obstacle to the improvement of patient survival. Our results show that C-C motif chemokine ligand 20 ( CCL20 ) is significantly elevated during taxane-containing chemotherapy in breast cancer patients with nonpathologic complete response. CCL20 promotes the self-renewal and maintenance of breast cancer stem cells ( BCSCs ) through the activation of the p65 nuclear factor kappa B ( NF-κB ) pathway, significantly increasing the frequency and taxane resistance of BCSCs. Moreover, CCL20 promotes the expression of ATP-binding cassette subfamily B member 1 ( ABCB1 ) /multidrug resistance 1 ( MDR1 ), leading to the extracellular efflux of taxane. These results suggest that chemotherapy-induced CCL20 mediates chemoresistance via up-regulation of ABCB1. In addition, NF-κB activation increases CCL20 expression, forming a positive feedback loop between NF-κB and CCL20 pathways, which provides sustained impetus for chemoresistance in breast cancer cells. Our results suggest that CCL20 can be a novel predictive marker for taxane response, and the blockade of CCL20 or its downstream pathway might reverse the taxane resistance in breast cancer patients.
Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite that can infect virtually all nucleated cells in warm-blooded animals. Toxoplasma tachyzoites are able to infect and successfully manipulate their host by transporting “GRA” proteins from unique secretory organelles called dense granules into the host cell. These proteins have diverse roles in Toxoplasma’s intracellular lifecycle, including co-opting host cell functions and proteins such as the cell cycle, c-Myc and p38 MAP kinase. However, the translocation process of these proteins across the parasitophorous vacuole membrane ( PVM ) into the host cell is not well understood. We previously showed that TgMYR1, which is cleaved by TgASP5 into two fragments, localizes to the PVM and is essential for GRA transport into the host cell. To identify additional proteins necessary for effector transport, we screened Toxoplasma mutants defective in c-Myc up-regulation for their ability to export GRA16 and GRA24 to the host cell nucleus. Here we report that novel proteins MYR2 and MYR3 play a crucial role in translocation of a subset of GRAs into the host cell. These proteins are secreted into the PV space and co-localize with PV membranes and MYR1. We further show that fusing intrinsically disordered effectors to a structured DHFR domain blocks the transport of other effectors, consistent with a translocon-based model of effector transport. Overall, these results reveal a novel complex at the PVM that is essential for effector translocation into the host cell.
Human papillomavirus ( HPV ) and bovine papillomavirus ( BPV-1 ) E2 proteins bind to the origin recognition complex ( ORC ) subunit 2 ( ORC2 ). However, ORC2 is not present at the viral origin and its depletion does not suppress viral replication. Instead, ORC2 depletion increases the presence of E1 and E2 at the viral origin and enhances viral replication in a transient replication model and in keratinocytes stably maintaining viral episomes. In contrast, ORC2 depletion has no effect on viral copy number in a cell line with an integrated HPV genome. These data suggest that ORC2 is not necessary for activation of the viral origin by E1 and E2 but instead suppresses E2 replicative function. Furthermore, we observed that over-expression of HPV E2 decreases ORC2 occupation at two known mammalian origins of replication, suggesting that E2 restricts pre-ORC assembly that could otherwise compete for host replication complexes necessary for viral genome amplification. We infer that the ORC2 complex with E2 restricts viral replication in the maintenance phase of the viral replication program and that elevated levels of E2 that occur during the differentiation dependent amplification stage subvert ORC loading and hence DNA synthesis at cellular origins.
Brucella DNA was detected in 10. 3% of 564 cow milk samples in the urban and peri-urban area of Dushanbe, Tajikistan by IS711-based real-time PCR. Brucella DNA was also detected in the milk of all seropositive cows, but 8. 3% of the seronegative cows also showed the presence of Brucella DNA. Sequence analysis of the rpoB gene suggests that one cow was infected with B. abortus and another cow was most likely infected with B. melitensis. This finding is concerning because consumption of unpasteurized dairy products is common in the region. The study highlights the need to further investigate whether there is a need for implementing complementary diagnostic strategies to detect false serological negative individuals in Brucella surveillance, control, and eradication programmes. In addition, vaccination of cattle with S19 in addition to vaccination of small ruminants with Rev 1 might be needed to control Brucella infections in the livestock population.
Chromosome and genome stability are important for normal cell function, and instability often correlates with disease and dysfunction of DNA repair mechanisms. The pathogenic fungus Zymoseptoria tritici has eight accessory chromosomes that are highly unstable during meiosis and mitosis, transcriptionally repressed, and enriched with heterochromatic histone methylation marks, such as trimethylation of H3 lysine 9 or lysine 27 ( H3K9me3, H3K27me3 ). To elucidate the role of heterochromatin on genome stability in Z. tritici, we deleted the genes encoding the methyltransferases responsible for H3K9me3 and H3K27me3, kmt1 and kmt6, respectively, and generated a double mutant. We combined experimental evolution and genomic analyses to determine the impact of these deletions on chromosome and genome stability, both in vitro and in planta. We used whole genome sequencing, ChIP-seq, and RNA-seq to compare changes in genome and chromatin structure, and differences in gene expression between mutant and wildtype strains. We found that H3K9me3 is important for the maintenance of genome stability because it disallows H3K27me3 in regions considered constitutive heterochromatin. In this system, H3K27me3 reduces the overall stability of accessory chromosomes, generating a “metastable” state for these quasi-essential regions of the genome.
Rabies post-exposure prophylaxis ( PEP ) is essential for preventing the fatal onset of rabies in individuals exposed to the virus. Unfortunately, life-saving vaccines and biologicals are often inaccessible and unaffordable to the poorest sectors of society who bear the largest burden of rabies. We evaluated the relative costs and benefits of different PEP vaccination regimens and found that PEP vaccination is an extremely cost-effective intervention, with costs ranging from $200 to less than $60 per death averted. Switching from intramuscular ( IM ) to intradermal ( ID ) administration of PEP was shown to result in significant savings in the volume of vaccine required to treat the same number of patients, which could mitigate vaccine shortages and reduce costs. We present financing mechanisms that could make PEP more affordable and accessible to those most in need, and support new and existing rabies control and prevention programs. We conclude that a universal switch to ID delivery would improve the affordability and accessibility of PEP for bite victims, leading to a likely reduction in human rabies deaths, as well as being economical for healthcare providers.
Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite that replicates in mammalian cells within a parasitophorous vacuole ( PV ) that does not fuse with any host organelles. One mechanism by which the parasite acquires nutrients is by attracting host organelles to the PV. Here, we show that Toxoplasma exploits host lipid droplets ( LD ), ubiquitous fat storage organelles, for nutrient acquisition. We demonstrate that Toxoplasma replication is reduced in host cells that are depleted of LD or impaired in TAG lipolysis or fatty acid catabolism. In infected cells, the number of host LD and the expression of host LD-associated genes ( ADRP, DGAT2 ) increase until the onset of parasite replication. Toxoplasma is capable of accessing lipids stored in host LD and incorporates these lipids into its own membranes and LD. To access LD-derived lipids, Toxoplasma intercepts and internalizes within the PV host LD, some of which remain associated with Rab7, which become wrapped by an intravacuolar network of membranes ( IVN ). Mutant parasites impaired in IVN formation display diminished capacity of lipid uptake from host LD. Moreover, parasites lacking an IVN-localized phospholipase A2 are less proficient in salvaging lipids from host LD in the PV, suggesting a major contribution of the IVN for host LD processing in the PV and lipid content release.
FhCL3 and FhCL1 are key cysteine proteases secreted by the liver flukes Fasciola hepatica and Fasciola gigantica, which cause fasciolosis, an emerging zoonotic disease. Triclabendazole is the preferred drug to control fluke infections, but resistance has been reported in several countries. Here, we report the identification of chalcones as novel inhibitors of FhCL3 and FhCL1 using a comprehensive experimental and computational approach. We screened a library of 40 flavonoid derivatives and identified chalcones substituted with phenyl and naphthyl groups as potent inhibitors of FhCL3 and FhCL1. One compound, C34, was identified as a slow-reversible inhibitor of FhCL3 with an IC50 of 5. 6 μM. We demonstrated that C34 interacts with the Cys-His catalytic dyad and key S2 and S3 pocket residues of FhCL3, determinants of the substrate specificity of this family of cysteine proteases. Interestingly, C34 induces a reduction in the ability of juvenile parasites to migrate through the gut wall and a loss of motility phenotype that leads to parasite death within a week in vitro, while it is not cytotoxic to bovine cells. These findings open new avenues for the development of novel agents to control fluke infection and possibly other helminthic diseases.
The visual system transmits information about fast and slow changes in light intensity through separate neural pathways. We used in vivo imaging to investigate how bipolar cells transmit these signals to the inner retina. We found that the volume of the synaptic terminal is an intrinsic property that contributes to different temporal filters. Individual cells transmit through multiple terminals varying in size, but smaller terminals generate faster and larger calcium transients to trigger vesicle release with higher initial gain, followed by more profound adaptation. Smaller terminals transmitted higher stimulus frequencies more effectively. Modeling global calcium dynamics triggering vesicle release indicated that variations in the volume of presynaptic compartments contribute directly to all these differences in response dynamics. These results indicate how one neuron can transmit different temporal components in the visual signal through synaptic terminals of varying geometries with different adaptational properties.
Fluorescence microscopy ( FM ) and electron microscopy ( EM ) are used for single-synapse analysis. FM offers high speed and low cost, but rigorous discrimination between synaptic and non-synaptic fluorescence signals is challenging. In contrast, EM is the gold standard for reliable identification of a synapse, but offers limited molecular discrimination and is slow and costly. To develop and test single-synapse image analysis methods, we have used datasets from conjugate array tomography ( cAT ), which provides voxel-conjugate FM and EM ( annotated ) images of the same individual synapses. We report a novel unsupervised probabilistic method for detection of synapses from multiplex FM ( muxFM ) image data, and evaluate this method both by comparison to EM gold standard annotated data and by examining its capacity to reproduce known important features of cortical synapse distributions. The proposed probabilistic model-based synapse detector accepts molecular-morphological synapse models as user queries, and delivers a volumetric map of the probability that each voxel represents part of a synapse. We show that our algorithm detects synapses from muxFM data alone as successfully as human annotators seeing only the muxFM data, and accurately reproduces known architectural features of cortical synapse distributions. This approach opens the door to data-driven discovery of new synapse types and their density.
Zinc is an essential trace element that plays a crucial role in many cellular processes, including nucleic acid metabolism, regulation of gene expression, signal transduction, cell division, immune- and nervous system functions, wound healing, and apoptosis. Impairment of zinc homeostasis can lead to various human pathologies. Zinc transport in mammals is mediated by two transporter families, ZnT and ZIP, with ZnT2 playing a key role in vesicular zinc accumulation and secretion into breast milk during lactation. However, the detailed mechanism of action of ZnT2 is currently unknown. Herein, we demonstrate that ZnT2 is a proton-coupled zinc antiporter with an apparent stoichiometry of two protons per zinc ion. We show that ZnT2-dependent zinc transport into intracellular vesicles is abolished by bafilomycin A1, a specific inhibitor of vacuolar-type proton ATPase, which alkalizes acidic vesicles. We further show that ZnT2 overexpression in intracellular vesicles and addition of exogenous zinc leads to vesicular pH alkalization, which is reversed in the presence of TPEN, a specific zinc chelator. We propose that ZnT2 functions as an electroneutral vesicular zinc exchanger, concentrating zinc in acidic vesicles at the expense of proton extrusion to the cytoplasm.
Exonuclease 1 ( Exo1 ) is a protein involved in the processing of stalled replication forks in yeast and mammalian cells. Exo1 activity is regulated by checkpoint-mediated phosphorylation events. We now identify 14-3-3 proteins as in vivo interaction partners of Exo1 in both yeast and mammalian cells. Yeast 14-3-3–deficient cells fail to induce Exo1 hyperphosphorylation and accumulate Exo1–dependent ssDNA gaps at stalled forks. This leads to persistent checkpoint activation and exacerbated recovery defects. Moreover, we show that 14-3-3 proteins promote fork progression under limiting nucleotide concentrations using DNA bi-dimensional electrophoresis. We propose that 14-3-3 proteins assist in controlling the phosphorylation status of Exo1 and additional unknown targets, promoting fork progression, stability, and restart in response to DNA replication stress. In yeast 14-3-3–deficient cells, the accumulation of Exo1–dependent ssDNA gaps is completely suppressed by EXO1 deletion. However, this does not reflect in suppression of HU sensitivity nor of defective fork progression in HU-treated 14-3-3 deficient cells. These data suggest that 14-3-3 proteins might regulate additional targets during replication stress, possibly through modulation of their phosphorylation.
The role of plasmacytoid dendritic cells ( pDC ) in human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) infection and pathogenesis remains unclear. We have developed a monoclonal antibody that specifically depletes human pDC in all lymphoid organs in humanized mice. When pDC were depleted prior to HIV-1 infection, the induction of type I interferons ( IFN-I ) and interferon-stimulated genes ( ISGs ) was abolished during acute HIV-1 infection. Consistent with the anti-viral role of IFN-I, HIV-1 replication was significantly up-regulated in pDC-depleted mice. Interestingly, the cell death induced by the highly pathogenic HIV-1 isolate was severely reduced in pDC-depleted mice. During chronic HIV-1 infection, depletion of pDC also severely reduced the induction of IFN-I and ISGs, associated with elevated HIV-1 replication. Surprisingly, HIV-1 induced depletion of human immune cells including T cells in lymphoid organs was reduced in spite of the increased viral replication. The increased cell number in lymphoid organs was associated with a reduced level of HIV-induced cell death in human leukocytes including CD4 T cells. We conclude that pDC play opposing roles in suppressing HIV-1 replication and in promoting HIV-1 induced immunopathogenesis. These findings suggest that pDC-depletion and IFN-I blockade will provide novel strategies for treating those HIV-1 immune non-responsive patients with persistent immune activation despite effective anti-retrovirus treatment.
Sulforaphane ( SFN ), a compound found in cruciferous vegetables, has been shown to inhibit HIV infection in primary macrophages but not in primary T cells or other cell lines. SFN acts through the transcription regulator Nrf2, which is mobilized by SFN to reprogram cellular gene expression. In primary macrophages, SFN triggers a block to HIV infection that impacts the virus after reverse transcription but before 2-LTR circle formation. This block relies on Nrf2, which is a transcription regulator of anti-oxidant genes. Importantly, we found that macrophages express sufficient Nrf2 to maintain a partial restriction even in the absence of SFN. Depletion of Nrf2 with siRNA increased HIV infectivity in primary macrophages and reduced the anti-viral effects of SFN treatment. This supports a model in which anti-viral activity is mediated through Nrf2 after it is mobilized by SFN.
Geohelminth infections are common among pregnant women in rural western Kenya, with 76. 2% of 390 participants infected with at least one geohelminth species. The most prevalent species were Ascaris lumbricoides ( 52. 3% ), hookworm ( 39. 5% ), and Trichuris trichiura ( 29. 0% ). Infection with at least one geohelminth species was associated with the use of an unprotected water source ( adjusted odds ratio [ AOR ] 1. 8, 95% confidence interval [ CI ] 1. 1–3. 0 ) and the lack of treatment of drinking water ( AOR 1. 8, 95% CI 1. 1–3. 1 ). Hookworm infection was associated with a lower mid upper arm circumference ( adjusted mean decrease 0. 7 cm, 95% CI 0. 3–1. 2 cm ). Hookworm infections with an egg count ≥1000/gram feces ( 11 women ) were associated with lower hemoglobin ( adjusted mean decrease 1. 5 g/dl, 95% CI 0. 3–2. 7 ). Among gravidae 2 and 3, women with A. lumbricoides were less likely to have malaria parasitemia ( OR 0. 4, 95% CI 0. 2–0. 8 ) compared to women without A. lumbricoides.
Mycolactone, a macrolide produced by the skin pathogen Mycobacterium ulcerans, displays anti-inflammatory effects on the nervous system. We investigated whether mycolactone affects the inflammatory responses of sensory neurons, Schwann cells, and microglia, which are involved in pain perception, transmission, and maintenance. We found that mycolactone suppressed the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by these cells, without affecting their viability. Notably, mycolactone also prevented the pro-inflammatory polarization of cortical microglia, which contribute to neuroinflammation. We next tested if mycolactone impacts neuroinflammation in vivo using a rat model of neuropathic pain induced by chronic constriction of the sciatic nerve. Mycolactone was injected daily for 3 days in the spinal canal to ensure proper delivery to the spinal cord. While this treatment failed to prevent injury-induced neuroinflammation, it significantly decreased the local production of inflammatory cytokines without inducing detectable cytotoxicity. Our study provides in vitro and in vivo evidence that mycolactone suppresses the inflammatory responses of sensory neurons, Schwann cells, and microglia. Together with previous studies using peripheral blood leukocytes, our work suggests that mycolactone-mediated analgesia may be partially explained by its anti-inflammatory properties.
Human African trypanosomiasis ( HAT ), a disease caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense, has a range of clinical outcomes in its human host in West Africa, including an acute form progressing rapidly to second stage, spontaneous self-cure, and individuals able to regulate parasitaemia at very low levels. To investigate if host genetic determinants influence this clinical diversity, the association between candidate gene polymorphisms and HAT outcome was investigated in populations from HAT active foci in Guinea. A total of 425 individuals were included in the study, comprising 232 HAT cases, 79 subjects with long lasting positive and specific serology but negative parasitology, and 114 endemic controls. Genotypes of 28 SNPs in eight genes were used for an association analysis. The study found that IL6 rs1818879 allele A was associated with a lower risk of progressing from latent infection to active disease ( p = 0. 0001, OR = 0. 39, CI95 = [0. 24–0. 63], BONF = 0. 0034 ). In contrast, MIF rs36086171 allele G was associated with an increased risk ( p = 0. 0239, OR = 1. 65, CI95 = [1. 07–2. 53], BONF = 0. 6697 ) and MIF rs12483859 C allele with latent infections ( p = 0. 0077, OR = 1. 86, CI95 = [1. 18–2. 95], BONF = 0. 2157 ). The study also confirmed earlier observations that APOL1 G2 allele ( DEL ) was associated with a higher risk of developing HAT ( p = 0. 0011, OR = 2. 70, CI95 = [1. 49–4. 91], BONF = 0. 0301 ) and APOL1 G1 polymorphism with a lower risk ( p = 0. 0005, OR = 0. 45, CI95 = [0. 29–0. 70], BONF = 0. 0129 ).
The Singapore Sequencing Indian Project ( SSIP ) has generated a publicly available genomic resource by sequencing the genomes of 38 South Asian Indians from Singapore at a target coverage of 30X. The genetic structure and diversity of these samples were compared against samples from the Singapore Sequencing Malay Project and populations in Phase 1 of the 1, 000 Genomes Project ( 1 KGP ). The SSIP samples exhibited greater intra-population genetic diversity and a higher heterozygous-to-homozygous genotype ratio than other Asian populations. When compared against a panel of well-defined Asian Indians, the genetic makeup of the SSIP samples was closely related to South Indians. However, eight samples were assigned to mitochondrial haplogroups that were predominantly present in Europeans and possessed higher European admixture than the remaining samples. An analysis of the relative relatedness between SSIP and two archaic hominins ( Denisovan, Neanderthal ) identified higher ancient admixture in East Asian populations than in SSIP. The data resource for these samples is expected to serve as a valuable complement to the South Asian samples in Phase 3 of 1 KGP.
Burkholderia pseudomallei, the causative agent of melioidosis, is intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides and macrolides due to the expression of the AmrAB-OprA efflux pump. We investigated the molecular basis of aminoglycoside susceptibility in Thai clinical isolates 708a, 2188a, and 3799a. We found that 708a lacked amrB transcripts, while 2188a and 3799a had greatly reduced levels of amrB. Serial passage of 2188a and 3799a on increasing gentamicin concentrations yielded mutants that were simultaneously resistant to other aminoglycosides and macrolides, whereas such mutants could not be obtained with 708a. Transcript analysis revealed that the resistance of the 2188a and 3799a mutants was due to upregulation of amrAB-oprA expression. In contrast, 708a lacked the amrAB-oprA operon due to a large deletion of more than 70 kb of genetic material. This deletion also removed the entire gene clusters for malleobactin and cobalamin synthesis, as well as the anaerobic arginine deiminase pathway, putative type 1 fimbriae, and secreted chitinase. Despite lacking several putative virulence genes, 708a was fully virulent in a murine melioidosis model.
During the early differentiation of naive CD4 T helper ( Th ) cells into Th1 versus Th2 states, we observed that transcription factors Tbet and Gata3 are co-expressed in individual cells at high levels, which is distinct from basal-level co-expression during lineage priming. Contrary to the expectation of mutually exclusive expression of antagonistic transcription factors, we found that cytokines are expressed only in a small subpopulation of cells, independent from the expression of transcription factors in these single cells. This cell-to-cell variation in cytokine expression during the early phase of T helper cell differentiation is significantly larger than in the fully differentiated state. Upon inhibition of cytokine signaling, we observed the classic mutual exclusion of antagonistic transcription factors, thus revealing a weak intracellular network otherwise overruled by the strong signals that emanate from extracellular cytokines. These results suggest that during the early differentiation process CD4 T cells acquire a mixed Th1/Th2 state, instructed by extracellular cytokines.
C. elegans PAQR-2, a transmembrane receptor homologous to mammalian insulin-sensitizing adiponectin receptors, is essential for adaptation to growth at 15°C, a low but usually acceptable temperature for this organism. By screening for novel paqr-2 suppressors, we identified mutations in genes involved in phosphatidylcholine synthesis ( cept-1, pcyt-1 and sams-1 ) and fatty acid metabolism ( ech-7, hacd-1, mdt-15, nhr-49 and sbp-1 ). We show that paqr-2, phosphatidylcholines, sbp-1 and Δ9-desaturases form a cold adaptation pathway that regulates the increase in unsaturated fatty acids necessary to retain membrane fluidity at low temperatures. This model is supported by the observations that the paqr-2 suppressors normalize the levels of saturated fatty acids, and that low concentrations of detergents that increase membrane fluidity can rescue the paqr-2 mutant.
Herpes simplex virus type-1 ( HSV-1 ) is a large and complex double-stranded DNA virus that causes a range of diseases from cold sores and chicken pox to congenital defects, blindness, and cancer. Despite extensive study, much remains to be learned about the structure of the genome packaging and release machinery in the capsids of herpesviruses. However, herpesviruses share a common evolutionary origin with tailed bacteriophages, which have well-characterized genome packaging and release machinery. In tailed bacteriophages, the genome exits from the virus particle through a portal and is transferred into the host cell by a complex apparatus located at the portal vertex. Here, we use electron cryo-tomography of HSV-1 virions to reveal a previously unsuspected feature at the portal vertex, which extends across the HSV-1 tegument layer to form a connection between the capsid and the viral membrane. The location of this assembly suggests that it plays a role in genome release into the nucleus and is also important for virion architecture.
Schistosoma mansoni soluble egg antigen ( SEA ) and recombinant Omega-1 ( rω-1 ) have been shown to modulate induced CD4+ T-lymphocyte responses and HIV-1 infection in vitro. Here, we analyzed the effects of SEA on modulating HIV-1 infection and cytokine/chemokine production in vitro. We found that SEA, specifically through kappa-5, potently binds to DC-SIGN and blocks DC-SIGN mediated HIV-1 trans-infection ( p<0. 05 ), while not interfering with cis-infection. Furthermore, DCs exposed to SEA while maturing under Th2 promoting conditions induce a T-cell population that is less susceptible to HIV-1 R5 infection ( p<0. 05 ) compared to DCs unexposed to SEA. This effect was not observed for DCs exposed to SEA while maturing under Th1 or Th1/Th2 ( Tmix ) promoting conditions. We further show that DCs maturing under Tmix conditions exposed to rω-1 induce T-cell populations that are less sensitive to HIV-1 R5 infection ( p<0. 05 ), but not for X4 virus infection. This inhibition is associated with a reduction in IFN-γ and MIP-1β expression, and in the case of rω-1, also with reduced CCR5 expression.
Neuronal stimulation causes a ∼30% shrinkage of the extracellular space ( ECS ) between neurons and surrounding astrocytes in both grey and white matter under experimental conditions. Despite its potential implications for understanding basic aspects of potassium clearance and astrocyte function, the phenomenon remains unexplained. Here, we present a dynamic model that accounts for current experimental data related to the shrinkage phenomenon in wild-type as well as in gene knockout individuals. We find that neuronal release of potassium and uptake of sodium during stimulation, astrocyte uptake of potassium, sodium, and chloride in passive channels, action of the Na/K/ATPase pump, and osmotically driven transport of water through the astrocyte membrane together seem sufficient for generating ECS shrinkage. However, when taking into account ECS and astrocyte ion concentrations observed in connection with neuronal stimulation, the actions of the Na+/K+/Cl− ( NKCC1 ) and the Na+/HCO3− ( NBC ) cotransporters appear to be critical determinants for achieving observed quantitative levels of ECS shrinkage.
Transcriptional silencing of transposons and repetitive DNA elements in eukaryotic genomes is mediated by the siRNA–mediated transcriptional gene silencing pathway in Arabidopsis thaliana. In this pathway, long non-coding RNAs ( lncRNAs ) produced by RNA Polymerase V ( Pol V ) guide ARGONAUTE4 ( AGO4 ) to chromatin and attract enzymes that establish repressive chromatin modifications. We show that SPT5L/KTF1, a silencing factor and a homolog of SPT5 elongation factors, binds chromatin at loci subject to transcriptional silencing. Chromatin binding of SPT5L/KTF1 occurs downstream of RNA Polymerase V, but independently from the presence of 24-nt siRNA. We also show that SPT5L/KTF1 and AGO4 are recruited to chromatin in parallel and independently of each other. Binding of both AGO4 and SPT5L/KTF1 is required for DNA methylation and repressive histone modifications of several loci. We propose that the coordinate binding of SPT5L and AGO4 creates a platform for direct or indirect recruitment of chromatin modifying enzymes.
