Borrelia burgdorferi, the causative agent of Lyme disease, requires the alternative sigma factor RpoS for dissemination within the vector during tick-to-mammal transmission. We demonstrate that RpoS-dependent gene expression is essential for the transmission of spirochetes by feeding nymphs, as RpoS-deficient organisms are confined to the midgut lumen and transform into an unusual morphotype ( round bodies ) during the later stages of the blood meal. Round body formation is rapidly reversible and appears to be attributable, in part, to reduced levels of Coenzyme A disulfide reductase, which provides NAD+ for glycolysis. Our data suggest that spirochetes default to an RpoS-independent program for round body formation upon sensing that the energetics for transmission are unfavorable. We show that RpoS is induced during the nymphal blood meal but is not expressed by spirochetes within replete larvae or unfed nymphs, thereby delineating the RpoS ON ( fed nymph ) and OFF ( fed larvae and unfed nymph ) states during the tick phase of the enzootic cycle. Our findings reveal a previously unsuspected role for RpoSBb in the physiological adaptations required for tick-to-mammal transmission as well as the existence of a proposed default survival mode ( round body formation ) triggered when spirochetes are unable to produce sufficient energy for dissemination within the nymph.
Deficiency in gibberellin ( GA ) and jasmonate ( JA ) causes male sterility in Arabidopsis, but little is known about the relationship between GA and JA in controlling stamen development. Here, we show that MYB21, MYB24, and MYB57 are GA-dependent stamen-enriched genes. Loss-of-function of two DELLAs, RGA and RGL2, restores the expression of these three MYB genes together with restoration of stamen filament growth in GA-deficient plants. Genetic analysis shows that the myb21-t1 myb24-t1 myb57-t1 triple mutant confers a short stamen phenotype leading to male sterility. Further genetic and molecular studies demonstrate that GA suppresses DELLAs to mobilize the expression of the key JA biosynthesis gene DAD1, and this is consistent with the observation that the JA content in the young flower buds of the GA-deficient quadruple mutant ga1-3 gai-t6 rga-t2 rgl1-1 is much lower than that in the WT. We conclude that GA promotes JA biosynthesis to control the expression of MYB21, MYB24, and MYB57. Therefore, we have established a hierarchical relationship between GA and JA in that modulation of JA pathway by GA is one of the prerequisites for GA to regulate normal stamen development in Arabidopsis.
Dietary restriction ( DR ) has been shown to extend lifespan in various species and slow the onset of age-related diseases. Previous studies have implicated the target of rapamycin ( TOR ) pathway in longevity phenotypes resulting from DR. TOR is a conserved protein kinase that regulates growth and metabolism in response to nutrients and growth factors. Here, we describe a novel role for hypoxia inducible factor-1 ( HIF-1 ) in modulating lifespan extension by DR in Caenorhabditis elegans. We find that HIF-1 deficiency results in extended lifespan, which overlaps with that by inhibition of the RSKS-1/S6 kinase, a key component of the TOR pathway. Using a modified DR method based on variation of bacterial food concentrations on solid agar plates, we find that HIF-1 modulates longevity in a nutrient-dependent manner. The hif-1 loss-of-function mutant extends lifespan under rich nutrient conditions but fails to show lifespan extension under DR. Conversely, a mutation in egl-9, which increases HIF-1 activity, diminishes the lifespan extension under DR. This deficiency is rescued by tissue-specific expression of egl-9 in specific neurons and muscles. Increased lifespan by hif-1 or DR is dependent on the endoplasmic reticulum ( ER ) stress regulator inositol-requiring protein-1 ( IRE-1 ) and is associated with lower levels of ER stress.
Keratinocytes are a type of skin cell that can transition between different functional states, such as differentiation and migration. These transitions are accompanied by changes in chromatin, the complex of DNA, histone proteins, and other non-histone proteins that make up chromatin. Here, we show that when keratinocytes differentiate or migrate, they form unique complements of enhancers and super-enhancers that are specific to each state. Enhancers are regions of chromatin that regulate gene expression, and super-enhancers are a subset of enhancers that are highly active. These super-enhancers link to gene expression that confers functions associated with the respective cell state. We also show that GRHL3, a transcription factor that promotes both differentiation and migration, binds preferentially to super-enhancers in differentiating keratinocytes and to promoters in migrating keratinocytes, where it represses the expression of genes that inhibit migration. Furthermore, GRHL3 regulates the formation of super-enhancers, including the suppression of non-keratinocyte super-enhancers in differentiating keratinocytes. Our studies suggest that GRHL3 regulates divergent gene expression programs in differentiating and migrating keratinocytes by switching locations of chromatin binding in the context of enhancer landscapes that are distinct for each state.
Endogenous retroviruses ( ERVs ) are remnants of ancient retroviral infections of the host germline that have been transmitted vertically from generation to generation. It has been hypothesized that some ERVs are used by the host as restriction factors to block the infection of pathogenic retroviruses. Using sheep as a model system, we investigated the evolutionary interplay between endogenous retroviruses, exogenous retroviruses, and their hosts. We isolated and characterized the evolutionary history and molecular virology of 27 enJSRV proviruses, which have been integrating in the host genome for the last 5–7 million years. Two enJSRV proviruses, enJS56A1 and enJSRV-20, which entered the host genome within the last 3 million years, acquired a defective Gag polyprotein resulting in a transdominant phenotype able to block late replication steps of related exogenous retroviruses. Both transdominant proviruses became fixed in the host genome before or around sheep domestication ( ∼ 9, 000 years ago ). Interestingly, a provirus escaping the transdominant enJSRVs has emerged very recently, most likely within the last 200 years. This study strongly suggests that endogenization and selection of ERVs acting as restriction factors is a mechanism used by the host to fight retroviral infections.
Schistosomiasis diagnosis currently relies on microscopic detection of schistosome eggs in stool or urine samples and serological assays. However, the poor sensitivity of standard microscopic procedures performed in routine laboratories makes molecular detection methods of increasing interest. We evaluated two in-house real-time Schistosoma PCRs targeting S. mansoni and S. haematobium in excreta, biopsies, and sera as potential tools to diagnose active infections and monitor treatment efficacy. We performed Schistosoma PCRs on 412 samples from patients with suspected schistosomiasis, before anti-parasitic treatment, and compared the results to microscopic examination and serological assays. Compared to microscopy, PCRs significantly increased the sensitivity of diagnosis, from 4% to 10. 5% and from 33. 7% to 48. 8%, for Sh in urine and Sm in stools, respectively. The overall sensitivity of PCR on serum samples was 72. 7% and reached 94. 1% in patients with positive excreta ( microscopy ). The specificity of serum PCR was 98. 9%. After treatment, serum PCR positivity rates slowly declined from 93. 8% at day 30 to 8. 3% at day 360, whereas antibody detection remained positive after 1 year. Schistosoma PCRs clearly outperform standard microscopy on stools and urine and could be part of reference methods combined with WB-based serology, which remains a gold standard for initial diagnosis.
In this study, we demonstrate that machine learning ( ML ) can be used to estimate the conformational energies of large, structurally complex molecules. We take the natural product Archazolid A, a potent inhibitor of vacuolar-type ATPase, from the myxobacterium Archangium gephyra, as an example. We use Gaussian process regression, a Bayesian non-parametric ML method, to model the relationship between the molecular structure of Archazolid A and its quantum mechanical ( QM ) properties. We use a simple molecular representation based on nuclear charges and inter-atomic distances to encode the conformations of Archazolid A. This representation is sensitive to structural variations in relaxed geometries and enables finding correlations between simulated conformations and computed energy values at the density functional theory ( DFT ) level of theory. We achieve mean absolute errors of less than 1 kcal/mol for energies of relaxed conformations at the DFT/BLYP-disp3/def2-TZVP level of theory. This study demonstrates that predictive ML models can be developed for structurally complex, pharmaceutically relevant compounds, potentially enabling considerable speed-ups in simulations of larger molecular structures.
Ebola virus disease ( EVD ) is a major public health concern in Central Africa, where it has caused recent declines in resident great ape populations. While vaccines have been proposed as an intervention to protect apes, their effectiveness would be improved if we could diagnostically confirm EVD as the cause of die-offs, establish ebolavirus geographical distribution, identify immunologically naïve populations, and determine whether apes survive virus exposure. Here, we report the first successful noninvasive detection of antibodies against Ebola virus ( EBOV ) from wild ape feces. Using this method, we have been able to identify gorillas with antibodies to EBOV with an overall prevalence rate reaching 10% on average, demonstrating that EBOV exposure or infection is not uniformly lethal in this species. Furthermore, evidence of antibodies was identified in gorillas thought previously to be unexposed to EBOV. Our new approach will contribute to a strategy to protect apes from future EBOV infections by early detection of increased incidence of exposure, by identifying immunologically naïve at-risk populations as potential targets for vaccination, and by providing a means to track vaccine efficacy if such intervention is deemed appropriate.
Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria ( Xcv ) is a plant pathogenic bacterium that causes disease in tomato and pepper plants. Here, we show that the novel type III effector XopL exhibits E3 ubiquitin ligase activity in vitro and in planta. This activity is associated with the C-terminal region of XopL, which specifically interacts with plant E2 ubiquitin conjugating enzymes and mediates formation of predominantly K11-linked polyubiquitin chains. The crystal structure of the XopL C-terminal domain revealed a novel fold, termed XL-box, not present in any previously characterized E3 ligase. Mutation of amino acids in the central cavity of the XL-box disrupts E3 ligase activity and prevents XopL-induced plant cell death. The crystal structure of the N-terminal region of XopL confirmed the presence of a leucine-rich repeat ( LRR ) domain, which may serve as a protein-protein interaction module for ubiquitination target recognition. While the E3 ligase activity is required to provoke plant cell death, suppression of PAMP responses solely depends on the N-terminal LRR domain. The unique structural fold of the E3 ubiquitin ligase domain within the Xanthomonas XopL is unprecedented and highlights the variation in bacterial pathogen effectors mimicking this eukaryote-specific activity.
HIV-infected individuals in the early stages of acute infection ( stage 1/2 ) and late acute infection ( stage 3 ) were studied in the RV254 cohort to investigate T helper-B cell responses and the impact of early antiretroviral treatment ( ART ) on T and B cell function. Circulating T follicular helper cells ( cTfh ) from this cohort were examined, and cTfh and memory B cell populations were phenotyped. We found that cTfh cell function was impaired in individuals treated in stage 3 compared to stage 1/2, and cTfh/B cell cocultures showed lower B cell survival and IgG secretion at stage 3 compared to stage 1/2. This coincided with lower IL-10 and increased RANTES and TNF-α, suggesting a role for inflammation in altering cTfh and B cell responses. Elevated plasma viral load in stage 3 was found to correlate with decreased cTfh-mediated B cell IgG production, indicating a role for increased viremia in cTfh impairment and dysfunctional humoral response. Phenotypic perturbations were also evident in the mature B cell compartment, most notably a decrease in resting memory B cells in stage 3 compared to stage 1/2, coinciding with higher viremia. Overall, cTfh-mediated B cell responses are significantly altered in stage 3 compared to stage 1/2, coinciding with increased inflammation and a reduction in memory B cells.
Schistosomiasis is a tropical parasitic disease affecting over 200 million people worldwide. Current therapy relies on a single drug, praziquantel ( PZQ ), which has several suboptimal features. To develop next generation anthelmintics, it is essential to identify and pharmacologically profile physiologically relevant targets. Here, we report the pharmacological profiling of a schistosome serotonergic G protein-coupled receptor ( Sm. 5HTR ) in a miniaturized screening assay compatible with high content screening. We employed a split luciferase based biosensor sensitive to cellular cAMP levels to resolve the proximal kinetics of GPCR modulation in intact cells. Our data evidence a divergent pharmacological signature between Sm. 5HTR and the closest human GPCR homolog ( Hs. 5HTR7 ), supporting the feasibility of optimizing parasitic selective pharmacophores. New ligands and chemical series with potency and selectivity for Sm. 5HTR over Hs. 5HTR7 were identified in vitro and validated for in vivo efficacy against schistosomules and adult worms. Furthermore, Sm. 5HTR displayed a property resembling irreversible inactivation, a phenomenon also observed at Hs. 5HTR7, which enhances the appeal of this abundantly expressed parasite GPCR as a target for anthelmintic ligand design. Overall, these data underscore the feasibility of profiling flatworm GPCRs in a high throughput screening format and the promise of Sm. 5HTR as a chemotherapeutically vulnerable node for development of next generation anthelmintics.
The separation of germ layers during embryonic development is crucial for the establishment of the metazoan body plan. In this process, the ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm must be separated, yet the ectoderm must also serve as a substratum for mesoderm migration. We show that localized detachment of cells at the ectoderm-mesoderm boundary, resulting from contact-induced signals, is at the core of ectoderm-mesoderm segregation. This process involves ephrinB/EphB signaling, with multiple ephrinB ligands and EphB receptors expressed on each side of the boundary. Forward signaling across the boundary in both directions, involving partially redundant ligands and receptors, and activation of Rac and RhoA, is required for tissue separation. This mechanism differs from a simple differential adhesion process of germ layer formation. Instead, it involves localized responses to signals exchanged at the tissue boundary and an attachment/detachment cycle that allows for cell migration across a cellular substratum.
The number of children diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) has increased dramatically over the last four decades. However, the underlying pathophysiology of ASD is still not well understood, and diagnosis is currently based on behavioral observations and psychometric tools. To address this limitation, we analyzed metabolite concentrations of the folate-dependent one-carbon metabolism and transulfuration pathways from blood samples of 83 children with ASD and 76 age-matched neurotypical peers. We used Fisher Discriminant Analysis to classify participants as on the spectrum or neurotypical, resulting in 96. 1% of neurotypical participants and 97. 6% of the ASD cohort being correctly identified. Furthermore, we used kernel partial least squares to predict adaptive behavior, as measured by the Vineland Adaptive Behavior Composite score, and found that measurement of five metabolites of the pathways was sufficient to predict the Vineland score with an R2 of 0. 45 after cross-validation. This level of accuracy far exceeds any other approach in this field and suggests that the metabolites under consideration are strongly correlated with an ASD diagnosis and that the statistical analysis used here offers tremendous potential for extracting important information from complex biochemical data sets.
Leishmaniasis is endemic in 98 countries with 350 million people at risk and approximately 2 million cases annually. Brazil is one of the most severely affected countries. We applied Bayesian geostatistical negative binomial models to analyze reported incidence data of cutaneous and visceral leishmaniasis in Brazil covering a 10-year period ( 2001–2010 ). The models were fitted using integrated nested Laplace approximations to perform fast approximate Bayesian inference. Bayesian variable selection was employed to determine the most important climatic, environmental, and socioeconomic predictors of cutaneous and visceral leishmaniasis. For both types of leishmaniasis, precipitation and socioeconomic proxies were identified as important risk factors. The predicted number of cases in 2010 were 30, 189 ( standard deviation [SD]: 7, 676 ) for cutaneous leishmaniasis and 4, 889 ( SD: 288 ) for visceral leishmaniasis. Our risk maps predicted the highest numbers of infected people in the states of Minas Gerais and Pará for visceral and cutaneous leishmaniasis, respectively. Our spatially explicit, high-resolution incidence maps identified priority areas where leishmaniasis control efforts should be targeted with the ultimate goal to reduce disease incidence.
Dengue patients admitted to a single hospital in southern Vietnam were studied to compare clinical and laboratory features, management, and outcome between adults and children. The study included 647 adults and 881 children with confirmed dengue. We found that signs of vascular leakage and shock were more frequent and severe in children than in adults, while bleeding manifestations and organ involvement were more common in adults. Additionally, adults experienced significantly more severe thrombocytopenia. Secondary infection was independently associated with greater thrombocytopenia, although with a smaller effect than age-group. The effect of age-group on platelet count was also apparent in the values obtained several weeks after recovery, indicating that healthy adults have intrinsically lower platelet counts compared to children.
Sooty mangabeys ( SM ) are natural hosts of the simian immunodeficiency virus ( SIVsmm ), which causes a non-pathogenic infection despite robust virus replication. We identified a novel SM CCR5 allele containing a two base pair deletion ( Δ2 ) that encodes a truncated molecule not expressed on the cell surface and does not support SIVsmm entry in vitro. This allele was present in 26% of a large SM colony, along with a 3% frequency of a CCR5Δ24 deletion allele that also abrogates surface expression. Overall, 8% of animals were homozygous for defective CCR5 alleles and 41% were heterozygous. The prevalence of natural SIVsmm infection was not significantly different in animals lacking functional CCR5 compared to heterozygous and homozygous wild-type animals. SIVsmm primary isolates infected both homozygous mutant and wild-type PBMC in a CCR5-independent manner in vitro, and Envs from both CCR5-null and wild-type infected animals used CXCR6, GPR15 and GPR1 in addition to CCR5 in transfected cells. These data indicate that SIVsmm relies on CCR5-independent entry pathways in SM that are homozygous for defective CCR5 alleles and suggest that SIVsmm tropism and host cell targeting in vivo is defined by the distribution and use of alternative entry pathways in addition to CCR5.
MEF2 transcription factors (TFs) have a dual role in the tumorigenic process: they can act as transcriptional activators or repressors depending on their interaction with co-activators or co-repressors. In leiomyosarcomas ( LMS ), a rare soft tissue sarcoma, MEF2 supports both pro-oncogenic and tumor suppressive activities depending on the presence of class IIa histone deacetylases ( HDACs ). Class IIa HDACs are overexpressed in approximately 22% of LMS, where high levels of MEF2, HDAC4, and HDAC9 inversely correlate with overall survival. In LMS cells, MEF2 is under the control of the ubiquitin-proteasome system ( UPS ), and its ablation reduces the expression of MEF2-target genes and enhances the transformed phenotype. In contrast, in LMS cells where HDAC9 is highly expressed, MEF2 is required for tumorigenesis and to repress the transcription of some MEF2-target genes. HDAC9 also coordinates the demethylation of H3K4me3 at the promoters of MEF2-target genes. Overall, our results suggest that class IIa HDACs, particularly HDAC9, are druggable targets for a therapeutic intervention in LMS.
Hydrophobins are a group of proteins produced by filamentous fungi that play an important role in their ability to affect their environment and promote growth. They are also of interest in nanotechnology due to their unique properties at interfaces. In this study, we have used a combination of protein docking, molecular dynamics simulation, and electron cryo-microscopy to gain insight into the surface structure of films composed of two class II hydrophobins: HFBI and HFBII produced by Trichoderma reesei. Our results suggest a unit cell composed of six proteins with P6 symmetry. However, our experimental results show P3 symmetry with a unit cell size of 56 Å. We also propose an alternate ordering with a three protein unit cell with P3 symmetry and a smaller unit cell size. Using a Monte Carlo simulation of a spin model representing the hydrophobin film, we show how this alternate metastable structure may play a role in increasing the rate of surface coverage by hydrophobin films. This may indicate a mechanism of more general significance to both biology and nanotechnology.
Leishmania donovani, the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis, is a protozoan parasite for which there is an urgent need for new therapeutic targets. Here, we report the functional characterization of L. donovani threonyl tRNA synthetase ( LdThrRS ), a central enzyme required for protein synthesis. We expressed and purified recombinant LdThrRS ( rLdThrRS ) in E. coli and determined its kinetic parameters. Immunofluorescence analysis revealed that LdThrRS is possibly localized to both the cytosol and mitochondria. We generated heterozygous mutants of LdThrRS in Leishmania promastigotes, which showed a restrictive growth phenotype and attenuated infectivity. These mutants were also more susceptible to inhibition by the known ThrRS inhibitor, borrelidin. Several attempts to obtain LdThrRS homozygous null mutants were unsuccessful, indicating that LdThrRS is essential for L. donovani survival. Borrelidin showed a strong affinity for LdThrRS ( KD: 0. 04 μM ) and was effective in inhibiting the aminoacylation activity of rLdThrRS ( IC50: 0. 06 μM ). Furthermore, borrelidin inhibited the promastigotes ( IC50: 21 μM ) stage of parasites. Our data suggests that LdThrRS is essential for L. donovani survival and is likely to bind with small drug-like molecules with strong affinity, thus making it a potential target for drug discovery efforts.
Hepatitis C virus ( HCV ) RNA is recognized as non-self by the innate immune protein RIG-I through the presence of a 5′-triphosphate ( 5′-ppp ) on the viral RNA in association with a 3′ poly-U/UC tract. Here we define the HCV PAMP and the criteria for RIG-I non-self discrimination of HCV by examining the RNA structure-function attributes that impart PAMP function to the poly-U/UC tract. We found that the 34 nucleotide poly-uridine “core” of this sequence tract was essential for RIG-I activation, and that interspersed ribocytosine nucleotides between poly-U sequences in the RNA were required to achieve optimal RIG-I signal induction. Importantly, HCV poly-U/UC RNA variants that strongly activated RIG-I signaling triggered potent anti-HCV responses in vitro and hepatic innate immune responses in vivo using a mouse model of PAMP signaling. Our studies define a multi-motif PAMP signature of non-self recognition by RIG-I that incorporates a 5′-ppp with poly-uridine sequence composition and length. This HCV PAMP motif drives potent RIG-I signaling to induce the innate immune response to infection.
Eosinophils, a type of white blood cell, have been found to support the growth of the parasitic nematode Trichinella spiralis in the host's skeletal muscle. This effect is mediated by the cytokine interleukin-4 ( IL-4 ), which is produced by eosinophils. Our results indicate that IL-4 and eosinophils are necessary for normal larval growth and that eosinophils from IL-4 competent mice are sufficient to support growth. This effect operates in the absence of adaptive immunity. Following invasion by newborn larvae, host gene expression in skeletal muscle is compatible with a regenerative response and a shift in the source of energy in infected tissue. The presence of eosinophils suppresses local inflammation while also influencing nutrient homeostasis in muscle. We found evidence for pathway activation and GLUT4 translocation in infected muscle cells, which supports a mechanism in which eosinophil-derived IL-4 promotes muscle larval growth directly by enhancing glucose uptake in host cells. Our results are consistent with a mechanism in which larval growth is supported when eosinophils, or eosinophil-derived IL-4, limits STAT1 signaling that otherwise would inhibit glucose and lipid metabolism in muscle.
Genome-wide replication timing studies have suggested that mammalian chromosomes consist of megabase-scale domains of coordinated origin firing separated by large originless transition regions. However, we report a quantitative genome-wide analysis of DNA replication kinetics in HeLa cells that contradicts this view. DNA combing in HeLa cells sorted into four temporal compartments of S phase shows that replication origins are spaced at 40 kb intervals and fire as small clusters whose synchrony increases during S phase. Replication fork velocity remains constant and narrowly distributed through S phase. Analysis of a genome-wide replication timing profile shows a broad distribution of replication timing gradients with practically no regions larger than 100 kb replicating at less than 2 kb/min. Therefore, HeLa cells lack large regions of unidirectional fork progression. Temporal transition regions are replicated by sequential activation of origins at a rate that increases during S phase and replication timing gradients are set by the delay and the spacing between successive origin firings rather than by the velocity of single forks.
Slowness is proposed as an objective for spike-timing–dependent plasticity ( STDP ) in the nervous system. This approach exploits the fact that object identities typically vary more slowly in time than contextual variables or noise. We show that slow feature analysis ( SFA ), an algorithm that is based on slowness, can be implemented in linear continuous model neurons by means of a modified Hebbian learning rule. This approach provides a link to the trace rule, another implementation of slowness learning. We then show analytically that for linear Poisson neurons, slowness learning can be implemented by STDP with a specific learning window. By studying the learning dynamics of STDP, we show that for functional interpretations of STDP, it is not the learning window alone that is relevant but rather the convolution of the learning window with the postsynaptic potential ( EPSP ). We derive STDP learning windows that implement SFA and the “trace rule. ” The resulting learning windows are compatible with physiological data both in shape and timescale. Moreover, our analysis shows that the learning window can be split into two functionally different components that are sensitive to reversible and irreversible aspects of the input statistics, respectively.
Cancer cells in heterogeneous non-small cell lung cancer ( NSCLC ) tumors can develop resistance to therapy through a previously unrecognized behavior called cooperative adaptation to therapy ( CAT ), in which cancer cells induce co-resistant phenotypes in neighboring cancer cells when exposed to cancer therapy. Using a CRISPR/Cas9 toolkit, we engineered phenotypically diverse NSCLC cells by conferring mutations in Dicer1, a type III cytoplasmic endoribonuclease involved in small non-coding RNA genesis. We monitored three-dimensional growth dynamics of fluorescently-labeled mutant and/or wild-type cells individually or in co-culture using a substrate-free NanoCulture system under unstimulated or drug pressure conditions. By integrating mathematical modeling with flow cytometry, we characterized the growth patterns of mono- and co-cultures using a mathematical model of intra- and interspecies competition. We found that the combination of WT and mutants in co-cultures allowed for beneficial growth in previously drug sensitive cells despite drug pressure via induction of cell state transitions described by a cooperative game theoretic change in the fitness values. We also used an ex vivo human tumor model that predicts clinical response through drug sensitivity analyses and determined that cellular and morphologic heterogeneity correlates to prognostic failure of multiple clinically-approved and off-label drugs in individual NSCLC patient samples. These findings present a new paradox in drug resistance implicating non-genetic cooperation among tumor cells to thwart drug pressure, suggesting that profiling for druggable targets ( i. e. mutations ) alone may be insufficient to assign effective therapy.
Spotted fever group ( SFG ) rickettsioses are endemic in sub-Saharan Africa, but the burden of disease, risk factors, and transmission patterns are not well described. A cross-sectional seroprevalence study was conducted in Mbeya Region, Southwestern Tanzania, to estimate the seroprevalence of IgG antibodies against SFG rickettsiae and to assess socioeconomic and environmental risk factors. A total of 1, 228 persons above the age of 5 years were randomly selected from nine participating communities, stratified by age, altitude of residence, and ownership of domestic mammals. The seroprevalence of SFG rickettsiae was found to be 67. 9% ( range among nine sites: 42. 8–91. 4% ). Multivariable analysis revealed associations with age ( prevalence ratio per 10 years: 1. 08; 95% CI 1. 06–1. 10 ), warmer temperatures ( prevalence ratio per °C: 1. 38; 1. 11–1. 71 ), male gender ( prevalence ratio 1. 08; 1. 00–1. 16 ), and low population density ( prevalence ratio per 1, 000 persons/km² increase: 0. 96; 0. 94–0. 99 ). At higher elevations, higher cattle density was associated with higher seroprevalence.
Oleate, a monounsaturated fatty acid, is required for innate immune activation and pathogen defense in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. We identified the two stearoyl-coenzyme A desaturases that synthesize oleate in C. elegans and show that the synthesis of oleate is necessary for the pathogen-mediated induction of immune defense genes. C. elegans deficient in oleate production are hypersusceptible to infection with diverse human pathogens, which can be rescued by the addition of exogenous oleate. However, oleate is not sufficient to drive protective immune activation. We show that the effect of oleate on innate immune activation is distinct from the effects of two polyunsaturated fatty acids, γ-linolenic acid and stearidonic acid, which are required for the basal expression of innate immune effectors. Our data indicate that oleate and these polyunsaturated fatty acids affect immune effector expression and pathogen resistance by different mechanisms.
Riboswitches are regulatory elements that modulate gene expression in response to specific metabolite binding. Guanine riboswitches are involved in the regulation of purine metabolite transport and biosynthesis, which are critical for the cellular pool of nucleotides. Upon guanine binding, these riboswitches stabilize a 5′-untranslated mRNA structure that causes transcription attenuation of the downstream open reading frame. We have identified a pyrimidine compound ( PC1 ) that binds to guanine riboswitches and exhibits bactericidal activity against a subgroup of bacterial species, including nosocomial pathogens. This activity is only achieved when the guaA gene, which codes for a GMP synthetase, is under the control of the riboswitch. PC1 targets a different metabolic pathway, as it inhibits several clinical strains exhibiting multiple drug resistance. In a mouse model, we have shown a direct correlation between the administration of PC1 and the reduction of Staphylococcus aureus infection in mammary glands. This work establishes the possibility of using existing structural knowledge to design novel guanine riboswitch-targeting antibiotics as powerful and selective antimicrobial compounds.
In the present study, we investigated how gaze informs the construction of mental space during wayfinding in macaque monkeys navigating a virtual reality maze for a reward. We found that hippocampal cells responded to one or more variables such as head direction, point of gaze, or task context. Many cells fired at the sight ( and in anticipation ) of a single landmark in a viewpoint- or task-dependent manner, simultaneously encoding the animal’s logical situation within a set of actions leading to the goal. Overall, hippocampal activity was best fit by a fine-grained state space comprising current position, view, and action contexts. Our findings indicate that counterparts of rodent place cells in primates embody multidimensional, task-situated knowledge pertaining to the target of gaze, supporting self-awareness in the construction of space. We show that space representation in primates embodies self-position with respect to the target of gaze and further carries cognitive information with respect to the current trajectory to a goal. Our data suggest that the counterpart of place cells in primates, as compared to rodents, is expressed as activity related to point of gaze in conjunction with other variables essential to navigation, such as position and identity of visual elements at key instants of trajectory planning.
During vertebrate development, the mid-hindbrain boundary ( MHB ) is established and maintained by a regulatory network between several transcription and secreted factors. We show that a Boolean analysis of the spatial gene expression patterns at the murine MHB reveals key regulatory interactions in this network. Our analysis predicts a maintaining, rather than inducing, effect of Fgf8 on Wnt1 expression, which we experimentally validate using mouse anterior neural plate/tube explant cultures. We show that Fgf8 only maintains but does not induce ectopic Wnt1 expression in these explants. In combination with previously validated interactions, this finding allows for the construction of a regulatory network between key transcription and secreted factors at the MHB. Analyses of Boolean, differential equation and reaction-diffusion models of this network confirm that it is able to explain the stable maintenance of the MHB as well as time-courses of expression patterns both under wild-type and various knock-out conditions. We demonstrate that similar to temporal also spatial expression patterns can be used to gain information about the structure of regulatory networks. We show that the spatial gene expression patterns around the MHB help us to understand the maintenance of this boundary on a systems level.
Theileria annulata is an apicomplexan parasite that transforms infected host cells by inducing uncontrolled proliferation and clonal expansion of the parasitized cell population. Shortly after sporozoite entry into the target cell, the parasite develops into the transforming schizont, which remains tethered to host cell microtubules ( MTs ) and engages the cell's astral and central spindle MTs to secure its distribution between the two daughter cells during mitosis and cytokinesis. The molecular mechanism by which the schizont recruits and stabilizes host cell MTs is not known. We now report that the schizont recruits end-binding protein 1 ( EB1 ), a central component of the MT plus end protein interaction network and key regulator of host cell MT dynamics. The schizont surface protein p104 functions as a genuine EB1-binding protein and can recruit EB1 in the absence of any other parasite proteins. Binding strictly depends on a consensus SxIP motif located in a highly disordered C-terminal region of p104. We further show that parasite interaction with host cell EB1 is cell cycle regulated. This is the first description of a pathogen-encoded protein to interact with EB1 via a bona-fide SxIP motif. Our findings provide important new insight into the mode of interaction between Theileria and the host cell cytoskeleton.
Telomeres are the protective caps at the ends of chromosomes that shorten with each cell division. In this study, we investigated how telomere length is regulated in response to DNA damage in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae. We found that a mutation in the replicative ligase Cdc9 results in a population of cells with persistent DNA damage, constitutive activation of the DNA damage checkpoint, and longer telomeres. This telomere lengthening requires functional telomerase, the core DNA damage signaling cascade Mec1-Rad9-Rad53, and the components of the break-induced replication ( BIR ) repair pathway. We also found that the Mec1-Rad53 induced phosphorylation of Pif1 is important for the role of Pif1 in BIR and telomere elongation in cdc9-1 cells. We propose that the passage of BIR forks through telomeres promotes telomerase activity and leads to telomere lengthening. In addition, we suggest that the DNA damage-induced phosphorylation of Pif1 promotes potentially telomere-stabilizing telomere extension while repressing deleterious de novo telomere addition events at DNA breaks.
Onchocerciasis, an infection caused by the filarial nematode Onchocerca volvulus, is a major public health concern due to its debilitating symptoms and concerns about recrudescence in areas of previous control. To improve diagnosis and monitoring of control measures, we investigated whether luciferase immunoprecipitation systems ( LIPS ) may be used as a more rapid, specific, and standardized diagnostic assay for Onchocerca volvulus infection. We tested four recombinantly produced Onchocerca volvulus antigens ( Ov-FAR-1, Ov-API-1, Ov-MSA-1, and Ov-CPI-1 ) on a large cohort of blinded sera comprised of both uninfected controls and patients with a proven parasitic infection, including Onchocerca volvulus, Wuchereria bancrofti, Loa loa, Strongyloides stercoralis, and other potentially cross-reactive infections. We found that antibody responses to the four different Onchocerca volvulus antigens allowed for unequivocal differentiation between Onchocerca volvulus-infected and uninfected control sera with 100% sensitivity and 100% specificity. We also found that antibody titers to each of these four antigens in individual Onchocerca volvulus-infected sera were markedly different and did not correlate with each other. The simplified method of using a mixture of the four Onchocerca volvulus antigens simultaneously in the standard format or a quick 15-minute format ( QLIPS ) showed 100% sensitivity and 100% specificity in distinguishing Onchocerca volvulus-infected sera from uninfected control sera.
Anemia, iron deficiency, iron deficiency anemia, and soil transmitted helminth infections are prevalent among women of reproductive age in resource-constrained settings. A 54-month population-based program of weekly iron-folic acid supplementation and regular de-worming was implemented in a rural population of women in northern Vietnam to evaluate its effectiveness in reducing anemia, iron deficiency, iron deficiency anemia, and soil transmitted helminth infections, and to identify predictive factors for hematological outcomes. A total of 389 women aged 16–45 years were enrolled just prior to the intervention. After 54 months, 76% of the participants were taking the iron-folic acid supplement and 95% had taken the most recently distributed deworming treatment. The mean hemoglobin level rose from 122 g/L to 131 g/L and anemia prevalence fell from 38% to 18%. Iron deficiency fell from 23% to 8% and iron deficiency anemia was reduced to 4%. The prevalence of hookworm infection was reduced from 76% to 11% and the level of moderate or heavy infestation of any soil-transmitted helminth was reduced to less than 1%.
Herpesviruses, such as Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ), have evolved immune evasion strategies to persist in the face of cell-mediated immunity. EBV gp150 is a novel, broadly acting immunoevasin that inhibits antigen presentation by HLA class I, HLA class II, and the non-classical, lipid-presenting CD1d molecules. gp150 is expressed during the late phase of viral replication and is heavily glycosylated, creating a shield that impedes surface presentation of antigen. This is an unprecedented immune evasion mechanism for herpesviruses. The mechanism of gp150-mediated T-cell escape does not depend on degradation of the antigen-presenting molecules nor does it require gp150’s cytoplasmic tail. Importantly, B cells infected with a gp150-null mutant EBV displayed rescued levels of surface antigen presentation by HLA class I, HLA class II, and CD1d, supporting an important role for iNKT cells next to classical T cells in fighting EBV infection. Our results indicate that EBV gp150 prolongs the timespan for producing viral offspring at the most vulnerable stage of the viral life cycle.
The actin binding domain of the translocated actin recruiting phosphoprotein ( Tarp ) is a conserved feature among all pathogenic chlamydial species and plays a critical role in bacterial invasion of host cells. Tarp is capable of nucleating actin polymerization independently of host factors in vitro. Sequence analysis of Tarp orthologs from multiple chlamydial species and C. trachomatis serovars revealed multiple putative actin binding sites and variable numbers of functional actin binding domains. Chlamydial Tarps from Caviae, C. muridarum, and various C. trachomatis serovars were capable of nucleating actin filament formation in vitro. A peptide antiserum specific for the Tarp actin binding domain inhibited Tarp mediated actin nucleation and reduced host cell susceptibility to chlamydial infection in vivo. Our findings indicate that Tarp mediated actin binding and nucleation is a conserved feature among diverse chlamydial species and plays a critical role in bacterial invasion of host cells.
Schistosomiasis japonica is a zoonotic disease with a number of mammalian species acting as reservoir hosts, including water buffaloes, which can contribute up to 75% to human transmission in the People's Republic of China. Accurate determination of prevalence and intensity of Schistosoma japonicum in mammalian hosts is important for calculating transmission rates and determining environmental contamination. A new procedure, the formalin–ethyl acetate sedimentation-digestion ( FEA–SD ) technique, has been developed for increased visualization of S. japonicum eggs in bovine feces. This technique involves filtration, sedimentation, potassium hydroxide digestion, and centrifugation steps prior to microscopy. The FEA–SD technique removes nearly 70% of debris from fecal samples, rendering the remaining debris translucent and allowing improved microscopic visualization of S. japonicum eggs. This method provides an accurate quantitative method for estimating infection in bovines and other ruminant reservoir hosts. We show that the FEA-SD technique is as efficient as real-time PCR ( qPCR ) for determining schistosome prevalence in bovines but is less costly to implement.
Mutations in the genes encoding cartilage associated protein ( CRTAP ) and prolyl 3-hydroxylase 1 ( P3H1 ) are the first identified causes of recessive Osteogenesis Imperfecta ( OI ). These proteins, together with cyclophilin B ( encoded by PPIB ), form a complex that 3-hydroxylates a single proline residue on the α1 ( I ) chain ( Pro986 ) and has cis/trans isomerase ( PPIase ) activity essential for proper collagen folding. Recent data suggest that prolyl 3-hydroxylation of Pro986 is not required for the structural stability of collagen; however, the absence of this post-translational modification may disrupt protein-protein interactions integral for proper collagen folding and lead to collagen over-modification. We generated knock-in mice carrying a single amino acid substitution in the catalytic site of P3h1 ( Lepre1H662A ). This substitution abolished P3h1 activity but retained ability to form a complex with Crtap and thus the collagen chaperone function. Knock-in mice showed absence of prolyl 3-hydroxylation at Pro986 of the α1 ( I ) and α1 ( II ) collagen chains but no significant over-modification at other collagen residues. They were normal in appearance, had no growth defects and normal cartilage growth plate histology but showed decreased trabecular bone mass. This new mouse model recapitulates elements of the bone phenotype of OI but not the cartilage and growth phenotypes caused by loss of the prolyl 3-hydroxylation complex. Our observations suggest differential tissue consequences due to selective inactivation of P3H1 hydroxylase activity versus complete ablation of the prolyl 3-hydroxylation complex.
Drosophila simulans, a species closely related to Drosophila melanogaster, has recently been invaded by the P-element, a selfish genetic element that causes hybrid dysgenesis. Hybrid dysgenesis is a syndrome of abnormal phenotypes, including sterility, that occurs in the offspring of crosses between strains carrying the P-element. Here, we report a hybrid dysgenesis-like phenotype in the offspring of crosses between D. simulans strains collected in different years, and show that this phenotype is associated with the invasion of the P-element. We surveyed 181 D. simulans strains and found that around 20% of strains induce hybrid dysgenesis. Using genomic and transcriptomic data, we show that this dysgenesis-inducing phenotype is associated with the presence of the P-element. We also surveyed 631 D. simulans strains collected on three continents and over 27 years for the presence of the P-element, and found that the invasion occurred rapidly and nearly simultaneously in the regions surveyed. Strains collected from the latter phase of this invasion have adapted to suppress the worst effects of the P-element, as evidenced by their resistance to the hybrid dysgenesis phenotype.
Aedes aegypti, the primary vector of dengue, chikungunya, and Zika viruses, is a major public health concern. The male-based sterile insect technique ( SIT ) and incompatible insect technique ( IIT ) have been proposed to control Ae. aegypti and Ae. albopictus populations. However, there is a need for an economical and rapid diagnostic tool to determine the dispersion and mating success of sterilized males in the wild. Here, we report on the use of rhodamine B to mark the body and seminal fluid of male Ae. aegypti for mark-release-recapture experiments and estimating the efficacy of sterile male releases. Rhodamine B, a thiol-reactive fluorescent dye, was administered to males via sugar-feeding and produced >95% transfer to females and successful body marking after 4 days of feeding. Importantly, rhodamine B marking had no effect on male mating competitiveness and proof-of-principle field releases demonstrated successful transfer of marked seminal fluid to females under field conditions and recapture of marked males. These results reveal rhodamine B to be a potentially useful evaluation method for male-based SIT/IIT control strategies as well as a viable body marking technique for male-based mark-release-recapture experiments without the negative side-effects of traditional marking methods.
Bacterial superantigens are a diverse family of toxins that induce an inflammatory cytokine storm that can lead to lethal shock. We show here that superantigens must bind directly into the dimer interface of CD28, a homodimer expressed on T cells, to elicit inflammatory cytokine gene expression and toxicity. CD28 functions as the principal costimulatory ligand in the immune response through an interaction with its B7 coligands. However, superantigens use a conserved β-strand/hinge/α-helix domain of hitherto unknown function to engage CD28. Mutation of this superantigen domain abolished inflammatory cytokine gene induction and lethality. Structural analysis showed that when a superantigen binds to the T cell receptor on the T cell and major histocompatibility class II molecule on the antigen-presenting cell, CD28 can be accommodated readily as third superantigen receptor in the quaternary complex, with the CD28 dimer interface oriented towards the β-strand/hinge/α-helix domain in the superantigen. Our findings identify the CD28 homodimer interface as a critical receptor target for superantigens.
Activation of the Wnt/β-catenin pathway in mouse embryonic stem cells ( mESCs ) triggers an anti-proliferative effect through the transcriptional activation of the Ink4/Arf tumor suppressor locus. The Wnt-effector Tcf1, but not Tcf3, is recruited to the promoter of cell cycle repressor genes such as p15Ink4b, p16Ink4a, and p19Arf, which mediate the Wnt-dependent anti-proliferative effect in mESCs. Activation of the Wnt pathway results in the downregulation of some cell differentiation genes, while the expression of pluripotency genes remains unperturbed. The cell cycle effects are dependent on β-catenin and the downstream transcription factor Tcf1 but independent of Tcf3, indicating specialized and non-overlapping functions of Tcf/Lef factors in mESCs. Furthermore, activation of the Wnt pathway induces an increased expression of negative regulators of the cell cycle such as the tumour suppressors Cdkn2a ( p16Ink4a, p19Arf ) and Cdkn2b ( p15Ink4b ). In contrast to its mitogenic effect in somatic cells, the Wnt/β-catenin pathway triggers an anti-proliferative effect in mESCs via Tcf1 activity.
Dengue virus ( DENV ) infection can cause a wide range of clinical manifestations, from asymptomatic to severe and even fatal. In this study, we investigated the role of plasmacytoid dendritic cells ( pDCs ) in DENV infection. pDCs are innate immune cells that produce interferon-α ( IFN-α ) and express membrane TRAIL ( mTRAIL ) in response to virus exposure. We characterized pDC activation in dengue patients and their function under DENV-2 stimulation in vitro. We found that pDCs from mild dengue patients exhibited significantly higher frequencies of mTRAIL compared to severe cases or healthy controls. Plasma levels of IFN-α and soluble TRAIL were also increased in mild compared to severe dengue patients, positively correlating with pDC activation. In vitro exposure to DENV-2 induced mTRAIL expression on pDCs and relocalized TRAIL from the intracellular compartment to the plasma membrane. Chloroquine treatment inhibited DENV-2-induced mTRAIL relocalization and IFN-α production by pDCs. We also found that pDCs exerted an antiviral activity in infected human primary monocytes and that this activity was mainly dependent on IFN-α production. Our results suggest that TRAIL-expressing pDCs may have an important role in the outcome of dengue disease.
The role of tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) in host defense against Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( Mtb ) infection is complex. TNF plays a major role in host defense against Mtb in both active and latent phases of infection. However, TNF-neutralizing drugs used to treat inflammatory disorders have been reported to increase the risk of tuberculosis ( TB ) in accordance with animal studies. To investigate the role of TNF in protection against the tubercle bacillus in both active and latent infection, we extend our previous mathematical models to investigate the roles and production of soluble ( sTNF ) and transmembrane TNF ( tmTNF ). We analyze effects of anti-TNF therapy in virtual clinical trials ( VCTs ) by simulating two of the most commonly used therapies, anti-TNF antibody and TNF receptor fusion, and predict mechanisms that explain observed differences in TB reactivation rates. We find that bioavailability of TNF following anti-TNF therapy is the primary factor for causing reactivation of latent infection and that sTNF, even at very low levels, is essential for control of infection. Using a mathematical model, it is possible to distinguish mechanisms of action of the anti-TNF treatments and gain insights into the role of TNF in TB control and pathology. Our study suggests that a TNF-modulating agent could be developed that could balance the requirement for reduction of inflammation with the necessity to maintain resistance to infection and microbial diseases.
In this study, we investigated inter-population differences in retrogene loss and expression in humans. We used data from the 1000 Genomes Project to examine the variation in loss of ancestral retrocopies among different human populations. We also analyzed retrocopy expression levels using RNA-Seq data from the Ilumina BodyMap project and lymphoblastoid cell lines from the Geuvadis Consortium. We developed a new approach to detect novel retrocopies absent from the reference human genome and experimentally confirmed the existence of 193 retroduplication variations ( RDVs ). The majority of these RDVs resulted from retrocopy deletion, and most had not been previously reported. We also experimentally confirmed the expression of 11 ancestral retrogenes that underwent deletion in certain individuals. The frequency of their deletion is very low, and the expression, conservation, and low rate of deletion of the remaining 10 retrocopies may suggest some functionality. In addition, we searched for differences in retrocopy expression levels between populations and found 9 retrogenes that undergo statistically significant differential expression.
Inflammation caused by praziquantel treatment of neurocysticercosis ( NCC ) depends on the location of Taenia solium cysticerci in the brain. NCC is a pleomorphic disease caused by infection of the central nervous system by T. solium cysticerci. Inflammation around the cysticerci is the major cause of disease, but its presence is variable. We analyzed the inflammatory responses to cysticerci located in the brain parenchyma, meninges, or partially in contact with both ( corticomeningeal ). Histological specimens of brain cysticerci from 11 pigs naturally infected with T. solium cysticerci were used. We found that cysticerci located in the brain parenchyma provoked a significantly greater level of pericystic inflammation after praziquantel treatment compared to those located in the meninges or corticomeningeal tissue. The inflammatory response to cysticerci located in the meninges was significantly decreased compared to those in the parenchyma. Disruption of the blood-brain barrier was associated with treatment only in parenchymal tissue. The suboptimal inflammatory response to cysticidal drugs may be the reason subarachnoid NCC is generally refractory to treatment compared to parenchymal NCC.
Yaws, a re-emerging endemic treponemal infection caused by Treponema pallidum ssp. pertenue, is reportedly endemic in Ghana. We conducted a cross-sectional survey in thirty communities in two districts of Ghana where mass drug administration ( MDA ) for trachoma had previously been conducted. Children aged 5–17 years with ulcerative lesions compatible with yaws were enrolled, and samples were collected for treponemal serology, lesion PCR, and syphilis serology. We found no evidence of ongoing transmission of yaws in these communities. All children had negative treponemal and non-treponemal serology, indicating that they had never been infected with yaws. PCR for T. pallidum ssp. pertenue was negative in all children, but Haemophilus ducreyi DNA was detected in 9 lesions. This suggests that H. ducreyi may be associated with a proportion of skin lesions, but the majority of lesions remain unexplained. These findings have implications for the WHO yaws eradication campaign and highlight the need for integration of diagnostic testing into both pre and post-MDA surveillance systems to better inform yaws control programmes.
HIV persistence in the body remains a major challenge in the treatment of HIV infection, despite the effectiveness of antiretroviral therapy ( ART ). The HIV reservoir, primarily composed of memory CD4 T cells, is a major obstacle to HIV eradication. The Jak-STAT pathway is a key regulator of T cell homeostasis, and dysregulation of this pathway is associated with HIV persistence. We evaluated the ability of two FDA-approved Jak inhibitors, tofacitinib and ruxolitinib, to block the seeding and maintenance of the HIV reservoir in vitro. Our results show that Jak inhibitors reduce the frequency of CD4+ T cells harboring integrated HIV DNA, block viral production from infected cells, and inhibit viral reactivation from latent stores. We also show that Jak inhibitors target key events downstream of γ-C cytokine ( IL-2, IL-7 and IL-15 ) ligation to their receptors, impacting the magnitude of the HIV reservoir in all memory CD4 T cell subsets in vitro and ex vivo. Importantly, we demonstrate that Jak inhibitors impede T cell activation and proliferation without impeding effector CD4 and CD8 HIV specific responses. Our results provide direct evidence for the involvement of the Jak-STAT pathway in HIV persistence in vivo, ex vivo, and in vitro, and suggest that Jak inhibitors may represent a therapeutic modality to prevent key events of T cell activation that regulate HIV persistence.
Baculovirus infection of Spodoptera exigua larvae leads to an unexpected increase in gut microbiota. In contrast to the expected host transcriptional shut-off, S. exigua cells show a balanced number of up- and down-regulated genes during the first 36 hours following infection with either the species-specific baculovirus SeMNPV or the generalist baculovirus AcMNPV. Many immune-related genes are down-regulated after infection, including those involved in pattern recognition, immune pathways, immune effectors, and the melanization cascade. This down-regulation of immune-related genes is also observed in the larval gut. We hypothesize that the increase in gut bacterial load is a consequence of viral infection. Subsequent experiments reveal that gut bacteria enhance baculovirus virulence, pathogenicity, and dispersion. The down-regulation of immune-related genes and the increase in gut microbiota suggest that baculoviruses may manipulate host immune responses for their own benefit. Recent studies have shown that baculoviruses encode microRNAs that target both viral and host genes. The present study extends previous works on the differential expression of host genes after infection with baculoviruses in other lepidopteran species.
Apomixis, a form of asexual clonal reproduction through seeds, is of great interest for its potential application in agriculture. One key element of apomixis is apomeiosis, a deregulation of meiosis that results in a mitotic-like division. Here, we report the isolation and characterisation of a novel gene that controls entry into the second meiotic division. By combining a mutation in this gene with two others that affect key meiotic processes, we created a genotype called MiMe in which meiosis is totally replaced by mitosis. This results in the production of functional diploid gametes that are genetically identical to the mother plant. The creation of the MiMe genotype and apomeiosis phenotype is an important step towards understanding and engineering apomixis. In the MiMe genotype, meiosis is completely replaced by a mitotic-like division, resulting in the production of genetically identical gametes that retain the mother plant's heterozygosity for every genetic marker tested. This is in contrast to a previous case of apomeiosis reported in the Arabidopsis dyad mutant, in which only 0. 2% of dyad ovules generate viable gametes. MiMe plants, on the other hand, produce quasi–wild type levels of viable—and apomeiotic—ovules and pollen grains.
The prioritization of disease-causing genes is a fundamental challenge in the post-genomic era. Current methods exploit a protein-protein interaction ( PPI ) network for this task. However, these methods use a static picture of human PPIs, while diseases impact specific tissues in which the PPI networks may be dramatically different. Here, we perform a large-scale assessment of the contribution of tissue-specific information to gene prioritization by integrating tissue-specific gene expression data with PPI information. We construct tissue-specific PPI networks for 60 tissues and investigate their prioritization power. We find that tissue-specific PPI networks considerably improve the prioritization results compared to those obtained using a generic PPI network. Furthermore, they allow predicting novel disease-tissue associations, pointing to sub-clinical tissue effects that may escape early detection.
Insecticide resistance is a major concern in the control of vector-borne diseases such as malaria. To inform and optimise public health insecticide deployment strategies, we developed a flexible two-locus model for the spread of insecticide resistance in mosquito populations. The model allows for differential exposure of males and females to high or low concentrations of insecticide, as well as varying selection pressures and dominance values depending on the concentration of insecticide encountered. We applied the model to investigate the relative merits of sequential use of insecticides versus their deployment as a mixture to minimise the spread of resistance. We recovered previously published results as subsets of this model and conducted a sensitivity analysis over an extensive parameter space to identify what circumstances favour mixtures over sequences. Our results indicate that mixtures are favoured when insecticide effectiveness is high and exposure is low, while sequential deployment may be more robust if insecticides do not reliably kill homozygous susceptible mosquitoes. We also found that resistance to an insecticide always spreads slower if that insecticide is used in a mixture, although this may be insufficient to outperform sequential use.
The sialome of Rhodnius neglectus, a vector of Chagas disease, was investigated using next generation sequencing and mass spectrometry-based protein identification. A total of 4, 230 coding DNA sequences ( CDS ) were deposited in GenBank, and 636 CDS of proteins of putative secretory nature were extracted from the assembled reads. Of these, 73 were confirmed by proteomic analysis. The sialome of R. neglectus was characterized, revealing the presence of ubiquitous protein families such as lipocalins, serine protease inhibitors, and antigen-5, as well as less abundant metalloproteases, disintegrins, and odorant binding protein families. Notably, serine protease transcripts were detected in the sialome of R. neglectus. The secreted class of proteins was organized into subclasses that include previously known gene families present in hematophagous saliva, such as lipocalin, nitrophorin, and antigen-5, as well as gene families not commonly reported in triatomine saliva, such as serine protease and disintegrin.
Caenorhabditis elegans, a nematode worm, is used as a model organism to study the interaction between nematodes and soil bacteria in grassland ecosystems. Using transcriptional profiling, we identified genes that are differentially expressed in response to different bacteria isolated from grassland nematodes or soils. Many of the regulated genes are predicted to affect metabolism and innate immunity, suggesting that similar genes could influence nematode community dynamics in natural systems. We used mutations to inactivate 21 of the identified genes and showed that most contribute to lifespan and/or fitness in a given bacterial environment. Moreover, we demonstrated that changes in food source, as can occur in environmental disturbance, can have a large effect on gene expression, with important consequences for fitness. We used regression analysis to show that for many genes, the degree of differential gene expression between two bacterial environments predicted the magnitude of the effect of the loss of gene function on life history traits in those environments.
Mammalian embryo development involves the formation of an inner cell mass (ICM) surrounded by a trophoectoderm (TE), a shell of cells that later form extraembryonic structures. We investigated the design principles responsible for the robust establishment of these structures using multi-scale, stochastic modeling. Our results suggest that stochasticity in the expression of critical genes promotes cell plasticity and has a critical role in accurately organizing the developing mouse blastocyst. We found that asymmetry in the levels of noise variation ( expression fluctuation ) of Cdx2 and Oct4 provides a means to gain the benefits of noise-mediated plasticity while ameliorating the potentially detrimental effects of stochasticity. By controlling the timing and pace of cell fate specification, the embryo temporally modulates plasticity and creates a time window during which each cell can continually read its environment and adjusts its fate. Our results suggest that noise has a crucial role in maintaining cellular plasticity and organizing the blastocyst.
Antibodies encoded by germline gene segments are capable of binding to a wide range of antigens, a phenomenon known as polyspecificity. In this study, we investigated the basis for this polyspecificity by computationally redesigning antibodies encoded by three VH gene segments that bind to different antigens. We used the Rosetta multi-state design process to predict antibody sequences that could bind to multiple antigens simultaneously. The predicted sequences matched the germline gene sequences to a remarkable degree, revealing the residues that enable polyspecificity. In contrast, when designing antibodies to bind to a single antigen, the predicted sequences were similar to those of mature antibodies. We demonstrated that the Rosetta computational design algorithm captures important aspects of antibody/antigen recognition. Our results suggest that the hypervariable region CDR1, CDR2, and the immunoglobulin framework are critical contributors to polyspecificity in germline antibodies. We found that designing antibodies for polyspecificity recovered germline gene-encoded sequences, while designing antibodies for monospecificity to a single target returned sequences similar to the mature antibody. This trend increased in strength with the number of somatic mutations that had accumulated, i. e., the further optimized the antibody had become.
Locusts exhibit two interconvertible behavioral phases: solitarious and gregarious. Solitarious locusts are repelled by other locusts, while gregarious locusts are attracted to conspecifics and can form large aggregations such as marching hopper bands. We construct a partial integrodifferential equation model that incorporates the interplay between phase change and spatial movement at the individual level in order to predict the dynamics of hopper band formation at the population level. Stability analysis of our model reveals conditions for an outbreak, characterized by a large scale transition to the gregarious phase. A model reduction enables quantification of the temporal dynamics of each phase, of the proportion of the population that will eventually gregarize, and of the time scale for this to occur. Numerical simulations provide descriptions of the aggregation's structure and reveal transiently traveling clumps of gregarious insects. Our predictions of aggregation and mass gregarization suggest several possible future biological experiments.
Enveloped viruses, such as flaviviruses, initiate membrane fusion through a series of triggered conformational changes of their envelope glycoproteins, or fusion proteins. Although high-resolution structures of viral fusion proteins in their prefusion and postfusion conformations are available, it has been difficult to define intermediate structures of the fusion pathway because of their transient nature. Here, we show that exposure of tick-borne encephalitis virus to alkaline pH instead of acidic pH traps the particles in an intermediate conformation in which the E dimers dissociate and interact with target membranes via the fusion peptide without proceeding to the merger of the membranes. Further treatment to low pH leads to fusion, suggesting that these monomers correspond to an as-yet-elusive intermediate required to convert the prefusion dimer into the postfusion trimer. Thus, the use of nonphysiological conditions allows a dissection of the flavivirus fusion process and the identification of two separate steps, in which membrane insertion of multiple copies of E monomers precedes the formation of hairpin-like trimers. This sequence of events provides important new insights for understanding the dynamic process of viral membrane fusion.
Extinction risk and diversification are linked in the Cape of South Africa, a global plant biodiversity hotspot. Here, we demonstrate that the taxonomic distribution of extinction risk differs significantly between the Cape and the UK floras, inconsistent with a simple, trait-based model of extinction. Using a comprehensive phylogenetic tree for the Cape flora, we reveal a phylogenetic signal in the distribution of plant extinction risks. However, the most threatened species cluster within short branches at the tips of the phylogeny, opposite to trends in mammals. From analyzing the distribution of threatened species across 11 exemplar clades, we suggest that mode of speciation best explains the unusual phylogenetic structure of extinction risks in plants of the Cape. Our results demonstrate that extinction risk is higher for young and fast-evolving plant lineages and cannot be explained by correlations with simple biological traits. Critically, we find that the most vulnerable plant species are marching towards extinction at a more rapid pace independently from anthropogenic effects.
Phagocytosis of the fungal pathogen Candida albicans by cells of the innate immune system is crucial for preventing infection. Dectin-1 is the major phagocytic receptor involved in anti-fungal immunity. We identify two new interacting proteins of Dectin-1 in macrophages, Bruton's Tyrosine Kinase ( BTK ) and Vav1. BTK and Vav1 are recruited to phagocytic cups containing C. albicans yeasts or hyphae but are absent from mature phagosomes. BTK and Vav1 localize to cuff regions surrounding the hyphae, while Dectin-1 lines the full length of the phagosome. BTK and Vav1 colocalize with the lipid PI ( 3, 4, 5 ) P3 and F-actin at the phagocytic cup, but not with diacylglycerol ( DAG ) which marks more mature phagosomal membranes. Using a selective BTK inhibitor, we show that BTK contributes to DAG synthesis at the phagocytic cup and the subsequent recruitment of PKCε. BTK- or Vav1-deficient peritoneal macrophages display a defect in both zymosan and C. albicans phagocytosis. Bone marrow-derived macrophages that lack BTK or Vav1 show reduced uptake of C. albicans, comparable to Dectin1-deficient cells. BTK- or Vav1-deficient mice are more susceptible to systemic C. albicans infection than wild type mice.
Rift Valley fever ( RVF ) is a vector-borne disease affecting ruminants and humans. Madagascar was heavily affected by RVF in 2008–2009, with evidence of a large and heterogeneous spread of the disease. Our study aimed to identify the environmental factors and areas favorable to RVF transmission to both cattle and humans, as well as human behaviors favoring human infections in Malagasy contexts. We characterized the environments of Malagasy communes using Multiple Factor Analysis ( MFA ) and analyzed cattle and human serological data collected at the national level using Generalized Linear Mixed Models. Our results showed that cattle and human seroprevalence rates were positively associated with humid environments ( p<0. 001 ) and that areas with high cattle density were at risk ( p<0. 01; OR = 2. 6 ). We also found that frequent contact with raw milk contributed to human infection ( OR = 1. 6 ). Our study highlighted the eastern-coast, western, and north-western parts of Madagascar as high-risk areas for RVF transmission in cattle. The association between cattle seroprevalence, humid environments, and high cattle density suggests that concomitant vectorial and direct transmissions are critical to maintain RVF enzootic transmission.
Prions are self-propagating protein conformations that can be transmitted between non-identical proteins. However, transmission of the prion state between homologous proteins from different species is frequently inefficient. Here, we use a yeast Rnq1/[PIN+]-based experimental system to explore the nature of transmission barriers. We show that Rnq1 encompasses multiple prion determinants that can independently drive amyloid formation in vitro and transmit the [PIN+] prion state in vivo. Subsequent analysis of [PIN+] transmission between Rnq1 fragments with different sets of prion determinants established that ( i ) one common QN-rich region is required and usually sufficient for the transmission; ( ii ) despite identical sequences of the common QNs, such transmissions are impeded by barriers of different strength. This indicates that in complex prion domains multiple prion determinants act cooperatively to attain the final prion conformation, and reveals transmission barriers determined by this cooperative fold.
Deep learning is introduced as a novel likelihood-free inference framework for population genetic analysis. This approach circumvents the problem of computing the likelihood of complex population genetic models given genomic variation data from multiple individuals. We demonstrate that deep learning can be effectively employed for population genetic inference and learning informative features of data. As a concrete application, we focus on jointly inferring natural selection and demography ( in the form of a population size change history ). Our method is able to separate the global nature of demography from the local nature of selection, without sequential steps for these two factors. We apply our method to 197 African Drosophila melanogaster genomes from Zambia to infer both their overall demography, and regions of their genome under selection. We find many regions of the genome that have experienced hard sweeps, and fewer under selection on standing variation ( soft sweep ) or balancing selection. Interestingly, we find that soft sweeps and balancing selection occur more frequently closer to the centromere of each chromosome. In addition, our demographic inference suggests that previously estimated bottlenecks for African Drosophila melanogaster are too extreme.
High-risk human papillomavirus ( HPV ) oncogenes, such as E6 and E7, contribute to the development of anogenital and oropharyngeal cancers by disrupting the Fanconi anemia ( FA ) DNA repair pathway. We show that E6/E7 expressing cells are hypersensitive to cisplatin, a DNA crosslinking agent, and have defects in repairing DNA interstrand crosslinks ( ICLs ). HPV oncogenes activate the FA pathway by increasing FancD2 monoubiquitination and foci formation. However, they inhibit the completion of the repair by multiple mechanisms. E6/E7 impair FancD2 colocalization with double-strand breaks ( DSBs ), which hinders the recruitment of the downstream protein Rad51 to DSBs in E6 expressing cells. Furthermore, E6 expression causes delayed FancD2 de-ubiquitination, an important process for effective ICL repair. Delayed FancD2 de-ubiquitination is associated with increased chromatin retention of FancD2, hindering USP1 de-ubiquitinating activity, and persistently activated ATR/CHK-1/pS565 FancI signaling. E6 mediated p53 degradation does not hamper the cell cycle specific process of FancD2 modifications but abrogates repair by disrupting FancD2 de-ubiquitination. Additionally, E6 reduces the expression and foci formation of Palb2, a repair protein downstream of FancD2.
Onchocerciasis, caused by the parasite Onchocerca volvulus, is a major public health problem in the Southern Chiapas focus of Mexico. Since 1998, all 559 endemic communities in this focus have undergone semi-annual mass treatment with ivermectin. In 2003, the treatment frequency was increased to four times a year in 50 communities, and in 2009, an additional 113 communities were added to the quarterly treatment regimen. The goal of the Onchocerciasis Elimination Program for the Americas is to eliminate new ocular morbidity caused by infection with O. volvulus and eventually eliminate transmission of the parasite in all 13 foci in Latin America. The Southern Chiapas focus represents one of the major onchocerciasis foci in Latin America, accounting for about 21% of the total at-risk population in the Americas. Since the 1990s, onchocerciasis control in Mexico has relied on the mass distribution of ivermectin to the at-risk communities. A total of 22 consecutive treatment rounds reaching >85% of the eligible population have been provided in the Southern Chiapas focus over the past 11 years. Ivermectin coverage of the eligible population has remained at a level greater than 85% every year from 1998 through 2011. In-depth epidemiologic and entomologic assessments were performed in six sentinel communities ( which had undergone 2 rounds of ivermectin treatment per year ) and three extra-sentinel communities ( which had undergone 4 rounds of ivermectin treatment per year ). None of the 67, 924 Simulium ochraceum s. l. collected from this focus during the dry season of 2011 were found to contain parasite DNA when tested by polymerase chain reaction-enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay ( PCR-ELISA ), resulting in an upper bound of the 95% confidence interval ( 95%-ULCI ) of the infective rate in the vectors of 0. 06/2, 000 flies examined. Serological assays testing for Onchocerca volvulus exposure conducted on 4, 230 children 5 years of age and under ( of a total population of 10, 280 in this age group ) revealed that 2/4, 230 individuals were exposed to O. volvulus ( 0. 05%; one sided 95% confidence interval = 0. 08% ). The in-depth epidemiological and entomological findings from the Southern Chiapas focus meet the criteria for interruption of transmission developed by the international community.
