Listeria monocytogenes is a Gram-positive facultative intracellular bacterial pathogen that invades mammalian cells and escapes from membrane-bound vacuoles to replicate within the host cell cytosol. A transcriptional activator known as PrfA regulates gene products required for intracellular bacterial growth and bacterial spread to adjacent cells. However, the signal that stimulates PrfA activation has not yet been defined. Here, we provide evidence for L. monocytogenes secretion of a small peptide pheromone, pPplA, which enhances the escape of L. monocytogenes from host cell vacuoles and may facilitate PrfA activation. The pPplA pheromone is generated via the proteolytic processing of the PplA lipoprotein secretion signal peptide. While the PplA lipoprotein is dispensable for pathogenesis, bacteria lacking the pPplA pheromone are significantly attenuated for virulence in mice and have a reduced efficiency of bacterial escape from the vacuoles of nonprofessional phagocytic cells. Mutational activation of PrfA restores virulence and eliminates the need for pPplA-dependent signaling. Experimental evidence suggests that the pPplA peptide may help signal to L. monocytogenes its presence within the confines of the host cell vacuole, stimulating the expression of gene products that contribute to vacuole escape and facilitating PrfA activation to promote bacterial growth within the cytosol.
Vibrio cholerae, the causative agent of cholera, is a highly adaptable pathogen that is able to colonize host small intestines and combat host-produced reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) during infection. In this study, we performed a whole-genome transposon sequencing analysis ( Tn-seq ) to dissect the molecular mechanisms utilized by V. cholerae to overcome ROS in vivo. We compared gene requirements for colonization using adult mice with and without the treatment of the antioxidant, N-acetyl cysteine ( NAC ). We found that mutants of the methyl-directed mismatch repair ( MMR ) system, such as MutS, displayed significant colonization advantages in untreated, ROS-rich mice, but not in NAC-treated mice. Further analyses suggest that the accumulation of both catalase-overproducing mutants and rugose colony variants in NAC-treated mice was the leading cause of mutS mutant enrichment caused by oxidative stress during infection. We also found that rugose variants could revert back to smooth colonies upon aerobic, in vitro culture. Moreover, the mutation rate of wildtype colonized in NAC-treated mice was significantly higher than that in NAC+ mice. These findings support a paradigm in which V. cholerae employs a temporal adaptive strategy to battle ROS during infection, resulting in enriched phenotypes.
Mlh1-Mlh3 is a heterodimeric endonuclease involved in both meiotic crossing over and DNA mismatch repair ( MMR ) in baker’s yeast. To understand how Mlh1-Mlh3 functions in both meiosis and MMR, we analyzed 60 new mlh3 alleles. Five alleles specifically disrupted MMR, whereas one ( mlh3-32 ) specifically disrupted meiotic crossing over. We purified and characterized Mlh1-mlh3-32 ( MMR+, crossover- ) and Mlh1-mlh3-45 ( MMR-, crossover+ ) and found that both displayed wild-type endonuclease activities in vitro. Msh2-Msh3 stimulated the endonuclease activity of Mlh1-mlh3-32 but not Mlh1-mlh3-45, suggesting that Mlh1-mlh3-45 is defective in MSH interactions. Whole genome recombination maps were constructed for wild-type and MMR+ crossover-, MMR- crossover+, endonuclease defective and null mlh3 mutants in an S288c/YJM789 hybrid background. All of the mlh3 mutants showed increases in the number of noncrossover events, consistent with recombination intermediates being resolved through alternative recombination pathways. Our observations provide a structure-function map for Mlh3 that reveals the importance of protein-protein interactions in regulating Mlh1-Mlh3’s enzymatic activity.
Host population structure plays an important role in the reversion dynamics of pathogen populations after the discontinuation of antibiotic treatment. We show that heterogeneity in the number of contacts among hosts leads to a non-random distribution of the resistant strain among the infected population during treatment, and affects the competition dynamics between sensitive and resistant strains after treatment is stopped. As a result, we observe a lower rate of reversion and a lower probability of reversion to sensitivity on the population level after treatment is stopped. Our simulations confirm that contact heterogeneity lowers the probability of reversion back to sensitivity, even when a substantial fraction of the pathogen population is sensitive at the time point when treatment is stopped. The impact of heterogeneity in the host structure is maximal in the biologically most plausible parameter range, namely when fitness costs of resistance are small. In this range, large fitness differences between sensitive and resistant strains result in a non-trivial distribution of sensitive and resistant infections over the network, which in turn influences the reversion dynamics once treatment is stopped.
Autism spectrum disorders ( ASDs ) are highly heritable and characterised by deficits in social interaction and communication, as well as restricted and repetitive behaviours. Although a number of highly penetrant ASD gene variants have been identified, there is growing evidence to support a causal role for combinatorial effects arising from the contributions of multiple loci. By examining synaptic and circadian neurological phenotypes resulting from the dosage variants of unique human:fly orthologues in Drosophila, we observe numerous synergistic interactions between pairs of informatically-identified candidate genes whose orthologues are jointly affected by large de novo copy number variants ( CNVs ). These CNVs were found in the genomes of individuals with autism, including a patient carrying a 22q11. 2 deletion. We first demonstrate that dosage alterations of the unique Drosophila orthologues of candidate genes from de novo CNVs that harbour only a single candidate gene display neurological defects similar to those previously reported in Drosophila models of ASD-associated variants. We then considered pairwise dosage changes within the set of orthologues of candidate genes that were affected by the same single human de novo CNV. For three of four CNVs with complete orthologous relationships, we observed significant synergistic effects following the simultaneous dosage change of gene pairs drawn from a single CNV. The phenotypic variation observed at the Drosophila synapse that results from these interacting genetic variants supports a concordant phenotypic outcome across all interacting gene pairs following the direction of human gene copy number change.
Cerebral malaria ( ECM ) is a severe complication of Plasmodium berghei ANKA infection of C57BL/6 mice. CD8+ T cells are known to play a central role in the development of ECM, but the mechanisms through which they mediate their pathogenic activity remain poorly understood. We show that CD8+ T cells accumulate within the perivascular spaces of the brains of mice infected with both ECM-inducing ( P. berghei ANKA ) and non-inducing ( P. berghei NK65 ) parasites. However, perivascular T cells displayed an arrested behavior specifically during P. berghei ANKA infection, characterized by long-term cognate interactions with CX3CR1-bearing antigen presenting cells ( APCs ) within the brains. These interactions did not prevent ECM development when abrogated by targeted depletion of the APCs. Pathogenic CD8+ T cells were found to colocalize with rare apoptotic cells expressing CD31, a marker of endothelial cells, within the brain during ECM. However, cellular apoptosis was a rare event and did not result in loss of cerebral vasculature or correspond with the extensive disruption to its integrity observed during ECM. Our data show that the arrest of T cells in the perivascular compartments of the brain is a unique signature of ECM-inducing malaria infection and implies an important role for this event in the development of the ECM-syndrome.
Tungiasis, also known as jigger infestation, is a parasitic disease caused by the sand flea Tunga penetrans. The disease is endemic in tropical and subtropical countries and affects communities living in precarious conditions. In Vihiga County, Kenya, the overall prevalence of tungiasis was found to be 21. 5% ( 95% CI: 17. 7–25. 3% ) based on a cross-sectional study of 437 participants aged 5 years and above. The study was conducted in 21 villages in 3 sub-locations and used a semi-structured questionnaire to assess socio-demographic factors, housing, presence and ownership of animals, knowledge and practice related to tungiasis. Multivariate analysis suggested that the occurrence of tungiasis was associated with variables indicating low economic status, such as a monthly income of Ksh ≤ 1000 ( adjusted odds ratio 27. 85; 95% CI: 4. 13–187. 59 ), earthen floor ( 0. 36; 0. 13–1. 024 ) and lack of toilet facilities ( 4. 27; 0. 82–22. 34 ). Other factors associated with tungiasis included age of participant ≤14 ( 27. 414; 10. 02–74. 99 ), no regular use of closed footwear ( 1. 98; 0. 987–3. 97 ) and common resting place inside the house ( 1. 93; 0. 96–3. 89 ).
A computational model of auxin transport in the Arabidopsis root tip has been developed to understand the dynamics of the regulatory network between auxin and cytokinins. The model shows that an auxin maximum is positioned along the xylem axis of the root tip due to mutual feedback between auxin and cytokinins mediated by the PIN class of auxin efflux transporters and AHP6, an inhibitor of cytokinin signalling. Our analysis reveals that an informative spatial pattern in cytokinin levels is theoretically unlikely and not required for correct and robust auxin patterning. Instead, auxin-dependent modifications of cytokinin response allow for the necessary feedbacks, which can amplify and stabilise the auxin maximum. The model also shows that polar localisation of PIN1 generates an auxin flux circuit that stabilises the accumulation of auxin within the xylem axis and provides a mechanism for auxin to accumulate specifically in the xylem-pole pericycle cells, an important early step in lateral root initiation. Furthermore, the model reveals that pericycle cells on opposite xylem poles compete for auxin accumulation, consistent with the observation that lateral roots are not initiated opposite to each other. The model also predicts and experimentally verifies a role of AUX1 and LAX1/2 auxin influx transporters in vascular patterning.
NPF/NO signaling pathway plays a regulatory role in phase-related locomotor plasticity in the migratory locust, Locusta migratoria. We report that the transcription factor CREB-B is a key mediator in the signaling pathway from NPF2 to NOS in the migratory locust, triggering locomotor activity shift between solitarious and gregarious phases. CREB-B directly activates brain NOS expression by interacting with the NOS promoter region. The phosphorylation at serine 110 site of CREB-B dynamically changes in response to population density variation and is negatively controlled by NPF2. The involvement of CREB-B in NPF2-regulated locomotor plasticity is further validated by RNAi experiment and behavioral assay. Furthermore, we reveal that protein kinase A ( PKA ) mediates the regulatory effects of NPF2 on CREB-B phosphorylation and NOS transcription. These findings highlight a precise signal cascade underlying environment-induced behavioral plasticity.
Maternally deposited proteins and mRNAs drive the earliest stages of development in most metazoans. In Drosophila, the maternal-to-zygotic transition ( MZT ) is preceded by the transcription of a small number of genes that initiate sex determination, patterning, and other early developmental processes. The zinc-finger protein Zelda ( ZLD ) plays a key role in their transcriptional activation. We used chromatin immunoprecipitation coupled with high-throughput sequencing ( ChIP-Seq ) to map regions bound by ZLD before, during, and after the MZT. We identified thousands of regions bound by ZLD in cycle 8 embryos, most of which remain bound through mitotic cycle 14. Early ZLD-bound regions include the promoters and enhancers of genes transcribed at this early stage. However, we also observed ZLD bound at cycle 8 to the promoters of roughly a thousand genes whose first transcription does not occur until the MZT and to virtually all of the thousands of known and presumed enhancers bound at cycle 14 by transcription factors that regulate patterned gene activation during the MZT. The association between early ZLD binding and MZT activity is so strong that ZLD binding alone can be used to identify active promoters and regulatory sequences with high specificity and selectivity. This suggests that ZLD is not only required for the earliest wave of transcription but also plays a major role in activating the genome at the MZT.
Circadian protein–protein interactions ( PPIs ) play a crucial role in the temporal organization of cellular functions. Here, we identified 109 novel PPIs among circadian clock proteins using a yeast-two-hybrid approach. Among them, the interaction of protein phosphatase 1 and CLOCK/BMAL1 was found to result in BMAL1 destabilization. We constructed a dynamic circadian PPI network predicting the PPI timing using circadian expression data. Systematic circadian phenotyping ( RNAi and overexpression ) suggests a crucial role for components involved in dynamic interactions. We found that interacting proteins are expressed at similar times likely to restrict regulatory interactions to specific phases. Moreover, we predict that circadian PPIs dynamically connect many important cellular processes ( signal transduction, cell cycle, etc. ) contributing to temporal organization of cellular physiology.
Nematode polyprotein allergens ( NPAs ) are an unusual class of lipid-binding proteins found only in nematodes. They are synthesized as large, tandemly repetitive polyproteins that are post-translationally cleaved into multiple copies of small lipid-binding proteins. The most common repeating unit of the NPA of Ascaris suum is ABA-1A, which is closely similar to that of Ascaris lumbricoides, the large intestinal roundworm of humans. Immune responses to NPAs have been associated with naturally-acquired resistance to infection in humans, and the immune repertoire to them is under strict genetic control. The solution structure of ABA-1A was determined by protein nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. It adopts a novel seven-helical fold comprising a long central helix that participates in two hollow four-helical bundles on either side. Discrete hydrophobic ligand-binding pockets are found in the N-terminal and C-terminal bundles, and the amino acid sidechains affected by ligand ( fatty acid ) binding were identified. Recombinant ABA-1A contains tightly-bound ligand ( s ) of bacterial culture origin in one of its binding sites. This is the first mature, post-translationally processed, unit of a naturally-occurring tandemly-repetitive polyprotein to be structurally characterized from any source, and it belongs to a new structural class.
Ciguatera fish poisoning is a significant public health problem in the Pacific Island Countries and Territories (PICTs). Between 1998 and 2008, there were 39, 677 reported cases of ciguatera, with a mean annual incidence of 194 cases per 100, 000 people across the region. This represents a 60% increase in the annual incidence of ciguatera compared to the reported annual incidence of 104/100, 000 between 1973 and 1983. Taking into account under-reporting, an estimated 500, 000 Pacific islanders may have suffered from ciguatera over the last 35 years. Ciguatera is caused by the consumption of coral reef fish contaminated with ciguatoxin, a toxin produced by dinoflagellates and cyanobacteria. The toxin bioaccumulates up the food web and can cause severe acute neurologic, gastrointestinal, and cardiac symptoms, as well as chronic neurologic symptoms lasting weeks to months. Ciguatera is often under-diagnosed and under-reported, with only 2 to 10% of cases reported to health authorities. The incidence of ciguatera is expected to continue to increase in the future due to changes in global climate patterns, degradation of coastal marine environments, and increased exploitation of coastal marine resources.
Chagas disease, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, is characterized by the persistence of the parasite and impairment of the cellular immune response. CD4+CD8+ T cells have been reported to expand in chronic Chagas disease patients, but little is known about the impact of antiparasitic treatment on this population. In this study, we investigated the effect of benznidazole treatment on the functional response of T. cruzi antigen-specific CD4+CD8+ T cells in chronic Chagas disease patients. We found that the frequency of CD4+CD8+ T cells was higher in chronic Chagas disease patients than in healthy donors, with a higher ratio of CD4+CD8low/CD4+CD8high subpopulations. We also observed higher expression and co-expression of inhibitory receptors in CD4+CD8+ T cells from chronic Chagas disease patients compared to healthy donors. Benznidazole treatment reduced the frequency of CD4+CD8+ T cells, decreased the ratio of CD4+CD8low/CD4+CD8high subpopulations, and reduced the co-expression level of inhibitory receptors. Importantly, treatment also enhanced the multifunctional capacity of CD4+CD8+ T cells and increased the frequency of T. cruzi antigen-specific CD4+CD8+ T cells expressing IL-2 and TNF-α. These findings suggest that CD4+CD8+ T cells play an important role in the control of T. cruzi infection and that benznidazole treatment improves the quality of antigen-specific CD4+CD8+ T cell responses and partially reverses the exhaustion process of these cells.
Phospholipase C2 ( AtPLC2 ) is the primary phosphoinositide-specific phospholipase in Arabidopsis thaliana and plays a crucial role in phosphoinositide metabolism and the endoplasmic reticulum ( ER ) stress response. Lipidomic profiling of multiple plc mutants showed that the plc2-1 mutant had increased levels of its substrates phosphatidylinositol 4-phosphate and phosphatidylinositol 4, 5-bisphosphate, suggesting that the major phosphoinositide metabolic pathway is impaired. AtPLC2 displayed a distinct tissue expression pattern and localized at the plasma membrane in different cell types, where phosphoinositide signaling occurs. The seedlings of plc2-1 mutant showed growth defects that were complemented by heterologous expression of AtPLC2, suggesting that phosphoinositide-specific phospholipase C activity borne by AtPLC2 is required for seedling growth. Moreover, the plc2-1 mutant showed hypersensitive response to ER stress as evidenced by changes in relevant phenotypes and gene expression profiles. Our results revealed the primary enzyme in phosphoinositide metabolism, its involvement in seedling growth and an emerging link between phosphoinositide and the ER stress response.
Reductionism assumes that causation in the physical world occurs at the micro level, excluding the emergence of macro-level causation. We challenge this assumption by employing a principled, well-defined measure of intrinsic cause-effect power–integrated information ( Φ ), and show that, according to this measure, it is possible for a macro level to “beat” the micro level. We evaluate cause-effect power across different spatial and temporal scales by systematically considering all possible black boxes. These are macro elements that consist of one or more micro elements over one or more micro updates. We show that black-box elements can have more common inputs and outputs than the corresponding micro elements, revealing the emergence of high-order mechanisms and joint constraints that are not apparent at the micro level. As a consequence, a macro, black-box system can have higher Φ than its micro constituents by having more mechanisms ( higher composition ) that are more interconnected ( higher integration ). We also show that, for a given micro system, one can identify local maxima of Φ across several spatiotemporal scales. The framework is demonstrated on a simple biological system, the Boolean network model of the fission-yeast cell-cycle, for which we identify stable local maxima during the course of its simulated biological function. These local maxima correspond to macro levels of organization at which emergent cause-effect properties of physical systems come into focus, and provide a natural vantage point for scientific inquiries.
Reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) are produced in the mitochondrial respiratory chain ( RC ) as a result of the interaction between molecular oxygen and free radicals, such as semiquinone ( Q− ). ROS are important signals that modulate cellular adaptation to the environment, but can also damage cells under conditions of hypoxia/reoxygenation relevant for various systemic diseases or transplantation. To investigate the mechanism and determinants of ROS production, we extended a rule-based model of complex III to account for electron transport in the whole RC coupled to proton translocation, transmembrane electrochemical potential generation, TCA cycle reactions, and substrate transport to mitochondria. The model fits respiratory electron fluxes measured in rat brain mitochondria fueled by succinate or pyruvate and malate, and the dynamics of NAD+ reduction by reverse electron transport from succinate through complex I. Our analysis revealed an association of ROS production with levels of specific radicals of individual electron transporters and their combinations in species of complexes I and III. We found that the phenomenon of bistability, previously revealed as a property of complex III, remains valid for the whole RC. The conditions for switching to a state with a high content of free radicals in complex III were predicted based on theoretical analysis and confirmed experimentally.
Motor proteins are essential for intracellular transport in eucaryotic cells, converting chemical energy into kinetic energy to transport cargo over long distances. Motor proteins work in teams to enable unidirectional and bidirectional transport. Disruptions in the underlying transport mechanisms can cause neurodegenerative diseases such as Huntington’s, Parkinson’s, and Alzheimer’s. For example, phosphorylation of the kinesin motor domain at the serine residue is implicated in Huntington’s disease. In this article, we report the effects of mutations of this nature on transport properties of cargo carried by multiple wild-type and mutant motors. Our results indicate that mutants with altered stall forces can determine the average velocity and run-length even when outnumbered by wild-type motors in the ensemble. We also show that mutants gain a competitive advantage and lead to an increase in the expected run-length when the load on the cargo is in the vicinity of the mutant’s stalling force or a multiple of its stalling force. We developed a semi-analytic method to analyze transport of cargo by multiple motors of multiple types. This method determines transition rates between various relative configurations of motors carrying the cargo and enables a computation of biologically relevant quantities such as average velocity and run-length without resorting to Monte Carlo simulations. Our method can also be used to introduce alterations of various single motor parameters to model a mutation and to deduce effects of such alterations on the transport of a common cargo by multiple motors.
The CACNA1C gene, which codes for the α subunit of the Cav1. 2 L-type high-voltage-gated Ca2+ channel, has been associated with severe learning deficits and psychiatric disorders. We investigated how a selective knockout of the Cacna1c gene would modulate the learning process on an operant cue discrimination task in mice. We found that Cacna1c knockout mice still managed to increase reward feedback across trials, but did so by adapting an outcome-based strategy. In contrast, the majority of matched controls adopted the experimentally intended cue-association rule. Our results suggest that the CACNA1C gene has a specific role in learning and that much more mechanistic insight could be gained by examining response patterns in terms of a larger repertoire of potential behavioral strategies. We used a detailed, individual-level analysis of learning on the operant cue discrimination task, combined with Bayesian selection among computational models estimated from the empirical data. Our results may also have clinical implications for treating psychiatric disorders associated with the CACNA1C gene.
Wolbachia-infected Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are being released to control arbovirus transmission. However, their ability to invade populations and persist depends on their interaction with environmental conditions, particularly temperature. We investigated the effects of cyclical heat stress on Wolbachia infections in Ae. aegypti. We reared larvae infected with wMel, wAlbB and wMelPop-CLA under diurnal cyclical temperatures of 26–37°C. We found that wMel and wMelPop-CLA infections exhibited reduced expression of cytoplasmic incompatibility, a reproductive manipulation induced by Wolbachia, and a sharp reduction in Wolbachia density in adults. Furthermore, wMel and wMelPop-CLA infections were not transmitted to the next generation when mosquitoes were exposed to 26–37°C across all life stages. In contrast, wAlbB infection was maintained at a high density, exhibited complete cytoplasmic incompatibility and was transmitted from mother to offspring with high fidelity under this temperature cycle. These findings have implications for the potential success of Wolbachia interventions across different environments and highlight the importance of temperature control in rearing.
Adenoviruses are important human pathogens that have been developed as vectors for gene therapies and genetic vaccines. We sought to understand the natural history of adenovirus infections in various non-human primates and discovered that healthy populations of great apes ( chimpanzees, bonobos, gorillas, and orangutans ) and macaques shed substantial quantities of infectious adenoviruses in stool. Shedding in stools from asymptomatic humans was found to be much less frequent, comparable to frequencies reported before. We purified and fully sequenced 30 novel adenoviruses from apes and 3 novel adenoviruses from macaques. Analyses of the new ape adenovirus sequences together with 22 complete adenovirus genomes available from GenBank revealed that ape adenoviruses could be classified into species corresponding to human adenovirus species B, C, and E. There was evidence for intraspecies recombination between adenoviruses, and the high degree of phylogenetic relatedness of adenoviruses across their various primate hosts provided evidence for cross species transmission events to have occurred in the natural history of B and E viruses. The high degree of asymptomatic shedding of live adenovirus in non-human primates and evidence for zoonotic transmissions warrants caution for primate handling and housing. Furthermore, the presence of persistent and/or latent adenovirus infections in the gut should be considered in the design and interpretation of human and non-human primate studies with adenovirus vectors.
Chromatin, the fundamental structural unit of the eukaryotic genome, is composed of a protein-DNA complex called the nucleosome, where 146 or 147 base pairs of DNA wrap 1. 75 times around a histone core. To function in cellular processes, nucleosomal DNA must be unwrapped, but the details of this process at an atomic level are not yet well understood. We used molecular dynamics simulation with an enhanced sampling method to calculate the free energy profiles for unwrapping the outer superhelical turn of nucleosomal DNA. The free energy change of about 11. 5 kcal/mol for the unwrapping agrees well with values obtained in single molecule experiments. The simulation revealed a variety of conformational states, indicating there are many potential paths to outer superhelical turn unwrapping, but the dominant path is likely asymmetric. The unwrapping process starts at one end of the DNA, where the first five base pairs unwrap, followed by a second five base pairs unwrapping at the same end with no increase in free energy. The unwrapping then starts at the other end of the DNA, where 10 base pairs are unwrapped. These results provide insight into the construction, disruption, and repositioning of nucleosomes, which are continuously ongoing during cellular processes.
Lipocalin Apolipoprotein D ( ApoD ) is an extracellular lipid binding protein with antioxidant capacity that is secreted by astrocytes in the nervous system to help neurons cope with oxidative stress. We demonstrate that ApoD is endocytosed and targeted to a subset of vulnerable lysosomes in a stress-dependent manner, where it helps to maintain lysosomal pH gradients by preventing lysosomal membrane permeabilization. ApoD is functionally stable in the acidic lysosomal environment, and its presence is sufficient and necessary for lysosomes to recover from oxidation-induced alkalinization in both astrocytes and neurons. We show that ApoD is a specific marker for the subpopulation of lysosomes vulnerable to oxidation, and that it helps to keep lipid peroxides levels under control. We also demonstrate that ApoD is required for lysosomal-dependent biological processes, such as myelin phagocytosis by astrocytes and optimization of neurodegeneration-triggered autophagy in a Drosophila in vivo model. Our results uncover a previously unknown biological function of ApoD and set a lipoprotein-mediated regulation of lysosomal membrane integrity as a new mechanism at the hub of many cellular functions, critical for the outcome of a wide variety of neurodegenerative diseases.
Phlebotomus orientalis sand flies are the main vectors of visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) caused by Leishmania donovani in East Africa. Here, we report on the life cycle parameters and susceptibility to L. donovani of two P. orientalis colonies originating from different sites in Ethiopia: Melka Werer ( MW ), a non-endemic site in the lowlands, and Addis Zemen ( AZ ), an endemic focus of human VL in the highlands. We found marked differences in life-cycle parameters between the two colonies, including distinct requirements for larval food and humidity during pupation. However, genetic analyses using Random Amplified Polymorphic DNA ( RAPD ) PCR and DNA sequencing of cytB and COI mitochondrial genes did not reveal any genetic differences between the two colonies. F1 hybrids developed successfully with higher fecundity than the parental colonies. Both MW and AZ colonies of P. orientalis were highly susceptible to experimental infections with L. donovani, even at the lowest infective dose tested ( 2×103 per ml ). Leishmania development in P. orientalis was fast, with the presence of metacyclic promastigotes in the thoracic midgut and the colonization of the stomodeal valve by haptomonads recorded in most P. orientalis females by day five post-blood feeding.
Schistosomiasis japonica is a serious health and economic burden in the People's Republic of China, yet it has not been included in the Global Burden of Disease ( GBD ) study. A patient-based quality-of-life evaluation was performed for advanced schistosomiasis japonica in a schistosoma japonicum-hyperendemic county. Of 506 suspected or officially registered cases, 215 were confirmed and evaluated using the European quality of life questionnaire with an additional cognitive dimension ( EQ-5D plus ), ultrasonography, and laboratory testing. Most patients reported impairments in at least one health dimension, such as pain or discomfort ( 90. 7% ), usual activities ( 87. 9% ), and anxiety or depression ( 80. 9% ). The overall disability weight ( DW ) was 0. 447, and age-specific DWs ranged from 0. 378 among individuals aged 30–44 years to 0. 510 among the elderly aged ≥60 years. DWs were positively associated with loss of work capacity, psychological abnormality, ascites, and active hepatitis B virus, while splenectomy and high albumin were protective factors for quality of life. These patient-preference disability estimates could provide updated data for a revision of the GBD, as well as for evidence-based decision-making in P. R. China's national schistosomiasis control program.
Sleeping sickness, also known as Human African Trypanosomiasis ( HAT ), and nagana, also known as African Animal Trypanosomiasis ( AAT ), are highly prevalent parasitic vector-borne diseases in sub-Saharan Africa. These diseases are caused by the protozoa Trypanosoma brucei ( T. b. ) spp. and are transmitted to humans through the bite of a tsetse fly infected with the parasite. In Kenya, tsetse flies are capable vectors for T. b. rhodesiense and other trypanosoma agents that cause AAT. This study examined the use of national census data from 1999 to estimate population vulnerability and disability in Kenya's 7 tsetse belts, where tsetse species are capable vectors for T. b. rhodesiense and other trypanosoma agents that cause AAT. The study used a multilevel study design to estimate the likelihood of disability in individuals, nested within households, nested within tsetse fly habitats of varying levels of poverty. Tsetse fly's impact on disability was conceptualised via two exposure pathways: directly from the bite of a pathogenic tsetse fly resulting in HAT infection or indirectly, as the potential for AAT takes land out of agricultural production and diseased livestock leads to livestock morbidity and mortality, contributing to nutritional deficiencies and poverty. The study identified tsetse belts that were significantly associated with increased disability prevalence and evaluated the direct and indirect exposure pathways.
In this study, we demonstrate that hexamethylene bisacetamide ( HMBA ) is a potent inducer of cell differentiation and HIV production in chronically infected cells. We show that HMBA activates the PI3K/Akt pathway, which leads to the phosphorylation of HEXIM1 and the subsequent release of active positive transcription elongation factor b ( P-TEFb ) from its transcriptionally inactive complex with HEXIM1 and 7SK small nuclear RNA ( snRNA ). As a result, P-TEFb is recruited to the HIV promoter to stimulate transcription elongation and viral production. Importantly, the inhibition of the PI3K/Akt pathway and the expression of a mutant HEXIM1 protein that cannot be phosphorylated and released from P-TEFb and 7SK snRNA via the PI3K/Akt pathway antagonize this HMBA-mediated induction of viral production. Thus, our studies reveal how HIV transcription is induced by HMBA and suggest how modifications in the equilibrium between active and inactive P-TEFb could contribute to cell differentiation.
Leishmaniasis is one of the most important human protozoan parasitic diseases worldwide, with a prevalence of 12 million infections and a further 350 million people living at risk across 98 countries. Patients suffering from cutaneous leishmaniasis ( CL ) caused by New World Leishmania ( Viannia ) species are at high risk of developing mucosal ( ML ) or disseminated cutaneous leishmaniasis ( DCL ). Recently, we connected this aggressive phenotype to the presence of Leishmania RNA virus ( LRV ) in strains of L. guyanensis, showing that LRV is responsible for elevated parasitaemia, destructive hyper-inflammation and an overall exacerbation of the disease. LRVs show significant evolutionary divergence, making detection and quantitation challenging. To address this, we report various techniques for LRV detection, including the use of an anti-dsRNA monoclonal antibody ( J2 ) that specifically and quantitatively recognizes dsRNA in a sequence-independent fashion. We evaluate each method and demonstrate successful LRV detection by the J2 antibody in several parasite strains, a freshly isolated patient sample and lesion biopsies of infected mice. We propose that refinements of these methods could be transferred to the field for use as a diagnostic tool in detecting the presence of LRV, and potentially assessing the LRV-related risk of complications in cutaneous leishmaniasis.
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli ( EHEC ) and enteropathogenic E. coli ( EPEC ) are closely related pathogens that attach to intestinal epithelial cells, efface microvilli, and promote cytoskeletal rearrangements into protrusions called actin pedestals. To trigger pedestal formation, EPEC employs the tyrosine phosphorylated transmembrane receptor Tir, while EHEC relies on the multivalent scaffolding protein EspFU. We characterized the colonization properties of EPEC and EHEC during infection of polarized epithelial cells and found that both pathogens formed distinct bacterial communities, or “macrocolonies, ” that encompassed multiple host cells. Tir and EspFU, as well as the host Arp2/3 complex, were all critical for the expansion of macrocolonies over time. We found that EspFU accelerated the formation of larger macrocolonies compared to EPEC Tir, as EspFU-mediated actin assembly drove faster bacterial motility to cell junctions, where bacteria formed a secondary pedestal on a neighboring cell and divided, allowing one of the daughters to disengage and infect the second cell. Collectively, these data reveal that EspFU enhances epithelial colonization by increasing actin-based motility and promoting an efficient method of cell-to-cell transmission.
Extracellular vesicles ( EVs ) from helminth pathogens, such as the liver fluke Fasciola hepatica ( F. hepatica ), need to be purified from their excretory-secretory products ( ESP ) for downstream studies and application development. The most commonly used purification method is differential centrifugation ( DC ), but size exclusion chromatography ( SEC ) has been used for EV purification from other pathogens. In this study, we compared DC and SEC methods for EV purification from F. hepatica culture media. Transmission electron and atomic force microscopy showed that SEC purified EVs were smaller and less diverse than DC purified EVs. Protein quantification and Western blotting demonstrated that SEC purified EVs had a higher purity to free ESP yield ratio than DC purified EVs. Proteomic analysis showed that DC purified EVs contained more ESP and tegumental proteins than SEC purified EVs. These results suggest that DC and SEC purification methods do not isolate equivalent EV population profiles. We propose that SEC methods should be used for EV purification prior to downstream studies. This is because SEC purified EVs have a higher purity to free ESP yield ratio and a less diverse EV proteome compared to DC purified EVs.
Post-transcriptional regulation of gap genes in Drosophila melanogaster has been studied using a reverse-engineering approach. This method involves fitting a model to data to infer and analyse regulatory mechanisms. We use detailed, quantitative datasets of gap gene mRNA and protein expression to solve and fit a model of post-transcriptional regulation, and establish its structural and practical identifiability. Our results show that post-transcriptional regulation is not required for patterning in this system, but is necessary for proper control of protein levels. We demonstrate that the uniqueness and specificity of a fitted model can be rigorously determined in the context of spatio-temporal pattern formation. This greatly increases the potential of reverse engineering for the study of development and other complex biological processes.
Rotavirus is a major cause of diarrhea worldwide and exhibits a pronounced tropism for small intestinal epithelial cells ( IECs ). Both human infants and neonatal mice are highly susceptible to rotavirus infection, whereas adult individuals remain asymptomatic and shed only low numbers of viral particles. Here, we investigated age-dependent mechanisms of the intestinal epithelial innate immune response to rotavirus infection in an oral mouse infection model. We found that expression of the innate immune receptor Toll-like receptor 3 ( Tlr3 ) was low in the epithelium of suckling mice but strongly increased during the postnatal period, inversely correlating with rotavirus susceptibility, viral shedding and histological damage. Adult mice deficient in Tlr3 or the adaptor molecule Trif ( TrifLps2/Lps2 ) exhibited significantly higher viral shedding and decreased epithelial expression of proinflammatory and antiviral genes as compared to wild-type animals. In contrast, neonatal mice deficient in Tlr3 or Trif did not display impaired cell stimulation or enhanced rotavirus susceptibility. Using chimeric mice, we detected a major contribution of the non-hematopoietic cell compartment in the Trif-mediated antiviral host response in adult animals. Finally, a significant age-dependent increase of TLR3 expression was also detected in human small intestinal biopsies.
We report on the results of whole-exome sequencing ( WES ) of 1, 039 subjects with autism spectrum disorders ( ASD ) and 870 controls of similar ancestry from the NIMH repository. The WES data came from two centers using different methods to produce sequence and call variants. To ensure the distribution of rare variation was similar for data from different centers, we filtered called variants by fraction of missing data, read depth, and balance of alternative to reference reads. Gene-based analyses of association were evaluated using seven samples sequenced at both centers and by results from the association study. We found that mega-analysis has better power than meta-analysis for gene-based tests. We also explored the impact of population structure on rare variant analysis in these data and found that principal component-based analyses were sufficient to control for ancestry and produce test statistics with appropriate distributions. After using a variety of gene-based tests and both meta- and mega-analysis, we found no new risk genes for ASD in this sample. Our results suggest that standard gene-based tests will require much larger samples of cases and controls before being effective for gene discovery, even for a disorder like ASD.
Madurella mycetomatis is the most prevalent causative agent of eumycetoma in Sudan, an infection characterized by the formation of grains. We investigated the association between polymorphisms in the genes encoding for the chitin-degrading enzymes chitotriosidase and AMCase and the incidence of M. mycetomatis mycetoma in a Sudanese population. Polymorphisms studied included a 24-bp insertion in the chitotriosidase gene ( rs3831317 ), a single nucleotide polymorphism ( SNP ) in the AMCase gene ( rs61756687 ), a SNP ( rs41282492 ), and a 10-bp insertion in the 5’UTR region of the AMCase gene ( rs143789088 ). DNA was isolated from blood and genotypes were determined using PCR-RFLP. Histological staining proved the presence of chitin in the fungal grain. The polymorphism resulting in decreased chitotriosidase activity was associated with increased odds of eumycetoma ( odds ratio 2. 9; p = 0. 004 ). No association was found for the polymorphisms in the genes for AMCase ( all p>0. 05 ).
Herpes simplex virus ( HSV ) has been used as a model to study viral latency, which is characterized by the persistence of viral DNA in the absence of infectious virus. Previous studies have shown that lytic genes can be transcribed during latency, but there has been no direct evidence that these transcripts are translated into proteins. We used a Cre-marking model to show that lytic and latent phases of HSV-1 infection are less clearly defined than previously thought. We found that around half of the HSV spread leading to latently infected sites occurred beyond the initial acute infection, and that lytic promoters can drive protein expression during latency. This is the most direct evidence to date showing that HSV-1 lytic promoters are capable of generating protein during latency establishment and maintenance. We also found that lytic promoters can drive protein expression during latency, which is consistent with either limited stochastic lytic gene expression being an integral part of latency or the early presentation of these proteins to CD8+ T cells providing an opportunity for reactivation to be halted at a very early stage by an immune mechanism.
Prion diseases are a group of neurodegenerative diseases characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain, including Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, frontotemporal dementia, and prion diseases. In prion diseases, the host prion protein is misfolded to form a pathogenic protease-resistant form, PrPSc, which accumulates in neurons, astroglia, and microglia in the central nervous system ( CNS ). Using dual-staining immunohistochemistry, we compared the cell specificity of PrPSc accumulation at early preclinical times post-infection using three mouse scrapie strains that differ in brain regional pathology. We found that PrPSc from each strain had a different pattern of cell specificity. Strain 22L was mainly associated with astroglia, whereas strain ME7 was mainly associated with neurons and neuropil. Strain RML was similar to 22L in thalamus and cortex, but similar to ME7 in substantia nigra. Despite the cellular differences in PrPSc accumulation, the pattern of upregulated genes involved in neuroinflammation was similar for all three strains, and the small differences observed correlated with variations in the early disease tempo. Gene upregulation correlated with activation of both astroglia and microglia detected in early disease prior to vacuolar pathology or clinical signs.
The 3D organization of chromosomes is crucial for regulating gene expression and cell function. Chromosomes are long and densely packed—topologically constrained—polymers, making it challenging to develop adequate models and simulation methods to investigate the multi spatio-temporal scales of such macromolecules. We proposed a generic strategy to develop efficient coarse-grained models for self-avoiding polymers on a lattice, accounting for the polymer entanglement length and the volumic density. Our simulation scheme captures the steady-state structural and dynamical properties of the system and tracks the same dynamics at different coarse-graining levels. This strategy offers a strong power-law gain in numerical efficiency and a systematic way to define reliable coarse-grained null models for chromosomes. We use our formalism to investigate the time evolution of the 3D organization of chromosome 3R ( 20 Mbp ) in drosophila during one cell cycle ( 20 hours ). We show that a combination of our coarse-graining strategy with a one-parameter block copolymer model integrating epigenomic-driven interactions quantitatively reproduces experimental data at the chromosome-scale and predicts that chromatin motion is very dynamic during the cell cycle.
The cell type specificity of expression quantitative trait loci ( eQTLs ), which are genetic variants that influence the quantity and spatiotemporal distribution of gene transcription, presents a problem for understanding the mechanistic basis of human complex phenotypic variation. eQTLs are increasingly used to provide mechanistic interpretations for genome-wide association study ( GWAS ) associations. However, eQTL data exist for a limited number of cell types, and the cell type from which a given physiological phenotype arises may not be known. Therefore, it is critical to quantify and understand the mechanisms generating cell type specific eQTLs. To address this need, we performed an eQTL analysis in three parts: first, we identified eQTLs from eleven studies on seven cell types; then we integrated eQTL data with cis-regulatory element ( CRE ) data from the ENCODE project; finally we built a set of classifiers to predict the cell type specificity of eQTLs. We found that eQTL SNP overlap with hundreds of cell type specific CRE classes, including enhancer, promoter, and repressive chromatin marks, regions of open chromatin, and many classes of DNA binding proteins. These associations provide insight into the molecular mechanisms generating the cell type specificity of eQTLs and the mode of regulation of corresponding eQTLs. Using a random forest classifier with cell specific CRE-SNP overlap as features, we demonstrate the feasibility of predicting the cell type specificity of eQTLs.
The HIV-1 envelope protein gp120 is a major target for the development of broadly neutralizing monoclonal antibodies ( bN-mAbs ). These antibodies recognize epitopes consisting of both amino acid and glycan residues, and the glycans required for binding are early intermediates in the N-linked glycosylation pathway. However, standard Chinese hamster ovary ( CHO ) cell lines used for biopharmaceutical production incorporate complex and hybrid glycosylation, making it challenging to produce vaccine immunogens that display these glycan-dependent epitopes. Here, we report the development of a stable suspension-adapted CHO cell line that limits glycosylation to mannose-5 ( Man5 ) and earlier intermediates. This cell line was created using the CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing system and contains a mutation that inactivates the MGAT1 gene, which is involved in the N-linked glycosylation pathway. Monomeric gp120s produced in the MGAT1− CHO cell line exhibit improved binding to prototypic glycan-dependent bN-mAbs, such as PG9, PGT128, and 10–1074, while preserving the structure of the important glycan-independent epitopes, such as VRC01. The ability of the MGAT1− CHO cell line to limit glycosylation to early intermediates without impairing the doubling time or ability to grow at high cell densities suggests that it will be a useful substrate for the biopharmaceutical production of HIV-1 vaccine immunogens.
Trehalose-6-phosphate phosphatase ( T6PP ) from the parasitic nematode Brugia malayi has been identified as a promising target for the development of anthelmintic drugs. T6PP is essential for nematode survival due to the toxic effects of trehalose 6-phosphate accumulation, and is also conserved in Mycobacterium tuberculosis. We determined the X-ray crystal structure of T6PP from B. malayi, which revealed a stabilizing N-terminal MIT-like domain and a catalytic C-terminal C2B-type HAD phosphatase fold. Structure-guided mutagenesis and kinetic analyses using a designed competitive inhibitor, trehalose 6-sulfate, identified five residues important for binding and catalysis. The structure-function analysis provided the basis for a proposed model of the T6PP-trehalose 6-phosphate complex, indicating a substrate-binding mode driven by shape complementarity and van der Waals interactions. This mode of binding is distinct from the homolog sucrose-6-phosphate phosphatase, where extensive hydrogen-bond interactions are made to the substrate. These results suggest that high-affinity inhibitors will be bi-dentate, taking advantage of substrate-like binding to the phosphoryl-binding pocket while simultaneously utilizing non-native binding to the trehalose pocket.
We present a novel computational framework for simulating vascular blood flow and interstitial fluid transport in whole, realistic tumours extracted ex vivo. Our model couples Poiseuille and Darcy descriptions of vascular and interstitial flow, respectively, and incorporates spatially heterogeneous blood vessel lumen and interstitial permeabilities to generate accurate predictions of tumour fluid dynamics. Our platform enables highly-controlled experiments to be performed which provide insight into how tumour vascular heterogeneity contributes to tumour fluid transport. We detail the application of our framework to an orthotopic murine glioma ( GL261 ) and a human colorectal carcinoma ( LS147T ), and perform sensitivity analysis to gain an understanding of the key biological mechanisms which determine tumour fluid transport. Our results show that incorporating realistic tumour vasculature is key to accurately predicting the spatial flow heterogeneities induced by blood vessels. We also show that reducing tumour interstitial fluid pressure is not essential to increase interstitial perfusion and that therapies should seek to develop an interstitial fluid pressure gradient. Finally, we suggest that normalizing the interstitial microenvironment may provide a more effective means to increase interstitial perfusion within tumours.
HIV-1 is known to spread through both cell-free and cell-cell transmission modes. However, the relative importance of cell-cell transmission in natural infection and its vulnerability to inhibition by neutralizing antibodies and entry inhibitors has not been resolved. Here, we report on the activity of neutralizing antibodies and entry inhibitors during cell-cell transmission using experimental strategies that enable discrimination between the two transmission routes. We demonstrate that the activity of neutralizing monoclonal antibodies ( mAbs ) and entry inhibitors varies depending on their mode of action. While gp41 directed agents remain active, CD4 binding site ( CD4bs ) directed inhibitors, including the potent neutralizing mAb VRC01, dramatically lose potency during cell-cell transmission. This implies that CD4bs mAbs act preferentially through blocking free virus transmission, while still allowing HIV to spread through cell-cell contacts. This provides a plausible explanation for how HIV maintains infectivity and rapidly escapes potent and broadly active CD4bs directed antibody responses in vivo. Our analyses provide compelling evidence that neutralizing antibodies differ in their capacity to block free virus and cell-cell transmission depending on their mode of action.
Visual attention has been shown to produce complex changes in neural responses, including changes in firing rates and receptive field structure. Existing models of attention suggest that these effects arise from selective modulation of neural inputs. However, anatomical and physiological observations suggest that attentional modulation targets higher levels of the visual system, such as V4 or MT, rather than input areas, such as V1. Here, we propose a simple mechanistic model that explains how a top-down attentional modulation, falling on higher visual areas, can produce the observed effects of attention on neural responses. Our model requires only the existence of modulatory feedback connections between areas and short-range lateral inhibition within each area. Feedback connections redistribute the top-down modulation to lower areas, which in turn alters the inputs of other higher-area cells, including those that did not receive the initial modulation. This produces firing rate modulations and receptive field shifts. Simultaneously, short-range lateral inhibition between neighboring cells produces competitive effects that are automatically scaled to receptive field size in any given area. Our model reproduces the observed attentional effects on response rates and receptive field structure without modifying model parameters.
In Drosophila, the posterior signalling centre ( PSC ) is a small group of cells that controls hemocyte homeostasis in the larval hematopoietic organ, the lymph gland. The PSC acts in a non–cell-autonomous manner to maintain janus tyrosine kinase/signal transducers and activators of transcription ( JAK/STAT ) signalling in hematopoietic progenitors ( prohemocytes ), thereby preserving their multipotent character necessary for differentiation into lamellocytes, a specific immune cell type required to fight wasp parasitism. We show that a short type I cytokine-related receptor, CG14225/Latran, is required for switching off JAK/STAT signalling in prohemocytes upon wasp parasitisation. Latran forms heteromers with Domeless, the Drosophila type I cytokine signalling receptor related to mammalian GP130, and antagonises Domeless activity in a dose-dependent manner. Upon wasp parasitism, there is a strong decrease in cytokine mRNA levels in the lymph gland, followed by an increase in the latran/domeless ratio. We propose that this sequence of events culminates in the complete inhibition of residual JAK/STAT signalling by Latran.
Begomoviruses, a family of single-stranded DNA viruses, exhibit high rates of genetic recombination. We investigated recombination patterns during experimental co-infections of tomato plants with the begomoviruses Tomato yellow leaf curl virus ( TYLCV ) and Tomato leaf curl Comoros virus ( TLCV ) over 120 days. We found that recombination patterns between these viruses can be highly complex, with some recombinant genomes containing up to 58 detectable recombination breakpoints. We show that local degrees of sequence similarity, but not genomic secondary structure, strongly influence where recombination breakpoints occur. Furthermore, we found that selection against recombinants with disrupted intra-genomic interactions, such as those required for protein and nucleic acid folding, strongly influences overall patterns of recombination. We also found that selection favoring the preservation of co-evolved protein-protein and protein-DNA interactions is so strong that it can be used to identify the exact sequence tracts involved in these interactions.
Nucleosomes, the basic units of eukaryotic chromatin, have been suggested to influence the evolution of eukaryotic genomes by altering the propensity of DNA to mutate and by selection acting to maintain or exclude nucleosomes in particular locations. Here, we show that despite fundamental differences between eukaryotic and archaeal nucleosomes, the association between nucleosome footprints and sequence evolution is strikingly conserved between humans and the model archaeon Haloferax volcanii. We compare substitution patterns around nucleosome footprints in humans to substitution dynamics in the Haloferax clade, a group of halophilic archaea. We find that neither the mutation nor the selection model are sufficient to explain the observed association between nucleosomes and sequence divergence. Instead, we demonstrate that nucleosome-associated substitution patterns are more consistent with a third model where sequence divergence results in frequent repositioning of nucleosomes during evolution. We show that nucleosome repositioning is both necessary and largely sufficient to explain the association between current nucleosome positions and biased substitution patterns. This finding highlights the importance of considering the direction of causality between genetic and epigenetic change.
Conformational diversity of the native state of a protein plays a central role in modulating protein function. The conformational selection model for ligand binding is based on the co-existence of conformers with different ligand-affinities in a dynamical equilibrium. Conformational diversity involves a dynamical equilibrium between conformers with lower ( ligand-free ) and higher ( ligand-bound ) affinities for the ligand. Internal protein motions guarantee the interconversion between them. Due to its relevance to protein function, conformational diversity associated to ligand binding should be evolutionary conserved. Here, we present a novel procedure to identify key positions whose mutations have a significant effect on vibrational normal modes involved in the ligand-free to ligand-bound conformational changes. We have applied our method to a refined dataset of paired protein structures in the ligand-free and ligand-bound form. Our findings allow us to identify key positions for the evolutionary conservation of the protein conformational diversity required for ligand binding. These positions are dynamically important residues that mediate the ligand-binding conformational change and are mostly buried aliphatic residues localized in regular structural regions of the protein like β-sheets and α-helix.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( Mtb ), the causative agent of tuberculosis ( TB ), has evolved to replicate and survive in diverse host environments by adapting its metabolic pathways to efficiently catabolize multiple carbon sources. Fructose-1, 6-bisphosphate aldolase ( FBA ) is central to both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis in Mtb. We investigated the role of FBA by engineering an Mtb strain in which FBA levels were regulated by anhydrotetracycline. We found that depletion of FBA resulted in clearance of Mtb in both the acute and chronic phases of infection in vivo, and loss of viability in vitro when cultured on single carbon sources. However, this essentiality could be overcome when cultured on mixtures of glycolytic and gluconeogenic carbon sources. In vitro studies revealed that lack of FBA could only be compensated for by a specific balance of glucose and butyrate, in which growth and metabolism of butyrate were dependent on Mtb's ability to co-catabolize glucose. These findings not only evaluate FBA as a potential drug target in both replicating and persistent Mtb, but also expand our understanding of the multiplicity of in vitro conditions that define the essentiality of Mtb's FBA in vivo.
Leishmania is a protozoan parasite that causes leishmaniasis in humans and animals. In this study, we investigated the role of the mitochondrial 2-Cys peroxiredoxin ( mTXNPx ) in the Leishmania infantum life cycle. mTXNPx is a member of the 2-Cys peroxiredoxin family, which is involved in peroxide removal in many organisms. However, Leishmania lacks catalase and selenium-glutathione peroxidases, suggesting that 2-Cys peroxiredoxins are essential for peroxide removal in this parasite. We generated mTXNPx null mutants ( mtxnpx− ) by gene replacement and found that they were unable to thrive in a murine model of infection. Unexpectedly, the avirulent phenotype of mtxnpx− was not due to the lack of peroxidase activity of mTXNPx, as these mutants behaved like controls when exposed to oxidants added exogenously or generated by macrophages during phagocytosis ex vivo. In addition, mtxnpx− were avirulent when inoculated into murine hosts unable to mount an effective oxidative phagocyte response. To definitively conclude that the peroxidase activity of mTXNPx is not required for parasite survival in mice, we showed that a peroxidase-inactive version of this protein was competent in rescuing the non-infective phenotype of mtxnpx−. We propose that mTXNPx has a novel function as a molecular chaperone, which may explain the impaired infectivity of the null mutants.
Histoplasma urine antigen ( HUAg ) is the preferred method for diagnosing progressive disseminated histoplasmosis ( PDH ) in HIV patients. We evaluated the diagnostic accuracy of the IMMY ALPHA Histoplasma EIA ( ALPHA-HUAg ) in a multicenter, prospective study of 288 HIV patients suspected of having PDH in Mexico. We compared the results of ALPHA-HUAg to the reference standard of Histoplasma capsulatum growth on blood, bone marrow, and tissue cultures or compatible histopathologic examination. We found that the sensitivity of ALPHA-HUAg was 67. 1% ( 95% CI, 56–76. 8% ) and the specificity was 97. 5% ( 95% CI, 94. 3–99. 1% ). The positive likelihood ratio was 27. 2 ( 95% CI; 11. 6–74. 4 ). In 10. 5% of the PDH–proven patients, a co-existing opportunistic infection was diagnosed, mostly disseminated Mycobacterium avium complex infection. We observed a high specificity but low sensitivity of IMMY-HUAg. The test may be useful to start early antifungals, but a culture-based approach is necessary since co-infections are frequent and a negative IMMY-HUAg result does not rule out PDH.
Diarrhea is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in children worldwide, resulting in approximately 1. 8 million deaths annually. However, in up to 40% of cases, no etiologic agent can be identified. The advent of metagenomic sequencing has enabled the systematic and unbiased characterization of microbial populations, including viruses, present in stool during episodes of acute diarrhea. In this study, we employed a strategy of “micro-mass sequencing” to characterize the eukaryotic viral communities present in diarrhea specimens from 12 children. This approach entails minimal starting sample quantity ( <100 mg stool ), minimal sample purification, and limited sequencing ( 384 reads per sample ). Using this methodology, we detected known enteric viruses as well as multiple sequences from putatively novel viruses with only limited sequence similarity to viruses in GenBank. Our results demonstrate that micro-mass sequencing can define the diversity of viral communities found in fecal samples from diarrhea patients. Both known viruses and novel viruses were detected by sequencing only a few hundred colonies from each sample library. These findings will serve as the springboard for future studies aimed at assessing whether any novel or unexpected viruses detected play a causal role in human diarrhea.
Zika and dengue are two arboviruses transmitted by the Aedes mosquito that have precipitated large epidemics worldwide. In the Dominican Republic, a large dengue outbreak in 2015/2016 was followed by a Zika outbreak, providing an opportunity to study the transmission dynamics of these two flaviviruses. Using national surveillance data, we compared the age and sex distributions of Zika and dengue cases, as well as the incidence of Guillain-Barre syndrome ( GBS ). We found that 75% of dengue cases occurred in individuals under 20 years of age, while Zika infections were more widely dispersed among the population. Dengue attack rates were marginally higher among males, while Zika infections were highly clustered among females. Age-adjusted Zika attack rates were 7. 64 per 10, 000 population among females compared to 2. 72 per 10, 000 population among males. The reproductive number ( R0 ) of Zika was also higher among females. However, GBS attack rates were slightly higher among males. We found little evidence that existing dengue immunity affected Zika attack rates at the population level. Our findings suggest that community awareness campaigns may have influenced the increased reporting of Zika cases among women of reproductive age, although biological susceptibility cannot be ruled out.
Poly ( ADP-ribose ) polymerase 2 ( PARP2 ) is the predominant enzyme responsible for poly ( ADP-ribosyl ) ation in response to DNA damage and immune responses in Arabidopsis thaliana. Unlike in animals, where PARP1 is the major contributor to poly ( ADP-ribosyl ) ation, PARP2 plays the major role in Arabidopsis. PARP2 is structurally distinct from PARP1, carrying SAP DNA binding motifs rather than the zinc finger domains found in plant and animal PARP1 proteins. We found that knockout of PARP2 rather than PARP1 severely depleted detectable PARP activity in Arabidopsis, with only marginal elevation of poly ( ADP-ribosyl ) ated proteins detected after bleomycin treatment of parp2-1 mutant plants. In contrast, knockout of PARP1 had little effect on poly ( ADP-ribosyl ) ation activity in Arabidopsis. We also found that PARG1 rather than PARG2 is the primary enzyme that counteracts poly ( ADP-ribosyl ) ation in Arabidopsis. In addition, we discovered that PARP1 associates with PARP2, and that PARP1 and PARP2 interact with both PARG1 and PARG2. Overall, our results indicate that Arabidopsis PARP2 and PARG1 play the predominant roles in plant poly ( ADP-ribosyl ) ation during DNA damage and immune responses.
The C. elegans PHR protein, RPM-1, regulates synapse formation and axon termination by acting as a ubiquitin ligase to inhibit the DLK-1 and MLK-1 MAP kinase pathways. We have identified a new MAP kinase pathway that suppresses synapse formation defects in rpm-1 mutants, but not axon termination defects, in the mechanosensory neurons. This pathway includes MIG-15 ( MAP4K ), NSY-1 ( MAP3K ), JKK-1 ( MAP2K ), and JNK-1 ( MAPK ). The MIG-15/JNK-1 pathway functions cell autonomously in the mechanosensory neurons and is sufficient to impair synapse formation in wild-type animals. Transgenic overexpression of MIG-15, NSY-1, or JKK-1 causes synapse formation defects at a similar frequency. Loss of MIG-15/JNK-1 signaling suppresses defects in habituation to repeated mechanical stimuli in rpm-1 mutants, a behavioral deficit that is likely to arise from impaired glutamatergic synapse formation. These findings indicate that the MIG-15/JNK-1 pathway can restrict both glutamatergic synapse formation and short-term learning.
Evolutionary Change within a Bipotential Switch Shaped the Sperm/Oocyte Decision in Hermaphroditic Nematodes. The sex-determination protein TRA-1 in Caenorhabditis elegans and Caenorhabditis briggsae is a bipotential transcription factor that can activate or repress the same target gene depending on the signal from upstream genes. TRR-1, a co-factor of TRA-1, is required for spermatogenesis in C. briggsae and works as part of the Tip60 Histone Acetyl Transferase complex to promote the expression of Cbr-fog-3, a gene needed for spermatogenesis. TRR-1 also regulates the development of the male tail and works through TRA-1 to activate Cbr-fog-3 and control the sperm/oocyte decision. In C. briggsae, TRR-1 null mutants prevent hermaphrodite spermatogenesis, but in C. elegans, Cel-trr-1 mutants do not prevent spermatogenesis. However, synthetic interactions confirm that both halves of the switch exist in each species. Thus, the relationship between the two halves of a bipotential switch can shift rapidly during evolution, so that the same phenotype is produced by alternative, complementary mechanisms.
Integrated information is a measure that quantifies the extent to which a system generates more information than the sum of its parts as it transitions between states, possibly reflecting levels of consciousness generated by neural systems. However, the current measure of integrated information, ΦDM, is defined only for discrete Markov systems, which are rare in biology. Here, we describe two new measures, ΦE and ΦAR, that overcome these limitations and are easy to apply to time-series data. We use simulations to demonstrate the in-practice applicability of our measures, and to explore their properties. Our results provide new opportunities for examining information integration in real and model systems, and carry implications for relations between integrated information, consciousness, and other neurocognitive processes. However, our findings pose challenges for theories that ascribe physical meaning to the measured quantities. We critically evaluate integrated information, a candidate measure that has received significant recent attention, especially in the domain of consciousness science. Our measures are framed in terms of process, and are easy to apply in practice, permitting the framing of testable hypotheses, and the specification of synthetic models, aimed at examining the role of integrated information in neurocognitive processes broadly construed.
Rhodesian human African trypanosomiasis ( HAT ) has been spreading in Uganda in recent years, raising concerns of a potential overlap with the Gambian form of the disease. Recent research has focused on the environmental and climatic factors that control the spatial distribution of the disease. A previous study used simple logistic regression methods to explore the relationship between HAT prevalence and several social, environmental and climatic variables in two of the most recently affected districts of Uganda. The study suggested that the disease had spread into the study area due to the movement of infected, untreated livestock. Here, we extend this study to account for spatial autocorrelation, incorporate uncertainty in input data and model parameters, and undertake predictive mapping for risk of high HAT prevalence in the future. Using a Bayesian geostatistical model, we demonstrate a more rigorous analytical approach, potentially resulting in more accurate parameter and significance estimates and increased predictive accuracy. Our analysis strongly supports the theory that Rhodesian HAT was imported to the study area via the movement of untreated, infected livestock from endemic areas. We also confirm the confounding effect of health care accessibility on the spatial distribution of Rhodesian HAT and the linkages between the disease's distribution and minimum land surface temperature. Predictive mapping indicates an increased risk of high HAT prevalence in the future in areas surrounding livestock markets, demonstrating the importance of livestock trading for continuing disease spread.
The feasibility of equilibria in large ecosystems is a neglected concept in the complexity-stability debate. Previous approaches assume the existence of a feasible equilibrium, i. e. with positive abundances, but this assumption has not been tested. We provide analytical results and simulations showing that equilibrium feasibility vanishes in species-rich systems. This leaves us in an uncomfortable situation in which the existence of a feasible equilibrium assumed in local stability criteria is far from granted. We extend our analyses by changing interaction structure and intensity, and find that feasibility and stability are warranted irrespective of species richness with weak interactions. Interestingly, we find that the dynamical behaviour of ecologically inspired architectures is very different and richer than that of unstructured systems. Our results suggest that a general understanding of ecosystem dynamics requires focusing on the interplay between interaction strength and network architecture. We show that, in situations compatible with previous works, the existence of a feasible equilibrium is not guaranteed, since the probability to observe such a point decreases exponentially towards zero as the size of the network grows. We also find that with weak interactions, non-trivial feasible equilibria are found only in ecologically-inspired systems, in a way that is ecologically sensible.
The sero-epidemiology of Coxiella burnetii, the causative agent of Q fever, was investigated in humans and cattle in Western Kenya. A cross-sectional study was conducted in 416 homesteads, where serum samples from 2049 humans and 955 cattle were tested for C. burnetii antibodies. The overall sero-prevalence of C. burnetii was 2. 5% in humans and 10. 5% in cattle. However, there was no evidence of correlation between cattle and human seroprevalence at the household level or when accounting for spatial proximity between households. This suggests that human exposure to C. burnetii may occur due to contact with or environmental contamination by livestock owned by other households. Multilevel regression analysis indicated that several factors were associated with exposure to C. burnetii in both humans and cattle. In humans, the youngest age group had the highest odds of seropositivity, and frequent livestock contact was a risk factor. In cattle, those obtained from market and those residing in areas with lower precipitation levels had the highest sero-prevalence.
Schistosoma mansoni, the causative agent of schistosomiasis, a major neglected tropical disease, is a blood fluke whose genome has been sequenced. To identify the role and importance of newly described schistosome genes, functional genomic approaches are being developed. Transgenesis is an established tool for functional genomics in model species, which can lead to gain- or loss-of-functions, facilitate vector-based RNA interference, and represent an effective forward genetics tool for insertional mutagenesis screens. However, progress toward routine transgenesis in schistosomes might be expedited if germ cells could be reliably localized in cultured schistosomes. Vasa, a member of the ATP-dependent DEAD-box RNA helicase family, is a prototypic marker of primordial germ cells and the germ line in the Metazoa. Using bioinformatics, 33 putative DEAD-box RNA helicases exhibiting conserved motifs that characterize helicases of this family were identified in the S. mansoni genome. Three of these helicases exhibited vasa-like sequences and were termed Smvlg1, Smvlg2, and Smvlg3. Phylogenetic analysis confirmed that Smvlg1, Smvlg2, and Smvlg3 were members of the Vasa/PL10 DEAD-box subfamily. Expression of Smvlg1, Smvlg2, and Smvlg3 was detected in developmental stages of S. mansoni with elevated expression in sporocysts, adult females, eggs, and miracidia, with strikingly high expression in the undeveloped egg.
VGLL4 plays a critical role in heart valve development and homeostasis. We found that VGLL4 is mainly expressed in valve interstitial cells at the post-endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) stage and is maintained until the adult stage. Tissue-specific knockout of VGLL4 in different cell lineages revealed that only loss of VGLL4 in endothelial cell lineage led to valve malformation with expanded expression of YAP targets. Further studies showed that loss of VGLL4 in endothelial cells resulted in abnormal arterial valve morphology and severe cardiac hypertrophy in 36-week-old mice, while semi-knockout of YAP rescued heart malformation induced by VGLL4 deletion. Altogether, our study shows that VGLL4 and precisely regulated Hippo signaling are required for proper heart valve remodeling and maturation. Thus, Hippo signaling in valve endothelial cells is required for post-EMT semilunar valve morphogenesis and homeostasis. Precise regulation of the Hippo pathway is required for proper proliferation of endocardium-derived mesenchymal cells and subsequent valve elongation. We identified a previously unknown function of VGLL4 in valve remodeling and homeostasis and suggest that mutations in VGLL4 may underlie human congenital heart valve dysplasia.
Since the initial description of the genomic patterns expected under models of positive selection acting on standing genetic variation and on multiple beneficial mutations—so-called soft selective sweeps—researchers have sought to identify these patterns in natural population data. Over the past two years, large-scale data analyses have argued that soft sweeps are pervasive across organisms of very different effective population size and mutation rate—humans, Drosophila, and HIV. However, others have evaluated the relevance of these models to natural populations, as well as the identifiability of the models relative to other known population-level processes, arguing that soft sweeps are likely to be rare. Here, we look to reconcile these opposing results by carefully evaluating three recent studies and their underlying methodologies. Using population genetic theory, as well as extensive simulation, we find that all three examples are prone to extremely high false-positive rates, incorrectly identifying soft sweeps under both hard sweep and neutral models. Furthermore, we demonstrate that well-fit demographic histories combined with rare hard sweeps serve as the more parsimonious explanation. These findings represent a necessary response to the growing tendency of invoking parameter-heavy, assumption-laden models of pervasive positive selection, and neglecting best practices regarding the construction of proper demographic null models.
Host-seeking behavior in female Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, the primary vector for dengue fever, is known to be inhibited for three days following a blood meal by a hemolymph-borne humoral factor.
