Head Peptide-I is a candidate peptide mediating this suppression, but the mechanism by which this peptide alters mosquito behavior and the receptor through which it signals are unknown. We identified eight Neuropeptide Y-Like Receptors ( NPYLRs ) in the Ae. aegypti genome and screened each in a cell-based calcium imaging assay for sensitivity against a panel of peptides. Four of the Ae. aegypti NPYLRs responded to one or more peptide ligands, but only NPYLR1 responded to Head Peptide-I as well as sNPFs. Injection of synthetic Head Peptide-I and sNPF-3 inhibited host-seeking behavior in non-blood-fed female mosquitoes. To ask if NPYLR1 is necessary for blood-feeding-induced host-seeking inhibition, we used zinc-finger nucleases to generate five independent npylr1 null mutant strains and tested them for behavioral abnormalities. npylr1 mutants displayed normal behavior in locomotion, egg laying, sugar feeding, blood feeding, host seeking, and inhibition of host seeking after a blood meal.
Schistosomiasis is a parasitic disease that can be influenced by environmental factors such as rivers, elevation, slope, land surface temperature, land use/cover, and rainfall. This study aimed to identify areas with suitable conditions for schistosomiasis transmission in Akure North Local Government Area ( LGA ) of Ondo State, Nigeria, using satellite derived environmental data and spatial analysis. The study used multicriteria evaluation ( MCE ) and Saaty’s analytical hierarchy process ( AHP ) to obtain the mapping weight or importance of each individual schistosomiasis risk factor. The study focused on temperature, drainage, elevation, rainfall, slope, and land use/land cover as the factors controlling schistosomiasis incidence in the study area. These factors were reclassified and overlaid to identify areas vulnerable to schistosomiasis. The prevalence of urinary schistosomiasis in the study area was also determined by parasitological analysis of urine samples collected through random sampling. The results showed a varying risk of schistosomiasis, with 82% of the area falling under the high and very high risk category. The study also showed that one community ( Oba Ile ) had the lowest risk of schistosomiasis, while the risk increased in the four remaining communities ( Iju, Igoba, Ita Ogbolu, and Ogbese ).
Streptococcus pneumoniae ( pneumococcal ) meningitis is the most common form of bacterial meningitis, with a patient survival rate of 75% and half of the patients suffering from long-term disabilities. Pneumolysin ( PLY ) is a critical pneumococcal pathogenic factor that belongs to the cholesterol-dependent cytolysin ( CDC ) group. Our studies demonstrate a pathogenic cascade linking the presence of PLY with glutamate release and the subsequent, NMDA-dependent dendritic and synaptic pathology associated with pneumococcal meningitis. We show that PLY induces glutamate release from astrocytes in a calcium-dependent manner, which we speculate to be a major source of elevated brain glutamate in pneumococcal meningitis and meningitis model systems. We further demonstrate that PLY causes permanent dendritic swelling, dendritic spine elimination, and synaptic loss in mouse brain slices at disease-relevant, non-lytic concentrations. The NMDA glutamate receptor antagonists MK801 and D-AP5 reduce this pathology, suggesting that PLY-induced glutamate release leads to subsequent glutamate-dependent synaptic damage. We propose that PLY plays a significant synapto- and dendritotoxic role in pneumococcal meningitis by initiating glutamate release from astrocytes, leading to subsequent glutamate-dependent synaptic damage.
Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) are DNA viruses associated with major human cancers. To develop new means to prevent HPV infections, such as vaccines and microbicides, a better understanding of the infectious life cycle of HPVs is required. The infectious life cycle of HPVs is closely linked to the differentiation state of the stratified epithelium it infects, with progeny virus only made in the terminally differentiating suprabasal compartment. It has been recognized that HPV must first establish its infection within the basal layer of stratified epithelium, but why this is the case has not been understood. Here, we used chemical biology approaches to reveal that cell cycle progression through mitosis is critical for HPV infection. Using infectious HPV16 particles containing the intact viral genome, G1-synchronized human keratinocytes as hosts, and early viral gene expression as a readout for infection, we learned that the recipient cell must enter M phase ( mitosis ) for HPV infection to take place. Late M phase inhibitors had no effect on infection, whereas G1, S, G2, and early M phase cell cycle inhibitors efficiently prevented infection. We conclude that host cells need to pass through early prophase for successful onset of transcription of the HPV encapsidated genes. These findings provide one reason why HPVs initially establish infections in the basal compartment of stratified epithelia.
Penicillium marneffei is the most important thermal dimorphic fungus causing systemic mycosis in China and Southeast Asia. We hypothesized that miRNA-like RNAs ( milRNAs ) may be expressed in P. marneffei and involved in the regulation of thermal dimorphism. We used high-throughput sequencing technology to identify milRNAs in P. marneffei in both mycelial and yeast phases. We identified 24 potential milRNA candidates, which were more abundantly expressed in mycelial than yeast phase. Two genes, dcl-1 and dcl-2, encoding putative Dicer-like proteins and the gene, qde-2, encoding Argonaute-like protein, were identified in P. marneffei. Phylogenetic analysis showed that dcl-2 of P. marneffei was more closely related to the homologues in other thermal dimorphic pathogenic fungi than to Penicillium chrysogenum and Aspergillus spp. Moreover, dcl-2 demonstrated higher mRNA expression levels in mycelial than yeast phase by 7 folds ( P<0. 001 ). Northern blot analysis confirmed the expression of two milRNAs, PM-milR-M1 and PM-milR-M2, only in mycelial phase. Using dcl-1KO, dcl-2KO, dclDKO and qde-2KO deletion mutants, we showed that the biogenesis of both milRNAs were dependent on dcl-2 but not dcl-1 or qde-2. Our findings provided the first evidence for differential expression of milRNAs in different growth phases of thermal dimorphic fungi and shed light on the evolution of fungal proteins involved in milRNA biogenesis and possible role of post-transcriptional control in governing thermal dimorphism.
Zika virus ( ZIKV ) emerged in French Polynesia in 2013 and spread through the Pacific region between 2013 and 2017. The main arbovirus vector in the region, Aedes aegypti, and the secondary vector of dengue virus, Aedes polynesiensis, may have contributed to the transmission of ZIKV. This study aimed to evaluate and compare the vector competence of wild Ae. aegypti and Ae. polynesiensis populations from different Pacific islands for a ZIKV strain that circulated in the region during the 2013–2017 outbreak. Field Ae. aegypti ( three populations ) and Ae. polynesiensis ( two populations ) from the Pacific region were collected and orally exposed to ZIKV ( 107 TCID50/mL ) isolated in the region in 2014. The results showed that ZIKV infection rates were heterogeneous between the Ae. aegypti populations, but the dissemination rates were moderate and more homogeneous between these populations. For Ae. polynesiensis, infection rates were less heterogeneous between the two populations tested. The transmission rate and efficiency results revealed a low vector competence for ZIKV of the different Aedes vector populations under study. Our results indicated a low ZIKV transmission by Ae. aegypti and Ae. polynesiensis tested from the Pacific region.
Xist is a long non-coding RNA ( lncRNA ) that plays a central role in the regulation of X-chromosome inactivation in mammalian cells. To understand how Xist and other lncRNAs function, it is essential to study their secondary and higher-order structures. We developed a new approach called Targeted Structure-Seq, which combines chemical probing of RNA structure in cells with target-specific massively parallel sequencing. This approach enriches for signals from the RNA of interest, providing high coverage of the target RNA with relatively few sequencing reads. We used Targeted Structure-Seq to probe the full-length Xist lncRNA and developed new models for functional elements within Xist, including the repeat A element in the 5’-end of Xist. Our analysis also identified new structural elements in Xist that are evolutionarily conserved, including a new element proximal to the C repeats that is important for Xist function. We validated the utility of Targeted Structure-Seq to study lncRNA conformation in mammalian cells and expect that this approach will be useful for advancing our mechanistic understanding of lncRNAs.
In this study, we develop a novel statistical framework to evaluate the performance of genetic risk prediction models for complex diseases. Previous studies have mainly used the area under the receiver operating characteristic ( ROC ) curve, or AUC, to judge the predictive value of genetic tests. However, AUC has its limitations and should be complemented by other measures. We show that given the overall disease prevalence and total variance in liability explained by the set of susceptibility variants, it is possible to estimate analytically a large variety of prediction metrics. These metrics include the AUC, the mean risk difference between cases and non-cases, the net reclassification improvement ( ability to reclassify people into high- and low-risk categories ), the proportion of cases explained by a specific percentile of population at the highest risk, the variance of predicted risks, and the risk at any percentile. We also demonstrate how to construct graphs to visualize the performance of risk models, such as the ROC curve, the density of risks, and the predictiveness curve ( disease risk plotted against risk percentile ). The results from simulations match very well with our theoretical estimates. We apply the methodology to nine complex diseases, evaluating the predictive power of genetic tests based on known susceptibility variants for each trait.
Trypanosoma brucei gambiense human African trypanosomiasis ( HAT ) is a vector-borne, neglected tropical disease that puts 70 million people living in sub-Saharan African countries at risk. The most common form of the disease is caused by infection with the protozoan parasite T. b. gambiense, which in 2015 accounted for more than 97% of all reported HAT cases. Diagnosis and treatment are central elements of strategies to control HAT, and serological screening is a key entry point in diagnostic algorithms. The Card Agglutination Test for Trypanosomiasis ( CATT ) has been the most widely used screening test for decades, but it has a number of practical limitations. The objective of this study was to evaluate the accuracy of a new rapid diagnostic test ( RDT ) developed using recombinant antigens ( SD BIOLINE HAT 2. 0 ), in comparison with an RDT produced using native antigens ( SD BIOLINE HAT ) and CATT. A total of 57, 632 individuals were screened in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and 260 HAT cases were confirmed by parasitology. The highest sensitivity was achieved with the SD BIOLINE HAT 2. 0 ( 71. 2% ), followed by CATT ( 62. 5% ) and the SD BIOLINE HAT ( 59. 0% ). Combining two or three tests resulted in a markedly increased sensitivity: when the SD BIOLINE HAT was combined with the SD BIOLINE HAT 2. 0, sensitivity reached 98. 4% in passive and 83. 0% in active screening.
Chagas disease, a neglected tropical disease endemic to Latin America, has been effectively controlled in most of Guatemala after multiple rounds of indoor residual insecticide spraying ( IRS ). However, a few foci remain with persistent Triatoma dimidiata infestation, including the municipality of Comapa in the southeastern region of Guatemala. We carried out three cross-sectional entomological and serological surveys in Comapa between 1999 and 2015 to evaluate a decade of vector control activities. After multiple rounds of IRS, the infestation index decreased significantly from 39% ( 2001–2 ) to 27% ( 2011 ). Household construction materials alone predicted <10% of infested houses. Chagas seroprevalence in school-aged children declined by 10–fold, from 10% ( 1999 ) to 1% ( 2015 ). However, seroprevalence in women of childbearing age remains >10%. The continued risk for vector-borne and congenital transmission poses a threat to the 2022 Chagas disease elimination goal. Systematic integrated vector control and improved Chagas disease screening and treatment programs for congenital and vector-borne disease are needed to reach the elimination goal in regions with persistent vector infestation.
Citrobacter rodentium is a natural mouse pathogen that causes attaching and effacing ( A/E ) lesions and shares a common virulence strategy with the clinically significant human pathogens enteropathogenic E. coli ( EPEC ) and enterohaemorrhagic E. coli ( EHEC ). We previously reported the complete genome sequence of C. rodentium strain ICC168, which displayed characteristics of a newly evolved pathogen. In this study, we found that the genome of C. rodentium is unstable as a result of repeat-mediated, large-scale genome recombination and active transposition of mobile genetic elements such as prophages. We sequenced an additional C. rodentium strain, EX-33, and found that the reference strain ICC168 is representative of the species and that most of the inactivating mutations were common to both isolates and likely to have occurred early on in the evolution of this pathogen. We draw parallels with the evolution of other bacterial pathogens and conclude that C. rodentium is a recently evolved pathogen that may have emerged alongside the development of inbred mice as a model for human disease. The genome of C. rodentium displays features associated with bacteria that have recently passed through an evolutionary bottleneck, including a large number of pseudogenes and IS elements.
Stochastic fluctuations in gene expression give rise to distributions of protein levels across cell populations. We propose a method for inferring sets of biochemical rate constants that govern chromatin modification, transcription, translation, and RNA and protein degradation from stochasticity in protein expression. We derived analytical solutions for the first four moments of the protein distribution and found that these four moments completely capture the shape of protein distributions. We developed an efficient algorithm for inferring gene expression rate constants from the moments of protein distributions. Using this algorithm, we find that most protein distributions are consistent with a large number of different biochemical rate constant sets. Despite this degeneracy, the solution space of rate constants almost always informs on underlying mechanism. For example, we distinguish between regimes where transcriptional bursting occurs from regimes reflecting constitutive transcript production. Our method agrees with the current standard approach, and in the restrictive regime where the standard method operates, also identifies rate constants not previously obtainable. Even without making any assumptions we obtain estimates of individual biochemical rate constants, or meaningful ratios of rate constants, in 91% of tested cases.
Smallpox vaccination has been shown to provide good protection against monkeypox virus ( MPXV ) in animal models and humans. However, most first- and second-generation smallpox vaccines are associated with morbidity and are contraindicated for a large proportion of the population. Third-generation vaccines, such as modified vaccinia virus Ankara ( MVA ), have been shown to be safer in non-human primates but require two administrations for complete protection. MPXV is an emerging orthopoxvirus zoonosis in the tropical rain forest of Africa and is endemic in the Congo-basin and sporadic in West Africa. The virus has a broad-host range and is capable of infecting many animal species. Cases of human MPX are increasing in Africa, which may be due to increasing interactions between humans and infected animals, cessation of routine vaccination against smallpox, increase in human susceptibility to the virus, increase in animal-human and human-human transmissibility of the virus, and adaptation of the virus to new host species. There are no FDA-approved therapies against MPXV, and current vaccines are limited due to safety concerns. In this study, a new vaccination strategy based on three recombinant bovine herpesvirus 4 ( BoHV-4 ) vectors, each expressing different MPXV glycoproteins, was investigated in terms of protection from a lethal MPXV challenge in STAT1 knockout mice. The results showed that BoHV-4-A-EF1α-M1RgD106ΔTK alone or in combination with BoHV-4-A-CMV-A29LgD106ΔTK and BoHV-4-A-EF1α-B6RgD106ΔTK was able to protect 100% and 80% of STAT1 ( -/- ) mice against mortality and morbidity, respectively.
Trypanosomes lack homologues to all subunits of the decapping complex, but instead use an ApaH-like phosphatase, TbALPH1, as their major mRNA decapping enzyme. TbALPH1 localises to a special granule at the posterior pole of the cell and co-localises exclusively with the 5’-3’ exoribonuclease XRNA. RNAi depletion of TbALPH1 is lethal and causes a massive increase in total mRNAs that are deadenylated but have not yet started 5’-3’ decay. This suggests that TbALPH1 acts downstream of deadenylation and upstream of mRNA degradation, consistent with a function in mRNA decapping. In vitro experiments show that recombinant, N-terminally truncated TbALPH1 protein sensitises the capped trypanosome spliced leader RNA to yeast Xrn1, but only if an RNA 5’ polyphosphatase is included. This indicates that the decapping mechanism of TbALPH1 differs from the decapping mechanism of Dcp2 by leaving more than one phosphate group at the mRNA’s 5’ end. This is the first reported function of a eukaryotic ApaH-like phosphatase, a bacterial-derived class of enzymes present in all phylogenetic super-groups of the eukaryotic kingdom.
The inactivation of the Arx gene in pancreatic α-cells is sufficient to trigger their neogenesis and conversion into functional β-like cells at any age. Using a combination of conditional loss-of-function and lineage tracing approaches, we show that the selective inhibition of Arx in α-cells is sufficient to promote the conversion of adult α-cells into β-like cells. Interestingly, this conversion induces the continuous mobilization of duct-lining precursor cells to adopt an endocrine cell fate, the glucagon+ cells thereby generated being subsequently converted into β-like cells upon Arx inhibition. Importantly, the loss of Arx in α-cells is sufficient to regenerate a functional β-cell mass and thereby reverse diabetes following toxin-induced β-cell depletion. Our data therefore suggest that strategies aiming at inhibiting the expression of Arx, or its molecular targets/co-factors, may pave new avenues for the treatment of diabetes.
Replication origins in eukaryotic cells must be tightly regulated to prevent re-initiation, which can lead to genomic alterations. It has been assumed that all origins are inhibited identically by global mechanisms that reduce the activity of replication initiation proteins. However, we have found that origins re-initiate with diverse efficiencies when these mechanisms are disabled, suggesting an additional layer of control that can differentially regulate re-initiation at distinct origins. We have identified novel genetic elements that are necessary for preferential re-initiation of two origins and sufficient to confer preferential re-initiation on heterologous origins when the control of re-initiation is partially deregulated. These elements, which we term re-initiation promoters ( RIPs ), map to ∼60 bp AT rich sequences that act in a distance- and sequence-dependent manner. The RIPs do not enhance the S phase timing or efficiency of adjacent origins and thus are specifically acting as re-initiation promoters. Our findings suggest that the RIP elements can overcome a block to re-initiation imposed after Mcm2-7 associates with origins. This local level of control creates a complex genomic landscape of re-replication potential that is revealed when global mechanisms preventing re-replication are compromised.
Invasive amebiasis ( IA ) caused by Entamoeba histolytica is an emerging problem in developed East Asian countries, particularly among men who have sex with men ( MSM ) co-infected with HIV-1. A retrospective analysis of the medical records of 170 HIV-1-infected patients with IA was conducted to characterize the clinical and epidemiological features of the disease in this population. The results showed that the clinical presentation of IA in HIV-1-infected patients was similar to that in the general population, with high fever, leukocytosis, and high C-reactive protein ( CRP ) levels associated with extraluminal amebic diseases. The outcome of treatment with metronidazole or tinidazole was excellent for uncomplicated amebiasis in HIV-1-infected individuals. However, luminal treatment following metronidazole or tinidazole treatment did not reduce the recurrence of amebiasis in high-risk populations. Recurrence was more frequent in patients who were HCV-antibody positive and those who acquired syphilis during the follow-up period. Various genotypes of E. histolytica were identified in 14 patients, but there was no correlation between genotype and clinical features. The results emphasize the difficulty of preventing IA recurrence without an educational approach to prevent new amebic infection in high-risk groups such as HIV-1-infected MSM.
Sleeping sickness, also known as human African trypanosomiasis ( HAT ), is a neglected tropical disease caused by the parasite Trypanosoma brucei gambiense transmitted by tsetse flies. In Chad, the Mandoul area is a persistent focus of HAT where around 100 cases were diagnosed and treated annually until 2013. We assessed whether adding tsetse control to case detection and treatment could further reduce transmission and incidence of HAT in Mandoul. We deployed ‘tiny targets’ that attract and kill tsetse in the riverine habitats of tsetse in 2014, 2015, and 2016. We conducted nine tsetse monitoring surveys and four medical surveys of the human population in 2014 and 2015, and used mathematical modelling to assess the relative impact of tsetse control on incidence compared to active and passive screening. Our results show that tsetse control reduced the catch of tsetse from 0. 7 flies/trap/day to 0. 005 tsetse/trap/day. Modelling indicates that 70. 4% ( 95% CI: 51–95% ) of the reduction in reported cases between 2013 and 2015 can be attributed to vector control, and 62. 8% ( 95% CI: 59–66% ) of the reduction in new infections can be attributed to tsetse control. Our results suggest that tsetse control may have interrupted transmission and that the combination of tsetse control and medical detection and treatment has played a major role in reducing HAT incidence in 2014 and 2015.
Imported strongyloidiasis is increasingly diagnosed in non-endemic areas, including Spain. This study describes the epidemiological, clinical and microbiological characteristics of 1245 patients with imported strongyloidiasis registered in the +REDIVI Spanish Collaborative Network from 2009 to 2017. The majority of patients were immigrants ( 66. 9% ) from South America, and most were asymptomatic. Eosinophilia was present in 82. 2% of cases, and detection of larvae in stool samples was observed in 21. 9% of patients. Serological tests were used to make the diagnosis in the remaining cases. Treatment with ivermectin was associated with a higher cure rate compared to albendazole ( OR 2. 34 ). The study highlights the importance of screening for S. stercoralis infection in patients coming from or traveling to endemic areas, especially those with immunosuppressant conditions, due to the long latency of the infection and the risk of developing a severe presentation.
Vaccination is an effective method to protect against infectious diseases, and determining the optimal amount of antigen or live attenuated pathogen ( inoculum dose ) is an important component of rational vaccine design. A combination of mathematical models with experimental data can help determine the impact of the inoculum dose on host immunity and morbidity. We illustrate the concept of using data and models to inform inoculum dose determination for vaccines by fitting a mathematical model to data from influenza A virus ( IAV ) infection of mice and human parainfluenza virus ( HPIV ) infection of cotton rats at different inoculum doses. We use the model to map inoculum dose to the level of immune protection and morbidity and to explore how such a framework might be used to determine an optimal inoculum dose. Our findings illustrate that the impact of inoculum dose on immune protection and morbidity can depend on the specific pathogen and that both protection and morbidity do not necessarily increase monotonically with increasing inoculum dose. We develop a modeling framework that might allow a systematic and quantitative determination of the impact of different inoculum doses on resulting immune protection and morbidity. We applied this approach to several data sets to illustrate how the general concept can lead to important insights, e. g. ‘more inoculum does not always lead to more immune protection’.
Anabaena filaments undergo a process of development in response to nitrogen deprivation, resulting in a one-dimensional pattern of nitrogen-fixing heterocysts separated by photosynthetic vegetative cells. The expression of hetR, a transcription factor essential for heterocyst differentiation, has been studied using a chromosomally-encoded translational hetR-gfp fusion. Statistical analysis of fluorescence at the individual cell level in wild-type and mutant filaments demonstrates that expression fluctuations of hetR in nearby cells are coupled, with a characteristic spatial range of circa two to three cells. This sets the scale for cellular interactions along a filament. Correlations between cells predominantly arise from intercellular molecular transfer and less from cell division. We found that under nitrogen-rich conditions, basal, steady-state expression of the HetR inhibitor PatS, cell-cell communication influenced by the septal protein SepJ and positive HetR auto-regulation are essential determinants of fluctuations in hetR expression and its distribution along filaments.
Japanese encephalitis virus ( JEV ) genotype I ( GI ) has replaced genotype III ( GIII ) in China as demonstrated by molecular epidemiological surveillance. We performed a serological survey in JEV-non-vaccinated pigs to confirm JEV genotype shift at the sero-epidemiological level. The average ratio of GI/GIII infection was 1. 87, suggesting co-circulation of GI and GIII infections with GI infection being more prevalent in pigs in China. To gain an insight into the reasons for this JEV genotype shift, we compared the replication kinetics of seven recently-isolated JEV isolates including three GI strains and four GIII strains in mosquito C6/36 cells, chicken fibroblast cells ( DF-1 ) and porcine iliac artery endothelial cells ( PIEC ). We observed that GI strains replicated more efficiently than GIII strains in DF-1 and PIEC cells, particularly in DF-1 cells with titers reaching 22. 9–225. 3 fold higher than GIII strains. To examine this enhanced replication efficiency in vivo, young domestic ducklings were used as the animal model and inoculated with GI and GIII strains at day 2 post-hatching. We observed that GI-inoculated ducklings developed higher viremia titers and displayed a comparatively longer viremic duration than GIII-inoculated ducklings. These results conform to the hypothesis of an enhanced replication efficiency for GI viruses in birds.
Candida albicans biofilm formation is regulated by an integrated network of six transcription factors: Bcr1, Brg1, Efg1, Ndt80, Rob1, and Tec1. To understand how these transcription factors function together to regulate biofilm formation, we used a systematic genetic interaction approach based on generating all possible double heterozygous mutants of the network genes and quantitatively analyzing the genetic interactions between them. We found that the network is highly susceptible to genetic perturbation, with all six network heterozygous mutants showing alterations in biofilm formation ( haploinsufficiency ). In addition, many double heterozygous mutants are as severely affected as homozygous deletions. The network shows properties of a highly interdependent ‘small-world’ network that is highly efficient but not robust. We found that TEC1 represents a network component whose expression is highly sensitive to small perturbations in the function of other network transcription factors. We also found that expression of ROB1 is dependent on both auto-regulation and cooperative interactions with other network transcription factors. Finally, we found that the heterozygous NDT80 deletion mutant is hyperfilamentous under both biofilm and hyphae-inducing conditions in a TEC1-dependent manner.
Leishmania infantum asparagine synthetase A ( LiAS-A ) is an enzyme responsible for converting aspartate into asparagine in an ATP-dependent manner, using ammonia or glutamine as a nitrogen source. Although LiAS-A is absent in humans and present in trypanosomatids, making it a potential drug target candidate, we demonstrate that it is not essential for parasite survival, growth, or infectivity in normal in vitro and in vivo conditions. We generated LiAS-A null mutants by targeted gene replacement in L. infantum and observed no significant growth or infectivity defect. However, a severe impairment of in vitro growth was observed when null mutants were cultured in asparagine limiting conditions. This suggests that LiAS-A is important under asparagine limitation, but not essential for parasite survival or infectivity in normal conditions. Our results exclude LiAS-A as a suitable drug target against L. infantum parasites.
Toxocariasis, a parasitic infection caused by Toxocara spp., is associated with epilepsy, according to a systematic review and meta-analysis of 11 case-control studies conducted in 13 countries worldwide. The studies included a total of 4740 subjects, of whom 2159 had epilepsy and 2581 did not. The overall pooled odds ratio ( OR ) for the association between epilepsy and Toxocara spp. seropositivity was 1. 69 ( 95% CI 1. 42–2. 01 ), indicating a positive association between the two conditions. Meta-regression showed no statistically significant association between covariates and outcome. The association was consistently reported in the restricted analysis, which included studies that used Western Blot as a confirmatory or diagnostic test, were conducted in younger populations, and were population-based. The results of the meta-analysis provide epidemiological evidence of a positive association between Toxocara seropositivity and epilepsy.
ATM plays a critical role in the cellular response to DNA double-strand breaks ( DSBs ). Here, we describe a novel ATM-mediated DNA damage response pathway involving microRNA ( miRNA ) : irradiation ( IR ) -induced DSBs activate ATM, which leads to the downregulation of miR-335, a miRNA that targets CtIP. CtIP is an important trigger of DNA end resection in homologous recombination repair ( HRR ). We demonstrate that CREB is responsible for a large portion of miR-335 expression by binding to the promoter region of miR-335. CREB binding is greatly reduced after IR, corroborating with previous studies that IR-activated ATM phosphorylates CREB to reduce its transcription activity. Overexpression of miR-335 in HeLa cells resulted in reduced CtIP levels and post-IR colony survival and BRCA1 foci formation. In two patient-derived lymphoblastoid cell lines with decreased post-IR colony survival, a “radiosensitive” phenotype, we demonstrated elevated miR-335 expression, reduced CtIP levels, and reduced BRCA1 foci formation. Colony survival, BRCA1 foci, and CtIP levels were partially rescued by miRNA antisense AMO-miR-335 treatment. These findings suggest that an ATM–dependent CREB–miR-335–CtIP axis influences the selection of HRR for repair of certain DSB lesions.
Mentalizing, the process of attributing mental states such as beliefs and emotions to others, plays a crucial role in human social interactions. In this study, we investigated whether mentalizing affects learning in the context of repeated social interactions. We asked participants to play repeated games against artificial mentalizing agents, which differed in their sophistication, in either a social or non-social framing. In the social framing, participants believed they were playing against another person, while in the non-social framing, they believed they were gambling like in a casino. We found that participants won against the artificial mentalizing agents in the social framing, but lost in the non-social framing. Moreover, participants' choice sequences were best explained by sophisticated mentalizing Bayesian learning models only in the social framing. This study is the first demonstration of the added-value of mentalizing on learning in the context of repeated social interactions.
Gaussian graphical model ( GGM ) is a probability model that characterizes the conditional dependence structure of a set of random variables by a graph. GGM has wide applications in the analysis of biological networks, such as inferring interaction or comparing differential networks. However, existing approaches are either not statistically rigorous or are inefficient for high-dimensional data that include tens of thousands of variables for making inference. We propose an efficient algorithm, FastGGM, to implement the estimation of GGM and obtain p-value and confidence interval for each edge in the graph. FastGGM is based on a recent proposal by Ren et al. ( 2015 ) and has been implemented in an R package named “FastGGM”. Through simulation studies, we demonstrate that FastGGM is faster by several orders of magnitude than the current implemented algorithm for Ren et al. without losing any accuracy. We apply FastGGM to two real data sets: transcriptomic data from a study of childhood asthma and proteomic data from a study of Alzheimer’s disease. We estimate the global gene or protein interaction networks for the disease and healthy samples. The resulting networks reveal interesting interactions and the differential networks between cases and controls show functional relevance to the diseases. FastGGM provides a computationally fast algorithm to implement a statistically sound procedure for constructing GGM and making inference with high-dimensional biological data.
Striatal medium spiny neurons ( MSNs ) form cell assemblies whose population firing rates vary coherently on slow behaviourally relevant timescales. We investigate how MSN network generated population activity interacts with temporally varying cortical driving activity, as would occur in a behavioural task. We find that at unrealistically high connectivity a stable winners-take-all type regime is found where network activity separates into fixed stimulus dependent regularly firing and quiescent components. In this regime only a small number of population firing rate components interact with cortical stimulus variations. Around connectivity a transition to a more dynamically active regime occurs where all cells constantly switch between activity and quiescence. In this low connectivity regime, MSN population components wander randomly and here too are independent of variations in cortical driving. Only in the transition regime do weak changes in cortical driving interact with many population components so that sequential cell assemblies are reproducibly activated for many hundreds of milliseconds after stimulus onset and peri-stimulus time histograms display strong stimulus and temporal specificity. We show that this activity is maximized at striatally realistic connectivities and IPSP sizes.
Polarized exocytosis and endocytosis are two transport pathways that work together to maintain polarized growth in cells. Polarized exocytosis transports membrane components to specific locations on the cell cortex, while endocytosis retrieves these components before they can diffuse away. We show that the yeast Rab GTPase Sec4p couples polarized exocytosis with cortical actin polymerization, which induces endocytosis. After polarized exocytosis to the plasma membrane, Sec4p binds Las17/Bee1p ( yeast Wiskott—Aldrich Syndrome protein [WASp] ) in a complex with Sla1p and Sla2p during actin patch assembly. Mutations that inactivate Sec4p, or its guanine nucleotide exchange factor ( GEF ) Sec2p, inhibit actin patch formation, whereas the activating sec4-Q79L mutation accelerates patch assembly. In vitro assays of Arp2/3-dependent actin polymerization established that GTPγS-Sec4p overrides Sla1p inhibition of Las17p-dependent actin nucleation. These results support a model in which Sec4p relocates along the plasma membrane from polarized sites of exocytic vesicle fusion to nascent sites of endocytosis. Activated Sec4p then promotes actin polymerization and triggers compensatory endocytosis, which controls surface expansion and kinetically refines cell polarization.
Acetaminophen ( APAP ) -induced liver injury ( AILI ) in mice is a widely used model for drug-induced liver injury in humans. The prevailing mechanistic explanation for early perivenous necrosis assumes that zonation of NAPQI formation, the reactive metabolite of APAP, is a necessary and sufficient prerequisite to explain this phenomenon. However, this hypothesis remains unchallenged in mice because it is infeasible to control influential variables and obtain sequential intracellular measurements at different lobular locations within the same mouse. To challenge this hypothesis, we employed virtual hepatocytes that use independently configured periportal-to-central vein ( CV ) gradients to exhibit lobule-location dependent behaviors. We posited that at least one additional feature must exhibit zonation by decreasing in the CV direction in order to achieve the Target Phenomenon, which is that necrosis begins adjacent to the CV and progresses outward. We instantiated and explored two alternative features: a glutathione depletion threshold that diminishes in the CV direction, and the ability to repair mitochondrial damage that diminishes in the CV direction. However, inclusion of one or the other feature failed to achieve the Target Phenomenon, but inclusion of both features enabled successful achievement of the Target Phenomenon. The merged mechanism provides a multilevel, multiscale causal explanation of key temporal features of APAP hepatotoxicity in mice.
Congenitally infected children with Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite responsible for Chagas disease, can be difficult to diagnose immediately after birth. The current gold standard for diagnosis is the INP micromethod, which detects parasites in blood samples by microscopy. However, this method is not sensitive enough to detect low levels of parasitemia. In this study, we investigated the relationship between the INP micromethod and quantitative DNA amplification in congenitally infected children. We analyzed blood samples from 51 children born to T. cruzi-infected mothers at three different time points: 1 month, 6 months, and 1 year after birth. We found that only infants with very high parasitemia levels could be diagnosed by parasitology screening at 1 month of age. Infants that required a second parasitological diagnosis at 6 months of age had lower parasitemia levels, and those diagnosed by serology at around 1 year of age had the lowest parasitemia levels of all. Our results show that the parasite burden in some children is below the detection limit of the INP micromethod. We also found that the current trypanocidal treatment is very effective in curing T. cruzi-infected children. Our study highlights the need for more sensitive parasitological methods to improve the early diagnosis of congenitally infected newborns and allow for prompt and effective treatment.
We propose a biophysical model of Escherichia coli that predicts growth rate and effective cellular composition from an effective, coarse-grained representation of its genome. The model assumes that E. coli is in a state of balanced exponential steady-state growth, growing in a temporally and spatially constant environment, rich in resources. We apply this model to a series of past measurements, where the growth rate and rRNA-to-protein ratio have been measured for seven E. coli strains with an rRNA operon copy number ranging from one to seven. These experiments show that growth rate markedly decreases for strains with fewer than six copies. Using the model, we were able to reproduce these measurements. The model suggests that the volume fraction of macromolecules inside E. coli is not fixed when the rRNA operon copy number is varied. Moreover, the model predicts that increasing the copy number beyond seven results in a cytoplasm densely packed with ribosomes and proteins. The model also predicts that growth rate will not increase substantially beyond the wild-type growth rate when the rRNA operon copy number is increased beyond seven. These predictions are consistent with other experiments and suggest that changing the rRNA operon copy number of wild-type E. coli cells growing in a constant rich environment does not substantially increase their growth rate.
RSM1, an Arabidopsis MYB protein, plays a role in seed germination and seedling development in response to abscisic acid ( ABA ) and salinity. We show that down-regulation or up-regulation of RSM1 expression alters the sensitivity of seed germination and cotyledon greening to ABA, NaCl and mannitol in Arabidopsis. The expression of RSM1 is dynamically regulated by ABA and NaCl. The transcription factors ELONGATED HYPOCOTYL 5 ( HY5 ) and HY5 HOMOLOG ( HYH ) regulate RSM1 expression via binding to the RSM1 promoter. Genetic analyses reveal that RSM1 mediates multiple functions of HY5 in responses of seed germination, post-germination development to ABA and abiotic stresses, and seedling tolerance to salinity. RSM1 interacts with HY5/HYH in vitro and in vivo. RSM1 and HY5/HYH may function as a regulatory module in responses to ABA and abiotic stresses. RSM1 binds to the promoter of ABA INSENSITIVE 5 ( ABI5 ), thereby regulating its expression, while RSM1 interaction also stimulates HY5 binding to the ABI5 promoter. RSM1 and HY5/HYH may converge on the ABI5 promoter and independently or dependently regulate ABI5 expression and ABI5-downstream ABA and abiotic stress-responsive genes.
Mitochondrial complex I is the largest and most complicated proton pump of the respiratory chain. It links the electron transfer from NADH to ubiquinone to the pumping of four protons from the matrix into the intermembrane space. Recent X-ray structural analysis of prokaryotic and eukaryotic complex I revealed that the redox reactions are confined to the hydrophilic peripheral arm of the L-shaped molecule and take place at a remarkable distance from the membrane domain. This implies that the proton pumping within the membrane arm of complex I is driven indirectly via long-range conformational coupling. However, the molecular mechanism and the number, identity, and localization of the pump-sites remain unclear. Here, we report that upon deletion of the gene for a small accessory subunit of the Yarrowia complex I, a stable subcomplex ( nb8mΔ ) is formed that lacks the distal part of the membrane domain. The analysis of the subunit composition of holo and subcomplex by three complementary proteomic approaches revealed that two of the three subunits with homology to bacterial Mrp-type Na+/H+ antiporters that have been discussed as prime candidates for harbouring the proton pumps were missing in nb8mΔ. Nevertheless, nb8mΔ still pumps protons at half the stoichiometry of the complete enzyme. Our results provide evidence that the membrane arm of complex I harbours two functionally distinct pump modules that are connected in series by the long helical transmission element recently identified by X-ray structural analysis.
Malaria and dengue fever are two infectious diseases that induce fever, a regulated increase in body temperature resulting from both infectious and non-infectious causes. Fever is known to play a role in modulating immune responses to infection, but the potential of febrile temperatures in regulating antigen binding affinity to antibodies has not been explored. Here, we investigated this process under in vitro conditions using Isothermal Titration Calorimetry and ELISA. We used selected malarial and dengue antigens against specific monoclonal antibodies, and observed a marked increase in the affinity of these antibody-antigen complexes at 40°C, compared to physiological ( 37°C ) or pathophysiological temperatures ( 42°C ). Induced thermal equilibration of the protein partners at these temperatures in vitro, prior to measurements, further increased their binding affinity. These results suggest another positive and adaptive role for fever in vivo, and highlight the favourable role of thermal priming in enhancing protein-protein affinity for samples with limited availability.
Actomyosin-based cortical flow is a fundamental engine for cellular morphogenesis. Cortical flows are generated by cross-linked networks of actin filaments and myosin motors, in which active stress produced by motor activity is opposed by passive resistance to network deformation. We study a computational model for a cross-linked network with active motors based on minimal requirements for production and dissipation of contractile stress: Asymmetric filament compliance, spatial heterogeneity of motor activity, reversible cross-links and filament turnover. Our analysis predicts that filament turnover is required to maintain active stress against external resistance and steady state flow in response to external stress. Steady state stress increases with filament lifetime up to a characteristic time τm, then decreases with lifetime above τm. Effective viscosity increases with filament lifetime up to a characteristic time τc, and then becomes independent of filament lifetime and sharply dependent on crosslink dynamics. These individual dependencies of active stress and effective viscosity define multiple regimes of steady state flow. In particular, our model predicts that when filament lifetimes are shorter than both τc and τm, the dependencies of effective viscosity and steady state stress on filament turnover cancel one another, such that flow speed is insensitive to filament turnover, and shows a simple dependence on motor activity and crosslink dynamics.
Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings are sensitive to high concentrations of glucose and fructose, which inhibit seedling growth and greening. A novel sugar-sensing quantitative trait locus ( QTL ), GSQ11, was identified in a Col X C24 F2 population using a selective genotyping approach. GSQ11 encodes the Arabidopsis NAC family transcription factor 060 ( ANAC060 ). The Col ANAC060 allele confers sugar insensitivity and is dominant over the sugar-sensitive C24 allele. A single-nucleotide polymorphism ( SNP ) in Col ANAC060 affects the splicing patterns of ANAC060, resulting in a truncated protein lacking the transmembrane domain ( TMD ) that is present in the C24 ANAC060 protein. The truncated ANAC060 protein is found in ∼12% of natural Arabidopsis accessions. GSQ11/ANAC060 expression is induced by glucose in a process that requires abscisic acid ( ABA ) signaling. Chromatin immunoprecipitation-qPCR and transient expression analysis showed that ABI4 directly binds to the GSQ11/ANAC060 promoter to activate transcription. Interestingly, Col ANAC060 reduced ABA sensitivity and Glc-induced ABA accumulation, and ABI4 expression was also reduced in Col ANAC060 lines. Thus, the sugar-ABA signaling cascade induces ANAC060 expression, but the truncated Col ANAC060 protein attenuates ABA induction and ABA signaling. This negative feedback from nuclear ANAC060 on ABA signaling results in sugar insensitivity.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilm formation and motility are controlled by the HptB regulatory cascade, which is intersected by the diguanylate cyclase HsbD. HsbD synthesizes cyclic di-GMP ( c-di-GMP ), a nucleotide second messenger that regulates a variety of eubacterial behaviors. We show that the HptB pathway controls biofilm formation and motility by involving both HsbD and the anti-anti-sigma factor HsbA. The rewiring of c-di-GMP signaling into the HptB cascade relies on the original interaction between HsbD and HsbA and on the control of HsbD dynamic localization at the cell poles. The acquisition of hsbD in P. aeruginosa and the genetic reorganization that brought together hsbD, hptB/hsbA/hsbR and additional flagellar and chemotactic genes to form a novel entity involved in the control of motility and biofilm reveals an interesting scenario on the possible evolution of c-di-GMP signaling. We show that HsbD and SadC, another diguanylate cyclase, act at distinct positions in the c-di-GMP network that controls P. aeruginosa behavior.
Visuomotor learning refers to the ability of humans to learn and store multiple visuomotor mappings, i. e., the relationship between visual information and motor responses. However, little is known about the associative learning between cue and required visuomotor mapping, and how learning generalises to novel but similar conditions. To investigate these questions, participants performed a rapid target-pointing task while we manipulated the offset between visual feedback and movement end-points. The visual feedback was presented with horizontal offsets of different amounts, dependent on the target shape. Participants thus needed to use different visuomotor mappings between target location and required motor response depending on the target shape in order to “hit” it. The target shapes were taken from a continuous set of shapes, morphed between spiky and circular shapes. After training, we tested participants’ performance, without feedback, on different target shapes that had not been learned previously. The results show that, although learning the associations requires explicit awareness of the cues’ role, participants apply the mapping corresponding to the trained shape that is most similar to the current one, consistent with a Bayesian learning model. Furthermore, the Bayesian learning model predicts that learning should slow down with increased numbers of training pairs, which was confirmed by the present results.
Climbing fibers are one of the two main inputs to the cerebellum and are generally believed to be related to the timing of motor commands and/or motor learning. Climbing fiber spikes lead to large all-or-none action potentials in cerebellar Purkinje cells, silencing these cells for a brief period of time afterwards. Empirical evidence shows that the climbing fiber can transmit a short burst of spikes as a result of an olivary cell somatic spike, potentially increasing the information being transferred to the cerebellum per climbing fiber activation. We used a detailed three-compartmental model of an inferior olivary cell to further investigate the possible factors determining the size of the climbing fiber burst. Our findings suggest that the phase-dependency of the burst size is present but limited and that charge flow between soma and dendrite is a major determinant of the climbing fiber burst. We also found that phenomena such as cell ensemble synchrony can have a big effect on the climbing fiber burst size through dendrodendritic gap-junctional coupling between olivary cells. Our model predicts that there may be a phase-dependency of climbing fiber burst size, but only in a limited range of sub-threshold oscillation ( STO ) amplitudes and in coupled cell ensembles of sufficient size.
Iron is an essential element for all known forms of life due to its redox properties; however, these same properties can also lead to toxicity through the production of reactive oxygen species. The liver plays a central role in maintaining safe levels of iron, and iron misregulation is implicated in many diseases. Despite recent advances in understanding the fate of iron in the body, a quantitative understanding of how its components interact to produce tight regulation remains elusive. Here, we present a mechanistic computational model of human liver iron metabolism that includes the core regulatory components. The model was constructed based on known mechanisms of regulation and their kinetic properties, and it was quantitatively validated by comparing its results with previously published physiological data. The model was able to reproduce multiple experimental findings, including a time course simulation following an oral dose of iron that recreated the dynamics and time scale of the systems response to iron challenge. We also created a disease state simulation of haemochromatosis by altering a single reaction parameter that mimics a human haemochromatosis gene ( HFE ) mutation. The simulation provides a quantitative understanding of the liver iron overload that arises in this disease. This model supports and supplements our understanding of the role of the liver as an iron sensor and provides a framework for further modelling, including simulations to identify valuable drug targets and design of experiments to improve further our knowledge of this system.
Nucleocytoplasmic transport ( NCT ) across the nuclear pore complex ( NPC ) plays a critical role in regulating transcription and protecting the genetic material of eukaryotic cells. The NPC is the exclusive gateway of material transport across the nuclear envelope, and its structure is highly conserved from yeast to vertebrates. However, the transport mechanism of NCT remains elusive. The interaction between karyopherins ( kaps ) and Phe-Gly ( FG ) repeat domains is central to the transport process. We have established a coarse-grained model of the NPC structure that mimics NCT, taking into account the polymeric nature of FG-repeats grafted on the elastic structure of the NPC and the kap-FG hydrophobic affinity. The model predicts that the first-passage time of a 15 nm cargo-complex is about 2. 6±0. 13 ms with an inverse Gaussian distribution. The cargo-complex is primarily attached to the channel wall where it interacts with the FG-layer as it passes through the central channel. The kap-FG hydrophobic interaction is highly dynamic and fast, ensuring efficient translocation through the NPC. The model also predicts that almost all eight hydrophobic binding spots on kap-β are occupied simultaneously during transport.
Determining the optimal infectious dose of a pathogen for nonhuman primate ( NHP ) models is a critical step in testing interventions designed to block infection by human pathogens such as HIV, tuberculosis, and malaria. In NHP models, it is desirable to use a limiting infectious dose as a challenge, which only infects a fraction of animals at each exposure. However, this requires careful titration of the infectious agent, as using a dose that is too high may lead to false negative results and using a dose that is too low may lead to insufficient infections within the time frame of the experiment. A 2-fold error in the challenge dose can significantly impact the power of an experiment. Here, we define a protocol for determining the dose of pathogen that infects 50% of the time ( AID50 ), which minimizes the number of animals and resources needed to define an infectious pathogen challenge dose in NHPs. On average, the protocol will enroll 15 animals, require 3 rounds, and result in an estimate of the AID50 within 40% of the true value. This protocol is generalizable to any pathogen and any animal model, but is most critical for NHP models where ethical considerations mandate minimization of animal use.
We report a new form of adaptation in a first-order auditory interneuron ( AN2 ) of crickets, characterized by a time constant of 1. 5 s for adaptation and recovery. The response of the AN2 neuron to amplitude-modulated sound stimuli shifts the stimulus–response curves toward higher stimulus intensities, resulting in reduced spike responses for low-intensity sounds. We tested how adaptation changes the input–response curve when presenting signals with two or three peaks in their amplitude distributions, for which selective coding and infomax predict conflicting changes. By means of Bayesian data analysis, we quantify the shifts of the measured response curves and find a slight reduction of their slopes. These decreases in slopes are smaller, and the absolute response thresholds are higher than those predicted by infomax. Most remarkably, adaptation actually reduces the amount of encoded information when considering the whole range of input signals. The response curve changes are also not consistent with the selective coding hypothesis, because the amount of information conveyed about the loudest part of the signal does not increase as predicted but remains nearly constant. Less information is transmitted about signals with lower intensity.
Prions are infectious proteins that cause neurodegenerative diseases such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans and Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy in cattle. Prions are composed of a misfolded form of the prion protein ( PrPSc ) that interacts with the normal form of the prion protein ( PrPC ). Previous studies have identified two polybasic domains in PrPC that bind PrPSc, suggesting that these domains serve as docking sites for PrPSc during prion propagation. In this study, we investigated the role of polybasic domains in the context of full-length PrPC. We used prion proteins lacking one or both polybasic domains expressed from Chinese hamster ovary ( CHO ) cells as substrates in serial protein misfolding cyclic amplification ( sPMCA ) reactions. We found that PrPSc molecules lacking the central polybasic domain ( ΔC ) were formed after ∼5 rounds of sPMCA. However, in contrast to wild-type prions, ΔC-PrPSc prions could bind to and induce quantitative conversion of all the polybasic domain mutant substrates into PrPSc molecules. Remarkably, ΔC-PrPSc and other polybasic domain PrPSc molecules displayed diminished or absent biological infectivity relative to wild-type PrPSc. These results suggest that the propagation of PrPSc molecules may not depend on a single stereotypic mechanism, but that normal PrPC/PrPSc interaction through polybasic domains may be required to generate prion infectivity.
In this study, we developed an inverse reinforcement learning ( IRL ) framework to identify an animal’s behavioral strategy from behavioral time-series data. We applied this framework to C. elegans thermotactic behavior and found that fed worms use both the absolute temperature and its temporal derivative to control their behavior. We identified two strategies used by fed worms: directed migration ( DM ) towards the cultivation temperature and isothermal migration ( IM ) along a constant temperature contour. In contrast, starved worms used only the absolute temperature to escape the cultivation temperature. We also found that the value function underlying the thermotactic behavior of fed worms represents the benefit of each state, namely, how much future rewards are expected starting from a given state. Our IRL approach is useful in identifying animal strategies from behavioral time-series data and could be applied to a wide range of behavioral studies, including decision-making in other organisms. We also investigated the neural basis underlying these strategies by applying our method to thermosensory neuron-deficient worms. Our results indicate that fed worms utilize sensory information of both the absolute temperature and its temporal derivative for their behavioral strategy, while starved worms use only the absolute temperature.
Chrysochromulina tobin, a member of the haptophyte order Prymnesiales, is the second haptophyte for which the nuclear genome has been sequenced. The nuclear genome of C. tobin is small ( 59 Mb ), compact ( ∼40% of the genome is protein coding ) and encodes approximately 16, 777 genes. Genes important to fatty acid synthesis, modification, and catabolism show distinct patterns of expression when monitored over the circadian photoperiod. The C. tobin genome harbors the first hybrid polyketide synthase/non-ribosomal peptide synthase gene complex reported for an algal species, and encodes potential anti-microbial peptides and proteins involved in multidrug and toxic compound extrusion. A new haptophyte xanthorhodopsin was also identified, together with two “red” RuBisCO activases that are shared across many algal lineages. The C. tobin genome provides new information on the evolutionary history, ecology, and economic importance of haptophytes.
Breast cancers that are triple-negative for the clinical markers ESR1, PGR, and HER2 typically belong to the Basal-like molecular subtype and are associated with defective Rb, p53, and Brca1 pathways. Our mouse genetic studies demonstrate that the combined inactivation of Rb and p53 pathways is sufficient to suppress the physiological cell death of mammary involution. Furthermore, concomitant inactivation of all three pathways in mammary epithelium has an additive effect on tumor latency and predisposes highly penetrant, metastatic adenocarcinomas. The tumors are poorly differentiated and have histologic features that are common among human Brca1-mutated tumors, including heterogeneous morphology, metaplasia, and necrosis. Gene expression analyses demonstrate that the tumors share attributes of both Basal-like and Claudin-low signatures, two molecular subtypes encompassed by the broader, triple-negative class defined by clinical markers. Our results show that concomitant inactivation of all three tumor suppressor pathways in mammary epithelium has an additive effect on tumor latency and predisposes highly penetrant, malignant carcinomas.
Aedes aegypti is the primary vector of dengue, the most important arboviral infection globally. Until an effective vaccine is licensed, Ae. aegypti control remains the principal tool in preventing and curtailing dengue transmission. Accurate predictions of Ae. aegypti populations are required to assess control methods and develop effective population reduction strategies. We expect that containers in an area of high development site density are more likely to be oviposition sites and to be more frequently used as oviposition sites than containers that are relatively isolated from other development sites. After accounting for individual container characteristics, containers more frequently used as oviposition sites are likely to produce adult mosquitoes consistently and at a higher rate. Pupal surveys were carried out from 2004 to 2007 in rural Kamphaeng Phet, Thailand. In total, 84, 840 samples of water holding containers were used to estimate model parameters. Regression modeling was used to assess the effect of larval development site density, access to piped water, and seasonal variation on container productivity. The number of suitable larval development sites and their density in the environment were the primary determinants of the distribution and abundance of Ae. aegypti pupae. The productivity of most container types increased significantly as habitat density increased. An ecological approach, accounting for development site density, is appropriate for predicting Ae. aegypti population levels and developing efficient vector control programs.
In the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans, the conserved Target of Rapamycin complex 2 ( TORC2 ) acts as a hub for communication of feeding state information from the gut to the brain, thereby contributing to modulation of neuronal function by internal state. We show that TORC2 acts in the intestine to regulate neuronal expression of the daf-7 TGF-β and daf-28 insulin-like peptide ( ILP ) genes, which together reflect bacterial-diet dependent feeding status and provide a mechanism for integration of food signals with external cues in the regulation of neuroendocrine gene expression. During development, pheromone, bacterial food, and temperature regulate expression of daf-7 and daf-28 in sensory neurons to promote a binary decision between reproductive growth and entry into the alternate dauer larval stage. In the adult, TORC2 similarly acts in the intestine to modulate food-regulated foraging behaviors via a PDF-2/PDFR-1 neuropeptide signaling-dependent pathway. We also demonstrate that genetic variation affects food-dependent larval and adult phenotypes, and identify quantitative trait loci ( QTL ) associated with these traits.
Embryonic stem ( ES ) cells are of fundamental interest for their ability to self-renew and differentiate into various cell types. Understanding the transcriptional regulation of pluripotent cells will greatly inform efforts aimed at directing differentiation of ES cells or reprogramming somatic cells. Here, we report the systematic identification of cis-regulatory sequences active in mouse and human ES cells. We first analyzed the transcriptional profiles of mouse ES cells and primordial germ cells and identified genes upregulated in pluripotent cells both in vitro and in vivo. These genes are enriched for roles in transcription, chromatin remodeling, cell cycle, and DNA repair. We developed a novel computational algorithm, CompMoby, which combines analyses of sequences both aligned and non-aligned between different genomes with a probabilistic segmentation model to systematically predict short DNA motifs that regulate gene expression. CompMoby was used to identify conserved overrepresented motifs in genes upregulated in pluripotent cells. We show that the motifs are preferentially active in undifferentiated mouse ES and embryonic germ cells in a sequence-specific manner, and that they can act as enhancers in the context of an endogenous promoter. Importantly, the activity of the motifs is conserved in human ES cells. We further show that the transcription factor NF-Y specifically binds to one of the motifs, is differentially expressed during ES cell differentiation, and is required for ES cell proliferation.
Vesicular stomatitis virus ( VSV ) is a non-segmented negative-strand RNA virus that requires a continuous supply of the nucleoprotein ( N ) in the form of a complex with the phosphoprotein ( P ) for replication. Here, we present the structural characterization of a soluble, heterodimeric complex between a variant of VSV N lacking its 21 N-terminal residues ( NΔ21 ) and a peptide of 60 amino acids ( P60 ) encompassing the molecular recognition element ( MoRE ) of P that binds RNA-free N ( N0 ). The complex crystallized in a decameric circular form and was solved at 3. 0 Å resolution, revealing how the MoRE folds upon binding to N and competes with RNA binding and N polymerization. Small-angle X-ray scattering experiments and NMR spectroscopy on the soluble complex confirm the binding of the MoRE and indicate that its flanking regions remain flexible in the complex. The structure of this complex also suggests a mechanism for the initiation of viral RNA synthesis.
In the fly visual system, the role of gap junctions ( GJs ) in the vertical system ( VS ) network, which plays a key role in visual processing, has been explored. Our information theoretical analysis of a realistic VS network model shows that within 10 ms following the onset of visual input, the presence of axonal GJs enables the VS system to efficiently encode the axis of rotation, θ, of the fly’s ego motion. This encoding efficiency, measured in bits, is near-optimal with respect to the physical limits of performance determined by the statistical structure of the visual input itself. We found that the VS 5-6-7 triplet, which is directly connected to downstream DNOVS1, 2 neurons, encodes motion more efficiently than the network as a whole, and reaches at least 90% of the physical limit of performance as determined by the statistical structure of the visual input itself. This near-optimal encoding efficiency emerged as robust regardless of the signal to noise ratios. We further demonstrate that this efficient encoding of motion by this subpopulation is necessary for the fly’s visually guided behavior, such as banked turns in evasive maneuvers. Because GJs are formed among the axons of the VS cells, they only impact the system’s readout, while maintaining the dendritic input intact, suggesting that the computational principles implemented by neural circuitries may be much richer than previously appreciated based on point neuron models.
Enterovirus 71 ( EV71 ) is one of the major causative agents of hand, foot, and mouth disease in children and has been associated with various neurological diseases including fatal cases in large EV71 outbreaks in the Asia Pacific region. Recently, PSGL-1 was identified as a cellular receptor for entry and replication of EV71 in leukocytes. PSGL-1 is a sialomucin expressed on the surface of leukocytes and serves as a high affinity counterreceptor for selectins. The PSGL-1–P-selectin interaction requires sulfation of at least one of three clustered tyrosines and an adjacent O-glycan expressing sialyl Lewis x in an N-terminal region of PSGL-1. To elucidate the molecular basis of the PSGL-1–EV71 interaction, we generated a series of PSGL-1 mutants and identified the post-translational modifications that are critical for binding of PSGL-1 to EV71. We expressed the PSGL-1 mutants in 293T cells and the transfected cells were assayed for their abilities to bind to EV71 by flow cytometry. We found that O-glycosylation on T57, which is critical for PSGL-1–selectin interaction, is not necessary for PSGL-1 binding to EV71. On the other hand, site-directed mutagenesis at one or more potential tyrosine sulfation sites in the N-terminal region of PSGL-1 significantly impaired PSGL-1 binding to EV71. Furthermore, an inhibitor of sulfation, sodium chlorate, blocked the PSGL-1–EV71 interaction and inhibited PSGL-1-mediated viral replication of EV71 in Jurkat T cells in a dose-dependent manner. Thus, the results presented in this study reveal that tyrosine sulfation, but not O-glycosylation, in the N-terminal region of PSGL-1 may facilitate virus entry and replication of EV71 in leukocytes.
Leishmaniasis is a serious global health problem that affects millions of people worldwide. Current treatments are limited by drug toxicity and the emergence of resistant strains. In this study, we investigated the therapeutic efficacy of mammalian target of rapamycin ( mTOR ) inhibitors in controlling infection with Leishmania major. We tested three mTOR inhibitors, namely rapamycin, GSK-2126458 and KU-0063794, in a mouse model of cutaneous leishmaniasis. Our results show that treatment with a clinically relevant dose of rapamycin or GSK-2126458, but not KU-0063794, dramatically lowered both footpad swelling and parasite load in the draining lymph node. Importantly, the employed dose of rapamycin did not kill the promastigotes in vitro. We also found that treatment with rapamycin significantly reduced IL-4 production by splenocytes and elevated the IFN-γ:IL-4 production ratio, suggesting a T helper-type 1 ( Th1 ) -skewed cytokine profile. Furthermore, the expression level of CD69, an early activation marker, on splenic and lymph node CD4+ and CD8+ T cells was enhanced in rapamycin-treated mice. Our findings suggest that select mTOR inhibitors may be used in therapeutic settings for the management of leishmaniasis. We propose that the beneficial effects of such inhibitors stem from their immunomodulatory properties, and that the adjuvanticity of mTOR inhibitors may also be considered in vaccination strategies against Leishmania species.
Natural transformation is a biological process by which competent bacteria take up free DNA, incorporate it into their genomes, and become genetically altered. To prevent deleterious transformation by foreign DNA, some bacteria preferentially take up their own DNA that contains a specific DNA uptake sequence ( DUS ). In Neisseria species, we recently identified ComP as the DUS receptor. Here, we report a functional analysis of the interdependence between DUS and ComP during natural transformation. We show that ComP is essential for transformation in the presence and absence of DUS, and that the inner bases of DUS are critical for recognition by ComP and hence transformation. We also show that naturally occurring DUS variants in human Neisseria commensals, differing from DUS by only one or two bases, are similarly impaired for transformation of N. meningitidis. Furthermore, we demonstrate that a ComP homolog from the N. subflava commensal specifically binds its cognate DUS variant and mediates DUS-enhanced transformation when expressed in a comP mutant of N. meningitidis. These findings shed new light on the molecular events involved in the earliest step of natural transformation and reveal an elegant mechanism for modulating horizontal gene transfer between competent species sharing the same niche.
Cytokinesis in fission yeast requires the coordinated closure of a contractile actomyosin ring ( CAR ) and the synthesis of a cell wall structure known as the division septum. Our study shows that cooperation between the paxillin homolog Pxl1 and the glucan synthase Bgs1 is required for stable anchorage of the CAR to the plasma membrane before septation onset and for cleavage furrow formation. Pxl1 is required for ring integrity, and Bgs1 is responsible for linear β ( 1, 3 ) glucan synthesis and primary septum formation. In cells lacking Pxl1, Bgs1 depletion causes failure of ring contraction and lateral cell wall overgrowth towards the cell lumen without septum formation. We also show that Pxl1 concentration at the CAR increases during cytokinesis and that this increase depends on the SH3 domain of the F-BAR protein Cdc15. The absence of Pxl1 is lethal when Cdc15 function is affected, generating a large sliding of the CAR with deposition of septum wall material along the cell cortex. Our findings indicate that CAR anchorage to the plasma membrane through Cdc15 and Pxl1, and concomitant Bgs1 activity, are necessary for CAR maintenance and septum formation in fission yeast.
Glanders is a highly infectious zoonotic disease caused by the gram-negative bacterium Burkholderia mallei. Although eradicated from many Western countries, it has recently emerged in Asia, the Middle East, Africa, and South America. We investigated a recent outbreak of glanders in Bahrain by applying high resolution genotyping and comparative whole genome sequencing to B. mallei isolated from infected horses and a camel. The results were compared to samples obtained from an outbreak in the United Arab Emirates in 2004, and further placed into a broader phylogeographic context based on previously published B. mallei data. The samples from the outbreak in Bahrain separated into two distinct clusters, suggesting a complex epidemiological background and evidence for the involvement of multiple B. mallei strains. The samples from Bahrain were more closely related to B. mallei isolated from horses in the United Arab Emirates in 2004 than other B. mallei, suggesting repeated importation to the region from similar geographic sources. The close relationship of the Dubai/UAE B. mallei populations to each other may be indicative of a similar geographic origin that has yet to be identified for the infecting strains. Our results provide evidence that the recent outbreak in Bahrain was caused by two different B. mallei strains, suggesting two independent introductions.
American cutaneous leishmaniasis ( ACL ) is a neglected tropical disease responsible for approximately 67, 000 new cases per year. In Colombia, the majority of ACL cases are caused by Leishmania ( Viannia ) ( L. V. ) subgenus parasites, which are more prone to treatment failure than those from the Leishmania ( Leishmania ) ( L. L. ) subgenus. Pentavalent antimonial derivatives, such as Glucantime or Sodium Stibogluconate, are recommended as first-line treatment for ACL caused by Leishmania braziliensis. However, the reasons for treatment failure are not well understood. A cross-sectional observational study was conducted to characterise the clinical and parasitological features of patients with ACL that did not respond to Glucantime treatment. The study included 43 patients recruited from three Colombian Army National reference centres for complicated ACL. The predominant infecting parasite species was L. braziliensis ( 95. 4% ), and 35% of the isolated parasites showed a significant decrease in in vitro Glucantime susceptibility associated with previous administration of the medicament. A negative correlation was found between lesion size and in vitro infectivity of the parasite ( Spearman: r = ( - ) 0, 548 and r = ( - ) 0, 726; respectively ). L. braziliensis was the main parasite species associated with treatment failure or relapse.
Siderophores and colibactin biosynthetic pathways in Escherichia coli are dependent on 4′-phosphopantetheinyl transferases ( PPTases ). Two PPTases, EntD and ClbA, have been identified, with EntD encoded in the core genome of E. coli and ClbA encoded on the pks pathogenicity island. The pks island is physically associated with the high pathogenicity island ( HPI ) in highly virulent E. coli strains. We investigated the potential interplay between siderophore and colibactin biosynthetic pathways through functional interchangeability between EntD and ClbA. We demonstrated that ClbA can contribute to siderophore synthesis and that inactivation of both entD and clbA abolished the virulence of extra-intestinal pathogenic E. coli ( ExPEC ) in a mouse sepsis model. The presence of either functional EntD or ClbA was required for the survival of ExPEC in vivo. This is the first report demonstrating a connection between multiple phosphopantetheinyl-requiring pathways leading to the biosynthesis of functionally distinct secondary metabolites in a given microorganism. We hypothesize that the association of the pks island with HPI has been selected in highly virulent E. coli because ClbA is a promiscuous PPTase that can contribute to the synthesis of both the genotoxin and siderophores.
Phylogenetic tree inference is a fundamental task in sequence analysis that involves calculating the probability of a multiple alignment given a phylogenetic tree relating the sequences and an evolutionary model describing how sequences change over time. However, the most widely used phylogenetic models only account for residue substitution events and do not account for insertion and deletion events. We describe a probabilistic model of a multiple sequence alignment that accounts for insertion and deletion events in addition to substitutions, given a phylogenetic tree, using a rate matrix augmented by the gap character.
