We construct a non-reversible generative ( birth–death ) evolutionary model for insertions and deletions, assuming that insertion and deletion events occur one residue at a time. We apply this model to phylogenetic tree inference by extending the program dnaml in phylip. Using standard benchmarking methods on simulated data and a new “concordance test” benchmark on real ribosomal RNA alignments, we show that the extended program dnamlε improves accuracy relative to the usual approach of ignoring gaps, while retaining the computational efficiency of the Felsenstein peeling algorithm.
Herpes Simplex Virus ( HSV ) initiates immunity in the human body by first infecting the mucosal epidermis and then entering nerve endings. In mice, epidermal Langerhans cells ( LCs ) are the first dendritic cells ( DCs ) to encounter HSV, but it is CD103+ dermal DCs that transport viral antigens to lymph nodes for antigen presentation. In this study, we compared HSV-1 infected human foreskin explants with biopsies of initial human genital herpes lesions to show that LCs are initially infected and then emigrate into the dermis. LCs bearing markers of maturation and apoptosis form large cell clusters with BDCA3+ dermal DCs and DC-SIGN+ DCs/macrophages. HSV-expressing LC fragments are observed inside the dermal DCs/macrophages and the BDCA3+ dermal DCs have up-regulated a damaged cell uptake receptor CLEC9A. Correspondingly, LCs isolated from human skin and infected with HSV-1 in vitro also undergo apoptosis and are taken up by similarly isolated BDCA3+ dermal DCs and DC-SIGN+ cells. Thus, we conclude that a viral antigen relay takes place where HSV infected LCs undergo apoptosis and are taken up by dermal DCs for subsequent antigen presentation.
Parasitophorous vacuoles ( PVs ) are membrane-bound organelles that house intracellular microorganisms, such as Leishmania amastigotes, within host macrophages. In this study, we investigated the biogenesis and remodeling of Leishmania PVs in primary mouse bone marrow-derived macrophages infected with either Leishmania major or L. amazonensis amastigotes. We used multidimensional imaging of live cells and the lysosomotropic fluorescent probe Lysotracker to compare and characterize PV biogenesis in macrophages hosting amastigotes of either L. major or L. amazonensis. We documented three dynamic features of Leishmania amastigote-hosting PVs: i ) entry of Lysotracker transients within tight-fitting, fission-prone L. major amastigote-housing PVs; ii ) the decrease in the number of macrophage acidic vesicles during the L. major PV fission or L. amazonensis PV enlargement; and iii ) the L. amazonensis PV remodeling after homotypic fusion. Our results show that L. major amastigotes are housed in tight-fitting PVs that undergo fission, while L. amazonensis amastigotes are housed in giant PVs that undergo homotypic fusion. We also found that approximately 50 acidic vesicles in macrophages infected with L. major or L. amazonensis are consumed in the course of intracellular infection, representing a hypothetical volume contribution of 30 µm3 to Leishmania PVs.
Chromatin structure plays a crucial role in regulating homologous recombination in vertebrate cells. Using the chicken B cell line DT40 as a model, we found that the immunoglobulin Vλ pseudogene array is characterized by histone modifications associated with active chromatin. We directly demonstrated the importance of chromatin structure for gene conversion by tethering the heterochromatin protein HP1 to the pseudo-Vλ donor array using a regulatable experimental system. Tethered HP1 diminished histone acetylation within the pseudo-Vλ array and altered the outcome of Vλ diversification, so that nontemplated mutations rather than templated mutations predominated. These results suggest that chromatin structure regulates homologous-directed repair and that histone modifications may contribute to maintaining genomic stability by preventing recombination between repetitive sequences.
Cerebellum-based motor learning is thought to be guided by the difference between the desired and the actual behavior, i. e., by error information. Climbing fibers, which connect with Purkinje cells in the cerebellum, are thought to transport information on instant errors needed for synaptic modification, but not to contribute to error memory. Here, we report work on monkeys tested in a saccadic learning paradigm that challenges this concept. We demonstrate not only a clear complex spikes ( CS ) signature of the error at the time of its occurrence, but also a reverberation of this signature much later, before a new manifestation of the behavior, suitable to improve it. This finding contrasts with the assumption that climbing fibers are confined to communicating instant errors. Our previous work on short-term saccadic adaptation observed patterns of CS that were at odds with this assumption. We therefore resorted to a random error saccadic adaptation paradigm, which avoids the gradual buildup of strong behavioral changes and the accompanying diminution of the error, potentially obscuring the electrophysiological fingerprint of the original error. We found statistically clear changes in the CS discharge rate, in particular the changes we found as a reflection of past errors in the CS discharge before the upcoming saccade.
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis ( ALS ) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease characterized by selective loss of motor neurons with inclusions frequently containing the RNA/DNA binding protein TDP-43. Using a yeast model of ALS, we show that TDP-43 overexpression dramatically alters cell shape and reduces ubiquitin dependent proteolysis of a reporter construct. Furthermore, we show that an excess of the Hsp40 chaperone, Sis1, reduces TDP-43’s effect on toxicity, cell shape and proteolysis. The strength of these effects is influenced by the presence of the endogenous yeast prion, [PIN+]. We also show that overexpression of the mammalian Sis1 homologue, DNAJB1, relieves TDP-43 mediated toxicity in primary rodent cortical neurons, suggesting that Sis1 and its homologues may have neuroprotective effects in ALS. TDP-43 aggregation is frequently associated with ALS and other neurological diseases, and overexpressed human TDP-43 is toxic and forms cytoplasmic aggregates in yeast and mammalian neurons. Our finding that TDP-43 aggregates inhibit clearance of a misfolded reporter protein by the ubiquitin proteasome system is consistent with the hypothesis that some of the TDP-43 associated toxicity is caused by proteolytic dysfunction.
Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite responsible for Chagas disease, is a major public health issue in many Latin American countries. In this study, we investigated the parasite load and molecular diversity of T. cruzi in patients with chronic Chagas disease from different regions of Brazil. We used a multilocus conventional PCR and quantitative real time PCR ( qPCR ) approaches to perform the molecular typing and parasite load quantification directly from blood specimens of 65 chronic Chagas disease patients. Of the 65 patients, 35 ( 53. 8% ) presented positive amplification by real time qPCR, being 20 ( 30. 7% ) with the clinical indeterminate form and 15 ( 23. 1% ) with the cardiac form of the disease. The parasite load median for all positive patients was 2. 54 [1. 43–11. 14] parasite equivalents/mL ( par. Eq. /mL ), with the load ranging from 0. 12 to 153. 66 par. Eq. /mL. Notably, the parasite load was significantly higher in patients over 70 years old ( median 20. 05 [18. 29–86. 86] par. Eq. /mL ). We were able to genotype the parasite up to 0. 5 par. Eq. /mL, with high specificity, and identified T. cruzi discrete typing units ( DTUs ) in 28 patients ( 80% ). The most prevalent DTUs were TcVI ( 40% ), TcII ( 17. 1% ), and mixed infection TcVI+TcII ( 14. 3% ).
Rabies virus ( RABV ) is considered enzootic in the New World, but few data are available for most countries in the region. As part of a larger pathogen detection program, enhanced bat rabies surveillance was conducted in Guatemala between 2009 and 2011. A total of 672 bats of 31 species were sampled and tested for RABV. The overall prevalence of RABV detection among all collected bats was low ( 0. 3% ). However, two common vampire bats ( Desmodus rotundus ) were found to be infected with RABV. Viral antigens were detected and infectious virus was isolated from the brains, oral swabs, lungs, and kidneys of both bats. Additionally, viral RNA was detected in all tissues examined by hemi-nested RT-PCR, except for the liver of one bat. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the two vampire bat RABV isolates were related to viruses associated with vampire bats in the eastern states of Mexico and El Salvador. Furthermore, 7% of sera collected from 398 bats demonstrated RABV neutralizing antibody. The proportion of seropositive bats varied significantly across trophic guilds, suggesting complex intraspecific compartmentalization of RABV perpetuation.
Herpes simplex virus ( HSV ) DNA initiates replication near the inner edge of the nucleus, and histones are excluded from these structures. The role of the nuclear lamina in HSV replication was examined in wild-type and A-type lamin–deficient ( Lmna−/− ) murine embryonic fibroblasts ( MEFs ). In Lmna−/− cells, viral replication compartments are reduced in size and fail to target to the nuclear periphery. Chromatin immunoprecipitation and immunofluorescence studies demonstrate that HSV DNA is associated with increased heterochromatin in Lmna−/− MEFs. These results argue for a functional role for A-type lamins as viral gene expression, DNA replication, and growth are reduced in Lmna−/− MEFs, with the greatest effect on viral replication at low multiplicity of infection. Thus, lamin A/C is required for targeting of the viral genome and the reduction of heterochromatin on viral promoters during lytic infection. The nuclear lamina can serve as a molecular scaffold for DNA genomes and the protein complexes that regulate both euchromatin and heterochromatin histone modifications.
Mitochondria originated from proteobacterial endosymbionts and their transition to organelles was tightly linked to the establishment of protein import pathways. The translocase of the outer membrane ( TOM ) is common to all forms of mitochondria, but an unexpected diversity of subunits between eukaryotic lineages has been predicted. Here, we characterise the TOM complex in hydrogenosomes, a metabolically specialised anaerobic form of mitochondria found in the excavate Trichomonas vaginalis. We demonstrate that the highly divergent β-barrel T. vaginalis TOM ( TvTom ) 40-2 forms a translocation channel to conduct hydrogenosomal protein import. TvTom40-2 is present in high molecular weight complexes, and their analysis revealed the presence of four tail-anchored ( TA ) proteins. Two of them, Tom36 and Tom46, with heat shock protein ( Hsp ) 20 and tetratricopeptide repeat ( TPR ) domains, can bind hydrogenosomal preproteins and most likely function as receptors. A third subunit, Tom22-like protein, has a short cis domain and a conserved Tom22 transmembrane segment but lacks a trans domain. The fourth protein, hydrogenosomal outer membrane protein 19 ( Homp19 ), has no known homology. Our results suggest that the triplet-pore TOM complex, composed of three conserved subunits, was present in the last common eukaryotic ancestor ( LECA ), while receptors responsible for substrate binding evolved independently in different eukaryotic lineages.
Autoimmune and inflammatory diseases are often associated with inappropriate activation or inadequate regulation of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. To better understand the genetic regulation of the immune system and its cellular phenotypes, we conducted a comparative eQTL analysis of CD4+ versus CD8+ T cells. We identified cell type-specific regulation of transcript levels of genes associated with several autoimmune diseases, including a trans-acting regulatory locus at chr12q13. 2 containing the rs1131017 SNP in the RPS26 gene. We also identified a common missense variant in IL27, associated with type 1 diabetes, that results in decreased functional activity of the protein and reduced expression levels of downstream IRF1 and STAT1 in CD4+ T cells only. Our results indicate that eQTL mapping in purified T cells provides novel functional insights into polymorphisms and pathways associated with autoimmune diseases. Furthermore, we show that the rs181206[G] variant of the IL27 gene confers protection against T1D through the inhibited expression of IRF1 and STAT1 in CD4+ T cells. Our results also suggest that IL-27 may promote autoimmunity toward pancreatic islets via the upregulation of the STAT1 pathway.
Sleeping sickness, also known as Human African Trypanosomiasis ( HAT ), is a major public health problem in the Democratic Republic of Congo ( DRC ). Despite efforts to control the disease, many people in the DRC do not participate in screening campaigns or adhere to treatment regimens. A qualitative study was conducted in the provinces of Bandundu and Kasaï Oriental, where HAT prevalence is high, to explore the reasons for this lack of participation. The study included interviews and focus group discussions with current and former HAT patients, healthcare providers, and program managers of the national HAT control program. The results show that community members and healthcare providers believe that certain prohibitions must be respected for six months after HAT treatment, including no work, no sexual intercourse, no hot food, and no walking in the sun. These prohibitions are believed to prevent serious and sometimes deadly complications, but they are not evidence-based and were originally intended to mitigate the adverse effects of the melarsoprol treatment regimen, which is no longer recommended by the World Health Organization ( WHO ). The study highlights the need for an improved understanding of these prohibitions and their impact on HAT control efforts in the DRC.
Visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) represents a significant health burden in eastern Gedaref State, Sudan. Between May 5th and June 17th, 2011, an exhaustive door-to-door survey was conducted in 45 villages of Al-Gureisha locality to estimate the VL incidence. The survey covered 94, 369 inhabitants in 17, 702 households. The crude mortality rate over the mean recall period of 409 days was 0. 13/10, 000 people per day. VL was a possible or probable cause for 19% of all deaths. The VL-specific mortality rate was estimated at 0. 9/1000 per year. The overall incidence of VL over the past year was 7. 0/1000 persons per year, or 7. 9/1000 per year when deaths possibly or probably due to VL were included. Overall, 12. 5% ( 11, 943/95, 609 ) of the population reported a past VL treatment episode. Active VL case detection had a very low yield in this specific setting with adequate access to care and may not be the priority intervention to enhance control in similar contexts.
Negative supercoiling in bacterial DNA is generated by the gyrase enzyme, which is composed of GyrA and GyrB proteins. The average supercoil density of large bacterial chromosomes and small plasmid DNA is influenced by mutations in gyrase and two other topoisomerases. The supercoil density of prokaryotic DNA occurs in two forms: diffusible supercoil density ( σD ) and constrained supercoil density ( σC ). Diffusible and constrained supercoils contribute roughly equally to the total in vivo negative supercoil density of wild-type cells. Unexpectedly, Escherichia coli chromosomes have a 15% higher level of σ compared to Salmonella enterica. We analyzed strains of Salmonella using a 9 kb “supercoil sensor” inserted at ten positions around the genome. The sensor contains a complete Lac operon flanked by directly repeated resolvase binding sites, and the sensor can monitor both supercoil density and transcription elongation rates in wild-type and mutant strains. We found that RNA transcription causes ( − ) supercoiling to increase upstream and decrease downstream of highly expressed genes. Excess upstream supercoiling was relaxed by Topo I, and gyrase replenished downstream supercoil losses to maintain an equilibrium state. Strains with TS gyrase mutations growing at permissive temperature exhibited significant supercoil losses varying from 30% of wild-type levels to a total loss of σD at most chromosome locations.
Leishmania amazonensis is an intracellular protozoan parasite that replicates in parasitophorous vacuoles ( PVs ) that share features with late endosomes/lysosomes. We show that host cells infected with L. amazonensis upregulate transcription of LYST/Beige, a gene previously implicated in regulating lysosome size. LYST/Beige functions as a host innate response to limit parasite growth by reducing PV volume and inhibiting intracellular survival. Mutations in LYST/Beige caused further PV expansion and enhanced L. amazonensis replication. In contrast, LYST/Beige overexpression led to small PVs that did not sustain parasite growth. Treatment of LYST/Beige over-expressing cells with vacuolin-1 reversed this phenotype, expanding PVs and promoting parasite growth. Enlarged PVs appear to protect parasites from oxidative damage, since inhibition of nitric oxide synthase had no effect on L. amazonensis viability within large PVs, but enhanced their growth within LYST/Beige-induced small PVs. Collectively, our findings provide direct experimental evidence for the idea that increased expression of LYST/Beige functions as a host innate response to restrict Leishmania growth by counteracting PV expansion.
Psychomotor retardation, characterized by motor and cognitive impairment, is a complex and poorly understood disorder. The Allan-Herndon-Dudley syndrome ( AHDS ) is an X-linked form of psychomotor retardation associated with mutations in the monocarboxylate transporter 8 ( mct8/slc16a2 ) gene, a thyroid hormone ( TH ) transporter. Previous studies using MCT8 knockout mice failed to replicate the neurological and behavioral symptoms of AHDS patients. Here, we generated an mct8 mutant ( mct8−/− ) zebrafish model using zinc-finger nuclease ( ZFN ) -mediated targeted gene editing. Similar to AHDS patients, mct8−/− larvae exhibited neurological and behavioral deficiencies, including reduced locomotor activity, altered response to external light and dark transitions, and increased sleep time. These deficiencies were associated with altered expression of myelin-related genes and neuron-specific deficiencies in circuit formation. Time-lapse imaging of single-axon arbors and synapses in live mct8−/− larvae revealed a reduction in filopodia dynamics and axon branching in sensory neurons and decreased synaptic density in motor neurons. Importantly, administration of TH analogs that can enter the cells in the absence of MCT8 restored the myelin and axon outgrowth deficiencies in mct8−/− larvae. These findings suggest a mechanism by which MCT8 regulates neural circuit assembly, ultimately mediating sensory and motor control of behavioral performance.
Human cytomegalovirus ( HCMV ) is a major pathogen in newborns and immunocompromised or immunosuppressed patients. Here, we demonstrate that HCMV gB and gH/gL form a stable complex early after their synthesis and in the absence of other viral proteins. This complex includes as much as 16–50% of the total gH/gL in HCMV virus particles. In contrast, only small amounts of gH/gL/gO and gH/gL/UL128-131 complexes were found associated with gB. These results have major implications for models describing herpesvirus entry, which suggest that gH/gL interacts with gB to mediate membrane fusion. Our results demonstrate that HCMV gB and gH/gL form stable gB-gH/gL complexes that are incorporated into virions without receptor binding or membrane fusion. Moreover, our data is the best support to date for the proposal that gH/gL interacts with gB. We also found that HCMV gB-gH/gL complexes are present in extracellular virions, suggesting that these complexes form before gB is activated for fusion and entry.
Mitochondrial DNA ( mtDNA ) sequence variants are known to segregate in a mutation and tissue-specific manner, but the underlying mechanisms remain unknown. In this study, we demonstrate that Gimap3, an outer mitochondrial membrane GTPase, is a critical regulator of mtDNA segregation in leukocytes. Using a heteroplasmic mouse model, we show that Gimap3 genetically regulates the rate of mtDNA segregation in hematopoietic tissues. We also demonstrate that segregation of mtDNA haplotypes in mouse hematopoietic tissues is a complex genetic trait regulated with age but independent of mtDNA copy number. Gimap3 is important for T cell development and survival, suggesting that leukocyte survival may be a key factor in the genetic regulation of mtDNA sequence variants and in modulating human mitochondrial diseases.
Buruli ulcer ( BU ) is a skin and soft-tissue infection caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans, a toxin-producing environmental pathogen. In Victoria, Australia, we estimated the incubation period ( IP ) of BU to be between 4 and 5 months. This estimate is based on a retrospective review of 443 cases of BU notified in Victoria between 2013 and 2016, as well as data from an earlier study incorporating cases from 2002 to 2012. We found that the mean incubation period was 143 days ( 4. 8 months ) among 20 new cases identified in short-term visitors to endemic regions, which is very similar to the previous estimate of 135 days ( 4. 5 months ). We found no association between incubation period and age, sex, location of exposure, duration of exposure to an endemic region, or location of BU lesion. Our study confirms the mean incubation period of BU in Victoria to be between 4 and 5 months. This knowledge can guide clinicians and suggests that the mode of transmission of BU is similar in different geographic regions in Victoria.
Toxoplasma gondii, an intracellular parasite, contains a protein with a sterol-sensing domain ( SSD ) that is a close relative of the human Niemann-Pick, type C1-related protein ( NPC1 ). This protein, named TgNCR1, is predicted to play a role in lipid homeostasis in the parasite. TgNCR1 lacks endosomal targeting signals and localizes to flattened vesicles beneath the plasma membrane of Toxoplasma. When expressed in mammalian NPC1 mutant cells and targeted to endo-lysosomes, TgNCR1 restores cholesterol and GM1 clearance from these organelles. This suggests that TgNCR1 functions in a similar way as human NPC1 to promote the movement of sterols and sphingolipids across the membranes of endo-lysosomes. To investigate the role of TgNCR1 in Toxoplasma, we generated a parasite cell line lacking NPC1 that is viable. The mutant parasites exhibit perturbations in their lipid content, including an overaccumulation of several species of cholesteryl esters, sphingomyelins, and ceramides. These mutants are also characterized by abundant storage lipid bodies and long membranous tubules derived from their parasitophorous vacuoles. Interestingly, these mutants can generate multiple daughters per single mother cell at high frequencies, allowing fast replication in vitro, and are slightly more virulent in mice than the parental strain.
Ophthalmo-acromelic syndrome ( OAS ), also known as Waardenburg anophthalmia syndrome, is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the combination of eye malformations, most commonly bilateral anophthalmia, with post-axial oligosyndactyly. Mutations in the SMOC1 gene have been identified as the major cause of OAS in eight unrelated families. The SMOC1 gene encodes a protein that functions as a Bone Morphogenic Protein ( BMP ) antagonist in early embryogenesis. Loss of BMP antagonism during mammalian development provides a plausible explanation for both the limb and eye phenotype in humans and mice. A targeted pre-conditional gene-trap mutation of the orthologous mouse gene, Smoc1, results in highly penetrant hindlimb post-axial oligosyndactyly in homozygous mutant animals. Eye malformations, most commonly coloboma, and cleft palate occur in a significant proportion of Smoc1tm1a/tm1a embryos and pups. The mouse phenotype shows significant overlap with the human disease. The SMOC1 gene is one of the two mammalian paralogs of Drosophila Pentagone, an inhibitor of decapentaplegic. The orthologous gene in Xenopus laevis, Smoc-1, also functions as a BMP antagonist in early embryogenesis.
TRIM22 is a key mediator of the antiviral activity of Type 1 interferons against HIV replication. We identified TRIM22 as one of the most strongly up-regulated genes in human cells treated with Type 1 interferons using transcriptional profiling. Over-expression of TRIM22 has previously been shown to inhibit HIV replication, but it was uncertain whether TRIM22 expressed at physiological levels would have antiviral activity. We used RNA interference to deplete TRIM22 in cells treated with Type 1 interferons and found that HIV particle release was significantly increased in the absence of TRIM22. This suggests that TRIM22 acts as a natural antiviral effector. Further studies showed that TRIM22 specifically inhibits the release of HIV Gag-only particles, but not particles of other retroviruses such as MLV or EIAV. We also found that TRIM22 disrupts the trafficking of HIV Gag, causing it to accumulate in the cytoplasm rather than at the plasma membrane. Mutational analyses showed that the catalytic amino acids Cys15 and Cys18 of the RING domain of TRIM22 are required for its antiviral activity.
Fig trees ( Ficus ) and their host-specific pollinator wasps ( Agaonidae ) form a classic example of an obligate mutualism, where both species benefit from each other. However, explaining the maintenance of this mutualism is problematic, as cheaters should outcompete cooperative conspecifics, leading to mutualism instability. In monoecious figs, pollinating wasps oviposit directly into ovules from inside the receptive syconium, but there is a segregation of pollinator galls in inner ovules and seeds in outer ovules. This pattern suggests that wasps avoid or are prevented from ovipositing into outer ovules, resulting in mutualism stability. However, the mechanisms preventing wasps from exploiting outer ovules remain unknown. We report that in Ficus rubiginosa, offspring in outer ovules are vulnerable to attack by parasitic wasps that oviposit from outside the syconium. This results in a gradient of offspring viability towards the centre of the syconium, where inner ovules provide enemy-free space for pollinator offspring. We suggest that this gradient in offspring viability contributes to selection on pollinators to avoid outer ovules, reducing their galling rates. This previously unidentified mechanism may contribute to mutualism persistence independent of additional factors that invoke plant defences against pollinator oviposition, or physiological constraints on pollinators that prevent oviposition in all available ovules.
Plant height is a dynamic trait in the model C4 grass Setaria that is influenced by both genetic and environmental factors. We have performed six controlled growth trials of an interspecific Setaria italica x Setaria viridis recombinant inbred line population to investigate the genetic architecture of plant height. The results show that plant height is reduced under water limitation and high density planting and is affected by growth environment. We find that plant height is a heritable, polygenic trait and that the major genetic loci that influence plant height function independently of growth environment. The identity and contribution of loci that influence height change dynamically throughout development and the reduction of growth observed in water limited environments is a consequence of delayed progression through the genetic program that establishes plant height in Setaria. In this population, alleles inherited from the weedy S. viridis parent act to increase plant height early, whereas a larger number of small effect alleles inherited from the domesticated S. italica parent collectively act to increase plant height later in development. We identify thirty seven QTL associated with plant height throughout development within a Setaria recombinant inbred population across twelve different experiments varying water availability and planting density.
Arboviruses, such as flaviviruses, circulate in the Pantanal region of West-Central Brazil due to the presence of diverse wildlife species and hematophagous arthropods. In the Nhecolândia sub-region of Pantanal, serological evidence of various flaviviruses, including West Nile virus and Ilheus virus ( ILHV ), has been reported in horses. To confirm the circulation of these viruses, we collected 3, 234 adult mosquitoes of 16 species during 2009 and 2010 and tested them for infectious virus and flaviviral RNA. One pool of 50 non-engorged female Aedes scapularis mosquitoes tested positive for ILHV by culture and for ILHV RNA by real-time RT-PCR, indicating a minimum infection rate of 2. 5 per 1, 000. The full-length genomic sequence exhibited 95% identity to the only full genome sequence available for ILHV. This study confirms the circulation of ILHV in the Brazilian Pantanal. The previously reported high prevalence of neutralizing antibodies for ILHV in horses combined with our isolation of ILHV in local mosquitoes confirm the activity of an arbovirus of potential medical importance in the region.
Moxidectin ( MOX ), a new oral treatment for scabies, was compared to ivermectin ( IVM ) in a preclinical study using a porcine scabies model. Twelve pigs were randomly assigned to receive a single oral dose of MOX ( 0. 3 mg/kg ), two oral doses of IVM ( 0. 2 mg/kg each ), or no treatment. We evaluated treatment efficacies by assessing mite count, clinical lesions, pruritus, and anti-S. scabiei IgG antibodies. At day 14 post-treatment, all four MOX-treated but only two IVM-treated pigs were mite-free. MOX efficacy was 100% and remained unchanged until day 47, compared to 62% ( range 26–100% ) for IVM, with one IVM-treated pig remaining infected until day 47. Clinical scabies lesions, pruritus, and anti-S. scabiei IgG antibodies had completely disappeared in all MOX-treated but only 75% of IVM-treated pigs. MOX persisted ~9 times longer than IVM in plasma and skin, thereby covering the mite’s entire life cycle and enabling long-lasting efficacy. Our data demonstrate that oral single-dose MOX was more effective than two consecutive IVM-doses, supporting MOX as a potential therapeutic approach for scabies.
Staphylococcus aureus is a Gram-positive pathogen known for its resistance to many antibiotics and prevalence in hospitals. Its genome encodes a low number of proteins with peptidoglycan ( PG ) synthesis activity, making it a good model for the study of a minimal PG synthesis machine. We deleted seven of the nine genes encoding PG synthesis enzymes from the S. aureus genome without affecting normal growth or cell morphology, generating a strain capable of PG biosynthesis catalyzed only by two penicillin-binding proteins, PBP1 and the bi-functional PBP2. We show that S. aureus cells are capable of PG synthesis catalyzed solely by the transpeptidase PBP1 and the bi-functional PBP2. Our results demonstrate the plasticity of the PG synthesis process in S. aureus. Apparently, S. aureus can synthesize its PG by using just two synthesis proteins, PBP1 and PBP2, which perform both transpeptidation and transglycosylation reactions. However, multiple PBPs are important in clinically relevant environments, as bacteria with a minimal PG synthesis machinery became highly susceptible to cell wall-targeting antibiotics, host lytic enzymes and displayed impaired virulence in a Drosophila infection model. The fact that S. aureus can grow and divide with only two active PG synthesizing enzymes shows that most of these enzymes are redundant in vitro and identifies the minimal PG synthesis machinery of S. aureus.
Melioidosis is a disease caused by the bacterium Burkholderia pseudomallei, which is mostly saprophytic but can infect humans and cause a difficult-to-manage disease with mortality rates ranging from 20% in Northern Australia to over 40% in Thailand. Little is known about how B. pseudomallei infects, invades and survives within its hosts, and virtually nothing is known about the contribution of critical nutrients such as iron to the bacterium's pathogenesis. It was previously assumed that B. pseudomallei used iron-acquisition systems commonly found in other bacteria. However, our previous discovery of a clinical isolate carrying a large chromosomal deletion missing the entire malleobactin gene cluster encoding the bacterium's major high-affinity siderophore while still being fully virulent in a murine melioidosis model suggested that other iron-acquisition systems might make contributions to virulence. We deleted the major siderophore malleobactin ( mba ) and pyochelin ( pch ) gene clusters in strain 1710b and revealed a residual siderophore activity which was unrelated to other known Burkholderia siderophores. Deletion of the two hemin uptake loci, hmu and hem, showed that Hmu is required for utilization of hemin and hemoglobin and that Hem cannot complement a Hmu deficiency. A mba pch hmu hem quadruple mutant could use ferritin as an iron source and upon intranasal infection was lethal in an acute murine melioidosis model. These data suggest that B. pseudomallei may employ a novel ferritin-iron acquisition pathway as a means to sustain in vivo growth.
Genome-scale, constraint-based metabolic models ( GSMs ) are integrated knowledge repositories and predictive mathematical models of cellular function. However, their usability is often hampered by inconsistencies at various levels. To address this, we present COMMGEN, a tool for COnsensus Metabolic Model GENeration that reconciles two or more distinct GSMs of the same organism beyond a common namespace. COMMGEN automatically identifies similarities, dissimilarities, and complements of the metabolic networks based on an extensive classification of problems that typically arise during GSM integration and on novel algorithms to resolve these problem classes. The tool forms a necessary bridge between full automation and high-quality manual curation for consensus metabolic model generation. Our tests of COMMGEN for four organisms showed that automatically generated consensus models were predictive and that they substantially increased coherence of knowledge representation. We demonstrated that automatically generated consensus models almost always have higher predictive power than the manually curated GSMs and that these models can be comparable to manually constructed consensus models. COMMGEN increases coherence with the actual biological system while maintaining predictive power. This balance is of utmost importance for the usability and reliability of GSMs to elucidate cell function interactions.
Chondrocytes embedded in a proteoglycan ( PG ) -rich matrix undergo a developmental transition, termed “maturation, ” when they express Indian hedgehog ( ihh ) to induce bone in the overlying tissue, the perichondrium. Here, we show that cartilage matrix controls the timing of endochondral ossification by inhibiting chondrocyte maturation. In a mutagenesis screen, we isolated zebrafish mutants with decreased cartilage matrix and increased perichondral bone. Positional cloning identified lesions in two genes, fam20b and xylosyltransferase1 ( xylt1 ), both of which encode PG synthesis enzymes. Mutants failed to produce wild-type levels of chondroitin sulfate PGs and initiated perichondral bone formation earlier than their wild-type siblings. Primary chondrocyte defects might induce the bone phenotype secondarily, because mutant chondrocytes precociously initiated maturation, showing increased and early expression of such markers as runx2b, collagen type 10a1, and ihh co-orthologs, and ihha mutation suppressed early perichondral bone in PG mutants. Ultrastructural analyses demonstrated aberrant matrix organization and also early cellular features of chondrocyte hypertrophy in mutants. Our data argue that defective cartilage PG synthesis alters expression of transcription factors that determine the rates of chondrocyte maturation, thus changing the timing of perichondral bone formation.
Topoisomerase II ( Top2 ) is required for the proper separation of heterochromatic regions during Drosophila melanogaster female meiosis. We show that knockdown of Top2 by RNAi in the later stages of meiosis results in a specific defect in the separation of heterochromatic regions after spindle assembly. In Top2 RNAi-expressing oocytes, heterochromatic regions of both achiasmate and chiasmate chromosomes often failed to separate during prometaphase I and metaphase I. Heterochromatic regions were stretched into long, abnormal projections with centromeres localizing near the tips of the projections in some oocytes. Despite these anomalies, we observed bipolar spindles in most Top2 RNAi-expressing oocytes, although the obligately achiasmate 4th chromosomes exhibited a near complete failure to move toward the spindle poles during prometaphase I. Both achiasmate and chiasmate chromosomes displayed defects in biorientation. Embryos from Top2 RNAi-expressing females frequently failed to initiate mitotic divisions. These data suggest that Topoisomerase II is involved in the resolution of heterochromatic DNA entanglements during meiosis I and that these entanglements must be resolved in order to complete meiosis.
Visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) is a zoonotic disease of great public health importance. Current control measures for canine visceral leishmaniasis ( CVL ) have limitations, indicating the need for new strategies. This study evaluated the effectiveness of mass use of deltamethrin-impregnated collars in dogs as a public health measure to control and prevent CVL in a highly endemic area in Brazil. An interventional study was conducted in two areas: an intervention area where VL seronegative dogs were collared, and a control area where only conventional CVL control measures were applied. Dogs were reevaluated every 7–8 months for almost two years. In the intervention area, dogs that remained seronegative received new collars and newly identified seronegative dogs were included and collared. Dogs that tested seropositive were marked for euthanasia as mandated by the Brazilian Ministry of Health. At the second evaluation, significant reductions in seroprevalence were seen in both areas, while seroprevalence in the intervention area reduced to 6. 0% during the final evaluation versus an increase of 11. 0% in the control area. The estimated relative risk ( RR = 0. 55 ) indicated protection against CVL in the intervention area. Although CVL incidence did not differ significantly between the areas, an increased tendency was observed in the control area.
Sexual antagonism and the avoidance of activity in the male germline have been proposed as causes of the nonrandom gene content on the mammalian X chromosome. However, we suggest that limits imposed on gene expression owing to haploid expression of the X chromosome may more profoundly shape gene content. We test this hypothesis using data from the Encyclopedia of DNA Elements ( ENCODE ) and the Functional Annotation of the Mammalian Genome ( FANTOM5 ) project. We find that the maximal expression of human X-linked genes is much lower than that of genes on autosomes. On average, maximal expression is three times lower on the X chromosome than on autosomes. We also find that autosome-to-X retroposition events are associated with lower maximal expression of retrogenes on the X than seen for X-to-autosome retrogenes on autosomes. Furthermore, X-linked genes have a lesser degree of increase in gene expression than autosomal ones if highly expressed, but not if lowly expressed. These trends cannot be fully accounted for in terms of alternative models of biased expression. We conclude that the notion that it is hard for genes on the Therian X to be highly expressed, owing to transcriptional traffic jams, provides a simple yet robustly supported rationale for many peculiar features of X’s gene content, gene expression, and evolution.
Helicobacter pylori is a gastric pathogen that originated in Africa and has been associated with humans for at least 100, 000 years. We investigated the prevalence and population structure of H. pylori among the Baka Pygmies, a subgroup of the Western Pygmies from Cameroon. We found that the Baka Pygmies had a significantly lower H. pylori infection rate ( 20. 8% ) than their neighboring agriculturalist populations ( 80. 2% ). We generated multilocus haplotypes for each H. pylori isolate and found that most were assigned to the hpNEAfrica or hpAfrica1 populations, which are associated with the expansion of the Nilo-Saharan language family and the Bantu languages, respectively. We also identified a new hpAfrica1 subpopulation mainly among Cameroonians. Using an age-structured transmission model, we show that the low H. pylori prevalence among Baka Pygmies is achievable within a few hundred years and suggest that demographic factors such as small population size and low life expectancy can lead to the eradication of H. pylori from individual human populations. Our results suggest that the Baka Pygmies were either H. pylori-free or lost their ancient lineages during past demographic fluctuations. Using coalescent simulations and phylogenetic inference, we show that the Baka Pygmies almost certainly acquired their extant H. pylori through secondary contact with their agriculturalist neighbors.
Dengue virus NS5 is the most conserved non-structural protein amongst the flaviviruses and is responsible for capping, methylation, and replication of the viral RNA genome. The C-terminal 18 amino acid region ( Cter18 ) of NS5 is essential for its subcellular localization and contains a conserved arginine residue ( R888 ) that is critical for infectious virus production. The Cter18 is sufficient to direct the protein to either the cytoplasm or nucleus, depending on the serotype of the virus. The Cter18 of DENV2 NS5 binds to the nuclear import receptor importin-alpha ( Impα ) with low micromolar affinity, and structure-guided mutational analysis reveals that the trans conformation of Pro-884 is essential for this interaction. Mutating Pro-884 to threonine ( P884T ) results in mislocalization of NS5 to the cytoplasm without compromising virus fitness. In contrast, mutating R888 to alanine ( R888A ) results in a completely non-viable virus, while mutating it to lysine ( R888K ) leads to a severely attenuated phenotype. The Cter18 of DENV2 and 3 NS5s may directly interact with cellular importins to target the protein to the nucleus, while the Cter18 of DENV1 NS5 may have evolved to bind to other host factors and is mostly located in the cytoplasm.
A novel integrated mapping protocol for neglected tropical diseases ( NTDs ), the Integrated Threshold Mapping ( ITM ) Methodology, has been developed and field-tested for lymphatic filariasis ( LF ), trachoma, schistosomiasis, and soil-transmitted helminths ( STH ). The protocol is designed to determine whether a threshold has been reached to trigger public health interventions in an implementation unit. It relies on World Health Organization ( WHO ) recommended indicators for each disease in specific age groups. We tested the protocol by comparing it to current WHO mapping methodologies for each disease in one district each in Mali and Senegal. The results show that the ITM methodology reached the same conclusions as the WHO methodologies regarding the initiation of public health interventions for trachoma, LF, and STH, but resulted in more targeted intervention recommendations for schistosomiasis. The ITM methodology was found to be practical, feasible, and cost-saving compared to the standard WHO methodologies. This integrated mapping tool could facilitate the implementation of much-needed programs in endemic countries.
Cdc14 is a conserved phosphatase required for the exit from mitosis in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. It is anchored to nucleolar chromatin by the Cfi1/Net1 protein until early anaphase, at which time it is released into the nucleoplasm. Cdc14 release is mediated by two redundant pathways, the FEAR ( Cdc fourteen early release ) network and the MEN ( mitotic exit network ). Here, we report a novel requirement for the ubiquitination of histone H2B by the Bre1 ubiquitin ligase in the cell cycle–dependent release of Cdc14 from nucleolar chromatin when the MEN is inactivated. This function is mediated by the activation of histone H3 methylation on lysines 4 and 79 ( meH3K4 and meH3K79 ) and is not dependent on the histone deacetylase ( HDAC ) Sir2. We also observed a defect in Cdc14 release in cells lacking H3 lysine 36 methylation ( meH3K36 ) and in cells lacking an HDAC recruited by this modification. These histone modifications represent previously unappreciated factors required for the accessibility to and/or action on nucleolar chromatin of FEAR network components.
GeneProgram is a new unsupervised computational framework that addresses several challenges in the discovery of expression programs from human expression data compendia. These challenges include cellular inhomogeneity within samples, genetic and environmental variation across samples, uncertainty in the numbers of programs and sample populations, and temporal behavior. GeneProgram is based on Hierarchical Dirichlet Processes and simultaneously organizes tissues into groups and genes into overlapping programs with consistent temporal behavior. It produces maps of expression programs, which are sorted by generality scores that exploit the automatically learned groupings. Using synthetic and real gene expression data, we showed that GeneProgram outperformed several popular expression analysis methods. We applied GeneProgram to a compendium of 62 short time-series gene expression datasets exploring the responses of human cells to infectious agents and immune-modulating molecules. GeneProgram produced a map of 104 expression programs, a substantial number of which were significantly enriched for genes involved in key signaling pathways and/or bound by NF-κB transcription factors in genome-wide experiments. Further, GeneProgram discovered expression programs that appear to implicate surprising signaling pathways or receptor types in the response to infection, including Wnt signaling and neurotransmitter receptors.
Human cytomegalovirus ( HCMV ) drives epigenetic imprinting of the IFNG locus in NKG2Chi natural killer ( NK ) cells. NK cells play a crucial role in the defense against HCMV and represent the main source of interferon ( IFN ) -γ. In HCMV seropositive individuals, only NKG2Chi NK cells undergo epigenetic remodeling of the IFNG conserved non-coding sequence ( CNS ) 1, similar to memory CD8+ T cells or TH1 cells. This epigenetic imprinting is required to enhance IFN-γ transcriptional activity in response to NKG2C and 2B4 engagement, leading to consistent IFN-γ production in NKG2Chi NK cells. Our data identify epigenetic imprinting of the IFNG locus as a hallmark and crucial mechanism driving strong and stable IFN-γ expression in HCMV-specific NK cell expansions, providing a molecular basis for the regulation of adaptive features in innate cells.
Legionella pneumophila exploits the host proteasome system to temporally regulate the function of a cognate effector protein. The effector protein LubX functions as an E3 ubiquitin ligase that hijacks the host proteasome to specifically target the bacterial effector protein SidH for degradation. This results in the shutdown of SidH within the host cells at later stages of infection. We propose the designation “metaeffector” for this class of bacterial effectors that regulate the function of another effector within the host cell. This is the first example of a bacterial effector that targets and regulates a cognate effector within the host cells. Importantly, the determinants of the susceptibility of SidH to degradation are encoded in the effector protein itself, and LubX controls SidH instability in the host cytosol by directly targeting this protein for host ubiquitination. This represents a novel mechanism by which bacterial effectors are regulated and illustrates a sophisticated level of coevolution between eukaryotic cells and L. pneumophila involving an effector that functions as a key regulator to temporally coordinate the function of a cognate effector protein.
HIV-1 env coding sequences from 81 very early B subtype infections were analyzed to study the pattern of diversification of HIV-1 upon transmission to a new host. We find evidence of adaptive evolution of HIV-1 env and identify a subset of codon sites that diversified more rapidly than can be explained by a model of neutral evolution. Of 24 such rapidly diversifying sites, 14 were either i ) clustered and embedded in CTL epitopes that were verified experimentally or predicted based on the individual's HLA or ii ) in a nucleotide context indicative of APOBEC-mediated G-to-A substitutions. In several cases, a rapidly evolving site was embedded both in an APOBEC motif and in a CTL epitope, suggesting that APOBEC may facilitate early immune escape. Ten rapidly diversifying sites could not be explained by CTL escape or APOBEC hypermutation, including the most frequently mutated site, in the fusion peptide of gp41. We also examined the distribution, extent, and sequence context of insertions and deletions, and we provide evidence that the length variation seen in hypervariable loop regions of the envelope glycoprotein is a consequence of selection and not of mutational hotspots. Our results provide a detailed view of the process of diversification of HIV-1 following transmission, highlighting the role of CTL escape and hypermutation in shaping viral evolution during the establishment of new infections.
The role of multiple epigenetic marks in the emergence of a stable bivalent chromatin state has been investigated in budding yeast. A minimal model of epigenetic silencing has been introduced and analyzed, which explicitly incorporates two key chromatin marks: H4K16 acetylation and H3K79 methylation. We find that the presence of both modifications is important for the robustness of epigenetic silencing. Besides the silenced and transcriptionally active fate of chromatin, our model leads to a novel state with bivalent ( i. e., both active and silencing ) marks under certain perturbations ( knock-out mutations, inhibition or enhancement of enzymatic activity ). The bivalent state appears under several perturbations and is shown to result in patchy silencing. We also show that the titration effect, owing to a limited supply of silencing proteins, can result in counter-intuitive responses. The design principles of the silencing system are systematically investigated and disparate experimental observations are assessed within a single theoretical framework.
Severe acute malnutrition ( SAM ) among children is a major health problem in developing countries, manifesting in both oedematous and non-oedematous forms. The pathogenesis of SAM remains largely unknown, but gut microbiota ( GM ) dysbiosis has recently been linked to oedematous malnutrition. We aimed to assess whether GM composition differed between Ugandan children suffering from either oedematous or non-oedematous malnutrition. As part of an observational study among children hospitalized with SAM aged 6–24 months in Uganda, fecal samples were collected at admission and analyzed by Denaturing Gradient Gel Electrophoresis ( DGGE ) and tag-encoded 16S rRNA gene-targeted high throughput amplicon sequencing. We found that GM composition differed between the two groups of children, with non-oedematous children having lower GM alpha diversity. However, beta diversity analysis did not reveal larger differences between the GM of children with oedematous and non-oedematous SAM. Our results indicate that non-oedematous SAM children have lower GM diversity compared to oedematous SAM children, but no clear compositional differences were identified.
Telomere length is a complex trait in yeast that is controlled by multiple loci and varies among individuals. We screened 112 wild-type Saccharomyces sensu stricto isolates and found extensive telomere length variation in S. paradoxus isolates, which correlated with their geographic origin. European strains had extremely short telomeres ( <150 bp ), whereas American isolates had telomeres approximately three times as long ( >400 bp ). We used insertions of a URA3 gene near telomeres to accurately analyze individual telomere lengths and telomere position effect ( TPE ). Crossing American and European strains resulted in F1 spores with a continuum of telomere lengths consistent with multiple quantitative trait loci ( QTLs ) being involved in length maintenance. Variation in TPE was similarly quantitative but only weakly correlated with telomere length. We identified several QTLs associated with telomere length and silencing variation, including likely candidate genes and regions with no known genes involved in telomeric properties. We detected transgressive segregation for both phenotypes and validated by reciprocal hemizygosity that YKU80 and TLC1 are telomere-length QTLs in the two S. paradoxus subpopulations. Furthermore, we propose that sequence divergence within the Ku heterodimer generates negative epistasis within one of the allelic combinations ( American-YKU70 and European-YKU80 ) resulting in very short telomeres.
Deciding Not to Decide: Computational and Neural Evidence for Hidden Behavior in Sequential Choice is a study that investigates the cognitive and neural processes that underlie human decision making in sequential choice paradigms. Sequential sampling models ( SSMs ) have greatly advanced the decision sciences by assuming that decisions emerge from a bounded evidence accumulation process. However, these models do not account for the possibility that people might decide to delay their choice and terminate the accumulation process temporarily. We developed several SSMs for predicting response times ( RTs ) from two independent samples of electroencephalography ( EEG ) and functional magnetic resonance imaging ( fMRI ) studies. In these studies, participants bought or rejected fictitious stocks based on sequentially presented cues and were free to respond at any time. Standard SSM implementations did not describe RT distributions adequately. However, by adding a mechanism for postponing decisions to the model, we obtained an accurate fit to the data. Time-frequency analysis of EEG data revealed alternating states of de- and increasing oscillatory power in beta-band frequencies ( 14–30 Hz ), indicating that responses were repeatedly prepared and inhibited. Finally, the extended model accounted for the results of an adapted version of our paradigm in which participants had to press a button for sampling more information. Our results show how computational modeling of decisions and RTs supports a deeper understanding of the hidden dynamics in cognition.
Hereditary nasal parakeratosis ( HNPK ) is a monogenic autosomal recessive skin disorder in Labrador Retrievers characterized by crusts and fissures on the nasal planum. A genome-wide association study ( GWAS ) of 13 HNPK cases and 23 controls identified a single strong association signal on chromosome 2. The analysis of shared haplotypes among the cases defined a critical interval of 1. 6 Mb with 25 predicted genes. A missense variant in the SUV39H2 gene, encoding a histone 3 lysine 9 ( H3K9 ) methyltransferase, was identified as the candidate causative variant. The variant c. 972T>G is predicted to change an evolutionary conserved asparagine into a lysine in the catalytically active domain of the enzyme ( p. N324K ). We further studied the histopathological alterations in the epidermis in vivo. Our data suggest that the HNPK phenotype is not caused by hyperproliferation, but rather delayed terminal differentiation of keratinocytes. Thus, our data provide evidence that SUV39H2 is involved in the epigenetic regulation of keratinocyte differentiation ensuring proper stratification and tight sealing of the mammalian epidermis.
Influenza A viruses ( IAVs ) have the ability to undergo genetic reassortment, which can lead to the emergence of pandemic strains. Swine are considered a potential “mixing vessel” for generating reassortants of avian and mammalian IAVs that could pose a risk to humans. However, the process by which a transmissible reassortant emerges in swine is not well understood. In this study, we investigated the generation of reassortants between avian H1N1 and swine H3N2 IAVs in a group of co-housed pigs. We recovered 571 isolates from nasal wash samples and respiratory tract tissues of the pigs and identified 30 distinct genotypes of reassortants. We found that viruses recovered from lower respiratory tract tissues had the largest genomic diversity, and those recovered from turbinates and nasal wash fluids had the least. Reassortants from lower respiratory tracts had the largest variations in growth kinetics in respiratory tract epithelial cells, and the cold temperature in swine nasal cells seemed to select the type of reassortant viruses shed by the pigs. One reassortant was consistently identified in upper, middle, and lower respiratory tract tissues and was confirmed to be transmitted efficiently between pigs. Our findings suggest that genetic reassortments are likely to occur in the lower respiratory tract, and tissue tropism is an important factor in selecting for a transmissible reassortant.
Schistosoma mansoni is a parasitic worm that causes schistosomiasis, a major public health problem in sub-Saharan Africa. Maternal infection with S. mansoni during pregnancy may influence the immune responsiveness of offspring to schistosome infection and schistosomiasis-associated morbidity. However, the effects of praziquantel treatment of S. mansoni during pregnancy on the risk of S. mansoni infection among offspring and on their immune responsiveness when they become exposed to S. mansoni are unknown. In this study, we examined the effects of praziquantel treatment of S. mansoni during pregnancy on the prevalence of S. mansoni infection and immune responsiveness among offspring at age five years. We conducted a trial in Uganda in which offspring of women treated with praziquantel or placebo during pregnancy were examined for S. mansoni infection and for cytokine and antibody responses to schistosome antigens, as well as for T cell expression of FoxP3, at age five years. We found no evidence that maternal S. mansoni infection and its treatment during pregnancy influence the prevalence and intensity of S. mansoni infection or effector immune response to S. mansoni infection among offspring at age five years. However, we found that praziquantel treatment of S. mansoni during pregnancy may affect immunoregulatory responsiveness in childhood schistosomiasis, as evidenced by higher IL-10 responses to SWA among offspring of women treated with praziquantel during pregnancy.
Macrophages are immune cells that play a crucial role in clearing infectious pathogens from the body. However, how macrophage activation is coupled to increased clearance of pathogens remains largely unknown. Here, we show that inflammatory stimuli induce a reprogramming of the macrophage endocytic machinery from receptor-mediated phagocytosis to macropinocytosis, allowing for the rapid transfer of internalized cargo to lysosomes in a receptor-independent manner. This reprogramming occurs through protein kinase C-mediated phosphorylation of the macrophage protein coronin 1, which activates phosphoinositol ( PI ) -3-kinase activity necessary for macropinocytic uptake. Importantly, expression of a phosphomimetic form of coronin 1 is sufficient to induce PI3-kinase activation and macropinocytosis even in the absence of inflammatory stimuli. This suggests a hitherto unknown mechanism to regulate the internalization and degradation of infectious material during inflammation. We found that upon macrophage activation, serine phosphorylation of coronin 1 is the key molecular switch that reprograms the macrophage from a phagocytic uptake mode to macropinocytosis. Moreover, expression of a phosphomimetic mutant of coronin 1 resulted in all mycobacteria being transferred to lysosomes followed by their elimination, regardless of the macrophage activation state.
Sleeping sickness, also known as human African trypanosomiasis ( HAT ), is a neglected tropical disease endemic to the African continent. Tsetse flies are the primary vectors of the disease. In an effort to control tsetse populations, insecticide-treated targets are being deployed in the West Nile region of Uganda. We conducted a qualitative study in Arua District to assess the knowledge, perceptions, and acceptance of tsetse baits ( traps, targets ) in villages where they had or had not been used previously. We conducted 16 focus group discussions with male and female participants in eight villages across Arua District. Our results show that villagers who had never seen traps before expressed fear, anxiety, and panic due to associations with witchcraft and “ghosts from the river”, which are traditionally linked with physical or mental illness, death, and misfortune. In contrast, villagers living in areas where traps had been used previously had positive attitudes towards them and were fully aware of their purpose and benefits. The success of community-based interventions against tsetse will depend on early engagement with communities and carefully designed sensitization campaigns that reach all communities, especially those living in areas new to such interventions.
Recombination in Drosophila melanogaster is a fundamental biological process that has profound evolutionary implications. Recombination increases the effectiveness of selection in natural populations, but direct tests of this prediction have been restricted by the lack of detailed characterization of recombination rate variation across genomes and within species. Here, we report the first integrated high-resolution description of genomic and population variation in recombination in D. melanogaster, distinguishing between the two outcomes of meiotic recombination: crossing over ( CO ) and gene conversion ( GC ). We characterized the products of 5, 860 female meioses by genotyping 139 million informative SNPs and mapped 106, 964 recombination events at a resolution down to 2 kilobases. This approach allowed us to generate whole-genome CO and GC maps as well as a detailed description of variation in recombination among individuals of this species. We describe many levels of variation in recombination rates, with CO rates exhibiting extreme and highly punctuated variation along chromosomes, and GC rates being more uniformly distributed across the genome. Recombination events are associated with numerous sequence motifs and tend to occur within transcript regions, suggesting that chromatin accessibility favors double-strand breaks.
IDN2 and its paralogs, IDP1 and IDP2, form a complex required for RNA-directed DNA methylation ( RdDM ) in Arabidopsis thaliana. IDP1 is required for de novo DNA methylation, siRNA accumulation, and transcriptional gene silencing, whereas IDP2 has partially overlapping roles with IDP1. Unlike IDN2, IDP1 and IDP2 are incapable of binding double-stranded RNA. The IDN2 coiled-coil domain is essential for IDN2 homodimerization, whereas the IDN2 C-terminal XH domain is required for IDN2 interaction with IDP1 and IDP2. The IDN2 XH domain is essential for the IDN2-IDP1/IDP2 complex formation as well as for IDN2 function in RdDM and transcriptional gene silencing. IDP1 and IDP2 belong to a different subfamily from IDN2 and its close homologs. IDN2 interacts with itself via the coiled-coil domain, whereas it interacts with IDP1 and IDP2 via the XH domain. Mutations in the IDN2 XH domain caused the mutated IDN2 transgenes to fail to complement the DNA methylation defect of idn2 at a canonical RdDM target.
Leishmania braziliensis, the causative agent of New World cutaneous leishmaniasis, triggers neutrophil activation and apoptosis. Neutrophils are the first line of defense against invading pathogens and are rapidly recruited to the sites of L. braziliensis inoculation. In this study, we investigated the interaction between neutrophils and L. braziliensis, focusing on cell activation and apoptotic fate. We found that inoculation of serum-opsonized L. braziliensis promastigotes in mice induced neutrophil accumulation in vivo, peaking at 24 h. In vitro, exposure of neutrophils to L. braziliensis modulated the expression of surface molecules such as CD18 and CD62L, and induced the oxidative burst. Neutrophil activation following contact with L. braziliensis was confirmed by the release of TNF-α and neutrophil elastase. Moreover, neutrophils infected with L. braziliensis but not with L. major displayed markers of early apoptosis. We show that L. braziliensis induces neutrophil recruitment in vivo and that neutrophils exposed to the parasite in vitro respond through activation and release of inflammatory mediators. This outcome may impact on parasite elimination, particularly at the early stages of infection.
Bovine tuberculosis ( bTB ) is a major disease affecting cattle worldwide, and vaccination is not currently used in international control programs due to interference with the tuberculin skin test. However, new diagnostic tests that can Differentiate Infected from Vaccinated Animals ( DIVA ) offer the potential to introduce vaccination within existing eradication programs. We use within-herd transmission models estimated from historical data from Great Britain to explore the feasibility of using BCG vaccination as a supplementary control measure. The economic impact of bTB on farmers is dominated by the costs associated with testing and restrictions on animal movements. We find that the specificity of the DIVA test, rather than its sensitivity, is the greatest barrier to seeing a herd level benefit of vaccination under the intensive testing regime used in Great Britain. We estimate that a DIVA specificity of at least 99. 85% and sensitivity of >40% is required to see a protective benefit of vaccination with no increase in the risk of missed infection. Using a cocktail of three DIVA antigens, we estimate that this target specificity could be achieved in vaccinates while maintaining a sensitivity of 73. 3% relative to post-mortem detection.
Trichuris trichiura, a parasitic whipworm, infects approximately 500 million people worldwide, causing physical growth and educational performance damage. Current treatments are limited and lack efficacy against the parasite, hindering eradication efforts. To develop new treatments, we screened a library of 480 novel small molecules against Trichuris muris, an established model for T. trichiura. We identified a class of dihydrobenz[e][1, 4]oxazepin-2 ( 3H ) -one compounds with anthelmintic activity against T. muris. Further screening and resynthesis led to the identification of 20 active dihydrobenzoxazepinones, a new class of molecules not previously implicated in nematode control. The most active compounds immobilised adult T. muris with EC50 values around 25–50μM, comparable to the existing anthelmintic levamisole. These compounds showed low cytotoxicity against murine gut epithelial cells, demonstrating selectivity for the parasite. Importantly, the dihydrobenzoxazepinone OX02983 reduced the ability of embryonated T. muris eggs to establish infection in the mouse host in vivo. This supports an alternative strategy of developing a therapeutic that acts in the environment to interrupt the parasite lifecycle.
The distinction between date and party hubs in protein–protein interaction networks is re-examined in this study. Date hubs are characterised by low co-expression with their interaction partners, whereas party hubs have high co-expression. It was previously proposed that party hubs act as local coordinators and date hubs as global connectors. However, we show that the importance of date hubs to network connectivity can be attributed to a small subset of highly central hubs, which do not display low expression correlation with their partners. This challenges the idea of a link between expression correlation and hub function. We also find that the bimodal distribution of hub co-expression, which motivated the date/party distinction, is not robust to methodological changes. Furthermore, we show that topological properties of hubs do not generally correlate with co-expression. In contrast, we find significant correlations between interaction centrality and the functional similarity of interacting proteins.
Pathogen genome sequences are increasingly used to reconstruct transmission trees in infectious disease outbreaks. However, a fundamental limitation of such approaches is the requirement for genetic diversity to arise on epidemiological timescales. We introduce the concept of ‘transmission divergence’, defined as the number of mutations separating whole genome sequences sampled from transmission pairs, to quantify and compare the useful genetic diversity expected from genetic data in different pathogen outbreaks. Using parameter values obtained by literature review, we simulated outbreak scenarios alongside sequence evolution for ten major outbreak-causing pathogens. We find that while mean values vary significantly between pathogens, their transmission divergence is generally very low, with many outbreaks characterised by large numbers of genetically identical transmission pairs. We demonstrate that genetic sequence data of rapidly evolving pathogens such as RNA viruses can provide valuable information on individual transmission events, whereas sequence data of pathogens with lower mean transmission divergence, including Streptococcus pneumoniae, Shigella sonnei and Clostridium difficile, provide little to no information about individual transmission events. Our results highlight the informational limitations of genetic sequence data in certain outbreak scenarios, and demonstrate the need to expand the toolkit of outbreak reconstruction tools to integrate other types of epidemiological data.
X chromosome inactivation ( XCI ) is a process that silences most genes on one X chromosome in female mammals. However, some genes escape XCI and are expressed from both X chromosomes. To identify escape genes in vivo and explore the molecular mechanisms that regulate this process, we analyzed the allele-specific expression and chromatin structure of X-linked genes in mouse tissues and cells with skewed XCI and distinguishable alleles. Using a binomial model to assess allelic expression, we demonstrate a continuum between complete silencing and expression from the inactive X ( Xi ). Overall, few genes ( 3–7% ) escape XCI in any of the mouse tissues examined, suggesting stringent silencing and escape controls. In contrast, an in vitro system represented by the embryonic-kidney-derived Patski cell line showed a higher density of escape genes ( 21% ). We identified both common escape genes and genes with significant differences in XCI status between tissues, which may be candidates for tissue-specific sex differences. We also found that allele-specific RNA polymerase II occupancy and DNase I hypersensitivity at the promoter of genes on the Xi correlated well with levels of escape, consistent with an open chromatin structure at escape genes.
Plasmodium vivax is one of the most predominant human malaria species worldwide, causing hundreds of millions of illnesses each year. Cysteine proteases of malaria parasites are essential for the parasite's survival, involved in physiological processes such as hemoglobin degradation, processing of food vacuole plasmepsins, and erythrocyte rupture. However, comprehensive studies of P. vivax cysteine proteases have been hindered by an inability to culture P. vivax. In this study, we describe the biochemical properties of a novel cysteine protease of P. vivax, designated as vivapain-4 ( VX-4 ). VX-4 has dual substrate specificity depending on the surrounding micro-environmental pH, with highest hydrolyzing activity against benzyloxycarbonyl-Leu-Arg-4-methyl-coumaryl-7-amide ( Z-Leu-Arg-MCA ) and Z-Phe-Arg-MCA at acidic pH ( 5. 5 ), and against Z-Arg-Arg-MCA at neutral pH ( 6. 5–7. 5 ). VX-4 preferred positively charged amino acids and Gln at the P1 position, with less strict specificity at P3 and P4. VX-4 was localized in the food vacuoles and cytoplasm of the erythrocytic stage of P. vivax. VX-4 showed maximal activity against actin at neutral pH, and that against P. vivax plasmepsin 4 and hemoglobin was detected at neutral/acidic and acidic pH, respectively. VX-4 demonstrates pH-dependent substrate switching, which might offer an efficient mechanism for the specific cleavage of different substrates in different intracellular environments.
Acetogens are ideal candidates for biotechnological production of commodity chemicals due to their unique ability to ferment a broad range of substrates, including H2:CO2 or syngas. However, advanced design strategies for acetogens are hampered by incomplete knowledge about their physiology and the inability to accurately predict phenotypes. Here, we describe the reconstruction of a novel genome-scale model of metabolism and macromolecular synthesis ( ME-model ) for the model acetogen Clostridium ljungdahlii. The completed ME-model, named iJL965-ME, captures all major central metabolic, amino acid, nucleotide, lipid, major cofactors, and vitamin synthesis pathways as well as pathways to synthesis RNA and protein molecules necessary to catalyze these reactions. This model represents the first ME-model of a Gram-positive bacterium and significantly broadens the scope and predictability of microbial systems biology. Using the model, we revealed how protein allocation and media composition influence metabolic pathways and energy conservation in acetogens and accurately predicted secretion of multiple fermentation products, including acetate, ethanol, and glycerol. Furthermore, we predicted and experimentally validated changing secretion rates based on different metal availability, which opens the window into fermentation optimization and provides new knowledge about the proteome utilization and carbon flux in acetogens.
Genome-wide association studies ( GWAS ) are moving towards the use of large cohorts of primary cell lines to study a disease of interest and to assign biological relevance to the genetic signals identified. Here, we use a panel of human osteoblasts ( HObs ) to carry out a transcriptomic survey, similar to recent studies in lymphoblastoid cell lines ( LCLs ). We performed cis-association analysis with SNP genotypes to identify genetic variations of transcript isoforms, and our analysis indicates that differential expression of transcript isoforms in HObs is also partly controlled by cis-regulatory genetic variants. These isoforms are regulated by genetic variants in both a tissue-specific and tissue-independent fashion, and these associations have been confirmed by RT–PCR validation. Our study suggests that multiple transcript isoforms are often present in both tissues and that genetic control may affect the relative expression of one isoform to another, rather than having an all-or-none effect. Examination of the top SNPs from a GWAS of bone mineral density show overlap with probeset associations observed in this study. Our approach to examining transcriptome variation in multiple tissue types is useful for detecting the proportion of genetic variation common to different cell types and for the identification of cell-specific isoform variants that may be functionally relevant, an important follow-up step for GWAS.
Saccharomyces eubayanus CBS 12357T, the non-S. cerevisiae parent of the lager-brewing hybrid S. pastorianus, is unable to utilize maltotriose, a major carbohydrate in brewer’s wort. In contrast, most S. cerevisiae and Frohberg-type S. pastorianus strains can utilize maltotriose. S. eubayanus CBS 12357T harbors four SeMALT genes that enable uptake of the α-di-glucoside maltose, but lacks maltotriose transporter genes. To study the evolvability of maltotriose utilization in S. eubayanus CBS 12357T, maltotriose-assimilating mutants were obtained after UV mutagenesis and subjected to laboratory evolution in carbon-limited chemostat cultures on maltotriose-enriched wort. An evolved strain showed improved maltose and maltotriose fermentation in 7 L fermenter experiments on industrial wort. Whole-genome sequencing revealed a novel mosaic SeMALT413 gene, resulting from repeated gene introgressions by non-reciprocal translocation of at least three SeMALT genes. The predicted tertiary structure of SeMalT413 was comparable to the original SeMalT transporters, but overexpression of SeMALT413 sufficed to enable growth on maltotriose. The mosaic structure of SeMALT413 resembles the structure of S. pastorianus maltotriose-transporter gene SpMTY1, which has high sequence identity to alternatingly S. cerevisiae MALx1, S. paradoxus MALx1 and S. eubayanus SeMALT3.
Influenza viruses are a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide, and timely and accurate assessment of their impact on human death is invaluable for influenza planning. However, current approaches rely mostly on intensive and unbiased influenza surveillance, which presents a substantial challenge. In this study, we propose a novel host-virus interaction model and establish a positive correlation between the excess mortalities caused by viral strains of distinct antigenicity and their antigenic distances to their previous strains for each ( sub ) type of seasonal influenza viruses. We further develop a method to rapidly assess the mortality burden of influenza A ( H1N1 ) virus by accurately predicting the antigenic distance between A ( H1N1 ) strains based on their HA sequences. Our method is based on a simplified host-virus interaction model that considers only the strains of distinct antigenicity that cause significant infection in the human population. We evaluate the ability of our method, called EADpred, to predict antigenic distance with a relatively high accuracy, suggesting its potential utility in the rapid estimation of influenza mortality burden. We further evaluate how well the predicted antigenic distance of A ( H1N1 ) virus correlates with the observed excess mortality and find a direct and positive correlation between the extent of antigenic variation of an influenza virus and the total excess mortality it may cause. We believe that our method will be useful for rapid assessment of the influenza mortality burden of other future A ( H1N2 ) and B viruses with proper modification.
The Asian soybean rust fungus, Phakopsora pachyrhizi, is an obligate biotrophic pathogen that causes severe soybean disease epidemics. The molecular mechanisms by which P. pachyrhizi and other rust fungi interact with their host plants are poorly understood. Here, we present the characterization of P. pachyrhizi effector candidate 23 ( PpEC23 ), a small, secreted cysteine-rich protein ( SSCRP ) that suppresses plant immunity.
