We show that PpEC23 interacts with soybean transcription factor GmSPL12l and that soybean plants in which GmSPL12l is silenced have constitutively active immunity, thereby identifying GmSPL12l as a negative regulator of soybean defenses. Collectively, our data present evidence for a virulence function of a rust SSCRP and suggest that PpEC23 is able to suppress soybean immune responses and physically interact with soybean transcription factor GmSPL12l, a negative immune regulator.
Chlamydia trachomatis is an obligate intracellular bacterium that invades host cells to replicate inside a membrane-bound vacuole called an inclusion. We have identified the cell surface tyrosine kinase EphrinA2 receptor ( EphA2 ) as a chlamydial adherence and invasion receptor that induces PI3 kinase ( PI3K ) activation, promoting chlamydial replication. C. trachomatis serovar L2 ( Ctr ) interacts with and activates EphA2 on the cell surface resulting in Ctr and receptor internalization. During chlamydial replication, EphA2 remains active accumulating around the inclusion and interacts with the p85 regulatory subunit of PI3K to support the activation of the PI3K/Akt signaling pathway that is required for normal chlamydial development. Overexpression of full length EphA2, but not the mutant form lacking the intracellular cytoplasmic domain, enhanced PI3K activation and Ctr infection. Despite the depletion of EphA2 from the cell surface, Ctr infection induces upregulation of EphA2 through the activation of the ERK pathway, which keeps the infected cell in an apoptosis-resistant state. The significance of EphA2 as an entry and intracellular signaling receptor was also observed with the urogenital C. trachomatis-serovar D. Our findings provide the first evidence for a host cell surface receptor that is exploited for invasion as well as for receptor-mediated intracellular signaling to facilitate chlamydial replication.
Active dendrites in neurons have been shown to exhibit excitability through the expression of voltage-gated ion channels. However, the role of this excitability for dendritic computation has remained elusive. Here, we show that the average output of a model of an active dendritic tree is a highly non-linear function of its afferent rate, attaining extremely large dynamic ranges ( above 50 dB ). Moreover, the model yields double-sigmoid response functions as experimentally observed in retinal ganglion cells. We propose that enhancement of dynamic range is the primary functional role of active dendritic conductances. We predict that neurons with larger dendritic trees should have larger dynamic range and that blocking of active conductances should lead to a decrease in dynamic range.
The inference of regulatory interactions and quantitative models of gene regulation from time-series transcriptomics data has been extensively studied. However, existing methods are based on implicit assumptions that are often not valid and bias the reverse engineering process. These assumptions include that measurements of mRNA abundance are representative of protein concentrations and that observed changes in gene expression are solely due to transcription factors and other specific regulators. Here, we investigate the importance of this bias and possible corrections using a combination of models and experiments. We measure in real time and in vivo the activity of genes involved in the FliA-FlgM module of the E. coli motility network and estimate protein concentrations and global physiological effects by means of kinetic models of gene expression. Our results indicate that correcting for the bias of commonly-made assumptions improves the quality of the models inferred from the data. Moreover, we show by simulation that these improvements are expected to be even stronger for systems in which protein concentrations have longer half-lives and the activity of the gene expression machinery varies more strongly across conditions than in the FliA-FlgM module. We propose new controls for transcriptome experiments and mathematical models for reconstructing protein concentrations and integrating global physiological effects into the network inference process. Our results demonstrate the importance of global physiological effects and the active regulation of FliA and FlgM half-lives for the dynamics of FliA-dependent promoters.
Zoonotic pathogens, such as hantavirus, are maintained in natural systems by their rodent reservoirs. However, few studies have been conducted at a microscale over short time periods to better capture the dynamical patterns of key populations. This study characterizes the landscape distribution and spatio-temporal dynamics of Oligoryzomys fulvescens ( O. fulvescens ), an important mammalian reservoir in Central America, in the community of Agua Buena in Tonosí, Panama, between April 2006 and December 2009. A 90 node grid was built to design a base map of the study area ( 2. 39 x 2. 69 km ). The temporal assessment dataset was divided into four periods for each year studied: the dry season, rainy season, and two months-long transitions between seasons. Spatial autocorrelation analyses indicated that local populations of O. fulvescens encompassed approximately 300–600 m. The species typically was locally absent during the late transitional months of the season, and re-established locally in subsequent years. These populations re-occurred in the same area during the first three years but subsequently re-established further south in the final year of the study. Our results provide an important characterization of the challenges in monitoring or predicting zoonotic disease outbreaks at the level of reservoir populations. These populations are subject to fluctuations over time ( both within and among years ), and the populations themselves are geographically restricted, even within their range.
The antigenic evolution of human influenza A ( H3N2 ) viruses has been studied by developing a computational method for inferring ‘antigenic trees’. These trees represent the antigenic evolution of the major viral surface protein hemagglutinin over a 35-year period from 1968 to 2003. The method is based on a least-squares optimization procedure that fits pairwise antigenic distances between isolates onto an evolutionary tree for the major antigenic determinant of influenza A. This allows for a more fine-grained resolution of the antigenic impact of individual amino acid changes than antigenic cartography. The method can be used to identify areas and branches in the tree corresponding to known antigenic types and transitions between these types. It can also be used to identify isolates and associated changes with large antigenic impact, which need to be identified for vaccine strain updates prior to antigenic type transitions. The method is not restricted to the analysis of influenza viruses or antigenic distance information, but can be applied to the study of any system where homologous genetic sequences and associated pairwise phenotype distances are available.
Human papillomavirus type 16 ( HPV16 ) requires nuclear envelope breakdown during mitosis for nuclear import of its viral DNA ( vDNA ). A large-scale RNA interference ( RNAi ) screen was used to identify host cell factors and processes involved in HPV16 infection. The screen revealed a cluster of mitotic genes and a previously undetermined mechanism for vDNA import into the nucleus. In interphase cells, viruses were endocytosed, routed to the perinuclear area, and uncoated, but the vDNA failed to be imported into the nucleus. However, upon nuclear envelope perforation in interphase cells, HPV16 infection occurred. During mitosis, the vDNA and L2 associated with host cell chromatin on the metaphase plate. We propose that HPV16 requires nuclear envelope breakdown during mitosis for access of the vDNA to the nucleoplasm. The results highlight the value of genes found by RNAi screens for investigation of viral infections. The list of cell functions required during HPV16 infection will provide a resource for future virus-host cell interaction studies.
Black Sigatoka or black leaf streak disease, caused by the Dothideomycete fungus Pseudocercospora fijiensis, is the most significant foliar disease of banana worldwide. Due to the lack of effective host resistance, management of this disease requires frequent fungicide applications, which greatly increase the economic and environmental costs to produce banana. To combat this disease, the genomes of two strains of P. fijiensis were sequenced and assembled with the aid of a new genetic linkage map. The 74-Mb genome of P. fijiensis is massively expanded by LTR retrotransposons, making it the largest genome within the Dothideomycetes. The genomes of two closely related members of the Sigatoka disease complex, P. eumusae and P. musae, also show expansion. The P. fijiensis genome will aid in developing fungicide treatment schedules to combat this pathogen and in improving the efficiency of banana breeding programs. A homologue of the Cladosporium fulvum Avr4 effector, PfAvr4, was identified in the P. fijiensis genome. Infiltration of the purified PfAVR4 protein into leaves of the resistant banana variety Calcutta 4 resulted in a hypersensitive-like response, suggesting that Calcutta 4 could carry an unknown resistance gene recognizing PfAVR4.
The evolution of lineage-specific transcription factor binding sites is thought to be a major contributor to the evolution of species-specific traits. However, most computational approaches to study regulatory elements focus on highly conserved sites and rely heavily on multiple sequence alignments. These approaches have limited ability to detect lineage-specific elements that could contribute to species-specific traits. Here, we describe a novel framework that utilizes a birth-death model to trace the evolution of lineage-specific binding sites without relying on detailed cross-species alignments. We applied our method to ChIP-seq data for six transcription factors ( GATA1, SOX2, CTCF, MYC, MAX, ETS1 ) along the lineage toward human after the human-mouse common ancestor. We estimate that a substantial fraction of binding sites ( ∼58–79% for each factor ) in humans have origins since the divergence with mouse. Over 15% of all binding sites are unique to hominids. These elements are often enriched near genes associated with specific pathways and harbor more common SNPs than older binding sites in the human genome. Our results support the ability of our method to identify lineage-specific regulatory elements and help understand their roles in shaping variation in gene regulation across species.
The zebrafish is a vertebrate model for studying how light entrains the endogenous circadian clock. Unlike mammals, most zebrafish tissues are directly exposed to light, leading to local clock entrainment. We investigated how light regulates the expression of the zebrafish period2 ( per2 ) gene, which plays a key role in mediating the effects of light on the circadian clock. Using transgenic fish and stably transfected cell line–based assays, we identified a Light Responsive Module ( LRM ) within the per2 promoter that is both necessary and sufficient for light-driven gene expression and circadian clock regulation. The LRM lies proximal to the transcription start site and contains E- and D-box elements that are critical for its function. While the E-box directs circadian clock regulation by mediating BMAL/CLOCK activity, the D-box confers light-driven expression. The zebrafish homolog of the thyrotroph embryonic factor ( tef ) binds efficiently to the LRM D-box and transactivates expression. We demonstrate that tef mRNA levels are light inducible and that knock-down of tef expression attenuates light-driven transcription from the per2 promoter in vivo. Our results support a model where a light-dependent crosstalk between E- and D-box binding factors is a central determinant of per2 expression.
The actin filament-binding protein coronin plays a crucial role in regulating motility in Plasmodium berghei sporozoites, the highly motile forms of a rodent malaria-causing parasite transmitted by mosquitoes. Here we show that coronin is required for efficient transmission of the parasite from mosquitoes to mice as parasites lacking coronin show defects in salivary gland invasion. Coronin localizes to the periphery of sporozoites in a calcium-dependent but actin-independent manner and actively contributes to parasite motility through actin filament-binding. Importantly, coronin organizes actin filaments for productive motility and is essential for efficient transmission of malaria. We found that protein kinase A contributes to actin filament disassembly and that calcium and cAMP-mediated signaling regulate a switch from rapid parasite motility to host cell invasion by differentially influencing actin dynamics. During the rapid onset of migration, extracellular ligands first trigger intracellular calcium release prior to actin filament formation and coronin relocalization to the rear of the gliding sporozoite.
Amphotericin B ( AmB ) is an important drug used to treat leishmaniasis, a disease caused by Leishmania parasites. However, the potential for resistance to this drug is a considerable threat. Here, we characterised four novel AmB-resistant Leishmania mexicana lines and found that they all exhibited altered sterol biosynthesis and hypersensitivity to pentamidine. Whole genome sequencing revealed that one line had a mutation in the sterol biosynthesis gene sterol C5-desaturase, while three lines had a loss of expression of the sterol C24-methyltransferase ( SMT ) gene, which is responsible for drug resistance and altered sterol biosynthesis. SMT is encoded by two tandem gene copies, which have very different expression levels. We found that reduced overall expression of SMT was associated with loss of the 3’ untranslated region of the dominant gene copy, resulting from structural variations at this locus. These structural variations correlated with the presence of SIDER1 retrotransposon elements that promote multi-gene amplification. We also found that loss of SMT expression was not associated with loss of virulence in primary macrophages or in vivo.
Predictive coding theory suggests that attention optimises the expected precision of predictions by modulating the synaptic gain of prediction error units in the brain. Prediction errors code for the difference between predictions and sensory signals, and attention is thought to increase the selectivity for mismatch information in the neural response to a surprising stimulus. Here, we applied forward encoding models to neural activity recorded via electroencephalography ( EEG ) as human observers performed a simple visual task to test for the effect of attention on both mismatch and feature information in the neural response to surprising stimuli. Participants attended or ignored a periodic stream of gratings, the orientations of which could be either predictable, surprising, or unpredictable. We found that surprising stimuli evoked neural responses that were encoded according to the difference between predicted and observed stimulus features, and that attention facilitated the encoding of this type of information in the brain. These findings advance our understanding of how attention and prediction modulate information processing in the brain, as well as support the theory that attention optimises precision expectations during hierarchical inference by increasing the gain of prediction errors.
Trypanosoma brucei brucei is unable to infect humans because it is sensitive to trypanosome lytic factors ( TLF ) 1 and 2 found in human serum. In contrast, T. b. rhodesiense and T. b. gambiense are able to resist lysis by TLF. T. b. gambiense is further divided into two distinct sub-groups that differ genetically and by human serum resistance phenotypes. Group 1 T. b. gambiense is resistant to TLF-1 due in part to reduced uptake of TLF-1 mediated by reduced expression of the TLF-1 receptor ( the haptoglobin-hemoglobin receptor ( HpHbR ) ) gene. However, group 2 T. b. gambiense exhibits variable resistance to TLF-1. Our data indicate that group 2 T. b. gambiense is innately resistant to the main lytic component of TLF-1, APOL1, which could be based on the same mechanism as group 1 T. b. gambiense. However, group 2 T. b. gambiense variably displays this phenotype and expression does not appear to correlate with a change in expression site or expression of HpHbR. Thus, there are differences in the mechanism of human serum resistance between T. b. gambiense groups 1 and 2.
DNA methylation of the HIV-1 5′ long terminal repeat ( LTR ) has been proposed as a mechanism of transcriptional suppression. However, the role of DNA methylation in the control of HIV-1 latency has not been unambiguously demonstrated. Here, we show that CpG methylation of the HIV-1 5′ LTR is an additional epigenetic restriction mechanism that controls resistance of latent HIV-1 to reactivation signals and thus determines the stability of the HIV-1 latency. In an in vitro model of reactivable latency and in a latent reservoir of HIV-1-infected patients, we found that CpG methylation acts as a late event during establishment of HIV-1 latency and is not required for the initial provirus silencing. The latent reservoir of some aviremic patients contained high proportions of the non-methylated 5′ LTR. In contrast, the latent reservoir of HIV-1-infected individuals without detectable plasma viremia contained HIV-1 promoters and enhancers to be hypermethylated and resistant to reactivation. However, even dense methylation of the HIV-1 5′ LTR did not confer complete resistance to reactivation of latent HIV-1 with some histone deacetylase inhibitors, protein kinase C agonists, TNF-α, and their combinations with 5-aza-2deoxycytidine. Our results explain the ambiguous conclusions emerging from methylation studies in cell lines latently infected with HIV-1 and correlate the in vitro data with data from HIV-1-infected patients.
The Drosophila melanogaster Genetic Reference Panel ( DGRP ) is a collection of 39 inbred lines used to study the relationship between genetic and phenotypic variation. Here, we present a nucleotide resolution catalog of single-nucleotide, multi-nucleotide, and structural variants in the DGRP lines. We identified more than 3. 6 million distinct variants, among which were more than 800, 000 unique insertions, deletions ( indels ), and complex variants ( 1 to 6, 000 bp ). We found that variants themselves are not mutagenic, nor are regions with high variant density particularly mutation-prone. Rather, the elevated SNP density around variants is mainly due to population-level processes. We mapped cis-expression quantitative trait loci ( cis-eQTLs ) for more than 2, 000 genes and found that indels comprise around 10% of all cis-eQTLs and show larger effects than SNP cis-eQTLs. We also identified two-fold more gene associations in males as compared to females and found that most cis-eQTLs are sex-specific, revealing a partial decoupling of the genomic architecture between the sexes. Finally, we performed RNA-seq-based allelic expression imbalance analyses in the offspring of crosses between sequenced lines, which revealed that the majority of strong cis-eQTLs can be validated in heterozygous individuals.
Amplitude cancellation in the rectified surface electromyogram (EMG) signal distorts its correlation with the neural drive to the muscle. The neural drive is the ensemble of discharge timings of all motor neurons innervating the muscle. In this study, we investigated the impact of amplitude cancellation on this correlation using analytical derivations and a computational model of motor neuron activity, force, and the EMG signal. We demonstrated analytically that an ideal rectified EMG signal without amplitude cancellation is superior to the actual rectified EMG signal as an estimator of the neural drive to the muscle. This observation was confirmed by simulations, which showed that the correlation between the neural drive in the 1–30 Hz band and the ideal rectified EMG ( r2 = 0. 59±0. 08 ) was matched by the correlation between the actual rectified EMG and the neural drive only when the level of amplitude cancellation was low ( <40% ) at low contraction levels ( <5% of maximum voluntary contraction force; MVC ). However, this correlation decreased linearly with amplitude cancellation ( r = -0. 83 ) to values of r2 <0. 2 at amplitude cancellation levels >60% ( contraction levels >15% MVC ). The simulations also showed that a stronger neural drive implied a stronger correlation between the rectified EMG and the neural drive, and that amplitude cancellation distorted this correlation mainly for low-frequency components ( <5 Hz ) of the neural drive.
Root growth in Arabidopsis thaliana is inhibited in response to aluminium ( Al ) stress, and auxin is necessary for this inhibition. However, the molecular mechanism controlling this process is largely unknown. Here, we report that YUCCA ( YUC ), which encodes flavin monooxygenase-like proteins, regulates local auxin biosynthesis in the root apex transition zone ( TZ ) in response to Al stress. We show that Al stress up-regulates YUC3/5/7/8/9 in the root-apex TZ, resulting in the accumulation of auxin in the root-apex TZ and root-growth inhibition during the Al stress response. These Al-dependent changes in the regulation of YUCs in the root-apex TZ and YUC-regulated root growth inhibition are dependent on ethylene signalling. Furthermore, ethylene enhances root growth inhibition under Al stress, which is strongly alleviated in yuc mutants or by co-treatment with yucasin, an inhibitor of YUC activity. We also show that ethylene-insensitive 3 ( EIN3 ) is involved in the direct regulation of YUC9 transcription, and that PHYTOCHROME INTERACTING FACTOR4 ( PIF4 ) functions as a transcriptional activator for YUC5/8/9. PIF4 promotes Al-inhibited primary root growth by regulating the local expression of YUCs and auxin signal in the root-apex TZ.
Immunodeficiency viruses, such as simian immunodeficiency virus ( SIV ), can modulate natural killer ( NK ) cell responses by stabilizing interactions between major histocompatibility complex ( MHC ) class I molecules and inhibitory killer-cell immunoglobulin-like receptors ( KIRs ) on NK cells. We investigated the functional implications of these interactions by testing SIV peptides bound by a common MHC class I molecule in rhesus macaques, Mamu-A1*002, for the ability to modulate Mamu-KIR3DL05+ NK cell responses. We found that 28 of 75 SIV peptides bound by Mamu-A1*002 suppressed the cytolytic activity of primary Mamu-KIR3DL05+ NK cells, including three immunodominant CD8+ T cell epitopes previously shown to stabilize Mamu-A1*002 tetramer binding to Mamu-KIR3DL05. Substitutions at C-terminal positions changed inhibitory peptides into disinhibitory peptides, and vice versa, without altering binding to Mamu-A1*002. The functional effects of these peptide variants on NK cell responses also corresponded to their effects on Mamu-A1*002 tetramer binding to Mamu-KIR3DL05. In assays with mixtures of inhibitory and disinhibitory peptides, low concentrations of inhibitory peptides dominated to suppress NK cell responses. Consistent with the inhibition of Mamu-KIR3DL05+ NK cells by viral epitopes presented by Mamu-A1*002, SIV replication was significantly higher in Mamu-A1*002+ CD4+ lymphocytes co-cultured with Mamu-KIR3DL05+ NK cells than with Mamu-KIR3DL05- NK cells. These results demonstrate that viral peptides can differentially affect NK cell responses by modulating MHC class I interactions with inhibitory KIRs, and provide a mechanism by which immunodeficiency viruses may evade NK cell responses.
Nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae ( NTHI ) is a common cause of otitis media ( OM ), a bacterial infection of the middle ear. In this study, we investigated how NTHI adapts to transient nutrient limitation, such as heme-iron restriction, and how this adaptation affects its ability to colonize and persist in the middle ear. We hypothesized that NTHI strains adapted to nutrient limitation are more adept at colonizing and evading host immune responses, resulting in persistence. To test this hypothesis, we isolated NTHI strains from the middle ear effusion ( MEE ) and nasopharynx ( NP ) of children with active OM and sequenced the icc gene, which encodes for 3’, 5’-cyclic adenosine monophosphate ( cAMP ) phosphodiesterase. We identified a single nucleotide polymorphism in icc that abolishes cAMP phosphodiesterase activity in the icc mutant strain. In a preclinical model of NTHI-induced OM, we observed that the icc mutant strain formed significantly more intracellular bacterial communities ( IBCs ) than the parental strain at early stages of infection. In contrast, the parental strain formed more IBCs at later stages of infection, coinciding with the absence of recoverable effusion, suggesting the presence of a mucosal reservoir following resolution of clinical disease. These data provide the first insight into NTHI microevolution during nutritional limitation and demonstrate the formation of IBCs in a preclinical model of chronic OM.
Burkholderia pseudomallei, the causative agent of melioidosis, modulates host iron homeostasis to facilitate iron availability and intracellular survival. Infection of primary macrophages with B. pseudomallei results in downregulation of the iron exporter ferroportin, leading to increased iron availability within macrophages. Exogenous modification of iron export function by hepcidin or iron supplementation by ferric ammonium citrate stimulates B. pseudomallei growth, whereas the iron chelator deferoxamine reduces bacterial survival. Iron-loaded macrophages exhibit a lower expression of NADPH oxidase, iNOS, lipocalin 2, cytokines, and activation of caspase-1. Infection of mice with B. pseudomallei causes a diminished hepatic ferroportin expression, higher iron retention in the liver, and lower iron levels in the serum ( hypoferremia ). In vivo administration of ferric ammonium citrate tends to promote bacterial growth and inflammatory response, whereas limitation of iron availability significantly ameliorates bacterial clearance, attenuates serum cytokine levels, and improves survival of infected mice.
Proteins accomplish their biological function through collective atomic motions. However, identifying collective motions related to a specific protein function from a molecular dynamics trajectory is often non-trivial. We propose a novel technique termed “functional mode analysis” ( FMA ) that aims to detect the collective motion directly related to a particular protein function. FMA is based on an ensemble of structures and an arbitrary “functional quantity” that quantifies the functional state of the protein. The functional quantity can correspond to a geometric, electrostatic, or chemical observable, or any other variable relevant to the function of the protein. FMA detects the collective motion that is maximally correlated to the functional quantity and estimates the motion that displays the largest likelihood to induce a substantial change in the functional quantity. Two correlation measures are applied: the Pearson correlation coefficient, which measures linear correlation only, and the mutual information, which can assess any kind of interdependence. The new approach is illustrated using a number of biomolecules, including a polyalanine-helix, T4 lysozyme, Trp-cage, and leucine-binding protein. In contrast to established methods such as principal component analysis and normal mode analysis, FMA aims to elucidate collective motions directly related to protein function.
Nonconventional introns are a type of intron found in the nuclear genes of euglenids and marine diplonemids that do not have the conserved borders characteristic of spliceosomal introns or the sequence complementary to U1 snRNA at the 5' end. These introns form a stable secondary structure that brings together both exon/intron junctions, but this conformation does not resemble the form of self-splicing or tRNA introns. In the genes studied so far, nonconventional introns have been found to insert at new positions, whereas conventional introns have been found at conserved positions or have been lost. In this work, we examined the order of intron removal from Euglena gracilis transcripts of the tubA and gapC genes, which contain both nonconventional and spliceosomal introns. The relative order of intron excision was compared for pairs of introns belonging to different types, and intermediate products of splicing were analyzed using the PacBio Next Generation Sequencing system. The results show that nonconventional introns are removed in a rapid way but later than spliceosomal introns. Furthermore, the observed accumulation of transcripts with conventional introns removed and nonconventional introns present may suggest the existence of a time gap between the two types of splicing.
Coxsackievirus B3 ( CVB3 ) is an enterovirus that commonly causes a self-limited febrile illness in infants, but severe cases can manifest as acute myocarditis. Although the chronic consequences of mild CVB3 infection are unknown, there is an epidemiologic association between early subclinical infections and late heart failure. Here, we describe a mouse model of juvenile infection with a subclinical dose of CVB3, which showed no evident symptoms immediately following infection or in adult mice. However, following physiological or pharmacologically-induced cardiac stress, juvenile-infected adult mice underwent cardiac hypertrophy and dilation indicative of progression to heart failure. Evaluation of the vasculature in the hearts of adult mice subjected to cardiac stress showed a compensatory increase in CD31+ blood vessel formation, although this effect was suppressed in juvenile-infected mice. Moreover, CVB3 efficiently infected juvenile c-kit+ cells, and cardiac progenitor cell numbers were reduced in the hearts of juvenile-infected adult mice. These results suggest that the exhausted cardiac progenitor cell pool following juvenile CVB3 infection may impair the heart's ability to increase capillary density to adapt to increased load.
Burkholderia pseudomallei, the causative agent of melioidosis, regulates IL-1β and IL-18 production through NLRP3 and pyroptosis via NLRC4. However, the downstream signalling pathways of these receptors and other cell death mechanisms induced during B. pseudomallei infection are not well understood. In this study, we show that caspase-1 processing and pyroptosis are exclusively dependent on NLRC4 in the early phase of macrophage infection, but not on NLRP3. At later time points, caspase-1 activation and cell death are NLRC4-independent. We identified an activation pathway involving caspases-9, -7 and PARP downstream of NLRC4 and caspase-1 in the early phase of infection. Analyses of caspase-1/11-deficient infected macrophages revealed a strong induction of apoptosis, which is dependent on activation of apoptotic initiator and effector caspases. The early activation pathway of caspase-1 in macrophages was markedly reduced or completely abolished after infection with a B. pseudomallei flagellin FliC or a T3SS3 BsaU mutant. Our results indicate a major role for a functional T3SS3 in early NLRC4-mediated caspase-1 activation and pyroptosis and a contribution of late caspase-1-dependent and -independent cell death mechanisms in the pathogenesis of B. pseudomallei infection.
The Arabidopsis KINβγ subunit of the SNF1-related protein kinase 1 ( SnRK1 ) complex plays a critical role in regulating pollen hydration on the stigma by mediating the level of reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) in pollen. We found that KINβγ is a cytoplasm- and nucleus-localized protein in the vegetative cells of pollen grains in Arabidopsis. The pollen of the Arabidopsis kinβγ mutant could not germinate on the stigma, although it germinated normally in vitro. Further analysis revealed that the hydration of kinβγ mutant pollen on the stigma was compromised. However, adding water to the stigma promoted the germination of the mutant pollen in vivo, suggesting that the compromised hydration of the mutant pollen led to its defective germination. We also found that the kinβγ mutant exhibited reduced levels of ROS in pollen. The addition of H2O2 in vitro partially compensated for the reduced water absorption of the mutant pollen, and reducing ROS levels in pollen by overexpressing Arabidopsis CATALASE 3 resulted in compromised hydration of pollen on the stigma. These results indicate that Arabidopsis KINβγ is critical for the regulation of ROS levels by mediating the biogenesis of mitochondria and peroxisomes in pollen, which is required for pollen–stigma interactions during pollination.
RNase III is an enzyme involved in the cleavage of double-stranded RNA in many biological systems. In bacteria, RNase III plays a role in ribosomal RNA maturation and mRNA turnover. However, in the bacterium Bacillus subtilis, RNase III is essential for cell survival. Here, we show that the essential role of RNase III in B. subtilis is to protect it from the expression of toxin genes borne by two prophages, Skin and SPβ, through antisense RNA. These prophages encode two toxin-encoding mRNAs, txpA and yonT, which are sensitive to RNase III. In the absence of these prophages or these two toxin-encoding mRNAs, deletion of the RNase III gene is possible and the growth rate of the resulting strains is hardly affected. We further explore the mechanism of RNase III–mediated decay of the txpA mRNA when paired to its antisense RNA RatA, both in vivo and in vitro. The essential role of RNase III in B. subtilis is not related to its function in rRNA metabolism or in the maturation of the scRNA, part of the essential 4. 5S particle involved in co-translational insertion of proteins in the cellular membrane.
The filarial nematode Brugia malayi is an etiological agent of Lymphatic Filariasis. We have profiled the release of extracellular vesicles ( EVs ) by B. malayi across all intra-mammalian life cycle stages ( microfilariae, L3, L4, adult male and female worms ). We used Nanoparticle Tracking Analysis to quantify and size EVs, revealing discrete vesicle populations and a secretory process that is conserved across the life cycle. Brugia EVs are internalized by murine macrophages with no preference for life stage, suggesting a uniform mechanism for effector molecule trafficking. Proteomic profiling of adult male and female EVs revealed quantitative and qualitative differences in the adult EV proteome, helping to define the biogenesis of Brugia EVs and revealing sexual dimorphic characteristics in immunomodulatory cargo. Finally, we found that ivermectin rapidly inhibits EV release by all Brugia life stages. This effect was also observed in the related filarial nematode Dirofilaria immitis, but not in an ivermectin-unresponsive field isolate of that parasite.
Scabies and impetigo are highly prevalent in the rural Western Province of the Solomon Islands. In a cross-sectional survey of 1908 residents from ten villages, the total unweighted prevalence of scabies was 19. 2% ( 95% CI 17. 5–21. 0 ), with the highest prevalence found in infants < 1 year of age ( 34. 1% ) and children aged 1–4 years ( 25. 7% ). The prevalence of active impetigo was 32. 7% ( 95% CI 30. 6–34. 8 ), with the highest prevalence found in children aged 1–4 years ( 42. 6% ). Scabies infestation was strongly associated with active impetigo infection ( AOR 2. 0, 95% CI 1. 6–2. 6 ), with 41. 1% of active impetigo cases also having scabies. Scabies affected two or more body regions in 80. 9% of participants, and 4. 4% of scabies cases were classified as severe.
Adult neurogenesis in the hippocampus of mice continues to occur throughout life. However, the function of this process remains unclear. In this study, we found a highly significant correlation between cellular proliferation in the hippocampus and the proportions of CD8+ versus CD4+ T lymphocyte subsets. This correlation is driven by shared genetic loci, with the exception of the H-2Ea locus, which has a dominant influence on T cell subsets but no impact on neurogenesis. We also found that CD4+ T cells or subpopulations thereof mediate the effect of T cells on adult neurogenesis. Our results reveal a broader role for T cell function on adult neurogenesis than previously suspected. We analyzed a large stock of outbred mice and found that the relationship between T cells and cellular proliferation in the hippocampus is not an artefact of transgenic or knockout mice, but rather arises from the subtle cues of natural genetic variation. We found that loci that contribute to variation in cell proliferation in the hippocampus also contribute to variation in the relative proportions of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. The correlation accounts for about 6% of the phenotypic variance and is much larger than that found for over 90 other phenotypes.
Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, is a major health problem in Latin America and an emerging infectious disease in the US. In this study, we investigated the protective efficacy of a multi-component DNA-prime/protein-boost vaccine ( TcVac2 ) in a murine model. TcVac2 was constituted of antigens identified by computational analysis of the T. cruzi sequence database and cytokine ( IL-12 and GM-CSF ) expression plasmids. C57BL/6 mice were immunized with antigen-encoding plasmids plus cytokine adjuvants, followed by recombinant proteins, and then challenged with T. cruzi trypomastigotes. TcVac2 induced a strong antigen-specific antibody response and a moderate level of lymphocyte proliferation in mice. Upon challenge infection, TcVac2-vaccinated mice expanded the IgG2b/IgG1 antibodies and elicited a substantial CD8+ T cell response associated with type 1 cytokines ( IFN-γ and TNF-α ) that resulted in control of acute parasite burden. During the chronic phase, antibody response persisted, and the tissue parasitism, inflammation, and fibrosis in heart and skeletal muscle of TcVac2-vaccinated mice were undetectable by histological techniques. In contrast, mice injected with vector or cytokines only responded to T. cruzi by elicitation of a mixed ( type 1/type 2 ) antibody, T cell and cytokine response, and exhibited persistent parasite burden and immunopathology in the myocardium. TcVac2-induced activation of type 1 antibody and lymphocyte responses provided resistance to acute T. cruzi infection, and consequently, prevented the evolution of chronic immunopathology associated with parasite persistence in chagasic hearts.
Genome-wide association studies ( GWAS ) have been successful in identifying disease susceptibility loci for common and complex diseases, including type 1 diabetes ( T1D ). However, a remaining question is whether we can quantify individual disease risk based on genotype data to facilitate personalized prevention and treatment for complex diseases. We propose that sophisticated machine-learning approaches with a large ensemble of markers may improve the performance of disease risk assessment. We applied a Support Vector Machine ( SVM ) algorithm on a GWAS dataset generated on the Affymetrix genotyping platform for T1D and optimized a risk assessment model with hundreds of markers. We tested this model on two independent datasets, one genotyped on the Illumina platform and the other on the Affymetrix platform, resulting in an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve ( AUC ) of ∼0. 84 in both datasets. In contrast, poor performance was achieved when limited to dozens of known susceptibility loci in the SVM model or logistic regression model. Our study suggests that improved disease risk assessment can be achieved by using algorithms that take into account interactions between a large ensemble of markers.
Central memory ( TCM ) CD8+ T cells are a subset of memory T cells that rapidly infiltrate non-lymphoid tissues, such as the skin, to provide protective immunity against viral infections. However, the subsequent fate of TCM CD8+ T cells after entering non-lymphoid tissues is largely unknown. Here, we show that in contrast to naïve CD8+ T cells, TCM CD8+ T cells traffic into the skin independent of CD62L-mediated lymph node re-activation and provide robust protective immunity against Vaccinia virus ( VacV ) infection. TCM, but not effector memory ( TEM ), CD8+ T cells differentiated into functional CD69+/CD103- tissue residents following viral clearance, which was dependent on local recognition of antigen in the skin microenvironment. We also found that memory CD8+ T cells expressed granzyme B after trafficking into the skin and utilized cytolysis to provide protective immunity against VacV infection. Collectively, these findings demonstrate that TCM CD8+ T cells become cytolytic following rapid infiltration of the skin to protect against viral infection and subsequently differentiate into functional CD69+ tissue-residents.
Myosin VI, a minus-end-directed motor, plays a vital role in the enrichment of proteins on the surface of axons in neurons. We show that engineering non-neuronal proteins to interact with Myosin VI causes them to become highly concentrated at the axonal surface in dissociated rat cortical neurons. Furthermore, disruption of either Myosin VI function or expression leads to aberrant dendritic localization of axonal proteins. Myosin VI mediates the enrichment of proteins on the axonal surface at least in part by stimulating dendrite-specific endocytosis, a mechanism that has been shown to underlie the localization of many axonal proteins. In addition, a version of Channelrhodopsin 2 that was engineered to bind to Myosin VI is concentrated at the surface of the axon of cortical neurons in mice in vivo, suggesting that it could be a useful tool for probing circuit structure and function. Together, our results indicate that myosins help shape the polarized distributions of both axonal and dendritic proteins.
Daphnia magna, a freshwater branchiopod crustacean, exhibits environmental sex determination ( ESD ), where parthenogenetic females produce males in response to environmental cues. We report the identification of two Doublesex ( Dsx ) genes, DapmaDsx1 and DapmaDsx2, in D. magna. DapmaDsx1 is responsible for male trait development when expressed during ESD. The domain organization of DapmaDsx1 is similar to that of Dsx from insects, which are thought to be the sister group of branchiopod crustaceans. However, the molecular basis for sexually dimorphic expression of DapmaDsx1 is different from that of insects. DapmaDsx1 exhibits sexually dimorphic differences in the abundance of its transcripts, which are primarily detected in male-specific structures during embryogenesis. Knock-down of DapmaDsx1 in male embryos resulted in the production of female traits, whereas ectopic expression of DapmaDsx1 in female embryos resulted in the development of male-like phenotypes. These results establish DapmaDsx1 as a key regulator of the male phenotype. Our findings reveal how ESD is implemented by selective expression of a fundamental genetic component that is functionally conserved in animals using genetic sex determination ( GSD ).
Herpes simplex virus type 2 ( HSV-2 ) is a major cause of genital herpes, a sexually transmitted infection that can lead to pain, neonatal herpes, and an increased risk of HIV acquisition and transmission. We evaluated the immunogenicity and efficacy of a trivalent HSV-2 subunit antigen vaccine in rhesus macaques and guinea pigs. The vaccine contains glycoproteins C, D, and E ( gC2, gD2, gE2 ) to block virus entry by gD2 and immune evasion by gC2 and gE2. In rhesus macaques, the trivalent vaccine induced plasma and mucosa neutralizing antibodies, antibodies that block gC2 and gE2 immune evasion activities, and stimulated CD4 T cell responses. After intravaginal challenge, a self-limited vaginal infection of brief duration was detected in naïve, but not in trivalent immunized macaques. In guinea pigs, the trivalent and trivalent + gD2 groups were 97% and 99% efficacious, respectively, in preventing genital lesions and both outperformed gD2 alone. Shedding of replication competent virus occurred on fewer days in the trivalent than gD2 immunized animals, while the trivalent + gD2 group had no shedding of replication competent virus. Overall, the trivalent group had genital lesions on < 1% days and shedding of replication competent virus on 0. 2% days.
Chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by sequencing ( ChIP-seq ) is a high throughput assay for profiling transcription factor ( TF ) binding and histone modifications. ChIP-seq experiments generate millions of short reads ( 50–100 bps ) that are typically mapped to a reference genome. However, reads from highly repetitive regions of the genome, such as segmental duplications, are difficult to map since they can map to multiple locations. Standard analytical methods discard such multi-mapping reads or are prone to large false positive and negative rates. We developed Perm-seq, a prior-enhanced read allocation method for ChIP-seq experiments, that can allocate multi-mapping reads in highly repetitive regions of the genome with high accuracy. Perm-seq capitalizes on DNase-seq and histone ChIP-seq data and read counts of local neighbourhoods of mapping locations to discriminate between multiple alignment positions of the same read. We comprehensively evaluated Perm-seq and found that our prior-enhanced approach significantly improves multi-read allocation accuracy over approaches that do not utilize additional data types. We applied Perm-seq to 64 ENCODE ChIP-seq datasets from GM12878 and K562 cells and identified many novel protein-DNA interactions in segmental duplication regions. Our analysis reveals that although the protein-DNA interactions sites are evolutionarily less conserved in repetitive regions, they share the overall sequence characteristics of the protein-DNA interactions in non-repetitive regions.
Schistosomiasis, a parasitic infection affecting 218 million people worldwide, has been associated with increased susceptibility to HIV-1 infection and impaired ability to control HIV-1 replication. We conducted a nested case-control study within a large population-based survey of HIV-1 transmission in Tanzania to determine whether schistosome infection affects susceptibility to HIV-1 acquisition and HIV-1 viral load at the time of HIV-1 seroconversion. Approximately 40% of the population had Schistosoma mansoni infection, and 2% had S. haematobium infection. We tested for schistosome antigens in the pre- and post-HIV-1-seroconversion blood spots of 73 HIV-1 seroconverters and 265 matched controls who did not acquire HIV-1. We found that women with schistosome infections had a higher odds of HIV-1 acquisition than those without ( adjusted OR = 2. 8 [1. 2–6. 6], p = 0. 019 ). In contrast, schistosome-infected men did not have an increased odds of HIV-1 acquisition ( adjusted OR = 0. 7 [0. 3–1. 8], p = 0. 42 ). We also found that HIV-1 seroconverters with schistosomiasis had higher HIV-1 viral loads at the time of seroconversion than those without schistosomiasis ( 4. 4 [3. 9–4. 6] log10 copies/mL versus 3. 7 [3. 2–4. 3], p = 0. 017 ).
Ribosomal DNA ( rDNA ) is one of the most variable regions in the human genome with respect to copy number. Despite its importance for cellular function, virtually nothing is known about what governs rDNA copy number, stability, and sequence in the mammalian genome. We applied computational and droplet digital PCR approaches to measure rDNA copy number in normal and cancer states in human and mouse genomes. We find that copy number and sequence can change in cancer genomes. Counterintuitively, human cancer genomes show a loss of copies, accompanied by global copy number co-variation. The sequence can also be more variable in the cancer genome. Cancer genomes with lower copies have mutational evidence of mTOR hyperactivity. The PTEN phosphatase is a tumor suppressor that is critical for genome stability and a negative regulator of the mTOR kinase pathway. Consistent with human cancer genomes, hematopoietic cancer stem cells from a Pten-/- mouse model for leukemia have lower rDNA copy number than normal tissue, despite increased proliferation, rRNA production, and protein synthesis. Loss of copies occurs early and is associated with hypersensitivity to DNA damage. Therefore, copy loss is a recurrent feature in cancers associated with mTOR activation.
Bacterial growth, death, and spread within mammalian hosts are complex processes that cannot be fully understood by studying a single bacterial population. Here, we report on the application of sophisticated experimental approaches to map spatiotemporal population dynamics of bacteria during an infection. We analyzed simultaneous infections with tagged Salmonella enterica populations ( wild-type isogenic tagged strains [WITS] ) in wild-type and gene-targeted mice. WITS are phenotypically identical but can be distinguished and enumerated by quantitative PCR, making it possible to estimate bacterial death rate based on the disappearance of strains through time. This multidisciplinary approach allowed us to establish the timing, relative occurrence, and immune control of key infection parameters in a true host–pathogen combination. Our analyses support a model in which shortly after infection, concomitant death and rapid bacterial replication lead to the establishment of independent bacterial subpopulations in different organs, a process controlled by host antimicrobial mechanisms. Later, decreased microbial mortality leads to an exponential increase in the number of bacteria that spread locally, with subsequent mixing of bacteria between organs via bacteraemia and further stochastic selection. This approach provides an unprecedented outlook on the pathogenesis of S. enterica infections, illustrating the complex spatial and stochastic effects that drive an infectious disease.
Binocular 3D motion perception is an ill-posed inverse problem, and existing processing schemes such as interocular velocity difference ( IOVD ), changing disparity over time ( CDOT ), and joint encoding of motion and disparity ( JEMD ) do not provide a general solution. Instead, we suggest that local velocity constraints in combination with binocular disparity and other depth cues provide a more flexible framework for the solution of the inverse problem. In the context of the aperture problem, we derive predictions from two plausible default strategies: ( 1 ) the vector normal prefers slow motion in 3D and ( 2 ) the cyclopean average is based on slow motion in 2D. Predicting perceived motion directions for ambiguous line motion provides an opportunity to distinguish between these strategies of 3D motion processing. Our theoretical results suggest that velocity constraints and disparity from feature tracking are needed to solve the inverse problem of 3D motion perception. We propose that motion and disparity input are processed in parallel and integrated late in the visual processing hierarchy.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa secretes the O-acetylated exopolysaccharide alginate to form a protective biofilm matrix during chronic infection in the lungs of cystic fibrosis patients. The O-acetylation of alginate is a common modification used by pathogenic organisms to protect against external forces. Four proteins have been implicated in the O-acetylation of alginate: AlgF, AlgI, AlgJ, and AlgX. We determined the structure of AlgJ to 1. 83 Å resolution and found that it is a SGNH hydrolase-like protein with a conserved catalytic triad composed of D190, H192, and S288. We demonstrated that AlgJ exhibits acetylesterase activity in vitro and identified residues in the AlgJ signature motifs that form an extensive network of interactions critical for O-acetylation of alginate in vivo. We compared the abilities of AlgJ and AlgX to bind and acetylate alginate using two different electrospray ionization mass spectrometry ( ESI-MS ) assays. We found that AlgJ exhibits either weak or no detectable polymer binding while AlgX binds polymannuronic acid specifically in a length-dependent manner. Additionally, AlgX was capable of utilizing the surrogate acetyl-donor 4-nitrophenyl acetate to catalyze the O-acetylation of polymannuronic acid. Our results suggest that AlgJ and AlgX have separate and distinct roles in O-acetylation and place AlgX as the terminal acetyltransferase in the alginate acetylation pathway.
Candida albicans is one of the most common causes of fungal infections in humans and is responsible for a significant number of deaths. This pathogen is able to evade detection by the innate immune system by masking its cell wall component β ( 1, 3 ) -glucan with an outer layer of heavily glycosylated mannoproteins. However, mutations or drugs that disrupt the cell wall can lead to the exposure of β ( 1, 3 ) -glucan, which can be detected by innate immune cells through receptors such as Dectin-1. Previous studies have shown that the phospholipid phosphatidylserine ( PS ) plays a role in β ( 1, 3 ) -glucan masking, and a PS synthase knockout mutant ( cho1Δ/Δ ) exhibits increased exposure of β ( 1, 3 ) -glucan. In this study, we investigated the role of the Cek1 MAPK pathway in β ( 1, 3 ) -glucan exposure. We found that Cek1 is constitutively activated in the cho1Δ/Δ mutant and acts downstream of the small GTPases Cdc42 and Rho1. We also found that hyperactivation of Rho1 in wild-type cells increases β ( 1, 3 ) -glucan exposure and activation of both Cek1 and Mkc1. Furthermore, hyperactivation of the MAP kinase kinase kinase Ste11 in wild-type cells leads to Cek1 activation and increased β ( 1, 3 ) -glucan exposure. These results suggest that upregulation of the Cek1 MAPK pathway causes β ( 1, 3 ) -glucan exposure and may be responsible for unmasking in the cho1Δ/Δ mutant.
Alzheimer's disease ( AD ) and related dementias are a major public health challenge for which we need additional insight into molecular pathogenesis. We performed a genome-wide association study and analysis of known genetic risk loci for AD dementia using neuropathologic data from 4, 914 brain autopsies. Neuropathologic data were used to define clinico-pathologic AD dementia or controls, assess core neuropathologic features of AD ( neuritic plaques, NPs; neurofibrillary tangles, NFTs ), and evaluate commonly co-morbid neuropathologic changes: cerebral amyloid angiopathy ( CAA ), Lewy body disease ( LBD ), hippocampal sclerosis of the elderly ( HS ), and vascular brain injury ( VBI ). Genome-wide significance was observed for clinico-pathologic AD dementia, NPs, NFTs, CAA, and LBD with a number of variants in and around the apolipoprotein E gene ( APOE ). We also discovered new genetic associations with specific neuropathologic features and aligned known genetic risk for AD dementia with specific neuropathologic changes in the largest brain autopsy study of AD and related dementias.
Urea is a protein denaturant that has been used for decades in the study of protein folding/unfolding; however, after many years of research the ultimate reasons of the denaturing properties of urea remain elusive. By analyzing a set of 30 proteins through extensive molecular dynamics simulations in denaturant, we derived robust rules for urea unfolding that are valid at the proteome level. Urea concentrates in the first solvation shell of quasi-native proteins, but with a density lower than that of the fully unfolded state. The presence of urea does not alter the spontaneous vibration pattern of proteins. Instead, it reduces the magnitude of such vibrations, leading to a counterintuitive slow down of the atomic-motions that opposes unfolding. Urea stickiness and slow diffusion is crucial for unfolding. Long residence urea molecules placed around the hydrophobic core are crucial to stabilize partially open structures generated by thermal fluctuations. Our simulations indicate that although urea does not favor the formation of partially open microstates, it is not a mere spectator of unfolding that simply displaces to the right of the folded←→unfolded equilibrium. On the contrary, urea actively favors unfolding: it selects and stabilizes partially unfolded microstates, slowly driving the protein conformational ensemble far from the native one and also from the conformations sampled during thermal unfolding.
Dengue disease is a major public health priority in Colombia, and a systematic literature review was conducted to describe the epidemiology of the disease in the country between 2000 and 2011. The review included 30 studies published in English or Spanish that met the inclusion criteria. The epidemiology of dengue disease in Colombia was characterized by a stable “baseline” annual number of dengue fever cases, with major outbreaks in 2001–2003 and 2010. The geographical spread of dengue disease cases showed a steady increase, with most of the country affected by the 2010 outbreak. The majority of dengue disease cases recorded during the review period were among those <15 years of age. The incidence of dengue disease was generally low in south and south-east Colombia, which has the lowest population density in the country. There was an apparent increase during the review period in the geographical area from which dengue disease cases were reported, with a 90% increase in the number of municipalities between 2000 and 2010. The review highlights the record number of cases of non-severe dengue disease reported for 2010 in Colombia. Gaps in epidemiological knowledge regarding dengue disease in Colombia were identified, including rates of asymptomatic dengue virus infection, primary and secondary dengue virus infections, risk factors for severity, and under-reporting of dengue disease.
Tegumentary leishmaniasis ( TL ) is a disease of the skin and/or mucosal tissues caused by Leishmania parasites. TL patients may concurrently carry other pathogens, which may influence the clinical outcome of TL. This review focuses on the frequency of TL coinfections in human populations, interactions between Leishmania and other pathogens in animal models and human subjects, and implications of TL coinfections for clinical practice. We searched MEDLINE and other databases and included 73 records: 21 experimental studies in animals and 52 studies about human subjects. Several reports describe the frequency of Trypanosoma cruzi coinfection in TL patients in Argentina ( about 41% ) and the frequency of helminthiasis in TL patients in Brazil ( 15% to 88% ). Different hypotheses have been explored about mechanisms of interaction between different microorganisms, but no clear answers emerge. Such interactions may involve innate immunity coupled with regulatory networks that affect quality and quantity of acquired immune responses.
Natural polymorphisms in the transporter associated with antigen processing 2 ( Tap2 ) gene in the rat major histocompatibility complex ( MHC ) influence negative selection and CD4∶CD8 lineage commitment. We mapped Quantitative Trait Loci ( QTLs ) associated with variation in MHC class I and II protein expression and the CD4∶CD8 T cell ratio in outbred Heterogeneous Stock rats. We identified 10 QTLs across the genome and found that QTLs for the individual traits colocalized within a region spanning the MHC. We then generated a large panel of MHC-recombinant congenic strains and refined the QTLs to two adjacent intervals of ∼0. 25 Mb in the MHC-I and II regions, respectively. An interaction between these intervals affected MHC class I expression as well as negative selection and lineage commitment of CD8 single-positive ( SP ) thymocytes. We mapped this effect to the Tap2 gene in the MHC-II region and the classical MHC class I gene ( s ) ( RT1-A ) in the MHC-I region. This interaction was revealed by a recombination between RT1-A and Tap2, which occurred in 0. 2% of the rats. Variants of Tap2 have previously been shown to influence the antigenicity of MHC class I molecules by altering the MHC class I ligandome. Our results show that a restricted peptide repertoire on MHC class I molecules leads to reduced negative selection of CD8SP cells.
Chagas disease, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, is a major public health concern in Latin America. In Europe, Spain is the country with the highest expected number of infected patients due to its large number of migrants from Latin America. We analyzed the Spanish National Health System’s Hospital Discharge Records Database ( CMBD ) to describe the evolution of Chagas disease in Spain from 1997 to 2011. We identified 1729 hospitalizations related to Chagas disease, of which 31. 6% were re-admissions. Hospitalization rates increased from 18 to 242. 8 per 100, 000 population between the two study periods ( 1997–2004 and 2005–2011 ). The majority of hospitalizations ( 75. 3% ) were related to Chagas disease without organ complications, while 23. 4% were related to Chagas disease with organ complications, mostly due to heart complications ( 81. 7% ). We found that being male, aged 45–64 years, and having a hospitalization cost above the median ( 3, 065 euros ) were associated with hospitalizations related to Chagas disease with organ complications. The number of detected infections increased in Spain since 2005, and the majority of patients were asymptomatic women of fertile age.
Psoriasis is a complex disease that has been associated with hundreds of genetic markers; however, the “missing heritability” of the disease remains elusive. We present BlocBuster, a novel systems-level approach that efficiently constructs genome-wide, allele-specific networks that accurately segregate homogenous combinations of genetic factors, tests the associations of these combinations with the given phenotype, and rigorously validates the results using a series of unbiased validation methods. We applied BlocBuster to analyze psoriasis, discovering a combinatorial pattern with an odds ratio of 3. 64 and Bonferroni-corrected p-value of 5. 01×10−16. This pattern was replicated in independent data, reflecting the robustness of the method. BlocBuster identified a bloc of SNP alleles that is significantly associated with psoriasis and improves upon previous results by supplying a precise allelic pattern within the major histocompatibility complex ( MHC ). The associated bloc lies within an exceptionally diverse genomic region and the occurrence of 17 SNP alleles in a single pattern with strong psoriatic association provides precise information for focusing future investigations. Our network-based result is advantageous over the results from conventional genome-wide association studies ( GWAS ).
Agenesis of the corpus callosum ( ACC ), cerebellar hypoplasia ( CBLH ), and polymicrogyria ( PMG ) are severe congenital brain malformations with largely undiscovered causes. We conducted a large-scale chromosomal copy number variation ( CNV ) discovery effort in 255 ACC, 220 CBLH, and 147 PMG patients, and 2, 349 controls. We found that significantly more ACC patients had rare genic CNVs over one megabase compared to controls ( p = 1. 48×10−3; odds ratio [OR] = 3. 19; 95% confidence interval [CI] = 1. 89–5. 39 ). Rare genic CNVs were those that impacted at least one gene in less than 1% of the combined population of patients and controls. We also found that significantly more ACC patients had rare CNVs impacting over 20 genes compared to controls ( p = 0. 01; OR = 2. 95; 95% CI = 1. 69–5. 18 ). Independent qPCR confirmation showed that 9. 4% of ACC patients had de novo CNVs, which preferentially overlapped de novo CNVs previously observed in patients with autism spectrum disorders ( p = 3. 06×10−4; OR = 7. 55; 95% CI = 2. 40–23. 72 ).
Regeneration is a complex process that requires the precise integration of multiple cues to initiate proliferation, direct differentiation, and re-pattern tissues to the proper size and scale. Here, we show that the effector of the Hippo signalling cascade, Yorkie ( Yki ), plays a key role in restricting early injury responses in the freshwater planarian, Schmidtea mediterranea. In Yki RNAi regenerating animals, wound responses are hyper-activated such that both stem cell proliferation and the transcriptional wound response program are heightened and prolonged. We also show that Yki RNAi animals have expanded epidermal and muscle cell populations, which we hypothesize are the increased sources of wound-induced genes. Furthermore, we show that in Yki RNAi animals, the sensing of the size of an injury by eyes or the pharynx is not appropriate, and the brain, gut, and midline cannot remodel or scale correctly to the size of the regenerating fragment. Our results suggest that Yki functions as a key molecule that can integrate multiple aspects of the injury response, including proliferation, apoptosis, injury-induced transcription, and patterning.
EV71 infection results in the upregulation of exosome secretion and the differential packaging of viral genomic RNA and miR-146a, a cellular miRNA that suppresses type I interferon response. We found that miR-146a is preferentially co-packaged with EV71 genomic RNA in exosomes and that exosomal miR-146a can be transferred to and suppress type I interferon expression in the recipient cell, thus facilitating the viral replication. The exosomal viral RNA can be transferred to and replicate in a new target cell while the exosomal miR-146a suppresses type I interferon response in the target cell. Moreover, we found that the IFN-stimulated gene factors ( ISGs ), BST-2/tetherin, are involved in regulating EV71-induced upregulation of exosome secretion. In vivo, exosomal viral RNA exhibits differential tissue accumulation compared to free virus particles.
Parkinson's disease ( PD ) is a neurodegenerative disorder caused by mutations in several genes, including PTEN-induced kinase 1 ( PINK1 ) and Parkin. PINK1 is a serine/threonine kinase with a predicted mitochondrial target sequence and a probable transmembrane domain at the N-terminus, while Parkin is a RING-finger protein with ubiquitin-ligase ( E3 ) activity. PINK1 is required for mitochondrial homeostasis, and mutations in PINK1 cause early-onset PD. Parkin has been suggested to function downstream of the PINK1 signalling pathway based on genetic studies in Drosophila. However, how PINK1 and Parkin regulate mitochondrial activity is largely unknown. Here, we report that a PINK1-binding mitochondrial protein, phosphoglycerate mutase 5 ( PGAM5 ), modulates the PINK1 pathway in Drosophila. Loss of PGAM5 can suppress the muscle degeneration, motor defects, and shorter lifespan that result from PINK1 inactivation and that can be attributed to mitochondrial degeneration. However, PGAM5 inactivation fails to modulate the phenotypes of Parkin mutant flies. Conversely, ectopic expression of PGAM5 exacerbated the PINK1 and Parkin phenotypes. These results suggest that PGAM5 negatively regulates the PINK1 pathway related to maintenance of the mitochondria and that PGAM5 acts between PINK1 and Parkin, or functions independently of Parkin downstream of PINK1.
Mycobacterium ulcerans is the causative agent of Buruli ulcer ( BU ), a chronic necrotizing human skin disease associated with the production of the cytotoxic macrolide exotoxin mycolactone. Despite extensive research, the type of immune responses elicited against this pathogen and the effector functions conferring protection against BU are not yet fully understood. In this study, we investigated the role of interferon-γ ( IFNγ ) in early host immune defense against M. ulcerans infection using an experimental BU mouse model. We found that IFNγ is a critical regulator of early host immune defense against M. ulcerans infections. IFNγ knockout mice displayed a faster progression of the infection compared to wild-type mice, with faster and more extensive tissue necrosis and oedema formation, as well as a significantly higher bacterial burden after five weeks of infection. This indicates that mice lacking IFNγ have a reduced capacity to kill intracellular bacilli during the early intra-macrophage growth phase of M. ulcerans. Our results demonstrate a prominent role of IFNγ in early defense against M. ulcerans infection and support the view that concepts for vaccine development against tuberculosis may also be valid for BU.
Reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) production in mitochondria is a major cause of systemic diseases. However, the mechanism of hypoxia-induced change in ROS production is not fully understood. We developed a new methodology to mathematically analyze this mechanism by constructing a system of differential equations to model electron transport in mitochondria. This approach allowed us to identify two steady state modes of operation ( bistability ) of respiratory complex III at the same microenvironmental conditions. Normally, complex III is in a low ROS producing mode, but temporal anoxia can switch it to a high ROS producing state, which persists after the return to normal oxygen supply. This bistability explains the mechanism of anoxia-induced cell damage. We qualitatively validated this prediction experimentally and found that anoxia can induce a significant increase in ROS production upon the resumption of oxygen supply. Our method of modeling can be widely used in systems biology studies and may enable novel therapeutic strategies for oxidative stress.
The terminal gap gene huckebein ( hkb ) plays a crucial role in the patterning system of Drosophila melanogaster. Gap genes constitute the first zygotic step in a regulatory cascade that leads to the determination of body segments along the anterior-posterior body axis during the blastoderm stage. Here, we use an integrative, systems-level approach to investigate the regulatory effect of hkb on gap gene expression. We present quantitative expression data for the Hkb protein, which enable us to include hkb in gap gene circuit models. These models are mathematical representations of gene networks used to extract regulatory information from spatial expression data. We show that considering variability in the data combined with analysis of parameter determinability significantly improves the biological relevance and consistency of the approach. Our models are in agreement with earlier results and extend them in two important respects. First, we show that hkb is involved in the regulation of the posterior hunchback ( hb ) domain, but does not have any other essential function. Second, our models are able to reproduce mutants of terminal gap genes, while previously published models were unable to reproduce any null mutants correctly. As a consequence, our models now capture the expression dynamics of all posterior gap genes and some variational properties of the system correctly.
Brucellosis is an important zoonotic disease that causes significant economic losses worldwide. Currently, there is no effective immunotherapy for Brucellosis or a biomarker to monitor the efficacy of therapy. We report here the successful immunotherapy of bovine Brucellosis by phage lysates of Brucella abortus vaccine strains S19 and RB51. Phage lysates retain maximum immunogenicity as opposed to killing by heat or chemicals. In this study, we explored the therapeutic potential of phage lysates of S19 and RB51 in Brucellosis in adult cattle and employed Brucella specific RNA in plasma as a biomarker to monitor the effect of therapy in the live animal in a non-destructive and minimally invasive manner. The immunotherapeutic agents ( phage lysates of Brucella abortus strain 19 and RB51 ) were injected only once in the Brucellosis affected cattle at a dose of 2 ml subcutaneously. Trials of phage lysate therapy were carried out on 21 naturally Brucellosis affected adult cows. The Brucellosis positive adult cows were divided into four groups: Group I animals ( n = 6 ) were immunized with Brucella abortus S19 lysate only, Group II animals ( n = 5 ) were immunized with Brucella abortus RB51 lysate only, Group III animals ( n = 5 ) were immunized with cocktail of S19 and RB51 lysates, and Group IV animals ( n = 5 ) were not immunized. A single dose of 2 ml of phage lysate of Brucella abortus attenuated strain RB51 alone or in combination with lysate of Brucella abortus attenuated strain S19 administered subcutaneously in naturally Brucellosis infected adult cows successfully eliminated virulent Brucella abortus from the infected cattle in 3 months.
Here we show that Cdk2 plays a specific role in orchestrating the DNA damage response in human cells. By replacing wild-type Cdk2 with a mutant version sensitized to inhibition by bulky adenine analogs, we found that transient, selective inhibition of Cdk2 after exposure to ionizing radiation ( IR ) enhances cell-killing. This indicates that Cdk2 activity is required for an effective DNA damage response. We also show that Cdk2 phosphorylates the Nijmegen Breakage Syndrome gene product Nbs1, a component of the conserved Mre11-Rad50-Nbs1 complex required for normal DNA damage repair and checkpoint signaling. This phosphorylation is dependent on a consensus CDK recognition site at Ser432 of Nbs1. In vivo, selective inhibition of Cdk2 delayed and diminished Nbs1-Ser432 phosphorylation during S phase, and mutation of Ser432 to Ala or Asp increased IR–sensitivity. Therefore, we have uncovered a non-redundant requirement for Cdk2 activity in response to DNA damage and a specific target of Cdk2 within the DNA repair machinery.
Genome-wide association ( GWA ) studies have identified many genetic loci associated with hematological and cardiovascular traits, but the functional mechanisms underlying these associations are not well understood. We applied the formaldehyde-assisted isolation of regulatory elements ( FAIRE ) method to map open chromatin in a megakaryocytic and an erythroblastoid cell line at 62 genetic loci associated with hematological and cardiovascular traits. We found that the two cell types exhibit distinct patterns of open chromatin and that cell-specific open chromatin can guide the finding of functional variants. We identified an open chromatin region at chromosome 7q22. 3 in megakaryocytes but not erythroblasts, which harbors the common non-coding sequence variant rs342293 known to be associated with platelet volume and function. Resequencing of this open chromatin region in 643 individuals provided strong evidence that rs342293 is the only putative causative variant in this region. We demonstrated that the C- and G-alleles of rs342293 differentially bind the transcription factor EVI1, affecting PIK3CG gene expression in platelets and macrophages. We also identified a protein–protein interaction network including up- and down-regulated genes in Pik3cg knockout mice, indicating that PIK3CG is associated with gene pathways involved in platelet membrane biogenesis and thrombus formation.
Respiratory rhythm generation in the pre-Bötzinger complex ( pre-BötC ) has been proposed to be dependent on a persistent sodium current ( INaP ). However, the effects of pharmacological blockade of INaP have been difficult to interpret due to the lack of understanding of the mechanisms of action of commonly used blockers. Using computer simulations, we demonstrate that the effects of INaP blockade by tetrodotoxin ( TTX ) and riluzole ( RZ ) depend on the pharmacological mechanism of action and network dynamics. TTX directly obstructs the Na+ pore, whereas RZ shifts INaP inactivation in the hyperpolarizing direction. We show that RZ may fail to effectively block INaP in the intact network due to the specific pharmacological mechanism of action and transient inhibitory network interactions, and that pre-I bursting in the intact network is likely dependent on both inhibitory network interactions and INaP. Importantly, we predict that experimental TTX application in the intact network will terminate respiratory rhythmicity. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for seemingly contradictory experimental results from in vitro studies of INaP block and illustrate the importance of considering mechanism when interpreting and simulating data relating to pharmacological blockade.
Gastric cancer ( GC ) is one of the leading causes of cancer-related deaths worldwide. In this study, we investigated the role of miR-218 in the regulation of GC metastasis. We found that miR-218 expression is decreased in metastatic GC and that its host gene, Slit3, is also downregulated. However, miR-218 negatively regulates Robo1, one of the Slit receptors, thus establishing a negative feedback loop. When miR-218 levels are low, Robo1 is upregulated, leading to the activation of the Slit-Robo1 pathway through the interaction between Robo1 and Slit2. This results in the promotion of tumor cell invasion and metastasis. In contrast, the restoration of miR-218 suppresses Robo1 expression and inhibits tumor cell invasion and metastasis both in vitro and in vivo. Our results provide new insights into the metastatic mechanisms in GC and reveal a novel regulatory mechanism of receptor signaling.
Atherosclerosis is a major risk factor for coronary artery disease and stroke. Despite the effectiveness of plasma lipid lowering regimes in halting atherosclerosis lesion development and reducing morbidity and mortality, the transcriptional response in the atherosclerotic lesion mediating these beneficial effects has not yet been carefully investigated. We performed transcriptional profiling at 10-week intervals in atherosclerosis-prone mice with human-like hypercholesterolemia and a genetic switch to lower plasma lipoproteins ( Ldlr−/−Apo100/100 Mttpflox/flox Mx1-Cre ). Atherosclerotic lesions progressed slowly at first, then expanded rapidly, and plateaued after advanced lesions formed. Analysis of lesion expression profiles indicated that accumulation of lipid-poor macrophages reached a point that led to the rapid expansion phase with accelerated foam-cell formation and inflammation. Genetic lowering of plasma cholesterol prevented the formation of advanced plaques and parallel transcriptional profiling of the atherosclerotic arterial wall identified 37 cholesterol-responsive genes mediating this effect. Validation by siRNA-inhibition in macrophages incubated with acetylated-LDL revealed a network of eight cholesterol-responsive atherosclerosis genes regulating cholesterol-ester accumulation. We have identified a network of atherosclerosis genes that in response to plasma cholesterol-lowering prevents the formation of advanced plaques. This network should be of interest for the development of novel atherosclerosis therapies.
The cell envelope of Gram-negative bacteria is a formidable barrier that is difficult for antimicrobial drugs to penetrate. To combat this, a detailed mechanistic understanding of envelope assembly is required. We developed a simple, quantitative, and high-throughput assay for mutants with envelope biogenesis defects and used it to screen an ordered single-gene deletion library of Escherichia coli. The screen was robust and correctly identified numerous mutants known to be involved in envelope assembly and implicated 102 genes of unknown function as encoding factors that likely impact envelope biogenesis.
