One of these factors, ElyC ( YcbC ), was characterized further and shown to play a critical role in the metabolism of the essential lipid carrier used for the biogenesis of cell wall and other bacterial surface polysaccharides. Further analysis of the function of ElyC and other hits identified in our screen is likely to uncover a wealth of new information about the biogenesis of the Gram-negative envelope and the vulnerabilities in the system suitable for drug targeting. The screening assay described here should be readily adaptable to other organisms to study the biogenesis of different envelope architectures.
Multivariable dynamics in biological systems, such as pattern formation in Drosophila, can be studied using a variety of techniques, each of which captures unique features of the system. However, the integration of heterogeneous datasets into an integrated view of multivariable dynamics remains a challenge. Here, we demonstrate that heterogeneous data fusion can be successfully implemented within a semi-supervised learning framework that exploits the intrinsic geometry of high-dimensional datasets. We illustrate our approach using a dataset from studies of pattern formation in Drosophila. The result is a continuous trajectory that reveals the joint dynamics of gene expression, subcellular protein localization, protein phosphorylation, and tissue morphogenesis. Our approach can be readily adapted to other imaging modalities and forms a starting point for further steps of data analytics and modeling of biological dynamics. By posing the task of data fusion as a semi-supervised learning problem, we obtained a closed-form expression for the estimated values of all variables using harmonic extension. The reconstructed trajectories provide the basis for the more advanced mechanistic studies of multivariable processes responsible for the highly reproducible dynamics of developmental pattern formation.
Snake venom hemorrhagic metalloproteinases ( SVMPs ) of the PI, PII and PIII classes were compared in terms of tissue localization and their ability to hydrolyze basement membrane components in vivo. Immunohistochemical analyses revealed that PII and PIII SVMPs co-localized with type IV collagen in capillaries, arterioles and post-capillary venules to a higher extent than PI SVMP, which showed a more widespread distribution in the tissue. The patterns of hydrolysis by these three SVMPs of laminin, type VI collagen and nidogen in vivo greatly differ, whereas the three enzymes showed a similar pattern of degradation of type IV collagen. This supports the concept that hydrolysis of type IV collagen is critical for the destabilization of microvessel structure leading to hemorrhage. Proteomic analysis of wound exudate revealed similarities and differences between the action of the three SVMPs. Higher extent of proteolysis was observed for the PI enzyme regarding several extracellular matrix components and fibrinogen, whereas exudates from mice injected with PII and PIII SVMPs had higher amounts of some intracellular proteins. Our results provide novel clues for understanding the mechanisms by which SVMPs induce damage to the microvasculature and generate hemorrhage.
In Drosophila melanogaster, the expression of the homeotic gene abd-A is repressed by the noncoding RNA iab-8 in the epidermis of the eighth abdominal segment, but not in the central nervous system. The iab-8 RNA produces a micro RNA that acts in trans to repress abd-A, as well as a second, redundant repression mechanism that acts only in cis. Transcriptional interference with the abd-A promoter is the most likely mechanism of this cis-repression. The iab-8 RNA interferes with an abd-A enhancer that lies downstream of the iab-4186 breakpoint, and the major poly ( A ) site of the iab-8 RNA lies only 1. 1 kb upstream of the initiation site of abd-A. The primary transcript of the iab-8 RNA likely continues past its poly ( A ) addition site. The iab-8 RNA can only repress the copy of abd-A on the chromosome from which it is transcribed, as shown by the lack of ABD-A misexpression in the CNS of PS13 embryos homozygous for the ΔmiR-iab-8 deletion over DfP9. Thus, there are two mechanisms by which the iab-8 RNA represses abd-A. Rearrangement breaks that truncate the iab-8 RNA near its start site cause a dramatic derepression of abd-A in the CNS of the 8th abdominal segment, indistinguishable from that seen in Df ( 3R ) C4 homozygotes.
Focal seizures are episodes of pathological brain activity that appear to arise from a localised area of the brain and have been distinguished into two types: low amplitude fast oscillations ( LAF ) and high amplitude spikes ( HAS ). Using a previously established computational model of neocortical tissue, we investigated the mechanisms underlying the different onset patterns of focal seizures. We validated the model using clinical recordings of focal seizures and reproduced the two onset patterns in their most defining properties. We found that LAF onset is initiated by independent patches of localised activity that slowly invade the surrounding tissue and coalesce over time. In contrast, HAS onset is a global, systemic transition to a coexisting seizure state triggered by a local event. This transition is enabled by an increase in the excitability of the “healthy” surrounding tissue, which by itself does not generate seizures, but can support seizure activity when incited. We also found that the difference in surrounding tissue excitability offers a simple explanation of the clinically reported difference in surgical outcomes.
Defensin-like cysteine-rich proteins, ZmES1-4, are secreted by the female gametophyte in maize and play a role in pollen tube growth arrest, burst, and explosive sperm release. ZmES1-4 are exclusively expressed in the cells of the female gametophyte and accumulate in vesicles at the secretory zone of mature synergid cells. Upon pollen tube arrival, vesicles containing ZmES4 are released and induce pollen tube burst in a species-preferential manner. We found that ZmES4 interacts with the potassium channel KZM1, converting it from a voltage-dependent inward rectifier to a voltage-independent, non-rectifying channel. This results in potassium influx into the pollen tube, leading to water uptake and osmotic tube burst.
HER-2-retargeted oncolytic herpes simplex virus ( R-LM249 ) has been developed to specifically infect and kill tumor cells expressing high levels of HER-2 oncoprotein, which is overexpressed in ovarian and breast cancers. We evaluated the efficacy of i. p. administered R-LM249 against disseminated HER-2+ ovarian and breast carcinomas in mouse models that recapitulate tumor spread to the peritoneum in women. R-LM249 strongly inhibited carcinomatosis, resulting in 60% of mice free from peritoneal diffusion, and 95% reduction in the total weight of neoplastic nodules. The virus effectively reduced the growth of ovarian and breast carcinoma disseminated to the peritoneal cavity. R-LM249 also inhibited the growth of ovarian metastases of HER-2+ MDA-MB-453 breast cells and reduced brain metastases. Notably, R-LM249 is effective against HER-2+ trastuzumab-resistant cells, an important property in view of clinical application. The ability of R-LM249 to infect only cells with a high level of HER-2 cell surface expression suggests that the virus is unlikely to infect cells with low level of HER-2, i. e. non cancer cells in which the gene is not amplified. Overall, the i. p. -administered R-LM249 exerted a strong antimetastatic effect against peritoneal metastases of breast cancers and some evidence of therapeutic effect on extraperitoneal metastases was also found.
In eukaryotic cells, centrosomes serve as the poles of the mitotic spindle and are essential for bipolar spindle formation and proper chromosome segregation. However, aberrant centrosome numbers are linked to chromosomal instability and are commonly observed in cancers. Our study identifies Sfi1, a conserved component of centrosomes, as the first cyclin-dependent kinase ( Cdk ) substrate required to restrict centrosome duplication to once per cell cycle. We found that reducing Cdk1 phosphorylation of Sfi1 by changing its phosphorylation sites to nonphosphorylatable residues leads to defects in separation of duplicated spindle pole bodies ( SPBs, yeast centrosomes ) and to inappropriate SPB reduplication during mitosis. In addition, these cells display defects in bipolar spindle assembly, chromosome segregation, and growth. We propose that Cdk1 phosphorylation of Sfi1 is required for SPB separation and a block to SPB reduplication. After SPB duplication is complete, Cdk1 phosphorylates at least four Sfi1 C-terminal residues, allowing for SPB separation and bipolar spindle formation during mitosis. These residues remain phosphorylated during mitosis, restricting licensing of SPB duplication until downregulation of mitotic cyclin/Cdk1 at the end of mitosis. Dephosphorylation of Sfi1 by Cdc14 at the end of mitosis then licenses the SPBs for the next cycle of G1 SPB duplication.
In this study, we investigated the role of viral protein R ( Vpr ) in HIV-1 infection and its contribution to the development of AIDS. Using a human hematopoietic stem cell-transplanted humanized mouse model, we demonstrated that Vpr causes G2 cell cycle arrest and apoptosis predominantly in proliferating CCR5+ CD4+ T cells, which mainly consist of regulatory CD4+ T cells ( Tregs ), resulting in Treg depletion and enhanced virus production during acute infection. This effect is observed in CCR5-tropic but not CXCR4-tropic HIV-1-infected mice, suggesting that these effects are dependent on the coreceptor usage by HIV-1. Immune activation was observed in CCR5-tropic wild-type but not in vpr-deficient HIV-1-infected humanized mice. Our findings suggest that Vpr takes advantage of proliferating CCR5+ CD4+ T cells for enhancing viremia of CCR5-tropic HIV-1. Because Tregs exist in a higher cycling state than other T cell subsets, Tregs appear to be more vulnerable to exploitation by Vpr during acute HIV-1 infection.
Plasmodium vivax, the parasite responsible for vivax malaria, was eradicated in South Korea in the late 1970s but re-emerged in 1993. To control malaria and evaluate the effectiveness of control measures, it is essential to understand the genetic structure and temporal dynamics of the parasite population. Here, we analyzed microsatellite DNA markers of P. vivax from 163 South Korean isolates collected from 1994 to 2008 to estimate the population structure and temporal dynamics of the parasite. We analyzed 14 microsatellite DNA loci and found a gradual decrease in linkage disequilibrium ( LD ) levels and an increase in genetic diversity from 1994 to 2008. However, a drastic genetic change occurred in the South Korean P. vivax population during 2002 and 2003, as suggested by the levels of genetic differentiation between successive years and the population structure based on the Bayesian approach. Although relapse and asymptomatic parasite carriage may have influenced the population structure, our results suggest the continual introduction of P. vivax into South Korea through other parasite population sources. One possible source is North Korea, particularly during 2002 and 2003. Molecular epidemiology using microsatellite DNA of the P. vivax population is effective for assessing the population structure and temporal dynamics of parasite transmission, which can assist in the elimination of vivax malaria in endemic areas.
The presence of a splicing-competent intron is a conserved feature among eukaryotes that enhances transcription. However, the molecular mechanism underlying this phenomenon is not entirely clear. Here we show that the intron is an important regulator of promoter directionality. Employing strand-specific transcription run-on ( TRO ) analysis, we show that the transcription of mRNA is favored over the upstream anti-sense transcripts ( uaRNA ) initiating from the promoter in the presence of an intron. Mutation of either the 5′ or 3′ splice site resulted in the reversal of promoter directionality, suggesting that it is not merely the 5′ splice site but the entire splicing-competent intron that regulates transcription directionality. ChIP analysis revealed the recruitment of termination factors near the promoter region in the presence of an intron. Removal of intron or the mutation of splice sites adversely affected the promoter localization of termination factors. We have earlier demonstrated that the intron-mediated enhancement of transcription is dependent on gene looping. Here we show that gene looping is crucial for the recruitment of termination factors in the promoter-proximal region of an intron-containing gene. In a looping-defective mutant, despite normal splicing, the promoter occupancy of factors required for poly ( A ) -dependent termination of transcription was compromised. This was accompanied by a concomitant loss of transcription directionality.
ZBED6 is a novel transcription factor derived from a domesticated DNA transposon that regulates IGF2 expression and muscle growth. A single nucleotide substitution in intron 3 of IGF2 in pigs leads to a 3-fold up-regulation of IGF2 in skeletal muscle, resulting in major effects on muscle growth, size of the heart, and fat deposition. We have identified ZBED6 as the repressor of IGF2 expression and found that it is specific to placental mammals and is derived from an exapted DNA transposon. Silencing of Zbed6 in mouse C2C12 myoblasts affects Igf2 expression, cell proliferation, wound healing, and myotube formation. Chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing using C2C12 cells identified about 2, 500 ZBED6 binding sites in the genome, and the deduced consensus motif gave a perfect match with the established binding site in Igf2. Genes associated with ZBED6 binding sites show a highly significant enrichment for certain Gene Ontology classifications, including development and transcriptional regulation. The phenotypic effects in mutant pigs and ZBED6-silenced C2C12 myoblasts, the extreme sequence conservation, its nucleolar localization, the broad tissue distribution, and the many target genes with essential biological functions suggest that ZBED6 is an important transcription factor in placental mammals, affecting development, cell proliferation, and growth.
The RNA editome of the rhesus macaque, a close relative of humans, has been accurately and quantitatively profiled for the first time. By combining genome and transcriptome sequencing of multiple tissues from the same animal, we identified 31, 250 editing sites, of which 99. 8% are A-to-G transitions. We verified 96. 6% of editing sites in coding regions and 97. 5% of randomly selected sites in non-coding regions by multiple independent means, demonstrating the feasibility of our experimental paradigm. Our findings support the notion that adenosine deamination is associated with the macaque editome, as A-to-G editing sites are flanked by sequences with the attributes of ADAR substrates, and both the sequence context and the expression profile of ADARs are relevant factors in determining the quantitative variance of RNA editing across different sites and tissue types. Furthermore, we detected a substitution valley of decreased divergence around the editing site, suggesting the evolutionary constraint in maintaining some of these editing substrates with their double-stranded structure. These findings complement the “continuous probing” model that postulates tinkering-based origination of a small proportion of functional editing sites. The macaque editome reported here highlights RNA editing as a widespread functional regulation in primate evolution, and provides an informative framework for further understanding RNA editing in humans.
In a two-alternative spatial frequency discrimination task, we report a new perceptual bias where observers read out the likelihood representation with remarkably low precision when discriminating grating spatial frequencies. We induced an asymmetry in the likelihood function of spatial frequency by using spectrally filtered noise, mainly affecting the likelihood of spatial frequencies that are irrelevant to the task at hand. As a result, we found a significant shift in perceived grating frequency, indicating that observers evaluate likelihoods of a broad range of irrelevant frequencies and discard prior knowledge of stimulus alternatives. We measured grating detectability and discriminability in the presence of filtered visual noise and found that filtered noise backgrounds dramatically alter the perception of grating spatial frequency. Embedding a grating in low-pass filtered noise causes the perceived spatial frequency of the grating to decrease, while high-pass filtered noise increases perceived grating spatial frequency. Our results suggest that observers consider the log likelihood values of spatial frequencies that are a-priori unlikely to occur during the tasks, which lowers grating detectability and leads to a bias in perceived spatial frequency.
Piwi-interacting RNAs ( piRNAs ) are a class of small RNAs that play a conserved role in defending the genome against foreign genetic elements in many organisms. In Caenorhabditis elegans, we show that each piRNA represents a tiny, autonomous transcriptional unit that requires only a 21 nucleotide ( nt ) piRNA sequence and an ∼50 nt upstream motif with limited genomic context for expression. We demonstrate that this upstream motif is necessary for independent expression of a germline-enriched, Piwi-dependent piRNA, and that a single nucleotide position within this motif directs differential germline enrichment. We further show that over 70% of C. elegans piRNAs are selectively expressed in male or female germline, and that these two populations have evolved independently. Our results indicate that C. elegans piRNA upstream motifs act as independent promoters to specify which sequences are expressed as piRNAs, how abundantly they are expressed, and in what germline. We also show that the 5′ nucleotide of the conserved core motif influences germline enrichment of the dependent 21U RNA species. Finally, we demonstrate that the clustered organization of endogenous piRNA loci is entirely dispensable for robust piRNA expression, and that each 21U RNA locus encodes all of the information necessary for driving independent, autonomous transcription from more than 15, 000 unique piRNA loci in C. elegans.
Brucella abortus replicates within host cells in the form of endoplasmic reticulum ( ER ) -derived vacuoles. The mechanisms by which the bacteria acquire the ER-derived membrane for their replication remain to be elucidated. Here, we demonstrate that the IRE1 pathway, but not the PERK and ATF6 pathways, of the unfolded protein response ( UPR ) is activated in a time-dependent manner during Brucella infection, and that the COPII vesicle components Sar1, Sec23, and Sec24D are upregulated. We also show that a marked accretion of ER-derived vacuoles is observed around replicating bacteria using fluorescent microscopy and electron microscopy. Furthermore, we identify a novel host factor, Yip1A, for the activation of the IRE1 pathway in response to both tunicamycin treatment and infection with B. abortus. Yip1A is responsible for the phosphorylation of IRE1 through high-order assembly of Ire1 molecules at ER exit sites ( ERES ) under the UPR conditions. In Yip1A-knockdown cells, B. abortus fails to generate the ER-derived vacuoles, and remains in endosomal/lysosomal compartments. These results indicate that the activation of the IRE1 pathway and the subsequent formation of ER-derived vacuoles are critical for B. abortus to establish a safe replication niche, and that Yip1A is indispensable for these processes.
Tomato bushy stunt virus ( TBSV ) and the closely-related carnation Italian ringspot virus ( CIRV ) hijack the cellular Vps34 phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase ( PI3K ) into the large viral replication compartment. The kinase function of Vps34 is critical for TBSV replication, suggesting that PI ( 3 ) P phosphoinositide is utilized by TBSV for building of the replication compartment. We also observed increased expression of Vps34 and the higher abundance of PI ( 3 ) P in the presence of the tombusviral replication proteins, which likely leads to more efficient tombusvirus replication. Overexpression of PI ( 3 ) P phosphatase in yeast or plants inhibited TBSV replication on the peroxisomal membranes and CIRV replication on the mitochondrial membranes. Moreover, the purified PI ( 3 ) P phosphatase reduced TBSV replicase assembly in a cell-free system. Detection of PI ( 3 ) P with antibody or a bioprobe revealed the enrichment of PI ( 3 ) P in the replication compartment. Vps34 is directly recruited into the replication compartment through interaction with p33 replication protein. Gene deletion analysis in surrogate yeast host unraveled that TBSV replication requires the vesicle transport function of Vps34. In the absence of Vps34, TBSV cannot efficiently recruit the Rab5-positive early endosomes, which provide PE-rich membranes for membrane biogenesis of the TBSV replication compartment. We found that Vps34 and PI ( 3 ) P are needed for the stability of the p33 replication protein, which is degraded by the 26S proteasome when PI ( 3 ) P abundance was decreased by an inhibitor of Vps34.
Transmission of dengue virus ( DENV ) from humans to Aedes aegypti mosquitoes is a critical component of dengue epidemiology. However, studies on this process have been hampered by a lack of methods that adequately represent natural acquisition of DENV by mosquitoes from humans. In this study, we assessed artificial and natural blood feeding methods based on rates of DENV infection and dissemination within mosquitoes for use in a field-based epidemiological cohort study in Iquitos, Peru. Between 2011 and 2015, we enrolled 58 participants aged 5 years and older with 5 or fewer days of fever from ongoing clinic- and neighborhood-based studies on dengue in Iquitos. Wild type, laboratory-reared Aedes aegypti were fed directly on febrile individuals or on blood collected from participants that was either untreated or treated with EDTA. Mosquitoes were tested after approximately 14 days of extrinsic incubation for DENV infection and dissemination. We found that DENV infection and dissemination rates were not significantly different following direct and indirect-EDTA feeding; however, they were significantly lower for mosquitoes that fed indirectly on blood with no additive. Relative to direct feeding, infection rates showed greater variation following indirect-EDTA than indirect-no additive feeding. No differences were detected in DENV infection or dissemination rates in mosquitoes fed directly on participants with different dengue illness severity. Our study demonstrates the feasibility of using direct and indirect feeding methods for field-based studies on vector competence.
Topoisomerase II poisons are a class of chemotherapeutic drugs that target the topoisomerase II enzyme, which is essential for relieving topological stress ahead of the replication fork in proliferative cell populations. However, these drugs are differentially effective from one patient to the next, and understanding the causes of this variability is a critical step towards the development of personalized treatments and improvements to existing medications. Using the model organism Caenorhabditis elegans, we show that wild strains of C. elegans vary in their sensitivity to topoisomerase II poisons, and that this natural variation is explained by a methionine-to-glutamine substitution in the topoisomerase II ( TOP-2 ) enzyme. We demonstrate that the presence of a non-polar methionine at this residue increases hydrophobic interactions between TOP-2 and its poison etoposide, resulting in increased genomic instability in strains that contain a methionine residue. This residue is conserved from yeast to humans and is one of the few differences between the two human topoisomerase II isoforms ( methionine in hTOPIIα and glutamine in hTOPIIβ ). We go on to show that this amino acid difference between the two human topoisomerase isoforms influences cytotoxicity of topoisomerase II poisons in human cell lines, demonstrating the utility of C. elegans in understanding the genetics of drug responses.
Long-lived rodents, such as African mole-rats, have life expectancies that are multiple times higher than similar sized and phylogenetically closely related rodents. To gain new insights into genetic mechanisms determining mammalian lifespans, we obtained genomic and transcriptomic data from 17 rodent species and scanned eleven evolutionary branches associated with the evolution of enhanced longevity for positively selected genes ( PSGs ). We identified 250 PSGs that showed an expression pattern fitting the antagonistic pleiotropy theory of aging in the liver of long-lived naked mole-rats and short-lived rats. These PSGs were enriched for genes known to be related to aging, including “cellular respiration” and “metal ion homeostasis”, as well as functional terms associated with processes regulated by the mTOR pathway, such as translation, autophagy, and inflammation. Among the identified PSGs were RHEB, a regulator of mTOR, and IGF1, both central components of aging-relevant pathways, as well as genes yet unknown to be aging-associated but representing convincing functional candidates, e. g. RHEBL1, AMHR2, PSMG1, and AGER.
Aedes albopictus mosquitoes are a major vector of chikungunya, dengue, and zika viruses. To control their populations, the endosymbiont Wolbachia has been exploited to produce sterile males and/or invasive females with reduced vector competence. A new Aedes albopictus transinfection ( ARwP-M ) was generated by introducing wMel Wolbachia in the ARwP line, which had previously been established by replacing wAlbA and wAlbB Wolbachia with the wPip strain. ARwP-M showed a 100% rate of maternal inheritance of wMel and wPip Wolbachia and did not differ in survival, female fecundity, and egg fertility from ARwP and wild-type Ae. albopictus. Crosses between ARwP-M males and wild-type females were fully unfertile, while egg hatch in reverse crosses increased from 0 to about 17% with wild-type males aging from 3 to 17 days. When competing with wild-type males for wild-type females, ARwP-M males induced a level of sterility significantly higher than that expected for an equal mating competitiveness. The overall Wolbachia density in ARwP-M females was about 15 fold higher than in ARwP, mostly due to the wMel infection. This corresponded to a strongly reduced vector competence for chikungunya and dengue viruses, with 5 and 0% rates of transmission at 14 and 21 days post infection, respectively.
Peptide-mediated interactions between proteins play a crucial role in regulating biological responses to intra- and extracellular stimuli. These interactions are characterized by a relatively small contact interface between a globular domain in one protein and a linear peptide from another. Most current methods for discovering such motifs exploit their tendency to occur in disordered regions of proteins. However, our work focuses on the observation that upon binding to their partner domain, motifs adopt a well-defined structure. We analyzed all peptide-mediated interactions of known high-resolution three-dimensional ( 3D ) structure and found that the structure of the peptide may be as characteristic as the consensus motif, helping to identify target peptides even if they do not match established patterns. We implemented a strategy based on a Support Vector Machine that uses structural features of peptides, along with other structure-encoded information about binding interfaces, to search the set of protein interactions of known 3D structure and identify unnoticed peptide-mediated interactions. We also derived consensus patterns for these interactions and compared them with established linear motif patterns and their binding domains. Finally, we cross-validated our identification strategy by scanning interactome networks from four model organisms and found significant over-representations for 64 domain-motif interactions, 46 of which had not been described before, involving over 6, 000 interactions for which we could suggest the molecular details determining the binding.
Environmental enteropathy ( EE ) is a condition associated with growth failure, micronutrient malabsorption, and impaired responses to oral vaccines. We studied 49 adults with EE in Lusaka, Zambia, using confocal laser endomicroscopy ( CLE ), histology, immunohistochemistry, and mRNA sequencing of small intestinal biopsies, and correlated these with plasma lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) and a zinc uptake test. CLE images showed virtually ubiquitous small intestinal damage, and epithelial defects were predominantly seen at the tips of villi, corresponding with leakage imaged in vivo by CLE. Circulating LPS was correlated with cell shedding events ( β = 0. 83; P = 0. 035 ) and with serum glucagon-like peptide-2 ( β = -0. 13; P = 0. 007 ). Zinc uptake from a test dose of 25mg was attenuated in 30/47 ( 64% ) individuals, and in multivariate analysis was reduced by HIV, but positively correlated with GLP-2 ( β = 2. 72; P = 0. 03 ). Transcriptomic analysis identified 23 differentially expressed genes in severe enteropathy, including protective peptides and proteins.
Turnip crinkle virus ( TCV ) is a small icosahedral plant virus with a ( + ) -strand RNA genome that encodes five proteins. Here we demonstrate that superinfection exclusion ( SIE ) of TCV is exclusively determined by p28, one of the two replication proteins encoded by this virus. We show that p28 expressed from a TCV replicon exerts strong SIE to a different TCV replicon, and that transiently expressed p28, delivered simultaneously with or ahead of a TCV replicon, largely recapitulates this repressive activity. Interestingly, p28-mediated SIE is dramatically enhanced by C-terminally fused epitope tags or fluorescent proteins, but weakened by N-terminal modifications, and it inversely correlates with the ability of p28 to complement the replication of a p28-defective TCV replicon. We further show that p28 in SIE-positive cells forms large, mobile punctate inclusions that trans-aggregate a non-coalescing, SIE-defective, yet replication-competent p28 mutant. These results support a model postulating that TCV SIE is caused by the formation of multimeric p28 complexes capable of intercepting fresh p28 monomers translated from superinfector genomes, thereby abolishing superinfector replication.
Immunization of mice with a plasmid encoding the Trypanosoma cruzi trans-sialidase ( TS ) gene has been shown to be highly immunogenic and provide protection against acute lethal challenge. However, long-term protection induced by TS DNA vaccines has not been reported. In the present study, we tested whether the co-administration of a plasmid encoding IL-15 ( pIL-15 ) could improve the duration of protection achieved through genetic vaccination with plasmid encoding TS ( pTS ) alone. We immunized BALB/c mice with pTS in the presence or absence of pIL-15 and studied immune responses and protection against lethal systemic challenge at 1 to 6 months post-vaccination. Mice receiving pTS alone developed robust TS-specific IFN-γ responses and survived a lethal challenge given within the first 3 months following immunization. The addition of pIL-15 to pTS vaccination did not significantly alter T cell responses or protection during this early post-vaccination period. However, mice vaccinated with both pTS and pIL-15 challenged 6 months post-vaccination were significantly more protected against lethal T. cruzi challenges than mice vaccinated with pTS alone ( P<0. 05 ). Improved protection correlated with significantly higher numbers of TS-specific IFN-γ producing total and CD8+ T cells detected>6 months post immunization.
Trypanosoma brucei, the causative agent of African trypanosomiasis, is a protozoan parasite that undergoes a complex cell division process involving basal body segregation, flagellum attachment and cytokinesis. The Polo-like kinase homolog in T. brucei, TbPLK, plays essential roles in these processes. However, the mechanism controlling TbPLK protein abundance remains unknown. Here, we report that a Cullin4-based ubiquitin ligase complex, CRL4WDR1, mediates TbPLK degradation in the basal body and the bilobe. CRL4WDR1 is composed of Cullin4, the DNA damage-binding protein 1 homolog TbDDB1 and a WD40-repeat protein WDR1. WDR1 acts as a receptor for TbPLK in the CRL4 ubiquitin ligase complex. We show that depletion of WDR1 impairs TbPLK ubiquitination and degradation, leading to excessive accumulation of TbPLK in the basal body and the bilobe and continuous phosphorylation of the bilobe protein TbCentrin2. This results in defective bilobe duplication, flagellum attachment zone filament assembly and flagellum detachment.
The RNA helicase DDX3X has been identified as an essential mediator of innate antimicrobial immunity. Mice lacking DDX3X in the hematopoietic system show an altered leukocyte composition in bone marrow and spleen and are highly susceptible to Listeria monocytogenes ( Lm ) infection. This suggests that DDX3X plays a vital role in innate immunity to Listeria. The sex-specific isoforms of DDX3 contribute to the innate immune response and may contribute to sex-related differences in resistance to microbes and resilience to inflammatory disease. Our data provide further in vivo evidence for an essential contribution of a non-RIG-I like receptor ( RLR ) DExD/H RNA helicase to innate immunity. DDX3X regulates the expression of genes contributing to the innate antimicrobial response of macrophages, and the extent to which DDX3X deficiency alters the transcriptome depends on the sex chromosomes of the cells. DDX3X has been identified as a regulator of IFN-I transcription in cells infected with viruses or Listeria monocytogenes. DDX3X belongs to the DEAD-box RNA helicase superfamily 2, which has widespread functions in RNA metabolism, including transcription, RNA processing, splicing, decay, and translation.
A biophysical model of the pheromone transduction cascade in male moth olfactory receptor neurons ( ORNs ) is presented. The model focuses on post-effector processes, including the production and degradation of second messengers ( IP3 and DAG ), the opening and closing of ionic channels ( IP3-gated Ca2+ channel, DAG-gated cationic channel, Ca2+-gated Cl− channel, and Ca2+- and voltage-gated K+ channel ), and Ca2+ extrusion mechanisms. These processes are regulated by modulators ( protein kinase C and Ca2+-calmodulin ) that exert feedback inhibition on the effector and channels. The model captures the main features of the dose–response curves, including the wide dynamic range of six decades with the same amplitudes as the experimental data, the short rising time, and the long falling time. It also reproduces the second messenger kinetics. The model suggests that the two main types of depolarizing ionic channels play different roles at low and high pheromone concentrations; the DAG-gated cationic channel plays the major role for depolarization at low concentrations, and the Ca2+-gated Cl− channel plays the major role for depolarization at middle and high concentrations.
Cellular stress activates the tumor suppressor protein p53, leading to selective binding to DNA response elements ( REs ) and gene transactivation from a large pool of potential p53 REs ( p53REs ). To elucidate how p53RE sequences and local chromatin context interact to affect p53 binding and gene transactivation, we mapped genome-wide binding localizations of p53 and H3K4me3 in untreated and doxorubicin ( DXR ) -treated human lymphoblastoid cells. We observed that the inducible expression of p53-regulated genes was associated with the steady-state chromatin status of the cell. Most highly inducible p53-regulated genes were suppressed at baseline and marked by repressive histone modifications or displayed CTCF binding. Comparison of p53RE sequences residing in different chromatin contexts demonstrated that weaker p53REs resided in open promoters, while stronger p53REs were located within enhancers and repressed chromatin. p53 occupancy was strongly correlated with similarity of the target DNA sequences to the p53RE consensus, but inversely correlated with pre-existing nucleosome accessibility ( DHS ) and evolutionary conservation at the p53RE. Occupancy by p53 of REs that overlapped transposable element ( TE ) repeats was significantly higher and correlated with stronger p53RE sequences relative to nonTE-associated p53REs.
Two-component signaling systems in bacteria offer a rich diversity of sensory systems that can be reengineered through synthetic biology. These systems are built around a core phosphotransfer reaction between histidine kinases and their output response regulator proteins. Here, we explore the signal-response relationship arising from a specific motif found in two-component signaling systems, where a single histidine kinase ( HK ) phosphotransfers reversibly to two separate output response regulator ( RR ) proteins. We show that this motif not only allows rapid signal termination but also implements a sigmoidal signal-response relationship. We identify two mathematical conditions on system parameters that are necessary for sigmoidal signal-response relationships and define key parameters that control threshold levels and sensitivity of the signal-response curve. We confirm these findings experimentally, by in vitro reconstitution of the one HK-two RR motif found in the Sinorhizobium meliloti chemotaxis pathway and measuring the resulting signal-response curve. We find that the level of sigmoidality in this system can be experimentally controlled by the presence of the sink RR, and also through an auxiliary protein that is shown to bind to the HK ( yielding Hill coefficients of above 7 ). These findings show that the one HK-two RR motif allows bacteria and yeast to implement tunable switch-like signal processing and provides an ideal basis for developing threshold devices for synthetic biology applications.
Single-cell RNA sequencing is used to quantify transcript heterogeneity in individual Saccharomyces cerevisiae cells treated with and without salt stress to explore population variation and identify cellular covariates that influence the stress-responsive transcriptome. The results reveal significant regulatory variation in individual yeast cells, both before and after stress. A subset of cells appears to decouple expression of ribosomal protein genes from the environmental stress response in a manner partly correlated with the cell cycle but unrelated to the yeast ultradian metabolic cycle. Live-cell imaging of cells expressing pairs of fluorescent regulators, including the transcription factor Msn2 with Dot6, Sfp1, or MAP kinase Hog1, reveals both coordinated and decoupled nucleocytoplasmic shuttling. Together with transcriptomic analysis, our results suggest that cells maintain a cellular filter against decoupled bursts of transcription factor activation but mount a stress response upon coordinated regulation, even in a subset of unstressed cells.
Trypanosoma brucei, the causative agent of African trypanosomiasis, accumulates in large numbers in the male reproductive organs of mice, including the epididymis, epididymal adipose tissue, and fibrous tunics of the testis. Histopathological analysis reveals that the parasites are associated with marked inflammatory cell infiltration, parasite degeneration, and severe tissue damage and rupture of epididymal ducts, which may be related to reduced fertility. In contrast, no parasites are found in the lumen of intact epididymal ducts or seminiferous tubules of the testis, indicating that the majority of parasites are not located in immune-privileged sites. Immunohistochemistry analysis shows that T. brucei is present in the epididymis and epididymal adipose tissue since at least day 6 post-infection, with the epididymis showing a temporal increase in parasite density that attains 105 parasites per mg of organ at late stages of the disease. Overall, we show that T. brucei is exposed to a strong immune response in the male reproductive organs, and that the epididymis and epididymal adipose tissue are major sites of parasite accumulation.
Chemoreceptor genes in Drosophila melanogaster undergo independent transcriptional regulation at different developmental stages and between sexes. Expression of distinct subgroups of chemoreceptor genes is sensitive to reproductive state and social interactions. Exposure to the odor of the opposite sex results in altered transcript abundance of chemoreceptor genes, which are distinct from those that show transcriptional plasticity when flies are allowed physical contact with same or opposite sex members. We analyzed covariance in transcript abundance of chemosensory genes across all environmental conditions and found that they segregated into 20 relatively small, biologically relevant modules of highly correlated transcripts. This finely pixilated modular organization of the chemosensory subgenome enables fine tuning of the expression of the chemoreceptor repertoire in response to ecologically relevant environmental and physiological conditions.
Meiotic recombination in human oocytes has been linked to the origin of human trisomies. Studies of human trisomies indicate that failure to recombine or recombination events located too near to or too far from the centromere are associated with nondisjunction at maternal meiosis I or II. We initiated studies of crossover-associated proteins ( e. g., MLH1 ) in human fetal oocytes to analyze their number and distribution on nondisjunction-prone human chromosomes and to characterize genome-wide levels of recombination in the human female. Our analyses indicate that the number of MLH1 foci is lower than predicted from genetic linkage analysis, but its localization pattern conforms to that expected for a crossover-associated protein. In studies of individual chromosomes, our observations provide evidence for the presence of “vulnerable” crossover configurations in the fetal oocyte, consistent with the idea that these are subsequently translated into nondisjunctional events in the adult oocyte. We evaluated the utility of MLH1 as a marker of crossing-over in females and asked whether achiasmate chromosomes and sub-optimal crossover patterns are a feature of human female meiosis.
Vector-borne diseases, such as malaria, leishmaniasis, and arboviral infections, are transmitted by blood-feeding arthropods like mosquitoes, sand flies, and ticks. When these arthropods bite a mammal, they inject saliva containing immunogenic compounds that can modulate the host's immune response. This pre-exposure to arthropod saliva can alter the course of disease progression if the host later becomes infected. Depending on the system in question, such pre-sensitisation of host immunity can either exacerbate or limit infection symptoms. We develop a general model of vector-borne disease to explore how immune pre-sensitisation alters the effects of vector control. Our model shows that if pre-sensitisation leads to more rapid clearance of infection, increasing vector mortality rates may achieve greater than expected disease control. However, if pre-sensitisation prolongs the duration of infection, increasing vector mortality rates can actually increase the total number of infected hosts. This may go unnoticed unless active surveillance methods are used to detect sub-clinical individuals who could provide long-lasting reservoirs for transmission and suffer long-term health consequences.
Leishmaniasis is an important disease that affects 12 million people in 88 countries, with 2 million new cases every year. Leishmania amazonensis is an important agent in Brazil, leading to clinical forms varying from localized cutaneous leishmaniasis ( LCL ) to diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis ( DCL ). To study the effect of the host immune system on Leishmania protein expression, we compared proteomes of amastigotes isolated from BALB/c and BALB/c nude mice. BALB/c nude mice resemble patients with diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis, considered T-cell hyposensitive or anergic to Leishmania´s antigens. Among the 44 differentially expressed spots, there were proteins related to oxidative/nitrosative stress and proteases. Some correspond to known Leishmania virulence factors such as oligopeptidase B ( OPB ) and tryparedoxin peroxidase. Specific isoforms of these two proteins were increased in parasites from nude mice, suggesting that T cells probably restrain their posttranslational modifications in BALB/c mice. On the other hand, an isoform of HSP70 was increased in amastigotes from BALB/c mice.
Activation-induced cytosine deaminase ( AID ) initiates immunoglobulin gene diversification in activated B cells by deaminating cytosines to uracils. AID is potentially highly mutagenic and causes genomic instability, evident as chromosomal translocations in B cell malignancies. Here we show that AID is cell cycle regulated. By high content screening microscopy, we demonstrate that AID undergoes nuclear degradation more slowly in G1 phase than in S or G2-M phase, and that mutations that affect regulatory phosphorylation or catalytic activity can alter AID stability and abundance. We directly test the role of cell cycle regulation by fusing AID to tags that destabilize nuclear protein outside of G1 or S-G2/M phases. We show that enforced nuclear localization of AID in G1 phase accelerates somatic hypermutation and class switch recombination, and is well-tolerated; while nuclear AID compromises viability in S-G2/M phase cells. We identify AID derivatives that accelerate somatic hypermutation with minimal impact on viability, which will be useful tools for engineering genes and proteins by iterative mutagenesis and selection.
Clostridium phytofermentans, a soil bacterium with 171 carbohydrate-active enzyme ( CAZyme )-encoding genes, is capable of fermenting a wide range of plant polysaccharides including glucans, mannans, xylans, galactans, pectins, and arabinans. We developed a method to analyze how microbes catabolize plant polysaccharides by integrating CAZyme assays, RNA sequencing, and anaerobic growth screening. We applied this method to C. phytofermentans and found that it ferments plant biomass components with variable efficiencies and prioritizes metabolism of preferred substrates. We identified 56 up-regulated CAZymes that were purified and tested for their ability to bind and cleave plant polysaccharides. These enzymes were then tested in combination to identify synergies between enzymes acting on the same substrate with different catalytic mechanisms. We found that most polysaccharides are degraded by multiple enzymes, often from the same family, but with divergent rates, specificities, and cellular localizations. These results advance our understanding of how microbes degrade and metabolize plant biomass and have implications for the development of improved enzyme mixtures and recombinant microbes for industrial processing of plant biomass.
In Sierra Leone, three rounds of mass drug administration ( MDA ) were conducted between 2008 and 2010 to control lymphatic filariasis ( LF ) in 12 districts that were co-endemic for LF and onchocerciasis. The districts had previously been treated for onchocerciasis since 2003 using the Community-Directed Treatment with Ivermectin ( CDTI ) strategy. A midterm assessment was conducted in 2011 to evaluate the impact of the MDAs on LF prevalence. The results showed a significant decrease in microfilaria ( mf ) prevalence from 2. 6% in 2007–2008 to 0. 3% in 2011, a reduction of 88. 5% ( p = 0. 000 ). In four districts ( Bo, Moyamba, Kenema, and Kono ), mf prevalence decreased to 0. 0% ( 100. 0% decrease ), and in seven other districts, mf prevalence decreased by between 70. 0% and 95. 0% ( p = 0. 000, 0. 060, 0. 001, 0. 014, 0. 000, 0. 000, and 0. 002 for Bombali, Bonthe, Kailahun, Kambia, Koinadugu, Port Loko, and Tonkolili districts, respectively ). Only Bombali district still had an mf prevalence ≥1. 0% ( 1. 58%, 95% CI: 0. 80%–3. 09% ), which had the highest baseline mf prevalence of 6. 9% ( 95% CI: 5. 3%–8. 8% ). The overall arithmetic mean mf density after three MDAs was 17. 59 mf/ml ( 95% CI: 15. 64 mf/ml–19. 55 mf/ml ) among mf-positive individuals ( 65. 4% decrease from baseline of 50. 9 mf/ml ( 95% CI: 40. 25 mf/ml–61. 62 mf/ml; p = 0. 001 ) and 0. 05 mf/ml ( 95% CI: 0. 03 mf/ml–0. 08 mf/ml ) for the entire population examined ( 96. 2% decrease from baseline of 1. 32 mf/ml ( 95% CI: 1. 00 mf/ml–1. 65 mf/ml; p = 0. 000 ) ).
High-throughput sequencing techniques, such as 16S rRNA gene profiling, have the potential to elucidate the complex inner workings of natural microbial communities. A key step in exploring such data is the identification of dependencies between members of these communities, which is commonly achieved by correlation analysis. However, the analysis of compositional data can produce unreliable results since the observed data take the form of relative fractions of genes or species, rather than their absolute abundances. Using simulated and real data from the Human Microbiome Project, we show that such compositional effects can be widespread and severe: in some real data sets many of the correlations among taxa can be artifactual, and true correlations may even appear with opposite sign. We show that community diversity is the key factor that modulates the acuteness of such compositional effects, and develop a new approach, called SparCC, which is capable of estimating correlation values from compositional data. To illustrate a potential application of SparCC, we infer a rich ecological network connecting hundreds of interacting species across 18 sites on the human body. Using the SparCC network as a reference, we estimated that the standard approach yields 3 spurious species-species interactions for each true interaction and misses 60% of the true interactions in the human microbiome data, and most of the erroneous links are found in the samples with the lowest diversity.
The muramidase activity of human lysozyme is responsible for its antimicrobial effect against Streptococcus pneumoniae, a bacterium that colonizes the upper respiratory tract. Lysozyme is abundant on mucosal surfaces, suggesting that successful colonizers must be able to evade its antimicrobial effects. Two enzymes, PgdA and Adr, modify the peptidoglycan of S. pneumoniae and have been implicated in its resistance to lysozyme in vitro. Here, we show that both modifications are required for full resistance to lysozyme and that the muramidase activity of lysozyme is responsible for its antimicrobial effect against pneumococci. We also show that the combined effect of PgdA and Adr on resistance to human lysozyme is due to its muramidase activity, rather than its non-muramidase activity. In competition experiments with wild-type and pgdAadr mutant pneumococci in lysozyme M-sufficient and -deficient mice, the wild-type strain out-competed the double mutant in lysozyme M-sufficient mice, but not in lysozyme M-deficient mice. In contrast, strains containing single mutations in either pgdA or adr prevailed over the wild-type strain in both lysozyme M-sufficient and lysozyme M-deficient mice. Our findings demonstrate that individual peptidoglycan modifications diminish fitness during colonization and that the combination of peptidoglycan modifications reduces overall fitness, but that this is outweighed by the benefits of resistance to the peptidoglycan degrading activity of lysozyme.
Dengue is the most important arthropod-borne viral disease worldwide in terms of morbidity and mortality. In Brazil, which is responsible for approximately 80% of dengue cases in the Americas, a total of 5, 944, 270 cases have been reported since the introduction of dengue in 1986, including 21, 596 dengue hemorrhagic fever and 874 fatal cases. The goal of this study was to investigate the usefulness of NS1 capture tests as an alternative tool to detect dengue virus ( DENV ) in tissue specimens from previously confirmed dengue fatal cases ( n = 23 ) that occurred in Brazil in 2002. We evaluated three tests for NS1 antigen capture: Dengue Early ELISA ( PanBio Diagnostics ), Platelia NS1 ( BioRad Laboratories ) and the rapid test NS1 Ag Strip ( BioRad Laboratories ). The overall dengue fatal case diagnosis based on the tissues analyzed by Dengue Early ELISA, Platelia NS1 and the NS1 Ag Strip was 34. 7% ( 08/23 ), 60. 8% ( 14/23 ) and 91. 3% ( 21/23 ), respectively. The Dengue Early ELISA detected NS1 in 22. 9% ( 17/74 ) of the specimens analyzed and the Platelia NS1 in 45. 9% ( 34/74 ). The highest sensitivity ( 78. 3%; 58/74 ) was achieved by the NS1 Ag Strip, and the differences in the sensitivities were statistically significant ( p<0. 05 ). The NS1 Ag Strip was the most sensitive in liver ( 91. 3%; 21/23 ), lung ( 71. 4%; 10/14 ), kidney ( 100%; 4/4 ), brain ( 80%; 8/10 ), spleen ( 66. 6%, 10/15 ) and thymus ( 100%, 3/3 ) when compared to the other two ELISA assays.
Multiple Myeloma ( MM ) is a plasma cell malignancy with a higher incidence and mortality rate among African Americans ( AA ) compared to Caucasians ( CA ). To elucidate differences in molecular alterations in MM as a function of self-reported race and genetic ancestry, we analyzed somatic whole exome, RNA-sequencing, and clinical data from 718 MM patients from the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation CoMMpass study Interim Analysis 9. Somatic mutational analyses revealed significant differences in mutation frequency between AA and CA cases. Notably, BCL7A, BRWD3, and AUTS2 demonstrated significantly higher mutation frequencies among AA cases. These genes are involved in translocations in B-cell malignancies. In contrast, TP53 and IRF4 mutation frequencies were higher among CA cases. Our study provides rationale for interrogating diverse tumor cohorts to understand tumor genomics across populations.
Clonal and subclonal passenger mutations in the exome of cancer cells can provide important information about the evolutionary history of an individual cancer and serve as a molecular clock. We study the stochastic expansion of a population of cancer cells describing the growth of primary tumors or metastatic lesions. We first analyze the process by looking forward in time and calculate the fixation probabilities and frequencies of successive passenger mutations ordered by their time of appearance. We compute the likelihood of specific evolutionary trees, thereby informing the phylogenetic reconstruction of cancer evolution in individual patients. Next, we derive results looking backward in time: for a given subclonal mutation we estimate the number of cancer cells that were present at the time when that mutation arose. We derive exact formulas for the expected numbers of subclonal mutations of any frequency. Fitting this formula to cancer sequencing data leads to an estimate for the ratio of birth and death rates of cancer cells during the early stages of clonal expansion. We show that the frequencies of the first and thus most abundant passenger mutations are influenced not only by the mutation rate, but also by the death-birth ratio of the cancer cells.
Polyglutamine ( polyQ ) expansion in the first exon ( XN1 ) of the huntingtin protein is linked to Huntington's disease. When the number of glutamines exceeds a threshold of approximately 36–40 repeats, XN1 can readily form amyloid aggregates similar to those associated with the disease. Misfolding of monomeric XN1 plays an important role in the length-dependent aggregation of XN1. The flanking sequences surrounding the polyQ region can play a critical role in determining the structural rearrangement and aggregation mechanism of XN1. To elucidate the misfolding of XN1 toward amyloid aggregation, we performed molecular dynamics simulations on monomeric XN1 with full flanking regions, a variant missing the polyproline regions, and an isolated polyQ peptide ( Qn ). We studied glutamine repeat lengths of 23, 36, 40 and 47 for each of these three constructs. We found that polyQ peptides have a positive correlation between their probability to form a β-rich misfolded state and their expansion length. We also found that the flanking regions of XN1 affect its probability to form a β-rich state compared to the isolated polyQ. The polyproline regions form polyproline type II helices and decrease the probability of the polyQ region to form a β-rich state.
The CRISPR ( Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats ) loci, together with cas ( CRISPR–associated ) genes, form the CRISPR/Cas adaptive immune system that eubacteria and archaea use to defend against foreign nucleic acids, such as phages and conjugative plasmids. To explore the distribution and diversity of CRISPRs in human-associated microbial communities, we analyzed hundreds of shotgun metagenomic datasets from the Human Microbiome Project ( HMP ). We developed a targeted assembly strategy to reconstruct CRISPR arrays that whole-metagenome assemblies fail to identify. We used the direct repeat consensus sequence of each known CRISPR type to recruit reads from each HMP dataset and then assembled the recruited reads into CRISPR loci. We also identified novel CRISPRs or new CRISPR variants in contigs from whole-metagenome assemblies and used targeted assembly to more comprehensively identify these CRISPRs across samples. We found that the distributions of CRISPRs, including 64 known and 86 novel ones, are largely body-site specific. For example, known streptococcal CRISPRs were identified in most oral microbiomes, totaling ∼8, 000 unique spacers. This work indicates the importance of effective identification and characterization of CRISPR loci to the study of the dynamic ecology of microbiomes.
In this study, we report the first identification of circadian-regulated transcripts in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. Using genome-wide expression profiling, we show that subsets of transcripts exhibit rhythmic expression with temperature-compensated 24-h periods and are sustained under constant conditions, suggesting that they are under circadian regulation. We find that light and temperature cycles strongly drive gene expression and appear to entrain largely nonoverlapping gene sets. Furthermore, we show that light and temperature can act as zeitgebers and drive as well as entrain transcripts at the genome-wide level. Our results suggest that C. elegans may utilize a timekeeping mechanism that is distinct from that described previously in other animals. We also find that the TAX-2 cyclic nucleotide-gated channel subunit is required to transduce both light and temperature information to the clock, implying that environmental cues act cell nonautonomously to entrain circadian rhythms. Together, these findings demonstrate circadian-regulated transcriptional rhythms in C. elegans and suggest that further analyses in this organism will provide new information about the evolution and function of this biological clock.
Reciprocal products of mitotic recombination in rad3-101 and rad3-102 hyper-recombination ( hyper-Rec ) mutants in Saccharomyces cerevisiae have been further characterized using a system in which the reciprocal products of mitotic recombination are recovered. Both rad3-101 and rad3-102 elevate the frequency of reciprocal crossovers about 100-fold. Mapping of these events shows that three-quarters of these crossovers reflect double sister-chromatid breaks ( DSCBs ), while the remainder reflects single chromatid breaks ( SCBs ). The ratio of DSCBs to SCBs is similar to that observed for spontaneous recombination events in wild-type cells. We mapped 216 unselected genomic alterations throughout the genome, including crossovers, gene conversions, deletions, and duplications, and found a significant association between the location of these recombination events and regions with elevated gamma-H2AX. In addition, there was a hotspot for deletions and duplications at the IMA2 and HXT11 genes near the left end of chromosome XV.
Helicobacter pylori, a gastric pathogen, has a large set of simple sequence repeats ( SSRs ) that constitute contingency loci. These SSRs generate heterogeneous populations through a slipped strand mispairing mechanism, facilitating adaptation to the ever-changing host environment. Here, we present a model that explains how an intergenically located T-tract, via slipped strand mispairing, operates with a rheostat-like function to fine-tune activity of the promoter that drives expression of the sialic acid binding adhesin, SabA. We show that the length of the T-tract generates multiphasic output from the sabA promoter, altering the H. pylori binding to sialyl-Lewis x receptors on gastric mucosa. In silico and functional in vitro analyzes revealed that the length of the T-tract affects the local DNA structure and thereby binding of the RNA polymerase, through shifting of the axial alignment between the core promoter and UP-like elements. We identified additional genes in H. pylori, with T- or A-tracts positioned similar to that of sabA, and show that variations in the tract length likewise acted as rheostats to modulate cognate promoter output. Thus, we propose that this generally applicable mechanism, mediated by promoter-proximal SSRs, provides an alternative mechanism for transcriptional regulation in bacteria, such as H. pylori, which possesses a limited repertoire of classical trans-acting regulatory factors.
Human papillomavirus ( HPV ) is a high-risk virus that must evade the innate immune response to establish persistent infections and amplify its genome upon epithelial differentiation. The JAK-STAT transcriptional regulator, STAT-5, plays an important role in modulating the inflammatory response and controlling cell cycle progression in response to cytokines and growth factors. Our studies show that the HPV E7 protein activates STAT-5 phosphorylation without altering total protein levels. Inhibition of STAT-5 phosphorylation by the drug pimozide abolishes viral genome amplification and late gene expression in differentiating keratinocytes. In contrast, treatment of undifferentiated cells that stably maintain episomes has no effect on viral replication. Knockdown studies show that the STAT-5β isoform is mainly responsible for this activity and that this is mediated through the ATM DNA damage response. The peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ ( PPARγ ) is a downstream target of STAT-5 and contributes to the effects on members of the ATM pathway. Overall, these findings identify an important new regulatory mechanism by which the innate immune regulator, STAT-5, promotes HPV viral replication through activation of the ATM DNA damage response.
Typhoid fever, caused by Salmonella enterica serotype Typhi ( S. Typhi ), is a major public health problem in typhoid endemic areas. Chronic carriers of S. Typhi may act as persistent reservoirs of infection, introducing the disease to susceptible individuals and new communities. However, little is known about the interaction between the host and pathogen in the biliary tract of chronic carriers, and there is currently no reliable diagnostic assay to identify asymptomatic S. Typhi carriage. To study host-pathogen interactions in the biliary tract during S. Typhi carriage, we applied an immunoscreening technique called in vivo-induced antigen technology ( IVIAT ) to identify potential biomarkers unique to carriers. We hypothesized that S. Typhi surviving in the biliary tract of humans may express a distinct antigenic profile. Thirteen S. Typhi antigens that were immunoreactive in carriers, but not in healthy individuals from a typhoid endemic area, were identified. The identified antigens included a number of putative membrane proteins, lipoproteins, and hemolysin-related proteins. One antigen, YncE ( STY1479 ), an uncharacterized protein with an ATP-binding motif, gave prominent responses in our screen. Further evaluation of YncE and other antigens identified by IVIAT could lead to the development of improved diagnostic assays to identify asymptomatic S. Typhi carriers.
Trans-reactivation is a new epigenetic phenomenon in which non-functional alleles of a gene can reactivate the expression of a wild type copy of the same gene that is silenced by heterochromatin. In this phenomenon, non-functional alleles of the white gene, which are unable to produce a coding transcript, can reactivate the expression of a wild type copy of white that is silenced by heterochromatin. This effect is heritable, relies on the presence of homologous RNA molecules, and is affected by mutations in genes involved in post-transcriptional gene silencing. Our data suggest that trans-reactivation is a new level of gene expression control mediated by homologous RNA molecules in the context of heterochromatic genes. The mechanisms of trans-reactivation appear to be different from previously characterized epigenetic reprogramming events, such as paramutation, transinduction, and transvection. In trans-reactivation, transcribing RNAs that are unable to produce a full coding transcript can positively influence the transcriptional state of an homologous locus silenced by heterochromatin. The presence of non-functional white alleles causes an increase in the wm4h gene transcript as well as an opening in the chromatin structure at the wm4h locus.
Boophilin is a multifunctional Kunitz protease inhibitor expressed in the midgut of the tick vector Rhipicephalus microplus. It targets thrombin, elastase, and kallikrein in the coagulation and complement cascades. Boophilin was expressed in HEK293 cells, purified to homogeneity, and characterized using amidolytic assays and surface plasmon resonance experiments. The results show that Boophilin behaves as a classical, non-competitive inhibitor of thrombin with respect to small chromogenic substrates, with a Ki of ~ 100 nM. It also inhibits thrombin in a non-canonical manner, despite possessing a canonical reactive site loop. Boophilin blocks platelet aggregation, fibrin formation, and clot-bound thrombin in vitro. Notably, it also inhibits FXIa, preventing FIX activation, and kallikrein activity, indicating that it targets the contact pathway. In addition, Boophilin inhibits cathepsin G- and plasmin-induced platelet aggregation and partially affects elastase-mediated cleavage of Tissue Factor Pathway Inhibitor ( TFPI ). Finally, Boophilin inhibits carotid artery occlusion in vivo triggered by FeCl3 and promotes bleeding according to the mice tail transection method.
Inflammation plays a significant role in the pathogenesis of many gastrointestinal diseases. The mucosa of the intestinal tract is a finely tuned system where tissue structure influences and is influenced by its function as both an absorptive surface and a defensive barrier. We have developed the Spatially Explicit General-purpose Model of Enteric Tissue ( SEGMEnT ) to dynamically represent existing knowledge of the behavior of enteric epithelial tissue as influenced by inflammation. SEGMEnT is an agent-based computational model that simulates the cellular and molecular interactions that maintain and modify the enteric mucosal architecture. It models the spatial dynamics of the crypt-villus tissue architecture as generated by the behavior of gut epithelial cells as they undergo replication, migration, and differentiation, with the novel incorporation of the effect of inflammation on those morphogenic processes. SEGMEnT represents a minimally sufficient set of components and interactions to achieve a face valid representation of the mechanisms involved in maintaining the enteric mucosal architecture ( morphogenesis ) and its response to an initial set of perturbations ( inflammation ). In addition to reproducing healthy ileal mucosal dynamics, SEGMEnT provides insight into a range of clinically relevant cellular-molecular mechanisms, such as a putative role for PTEN/PI3K as a key point of crosstalk between inflammation and morphogenesis, the protective role of enterocyte sloughing in enteric ischemia-reperfusion, and chronic low level inflammation as a driver for colonic metaplasia. These results suggest that SEGMEnT can serve as an integrating platform for the study of inflammation in gastrointestinal disease.
Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are a major vector of arboviruses such as dengue, Zika, and chikungunya. Traditional vector control methods have limited effect on reducing Ae. aegypti populations. Wolbachia, an endosymbiotic bacterium, has been proposed as a promising tool to mitigate arbovirus transmission. The wMelBr strain of Wolbachia was released in the community of Tubiacanga, Rio de Janeiro for 20 consecutive weeks. However, the frequency of Wolbachia-positive Ae. aegypti mosquitoes plateaued at around 40% after 7–19 weeks and declined after releases stopped. This was attributed to the high level of pyrethroid resistance in the local Ae. aegypti population. A new strain, wMelRio, was produced by backcrossing wMelBr females with males from the field to introduce pyrethroid resistance alleles. The wMelRio strain successfully established in the local population where wMelBr failed, highlighting the importance of matching the local population genetics, especially the insecticide resistance background, to achieve Wolbachia invasion. The wMelRio strain increased mosquito survival but had negative effects on Ae. aegypti fecundity traits. The results suggest that Wolbachia deployment should match the insecticide resistance profile of the wild population to achieve invasion.
Poxviruses are complex viruses that have evolved sophisticated signaling pathways to engage cellular defense mechanisms while ensuring proper modulation of viral factors. The vaccinia B1 protein kinase plays a crucial role in inactivating the cellular antiviral factor BAF and likely orchestrates other pathways as well. In this study, we used experimental evolution of a B1 deletion virus to identify novel pathways involving B1. After several passages of the ΔB1 virus, we observed a robust increase in viral titer of the adapted virus. Characterization of the adapted viruses revealed that mutations correlating with a loss of function of the vaccinia B12 pseudokinase provide a striking fitness enhancement to this virus. We present multiple lines of evidence demonstrating that expression of full length B12 leads to a fitness reduction in viruses with a defect in B1, but has no apparent impact on wild-type virus or other mutant poxviruses. We infer that B12 possesses a potent inhibitory activity that can be masked by the presence of the B1 kinase. B12 primarily localizes to the nucleus and may function in part by enhancing antiviral activity of BAF. Our studies of B1 and B12 present novel evidence that a paralogous kinase-pseudokinase pair can exhibit a unique epistatic relationship in a virus, perhaps serving to enhance B1 conservation during poxvirus evolution and to orchestrate yet-to-be-discovered nuclear events during infection.
The conformational behavior of two synthetic peptides, LK and EALA, with built-in secondary α-helical amphiphilicity, has been studied using molecular dynamics simulations. The peptides are neither random coils nor fully formed α-helices in bulk water, but instead adopt multiple conformations and secondary structure elements with short lifetimes on the order of 100 ns or less. The α-helix conformation is not stable in bulk water, and the peptides display a variety of secondary structures, including partial α-helices. The conformation of these intrinsically disordered peptides strongly depends on the environment. The presence of a macroscopic vacuum/water interface leads to a strong partitioning of hydrophobic/hydrophilic residues, which enforces a unique conformation by stabilizing the α-helical form for both model systems. In the case of the LK peptide, the bulk water ensemble is already dominated by conformations where a large fraction of the residues are in an α-helical state. Differences in the peptides’ response to macroscopic and molecular interfaces can be linked to their inherent α-helical tendencies in bulk water. The peptides’ aggregation behavior is also strongly affected by the presence or absence of an interface, and rather subtly depends on their surface charge and hydrophobicity.
Human herpesvirus 6A ( HHV-6A ) and 6B ( HHV-6B ) are ubiquitous betaherpesviruses that infect humans within the first years of life and establish latency in various cell types. Both viruses can integrate their genomes into telomeres of host chromosomes in latently infected cells. The molecular mechanism of viral integration has remained elusive. Interestingly, HHV-6A, HHV-6B and several other herpesviruses harbor arrays of telomeric repeats ( TMR ) identical to human telomere sequences at the ends of their genomes. To determine if the TMR are involved in virus integration, we deleted both pTMR and impTMR in the HHV-6A genome. Upon reconstitution, the TMR mutant virus replicated comparable to wild type ( wt ) virus, indicating that the TMR are not essential for HHV-6A replication. However, integration of HHV-6A was severely impaired in the absence of the TMR and the virus genome was lost rapidly, suggesting that integration is crucial for the maintenance of the virus genome. Individual deletion of the pTMR and impTMR revealed that the pTMR play the major role in HHV-6A integration, whereas the impTMR only make a minor contribution, allowing us to establish a model for HHV-6A integration. Taken together, our data shows that the HHV-6A TMR are dispensable for virus replication, but are crucial for integration and maintenance of the virus genome in latently infected cells.
Poxviruses are unique among enveloped viruses in that they do not acquire their internal lipid membrane by budding through cellular compartments. Instead, they produce infectious particles from atypical crescent-shaped precursors whose architecture and composition have been contentious. Here, we describe the 2. 6 Å crystal structure of vaccinia virus D13, a key structural component of the outer scaffold of viral crescents. D13 folds into two jellyrolls decorated by a head domain of novel fold and assembles into trimers that are homologous to the double-barrel capsid proteins of adenovirus and lipid-containing icosahedral viruses. We show that when tethered onto artificial membranes, D13 forms a honeycomb lattice and assembly products structurally similar to the viral crescents and immature particles. The architecture of the D13 honeycomb lattice and the lipid-remodeling abilities of D13 support a model of assembly that exhibits similarities with the giant mimivirus. Overall, these findings establish that the first committed step of poxvirus morphogenesis utilizes an ancestral lipid-remodeling strategy common to icosahedral DNA viruses infecting all kingdoms of life. Furthermore, D13 is the target of rifampicin and its structure will aid the development of poxvirus assembly inhibitors.
Brachypodium distachyon ( Brachypodium ) is a monocotyledonous plant used as a model organism to study plant development. In contrast to Arabidopsis thaliana ( Arabidopsis ), a dicotyledonous plant, Brachypodium mutants in the TAR2-LIKE ( BdTAR2L ) gene, which encodes a tryptophan aminotransferase involved in auxin biosynthesis, display dramatically elongated seminal roots due to enhanced cell elongation. This phenotype is also observed in another BdTAR2L allele and can be mimicked by treating wild type with L-kynerunine, a specific TAA1/TAR inhibitor. Surprisingly, L-kynerunine-treated as well as Bdtar2l roots display elevated rather than reduced auxin levels, which does not appear to result from compensation by alternative auxin biosynthesis pathways. Instead, expression of YUCCA genes, which are rate-limiting for conversion of indole-3-pyruvic acid ( IPA ) to auxin, is increased in Bdtar2l mutants. Our results reveal a delicate homeostasis of local auxin and ethylene activity to control cell elongation in Brachypodium roots and suggest alternative wiring of auxin-ethylene crosstalk as compared to Arabidopsis.
The organization of promoter nucleosomes has been found to shape the evolution of gene expression in species of the budding yeast. The rate at which genes diverge in expression correlates with the organization of their promoter nucleosomes: genes lacking a nucleosome-free region ( OPN ) vary widely between species, while the expression of those containing a nucleosome-free region ( DPN ) remains largely conserved. To examine if early evolutionary dynamics contributes to this difference in divergence, we artificially selected for high expression of GFP–fused proteins. Surprisingly, selection was equally successful for OPN and DPN genes, with ∼80% of genes in each group stably increasing in expression by a similar amount. Notably, the two groups adapted by distinct mechanisms: DPN–selected strains duplicated large genomic regions, while OPN–selected strains favored trans mutations not involving duplications. When selection was removed, DPN ( but not OPN ) genes reverted rapidly to wild-type expression levels, consistent with their lower diversity between species. Our results suggest that promoter organization constrains the early evolutionary dynamics and in this way biases the path of long-term evolution.
The human T lymphotropic virus type 1 ( HTLV-1 ) trans-activator/oncoprotein, Tax, is thought to promote cell proliferation and transformation by activating I-κB kinases ( IKKs ) and NF-κB. However, in most cells, Tax expression leads to the up-regulation of cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors, p21CIP1/WAF1 and p27KIP1, resulting in p53-/pRb-independent cellular senescence. Here, we demonstrate that p21CIP1/WAF1-/p27KIP1-mediated senescence constitutes a checkpoint against IKK/NF-κB hyper-activation. Senescence induced by Tax in HeLa cells is attenuated by mutations in Tax that reduce IKK/NF-κB activation and prevented by blocking NF-κB using a degradation-resistant mutant of I-κBα. We show that RelA induces this senescence program by acting upstream of the anaphase promoting complex and RelB to stabilize p27KIP1 protein and p21CIP1/WAF1 mRNA, respectively. Finally, we show that down-regulation of NF-κB by the HTLV-1 anti-sense protein, HBZ, delays or prevents the onset of Tax-induced senescence. We propose that the balance between Tax and HBZ expression determines the outcome of HTLV-1 infection. Robust HTLV-1 replication and elevated Tax expression drive IKK/NF-κB hyper-activation and trigger senescence, while HBZ modulates Tax-mediated viral replication and NF-κB activation, allowing HTLV-1-infected cells to proliferate, persist, and evolve.
The frontal lobes of the human brain are responsible for decision-making and executive control, which involves the selection and coordination of goal-directed behaviors. However, current models of frontal executive function do not fully explain how humans make decisions in everyday situations that are uncertain, changing, and open-ended. Here, we propose a computational model of human executive function that clarifies this issue. The proposed model predicts human decisions and their variations across individuals in naturalistic situations.
