It reveals that the human frontal function monitors up to three or four concurrent behavioral strategies and infers their ability to predict action outcomes. When one strategy appears more reliable than others, it is chosen to guide the selection and learning of actions that maximize rewards. Otherwise, a new behavioral strategy is tentatively formed from those stored in long-term memory, then probed, and if competitive, confirmed to drive action. The human executive function has a monitoring capacity limited to three or four behavioral strategies, which is compensated by a binary structure of executive control that promotes the exploration and creation of new behavioral strategies in ambiguous and unknown situations. The results support a model of human frontal function that integrates reasoning, learning, and creative abilities in the service of decision-making and adaptive behavior.
Pharmacological interventions are increasingly used to treat progressive diseases, but their long-term effects are difficult to predict. To address this challenge, we present a new modeling approach called Analysis of Dynamic Adaptations in Parameter Trajectories ( ADAPT ). ADAPT employs mathematical modeling to predict the long-term effects of a pharmacological intervention by introducing a concept of time-dependent descriptions of model parameters to study the dynamics of molecular adaptations. This approach dynamically links different experimentally observed phenotypes as a function of time, providing an integrated understanding of the outcome of a pharmacological intervention or disease progression. We applied ADAPT to a model of hepatic lipid and plasma lipoprotein metabolism to predict the metabolic adaptations induced upon pharmacological treatment of mice with the liver X receptor ( LXR ) agonist T0901317. Our computational analysis showed that although activation of LXR promotes cholesterol efflux and excretion, the hepatic capacity to clear cholesterol was reduced upon prolonged treatment. This prediction was confirmed experimentally by immunoblotting measurements of scavenger receptor class B1 ( SR-B1 ) in hepatic membranes. ADAPT can be used to identify potential unwanted side effects of pharmacological interventions and to design new target interventions to prevent them.
The cerebellum plays a crucial role in the coordination of our multi-segmented bodies and limbs. However, the mechanisms that underlie this function are not well understood. In this paper, we propose a new hypothesis for how the spinocerebellar systems and the cerebellar cortex interact to support coordination. Our hypothesis suggests that the spinal circuitry provides useful recombinations of sensory and motor signals to the cerebellar cortex, which can be described as linear projections through the multi-dimensional sensorimotor input space. These projections are enhanced by the cerebellar granule layer, which allows the Purkinje cell to establish piecewise-linear approximations of non-linear functions. We argue that the close correspondence between sensor signals and motor command signals in the individual neurons of the spinocerebellar system is a means to avoid superfluous recombinations and to form ‘good enough’ recombinations with a high probability. Our hypothesis provides a novel view on the function of the spinal circuitry and cerebellar granule layer, illustrating how the coordinating functions of the cerebellum can be crucially supported by the recombinations performed by the neurons of the spinocerebellar systems.
Chikungunya virus ( CHIKV ) infection in Aedes albopictus, an important mosquito vector, leads to changes in the expression of microRNAs ( miRNAs ). miRNAs are small non-coding RNAs that regulate gene expression and are involved in various cellular processes. In this study, we identified 88 and 79 known miRNAs in uninfected and CHIKV infected Ae. albopictus cell lines, respectively. We further identified nine novel miRNAs in Ae. albopictus. Comparison of the two libraries revealed differential expression of 77 common miRNAs between them. CHIKV infection specifically altered the miRNA profile of a specific set of eight miRNAs. We identified putative targets of these regulated miRNAs and classified them into their pathways. We further analyzed the distribution and abundance of these miRNAs and evaluated their modulation upon CHIKV infection. We identified four significantly over-expressed miRNAs ( miR-100, miR-283, miR-305-3p and miR-927 ) and four under-expressed miRNAs ( miR-1000, miR-2b, miR-2c-3p and miR-190-5p ) upon CHIKV infection in Ae. albopictus.
Cystic echinococcosis ( CE ) is a parasitic infection of humans and livestock with significant medical and economic importance in many developing countries, including Iran. The present study aimed to determine the monetary burden of CE in Iran using epidemiological and economic data obtained from regional hospitals, the scientific literature, and official government reports. The study estimated the mean number of surgical CE cases per year for 2000–2009 at 1, 295, and the number of asymptomatic individuals living in the country at 635, 232 ( 95% Credible Interval, CI 149, 466–1, 120, 998 ). The overall annual cost of CE in Iran was estimated at US$232. 3 million ( 95% CI US$103. 1–397. 8 million ), including both direct and indirect costs. The cost associated with human CE was estimated at US$93. 39 million ( 95% CI US$6. 1–222. 7 million ) and the annual cost associated with CE in livestock was estimated at US$132 million ( 95% CI US$61. 8–246. 5 million ). The cost per surgical human case was estimated at US$1, 539. The economic impact of CE on Iran was considerable, with the cost of the disease approximated at 0. 03% of the country's gross domestic product.
Mouse polyomavirus ( MPyV ) is a highly oncogenic virus that infects mouse cells, transforms rat cells in culture, and causes cancer in rodents. In this study, we have used deep sequencing to follow MPyV infection of mouse NIH3T6 cells at various times after infection and analyzed both the viral and cellular transcriptomes. We found that both early-strand and late-strand RNAs are transcribed at all times after infection, and that there is widespread RNA editing of viral transcripts at late times in infection. By 36 hours after infection, 359 host genes were significantly upregulated and 857 were downregulated. Gene ontology analysis revealed that transcripts involved in translation, metabolism, RNA processing, DNA methylation, and protein turnover were upregulated, while transcripts involved in extracellular adhesion, cytoskeleton, zinc finger binding, SH3 domain, and GTPase activation were downregulated. We also found that the levels of a number of long noncoding RNAs were altered, including the downregulation of the long noncoding RNA MALAT1, which is involved in splicing speckles and used as a marker in many late-stage cancers.
Each year, hundreds of thousands of runners attempt to complete a marathon, but more than two-fifths experience severe and performance-limiting depletion of physiologic carbohydrate reserves, a phenomenon known as ‘hitting the wall. ’ Previous analyses of endurance physiology have suggested that human glycogen reserves are insufficient to fuel a marathon or that maximal glycogen loading is required to complete a marathon without ‘hitting the wall. ’ However, the present study demonstrates that the energetic constraints on endurance runners are more subtle and depend on several physiologic variables, including muscle mass distribution, liver and muscle glycogen densities, and running speed. The study presents a computational model that estimates the distance at which runners will exhaust their glycogen stores as a function of running intensity. The model also provides a basis for guidelines ensuring the safety and optimizing the performance of endurance runners by setting personally appropriate paces and prescribing midrace fueling requirements to avoid ‘hitting the wall. ’ The analysis also sheds light on important standards in marathon running, such as the qualifying times for the Boston Marathon.
Toxoplasma gondii is a protozoan parasite that infects a wide range of hosts and causes toxoplasmosis, a disease with variable outcomes in humans and mice. The parasite exists in three genetically distinct clonal lineages ( type I, II, and III ) in Europe and North America, but a great variety of other strains are found in South America. These strains differ in virulence, persistence, oral infectivity, migratory capacity, induction of cytokine expression, and modulation of host gene expression. To determine if non-canonical Toxoplasma strains have unique interactions with the host cell, we infected murine macrophages with 29 different Toxoplasma strains, representing global diversity, and used RNA-sequencing to determine host and parasite transcriptomes. We identified large differences between strains in the expression level of known parasite effectors and large chromosomal structural variation in some strains. We also identified novel strain-specifically regulated host pathways, including the regulation of the type I interferon response by some atypical strains. We found that IFNβ production by infected cells was associated with parasite killing, independent of interferon gamma activation, and dependent on endosomal Toll-like receptors in macrophages and the cytoplasmic receptor retinoic acid-inducible gene 1 ( RIG-I ) in fibroblasts. Our study provides global insight into host cells and parasite transcriptional responses upon infection with both canonical and exotic Toxoplasma strains, and allows identification of novel strain-specific host cell responses and parasite effectors.
Recombination in enteroviruses is an evolutionary mechanism that allows for the acquisition of extensive regions of novel sequence and has been implicated in the emergence of novel neuropathogenic variants of poliovirus. Despite its importance, the recombination process in enteroviruses remains poorly understood. We investigated heterologous recombination in polioviruses using a novel reverse genetic approach that resulted in the isolation of intermediate chimeric intertypic polioviruses bearing genomes with extensive duplicated sequences at the recombination junction. Serial passage of viruses exhibiting such imprecise junctions yielded progeny with increased fitness that had lost the duplicated sequences. We propose that extant recombinants result from a biphasic process in which an initial recombination event is followed by a process of resolution, deleting extraneous sequences and optimizing viral fitness. Mutations or inhibitors that changed polymerase fidelity or the coalescence of replication complexes markedly altered the yield of recombinants, indicating that the process is replicative and may be possible to enhance or reduce recombination-mediated viral evolution if required.
Beiging of white adipose tissue ( WAT ) is a promising target for the treatment of metabolic diseases, and norepinephrine ( NE ) -mediated signaling pathways play a key role in this process. Previous studies have identified NE clearance mechanisms via SLC6A2 on sympathetic neurons or proinflammatory macrophages in adipose tissues ( ATs ). However, the low catecholamine clearance capacity of SLC6A2 may limit the cleaning efficiency. Here, we report that mouse organic cation transporter 3 ( Oct3; Slc22a3 ) is highly expressed in WAT and displays the greatest uptake rate of NE as a selective non-neural route of NE clearance in white adipocytes. We further show that adipocytes express high levels of NE degradation enzymes Maoa, Maob, and Comt, providing the molecular basis for NE clearance by adipocytes together with its reuptake transporter Oct3. Our results demonstrate that Oct3 is essential in catecholamine clearance in adipocytes of WAT and blunts intracellular responses upon sustained catecholamine stimulation by regulating the activity of β-AR. In adipose-specific Oct3-deficient mice, NE administration induces higher body temperature, thermogenesis, and lipolysis compared with littermate controls. After prolonged cold challenge, inguinal WAT in adipose-specific Oct3-deficient mice shows much stronger browning characteristics and significantly elevated expression of thermogenic and mitochondrial biogenesis genes than in littermate controls.
HP1 proteins are a family of heterochromatin-enriched proteins that play a critical role in the regulation of transcription. They contain two related domains: the chromo-domain ( CD ) and the chromoshadow-domain ( CSD ). The CD binds to histone H3 tails that are methylated on lysine 9 ( H3K9 ), an epigenetic mark associated with transcriptional repression. However, in vivo and in vitro experiments have shown that the affinity of HP1 proteins to native methylated chromatin is relatively poor, and that the opening of chromatin during DNA replication facilitates their binding to nucleosomes. We show that HP1 proteins use the CSD to associate with histone H3 at the level of the entry/exit point of the nucleosome barrel, a region also contacted by the catalytic subunits of the human SWI/SNF complex, Brg1 and Brm. This interaction is essential for efficient SWI/SNF remodeling and is inhibited in the presence of HP1 proteins. We also show that SWI/SNF activity favors the loading of HP1 proteins onto chromatin both in vivo and in vitro. Altogether, our data suggest that HP1 chromoshadow-domains can benefit from the opening of nucleosomal structures to bind chromatin and that HP1 proteins use this property to detect and arrest unwanted chromatin remodeling.
MicroRNAs ( miRNAs ) are a class of functional RNAs that require structural invariance during biogenesis, which involves extraction of the substructure from a larger structural context. We define the property of self containment to be the tendency for an RNA sequence to robustly adopt the same optimal secondary structure regardless of whether it exists in isolation or is a substring of a longer sequence of arbitrary nucleotide content. We developed a scoring method called the self-containment index to measure the degree of self containment. We found that miRNA stem loops exhibit high self containment, consistent with the requirement for structural invariance imposed by the miRNA biogenesis pathway, while most other structured RNAs do not. Further analysis revealed a trend toward higher self containment among clustered and conserved miRNAs, suggesting that high self containment may be a characteristic of novel miRNAs acquiring new genomic contexts. We found that miRNAs display significantly enhanced self containment compared to other functional RNAs, but we also found a trend toward natural selection for self containment in most functional RNA classes. We suggest that self containment arises out of selection for robustness against perturbations, invariance during biogenesis, and modular composition of structural function.
Necrotrophic fungal pathogens, such as Botrytis cinerea and Plectosphaerella cucumerina, cause disease in plants by killing host cells and using them as a nutrient source. Although several signaling components of disease resistance against necrotrophic fungal pathogens have been identified, our understanding of how molecular components and host processes contribute to plant disease susceptibility is limited. Here, we identified four transcription factors ( TFs ) from Arabidopsis that limit pathogen spread. Arabidopsis mutants defective in any of these TFs displayed increased disease susceptibility to Botrytis cinerea and Plectosphaerella cucumerina, and a general activation of non-immune host processes that contribute to plant disease susceptibility. Transcriptome analyses revealed that the mutants share a common transcriptional signature of 77 up-regulated genes. We characterized several of the up-regulated genes that encode peptides with a secretion signal, which we named PROVIR ( for provirulence ) factors. Forward and reverse genetic analyses revealed that many of the PROVIRs are important for disease susceptibility of the host to fungal necrotrophs. Over-expression of many of the PROVIR factors in Arabidopsis conferred increased susceptibility to the necrotroph P. cucumerina, and, conversely, loss-of-function mutants conferred increased resistance.
FOXO1 is a transcription factor that plays a critical role in regulating uterine epithelial integrity and progesterone receptor (PGR) expression, both of which are essential for successful embryo implantation. We demonstrate that uterine ablation of Foxo1 in mice results in infertility due to altered epithelial cell polarity and apoptosis, which prevents the embryo from penetrating the luminal epithelium. The uterine transcriptome after Foxo1 ablation shows alterations in gene expression for transcripts involved in cell invasion, molecular transport, apoptosis, β-catenin ( CTNNB1 ) signaling pathway, and an increase in PGR signaling. The increase in PGR signaling is due to PGR expression being retained in the uterine epithelium during the window of receptivity. Constitutive expression of epithelial PGR during this receptive period inhibits expression of FOXO1 in the nucleus of the uterine epithelium. The reciprocal expression of PGR and FOXO1 is conserved in human endometrial samples during the proliferative and secretory phase. This demonstrates that expression of FOXO1 and the loss of PGR during the window of receptivity are interrelated and critical for embryo implantation. FOXO1 regulates the expression of multiple components of signaling pathways that establish the receptive phase, including activation of cell invasion, molecular transport, apoptosis, CTNNB1 signaling pathway, as well as inhibition of PGR signaling in the murine endometrial epithelium.
Dengue fever is a major public health concern in Bangladesh, with the majority of reported cases occurring between August and September. We present the first model-based estimates of the monthly geographical distribution of dengue cases in Bangladesh using a negative binomial generalised linear mixed effect model accounting for zero-inflation, spatial, and temporal random effects. The model was fitted to the district-level monthly reported dengue cases aggregated over the period 2000 to 2009. We found that mean monthly temperature and its interaction with mean monthly diurnal temperature range, lagged by two months, were significantly associated with dengue incidence. Mean monthly rainfall at two months lag was positively associated with dengue incidence. Densely populated districts and districts bordering India or Myanmar had higher incidence than others. The model estimated that 92% of the annual dengue cases occurred between August and September. Cases were identified across the country with 94% in the capital Dhaka. Less than half of the affected districts reported cases as observed from the surveillance data. The proportion reported varied by month with a higher proportion reported in high-incidence districts, but dropped towards the end of the high transmission season.
Mice are known to establish a preferred place in a novel environment, characterized by the highest number of visits and longest cumulative time spent in it, which we term the home base. In addition to the home base, we have identified a new type of preferred place called a knot, which is marked by the performance of a tortuous path full of twists and turns during exploratory behavior in an open field arena. This behavior is termed knot-scribbling. Knots are characterized by a high path density, frequent visits that do not involve knot-scribbling, and a higher speed on the way into the knot than on the way out of it. Unlike the home base, knots are not characterized by long visits and are typically situated in the place of introduction into the arena, away from walls. The establishment of knots is enhanced by injecting the mouse with saline and placing it in an exposed portion of the arena, suggesting that stress and the associated arousal consolidate a long-term contingency between a particular locale and knot-scribbling. Knot-scribbling could function as a way to obtain an overview of the entire environment, allowing re-calibration of the mouse's locale map and compass directions.
Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that causes more deaths than malaria worldwide. We identified the ergoline compound NGx04 in an antifungal screen with selectivity over mammalian cells. High-resolution chemogenomics identified the lipid transfer protein Sec14p as the target of NGx04. Sec14p is essential for the pathogenicity of C. neoformans and is involved in the secretion of virulence determinants. We demonstrate that NGx04 inhibits the growth of two clinical isolates of C. neoformans and that NGx04-related compounds have equal and even higher potency against C. neoformans. Furthermore, NGx04 analogues showed fungicidal activity against a fluconazole-resistant C. neoformans strain. We present genetic evidence that NGx04 inhibits fungal Sec14p and initial data supporting NGx04 as a novel antifungal starting point.
Schistosomiasis, an often neglected tropical disease, is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The only available drug for its treatment and control is praziquantel. However, the large-scale use of praziquantel may select for drug-resistant parasites. Therefore, there is a need to develop new antischistosomal compounds. Here, we report that the antimalarial drug mefloquine possesses promising antischistosomal properties in mice. A single dose of mefloquine ( 200 or 400 mg/kg ) administered orally to mice infected with adult Schistosoma mansoni or adult S. japonicum resulted in high or complete total and female worm burden reductions ( 72. 3%–100% ). Importantly, high worm burden reductions were also observed for young developing stages of S. mansoni and S. japonicum harbored in the mouse. Both mefloquine erythro-enantiomers resulted in high and comparable total and female worm burden reductions when given to mice with either a sub-patent or patent S. mansoni infection. Our findings hold promise for the development of a novel antischistosomal drug based on an aminoalcohol functionality. Further in vitro and in vivo studies have been launched to elucidate the possible mechanism of action and to study the effect of mefloquine on S. haematobium and other trematodes.
Podoconiosis, a non-filarial elephantiasis causing massive swelling of the lower legs, has been identified as a neglected tropical disease by the World Health Organization ( WHO ) since 2011. However, the geographical distribution of podoconiosis in Cameroon remains poorly understood. This study aimed to map the distribution of podoconiosis in Cameroon using parasitological, serological, and clinical evidence to exclude other causes of lymphedema. A multi-stage sampling design was used to select 76 villages from 40 health districts across ten regions of Cameroon. A total of 10, 178 individuals from 4, 603 households were surveyed, and 83 individuals with lymphedema were identified. After applying a clinical algorithm to exclude filarial-associated lymphedema, 52 individuals were diagnosed with podoconiosis. The overall prevalence of podoconiosis was found to be 0. 5% ( 95% CI; 0. 4–0. 7 ). Podoconiosis was found to be widespread in Cameroon, with at least one case identified in every region except the two surveyed villages in Adamawa. The prevalence of podoconiosis ranged from 0. 2% to 2. 7% across the 40 health districts surveyed.
In Drosophila female germline stem cells ( GSCs ), Notch signaling is increased with age and results in their removal from the niche. Clonal analysis revealed that GSCs with low levels of Notch signaling exhibit increased adhesiveness to the niche, thereby out-competing their neighbors with higher levels of Notch. This increased adhesiveness is altered through regulation of E-cadherin expression. Experimental enhancement of Notch signaling in GSCs hastens their age-dependent loss from the niche, and such loss is at least partially mediated by Sex lethal. However, disruption of Notch signaling in GSCs does not delay GSC loss during aging, and nor does it affect BMP signaling, which promotes self-renewal of GSCs. In contrast to GSCs, Notch signaling in niche cells is decreased with age, thus contributing to age-induced GSC loss. Our findings expose a novel role of Notch signaling in controlling GSC-niche adhesion in response to aging, and are also of relevance to metastatic cancer cells, in which Notch signaling suppresses cell adhesion.
Human cytomegalovirus ( HCMV, or HHV-5 ( human herpesvirus 5 ) ) encodes the UL97 protein, a kinase that phosphorylates the cellular retinoblastoma ( Rb ) tumor suppressor and lamin A/C proteins, which are also substrates of cellular cyclin-dependent kinases ( Cdks ). A functional complementation assay has shown that UL97 has authentic Cdk-like activity. The other seven human herpesviruses each encode a kinase with sequence and positional homology to UL97. These UL97-homologous proteins have been termed the conserved herpesvirus protein kinases ( CHPKs ). To determine if the Cdk-like activities of UL97 were shared by all of the CHPKs, we individually expressed epitope-tagged alleles of each protein in human Saos-2 cells to test for Rb phosphorylation, human U-2 OS cells to monitor nuclear lamina disruption and lamin A phosphorylation, or S. cerevisiae cdc28-13 mutant cells to directly assay for Cdk function. We found that the ability to phosphorylate Rb and lamin A, and to disrupt the nuclear lamina, was shared by all CHPKs from the beta- and gamma-herpesvirus families, but not by their alpha-herpesvirus homologs. Similarly, all but one of the beta and gamma CHPKs displayed bona fide Cdk activity in S. cerevisiae, while the alpha proteins did not.
Burkholderia pseudomallei, the causative agent of melioidosis, is a Gram-negative bacillus present in the environment in many tropical countries. Defining the global distribution of B. pseudomallei is important for developing a risk map for melioidosis, as it provides the geographical setting for preventive measures and raises awareness of the disease among healthcare workers in affected areas. Our objective was to review the literature on the detection of environmental B. pseudomallei, update the risk map for melioidosis, and propose international consensus guidelines for soil sampling. We found that global coverage was patchy, with a lack of studies in many areas where melioidosis is suspected to occur. The sampling strategies and bacterial identification methods used were highly variable, and not all were robust. We developed consensus guidelines with the goals of reducing the probability of false-negative results and providing affordable and ‘low-tech’ methodology applicable in both developed and developing countries. The proposed consensus guidelines provide the basis for the development of an accurate and comprehensive global map of environmental B. pseudomallei.
Dengue-virus entry into host cells is mediated by the envelope glycoprotein ( E ), which undergoes large-scale domain rearrangements to facilitate membrane fusion. We have identified peptides derived from the membrane proximal region of the E protein that bind specifically to the postfusion conformation of the E protein, which is a model for a fusion intermediate. These peptides inhibit dengue-virus infectivity, even when free peptide is removed from a preincubated inoculum before infecting cells. This suggests that the peptides bind virions before attachment and are carried with virions into endosomes, the compartment in which acidification initiates fusion. Binding depends on particle dynamics, as there is no inhibition of infectivity if preincubation and separation are at 4°C rather than 37°C. We propose a two-step model for the mechanism of fusion inhibition, in which the peptides bind to the postfusion conformation of the E protein and prevent the transition to the fusion-competent conformation. Our data support and extend proposed mechanisms for how the E conformational change promotes membrane fusion, and suggest strategies for inhibiting flavivirus entry.
Cholera, caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae, is a major public health concern worldwide, with an estimated 4 million cases and 95, 000 deaths annually. Recent outbreaks in Haiti and Yemen highlight the need for rapid, low-cost, and sustainable methods for molecular analysis of V. cholerae in resource-limited settings. Here, we demonstrate that whole genome sequencing ( WGS ) of V. cholerae can be performed directly from stool specimens preserved on filter paper. We show that a minimum concentration of 0. 02 ng/μL of V. cholerae DNA is sufficient to produce quality genomic information. WGS confirmed the presence or absence of genes of epidemiological interest, including cholera toxin and pilus loci, and identified a variety of diarrheal pathogens from alkaline peptone water ( APW )-enriched specimen spotted filter papers. These results highlight the potential for this technique to explore the gut microbiome and identify co-infections that may impact the severity of disease. WGS also allowed for mapping of short reads from APW-enriched specimen and culture isolate spotted filter papers, providing valuable molecular epidemiological sequence information on V. cholerae strains from remote, low-resource settings. These results identified the presence of co-infecting pathogens and provided rare insight into the specific V. cholerae strains causing outbreaks in cholera-endemic areas.
Dynein, a cytoplasmic motor protein, has been identified as an essential regulator of epithelial polarity in Drosophila follicle cells. Through a genetic screen for epithelial defects, we have found that Dynein is required for apico–basal polarity. Our data suggest that Dynein acts through the cytoplasmic scaffolding protein Stardust ( Sdt ) to localize the transmembrane protein Crumbs, in part through the apical targeting of specific sdt mRNA isoforms. We have mapped the sdt mRNA localization signal to an alternatively spliced coding exon. The presence or absence of this exon corresponds to a developmental switch in sdt mRNA localization in which apical transcripts are only found during early stages of epithelial development, while unlocalized transcripts predominate in mature epithelia. This work represents the first demonstration that Dynein is required for epithelial polarity and suggests that mRNA localization may have a functional role in the regulation of apico–basal organization. Moreover, we introduce a unique mechanism in which alternative splicing of a coding exon is used to control mRNA localization during development.
Leishmania infantum, the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis, has traditionally been thought to reproduce clonally. However, recent studies have proposed the existence of a non-obligate sexual cycle in the extracellular stage of the parasite within the sand fly vector. In this study, we provide the first evidence of intraclonal genetic exchange in Leishmania infantum. We have developed transgenic L. infantum lines expressing drug resistance markers linked to green and red fluorescent reporters, which were successfully exchanged within the sand fly midgut of the natural vector Phlebotomus perniciosus when individuals from these species were fed with a mixture of parental clones. Using the yellow phenotype and drug resistance markers, we provide evidence for genetic exchange in L. infantum. The hybrid progeny appeared to be triploid based on DNA content analysis. The hybrid clone analyzed was stable throughout the complete parasite life cycle. The progress of infections by the hybrid clone in BALB/c mice caused a reduction in parasite loads in both spleen and liver, and provided weight values similar to those obtained with uninfected mice. Spleen arginase activity was also significantly reduced relative to parental strains.
Leishmania donovani is the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ), a major health problem in Ethiopia. Recently isolated strains from VL and HIV-VL co-infected patients in north and south Ethiopia were characterized as part of a longitudinal study on VL transmission. A total of 63 L. donovani strains were examined by polymerase chain reaction ( PCR ) targeting three regions: internal transcribed spacer 1 ( ITS1 ), cysteine protease B ( cpb ), and HASPB ( k26 ). Interestingly, the k26 - PCR amplicon size varied depending on the patient's geographic origin. Most strains from northwestern Ethiopia ( 36/40 ) produced a 290 bp product with a minority ( 4/40 ) giving a 410 bp amplicon. All of the latter strains were isolated from patients with HIV-VL co-infections, while the former group contained both VL and HIV-VL co-infected patients. Almost all the strains ( 20/23 ) from southwestern Ethiopia produced a 450 bp amplicon with smaller products ( 290 or 360 bp ) only observed for three strains. Sudanese strains produced amplicons identical ( 290 bp ) to those found in northwestern Ethiopia; while Kenyan strains gave larger PCR products ( 500 and 650 bp ). High-resolution melt ( HRM ) analysis distinguished the different PCR products. Sequence analysis showed that the k26 repeat region in L. donovani is comprised of polymorphic 13 and 14 amino acid motifs. The 13 amino acid peptide motifs, prevalent in L. donovani, are rare in L. infantum. The number and order of the repeats in L. donovani varies between geographic regions. HASPB repeat region ( k26 ) shows considerable polymorphism among L. donovani strains from different regions in East Africa.
Recombinant HIV-1 genomes contribute significantly to the diversity of the HIV/AIDS pandemic, and it is assumed that some of these mosaic genomes may have novel properties that have led to their prevalence. To test this hypothesis, we generate a probabilistic model of HIV-1 copy-choice recombination and compare the predicted breakpoint distribution to the distribution from the HIV/AIDS pandemic. We find that across much of the HIV-1 genome, the observed frequencies of inter-subtype recombination are predicted accurately by our model. This indicates that in these regions a probabilistic model, dependent on local sequence identity, is sufficient to explain breakpoint locations. However, in regions where there is a significant over- ( either side of the env gene ) or under- ( short regions within gag, pol, and most of env ) representation of breakpoints, we infer natural selection to be influencing the recombination pattern. The paucity of recombination breakpoints within most of the envelope gene indicates that recombinants generated in this region are less likely to be successful. Our findings provide the first clear indication of the existence of a specific portion of the genome that deviates from a probabilistic null model for recombination. This suggests that despite the wide diversity of recombinant forms seen in the viral population, only a minority of recombination events appear to be of significance to the evolution of HIV-1.
Bayesian hierarchical inference ( HBI ) is proposed as a novel framework for concurrent model comparison, parameter estimation, and inference at the population level. This framework addresses the interdependence between model comparison and parameter estimation, where the relevant population for estimating parameters of a model depends on which subjects express the model. The HBI framework combines previous approaches and has important advantages for both parameter estimation and model comparison. The parameters estimated by HBI show smaller errors compared to other methods, and model comparison by HBI is robust against outliers and not biased towards overly simplistic models. The fully Bayesian approach of our theory enables researchers to make inference on group-level parameters by performing HBI t-tests. The HBI framework is hierarchical in the sense that parameters at the individual level are regularized by statistics across all individuals in the group, and Bayesian in the sense that all uncertainties at both individual and group levels are represented by probability distributions. This work addresses issues of statistical inference over both parameters and models, which have remained elusive with previous hierarchical methods.
In the developing mouse brainstem, rhombomeres ( r ) contribute to the formation of auditory nuclei. Here, we show that r4 is involved in the assembly of functionally linked sensory and motor components of the auditory circuitry, including the ventral nucleus of the lateral lemniscus, posterior ventral cochlear nuclei ( VCN ), and motor olivocochlear neurons. The assembly of r4-derived auditory components depends on regulatory interactions between Hoxb1 and Hoxb2. In Hoxb1 and Hoxb2 mutant mice, the transmission of low-level auditory stimuli is lost, resulting in hearing impairments. On the other hand, Hoxa2 regulates the Rig1 axon guidance receptor and controls contralateral projections from the anterior VCN to the medial nucleus of the trapezoid body, a circuit involved in sound localization. Thus, individual rhombomeres and their associated Hox codes control the assembly of distinct functionally segregated sub-circuits in the developing auditory brainstem. Interestingly, VCN neurons are also involved in the MEM reflex loop through the action of the facial motor nucleus, originated in ventral r4 and strongly affected in Hoxb1 mutant mice.
The complete genome sequence of the marine bacterium Saccharophagus degradans strain 2-40 ( Sde 2-40 ) has been reported. This bacterium is a member of a recently discovered group of marine and estuarine bacteria that can recycle complex polysaccharides. The genome sequence of Sde 2-40 reveals an unusually large number of enzymes that can degrade more than 10 different complex polysaccharides. Many of these enzymes exhibit novel combinations of catalytic and substrate-binding modules. We hypothesize that these features are adaptations that facilitate the depolymerization of complex polysaccharides in the marine environment. Sde 2-40 is the first sequenced genome of a marine bacterium that can degrade plant cell walls, an important component of the carbon cycle that is not well-characterized in the marine environment.
Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) is a zoonotic flavivirus that causes the most significant etiology of childhood viral neurological infections in Asia. In the last 20 years, JEV genotype dominance has shifted from genotype III ( GIII ) to genotype I ( GI ), but the exact mechanism of this displacement is still unknown. Culex pipiens mosquitoes are the most common species in China and play an essential role in maintaining the JEV enzootic transmission cycle. In this study, we used Cx. pipiens mosquitoes from China as an in vivo mosquito model to explore if mosquitoes played a potential role in JEV genotype shift. We found that Cx. pipiens mosquitoes were competent vectors for both GI and GIII JEV infection, with similar infection rates, growth kinetics, dissemination rates, and transmission rates. Our data demonstrated that GI and GIII viruses have similar infectivity in Cx. pipiens mosquitoes, suggesting that Cx. pipiens mosquitoes from China may not play a critical role in JEV genotype shift. Although the current data were obtained solely from Cx. pipiens mosquitoes, it is likely that the conclusion drawn could be extrapolated to the role of mosquitoes in JEV genotype shift.
Dengue infection is the fastest spreading mosquito-borne viral disease in tropical and subtropical countries. In Malaysia, large dengue outbreaks have occurred in recent years. We conducted a retrospective review of all dengue deaths that occurred nationwide between 2013 and 2014 to study the demographics and clinical characteristics associated with dengue deaths. A total of 322 dengue deaths were reviewed, with a mean age of 40. 7±19. 30 years, and 72. 5% were adults. Diabetes and hypertension were common co-morbidities among adults and elderly. The most common warning signs reported were lethargy and vomiting, but 22. 4% did not have any warning signs. Only 34% were suspected of dengue illness at their initial presentation. Dengue shock syndrome ( DSS ) contributed to more than 70% of dengue deaths, followed by severe organ involvement ( 69% ) and severe bleeding ( 29. 7% ). DSS was the leading cause of death, regardless of age groups. Dengue deaths occurred primarily in adult patients, and the atypical presentation and dynamic progression of severe dengue in this cohort prompts early recognition and aggressive intervention to prevent deaths.
Insulin signaling, a nutrient-sensing pathway, affects female sexual attractiveness in Drosophila melanogaster. We show that insulin signaling in the fat body and ovarian follicle cells, but not in germline cells or early follicle cells, is required for global insulin signaling effects on attractiveness. Manipulations of insulin signaling in the fat body produced opposite effects on attractiveness compared to those caused by global and late follicle cell manipulations, suggesting a competitive relationship between the fat body and the ovary. Insulin signaling in late follicle cells recapitulated effects of global manipulations, and functional ovaries were required for global insulin signaling effects on attractiveness. The cues themselves, cuticular hydrocarbons, responded distinctly to fat body and follicle cell manipulations, indicating independent readouts of the pathway activity from these two tissues. Furthermore, all investigated tissue-specific insulin signaling manipulations that changed attractiveness also changed fecundity in the corresponding direction, pointing to insulin pathway activity as a reliable link between fecundity and attractiveness cues.
During the 2013–2015 Ebola virus disease ( EVD ) epidemic in West Africa, the disease spread heterogeneously across the hardest-hit countries of Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone. To investigate district-level transmissibility of EVD, we applied a statistical modelling approach to estimate the basic reproduction number ( R0 ) for each affected district and each country. We used weekly incident case numbers to estimate growth rates during the early exponential phase of the outbreak and fitted a mixed effects model to take into account heterogeneity between and within countries. At district level, R0 ranged from 0. 36 ( Dubréka ) to 1. 72 ( Beyla ) in Guinea, from 0. 53 ( Maryland ) to 3. 37 ( Margibi ) in Liberia, and from 1. 14 ( Koinadugu ) to 2. 73 ( Western Rural ) in Sierra Leone. At national level, we estimated an R0 of 0. 97 ( 95% CI 0. 77–1. 18 ) for Guinea, 1. 26 ( 95% CI 0. 98–1. 55 ) for Liberia, and 1. 66 ( 95% CI 1. 32–2. 00 ) for Sierra Leone. We found that socio-demographic variables related to urbanisation, such as high population density and high wealth index, were positively associated with R0, suggesting that the consequences of fast urban growth in West Africa may have contributed to the increased spread of EVD.
Evolutionary rates of proteins are determined by a combination of intrinsic and historical factors. Here, we investigate the interplay between a protein's age and its structural properties as determinants of evolutionary rate. We use a large set of one-to-one orthologs between human and mouse proteins, with mapped PDB structures. We find that previously reported relationships between structural properties and evolutionary rate also hold within each age group. For example, residues with high solvent accessibility evolve more quickly, while proteins with a larger fraction of exposed residues evolve more slowly. However, we also find that the age of a protein modulates the correlation between structural properties and evolutionary rates. Younger proteins, despite being less designable, tend to evolve faster than older proteins. We show that previously reported relationships between age and rate cannot be explained by structural biases among age groups. Furthermore, we find that older proteins are more stable for their native structure and more robust to mutations than younger ones.
Polycomb-like 3 ( Pcl3 ) is a component of the Polycomb repressive complex 2 ( PRC2 ) that promotes embryonic stem cell ( ESC ) self-renewal. Pcl3 interacts with Suz12, a core component of PRC2, and promotes the binding of PRC2 to a subset of its genomic targets, particularly CpG islands. We show that Pcl3 knockdown in ESCs increases spontaneous differentiation and reduces H3K27me3 levels, while overexpression of Pcl3 increases H3K27me3 levels. Chromatin immunoprecipitation and sequencing ( ChIP-seq ) reveal that Pcl3 co-localizes with Suz12 and depletion of Pcl3 decreases Suz12 binding at over 60% of PRC2 targets. The Tudor domain of Pcl3 is essential for its function, as mutation of conserved residues within this domain compromises H3K27me3 formation. We also show that Pcl3 and its paralog, Pcl2, exist in different PRC2 complexes but bind many of the same PRC2 targets, particularly CpG islands regulated by Pcl3. Thus, Pcl3 is a critical component of PRC2 that regulates ESC self-renewal, histone methylation, and recruitment of PRC2 to a subset of its genomic sites.
Chemoreceptor gene expression in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans is regulated by both cell-autonomous and non-cell-autonomous transcriptional mechanisms involving the transcription factors MEF-2 and basic helix-loop-helix ( bHLH ). We show that MEF-2 acts together with bHLH transcription factors to regulate the expression of the chemoreceptor gene srh-234 in the ADL sensory neuron of C. elegans as a function of feeding state. A cis-regulatory MEF2 binding site is necessary and sufficient for the starvation-induced down regulation of srh-234 expression, while an E-box site is required to drive srh-234 expression in ADL neurons. The bHLH transcription factors HLH-2, HLH-3, and HLH-4 act in ADL neurons to regulate srh-234 expression. Furthermore, we show that the expression levels of srh-234 in ADL neurons are regulated remotely by the transcription factors MXL-3 and HLH-30 acting in the intestine, which is dependent on insulin signaling functioning specifically in ADL neurons. This non-cell-autonomous regulation involves a subset of insulin-like peptides.
Mycobacterium ulcerans is the causative agent of Buruli ulcer ( BU ), a destructive skin condition. The mode of transmission of M. ulcerans is not well understood, but several studies have suggested that biting insects may play a role. In this study, we investigated the association between the detection of M. ulcerans in mosquitoes and the risk of BU disease in humans in an endemic area of southeastern Australia. Mosquitoes were trapped in seven towns on the Bellarine Peninsula in Victoria, Australia, from 2004 to 2009 and screened for M. ulcerans by real-time PCR. We found a strong dose-response relationship between the detection of M. ulcerans in mosquitoes and the risk of human disease ( r, 0. 99; 95% CI, 0. 92–0. 99; p<0. 001 ). The proportion of M. ulcerans-positive mosquitoes in each town was positively correlated with the average cumulative incidence of BU in the same location. The association was strongest in Point Lonsdale and Barwon Heads, which had the highest incidences of BU and the highest proportions of M. ulcerans-positive mosquitoes. These findings strengthen the hypothesis that mosquitoes are involved in the transmission of M. ulcerans in southeastern Australia and have implications for the development of intervention strategies to control and prevent BU.
Demyelination in the central nervous system ( CNS ) of dmy/dmy rats results from a loss-of-function mutation in the Mrs2 gene, which encodes an essential component of the major Mg2+ influx system in mitochondria. By positional cloning, we identified a novel splice acceptor site generated by a G-to-A transition 177 bp downstream of exon 3 of the Mrs2 gene, resulting in functional inactivation of the mutant allele. Transgenic rescue with wild-type Mrs2-cDNA validated our findings. We showed that dmy/dmy rats have major mitochondrial deficits, including elevated lactic acid concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid, a 60% reduction in ATP, and increased numbers of mitochondria in the swollen cytoplasm of oligodendrocytes. MRS2-GFP recombinant BAC transgenic rats showed that MRS2 was dominantly expressed in neurons rather than oligodendrocytes and was ultrastructurally observed in the inner membrane of mitochondria. Our observations led to the conclusion that dmy/dmy rats suffer from a mitochondrial disease and that the maintenance of myelin has a different mechanism from its initial production. We also established that Mg2+ homeostasis in CNS mitochondria is essential for the maintenance of myelin.
Microarray gene expression signatures have the potential to improve diagnosis and prognosis of disease. However, current documentation standards of such signatures do not allow for an unambiguous application to study-external patients. This hinders independent evaluation and delays the use of signatures in clinical practice. We analyzed data from eight publicly available clinical microarray studies and evaluated the consistency of study-internal with study-external diagnoses. Study-external classifications were based on documented information only. We found that discrepancies between study-internal and study-external diagnoses can be as frequent as 30% ( worst case ) and 18% ( median ). By using the proposed documentation by value strategy, which documents quantitative preprocessing information, the median discrepancy was reduced to 1%. We propose guidelines and methodology for building and documenting signatures unambiguously to improve the process of evaluating microarray gene expression diagnostic signatures and bringing them to clinical practice.
Curli amyloid fibrils, secreted by Enterobacteriaceae, play a key role in host cell adhesion and biofilm formation, thereby promoting bacterial resistance to environmental stressors. Here, we present crystal structures of amyloid-forming segments from the major curli subunit, CsgA, revealing steric zipper fibrils of tightly mated β-sheets. These structures demonstrate a structural link between curli and human pathological amyloids, such as Alzheimer’s disease-associated amyloid-β. We show that D-enantiomeric peptides, originally developed to interfere with Alzheimer’s disease-associated amyloid-β, inhibit CsgA fibrillation and reduce biofilm formation in Salmonella typhimurium. Furthermore, we demonstrate that CsgA fibrils cross-seed fibrillation of amyloid-β, providing support for the proposed structural resemblance and potential for cross-species amyloid interactions.
Japanese encephalitis virus ( JEV ) is an important cause of encephalitis in most of Asia, with high case fatality rates and significant neurologic sequelae among survivors. The epidemiology of JE in the Philippines is not well defined. We conducted a systematic literature review and summarized JE surveillance data from 2011 to 2014 to support consideration of JE vaccine for introduction into the national schedule in the Philippines. We identified 29 published reports and presentations on JE in the Philippines, including 5 serologic surveys, 18 reports of clinical cases, and 8 animal studies. The 18 clinical studies reported 257 cases of laboratory-confirmed JE from 1972 to 2013. JE virus ( JEV ) was the causative agent in 7% to 18% of cases of clinical meningitis and encephalitis combined, and 16% to 40% of clinical encephalitis cases. JE predominantly affected children under 15 years of age and 6% to 7% of cases resulted in death. Surveillance data from January 2011 to March 2014 identified 73 ( 15% ) laboratory-confirmed JE cases out of 497 cases tested. This review demonstrates the endemicity and extensive geographic range of JE in the Philippines, and supports the use of JE vaccine in the country. Continued and improved surveillance with laboratory confirmation is needed to systematically quantify the burden of JE, to provide information that can guide prioritization of high risk areas in the country and determination of appropriate age and schedule of vaccine introduction, and to measure the impact of preventive measures including immunization against this important public health threat.
Genetic robustness, the ability of a species to endure genetic perturbations, is still under debate as to whether it arises from environmental requirements, intrinsic factors, or adaptive selection. Here, we study the evolutionary origins of genetic robustness in hundreds of bacterial species across many simulated growth environments. We decouple genetic robustness into two components: environmental-dependent and environmental-independent robustness. Environmental-dependent robustness is responsible for at least 20% of non-essential reactions and is associated with a species' lifestyle ( specialized or generalist ). In contrast, environmental-independent robustness is associated with a species' intrinsic metabolic capacities, with higher robustness observed in fast growers or organisms with extensive secondary metabolite production. We also identify reactions uniquely susceptible to perturbations in human pathogens, potentially serving as novel drug targets.
Schistosoma mansoni infection is associated with immune modulation that can influence responses to non-schistosome antigens. We investigated the effect of S. mansoni infection on antibody responses to measles catch-up immunisation and the effect of praziquantel treatment on this outcome in a randomised trial. The Immune Modulation and Childhood Immunisation ( IMoChI ) study was based in Entebbe, Uganda. Children aged 3–5 years ( 193 S. mansoni-infected and 61 uninfected ) were enrolled. Infected children were randomised in a 1:1:1 ratio to receive praziquantel 2 weeks before, at time of, or 1 week after, measles catch-up immunisation. Plasma anti-measles IgG was measured at enrolment, 1 week and 24 weeks after measles immunisation. We found that S. mansoni-infected children had lower levels of anti-measles IgG at 1 week post-immunisation compared to uninfected children ( adjusted geometric mean ratio ( aGMR ) 0. 4 [95% CI 0. 2–0. 7] ). Among S. mansoni-infected children, anti-measles IgG one week post-immunisation was higher among those treated with praziquantel than among those who were not yet treated ( treatment before immunisation, aGMR 2. 3 [1. 5–4. 8]; treatment at immunisation aGMR 1. 8 [1. 1–3. 5] ). At 24 weeks post-immunisation, IgG levels did not differ between the trial groups, but tended to be lower among previously-infected children who were still S mansoni stool-positive than among those who became stool-negative. Our findings suggest that S. mansoni infection among pre-school children is associated with a reduced antibody response to catch-up measles immunisation, and that praziquantel treatment improves the response.
The evolution of bacterial populations has become better understood with the advent of large-scale sequencing of population samples. However, traditional statistical methods for evolutionary inference, such as phylogenetic analysis, are associated with several difficulties under an extensive sampling scenario, in particular when a considerable amount of recombination is anticipated to have taken place. To meet the needs of large-scale analyses of population structure for bacteria, we introduce here several statistical tools for the detection and representation of recombination between populations. We also introduce a model-based description of the shape of a population in sequence space, in terms of its molecular variability and affinity towards other populations. We demonstrate the potential of an approach where these population genetic tools are combined with phylogenetic analysis using extensive real data from the genus Neisseria. The statistical tools introduced here are freely available in BAPS 5. 2 software, which can be downloaded from http://web. abo. fi/fak/mnf/mate/jc/software/baps. html. We illustrate the levels of complexity at which our methods can operate using a population sample of 5086 strains that have been identified as Neisseria meningiditis and Neisseria lactamica species.
Top-down beta rhythms have been shown to play a crucial role in supporting selective attention via interlaminar interaction. These rhythms are generated in higher cognitive areas and delivered to earlier sensory areas to modulate attentional gain. To elucidate the functional roles of beta rhythms and their underlying mechanisms, we built a computational model of sensory cortical areas. Our simulation results show that top-down beta rhythms can activate ascending synaptic projections from layer 5 ( L5 ) to layer 4 ( L4 ) and layer 2/3 ( L2/3 ), responsible for biased competition in superficial layers. Slow-inhibitory interneurons in L5 are shown to resonate to the 20 Hz input and modulate the activity in superficial layers in an attention-related manner. This provides a potential mechanism by which cholinergic drive can support selective attention. Our results suggest that top-down beta rhythms can enhance gamma rhythms in L2/3, reduce beta rhythms in L2/3, and enhance spiking activity of L2/3 regular spiking ( RS ) cells. This is consistent with the pattern of neural response modulation induced by attention reported in previous studies.
Stochastic transmission dynamic models are useful for studying the early emergence of novel pathogens. However, methods for parameter estimation and prediction for these types of stochastic models remain limited. We describe a calibration and prediction framework for stochastic compartmental transmission models of epidemics. The proposed method, Multiple Shooting for Stochastic systems ( MSS ), applies a linear noise approximation to describe the size of the fluctuations, and uses each new surveillance observation to update the belief about the true epidemic state. We evaluate the accuracy of MSS for real-time parameter estimation and prediction during epidemics using simulated outbreaks of a novel viral pathogen. We assume that weekly counts for the number of new diagnosed cases are available and serve as an imperfect proxy of incidence. MSS produces accurate estimates of key epidemic parameters ( i. e. mean duration of infectiousness, R0, and Reff ) and can provide an accurate estimate of the unobserved number of infectious individuals during the course of an epidemic. MSS also allows for accurate prediction of the number and timing of future hospitalizations and the overall attack rate. We compare the performance of MSS to three state-of-the-art benchmark methods and find that MSS significantly outperforms each of these methods in the majority of epidemic scenarios tested.
Visual perception is shaped by two contrasting forces: a repulsive force exerted by sensory adaptation and an attractive force exerted by past decisions. In a series of experiments, we used multilevel modeling and cross-validation approaches to investigate the impact of previous stimuli and decisions on behavioral reports during adjustment and forced-choice tasks. Our results revealed that each perceptual report is permeated by opposite biases from a hierarchy of serially dependent processes: low-level adaptation repels perception away from previous stimuli, whereas decisional traces attract perceptual reports toward the recent past. This finding is consistent with a Two-process model of serial dependence in which the persistence of readout weights in a decision unit compensates for sensory adaptation, leading to attractive biases in sequential perception. We propose a unified account of serial dependence in which functionally distinct mechanisms, operating at different stages, promote the differentiation and integration of visual information over time.
In Drosophila, the Clock–Cycle ( CLK–CYC ) heterodimer is a key component of the circadian transcription complex. We have analyzed the effects of a CYC–viral protein 16 ( VP16 ) fusion protein in the Drosophila system to address the role of transcription in core circadian timekeeping. The addition of VP16 to CYC imparts strongly enhanced transcriptional activity to the CLK–CYC-VP16 complex relative to the normal CLK–CYC heterodimer. This increase in transcriptional activity is manifested in flies expressing CYC-VP16 as well as in S2 cells. These flies have increased levels of CLK–CYC direct target gene mRNAs, including those from per and tim, and a short period, implicating circadian transcription in period determination. Importantly, the behavioral effects require a period ( per ) promoter and are therefore unlikely to be merely a consequence of generally higher PER levels. This indicates that the CLK–CYC-VP16 behavioral effects are a consequence of increased per transcription. Our results suggest that the timing of transcriptional activation and not the activation itself is the key event responsible for the behavioral effects observed in CYC-VP16-expressing flies. The results taken together indicate that circadian transcription contributes to core circadian function in Drosophila.
The PmrA/PmrB two-component system in Salmonella enterica and the closely related bacterium Escherichia coli plays a key role in conferring polymyxin B resistance. The pmrD gene, which is horizontally acquired, activates the PmrA/PmrB system in Salmonella but not in E. coli. We show that the Salmonella PmrD protein binds to the phosphorylated PmrA protein ( PmrA-P ) and protects it from dephosphorylation by the PmrB protein, resulting in the transcription of PmrA-dependent genes. In contrast, the E. coli PmrD protein cannot activate the PmrA/PmrB system in E. coli. However, we found that the E. coli PmrD protein can activate the PmrA/PmrB system in Salmonella, suggesting that E. coli and Salmonella differ in an additional component controlling PmrA-P levels. We established that the E. coli PmrB protein displays higher phosphatase activity towards PmrA-P than the Salmonella PmrB protein. We identified a PmrB subdomain responsible for this property and showed that replacement of the E. coli pmrB gene with the Salmonella homolog was sufficient to render E. coli resistant to polymyxin B under PmrD-inducing conditions.
The differentiation of embryonic stem cells is initiated by a gradual loss of pluripotency-associated transcripts and induction of differentiation genes. To identify the causal genes that either promote or inhibit differentiation, we need to detect differentially expressed genes at the early stages of differentiation. However, previous methods of identifying differentially expressed genes by comparing different cell types inevitably include a large portion of genes that respond to, rather than regulate, the differentiation process. Here, we demonstrate that the gene expression data obtained without prior separation of cell types are informative for detecting differentially expressed genes at the early stages of differentiation. We propose a novel statistical approach, called the Differentiation-Test, to analyze the differentiation process. This method assumes that the differentiation process starts from a relatively homogeneous initial cell mixture and progresses into a more heterogeneous cell mixture with identifiable events of divergence of expression levels of certain genes during the process. We apply the Differentiation-Test to study the differentiation of mouse embryonic stem cells into embryoid bodies and identify Smarcad1 as a novel regulator of pluripotency and self-renewal.
Next-generation sequencing studies often rely on groupwise functional analysis of gene variants. However, the function of many genes is unknown, and their classification to pathways is limited. As a result, functional associations between genes are often inferred from large-scale omics data, such as protein–protein interactions and gene co-expression networks. Statistical significance is assessed by comparing the interconnectedness of mutated genes with that of random gene sets. However, interconnectedness can be affected by confounding bias, potentially resulting in false positive findings. We show that genes implicated through de novo sequence variants are biased in their coding-sequence length and tend to cluster together, leading to exaggerated p-values in functional studies. To address this bias, we present an integrative method that controls for the confounding bias in coding-sequence length. We have inferred functional associations between human genes from diverse data types and assessed them with a novel phenotype-based method. Examining the functional association between de novo gene variants, we find that genes mutated in the same disease cluster more significantly in an integrated phenotypic-linkage network than in other gene networks. We present a tool that identifies functional associations among genes mutated in the same disease even after accounting for significant sequencing study bias.
The Mexican government implemented an 8% tax on nonessential foods with energy density ≥275 kcal/100 g and a peso-per-liter tax on sugar-sweetened beverages ( SSBs ) in January 2014 to combat obesity and diabetes. This study evaluates the impact of these taxes on the volume of taxed and untaxed packaged food purchases in the Mexican urban population. Using data from The Nielsen Company’s Mexico Consumer Panel Services ( CPS ), we included 6, 248 households that participated in the Nielsen CPS in at least 2 mo during 2012–2014. We analyzed the volume of purchases of taxed and untaxed foods from January 2012 to December 2014, using a longitudinal, fixed-effects model that adjusted for preexisting trends. We found that the mean volume of purchases of taxed foods in 2014 changed by -25 g ( 95% confidence interval = -46, -11 ) per capita per month, or a 5. 1% change beyond what would have been expected based on pre-tax ( 2012–2013 ) trends, with no corresponding change in purchases of untaxed foods. Low SES households purchased on average 10. 2% less taxed foods than expected ( -44 [–72, –16] g per capita per month ) ; medium SES households purchased 5. 8% less taxed foods than expected ( -28 [–46, –11] g per capita per month ), whereas high SES households’ purchases did not change.
The response properties of collision-sensitive neurons, such as the Lobula Giant Movement Detector Neuron ( LGMD ) of the locust, can be explained by a biophysically plausible model. The LGMD responds best to objects approaching one of the locust’s compound eyes on a direct collision course. We present a new model ( “n-ψ” ) for the LGMD and other collision-sensitive neurons with η-like response properties. The n-ψ model is based on its predecessor model Ψ, which used an exact power law for re-scaling the inhibitory input. The n-ψ model assumes that each information channel is noisy and has a response threshold. As a result, an approximative power law is obtained as a result of pooling these channels. We show that the n-ψ model can successfully predict many response characteristics of the LGMD. The results depend critically on noise in the inhibitory pathway, but are fairly robust against noise in the excitatory pathway. The integration process, or pooling, could be carried out by the dendritic tree of the LGMD neuron. The only preconditions for each channel are the presence of noise ( uncorrelated across channels ), and a response threshold.
Buruli ulcer ( BU ) is a neglected tropical disease endemic in Cameroon. The national BU control programme ( NBUCP ) was established in 2002, 33 years after the first cases were reported in 1969. We describe the evolution, achievements, and challenges of the NBUCP from 2001 to 2014. The programme aims to detect cases early, confirm 70% of clinical cases by PCR, treat all active cases according to standard guidelines, and heal at least 95% of patients without limitation of joint movement. Over 14 years, 3700 cases were notified, and the BU detection rate dropped significantly from 3. 89 to 1. 45 per 100 000 inhabitants. The number of BU endemic health districts rose from two to 64, and five BU diagnostic and treatment centres are functional, with two more planned for 2015. The health system has been strengthened, and BU research and education have gained more interest in Cameroon. However, the reduction in programme resources and activities by major support partners has led to a steady drop in performance indicators since 2010.
In two experiments, we investigated the effect of outcome valence ( gains or losses ) on confidence while participants learned stimulus-outcome associations by trial-and-error in a reinforcement-learning task. We found that participants were more confident in their choices when learning to seek gains compared to avoiding losses, despite equal difficulty and performance between the two contexts. Computational modelling revealed that this bias is driven by the context-value, a dynamically updated estimate of the average expected-value of choice options, necessary to explain equal performance in the gain and loss domain. This biasing effect of context-value on confidence is domain-general and likely has important functional consequences. We show that one such consequence emerges in volatile environments, where the flexibility of individuals’ learning strategies differs when outcomes are framed as gains or losses.
Alphaviruses are a family of positive-strand RNA viruses that cause diseases such as Chikungunya, Sindbis, and Semliki Forest virus ( SFV ) in humans and animals. Among the four non-structural proteins of alphaviruses, the function of nsP3 is the least well understood. We found that the carboxyterminal region of nsP3 contains a conserved proline-rich sequence motif that serves as a preferred target site for the Src-homology 3 ( SH3 ) domains of amphiphysin-1 and -2. Amphiphysins are host cell proteins that are involved in endocytosis and membrane trafficking. We found that nsP3 proteins of SFV, SINV, and Chikungunya viruses all showed avid and SH3-dependent binding to amphiphysins. Upon alphavirus infection, the intracellular distribution of amphiphysin was dramatically altered and colocalized with nsP3. We found that mutations in nsP3 disrupting the amphiphysin SH3 binding motif as well as RNAi-mediated silencing of amphiphysin-2 expression resulted in impaired viral RNA replication in HeLa cells infected with SINV or SFV. Infection of Balb/c mice with SFV carrying an SH3 binding-defective nsP3 was associated with significantly decreased mortality. These data establish SH3 domain-mediated binding of nsP3 with amphiphysin as an important host cell interaction promoting alphavirus replication.
Chromoblastomycosis is a mutilating disease caused by melanized members of the order Chaetothyriales. We analyzed 123 clinical strains from cases of chromoblastomycosis from different endemic areas in Brazil to assess population diversity among agents of the disease. We applied sequencing of the rDNA internal transcribed spacer region and partial cell division cycle and β-tubulin genes. The strains were limited to three clusters within the single family Herpotrichiellaceae, which comprises agents of chromoblastomycosis. The Fonsecaea cluster contained the most important agents, with Fonsecaea pedrosoi being the most prevalent ( 80% of the total set of strains ), followed by Fonsecaea monophora ( 13% ), Fonsecaea nubica ( 3% ), and a single isolate of Fonsecaea pugnacius. In addition, we identified two novel species among members of the genera Rhinocladiella and Cyphellophora, with frequencies of 3% and 1%, respectively. The Brazilian clinical isolates were all derived from humid climate zones, and members of the Cladophialophora carrionii group were not encountered.
Listeria monocytogenes dampens the host DNA damage response ( DDR ) by inducing DNA breaks in host cells while controlling the activation of the DDR. We show that infection with L. monocytogenes induces DNA breaks and activates the DDR in host cells in vitro and in vivo. Strikingly, L. monocytogenes is able to dampen activation of the DNA-damage signaling pathway through the bacterial factor listeriolysin O ( LLO ). LLO induces the degradation of the host protein Mre11, one of the major sensors of DNA damage, through a mechanism independent of proteasome degradation. This dampening of the DDR is important for infection as inhibition of proteins implicated in this pathway increases bacterial infection. We show that deletion or inhibition of proteins involved in the DDR leads to higher levels of infection, demonstrating for the first time that the DDR can be a negative regulator of a bacterial infection.
Human herpes simplex viruses 1 and 2 ( HSV-1 and HSV-2 ) are common pathogens that cause human diseases. Both host and viral factors are involved in HSV lytic infection, but the detailed mechanisms remain elusive. We identified bromodomain-containing protein 4 ( BRD4 ) as a critical player in HSV infection by screening a chemical library of epigenetic regulation. We found that treatment with a pan BD domain inhibitor enhanced both HSV-1 and HSV-2 infection. Using JQ1 as a probe, we found that JQ1, a defined BD1 inhibitor, acts through BRD4 protein since knockdown of BRD4 expression ablated JQ1 effect on HSV infection. BRD4 regulates HSV replication through complex formation involving CDK9 and RNAP II; whereas, JQ1 promotes HSV-1 infection by allocating the complex to HSV gene promoters. Our data support a model that JQ1 enhances HSV infection by switching BRD4 to transcription regulation of viral gene expression from chromatin targeting. In addition to the identification that BRD4 is a modulator for JQ1 action on HSV infection, this study demonstrates BRD4 has an essential role in HSV infection.
Noma, also known as cancrum oris, is an ancient and devastating illness that causes severe facial disfigurement in over 140, 000 malnourished children every year. The exact cause of noma is still unknown, but it is thought to result from a combination of microbial infection, poor oral hygiene, and a weakened immune system. To better understand the microbial ecology of noma, we performed a cross-sectional sequencing study of 16S rRNA gene amplicons from sixty samples of gingival fluid from twelve healthy children, twelve children suffering from noma, twelve children suffering from Acute Necrotizing Gingivitis ( ANG ), and twelve healthy controls. We found that noma lesions were enriched with Spirochaetes and depleted for Proteobacteria compared to healthy individuals. In contrast, samples from healthy sites of diseased mouths had similar proportions of Spirochaetes and Proteobacteria to healthy controls. We also found that the microbial communities in noma and ANG lesions were dominated by the same Prevotella intermedia OTU, which was much less abundant in healthy sites sampled from the same mouths. Multivariate analysis confirmed that bacterial communities in healthy and lesion sites were significantly different. Several OTUs in the Orders Erysipelotrichales, Clostridiales, Bacteroidales, and Spirochaetales were identified as indicators of noma, suggesting that one or more microbes within these Orders is associated with the development of noma lesions.
Bacillus thuringiensis, a Gram-positive bacterium, uses quorum sensing to coordinate its adaptation properties, cell fate, and commitment to sporulation. The NprR-NprX regulation system is a typical Gram-positive quorum-sensing system in which NprX is the signaling peptide. In the presence of NprX, NprR acts as a transcriptional activator, regulating a set of genes involved in the necrotrophic lifestyle of B. thuringiensis, allowing the bacterium to survive in the insect cadaver. However, in the absence of NprX and independently of its transcriptional activator function, NprR negatively controls sporulation. NprR inhibits the expression of Spo0A-regulated genes by preventing the KinA-dependent phosphorylation of the phosphotransferase Spo0F, thus delaying the initiation of the sporulation process. This function of NprR displays similarities with the Rap proteins, which also belong to the RNPP family, but are devoid of a DNA-binding domain and indirectly control gene expression via protein-protein interactions. The crystal structure of apo NprR confirms that NprR displays a highly flexible Rap-like structure. We propose a molecular regulatory mechanism in which key residues of the bifunctional regulator NprR are directly and alternatively involved in its two functions. NprX binding switches NprR from a dimeric inhibitor of sporulation to a tetrameric transcriptional activator involved in the necrotrophic lifestyle of B. thuringiensis. NprR thus tightly coordinates sporulation and necrotrophism, ensuring survival and dissemination of the bacteria during host infection.
Proteochemometric ( PCM ) models have been developed to predict the efficacy of antiretroviral ( ARV ) drugs against HIV by combining chemical and protein target properties in a single bioactivity model. These models are based on a large-scale clinical database of genotypic and phenotypic information, containing over 300, 000 drug-mutant bioactivity data points. Our models achieved a prediction error below 0. 5 Log Fold Change and outperformed previously published sequence-based models in resistance classification and prediction of Log Fold Change ( 0. 76 log units versus 0. 91 ). We were able to identify known and novel resistance-conferring mutations of HIV Reverse Transcriptase ( e. g. K102Y, T216M ) and HIV Protease ( e. g. Q18N, N88G ) from our dataset. We applied our models prospectively to the public HIV resistance database from Stanford University and obtained a correct resistance prediction rate of 84% on the full set, compared to 80% in previous work on a high quality subset. We conclude that PCM models are able to accurately predict phenotypic resistance based on genotypic data even for novel mutants and mixtures. Furthermore, we add an applicability domain to the prediction, informing the user about the reliability of predictions.
Chemotaxis in eukaryotic cells has been extensively studied, yet the underlying mechanism remains unclear. We recently proposed an alternative mechanism of chemotaxis in which pseudopods are formed by a self-generated cycle rather than by actin polymerization caused by chemoattractants. To test the explanatory and predictive powers of this mechanism, we developed a computational model of cell movement and chemotaxis based on pseudopod autocatalysis. The model reproduces a wide range of existing data about cell movement and chemotaxis, including cell polarization and persistence without stimuli, selection of accurate pseudopods when chemoattractant gradients are present, and bias of pseudopod position in low chemoattractant gradients. The model also predicts lateral pseudopod initiation in high gradients, a phenomenon not previously observed. We tested the predictive ability of the model by measuring the angles between successive pseudopods in chemotaxing Dictyostelium cells under different conditions and found that the results agreed with the model extremely well. Our model and data together suggest that in rapidly moving cells like Dictyostelium and neutrophils, an intrinsic pseudopod cycle lies at the heart of cell motility.
