This implies that the mechanism behind chemotaxis relies on modification of intrinsic pseudopod behaviour rather than generation of new pseudopods or actin polymerization by chemoattractants.
Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of plague, can be transmitted by fleas through two mechanisms: early-phase transmission ( EPT ) and biofilm-dependent transmission ( BDT ). However, the efficiency of transmission varies among flea species and is influenced by the species of rodent blood used for the infectious blood meal. In this study, fleas were fed bacteremic blood from mice, rats, guinea pigs, or gerbils, and the location and characteristics of the infection in the digestive tract and transmissibility of Y. pestis were assessed 1 to 3 days after infection. We observed that fleas fed bacteremic rat or guinea pig blood frequently regurgitated a portion of the infected blood meal into the esophagus within 24 h of feeding, a phenomenon we term post-infection esophageal reflux ( PIER ). In contrast, PIER was rarely observed in fleas fed bacteremic mouse or gerbil blood. PIER correlated with the accumulation of a dense mixed aggregate of Y. pestis, red blood cell stroma, and oxyhemoglobin crystals that filled the proventriculus. At their next feeding, fleas with PIER were 3–25 times more likely to appear partially blocked, with fresh blood retained within the esophagus, than were fleas without PIER. Our data support a model in which EPT results from regurgitation of Y. pestis from a partially obstructed flea foregut and that EPT and BDT can sometimes temporally overlap.
Positive correlations between the activity of neurons in the brain have been shown to be detrimental to the fidelity of population codes, or at best marginally favorable compared to independent codes. However, we show that positive correlations can enhance coding performance by many orders of magnitude. Specifically, the probability of discrimination error can be suppressed by many orders of magnitude, and the number of stimuli encoded—the capacity—can be enhanced more than tenfold. These effects can occur for populations with a few tens of neurons and do not necessitate unrealistic correlation values. We further show that both effects benefit from heterogeneity commonly seen in population activity. We demonstrate that a class of patterns of positive correlation can suppress coding errors in a two-alternative discrimination task, and that the advantageous role of heterogeneity seems to be a rather general feature of population coding. We refer to the phenomenon in which neural correlation suppresses the discrimination errors to negligible values and dramatically boosts the capacity of a population as high-fidelity coding. We exploit the idea that correlation can enhance coding performance by relegating the variability of neural response into non-informative modes of the population activity.
Cholera is a severe diarrheal disease caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae, and protection against cholera is serogroup specific. Here, we report the development of a conjugate vaccine for cholera that targets the O-specific polysaccharide ( OSP ) of V. cholerae O1 Inaba. The vaccine is composed of the OSP of V. cholerae O1 Inaba strain PIC018 and a recombinant heavy chain fragment of tetanus toxin ( OSP:rTTHc ). We assessed a range of vaccine doses ( 10-50 μg ), vaccine compositions varying by molar loading ratio of OSP to rTTHc ( 3:1, 5:1, 10:1 ), effect of an adjuvant, and route of immunization. Immunized mice developed prominent anti-OSP and anti-TT serum IgG responses, as well as vibriocidal antibody and memory B cell responses following intramuscular or intradermal vaccination. Intestinal lamina proprial IgA responses targeting OSP occurred following intradermal vaccination. We found comparable immune responses in mice immunized with these variations, although memory B cell and vibriocidal responses were blunted in mice receiving the highest dose of vaccine ( 50 μg ). We found no appreciable change in immune responses when the conjugate vaccine was administered in the presence or absence of immunoadjuvant alum. Administration of OSP:rTTHc resulted in 55% protective efficacy in a mouse survival cholera challenge model. We report development of an Inaba OSP:rTTHc conjugate vaccine that induces memory responses and protection against cholera in mice.
Lymphatic filariasis ( LF ) is a disease caused by the parasite Wuchereria bancrofti. The ICT card test is a tool used to map the distribution of LF in endemic areas. However, in areas with high levels of Loa loa ( L. loa ) microfilaria ( Mf ), the ICT test may produce false positive results due to cross-reactivity with L. loa. In this study, we investigated the cross-reactivity of the ICT test in areas with contrasting levels of L. loa and Mansonella perstans ( M. perstans ) endemicity in Cameroon. We conducted a cross-sectional study in 42 villages across three regions of the Cameroon rainforest domain, assessing the prevalence and intensity of W. bancrofti, L. loa, and M. perstans. We found that the ICT test was strongly associated with high L. loa Mf intensity, with 21 subjects having more than 8, 000 L. loa Mf/ml of blood. We also observed a strong positive association between the prevalence of L. loa and ICT positivity by area, with a rate of 1% or more of positive ICT results found only in areas with an L. loa Mf prevalence above 15%. In contrast, there was no association between ICT positivity and M. perstans prevalence or Mf density. These results suggest that the main confounding factor for positive ICT test card results is high levels of L. loa.
Positive-strand RNA viruses, such as SARS-CoV, replicate in the cytoplasm of infected host cells. Their replication complexes are commonly associated with modified host cell membranes, which can range from distinct spherular membrane invaginations to elaborate networks of membranes and vesicles. The ultrastructure, morphogenesis, and exact role of these structures in viral replication remain poorly defined. We have used electron tomography of cryofixed infected cells to define a unique reticulovesicular network of modified endoplasmic reticulum that integrates convoluted membranes, numerous interconnected double-membrane vesicles ( DMVs ), and “vesicle packets” arising from DMV merger. The convoluted membranes were most abundantly immunolabeled for viral replicase subunits. However, double-stranded RNA, presumably revealing the site of viral RNA synthesis, mainly localized to the DMV interior. Our analysis raises several questions about the mechanism of DMV formation and the actual site of SARS-CoV RNA synthesis. Our data document the extensive virus-induced reorganization of host cell membranes into a network that is used to organize viral replication and possibly hide replicating RNA from antiviral defense mechanisms.
Arabidopsis thaliana is a model organism used to study the role of suberin in plant roots. Suberin is a waxy, hydrophobic compound that has been hypothesized to form an extracellular barrier limiting the apoplastic transport of water and solutes in plant roots. Here, we present direct genetic evidence that suberin in the roots of Arabidopsis thaliana plays a critical role in controlling both water and mineral ion uptake and transport to the leaves. Using the newly characterized enhanced suberin1 ( esb1 ) mutant, we established a connection between suberin in the root and both water movement through the plant and solute accumulation in the shoot. Esb1 mutants, characterized by increased root suberin, were found to have reduced daytime transpiration rates and increased water-use efficiency during their vegetative growth period. Furthermore, these changes in suberin and water transport were associated with decreases in the accumulation of Ca, Mn, and Zn and increases in the accumulation of Na, S, K, As, Se, and Mo in the shoot.
The kinetics of rhodopsin deactivation and its role in regulating recovery and reproducibility of rod photoresponse have been investigated using a Continuous Time Markov Chain ( CTMC ) model. The model is based on the biochemistry of rhodopsin activation and deactivation and is interfaced with a spatio-temporal model of phototransduction. The model parameters are extracted from the photoresponse data of both wild type and mutant mice with variable numbers of phosphorylation sites. The model reproduces both wild type and mutant responses with the same set of parameters. The sources of variability are dissected into their components, and the results show that only the randomness of the sojourn times in each of the phosphorylated states contributes to the Coefficient of Variation ( CV ) of the response, whereas the randomness of the number of R* turnoff steps has a negligible effect. These results counter the view that the larger the number of decay steps of R*, the more stable the photoresponse is. Our results indicate that R* shutoff is responsible for the variability of the photoresponse, while the diffusion of the second messengers acts as a variability suppressor.
In this work, we develop a general mathematical framework to uncouple the dynamics of a stochastic reaction network from its fluctuating extrinsic environment. This is achieved by marginalizing the system dynamics with respect to the extrinsic fluctuations, resulting in a decoupled model that summarizes all system behaviors attainable under all possible realizations of the extrinsic noise. The decoupled dynamics provide a novel analytical tool to study how environmental stochasticity is propagated along coupled reaction networks. We show that the total environmental noise splits up into two terms: one corresponding to the noise that is suppressed and a second term that quantifies the effective noise that is sensed by the target network. In the context of Monte Carlo simulation, the decoupled process can yield a significant reduction in computational effort when compared to standard SSA, especially if the environmental network is costly to simulate. We describe the time-evolution of a stochastic reaction network by a continuous-time Markov chain ( CTMC ) with chemical species and reaction channels. The system state at time is denoted and we write its random path on time intervals as. We derive the corresponding process- and master equations for the decoupled model and show how stochastic simulations can be performed.
A novel closed-loop brain-machine interface ( BMI ) training architecture has been developed that enables robust control and extends to various tasks. The architecture, termed adaptive optimal feedback-controlled ( OFC ) point process filter ( PPF ), incorporates an infinite-horizon optimal feedback control model of the brain’s behavior in closed-loop BMI control and a point process model of spikes. The OFC model infers the user’s motor intention during closed-loop decoder adaptation ( CLDA ) and is used to design an autonomous and dynamic assisted training technique. The point process model allows for neural processing, control, and decoder adaptation with every spike event and at a faster time-scale than current decoders. We conducted closed-loop experiments in a non-human primate over tens of days to dissociate the effects of these novel CLDA components. The OFC intention estimation improved BMI performance compared with current intention estimation techniques. OFC assisted training allowed the subject to consistently achieve proficient control. Spike-event-based adaptation resulted in faster and more consistent performance convergence compared with batch-based methods, and was robust to parameter initialization. Finally, the architecture extended control to tasks beyond those used for CLDA training.
Retinal ganglion cells in the mammalian retina respond to a wide range of stimuli with varying degrees of spatial and temporal correlations. To investigate the effect of stimulus structure on redundancy in retinal responses, we measured simultaneous responses from populations of retinal ganglion cells presented with natural and artificial stimuli that varied greatly in correlation structure. We found that responding to spatio-temporally structured stimuli such as natural movies, pairs of ganglion cells were modestly more correlated than in response to white noise checkerboards, but they were much less correlated than predicted by a non-adapting functional model of retinal response. Meanwhile, responding to stimuli with purely spatial correlations, pairs of ganglion cells showed increased correlations consistent with a static, non-adapting receptive field and nonlinearity. We found that in response to spatio-temporally correlated stimuli, ganglion cells had faster temporal kernels and tended to have stronger surrounds. These properties of individual cells, along with gain changes that opposed changes in effective contrast at the ganglion cell input, largely explained the pattern of pairwise correlations across stimuli where receptive field measurements were possible.
Synthetic lethal ( SL ) interactions occur when a combination of mutations results in a surprising phenotype. These interactions are important for predicting function, dissecting protein complexes into functional pathways, and exploring the mechanistic underpinnings of common human diseases. However, only a small proportion of gene pairs have been tested for genetic interactions due to the large number of possible combinations of gene pairs. To expand the set of known SL interactions, we have devised an integrative, multi-network approach for predicting these interactions that significantly improves upon the existing approaches. We defined a large number of features for characterizing the relationships between pairs of genes from various data sources. These features are independent of the known SL interactions, in contrast to some previous approaches. We developed a non-parametric multi-classifier system for predicting SL interactions that enabled the simultaneous use of multiple classification procedures. Using this approach, we derived the first yeast transcription factor genetic interaction network, part of which was well supported by literature. We also used this approach to predict SL interactions between all non-essential gene pairs in yeast. This integrative approach is expected to be more effective and robust in uncovering new genetic interactions from the tens of millions of unknown gene pairs in yeast and from the hundreds of millions of gene pairs in higher organisms like mouse and human, in which very few genetic interactions have been identified to date.
The BRCA Challenge is a global data-sharing project initiated by the Global Alliance for Genomics and Health ( GA4GH ) to aggregate data on BRCA1 and BRCA2 variants. The project aims to generate a comprehensive understanding of the impact of genetic variation on cancer risk in these genes. The BRCA Exchange, a newly created web portal ( www. brcaexchange. org ), aggregates over 20, 000 reported variants in BRCA1 and BRCA2, three times the number found in the next-largest public database at the project’s outset. Approximately 7, 250 of these variants have expert classifications. The data set is based on shared information from existing clinical databases, including the Breast Cancer Information Core ( BIC ), ClinVar, and the Leiden Open Variation Database ( LOVD ), as well as population databases. The BRCA Challenge has brought together experts from the Evidence-based Network for the Interpretation of Germline Mutant Alleles ( ENIGMA ) consortium, clinicians, diagnosticians, researchers, and database providers to advance our understanding of BRCA1 and BRCA2 variation. The project pioneers the hypothesis-free linkage of molecular variants with electronic patient records to build an unbiased prospective knowledge base of cancer predisposition. The BRCA Challenge represents an important step in the sharing and collaborative annotation of BRCA1 and BRCA2 variants to advance human health globally.
Malaria, caused by the apicomplexan parasite Plasmodium, is a major threat to human health and welfare. In order to deal with high fluxes of reactive oxygen species and maintain redox regulatory processes and pathogenicity, Plasmodium depends upon an adequate redox balance. By systematically studying the subcellular localization of the major antioxidant and redox regulatory proteins, we obtained the first complete map of redox compartmentation in Plasmodium falciparum. We demonstrate the targeting of two plasmodial peroxiredoxins and a putative glyoxalase system to the apicoplast, a non-photosynthetic plastid. Furthermore, we obtained a complete picture of the compartmentation of thioredoxin- and glutaredoxin-like proteins. Notably, for the two major antioxidant redox-enzymes – glutathione reductase and thioredoxin reductase – Plasmodium makes use of alternative-translation-initiation ( ATI ) to achieve differential targeting. Our study provides the first comprehensive picture of the subcellular compartmentation of cellular redox metabolism in malaria parasites. The apicoplast, a non-photosynthetic plastid of Plasmodium, harbours indispensable plant-like metabolic pathways including fatty-acid and haem biosynthesis.
PUMA is an intrinsically disordered protein that binds to its cellular partner Mcl-1 through its BH3 motif, which folds into an α helix upon binding. We have used a structure-based coarse-grained model to investigate the role of electrostatic interactions in the coupled folding and binding of PUMA with Mcl-1. The model was calibrated with experimental data on helical content and affinity, and was shown to be consistent with previously published experimental data on binding rate changes with respect to ionic strength. Our results suggest that intramolecular electrostatic interactions have a marginal influence on the unbound states of PUMA. However, we find that intermolecular electrostatic interactions, and in particular non-native electrostatic interactions, are involved in the formation of the initial encounter complex between PUMA and Mcl-1. Our simulations indicate that the binding process is accelerated by electrostatic interactions, and that association rates decrease at higher ionic strengths where charges are more efficiently screened from each other and electrostatic interactions are weakened.
Polycomb group ( PcG ) proteins are conserved chromatin factors that maintain silencing of key developmental genes outside of their expression domains. Here, we studied the nuclear distribution of two PcG proteins, PC and Polyhomeotic ( PH ), during fly embryogenesis. Using a combination of immunostaining, immuno-FISH, and live imaging of GFP fusion proteins, we analyzed the formation and motion of PC bodies, which are nuclear structures containing PcG-silenced genes. We found that PC bodies mainly correspond to 3D structural counterparts of the linear genomic domains identified in genome-wide studies. During early embryogenesis, PC and PH progressively accumulate within PC bodies, which form nuclear structures localized on distinct euchromatin domains containing histone H3 tri-methylated on K27. Time-lapse analysis indicates that two types of motion influence the displacement of PC bodies and chromatin domains containing H2Av-GFP. First, chromatin domains and PC bodies coordinately undergo long-range motions that may correspond to the movement of whole chromosome territories. Second, each PC body and chromatin domain has its own fast and highly constrained motion. The fast motion of PC bodies and chromatin domains observed during early embryogenesis strongly decreases in late developmental stages, indicating a possible contribution of chromatin dynamics in the maintenance of stable gene silencing.
Mitochondrial DNA ( mtDNA ) mutations are implicated in the aging process, but there is no universally accepted method for their accurate quantification. We have used ultra-deep sequencing to study genome-wide mtDNA mutation load in the liver of normally- and prematurely-aging mice. Mice that are homozygous for an allele expressing a proof-reading–deficient mtDNA polymerase ( mtDNA mutator mice ) have 10-times-higher point mutation loads than their wildtype siblings. In addition, the mtDNA mutator mice have increased levels of a truncated linear mtDNA molecule, resulting in decreased sequence coverage in the deleted region. In contrast, circular mtDNA molecules with large deletions occur at extremely low frequencies in mtDNA mutator mice and can therefore not drive the premature aging phenotype. Sequence analysis shows that the main proportion of the mutation load in heterozygous mtDNA mutator mice and their wildtype siblings is inherited from their heterozygous mothers consistent with germline transmission. We found no increase in levels of point mutations or deletions in wildtype C57Bl/6N mice with increasing age, thus questioning the causative role of these changes in aging. Our results from studies of mice thus indicate that most somatic mtDNA mutations occur as replication errors during development and do not result from damage accumulation in adult life.
The F1Fo-ATP synthase from the anaerobic bacterium Fusobacterium nucleatum has been shown to be directly coupled to ATP synthesis via a novel Na+ recognition motif. This motif is shared by other human pathogens and is characterized by a two-carboxylate ion-coupling motif. Molecular modeling and free-energy simulations of the rotary element of the enzyme, the c-ring, indicate Na+ specificity in physiological settings. Consistently, activity measurements showed Na+ stimulation of the enzyme, either membrane-embedded or isolated, and ATP synthesis was sensitive to the Na+ ionophore monensin. Furthermore, Na+ has a protective effect against inhibitors targeting the ion-binding sites, both in the complete ATP synthase and the isolated c-ring. Definitive evidence of Na+ coupling is provided by two identical crystal structures of the c11 ring, solved by X-ray crystallography at 2. 2 and 2. 6 Å resolution, at pH 5. 3 and 8. 7, respectively. Na+ ions occupy all binding sites, each coordinated by four amino acids and a water molecule.
T cells recognize foreign peptides bound to major histocompatibility complex ( pMHC ) molecules on the surface of antigen presenting cells ( APCs ) to initiate adaptive cellular immunity. In vitro, high-affinity binding and/or long-lived interactions between T cell receptors ( TCRs ) and pMHC correlate with high-potency T cell activation. However, the influence of TCR/pMHC interaction parameters on T cell responses in vivo is less well understood. We studied the influence of TCR/pMHC binding characteristics on in vivo T cell immunity by tracking CD4+ T cell activation, effector, and memory responses to immunization with peptides exhibiting a range of TCR/pMHC half-lives and in vitro T cell activation potencies. Contrary to predictions from in vitro studies, we found that optimal in vivo T cell responses occur to ligands with intermediate TCR/pMHC half-lives. The diminished in vivo responses we observed to the ligand exhibiting the longest TCR/pMHC half-life were associated with attenuation of intracellular signaling, expansion, and function over a broad range of time points. Our results reveal a level of control over T cell activation in vivo not recapitulated in in vitro assays and highlight the importance of considering in vivo efficacy of TCR ligands as part of vaccine design.
Nectria haematococca, also known by its asexual name Fusarium solani, is a member of the Fusarium solani species complex, a group of over 50 phylogenetic species. This fungus is known to colonize a wide variety of environments and can cause disease in over 100 genera of plants as well as opportunistic infections in humans. The most extensively studied member of this complex is N. haematococca mating population VI ( MPVI ). The genome of N. haematococca MPVI isolate 77-13-4 consists of 17 chromosomes ranging from 530 kb to 6. 52 Mb and has a physical size of 54. 43 Mb, which is larger than that of any other published ascomycete. The number of predicted genes, 15, 707, is also among the largest reported for ascomycetes. Two classes of genes have contributed to gene expansion in N. haematococca MPVI: genes that are not found in other fungi, including its closest sequenced relative Fusarium graminearum, and genes that occur as single copies in other fungi but are present as multiple copies in N. haematococca MPVI. The supernumerary nature of three chromosomes, 14, 15, and 17, was confirmed by their absence in pulsed field gel electrophoresis experiments of some isolates and by demonstrating that these isolates lacked chromosome-specific sequences found on the ends of these chromosomes. These supernumerary chromosomes contain more repeat sequences, are enriched in unique and duplicated genes, and have a lower G+C content in comparison to the other chromosomes.
Egress of newly assembled herpesvirus particles from infected cells is a highly dynamic process that involves the host secretory pathway working in concert with viral components. To elucidate the location, dynamics, and molecular mechanisms of alpha herpesvirus egress, we developed a live-cell fluorescence microscopy method to visualize the final transport and exocytosis of pseudorabies virus ( PRV ) particles in non-polarized epithelial cells. Our method is based on total internal reflection fluorescence ( TIRF ) microscopy to selectively image fluorescent virus particles near the plasma membrane, and takes advantage of a virus-encoded pH-sensitive probe to visualize the precise moment and location of particle exocytosis. We found that individual virus particles travel to the plasma membrane inside small, acidified secretory vesicles. These vesicles undergo fast, directional transport directly to the site of exocytosis, which is most frequently near patches of LL5β, part of a complex that anchors microtubules to the plasma membrane. Vesicles are tightly docked at the site of exocytosis for several seconds, and membrane fusion occurs, displacing the virion a small distance across the plasma membrane. After exocytosis, particles remain tightly confined on the outer cell surface. We propose an integrated model that links together the intracellular transport pathways and exocytosis mechanisms that mediate alpha herpesvirus egress.
Enterobius vermicularis infection and its treatment with mebendazole have been associated with changes in the intestinal microbiota of primary school children. In this study, we examined the impact of pinworm infection and mebendazole treatment on intestinal microbial composition and mucosal immune responses in 109 primary school children. We found that pinworm infection was associated with increased intestinal bacterial diversity, which peaked after administration of mebendazole. At the phylum level, pinworm infection and mebendazole deworming were associated with a decreased relative abundance of Fusobacteria and an increased proportion of Actinobacteria. Furthermore, the relative abundance of the probiotic Bifidobacterium increased after enterobiasis and mebendazole treatment. The intestinal secretory immunoglobulin A ( SIgA ) level was found to be lower in the pinworm-infected group, and was elevated in half of the mebendazole-treated group. However, a higher proportion of pre-treatment Salmonella spp. was associated with a non-increase in SIgA after mebendazole deworming treatment. These findings suggest that childhood exposure to pinworm plus mebendazole is associated with increased bacterial diversity, an increased abundance of Actinobacteria including the probiotic Bifidobacterium, and a decreased proportion of Fusobacteria.
Root length in Arabidopsis thaliana is a complex trait that does not follow the common view in quantitative genetics that most genetic variance for complex traits is expected to be additive. We found that the genomic narrow-sense heritability for root length in the examined population was statistically zero, and the low amount of additive genetic variance that could be captured by the genome-wide genotypes likely explains why no associations to root length could be found using standard additive-model-based genome-wide association ( GWA ) approaches. However, the broad-sense heritability for root length was significantly larger and primarily due to epistasis. Therefore, we also performed an epistatic GWA analysis to map loci contributing to the epistatic genetic variance. This analysis revealed four interacting pairs of loci involving seven chromosomal loci that passed a standard multiple-testing corrected significance threshold. The genotype-phenotype maps for these pairs revealed epistasis that cancelled out the additive genetic variance, explaining why these loci were not detected in the additive GWA analysis. We estimated the false-positive risk using a new statistical approach that suggested half of the associated pairs to be true positive associations. Our experimental evaluation of candidate genes within the seven associated loci suggests that this estimate is conservative; we identified functional candidate genes that affected root development in four loci that were part of three of the pairs.
Mitochondrial DNA ( mtDNA ) mutations are a common cause of human disease. We analyzed 30, 506 mtDNA sequences from around the world and found that the background mtDNA haplogroup influences the occurrence and severity of disease-causing mtDNA mutations. We determined the pathogenicity score of the major alleles for each sequence and found that the mean pathogenicity score for known disease-causing mutations was significantly different between mtDNA macro-haplogroups. We also found that disease-causing mutations were more frequent on young sequences and that genomes with two or more disease-causing mutations were more common than expected by chance. These findings implicate the mtDNA background in recurrent mutation events that have been purified through natural selection in older populations. This provides an explanation for the low frequency of mtDNA disease reported in specific ethnic groups. We found that the number of mtDNA sequences harboring two or more disease-causing mutations was 6-fold lower than expected by chance in macro-haplogroup N sequences. This suggests that the mtDNA sequence background influences the likelihood of acquiring or retaining a disease-causing mutation. We also found statistical evidence of haplogroup clustering for 10 ( 29. 4% ) of the 34 recurrent disease-causing mtDNA mutations.
Collective cell migration is an important biological process that plays a key role in cancer metastasis, embryonic development, and wound healing. In this process, cells are able to coordinate their motion, leading to collective motility. To study these cell-cell interactions, which include contact inhibition of locomotion ( CIL ), micropatterned substrates are often used to restrict cell migration to linear, quasi-one-dimensional paths. Using a computational phase field model of collective cell motility that includes the mechanics of cell shape and a minimal chemical model for CIL, we are able to reproduce all cases seen in two-cell collisions. A subtle balance between the internal cell polarization, CIL and cell-cell adhesion governs the collision outcome. We identify the parameters that control transitions between the different cases, including cell-cell adhesion, propulsion strength, and the rates of CIL. These parameters suggest hypotheses for why different cell types have different collision behavior and the effect of interventions that modulate collision outcomes.
The dissociation mechanism of thioredoxin ( Trx ) mixed disulfide complexes has been a subject of debate for over twenty years. We investigated the dissociation mechanism of the Trx mixed disulfide complex with its endogenous substrate, arsenate reductase ( ArsC ), using a multidisciplinary approach including theoretical reactivity analysis, molecular dynamics simulations, and biochemical complex formation experiments with Cys-mutants. Our results show that the conformational changes around the intermediate disulfide bring Cys32Trx in contact with Cys29Trx. Cys32Trx is activated for its nucleophilic attack by hydrogen bonds and is found to be more reactive than Cys82ArsC. Additionally, Cys32Trx directs its nucleophilic attack on the more susceptible Cys29Trx and not on Cys89ArsC. Our results provide fresh insights into a universal thiol/disulfide exchange reaction mechanism that results in reduced substrate and oxidized Trx. In this mechanism, Cys29Trx nucleophilically attacks Cys89ArsC of the Cys82ArsC-Cys89ArsC disulfide, leading to the formation of the Trx-ArsC mixed disulfide intermediate complex between Cys29Trx and Cys89ArsC. Cys32Trx then performs a nucleophilic attack on Cys29Trx of the Cys29Trx-Cys89ArsC disulfide, leading to the dissociation of the mixed disulfide and the release of reduced ArsC and oxidized Trx.
Inter-temporal preferences refer to the degree to which an outcome feature contributes to a person’s preference. We hypothesised that people can be uncertain about their preferences and that this uncertainty is reflected in their choice variability. This uncertainty can be updated by considering evidence, such as the preferences of others, and performing Bayesian updating. Temporal discounting coefficients, which quantify impulsivity, are an important example of taste–for patience and can change upon observing others’ choices. We examined discounting preferences in a large community study of 14–24 year olds. We found good evidence for taste uncertainty and for Bayesian taste updating. First, participants displayed decision variability which was better accounted for by a random-taste than by a response-noise model. Second, apparent taste shifts were well described by a Bayesian model taking into account taste uncertainty and the relevance of social information. Our findings have important neuroscientific, clinical and developmental significance.
Filamentous growth in budding yeast is a complex differentiation response that occurs under specific environmental conditions and is regulated by multiple pathways. To identify new aspects of filamentous growth regulation, we developed a novel screening approach called secretion profiling that measures the release of the extracellular domain of Msb2p, the signaling mucin that functions at the head of the filamentous growth ( FG ) MAPK pathway. Secretion profiling of complementary genomic collections showed that many of the pathways that regulate filamentous growth ( RAS, RIM101, OPI1, and RTG ) are also required for FG pathway activation. This regulation sensitizes the FG pathway to multiple stimuli and synchronizes it to the global signaling network. Several of the regulators are required for MSB2 expression, which identifies the MSB2 promoter as a target “hub” where multiple signals converge. The MSB2 promoter is further regulated by the histone deacetylase ( HDAC ) Rpd3p ( L ), which positively regulates FG pathway activity and filamentous growth. Our findings provide the first glimpse of a global regulatory hierarchy among the pathways that control filamentous growth and suggest that systems-level integration of signaling circuitry is likely to coordinate other regulatory networks that control complex behaviors.
Fruiting body development in filamentous fungi is an ideal system for studying the evolution of sexual phenotypes. In the Sordariomycetes, we have shown that few developmental genes whose expression evolves retain common phenotypes or even phenotypes corresponding to a common stage of development, yet numerous genes do retain some function within the larger fruiting body developmental process. We have identified key genes and their relevance to sexual development, and their lability in the network regulating fungal sexual reproduction using an efficient systematic approach empowered by comparison and contrast of gene expression programs across multiple taxa. We reconstructed ancestral gene expression phenotypes, identifying genes with the largest evolved increases in gene expression across development. Conducting knockouts and performing phenotypic analysis in two divergent species typically demonstrated altered fruiting body development in the species that had evolved increased expression. Our evolutionary approach to finding relevant genes proved far more efficient than other gene deletion studies targeting whole genomes or gene families. Combining gene expression measurements with knockout phenotypes facilitated the refinement of Bayesian networks of the genes underlying fruiting body development, regulation of which is one of the least understood processes of multicellular development.
Schistosomes are parasitic flatworms that cause schistosomiasis, a major public health problem in tropical and subtropical regions. The schistosome egg represents an attractive target for transgenesis because of the high ratio of germ to somatic cells, which allows for the propagation and amplification of transgenes. Here, we investigated the utility of square wave electroporation to deliver transgenes and other macromolecules into eggs of Schistosoma mansoni. We found that electroporation was more efficient than soaking alone for transduction of schistosome eggs by messenger RNA encoding luciferase and by pseudotyped retrovirus virions. Electroporation resulted in 2–3 times as many copies of provirus in miracidia hatched from virion-exposed eggs compared to soaking alone. We also found that electroporated Cy3-siRNA entered the eggs and entered the miracidium within the eggshell. Luciferase activity was detected in extracts of eggs three hours after electroporation of capped mRNA, but not after soaking alone. These findings underscore the potential of targeting the schistosome egg for germ line transgenesis.
The Perturbation-based Markovian Transmission ( PMT ) model is a novel approach developed to study the dynamic properties of large macromolecular assemblies. This method involves probing the macromolecular assembly with an initial perturbation and monitoring the time-dependent responses of all residues simultaneously from the moment of perturbation until all residues reach the equilibrium state. The PMT model assumes that perturbations are transmitted by a Markovian process through the connected network defined by the contacts between atoms and residues. This approach enables the characterization of the temporal dynamic response to signal perturbation across all residues in a large macromolecular assembly at all time scales, from the beginning perturbation until the equilibrium state is reached. The PMT model can identify pivot residues important for macromolecular movement, messenger residues key to signal mediating, and anchor residues important for binding interactions. We applied the PMT model to the GroEL-GroES chaperone system and found that our predictions have an accuracy of 71–84% judged by independent experimental studies reported in the literature. This approach is general and can be applied to other large macromolecular machineries such as the virus capsid and ribosomal complex.
CGL2, a galectin from the fungus Coprinopsis cinerea, is toxic to the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. C. elegans fed with E. coli cells expressing CGL2 exhibited inhibited development, reproduction, and ultimately death. The nematotoxicity of CGL2 depends on the interaction between the galectin and a fucose-containing glycoconjugate. A screen for CGL2-resistant C. elegans mutants identified the glycoconjugate as a Galβ1, 4Fucα1, 6 modification of C. elegans N-glycan cores. This modification is required for CGL2-mediated nematotoxicity, as C. elegans mutants defective in GDP-fucose biosynthesis were resistant to CGL2. The X-ray crystal structure of a complex between CGL2 and the Galβ1, 4Fucα1, 6GlcNAc trisaccharide at 1. 5 Å resolution revealed the biophysical basis for this interaction. Our results suggest that fungal galectins play a role in the defense of fungi against predators by binding to specific glycoconjugates of these organisms. The identification of a novel putative glycosyltransferase required for the biosynthesis of the Galβ1, 4Fucα1, 6 modification of C. elegans N-glycan cores may shed light on the physiological significance of this N-glycan modification.
The existence of long-lived reservoirs of latently infected CD4+ T cells is a major barrier to curing HIV. We present a within-host quasispecies model that incorporates a long-lived reservoir, which we then nest into an epidemiological model of HIV dynamics. For biologically plausible parameter values, we find that the presence of a latent reservoir can severely delay evolutionary dynamics within a single host, with longer delays associated with larger relative reservoir sizes and/or homeostatic proliferation of cells within the reservoir. These delays can fundamentally change the dynamics of the virus at the epidemiological scale. In particular, the delay in within-host evolutionary dynamics can be sufficient for the virus to evolve intermediate viral loads consistent with maximising transmission, as is observed, and not the very high viral loads that previous models have predicted. These results depend strongly on within-host characteristics such as the relative reservoir size, with the evolution of intermediate viral loads observed only when the within-host dynamics are sufficiently delayed. We argue that the latent reservoir has important, and hitherto under-appreciated, roles in both within- and between-host viral evolution.
Coxsackievirus B3 ( CVB3 ) profoundly inhibits the MHC class I antigen presentation pathway in vivo, thereby evading CD8+ T cell immunity. In contrast, the presentation of CVB3-encoded MHC class II epitopes is relatively unencumbered, and CVB3 induces in vivo CD4+ T cell responses that are phenotypically normal. CVB3-specific CD4+ T cells display an effector phenotype and a Th1 cytokine profile, and are enriched among CD4+ T cells in peripheral sites of virus infection that are major targets of CVB3 pathogenesis. Using epitope-specific transgenic CD4+ and CD8+ T cells as sensors of in vitro and in vivo antigen presentation, we show that CVB3 induces essentially no detectable in vivo primary CD8+ T cell response. In contrast, CVB3 induces both primary and memory CD4+ T cell responses. CVB3-specific CD4+ T cells expand dramatically following challenge infection and rapidly differentiate into secondary effector cells capable of secreting multiple cytokines. Our findings have implications for the efficiency of antigen cross-presentation during coxsackievirus infection.
Leprosy Type 1 reactions ( T1Rs ) are a major cause of nerve damage and preventable disability in leprosy patients. Leprosy T1Rs are treated with oral corticosteroids, but the optimal dose and duration of treatment are not well established. Leprosy T1Rs are characterised by a Th1 immune profile, with cells in cutaneous and neural lesions expressing interferon-γ and interleukin-12. We investigated the efficacy of high dose intravenous methylprednisolone ( MP ) followed by oral prednisolone compared to oral prednisolone alone in patients with leprosy T1Rs and/or nerve function impairment ( NFI ). Forty-two patients were randomised to receive MP followed by oral prednisolone ( n = 20 ) or oral prednisolone alone ( n = 22 ). There were no significant differences in the rate of adverse events or clinical improvement at the completion of the study. However, patients treated with MP were less likely to experience deterioration in sensory function between day 29 and day 113 of the study. The study also demonstrated that 50% of patients with leprosy T1Rs and/or NFI required additional prednisolone despite treatment with 16 weeks of corticosteroids. These findings support the use of more prolonged courses of corticosteroids to treat leprosy T1Rs and the investigation of risk factors for recurrence of leprosy T1Rs and NFI during and after corticosteroid treatment.
Regulatory CD4+CD25highFoxP3+ T cells ( Treg ) have been shown to modulate CD8+ T cell responses in HIV-negative settings, at least in part through the PD-1/PD-L1 pathway. We investigated the effects of Treg from HIV-infected patients ( Treg/HIV+ ) on CD8+ T cell responses in chronic HIV infection. We found that Treg/HIV+ did not significantly inhibit polyclonal autologous CD8+ T cell function, suggesting either a defect in the suppressive capacity of Treg/HIV+ or a lack of sensitivity of effector T cells in HIV infection. However, Treg/HIV+ inhibited the IFN-γ expression of autologous CD8+ T cells stimulated with recall CMV/EBV/Flu ( CEF ) antigens, but did not inhibit HIV-Gag–specific CD8+ T cells. In contrast, Treg from HIV-negative controls ( Treg/HIV- ) inhibited the differentiation of both CEF- and Gag-specific CD8+ T cells from HIV-infected patients. The expression of PD-1 and PD-L1 was higher on Gag-specific CD8+ T cells than on CEF-specific CD8+ T cells, and did not change significantly after Treg depletion or co-culture with Treg/HIV-. Our results suggest that Treg/HIV+ have a defect in modulating both the differentiation and the expression of PD-1/PD-L1 molecules on HIV-specific CD8 T cells, which might contribute to the exhaustion of HIV-specific T cell responses.
Wuchereria bancrofti glutathione-S-transferase ( WbGST ) has been evaluated as a vaccine candidate against lymphatic filariasis. The WbGST gene was cloned from the third stage larval ( L3 ) cDNA libraries of W. bancrofti, and recombinant WbGST ( rWbGST ) was expressed and purified. Serum samples from individuals living in an endemic area were analyzed for their reactivity with rWbGST, showing that sera from endemic normal individuals ( EN ) carry significant levels of anti-WbGST IgG antibodies compared to subjects who are microfilaraemic ( Mf ) or show symptoms of clinical pathology ( CP ). Subsequent functional analysis of rWbGST showed that the rWbGST protein retained the enzymatic activity of GST and the antibodies in EN sera could inhibit this enzymatic activity. Similar results were obtained when anti-rWbGST antibodies raised in mice were used in the neutralization assay. Brugia malayi GST and WbGST show significant sequence similarity. Therefore, to evaluate the vaccine potential of rWbGST, we used B. malayi L3 as challenge parasites. Vaccine potential of rWbGST was initially evaluated by confirming the role of human and mice WbGST antibodies in an antibody dependent cellular cytotoxicity ( ADCC ) assay. Subsequent vaccination studies in a jird model showed that approximately 61% protection could be achieved against a B. malayi L3 challenge infection in jirds immunized with rWbGST.
CRISPR-Cas9 technologies have revolutionized genome editing of experimental organisms and hold immense potential for therapeutic applications. However, despite significant advances in our understanding of the CRISPR-Cas9 system, concerns remain over the potential for off-target effects. Recent studies have used whole-genome sequencing of gene-edited embryos or animals to search for de novo mutations ( DNMs ), which may represent candidate changes introduced by poor editing fidelity. However, these studies used strain-matched, but not pedigree-matched controls, and thus were unable to reliably distinguish generational or colony-related differences from true DNMs. Here, we used a trio design and whole-genome sequenced 8 parents and 19 embryos, where 10 of the embryos were mutagenised with well-characterised gRNAs targeting the coat colour Tyrosinase ( Tyr ) locus. We found that if CRISPR mutagenesis were causing SNV or indel off-target mutations in treated embryos, then the number of these mutations is not statistically distinguishable from the background rate of DNMs occurring due to other processes.
Stomatal pores on plant leaves regulate CO2 uptake for photosynthesis and water loss by transpiration. Blue light is one of the environmental signals that control stomatal aperture, and the signal transduction cascades that link light perception to stomatal opening are still largely unknown. Here, we report two new players, Hypersensitive to Red and Blue 1 ( HRB1 ) and Protein Phosphatase 7 ( PP7 ), and their genetic and biochemical interactions in the control of stomatal aperture. Mutations in either HRB1 or PP7 lead to misregulation of stomatal aperture and reduced water loss under blue light. Both HRB1 and PP7 are expressed in guard cells in response to a light-to-dark or dark-to-light transition. HRB1 interacts with PP7 through its N-terminal ZZ-type zinc finger motif and requires a functional PP7 for its stomatal opening response. HRB1 is phosphorylated in vivo, and PP7 can dephosphorylate HRB1. We propose that a modification of HRB1 by PP7 under blue light is essential to acquire a proper conformation or to bring in new components for the assembly of a functional HRB1 protein complex. This study may furnish strategies that allow plants to enjoy the advantages of both constitutive and ABA-induced protection under water-limiting conditions.
The C. elegans Mediator subunit MDT-15 is a transcriptional coregulator that plays a critical role in integrating metabolic responses to ingested materials, including nutrients, xenobiotics, and heavy metals. MDT-15 is a component of the Mediator complex, which is targeted by many transcriptional regulatory factors. In this study, we demonstrate that MDT-15 is required for the induction of detoxification genes in response to certain xenobiotics and heavy metals, and that depletion of MDT-15 or mutation of the mdt-15 gene renders C. elegans hypersensitive to toxin exposure. MDT-15 appears to selectively affect stress responses related to ingestion, as it does not abrogate other stress responses, such as thermotolerance. Our findings suggest that MDT-15 integrates several transcriptional regulatory pathways to monitor both the availability and quality of ingested materials. We propose a model whereby MDT-15 coordinates systemic adaptation to ingestion-related stress, ensuring maintenance of health and longevity. MDT-15 integrates expression of metabolic genes by interacting with at least two metabolic regulatory factors, NHR-49 and SBP-1, and may similarly integrate the transcriptional response to environmental stressors such as xenobiotics and heavy metals by employing a different set of regulatory factors.
Hippocampal spatial map formation is central to an animal's ability to navigate its environment. We hypothesize that the temporal pattern of neuronal firing, particularly co-firing, is key to decoding spatial information. Since co-firing implies spatial overlap of place fields, a map encoded by co-firing will be based on connectivity and adjacency, i. e., it will be a topological map. We test this topological hypothesis with a simple model of hippocampal activity, varying three parameters ( firing rate, place field size, and number of neurons ) in computer simulations of rat trajectories in three topologically and geometrically distinct test environments. Using a computational algorithm based on Persistent Homology theory, we find that the patterns of neuronal co-firing can convey topological information about the environment in a biologically realistic length of time. Our simulations reveal a “learning region” that highlights the interplay between the parameters in combining to produce hippocampal states that are more or less adept at map formation. For example, within the learning region a lower number of neurons firing can be compensated by adjustments in firing rate or place field size, but beyond a certain point map formation begins to fail. We propose that this learning region provides a coherent theoretical lens through which to view conditions that impair spatial learning by altering place cell firing rates or spatial specificity.
Hepatitis C virus ( HCV ) egress from infected cells involves the assembly of virions on lipid droplets, envelopment at the endoplasmic reticulum ( ER ) in association with components of very low-density lipoprotein ( VLDL ) synthesis, and egress via the secretory pathway. However, the cellular requirements for and mechanistic understanding of HCV secretion are incomplete. We combined RNA interference ( RNAi ) analysis of host factors for infectious HCV secretion with live cell imaging of HCV core trafficking to gain a detailed understanding of HCV egress. RNAi studies identified multiple components of the secretory pathway, including ER to Golgi trafficking, lipid and protein kinases that regulate budding from the trans-Golgi network ( TGN ), VAMP1 vesicles and adaptor proteins, and the recycling endosome. Our results support a model wherein HCV is infectious upon envelopment at the ER and exits the cell via the secretory pathway. We constructed infectious HCV with a tetracysteine ( TC ) tag insertion in core ( TC-core ) to monitor the dynamics of HCV core trafficking in association with its cellular cofactors. TC-core traffics to the cell periphery along microtubules and this movement can be inhibited by nocodazole. Sub-populations of TC-core localize to the Golgi and co-traffic with components of the recycling endosome. Silencing of the recycling endosome component Rab11a results in the accumulation of HCV core at the Golgi. The majority of dynamic core traffics in association with apolipoprotein E ( ApoE ) and VAMP1 vesicles.
Loss of the imprinted gene Grb10 promotes tumor formation in irradiated Nf1+/- mice. Grb10 is an imprinted gene that is expressed from only one parental allele, and heterozygous loss of the expressed allele results in complete loss of protein expression. In a mouse model of radiotherapy-associated second malignant neoplasms that arise in irradiated NF1 patients, Grb10 expression was found to be widely absent in tumor cell lines. Analysis of cell lines and primary tumors demonstrated that the expressed allele of Grb10 was commonly lost in diverse Nf1 mutant tumors. We show that Grb10 loss can occur during in vivo tumorigenesis, with a functional consequence in untransformed primary cells. In tumors, Grb10 loss independently promotes Ras pathway hyperactivation, which promotes hyperproliferation, an early feature of tumor development. In the context of a robust Nf1 mutant mouse model of cancer, this work identifies a novel role for an imprinted gene in tumorigenesis. We show that Grb10 is a negative regulator of Ras signaling, and contributes significantly to Ras dysregulation in the setting of Nf1-mediated tumorigenesis. These findings demonstrate a previously undescribed role for an imprinted gene in disease and suggest that mutations in imprinted genes should be considered with regard to parental origin.
Learning to predict threat from environmental cues is a fundamental skill in changing environments. Pavlovian threat conditioning is a laboratory example of this process, in which the contingent presentation of predictive cues ( conditioned stimuli, CS ) and aversive events ( unconditioned stimuli, US ) engages a process of associative learning. However, our understanding of this process is fragmented, and different computational models give rise to different and partly opposing predictions for the trial-by-trial dynamics of learning. Here, we investigate human autonomic nervous system ( ANS ) responses to conditioned stimuli during Pavlovian fear conditioning. We build on a statistical framework for psychophysiological modelling to obtain precise, trial-by-trial, single-subject estimates of ANS responses. We then consider previously proposed non-probabilistic models, a simple probabilistic model, and non-learning models, as well as different observation functions to link learning models with ANS activity. Across three experiments, and both for skin conductance ( SCR ) and pupil size responses ( PSR ), a probabilistic learning model best explains ANS responses. Notably, SCR and PSR reflect different quantities of the same model: SCR track a mixture of expected outcome and uncertainty, while PSR track expected outcome alone. This suggests that the formation and maintenance of Pavlovian threat predictions in humans may rely on probabilistic inference and includes estimation of uncertainty.
In the filamentous fungus Aspergillus nidulans, the septation initiation network ( SIN ) and the mitogen-activated protein kinase ( MAPK ) pathway play essential roles in cytokinesis, septation, and conidiation. The SIN is composed of a conserved SepH ( Cdc7p ) kinase cascade, while the MAPK pathway depends on successive signaling cascade phosphorylation to sense and respond to stress and environmental factors. In this study, we identified a SepH suppressor, PomA, as a negative regulator of septation and conidiation. The pomA mutant is able to cure defects of sepH1 in septation and conidiation, and overexpression of pomA remarkably suppresses septation. Under normal cultural conditions, SepH positively regulates the phosphorylation of MAPK-HogA, while PomA reversely affects this process. In the absence of PbsB, a putative upstream member of HogA, PomA and SepH are unable to affect the phosphorylation level of HogA. Under osmotic stress conditions, the induced phosphorylated HogA is capable of bypassing the requirement of SepH, but not the whole SIN requirement.
Leishmania RNA virus 1 ( LRV1 ) has been associated with the severity of mucosal leishmaniasis ( ML ) in experimental animal models. However, the relationship between LRV1 and the clinical manifestations of tegumentary leishmaniasis ( TL ) in humans is not fully understood. In this study, we investigated the presence of LRV1 in patients with TL and its association with the clinical manifestations of the disease. A total of 156 patients with TL were included in the study, of whom 109 had cutaneous leishmaniasis ( CL ), 38 had mucosal leishmaniasis ( ML ), 5 had concomitant CL and ML, 3 had disseminated leishmaniasis ( DL ), and 1 had diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis ( DCL ). LRV1 was detected in 71. 1% of patients with ML and 36. 7% of patients with CL. The presence of LRV1 was significantly associated with the occurrence of ML ( odds ratio = 2. 93; 95% CI 1. 57–5. 46; p < 0. 001 ). LRV1 was detected in patients infected with Leishmania ( Viannia ) braziliensis, Leishmania ( V. ) guyanensis, Leishmania ( V. ) lainsoni, Leishmania ( Leishmania ) amazonensis, and Leishmania sp. LRV1 is not the only factor contributing to the clinical manifestations of TL, and other factors such as the species of Leishmania and the immune status of the host may also play a role.
Type I interferon ( IFN-I ) plays an important role in the host defense against Streptococcus pneumoniae infection by counteracting the transmigration of bacteria from the lung to the blood. Mice lacking the type I interferon receptor ( Ifnar1−/− ) or treated with a neutralizing antibody against the type I interferon receptor exhibited enhanced development of bacteremia following intranasal pneumococcal infection, while maintaining comparable bacterial numbers in the lung. In contrast, treatment of mice with IFNβ or IFN-I-inducing synthetic double stranded RNA ( poly ( I:C ) ) dramatically reduced the development of bacteremia following intranasal infection with S. pneumoniae. IFNβ treatment led to upregulation of tight junction proteins and downregulation of the pneumococcal uptake receptor, platelet activating factor receptor ( PAF receptor ). As a result, IFN-I reduced pneumococcal cell invasion and transmigration across epithelial and endothelial layers, and Ifnar1−/− mice showed overall enhanced lung permeability. Our data identify IFN-I as an important component of the host immune defense that regulates two possible mechanisms involved in pneumococcal invasion, i. e. PAF receptor-mediated transcytosis and tight junction-dependent pericellular migration, ultimately limiting progression from a site-restricted lung infection to invasive, lethal disease.
In this study, we demonstrate that a multi-layer network of spiking neurons is capable of learning a complex foraging task involving pattern discrimination and decision making. The network consists of three layers: an input layer ( I ), a hidden layer ( H ), and an output layer ( O ). The hidden layer employs non-reward modulated spike time dependent plasticity ( STDP ), while the output layer employs reward modulated STDP. We show that the addition of a hidden layer with non-reward modulated STDP creates neurons that respond to specific combinations of inputs, allowing for basic classification of input patterns. When combined with a following layer of neurons implementing rewarded STDP, the network is able to learn discrimination between rewarding and punishing patterns without labeled training data. Synaptic noise allows for trial-and-error learning, enabling the network to identify goal-oriented strategies that are effective in solving the task. The study predicts that a set of properties of the spiking neuronal network with STDP is sufficient to solve a complex foraging task involving pattern classification and decision making.
The transcription factor ELF5 has been identified as a key driver of metastasis in luminal breast cancer. In the mouse mammary tumor virus-Polyoma Middle T ( MMTV-PyMT ) model of luminal breast cancer, induction of ELF5 increased leukocyte infiltration, angiogenesis, and blood vessel permeability in primary tumors, and greatly increased the size and number of lung metastases. ELF5 was found to recruit myeloid-derived suppressor cells ( MDSCs ) to the tumor, a group of immature neutrophils implicated in vasculogenesis and metastasis. Depletion of MDSCs using specific antibodies prevented ELF5 from driving vasculogenesis and metastasis. Expression signatures in luminal A breast cancers indicated that increased MDSC invasion and inflammation were correlated with ELF5 expression, and increased ELF5 immunohistochemical staining predicted much shorter metastasis–free and overall survival of luminal A patients. Thus, in the MMTV-PyMT mouse mammary model, increased ELF5 levels drive metastasis by co-opting the innate immune system. This finding implicates ELF5 as a defining factor in the acquisition of the key aspects of the lethal phenotype in luminal A breast cancer.
The interaction between chromatin loops plays an important role in determining the level of cell-to-cell variability in gene expression. These loops can be characterized by three factors: connection pattern, distance between regulatory elements, and communication form. In this study, we develop a stochastic model that maps these factors into a 4–state model of stochastic transcription. We first show that nested loops enhance mRNA expression and reduce expression noise, whereas alternating loops have the opposite effects. We then compare the effects of facilitated tracking and direct looping on gene expression and find that the former performs better than the latter in controlling mean expression and in tuning expression noise. However, this control or tuning is distance–dependent, remarkable for moderate loop lengths, and there is a limit loop length such that the difference in effect between the two communication forms almost disappears. Our analysis and results justify the facilitated chromatin–looping hypothesis.
Metabolic engineering increasingly relies on RNA technology to customly rewire the metabolism to maximize production. However, the development of pure riboregulators, which repress gene expression without the need for a coexpressed protein, is limited by the lack of clear design principles. Here, we present a framework for the de novo design of translation inhibiting RNAs ( tiRNAs ), which repress gene expression by blocking translation initiation. To develop this framework, we analyzed the influence of all features previously attributed to post-transcriptional gene modulation in a design of experiments ( DOE ). We identified 12 structural and thermodynamic features, of which six were retained after removing correlations from an in silico generated riboregulator library. From this library, 18 riboregulators were selected, constructed, and co-expressed with two target untranslated regions to link the translation inhibiting RNA features to functionality. The pure riboregulators showed repression down to 6% of the original protein expression levels, which could only be partially explained by an ordinary least squares regression model. A partial least squares regression model was constructed and validated to link the properties of translation inhibiting RNA riboregulators to gene repression. This approach enables a more reliable de novo forward engineering of effective pure riboregulators, which further expands the RNA toolbox for gene expression modulation.
Transient associations among neurons are thought to underlie memory and behavior. However, little is known about how such associations occur or how they can be identified. Here we show that when the composite activity of a local neuronal group exceeds a threshold, its activity pattern, as reflected in the local field potential ( LFP ), occurs without distortion at other cortex sites via fast synaptic transmission. These large-amplitude LFPs, which we call coherence potentials, extend up to hundreds of milliseconds and mark periods of loss-less spread of temporal and amplitude information much like action potentials at the single-cell level. Coherence potentials have an additional degree of freedom in the diversity of their waveforms, which provides a high-dimensional parameter for encoding information and allows identification of particular associations. Such nonlinear behavior is analogous to the spread of ideas and behaviors in social networks.
Nuclear size correlates with cell size, but the mechanism by which this scaling is achieved is not known. Here, we report the results of a systematic genetic screen of fission yeast gene deletion mutants to identify essential factors involved in nuclear size control. Our screen has identified 25 essential factors that alter nuclear size, and our analysis has implicated RNA processing and LINC complexes in nuclear size control. This study has revealed lower and more extreme higher nuclear size phenotypes and has identified global cellular processes and specific structural nuclear components important for nuclear size control. In fission yeast, nuclear volume increases steadily with cell volume during the cell cycle, maintaining a constant nuclear volume to cell volume ( N/C ) ratio throughout interphase. A screen of non-essential S. pombe gene deletion mutants implicated both bulk nucleocytoplasmic transport and regulation of lipid biosynthesis in nuclear size control. This suggests that both the regulation of global cellular processes, balancing levels of nucleoplasmic transcription and cytoplasmic translation, and regulation of the levels of specific structural components of the nucleus are important for nuclear size control. In multicellular organisms, the nucleocytoplasmic ratio varies between cell types, but is generally restricted to a narrow range for cells of each type. Nuclear volume correlates with cell volume across a wide range of cell sizes in both budding and fission yeasts.
Deep brain stimulation ( DBS ) is an effective treatment for a variety of neurological disorders, including Parkinson’s disease and essential tremor ( ET ). The success of closed-loop DBS depends on devising a stimulation strategy that minimizes oscillations in neural activity associated with symptoms of motor disorders. Our work focuses on the use of coupled oscillators to represent neurons in areas generating pathological oscillations. We use a reduced form of the Kuramoto model to analyse how a patient should respond to stimulation when neural oscillations have a given phase and amplitude, provided a number of conditions are satisfied. We predict that the best stimulation strategy should be phase specific but also that stimulation should have a greater effect if applied when the amplitude of brain oscillations is lower. We compare this prediction with data obtained from ET patients and propose a new hybrid strategy which effectively combines two of the closed-loop strategies found in the literature, namely phase-locked and adaptive DBS. Our predictions have been shown to generalize to other models and have been observed in a biologically realistic model of a neural circuit generating oscillations related to Parkinson’s disease.
Schistosomiasis is one of the most common endemic parasitic diseases, affecting over 230 million people worldwide. Schistosoma mansoni is the main causative agent of intestinal and hepatic schistosomiasis. Biomphalaria glabrata snails are the intermediate hosts of S. mansoni. To control schistosomiasis, it is essential to develop new molecular monitoring assays for large-scale screening of snails from transmission sites to detect the presence of schistosomes. We developed and evaluated a new loop-mediated isothermal amplification ( LAMP ) assay combined with a simple DNA extraction method to detect S. mansoni in experimentally infected Biomphalaria glabrata snails. The LAMP assay targets a sequence of S. mansoni ribosomal intergenic spacer 28S-18S rRNA and has a detection limit of 0. 1 fg of S. mansoni DNA at 63°C for 50 minutes. The assay was evaluated by examining S. mansoni DNA in snails exposed to miracidia at different times post-exposure. We detected S. mansoni DNA in all groups of snails by using a commercial DNA extraction kit or a simple heat NaOH extraction method. Our LAMP assay, named Biompha-LAMP, is specific, sensitive, rapid, and potentially adaptable as a cost-effective method for screening of intermediate hosts infected with S. mansoni in both individual snails and pooled samples. This assay could be suitable for large-scale field surveys for schistosomes control campaigns in endemic areas.
Dengue has been reported as a public health problem in Sri Lanka since the 1960s. The Ministry of Health is responsible for controlling dengue and other disease outbreaks. We estimated the public sector costs of dengue control activities and the direct costs of hospitalizations in Colombo, the most heavily urbanized district in Sri Lanka, during the epidemic year of 2012. The total cost of dengue control and reported hospitalizations was estimated at US$3. 45 million ( US$1. 50 per capita ) in Colombo district in 2012. Personnel costs accounted for the largest shares of the total costs of dengue control activities ( 79% ) and hospitalizations ( 46% ). The results indicated a per capita cost of US$0. 42 for dengue control activities. The average costs per hospitalization ranged between US$216–609 for pediatric cases and between US$196–866 for adult cases according to disease severity and treatment setting. This analysis is a first attempt to assess the economic burden of dengue response in the public health sector in Sri Lanka.
European Y-chromosomal lineages, which are passed down from father to son, have been the subject of intense debate regarding their origins. Previous studies suggested that haplogroup R1b1b2 ( R-M269 ), the most common European Y-chromosomal lineage, originated from Paleolithic hunter-gatherers. However, we show that the geographical distribution of its microsatellite diversity is best explained by its spread from a single source in the Near East via Anatolia during the Neolithic period. This suggests that most European Y chromosomes originate in the Neolithic expansion. The expansion of haplogroups R1b1b2, E1b1b1 ( E-M35 ), and J from the Near East during the Neolithic period makes Europe a prime example of how technological and cultural change is linked with the expansion of a Y-chromosomal lineage. This pattern contrasts with that shown by maternally inherited mitochondrial DNA, which suggests a unique role for males in the transition.
Motor learning is a complex process that can be influenced by a variety of factors, including movement variability. It has been suggested that movement variability can increase the speed of motor learning. However, we use computational modeling of motor adaptation to show that variability can have both positive and negative effects on learning. Our model simulations reveal that increased variability does not typically enable faster learning and sometimes even slows it down. In fact, it makes no computational sense for movement variability to generally increase learning speed. We performed computer simulations of error-based learning with a widely accepted optimal learner model and found that the relation between variability and learning rate varies widely in motor adaptation, possibly depending on which computational factor dominates the performance in a specific task. We also performed a meta-analysis of published papers and found that across a wide range of experiments, movement variability has no statistical relation with learning rate. We hypothesize that motor variability is correlated to learning rate in a task-specific way, depending on which factor predominantly affects task performance. Our results suggest that further research is needed to understand the relative importance of the factors involved in motor learning.
RelA, the most potent and ubiquitously expressed member of the NF-κB family, plays a crucial role in cellular immune and inflammatory responses, survival, and proliferation by regulating the transcription of various genes involved in these processes. RelA interacts with transcriptional co-activators such as CREB-binding protein ( CBP ) and its paralog p300 in addition to its cognate κB sites on the promoter/enhancer regions of DNA. The RelA:CBP/p300 complex is comprised of two components: the DNA binding domain of RelA interacts with the KIX domain of CBP/p300, and the transcriptional activation domain ( TAD ) of RelA binds to the TAZ1 domain of CBP/p300. A phosphorylation event of a well-conserved RelA ( Ser276 ) is prerequisite for the former interaction to occur. Here, we provide the solution structure of the latter component of the RelA:CBP complex by NMR spectroscopy. The structure reveals the folding of RelA–TA2 upon binding to TAZ1 through its well-conserved hydrophobic sites in a series of grooves on the TAZ1 surface. We further show how the RelA:CBP/p300 interaction controls the nuclear response of NF-κB through the negative feedback loop of the NF-κB pathway.
Gene set analysis is a statistical method used to analyze gene expression data by considering predefined groups of genes. However, this method has been mainly applied to cross-sectional studies. Here, we introduce time-course gene set analysis ( TcGSA ), an extension of gene set analysis to longitudinal data. TcGSA is based on random effects modeling with maximum likelihood estimates and can handle unbalanced data due to missing at random ( MAR ) measurements. It is a hypothesis-driven method that identifies a priori defined gene sets with significant expression variations over time, taking into account the potential heterogeneity of expression within gene sets. When comparing biological conditions, TcGSA indicates if the time patterns of gene sets significantly differ according to these conditions. We applied TcGSA to two real-life datasets: an HIV therapeutic vaccine trial ( DALIA-1 trial ) and a study on influenza and pneumococcal vaccines. TcGSA revealed a significant change in gene expression over time within 69 gene sets during vaccination in the DALIA-1 trial, while a standard univariate individual gene analysis and a standard Gene Set Enrichment Analysis ( GSEA ) for time series failed to detect any significant pattern change over time. In the second dataset, TcGSA allowed the identification of 4 gene sets linked with the influenza vaccine, although they were found to be associated with the pneumococcal vaccine only in previous analyses.
Plasmodium vivax is the second most prevalent malaria parasite after Plasmodium falciparum. However, the spatial epidemiology and geographical distribution of P. vivax are far less well understood than that of P. falciparum. Here, we present the first systematic effort to map the global endemicity of P. vivax. We updated our earlier estimate of the geographical limits of P. vivax transmission to 2010 and used a spatiotemporal Bayesian model-based geostatistical approach to estimate endemicity within every 5×5 km resolution grid square. The model incorporated data on Duffy negative phenotype frequency to suppress endemicity predictions, particularly in Africa. We used 9, 970 geopositioned P. vivax parasite rate ( PvPR ) surveys collected from 1985 to 2010. Endemicity was predicted within a relatively narrow range throughout the endemic world, with the point estimate rarely exceeding 7% PvPR1–99. The Americas contributed 22% of the global area at risk of P. vivax transmission, but high endemic areas were generally sparsely populated and the region contributed only 6% of the 2. 5 billion people at risk ( PAR ) globally. In Africa, Duffy negativity meant stable transmission was constrained to Madagascar and parts of the Horn, contributing 3. 5% of global PAR. Central Asia was home to 82% of global PAR with important high endemic areas coinciding with dense populations particularly in India and Myanmar.
Clumping factor B ( ClfB ) is a cell wall-anchored protein expressed by Staphylococcus aureus that has been shown to play an important role in the pathogenesis of skin and soft tissue infections ( SSTIs ). Previous studies have demonstrated that ClfB facilitates S. aureus nasal colonization by binding to host ligands such as loricrin and cytokeratin 10 in the anterior nares. However, the role of ClfB in SSTIs has not been investigated until now. This study reveals that ClfB is crucial in determining the structure and bacterial burden of skin abscesses early in infection, and that this is dependent on a specific interaction with loricrin expressed within the abscess tissue. ClfB exerts its effect in the early stage of infection and its interaction with loricrin appears to play a role during pathogenesis. Targeting ClfB using a model vaccine that induced both protective humoral and cellular responses leads to protection during S. aureus skin infection. This study therefore identifies ClfB as an important antigen for future SSTI vaccines.
To achieve the 90-90-90 goals set by UNAIDS, the number of new HIV infections needs to decrease to approximately 500, 000 by 2020. One of the ‘five pillars’ to achieve this goal is pre-exposure prophylaxis ( PrEP ). Currently, Truvada ( emtricitabine-tenofovir ) is the only medication approved for PrEP, but it is costly and requires individuals to adhere to a once-daily regimen. To improve PrEP, next-generation regimens, including long-acting formulations, are being investigated. However, pre-clinical testing often fails to translate into clinical efficacy, and quantifying prophylactic efficacy in the clinic is ethically problematic and requires long and large trials. To prioritize and help design PrEP regimens, tools are urgently needed that integrate pharmacological, viral, and host factors determining prophylactic efficacy. We developed an efficient and exact stochastic simulation approach to predict prophylactic efficacy, as an example for dolutegravir ( DTG ). Combining population pharmacokinetics of DTG with the stochastic framework, we predicted that plasma concentrations of 145. 18 and 722. 23nM prevent 50% and 90% sexual transmissions, respectively.
