In all of the species analyzed, the MAT loci are fused and a single HD gene is present in each mating type, similar to the organization in the pathogenic Cryptococci. However, the HD and P/R allele combinations in the Trichosporonales are different from those in the pathogenic Cryptococci. This suggests that fusion of the HD and P/R loci occurred independently in the Trichosporonales and pathogenic Cryptococci, supporting the hypothesis of convergent evolution towards fused MAT regions. The gene content and gene order within the fused MAT loci are highly conserved in the Trichosporonales, and there is no apparent suppression of recombination extending from the MAT loci to adjacent chromosomal regions.
Chagas disease, the most important vector-borne disease in Latin America, is caused by non-domiciliated vectors such as Triatoma dimidiata in the Yucatán Peninsula, Mexico. While regional initiatives have successfully controlled domiciliated vectors, non-domiciliated vectors remain responsible for a significant transmission risk. A mathematical model was developed to predict the temporal variations in abundance of non-domiciliated vectors inside houses. The model was fitted to two years of field data from the Yucatán Peninsula and accurately predicted field data in the absence and presence of insecticide spraying. Pyrethroid spraying was found to be effective when 50 mg/m2 were applied yearly within a two-month period matching the immigration season. However, larger doses or more frequent interventions did not improve the reduction in bug abundance, and it decreased drastically for different timing and lower frequencies of intervention. In contrast, the use of insect screens consistently reduced bug abundance proportionally to the reduction of the vector immigration rate. Our results suggest that control of non-domiciliated vectors can hardly be achieved by insecticide spraying, but that insect screens may offer an effective and sustainable alternative for the integrated control of neglected vector-borne diseases.
Feather patterning in avian skin relies on an integrated reaction-diffusion-taxis system that involves coupled fibroblast growth factor (FGF) and bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) signalling together with mesenchymal cell movement. This system is partly mechanochemical, with mechanical-chemical integration occurring through a positive feedback loop centred on FGF20, which induces cell aggregation, mechanically compressing the epidermis to rapidly intensify FGF20 expression. The travelling wave of feather formation is imposed by expanding expression of Ectodysplasin A ( EDA ), which initiates the expression of FGF20. The EDA wave spreads across a mesenchymal cell density gradient, triggering pattern formation by lowering the threshold of mesenchymal cells required to begin to form a feather bud. In flighted birds, the key role of the EDA/Ectodysplasin A receptor ( EDAR ) pathway in vertebrate skin patterning has been recast to activate this process in a quasi-1-dimensional manner, imposing highly ordered pattern formation. We find that the skin of chicken, duck, ostrich, and emu embryos have pronounced differences in their feather arrangements. The absence of FGF20 in the scaleless mutant leads to a failure of feather primordium formation, demonstrating a defining role for the epidermis in avian skin patterning.
Filoviruses, which include Ebola and Marburg viruses, can be present in the body fluids of infected people and survivors. A rapid systematic review of 33 studies found that filoviruses were detected in most types of body fluids, but not in every sample from every patient. The presence of filoviruses in body fluids was highly variable, and most body fluids taken more than 16 days after the onset of illness were usually negative. In the six studies that used both RT-PCR tests for filovirus RNA and tissue culture, RT-PCR tests gave positive results about 4 times more often than tissue culture. This suggests that most non-blood, RT-PCR positive samples are likely to be culture negative and possibly of low infectious risk. However, it is not apparent how relatively infectious many body fluids are during or after illness, even when culture-positive, because most test results come from more severe cases. Contact with blood and blood-stained body fluids remains the major risk for disease transmission because of the known high viral loads in blood.
Neuronal spike timing adaptation can be described with a fractional leaky integrate-and-fire model in which the exponent of the fractional derivative can vary from 0 to 1, with 1 representing the normal derivative. This model can reproduce upward and downward spike adaptations found experimentally in neocortical pyramidal cells and tectal neurons in vitro by varying only the fractional exponent. The model also produces spikes with longer first-spike latency and high inter-spike variability with power-law distribution. The fractional model generates reliable spike patterns in response to noisy input and reflects the temporal accumulated intrinsic membrane dynamics that affect the response of the neuron to external stimulation. In this context, the fractional order leaky integrate-and-fire model is a unified mathematical and computational framework that can be used to describe power-law dynamics and long-range correlations in neuronal activity. The fractional derivative can capture relationships between the distribution of conductances that can be complicated to model using explicit techniques. The emergent effect of these membrane correlations is a non-Markovian process that can be modeled with a fractional derivative, representing a non-local process in which the value of the variable is determined by integrating a temporal weighted voltage trace, also called the memory trace.
Paracoccidioides spp., the causative agent of paracoccidioidomycosis, is able to defend itself against reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) produced by host effector cells by expressing different antioxidant enzymes, including superoxide dismutases ( SODs ). In this study, we identified six SODs isoforms encoded by the Paracoccidioides genome and determined their expression levels in representative isolates of the phylogenetic lineages of Paracoccidioides spp. ( S1, PS2, PS3 and Pb01-like ). We found that PbSOD1 and PbSOD3 were similarly expressed during the yeast phase, while in mycelia PbSOD1 expression was slightly higher for S1, PS2 and P. lutzii isolates. Importantly, we observed an increased expression of PbSOD1 and PbSOD3 during the transition process, exposure to oxidative agents and interaction with phagocytic cells, suggesting that these proteins could assist in combating the superoxide radicals generated during the host-pathogen interaction. Using PbSOD1 and PbSOD3 knockdown strains we showed that these genes are involved in the response of the fungus against host effector cells, particularly the oxidative stress response, and in a mouse model of infection. Our data suggest that PbSOD3 expression is linked with a pronounced extracellular activity while PbSOD1 seems more related to intracellular requirements of the fungus.
Intrinsically disordered/unstructured proteins ( IDPs ) are extremely sensitive to proteolysis in vitro, but show no enhanced degradation rates in vivo. It has been suggested that IDPs are preferentially associated with chaperones in the cell, which may offer protection against degradation by proteases. To test this inference, we analyzed pairwise interaction data from high-throughput interaction studies to see if predicted disorder correlates with the tendency of chaperone binding by proteins. Our major finding is that disorder predicted by the IUPred algorithm actually shows negative correlation with chaperone binding in E. coli, S. cerevisiae, and metazoa species. This means that IDPs in the cell tend to avoid being bound to chaperones. The effect may be correlated with the presence of ordered domains, as observed with Pfam domains. We also found that binding of chaperones to disordered proteins is frequently accompanied by binding to other proteins, suggesting that IDPs use chaperones not for folding, but for assistance with association with other proteins.
The Drosophila genes spalt major ( salm ) and spalt-related ( salr ) encode Zn-finger transcription factors that are regulated by the Decapentaplegic ( Dpp ) signalling pathway in the wing imaginal disc. These transcription factors are required for cell survival and proliferation in the central region of the wing disc, as well as for vein patterning in the lateral regions. To identify direct Salm and Salr target genes, we compared the expression profile of salm/salr knockdown wing discs with control discs in microarray experiments. We found that candidate Salm/Salr target genes include both genes whose expression is turned off and genes whose expression is positively regulated by Salm/Salr. Furthermore, loss-of-function phenotypic analysis of these genes indicates that a fraction of them are required for wing growth and patterning. The identification and analysis of candidate Salm/Salr target genes opens a new avenue to reconstruct the genetic structure of the wing, linking the activity of the Dpp pathway to the development of this epithelial tissue. Our analysis uncovered an unsuspected complexity in the transcriptional landscape regulated by Salm/Salr, consisting of batteries of activated and repressed genes.
Protein phosphatase 1 ( PP1 ) is a critical regulator of centriole duplication in the C. elegans embryo. We have identified two PP1 orthologs, GSP-1 and GSP-2, and their regulators, I-2SZY-2 and SDS-22, as key regulators of ZYG-1 protein levels. ZYG-1 is the C. elegans homolog of Plk4 and is required for centriole duplication. Down-regulation of PP1 activity either directly or by mutation of szy-2 or sds-22 can rescue the loss of centriole duplication associated with a zyg-1 hypomorphic allele. This is achieved through an increase in ZYG-1 levels. Our data indicate that PP1 normally regulates ZYG-1 through a post-translational mechanism. While moderate inhibition of PP1 activity can restore centriole duplication to a zyg-1 mutant, strong inhibition of PP1 in a wild-type background leads to centriole amplification via the production of more than one daughter centriole. Our results thus define a new pathway that limits the number of daughter centrioles produced each cycle.
Visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) is a zoonotic disease that has been expanding rapidly in Brazil. In the municipality of Campinas, southeastern Brazil, the first autochthonous case of VL was reported in 2009 in a dog living in an upscale residential condominium located inside an environmentally protected area ( EPA ). Since then, disease transmission has remained restricted to dogs inhabiting two geographically contiguous condominiums within the EPA. We conducted a cross-sectional study to investigate Leishmania spp. infection in domestic dogs, wild mammals and sand flies using molecular tools and serological techniques. Canine seroprevalences of 1. 5% and 1. 2% were observed in 2013 and 2015, respectively. Six species of sand flies were identified as potential vectors or transmitters of Leishmania, including Lutzomyia longipalpis, the main vector of VL in Brazil. Natural infection by L. ( L. ) infantum was recorded in one sand fly and two wild mammals, a white-eared opossum ( Didelphis albiventris ), a known reservoir of VL. The proximity between infected animals, human residences and forest areas suggests that the EPA has an active VL focus. The risk of establishing and maintaining disease transmission foci in similar scenarios, i. e. wild areas that undergo environmental modifications, is evident.
Nasopharyngeal carcinoma ( NPC ) is a highly metastatic type of tumor that is frequently reported in South Asia. Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) is an oncogenic virus that is closely associated with NPC, and several viral proteins have been found to promote the migration and invasiveness of NPC cells. However, not all tumor tissues express these viral oncoproteins, suggesting that other mechanisms may contribute to the aggressive behavior of NPC tumor cells. In this study, we investigated the role of the EBV-encoded microRNA miR-BART9 in NPC. We found that miR-BART9 is highly expressed in all EBV-positive NPC tissues and promotes the migration and invasiveness of NPC cells in vitro and in vivo. Computational analysis revealed that miR-BART9 may target E-cadherin, a membrane protein that is pivotal in preserving cell-cell junctions and the epithelial phenotype. Through biochemical assays and functional rescue analysis, we confirmed that miR-BART9 specifically inhibits E-cadherin to induce a mesenchymal-like phenotype and promote the migration of NPC cells. These results indicated that miR-BART9 is a prometastatic viral miRNA and suggested that high levels of miR-BART9 in EBV-positive NPC cells may contribute to the aggressiveness of tumor cells. Our findings indicate that miR-BART9 is a significant viral contributor to the migratory and invasive capability of EBV-infected tumor cells.
We present ggsashimi, a command-line tool for visualizing splicing events across multiple samples. Given a genomic region, ggsashimi creates sashimi plots for individual RNA-seq experiments as well as aggregated plots for groups of experiments, a feature unique to this software. ggsashimi uses popular bioinformatics file formats, is annotation-independent, and allows the visualization of splicing events even for large genomic regions by scaling down the genomic segments between splice sites. It is freely available at https://github. com/guigolab/ggsashimi. ggsashimi is implemented in Python and internally generates R code for plotting. The tool was developed to address the limitations of current sashimi plot implementations, including the need for specialized annotation formats and the inability to visualize splicing events for large genomic regions. ggsashimi eliminates the need for specialized annotation formats and supports summarized views for hundreds of samples. We compared ggsashimi with the sashimi-plot built-in available within the Integrative Genomics Viewer ( IGV ) and found that ggsashimi provides enhanced visualization of splicing events by applying aggregation of samples belonging to the same group and shrinkage of intron lengths.
We propose a probabilistic model of cis-regulatory module ( CRM ) evolution that captures different modes of evolution of functional transcription factor binding sites ( TFBSs ) and background sequences. The model explicitly treats the special properties of CRM sequences, including substitutions and indels in background sequences, and constraints and turnover of TFBSs. We present a computational framework that uses this model to solve the problems of CRM alignment and prediction. Our alignment method is similar to existing methods of statistical alignment but uses conserved binding sites to improve alignment. Our CRM prediction method deals with the inherent uncertainties of binding site annotations and sequence alignment in a probabilistic framework. We demonstrate that our program is able to improve both alignment and prediction of CRM sequences over several state-of-the-art methods in both simulated and real data. We also use alignments produced by our program to study binding site conservation in genome-wide binding data of key transcription factors in the Drosophila blastoderm, with two intriguing results: ( i ) the factor-bound sequences are under strong evolutionary constraints even if their neighboring genes are not expressed in the blastoderm and ( ii ) binding sites in distal bound sequences tend to be more conserved than those in proximal regions. Our approach is implemented as software, EMMA ( Evolutionary Model-based cis-regulatory Module Analysis ), ready to be applied in a broad biological context.
The piRNA ( PIWI-interacting RNA ) pathway in Drosophila is known to silence transposons in the germline. However, it is unclear if this pathway has additional functions during development. Here we show that mutations in the Drosophila piRNA pathway genes, armi, aub, ago3, and rhi, lead to extensive fragmentation of the zygotic genome during the cleavage stage of embryonic divisions. Additionally, aub and armi show defects in telomere resolution during meiosis and the cleavage divisions; and mutations in lig-IV, which disrupt non-homologous end joining, suppress these fusions. By contrast, lig-IV mutations enhance chromosome fragmentation. Chromatin immunoprecipitation studies show that aub and armi mutations disrupt telomere binding of HOAP, which is a component of the telomere protection complex, and reduce expression of a subpopulation of 19- to 22-nt telomere-specific piRNAs. Mutations in rhi and ago3, by contrast, do not block HOAP binding or production of these piRNAs. These findings uncover genetically separable functions for the Drosophila piRNA pathway. The aub, armi, rhi, and ago3 genes silence transposons and maintain chromosome integrity during cleavage-stage embryonic divisions. However, the aub and armi genes have an additional function in assembly of the telomere protection complex.
In November 2007, a large hemorrhagic fever ( HF ) outbreak was reported in Bundibugyo District, Western Uganda. The outbreak was caused by a newly discovered ebolavirus species, named Bundibugyo ebolavirus, which is distantly related to the Côte d'Ivoire ebolavirus found in western Africa. The new virus was identified using a combination of classic laboratory methods and a recently developed random-primed pyrosequencing approach. The outbreak resulted in 149 suspected cases and 37 deaths, with a case fatality rate of approximately 36%. This is lower than the case fatality rates observed for Zaire ebolavirus ( 80–90% ) and Sudan ebolavirus ( 50–55% ). The new virus was detected in eight specimens using a broadly reactive ebolavirus antigen capture assay and an IgM capture assay based on Zaire ebolavirus reagents. The Uganda Virus Research Institute was able to quickly transfer antigen-capture, IgM, IgG, and real-time PCR assays to the affected area to facilitate rapid identification and isolation of Ebola cases for efficient control of the outbreak. The discovery of Bundibugyo ebolavirus has important implications for the design of future diagnostic assays to monitor Ebola HF disease in humans and animals, as well as ongoing efforts to develop effective antivirals and vaccines.
Alzheimer's disease ( AD ) is characterized by a high degree of heterogeneity in its progression patterns among patients. The Global Deterioration Scale ( GDS ) and Functional Assessment Staging procedure ( FAST ) describe seven stages in the course of AD from normal aging to severe dementia. However, there has been no quantitative study of the amount of heterogeneity in AD progression rates and their variances among patients for each stage of AD. To address this, we used statistical analysis to reconstruct GDS/FAST stage durations in a cohort of 648 AD patients with an average follow-up time of 4. 78 years. We found that the standard deviations for GDS/FAST stages 4–6 are comparable with their mean durations, indicating large variations in the AD progression among patients. This is consistent with the existence of several sub-groups of AD patients, which differ by their patterns of decline. Our findings are consistent with previous reports of high variability in the temporal progression of AD, with patients transiting the stages of the disease having time-courses ranging from months to decades. The underlying reasons for such variations remain largely uncertain, and it is plausible that a combination of many different factors is responsible for a high variability of AD progression rates.
Adult neurogenesis in the hippocampus has been shown to be a superior adaptation strategy compared to conventional synaptic plasticity and neuronal turnover in a simplified hippocampal memory model. Here, we extend this model to include realistic, spatially driven input firing patterns in the form of grid cells in the entorhinal cortex. We compare network performance across a sequence of spatial environments using three distinct adaptation strategies: conventional synaptic plasticity, neuronal turnover, and additive neurogenesis. We confirm that additive neurogenesis is a superior adaptation strategy when using realistic, spatially structured input patterns. We then show that a more biologically plausible neurogenesis rule that incorporates cell death and enhanced plasticity of new granule cells has an overall performance significantly better than any one of the three individual strategies operating alone. This adaptation rule can be tailored to maximise performance of the network when operating as either a short- or long-term memory store. We also examine the time course of adult neurogenesis over the lifetime of an animal raised under different hypothetical rearing conditions. Finally, we show that place cells can emerge and refine in a realistic manner in our model as a direct result of the sparsification performed by the dentate gyrus layer.
Trypanosoma brucei, the causative agent of African trypanosomiasis, expresses three virtually identical glutathione peroxidase ( Px ) -type enzymes in the cytosol ( Px I–II ) and mitochondrion ( Px III ). These enzymes detoxify lipid-derived hydroperoxides and can be replaced by α-tocopherol or Trolox. In the absence of cytosolic Px I and Px II, parasites undergo rapid lipid peroxidation and cell lysis. We show that the lysosome is the primary site of oxidative damage and that cytosolic trypanothione/tryparedoxin-dependent peroxidases protect the lysosome from iron-induced membrane peroxidation. This process is closely linked to the high endocytic rate and distinct iron acquisition mechanisms of the infective stage of T. brucei. The respective knockout of cytosolic Px I–II in the procyclic insect form resulted in cells that were fully viable in Trolox-free medium.
Melanocytes are pigment cells that produce eumelanin, the pigment responsible for skin, hair, and eye color. Melanosomes are organelles within melanocytes where eumelanin accumulates and is transferred to keratinocytes. Melanophilin ( PMEL ) is an amyloidogenic protein that forms intralumenal fibrils within early stage melanosomes. Here, we report that inactivation of the Pmel gene ( Pmel−/− ) results in spherical melanosomes in melanocytes from hair, skin, and eye tissues. This is in contrast to the rod-shaped melanosomes present in wild-type animals. The Pmel−/− mice are fully viable, fertile, and display no obvious developmental defects. However, inactivation of Pmel has only a mild effect on the coat color phenotype in four different genetic backgrounds, with the clearest effect in mice also carrying the brown/Tyrp1 mutation. This suggests that other previously described alleles in vertebrates with more striking effects on pigmentation are likely dominant-negative mutations. Despite the mild effect on visible pigmentation, inactivation of Pmel led to a substantial reduction in eumelanin content in hair, demonstrating that PMEL has a critical role in maintaining efficient epidermal pigmentation.
Dengue vector control remains the primary method to prevent dengue infections, and environmental interventions represent a sustainable and safe approach. A systematic review and meta-analysis were conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of three environmental methods for dengue vector control: ( a ) container covers with and without insecticides, ( b ) waste management and clean-up campaigns, and ( c ) elimination of breeding sites by rendering potential mosquito breeding sites unusable or by eliminating them. Nineteen studies were eligible for the systematic review, and sixteen contributed data to the meta-analysis. Study quality was highest for container covers with insecticides, followed by waste management without direct garbage collection and elimination of breeding places. Both the systematic review and meta-analysis showed a weak effect of the interventions on larval populations, with no obvious differences between the results of each individual method. For the meta-analysis, both container covers without insecticides and waste management with direct garbage collection achieved the strongest reductions for the Breteau index, whereas for the pupae per person index, container covers with insecticides and elimination of breeding places showed the strongest effects. Each of the investigated environmental methods showed some effectiveness in reducing larval and pupal densities of Aedes sp. mosquitoes. However, there is a need for more comparable high-quality studies at an adequate standard to strengthen this evidence.
Small molecules that inhibit protein synthesis by selectively stalling the ribosome have been identified as a new strategy for therapeutic development. One such compound, PF-06378503 ( PF8503 ), inhibits the translation of PCSK9, a major regulator of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, and has been shown to reduce LDL cholesterol in preclinical models. However, it is not known how PF8503 impacts the physiology of cells or ribosome quality control pathways. Here, we used a genome-wide CRISPRi screen to identify proteins and pathways that modulate cell growth in the presence of high doses of PF8503. The two most potent genetic modifiers of cell fitness in the presence of PF8503 were the ubiquitin binding protein ASCC2 and the helicase ASCC3, which bind to the ribosome and protect cells from toxic effects of high concentrations of the compound. In contrast, translation quality control proteins Pelota and HBS1L sensitize cells to PF8503 treatment. Genetic interaction experiments revealed that ASCC3 acts together with ASCC2, and functions downstream of HBS1L. These results identify new connections between ribosome quality control pathways and provide new insights into the selectivity of compounds that stall human translation, which will aid the development of next-generation selective translation stalling compounds to treat disease.
Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus ( KSHV ) promotes widespread destruction of cellular mRNAs to block host gene expression and evade immune detection. The viral protein SOX is responsible for this phenotype, but the mechanism of SOX-induced mRNA turnover has remained unknown. Here, we report that KSHV SOX stimulates cellular transcriptome turnover via a unique mechanism involving aberrant polyadenylation. Transcripts in SOX-expressing cells exhibit extended poly ( A ) polymerase II-generated poly ( A ) tails and polyadenylation-linked mRNA turnover. SOX-induced polyadenylation changes correlate with its RNA turnover function, and inhibition of poly ( A ) tail formation blocks SOX activity. Both nuclear and cytoplasmic poly ( A ) binding proteins are critical cellular cofactors for SOX function, the latter of which undergoes striking nuclear relocalization by SOX. SOX-induced mRNA turnover represents both a novel mechanism of host shutoff as well as a new model system to probe the regulation of poly ( A ) tail-stimulated mRNA turnover in mammalian cells.
Bacterial pathogens, such as Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, induce the production of type III interferon ( IFNλ ) in the lung. IFNλ signaling is mediated by the IL-28R receptor, which is abundantly expressed in the respiratory tract and is essential for host defense against some viral pathogens. However, the role of IFNλ in the innate immune response to bacterial pathogens is not well understood. In this study, we found that IFNλ is induced in the course of bacterial airway infection and results in downregulation of the microRNA miR-21, sustained expression of PDCD4, and increased proinflammatory cytokine production. Mice lacking the IFNλ receptor, IL-28R, or PDCD4 had significantly improved clearance of both airway pathogens and less pulmonary pathology associated with reduced levels of inflammatory cytokines. These data suggest that during bacterial pneumonia, IFNλ promotes inflammation by inhibiting miR-21 regulation of PDCD4. Furthermore, we found that IFNλ and PDCD4 are conserved elements in the response to airway pathogens and that the selective expression of IL-28R may be important in the specific cytokine responses evoked by different pathogens.
Sleeping sickness, also known as Human African Trypanosomiasis ( HAT ), is a serious disease caused by the parasite Trypanosoma brucei gambiense or T. brucei rhodesiense. In the Democratic Republic of Congo ( DRC ), we conducted a retrospective study on 781 patients with advanced stage-2 HAT admitted between 1989 and 2012. The study aimed to investigate mortality trends and risk factors for death in these patients. We found that death rates varied depending on the treatment regimen: 17. 2% in the standard melarsoprol schedule, 12. 1% in the short schedule melarsoprol, 5. 4% in the first-line eflornithine, 9. 1% in the NECT treatment regimen, and 36% in the group treated with eflornithine due to advanced disease. After adjusting for treatment, we found that clinical dysfunction on admission, high protidorachy, presence of parasites in the cerebrospinal fluid ( CSF ), and high cytorachy were significant predictors of death. A multivariable analysis within treatment groups retained clinical status on admission and high protidorachy as significant predictors of death. The study highlights the importance of clinical manifestations in assessing disease severity and the need for an objective test to assess HAT clinical severity.
Isolation profoundly affects social behavior in all animals, including humans, and has serious effects on health. Drosophila melanogaster is a powerful model to study small-scale, temporally-transient social behavior. However, longer-term analysis of large groups of flies is hampered by the lack of effective and reliable tools. We describe a novel framework for the accurate tracking of multiple flies, their behavior classification and a method to study social network dynamics. We use this framework to study the effects of isolation on social network dynamics and perform the first genome-wide gene expression analysis to correlate transcriptomic and behavioral changes upon social isolation in male Drosophila. Our results show strong and specific effects of isolation on social network dynamics, metabolic gene expression and animal physiology. We observe that isolation significantly and swiftly enhances individual and local social network parameters depicting near-neighbor relationships. We explore the genome-wide molecular correlates of these behavioral changes and find that whereas behavior changes throughout the six days of isolation, gene expression alterations occur largely on day one. These changes occur mostly in metabolic genes, and we verify the metabolic changes by showing an increase of lipid content in isolated flies.
Diarrheal disease is a major cause of morbidity and mortality, especially in resource-limited settings. The World Health Organization ( WHO ) has developed evidence-based guidelines for the management of diarrheal disease, but adherence to these guidelines is often suboptimal. We evaluated the impact of a smartphone adaptation of the WHO diarrheal disease management guidelines, including a modality for age-based weight estimation, in a clinical pilot study conducted in rural Bangladesh during the fall 2015 cholera season. The study consisted of a 6 week pre-intervention and 6 week intervention period with a 10-day post-discharge follow-up. A total of 841 patients were enrolled, and the primary outcome was adherence to guidelines for prescriptions of intravenous ( IV ) fluids, antibiotics, and zinc. During the intervention, the proportion of prescriptions for IV fluids decreased at the district and sub-district hospitals, and when IV fluids were prescribed, the volume better adhered to recommendations. The proportion of prescriptions for the recommended antibiotic azithromycin increased, while prescriptions for other antibiotics decreased, and zinc adherence increased. These findings demonstrate that a smartphone-based tool can improve guideline adherence and support the hypothesis that technology-enabled decision-support tools can promote evidence-based practice in resource-limited settings.
Host–parasite interactions are complex, making it difficult to predict how they will respond to climate change. In particular, host and parasite traits such as survival and virulence may have distinct temperature dependencies that must be integrated into models of disease dynamics. To address this, we fitted a mechanistic model of within-host parasite population dynamics to experimental data from Daphnia magna and its natural microsporidian parasite, Ordospora colligata. We used the metabolic theory of ecology ( MTE ) to specify model parameters comprising host aging and mortality, as well as parasite growth, virulence, and equilibrium abundance. The MTE-based model effectively predicted host survival, parasite growth, and the cost of infection across temperature while using less than half the parameters compared to modeling temperatures discretely. Our results serve as a proof of concept that linking simple metabolic models with a mechanistic host–parasite framework can be used to predict temperature responses of parasite population dynamics at the within-host level.
GABAergic interneurons play an important role in shaping the activity of excitatory pyramidal cells ( PCs ) by controlling the distribution of somatic and dendritic inhibition. Here, we propose a functional role for a network motif consisting of parvalbumin- ( PV ), somatostatin- ( SOM ) and vasoactive intestinal peptide ( VIP ) -expressing interneurons. PV interneurons mainly inhibit the perisomatic regions and basal dendrites of PCs, while SOM interneurons mainly target the apical dendrites of PCs and strongly inhibit other interneuron types. VIP interneurons mainly connect to the dendrite-targeting SOM neurons, thereby providing a disinhibitory circuit for the distal dendrite of PCs. We hypothesize that a subnetwork consisting of SOM and VIP neurons is optimized to efficiently control the PV/SOM-mediated redistribution of somatic and dendritic inhibition. Using a computational model, we show that the neuronal and synaptic properties of the circuit support this hypothesis. Moreover, we demonstrate that the SOM-VIP motif allows transient inputs to persistently switch the circuit between two processing modes, in which top-down inputs onto apical dendrites of PCs are either integrated or cancelled. We have shown that the microcircuit comprising excitatory PCs and inhibitory PV, SOM and VIP neurons can act as an amplifier that translates weak input onto VIP cells into large changes in the somato-dendritic distribution of inhibition onto PCs.
Microbiome-wide association studies compare microbial abundances between two groups of samples to link specific microbes to host phenotypes. However, abundance differences reflect not only direct associations with the phenotype, but also indirect effects due to microbial interactions. We found that microbial interactions can easily generate a large number of spurious associations that provide no mechanistic insight. Using techniques from statistical physics, we developed a method to remove indirect associations and applied it to the largest dataset on pediatric inflammatory bowel disease. Our method corrected the inflation of p-values in standard association tests and showed that only a small subset of associations is directly linked to the disease. Direct associations had a much higher accuracy in separating cases from controls and pointed to immunomodulation, butyrate production, and the brain-gut axis as important factors in the inflammatory bowel disease. We show that realistic microbial interactions produce a large number of spurious associations between particular members of the microbiome and phenotypes. These indirect associations can be removed by a simple procedure based on maximum entropy models from statistical physics.
Dengue and West Nile viruses are transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes. Wolbachia is a bacterium that can be used to block the replication and transmission of these viruses in mosquitoes. However, the effect of Wolbachia on pathogen replication and transmission is heavily influenced by the host-Wolbachia interaction and the model of infection. In this study, we compared the effect of Wolbachia in two infection models, stable transinfected and transiently infected mosquitoes, on the replication and transmission of two flaviviruses, DENV and WNV ( Kunjin strain ). Our results indicate that Wolbachia had similar blocking effects in both stable and transient models of infection. However, the magnitude of the blocking effect was significantly lower in mosquitoes transiently infected with Wolbachia. No evidence was found for any enhancement of either DENV or WNV ( Kunjin strain ) infection in Ae. aegypti infected with Wolbachia, supporting a role for Wolbachia as an effective and safe means for restricting transmission of these viruses.
Cilia are microtubule-based cellular organelles that mediate signal transduction and are composed of several distinct regions: the basal body, the transition zone ( TZ ), and the cilia shaft. In C. elegans, the cilia shafts of amphid channel and phasmid sensory cilia are subdivided into two regions defined by different microtubule ultrastructure: a proximal doublet-based region adjacent to the TZ, and a distal singlet-based region. We show that the InvC is conserved and distinct from the doublet region in C. elegans. The InvC and doublet region genes can be sorted into two modules—nphp-2+klp-11 and arl-13+unc-119—which are both antagonized by the hdac-6 deacetylase. The genes of this network modulate the sizes of the NPHP-2 InvC and ARL-13 doublet region. Glutamylation, a tubulin post-translational modification, is not required for ciliary targeting of InvC and doublet region components; rather, glutamylation is modulated by nphp-2, arl-13, and unc-119. We conclude that the C. elegans InvC is distinct from the doublet region, and that components in these two regions interact to regulate ciliogenesis via cilia placement, ciliary microtubule ultrastructure, and protein localization.
Myelination and remyelination in the central nervous system ( CNS ) require profound morphological changes in oligodendrocytes, the myelin-forming cells of the CNS. Here, we demonstrate that the basal polarity complex protein Scribble is required for CNS myelination and remyelination. Scribble is expressed throughout oligodendroglial development and is up-regulated in mature oligodendrocytes where it is localised to both developing and mature CNS myelin sheaths. Knockdown of Scribble expression in cultured oligodendroglia results in disrupted morphology and myelination initiation. In transgenic mice, conditional elimination of Scribble expression in myelinating glia results in disrupted myelin initiation during development and following focal demyelination, as well as disrupted longitudinal extension of the myelin sheath. At later stages of myelination, Scribble acts to negatively regulate myelin thickness and suppresses the extracellular signal-related kinase ( ERK ) /mitogen-activated protein kinase ( MAP ) kinase pathway. Furthermore, Scribble localises to non-compact myelin flanking the node of Ranvier where it is required for paranodal axo-glial adhesion.
Streptolysin S ( SLS ) is a bacteriocin-like haemolytic and cytotoxic virulence factor that plays a key role in the virulence of Group A Streptococcus ( GAS ), the causative agent of pharyngitis, impetigo, necrotizing fasciitis and streptococcal toxic shock syndrome. Although SLS was thought to be produced exclusively by GAS and related streptococci, evidence suggests that a number of Gram-positive pathogenic bacteria, including Listeria monocytogenes, Clostridium botulinum and Staphylococcus aureus, produce related peptides. Notably, the L. monocytogenes cluster is found exclusively among a subset of lineage I strains, which are responsible for the majority of outbreaks of listeriosis. Expression of these genes results in the production of a haemolytic and cytotoxic factor, designated Listeriolysin S ( LLS ), which contributes to the virulence of the pathogen as assessed by murine- and human polymorphonuclear neutrophil–based studies. In silico analysis reveals that gene clusters potentially encoding SLS-like factors are also present in some of the most notorious Gram-positive pathogens, including Listeria monocytogenes, Staphylococcus aureus and Clostridium botulinum.
Mycetoma is a chronic granulomatous inflammatory disease caused by fungi or bacteria. The disease is characterized by the formation of macroscopic structures called grains, which are surrounded by a massive inflammatory reaction. We investigated the expression of interleukin-17 ( IL-17 ) and matrix metalloprotease-9 ( MMP-9 ) in the mycetoma granuloma and their correlation with the severity of the disease. We obtained surgical biopsies from 100 patients with confirmed mycetoma and evaluated IL-17 and MMP-9 expression in the mycetoma granuloma using immunohistochemistry. We found that IL-17 was mainly expressed in Zones I and II, while MMP-9 was mainly expressed in Zones II and III. MMP-9 was more highly expressed in Actinomadura pelletierii and Streptomyces somaliensis biopsies compared to Madurella mycetomatis biopsies. We also found that MMP-9 levels were directly proportional to the levels of IL-17 ( p = 0. 001 ). The only significant association between MMP-9 and the patients’ characteristics was the disease duration ( p<0. 001 ). There was an insignificant correlation between the IL-17 levels and the patients’ demographic characteristics.
Molecular recognition by intrinsically disordered proteins ( IDPs ) commonly involves specific localized contacts and target-induced disorder to order transitions. However, some IDPs remain disordered in the bound state, a phenomenon coined “fuzziness”, characterized by IDP polyvalency, sequence-insensitivity and a dynamic ensemble of disordered bound-state conformations. The transcriptional activation domain of the Ewing's Sarcoma oncoprotein family ( EAD ) is an IDP that exhibits many features of fuzziness, with multiple EAD aromatic side chains driving molecular recognition. We hypothesized that EAD-target binding involves polycation-π contacts between a disordered EAD and basic residues on the target. Herein we evaluated the polycation-π hypothesis via functional and theoretical interrogation of EAD variants. The experimental effects of a range of EAD sequence variations, including aromatic number, aromatic density and charge perturbations, all support the cation-π model. Moreover, the activity trends observed are well captured by a coarse-grained EAD chain model and a corresponding analytical model based on interaction between EAD aromatics and surface cations of a generic globular target. EAD-target binding, in the context of pathological Ewing's Sarcoma oncoproteins, is thus seen to be driven by a balance between EAD conformational entropy and favorable EAD-target cation-π contacts. Such a highly versatile mode of molecular recognition offers a general conceptual framework for promiscuous target recognition by polyvalent IDPs.
Borrelia burgdorferi, the etiologic agent of Lyme disease, codes for two putative ATP-dependent Lon homologs, Lon-1 and Lon-2. Previous studies have shown that B. burgdorferi Lon-1 is upregulated transcriptionally by exposure to blood in vitro, while Lon-2 is not. We sought to clarify the functional roles of these two proteases in B. burgdorferi. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that Lon-1 and Lon-2 cluster separately due to differences in the NH2-terminal substrate binding domains, which may reflect differences in substrate specificity. Recombinant Lon-1 manifested properties of an ATP-dependent chaperone-protease in vitro but did not complement an E. coli Lon mutant, while Lon-2 corrected two characteristic Lon-mutant phenotypes. We conclude that B. burgdorferi Lon-1 and Lon-2 have distinct functional roles. Lon-2 functions in a manner consistent with canonical Lon, engaged in cellular homeostasis. Lon-1, by virtue of its blood induction, may be important in host adaptation from the arthropod to a warm-blooded host.
Antibody-dependent phagocytosis ( ADP ) is a function of the immune system that is thought to play a role in controlling viral infections. However, the role of ADP in HIV-1 infection is unknown. In this study, we sought to directly measure the ability of antibodies to mediate the internalization of HIV-1 virions by phagocytic cells. We found that HIV-1 virions are poor targets for phagocytosis by phagocytic effector cells, including THP-1 and U937 cells, as well as freshly isolated primary monocytes from healthy individuals. In contrast, HIV-1 virions coated with gp41 or gp41-derived peptides were efficiently phagocytosed by gp41-specific monoclonal antibodies. We found that a minimum of a few hundred gp41 molecules were needed for successful phagocytosis, which is similar to the number of envelope spikes on viruses that are readily phagocytosed. We also found that virion-decorated cells were targets for ADP or trogocytosis in the presence of HIV-specific antibodies. Our findings suggest that ADP of virions may not play a role in preventing HIV infection, likely due to the paucity of trimers and the consequent inability of virion-bound antibody to cross-link FcyRs on phagocytes. However, ADP or trogocytosis could play a role in clearing HIV-infected cells and cells on the verge of infection.
Hookworm infection is a highly endemic disease in many countries around the world, yet its global economic and health impact is not well known. We developed a computational simulation model to estimate the economic and health burden of hookworm infection in every country, WHO region, and globally in 2016 from the societal perspective. Using 2004 and 2010 disability weight estimates, we found that hookworm infection resulted in a total of 2, 126, 280 and 4, 087, 803 disability-adjusted life years ( DALYs ) worldwide, respectively. Excluding cognitive impairment outcomes, total productivity losses varied with the probability of anemia and calculation method used, ranging from $7. 5 billion to $138. 9 billion annually using gross national income per capita as a proxy for annual wages and ranging from $2. 4 billion to $43. 9 billion using minimum wage as a proxy for annual wages. The economic and health burden of hookworm infection exceeded published estimates for a number of diseases that have received more attention than hookworm, such as rotavirus. Even though hookworm is classified as a neglected tropical disease, certain large countries that are transitioning to higher income countries, such as Brazil and China, still face considerable hookworm burden.
Developmental hypoxia is a major cause of chronic neurodevelopmental impairments in humans, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. We have found that hypoxia disrupts pathfinding of forebrain neurons in zebrafish ( Danio rerio ), leading to errors in which commissural axons fail to cross the midline. The pathfinding defects result from activation of the hypoxia-inducible transcription factor ( hif1 ) pathway and are mimicked by chemical inducers of the hif1 pathway or by expression of constitutively active hif1α. We identified ephrinB2a as a target of hif1 pathway activation and showed that knock-down of ephrinB2a rescued the guidance errors. We also found that the receptor ephA4a is expressed in a pattern complementary to the misrouting axons. By targeting a constitutively active form of ephrinB2a to specific neurons, we found that ephrinB2a mediates the pathfinding errors via a reverse-signaling mechanism. Finally, we found that magnesium sulfate, used to improve neurodevelopmental outcomes in preterm births, protects against pathfinding errors by preventing upregulation of ephrinB2a. These results demonstrate that evolutionarily conserved genetic pathways regulate connectivity changes in the CNS in response to hypoxia, and they support a potential neuroprotective role for magnesium.
Paracoccidioidomycosis ( PCM ) is an endemic fungal disease of pulmonary origin caused by the thermally dimorphic fungus Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. The disease tends to run a chronic progressive course and disseminates to different sites including the lungs, oral mucous membranes, skin, adrenal glands, and reticuloendothelial system. In this study, we developed a mouse model of pulmonary PCM by intranasally inoculating male BALB/c mice with P. brasiliensis conidia. We used high resolution computed tomography ( HRCT ) and histopathology to evaluate and quantify pulmonary damage in the infected mice. HRCT was performed every four weeks to determine pulmonary lesions, quantify lung density, and reconstruct and quantify lung air structure. Histopathology and histomorphometry were also used to analyze lung lesions. Three different patterns of lesions were evidenced by HRCT and histopathology: nodular-diffuse, confluent, and pseudo-tumoral. The lesions were mainly located around the hilus and affected more frequently the left lung. HRCT showed that 80% of the Pb-infected mice had peri-bronchial consolidations associated with a significant increase in upper lung density at the 4th week post-challenge. Histopathology revealed that consolidation was equivalent to a confluent granulomatous reaction, while nodules corresponded to individual compact granulomas. Confluent granulomas formed pseudo-tumoral masses that obstructed large bronchi at the 16th week of infection. This study demonstrated that conventional HRCT is a useful tool for evaluation and quantification of pulmonary damage occurring in experimental mouse PCM.
Leishmania donovani is the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ), a disease endemic in many parts of the world. In areas where VL is common, a large number of infected individuals remain asymptomatic and are able to mount a protective cellular immune response. Here, we propose the use of an interferon-gamma release assay ( IFN-γRA ) as a novel marker for latent L. donovani infection. We modified a commercial IFN-γRA kit ( QuantiFERON ) to evaluate five different leishmania-specific antigens: H2B, H2B-PSA2, H2B-Lepp12, crude soluble antigen ( CSA ), and soluble leishmania antigen ( SLA ). We evaluated the assay on blood samples from active VL patients, cured VL patients, non-endemic healthy controls, and healthy endemic controls. The assay based on SLA had a sensitivity of 80% and specificity of 100%. Our findings suggest that a whole-blood SLA-based QuantiFERON assay can be used to measure the cell-mediated immune response in L. donovani infection. Interestingly, active VL patients showed a positive IFN-γ response to stimulation with leishmania antigen, which is contradictory to the conventional finding of a non-proliferative antigen-specific response of peripheral blood mononuclear cells.
Yersinia pseudotuberculosis is an enteric pathogen that can establish persistent infections in the gastrointestinal tract and cause relapsing enteritis and autoimmune disorders. In order to establish a persistent infection, the bacteria have to overcome the hostile environment of the intestinal epithelium and colonize the underlying gut-associated lymphatic tissues. Here, we show that the CNFY toxin, which enhances the translocation of the antiphagocytic Yop effectors, induces inflammatory responses that result in extensive tissue destruction, alteration of the intestinal microbiota, and bacterial clearance. However, suppression of CNFY function increases interferon-γ-mediated responses, comprising non-inflammatory antimicrobial activities and tolerogenesis. This process is accompanied by a preterm reprogramming of the pathogen's transcriptional response towards persistence, which gives the bacteria a fitness edge against host responses and facilitates establishment of a commensal-type lifestyle.
Magnaporthe oryzae is a fungal pathogen that causes rice blast, a devastating disease of rice. To successfully colonize and reproduce in host plants, pathogens need to overcome the innate defenses of the plant. We identified a novel pathogenicity gene in M. oryzae, named DES1, that regulates counter-defenses against host basal resistance. DES1 was identified by screening for pathogenicity-defective mutants in a T-DNA insertional mutant library. Bioinformatic analysis revealed that DES1 encodes a serine-rich protein with unknown biochemical properties, and its homologs are strictly conserved in filamentous Ascomycetes. Targeted gene deletion of DES1 had no apparent effect on developmental morphogenesis, including vegetative growth, conidial germination, appressorium formation, and appressorium-mediated penetration. However, the Δdes1 mutant was hypersensitive to exogenous oxidative stress and the activity and transcription level of extracellular enzymes, including peroxidases and laccases, were severely decreased in the mutant. In addition, ferrous ion leakage was observed in the Δdes1 mutant. In the interaction with a susceptible rice cultivar, rice cells inoculated with the Δdes1 mutant exhibited strong defense responses accompanied by brown granules in primary infected cells, the accumulation of reactive oxygen species ( ROS ), the generation of autofluorescent materials, and PR gene induction in neighboring tissues. The Δdes1 mutant displayed a significant reduction in infectious hyphal extension, which caused a decrease in pathogenicity.
Schistosomiasis is a major public health problem in Ghana, and mapping its distribution is essential to determine where control programs should operate. However, because it is impractical to assess infection prevalence in every potentially endemic community, model-based geostatistics ( MBG ) is increasingly being used to predict prevalence and determine intervention strategies. To assess the accuracy of MBG predictions for Schistosoma haematobium infection in Ghana, school surveys were evaluated at 79 sites to yield empiric prevalence values that could be compared with values derived from recently published MBG predictions. Based on these findings, schools were categorized according to WHO guidelines so that practical implications of any differences could be determined. Using the mean predicted values alone, 21 of the 25 empirically determined ‘high-risk’ schools requiring yearly praziquantel treatment would have been undertreated, and almost 20% of the remaining schools would have been treated despite empirically-determined absence of infection. This translates into 28% of the children in the 79 schools being undertreated and 12% receiving treatment in the absence of any demonstrated need.
Sperm guidance in the Caenorhabditis elegans ( C. elegans ) reproductive tract is a complex process that is not well understood. We have shown that C. elegans oocytes synthesize a heterogeneous mixture of F-series prostaglandins from polyunsaturated fatty acid ( PUFA ) precursors provided in yolk lipoprotein complexes. These prostaglandins function collectively and largely redundantly to promote sperm guidance. We have partially delineated the F-series prostaglandin metabolism pathways in C. elegans using genetics and electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry. Our results show that omega-6 and omega-3 PUFAs, including arachidonic and eicosapentaenoic acids, are converted into more than 10 structurally related F-series prostaglandins. Disruption of omega-3 PUFA synthesis triggers compensatory up-regulation of prostaglandins derived from omega-6 PUFAs. We have also identified a conserved cytochrome P450 enzyme that functions to inhibit prostaglandin metabolism, possibly by diverting their precursors into an alternative pathway. Our results support the model that multiple cyclooxygenase-independent prostaglandins function together to promote sperm motility important for fertilization.
Immunogenicity of biotherapeutics is a major barrier to their development and clinical application. To address this issue, we have developed algorithms that simultaneously optimize proteins for reduced T cell epitope content and high-level function. In silico analysis of this dual objective design space reveals that there is no single global optimum with respect to protein deimmunization, but rather a spectrum of designs that exhibit tradeoffs between immunogenic potential and molecular function. The leading edge of this design space is the Pareto frontier, i. e. the undominated variants for which no other single design exhibits better performance in both criteria. Here, we have designed, constructed, and experimentally evaluated the Pareto frontier of a therapeutic enzyme. Our results represent the first systematic and rigorous assessment of the functional penalty that must be paid for pursuing progressively more deimmunized biotherapeutic candidates. We have produced 18 of these Pareto optimal variants and subjected them to a rigorous experimental analysis of key performance parameters. The predictions underlying the design process correlated well with experimental analyses of protein function, and we observed that incremental deletion of T cell epitopes leads to a relative escalation in concomitant loss of function.
In Arabidopsis thaliana, we show that elevated temperature increases the frequency of meiotic crossovers ( COs ) via the Type I recombination pathway, which is sensitive to interference. COs are essential for proper chromosome segregation during meiosis, and their frequency and distribution are regulated by intrinsic and extrinsic factors. Here, we demonstrate that elevated temperature induces hyper-recombination in Arabidopsis and that the extra COs are derived from the Type I pathway. We also show that heat-induced COs are not the result of an increase in DNA double-strand breaks and that the hyper-recombinant phenotype is likely specific to thermal stress rather than a more generalized stress response. Our findings provide initial mechanistic insight into how environmental cues modulate plant meiotic recombination and may offer practical applications for plant breeding.
Biomedical research is becoming increasingly challenging to navigate due to the rapid growth of new results in the scientific literature, particularly in molecular biomedicine. To address this challenge, we describe a novel computational approach that combines reading, reasoning, and reporting methods to facilitate the analysis of experimental data. This approach, called the Hanalyzer, extracts information from external resources, tracks knowledge provenance, and combines all sources into a knowledge network that represents the integration of all sorts of relationships between a pair of genes. The knowledge network is then combined with a congruent network constructed from experimental data and visualized in a tool that facilitates the knowledge-based analysis of that data. We demonstrate the use of the Hanalyzer on a large-scale gene expression array dataset relevant to craniofacial development. The tool was critical in the creation of hypotheses regarding the roles of four genes never previously characterized as involved in craniofacial development; each of these hypotheses was validated by further experimental work. We also describe a Cytoscape plugin called CommonAttributes that allows the user to trace the provenance of links in the knowledge network and directly access the underlying data sources and publications.
Helminth parasites, such as Fasciola hepatica, secrete extracellular vesicles ( EVs ) that can be internalised by host immune cells to modulate host immunity. While the molecular cargo of EVs has been characterised in many parasites, little is known about the surface-exposed molecules that participate in ligand-receptor interactions with the host cell surface to initiate vesicle docking and subsequent internalisation. Using a membrane-impermeable biotin reagent to capture proteins displayed on the outer membrane surface of two EV sub-populations ( termed 15k and 120k EVs ) released by adult F. hepatica, we describe 380 surface proteins including virulence factors, membrane transport proteins and molecules involved in EV biogenesis/trafficking. Proteomics and immunohistochemical analysis show that the 120k EVs have an endosomal origin and may be released from the parasite via the protonephridial ( excretory ) system whilst the larger 15k EVs are released from the gastrodermal epithelial cells that line the fluke gut.
MicroRNAs ( miRNAs ) are small non-coding RNAs that play a crucial role in the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes. In plants, miRNAs are first transcribed as stem-loop primary miRNAs ( pri-miRNAs ) by RNA polymerase II, then cleaved into mature miRNAs by Dicer-like 1 ( DCL1 ). We identified a cycling DOF transcription factor, CDF2, which interacts with DCL1 and regulates the accumulation of a population of miRNAs. CDF2 binds directly to the promoters of some miRNAs and works as a transcription activator or repressor for these miRNA genes. In addition, CDF2 binds preferentially to the pri-miRNAs regulated by itself and affects DCL1-mediated processing of these pri-miRNAs. We found that CDF2 regulates a group of pri-miRNAs at both the transcriptional and post-transcriptional levels to maintain proper levels of their mature miRNAs. This regulation is important for plant development, as CDF2 works in the same pathway as miR156 or miR172 to control flowering. We also found that CDF2 regulates the expressions of components involved in miRNA biogenesis, which may affect miRNA biogenesis through regulating the levels of these components.
Folliculogenesis, the process by which follicles develop in the ovary to produce ova, is a highly regulated process that requires bidirectional communication between the oocyte and granulosa cells. This communication is essential for the proliferation of granulosa cells and the transition from primary to secondary follicles, a key phase of folliculogenesis. Here, we report that oocyte geranylgeranyl diphosphate ( GGPP ), a metabolic intermediate involved in protein geranylgeranylation, is required for the establishment of oocyte-granulosa cell communication. GGPP levels increase in oocytes during early follicular development and are synthesized from farnesyl diphosphate ( FPP ) by geranylgeranyl diphosphate synthase ( Ggpps ). Depletion of GGPP in oocytes impairs the proliferation of granulosa cells, the transition from primary to secondary follicles, and female fertility. Mechanistically, GGPP depletion inhibits Rho GTPase geranylgeranylation and its GTPase activity, which is responsible for the accumulation of cell junction proteins in the oocyte cytoplasm and the failure to maintain physical connection between oocyte and granulosa cells. GGPP depletion also blocks Rab27a geranylgeranylation, which might account for the impaired secretion of oocyte materials such as Gdf9. Moreover, GGPP administration restores the defects in oocyte-granulosa cell contact, granulosa cell proliferation, and primary-secondary follicle transition in Ggpps depletion mice.
RNA polymerase II ( Pol II ) is a eukaryotic enzyme that catalyzes the synthesis of messenger RNA using a DNA template. Despite extensive biochemical and biophysical studies, it has been unclear whether the “secondary channel” is the only route for nucleoside triphosphate ( NTP ) to reach the active site of the enzyme or if the “main channel” could be an alternative. We have built a structural model of Pol II with a complete transcription bubble based on multiple sources of existing structural data and used Molecular Dynamics ( MD ) simulations together with structural analysis to shed light on NTP entry pathways. We found that although both channels have enough space to allow NTP loading, the percentage of MD conformations containing enough space for NTP loading through the secondary channel is twice higher than that of the main channel. Further energetic study based on MD simulations with NTP loaded in the channels has revealed that the diffusion of the NTP through the main channel is greatly disfavored by electrostatic repulsion between the NTP and the highly negatively charged backbones of nucleotides in the non-template DNA strand. Taken together, our results suggest that the secondary channel is the major route for NTP entry during Pol II transcription.
Dengue is a major public health problem in Thailand and Cambodia, where children below 15 years of age are especially affected. Although dengue is a reportable disease in both countries, the degree to which reported incidence underrecognizes the true disease burden is unknown. We estimated the magnitude of dengue underrecognition and established more accurate disease burden estimates for these countries by utilizing dengue incidence calculated from laboratory-confirmed outpatient and inpatient cases in prospective cohort studies. Cohort studies were conducted among children aged <15 years by members of a dengue field site consortium over at least 2 dengue seasons. Age-group specific multiplication factors ( MFs ) were computed by comparing data from three cohort studies to national surveillance data in the same province and year. In Thailand, 14, 627 person-years of prospective cohort data were obtained in two provinces and 14, 493 person-years from one province in Cambodia. The average annual incidence of laboratory-confirmed dengue was 23/1, 000 and 25/1, 000 in Thailand, and 41/1, 000 in Cambodia. Calculated MFs in these provinces varied by age-group and year ( range 0. 4–29 ). Average age-group specific MFs were then applied to country-level reporting data and indicated that in Thailand a median 229, 886 ( range 210, 612–331, 236 ) dengue cases occurred annually during 2003–2007 and a median 111, 178 ( range 80, 452–357, 135 ) cases occurred in Cambodia in children <15 years of age.
Natural killer ( NK ) cells have been shown to directly contribute to the control of viral replication, but their role in orchestrating global antiviral defense is not well understood. To address this question, we examined the consequences of specific defects in the ability of NK cells to control mouse cytomegalovirus ( MCMV ) on antiviral CD8 T cell responses. By using congenic or mutant mice and wild-type versus genetically engineered viruses, we demonstrated that NK cells accelerate CD8 T cell responses against a viral infection in vivo. We identified the underlying mechanism as the ability of NK cells to limit IFN-α/β production to levels not immunosuppressive to the host. This is achieved through the early control of cytomegalovirus, which dramatically reduces the activation of plasmacytoid dendritic cells ( pDCs ) for cytokine production, preserves the conventional dendritic cell ( cDC ) compartment, and accelerates antiviral CD8 T cell responses. Conversely, exogenous IFN-α administration in resistant animals ablates cDCs and delays CD8 T cell activation in the face of NK cell control of viral replication. Our data demonstrate that the ability of NK cells to respond very early to cytomegalovirus infection critically contributes to balance the intensity of other innate immune responses, which dampens early immunopathology and promotes optimal initiation of antiviral CD8 T cell responses. Thus, the extent to which NK cell responses benefit the host goes beyond their direct antiviral effects and extends to the prevention of innate cytokine shock and to the promotion of adaptive immunity.
In Arabidopsis thaliana, we have identified four major rRNA gene variants that are differentially expressed in plants with a disrupted nucleolin-like protein gene ( Atnuc-L1 ). The most highly represented rRNA gene variant, which is normally inactive in wild-type plants, is reactivated in Atnuc-L1 mutants. We show that the accumulation of pre–rRNAs in Atnuc-L1 mutant plants originates from RNA Pol I transcription and is processed accurately. Moreover, we demonstrate that disruption of the AtNUC-L1 gene induces loss of symmetrical DNA methylation without affecting histone epigenetic marks at rRNA genes. These data reveal a novel mechanism for rRNA gene transcriptional regulation in which the nucleolin protein plays a major role in controlling active and repressed rRNA gene variants in Arabidopsis.
Human cytomegalovirus ( HCMV ) gene expression is regulated in part by histone deacetylation, a process mediated by the histone deacetylase 1 ( HDAC1 ) protein. In this study, we identified candidate HDAC1-interacting proteins in the context of HCMV infection, including the viral proteins pUL38 and pUL29/28. We confirmed the interaction of pUL38 and pUL29/28 with HDAC1 by reciprocal immunoprecipitations. HDAC1 is a component of the nucleosome remodeling and deacetylase protein complex ( NuRD ), and we found that pUL38 and pUL29/28 associated with the MTA2 component of NuRD. Knockdown of the NuRD constituents RBBP4 and CHD4 inhibited HCMV immediate-early RNA and viral DNA accumulation, suggesting that multiple components of the NuRD complex are needed for efficient HCMV replication. We also found that the growth of pUL29/28- or pUL38-deficient viruses could not be rescued by treating infected cells with the deacetylase inhibitor trichostatin A, and that transient expression of pUL29/28 enhanced activity of the HCMV major immediate-early promoter in a reporter assay. Importantly, induction of the major immediate-early reporter activity by pUL29/28 required functional NuRD components. We propose that pUL29/28 modifies the NuRD complex to stimulate the accumulation of immediate-early RNAs.
Respiratory Syncytial Virus ( RSV ) is the major cause of pneumonia among infants. Here we elucidated the antibody repertoire following primary RSV infection and traced its evolution through adolescence and adulthood. We used whole genome-fragment phage display libraries ( GFPDL ) expressing linear and conformational epitopes in the RSV fusion protein ( F ) and attachment protein ( G ) to determine the epitope repertoires of polyclonal serum antibodies from infants prior to and following RSV infection. We observed modest changes in the anti-F epitope repertoires post-RSV infection, while anti-G epitope repertoires revealed a 100-fold increase in the number of bound phages following infection. The G-reactive epitopes spanned the N- and C-terminus of the G ectodomain, along with increased reactivity to the central conserved domain ( CCD ). We also observed a steady increase in RSV-F epitope repertoires from young children to adults. Importantly, several novel epitopes were identified in pre-fusion F and an immunodominant epitope in the F-p27. In all age groups, antibody binding to pre-fusion F was 2–3 folds higher than to post-fusion form. For RSV-G, antibody responses were high following early RSV infection in children, but declined significantly in adults. This study identified unlinked evolution of anti-F and anti G responses and supportive evidence for immune pressure driven evolution of RSV-G.
Emodepside, a veterinary anthelmintic, has been reported to have macrofilaricidal effects against adult filarial nematodes. Here, we explore the mode of action of emodepside using adult Brugia malayi, one of the species that causes lymphatic filariasis. Our results show that emodepside potently inhibits motility by activating voltage-gated potassium channels and that the male is more sensitive than the female. We found that emodepside targets SLO-1 K channels and that the slo-1f isoform, found in muscles of males, is more sensitive to emodepside than the slo-1a isoform found in muscles of females. Selective RNAi of the slo-1a isoform in female worms increased emodepside potency. In silico modeling identified an emodepside binding pocket in the same RCK1 region of different species of filaria that is affected by these splice variations. Our observations show that emodepside has potent macrofilaricidal effects and alternative splicing in the RCK1 binding pocket affects potency. Therefore, the evaluation of potential sex-dependent effects of an anthelmintic compound is of importance to prevent any under-dosing of one or the other gender of nematodes once given to patients.
The Global Program to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis ( LF ) relies on rapid diagnostic tests ( RDTs ) to determine where annual mass drug administration for LF is required and when it can be stopped. These tests detect a Wuchereria bancrofti glycoprotein in the blood of infected persons via a carbohydrate moiety recognized by the monoclonal antibodies AD12 and DH6. 5. Loiasis cross-reactivity with LF RDTs has recently been recognized as a serious obstacle to LF elimination in loiasis-endemic areas. To better understand the nature of this cross-reactivity, we used the DH6. 5 antibody to immunoaffinity purify Loa loa antigens from the sera of individuals with a positive RDT due to loiasis. Immunoblot analysis revealed many circulating AD12/DH6. 5-reactive antigens, and proteomic analysis identified multiple L. loa proteins in LF RDT-positive loiasis sera. These included both secreted and somatic proteins, suggesting that they may be released by dying L. loa adult worms and/or microfilariae. Unlike the single high molecular weight W. bancrofti circulating filarial antigen that is reliably present in the blood of persons with bancroftian filariasis, reactive L. loa antigens appeared to be only transiently present in the blood of a subset of persons with loiasis. These key differences between the circulating antigens of W. bancrofti and L. loa can be used to differentiate positive results generated by both species and may lead to improved diagnostic tests for LF and loiasis.
Primary cilia are sensory and developmental signalling organelles extending from the surface of most eukaryotic cells. Defects in these organelles cause ciliopathies, such as retinitis pigmentosa and Bardet-Biedl syndrome ( BBS ), affecting multiple physiological and developmental processes. Cilia formation, maintenance and function depend on intraflagellar transport ( IFT ), which is driven by kinesin-2 and IFT-dynein motors and regulated by the Bardet-Biedl syndrome ( BBS ) cargo-adaptor protein complex, or BBSome. To identify new cilium-associated genes, we employed the nematode C. elegans, where ciliogenesis occurs within a short timespan during late embryogenesis. Using whole-organism RNA-Seq libraries, we discovered a signature expression profile highly enriched for transcripts of known ciliary proteins, including FAM-161, CCDC-104, and RPI-1. From a list of 185 candidate ciliary genes, we uncovered orthologues of human MAP9, YAP, CCDC149, and RAB28 as conserved cilium-associated components. Further analyses of C. elegans RAB-28, recently associated with autosomal-recessive cone-rod dystrophy, reveal that this small GTPase is exclusively expressed in ciliated neurons where it dynamically associates with IFT trains.
The brain represents the outside world by relying on neural responses to external stimuli. However, it is unclear how the brain can “decode” these responses without independent access to the stimuli. We investigate what can be learned about a space of stimuli using only the action potentials ( spikes ) of cells with stereotyped—but unknown—receptive fields. Using hippocampal place cells as a model system, we show that one can ( 1 ) extract global features of the environment and ( 2 ) construct an accurate representation of space, up to an overall scale factor, that can be used to track the animal's position. Unlike previous approaches to reconstructing position from place cell activity, this information is derived without knowing place fields or any other functions relating neural responses to position. We find that simply knowing which groups of cells fire together reveals a surprising amount of structure in the underlying stimulus space; this may enable the brain to construct its own internal representations. We find that the simple knowledge of which groups of hippocampal place cells fire together is enough to ( 1 ) extract global topological features of the environment, and ( 2 ) reconstruct an accurate geometric representation of physical space within which the animal's position can be faithfully tracked. We have shown that, in the case of hippocampal place cell activity, global topological features of a two-dimensional environment as well as an accurate geometric reconstruction of physical space—including the animal's position within it—can be inferred from spikes alone.
The NLRP3 inflammasome and IL-1β play a critical role in the pathogenesis of viral fulminant hepatitis ( FH ), a severe disease with high mortality resulting from excessive inflammation in the infected liver. We show that mice infected with murine hepatitis virus strain-3 ( MHV-3 ), a model for viral FH, manifest with severe disease and high mortality in association with a significant elevation in IL-1β expression in the serum and liver. In contrast, mice deficient in the IL-1β receptor ( IL-1R1-/- ) or treated with IL-1 receptor antagonist ( IL-1Ra ) show reductions in virus replication, disease progression, and mortality. Furthermore, IL-1R1 deficiency appears to debilitate virus-induced fibrinogen-like protein-2 ( FGL2 ) production in macrophages and CD45+Gr-1high neutrophil infiltration in the liver. We also show that mice deficient in p47phox, a nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate ( NADPH ) oxidase subunit that controls acute reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) production, present with reductions in NLRP3 inflammasome activation and subsequent IL-1β secretion during viral infection. Moreover, mice deficient in NLRP3 and Caspase-1, two essential components of the inflammasome complex, also show reduced IL-1β induction and ameliorated hepatitis.
Severe anemia and iron deficiency are important causes of morbidity in pre-school children in the tropics, and hookworm infections are considered a key factor. However, the contribution of the two main hookworm species, Ancylostoma duodenale ( A. duodenale ) and Necator americanus ( N. americanus ), to the disease burden is rarely assessed due to limitations of current diagnostic methods. In this study, we used multiplex real-time PCR to determine the prevalence of A. duodenale and N. americanus, as well as their contribution to severe anemia and bone marrow iron deficiency in pre-school children in Malawi. We found that 34. 1% of the severely anemic cases and 27. 0% of the non-severely anemic controls were infected with hookworms. The prevalence of A. duodenale and N. americanus was 26. 1% and 4. 9%, respectively. We also found that moderate and high load A. duodenale infections were positively associated with severe anemia ( adjusted odds ratio: 2. 49 ( 95%CI 1. 16–5. 33 ) and 9. 04 ( 95%CI 2. 52–32. 47 ), respectively ). Furthermore, iron deficiency was positively associated with the intensity of A. duodenale infection ( adjusted odds ratio: 3. 63 ( 95%CI 1. 18–11. 20 ) ; 16. 98 ( 95%CI 3. 88–74. 35 ) and 44. 91 ( 95%CI 5. 23–385. 77 ) for low, moderate and high load, respectively ).
In Caenorhabditis elegans, meiotic double-strand breaks ( DSBs ) can be repaired via homologous recombination ( HR ) or non-homologous end joining ( NHEJ ).
