HR is required for the formation of interhomolog crossovers ( COs ), which are necessary for meiotic chromosome segregation. Here, we identify COM-1, the homolog of CtIP/Sae2/Ctp1, as a crucial regulator of DSB repair pathway choice during C. elegans gametogenesis. COM-1 is not required for the initiation of meiotic DSB repair, but instead promotes meiotic recombination by counteracting the NHEJ complex Ku. In the absence of COM-1, germ cells repair meiotic DSBs via NHEJ, resulting in a lack of COs, extensive chromosomal aggregation, and near-complete embryonic lethality. In contrast, animals defective for both COM-1 and Ku are viable and proficient in CO formation. COM-1 acts parallel to the nuclease EXO-1 to promote interhomolog HR at the early pachytene stage of meiotic prophase and thereby safeguards timely CO formation. Our results uncover the potentially lethal properties of NHEJ during meiosis and identify a critical role for COM-1 in NHEJ inhibition and CO assurance in germ cells.
Melioidosis is a disease caused by the bacterium Burkholderia pseudomallei that results in high mortality rates in Southeast Asia and Northern Australia. To better understand the immune response to B. pseudomallei, a caprine melioidosis model of aerosol infection was developed. In this model, B. pseudomallei was delivered as an intratracheal aerosol to outbred goats. The humoral immune response was analyzed by ELISA and western blot, and the antigenic proteins were identified by mass spectrometry. The results showed a greater humoral response with IgG antibodies compared to IgM antibodies throughout the course of the infection. Pre-infection sera showed multiple immunogenic proteins already reactive for IgG and IgM in most of the goats. After infection, the number of IgG reactive proteins increased as the disease progressed. Early stage infection showed immune reaction to chaperone proteins GroEL, EF-Tu, and DnaK. These proteins were detected in all serum samples after infection, with GroEL immunogenically dominant. The heat shock protein GroEL1 elicited the strongest goat antibody immune response compared to other antigens.
Cyclin B1–cyclin-dependent kinase 1 ( Cdk1 ) activation is the key event that initiates mitotic entry, triggered by a positive feedback loop at the end of G2. Cyclin B1–Cdk1 is inactivated by the anaphase-promoting complex/cyclosome–dependent destruction of cyclin B1 in metaphase, allowing mitotic exit and cell division. We used a novel approach to determine the temporal development of cyclin B1–Cdk1 activity in single cells. By quantifying both dephosphorylation of Cdk1 and phosphorylation of the Cdk1 target anaphase-promoting complex/cyclosome 3, we found that cyclin B1–Cdk1 continues to be activated after centrosome separation. Importantly, we discovered that cytoplasmic cyclin B1–Cdk1 activity can be maintained even when cyclin B1 translocates to the nucleus in prophase. We propose that gradually increasing cyclin B1–Cdk1 activity after centrosome separation is critical to coordinate mitotic progression. In line with the observed kinetics, cyclin B1–Cdk1 levels required to enter mitosis are lower than the amount of cyclin B1–Cdk1 needed for mitotic progression. We propose that distinct thresholds for cyclin B1–Cdk1 activity exist that control successive mitotic events.
HIV-1 vaccines have failed to elicit neutralizing antibodies ( Nabs ) capable of protecting against diverse HIV-1 subtypes. HIV-1 superinfection ( SI ), defined as sequential infections from different source partners, has been shown to lead to a broader and more potent Nab response compared to single infection. However, it is unclear whether SI impacts epitope specificity and if the epitopes targeted after SI differ from those targeted after single infection. Here, we examined the post-SI Nab responses from 21 Kenyan women who were collectively exposed to subtypes A, C, and D and superinfected after a median time of ~1. 07 years following initial infection. Plasma samples were collected at a median time point ~2. 72 years post-SI. We focused on 4 main epitopes on the HIV-1 Envelope, including the CD4-binding site, a V1/V2 glycan, the N332 supersite in V3, and the membrane proximal external region of gp41. Using standard epitope mapping techniques, we found that SI did not induce a dominant Nab response to any one of these epitopes in the 21 women. Computational sera delineation analyses also suggested that 20 of the 21 superinfected women’s Nab responses could not be ascribed a single specificity with high confidence. These data are consistent with a model in which SI with diverse subtypes promotes the development of a broad polyclonal Nab response, and thus would provide support for vaccine designs using multivalent HIV immunogens to elicit a diverse repertoire of Nabs.
Congenital human cytomegalovirus ( HCMV ) infection is the leading cause of neurological disabilities in children worldwide. HCMV infection has been shown to dysregulate the Notch signaling pathway in human neural progenitor cells ( NPCs ). As an important downstream effector of Notch signaling, the transcriptional regulator Hairy and Enhancer of Split 1 ( Hes1 ) is essential for governing NPC fate and fetal brain development. In the present study, we report that HCMV infection downregulates Hes1 protein levels in infected NPCs. The HCMV 72-kDa immediate-early 1 protein ( IE1 ) is involved in Hes1 degradation by assembling a ubiquitination complex and promoting Hes1 ubiquitination as a potential E3 ubiquitin ligase, followed by proteasomal degradation of Hes1. A C-terminal acidic region in IE1, spanning amino acids 451 to 475, is required for IE1/Hes1 physical interaction and IE1-mediated Hes1 ubiquitination, but is dispensable for IE1/Sp100A interaction and ubiquitination. Our study suggests a novel mechanism linking downregulation of Hes1 protein to neurodevelopmental disorders caused by HCMV infection. Our findings also complement the current knowledge of herpesviruses by identifying IE1 as the first potential HCMV-encoded E3 ubiquitin ligase.
Divergence of transcription factor ( TF ) binding in Drosophila embryos has been studied in four species: Drosophila melanogaster, Drosophila yakuba, Drosophila pseudoobscura, and Drosophila virilis. Genome-wide binding of four TFs involved in early anterior-posterior patterning was measured by ChIP-seq, while gene expression was measured by mRNA-seq. We found that mRNA levels are much better conserved than individual TF binding events, and that changes in a gene's expression are poorly explained by changes in adjacent TF binding. However, highly bound sites, sites in regions bound by multiple factors, and sites near genes are conserved more frequently than other binding. This suggests that a considerable amount of TF binding is weakly or non-functional and not subject to purifying selection. We found that the genomic binding of A-P factors has changed extensively along the Drosophila tree with little effect on downstream gene expression. We identified two potential genetic sources of binding divergence: alterations of BCD, HB, GT, and KR-specific motifs drive a portion of the binding divergence. We also found that mRNA levels are highly correlated between species, with the correlation decaying with phylogenetic distance. Overall, we conclude that TF binding has diverged considerably within the Drosophila genus.
Lymphatic filariasis is a major public health problem in India, and the National Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis ( NPELF ) aims to eliminate the disease by 2015. Monitoring and evaluation of the programme requires impact assessments in at least one sentinel and one spot-check site in each implementation unit ( IU ). Transmission assessment surveys ( TAS ) that assess antigenaemia ( Ag ) in children in IUs that have completed at least five rounds of mass drug administration ( MDA ) each with >65% coverage and with microfilaria ( Mf ) levels <1% in the monitored sites form the basis for stopping the MDA. However, this multi-step process is likely to miss sites with transmission potential ( ‘hotspots’ ) and its statistical assumptions for sampling and threshold levels for decision-making have not been validated. We carried out a large-scale epidemiological study in two primary health centres in Thanjavur district, India, endemic for bancroftian filariasis that had undergone eight rounds of MDA. The prevalence and intensity of Mf ( per 60 µl blood ) were 0. 2% and 0. 004 respectively in the survey that covered >70% of 50, 363 population. The corresponding values for Ag were 2. 3% and 17. 3 Ag-units respectively. We identified 7 “residual” ( Mf-prevalence ≥1%, irrespective of Ag-status in children ) and 17 “transmission” ( at least one Ag-positive child born during the MDA period ) hotspots, and an Ag-prevalence of ∼1% in children ( equivalent to 0. 4% community Mf-prevalence ) as a possible threshold value for stopping MDA.
Dengue fever is a major public health problem in tropical and subtropical regions, and controlling its vector, the Aedes aegypti mosquito, is essential for disease prevention. One of the most commonly used methods for dengue vector control is the application of temephos, an organophosphate larvicide, to water storage containers. A systematic literature review was conducted to assess the community-effectiveness of temephos in controlling both vectors and dengue transmission when used as a single intervention or in combination with other interventions. The review included 27 studies, of which 11 were single intervention studies and 16 were combined intervention studies. The results showed that temephos was effective in reducing entomological indices when used as a single intervention, but this effect was not sustained when used in combination with other chemical vector control methods. The effectiveness of temephos was found to be dependent on several factors, including the quality of delivery, water turnover rate, type of water, and environmental factors such as organic debris, temperature, and exposure to sunlight. The review also identified several limitations of temephos use, including the need for reapplication, reluctance to apply temephos to drinking water, and operational aspects such as cost, supplies, time, and labour.
The Ctf19 kinetochore subcomplex and the replication fork-associated factor Csm3 play important roles in the establishment of cohesion at the pericentromere, the region surrounding the centromere where sister chromatids are held together by the cohesin complex. We show that the Ctf19 complex directs the increased association of cohesin with the pericentromere, while Csm3 is essential for ensuring the functionality of cohesin in holding sister centromeres together. The Ctf19 complex is required for the enhancement of cohesin in the pericentromere, and two of its peripheral proteins, Iml3 and Chl4, direct increased cohesin association with the pericentromeric region during both mitosis and meiosis. In the absence of Iml3 and Chl4, cohesin binding at the pericentromere is reduced and this has important implications for sister chromatid cohesion and chromosome segregation. Csm3 is crucial in ensuring the integrity of the replisome and its association with cohesion establishment factors as it traverses the protein-DNA barrier that surrounds the centromere. The resultant enhanced cohesion in the vicinity of the centromere safeguards the fidelity of chromosome segregation. We conclude that the Ctf19 complex plays similar roles in pericentromeric cohesion establishment during mitosis and meiosis, and that the Ctf19 complex and Csm3 are highly conserved.
Dengue fever/dengue hemorrhagic fever ( DF/DHF ) is a major public health concern in tropical and subtropical regions, with an estimated 100 million infections occurring annually. To better understand the underlying molecular mechanisms of dengue pathogenesis, we conducted a systems level characterization of serum metabolome and lipidome in adult patients with primary dengue infection at early febrile, defervescence, and convalescent stages. Using liquid chromatography- and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry, we identified 60 differential metabolites in a relatively large sample size of 44 patients and 50 healthy controls. The main metabolite classes were free fatty acids, acylcarnitines, phospholipids, and amino acids. Major perturbed metabolic pathways included fatty acid biosynthesis and β-oxidation, phospholipid catabolism, and the steroid hormone pathway. These changes suggest a multifactorial nature of human host responses to dengue infection. Analysis of phospholipids and sphingolipids revealed association with lymphocytes and platelets numbers, and these metabolites were significantly perturbed during the early stages and normalized to control levels at the convalescent stage, suggesting their potential utility as prognostic markers. Our findings provide a first detailed description of the metabolome changes in patients with acute dengue infection and offer a global molecular view that leads to the overall homeostatic physiological outcome of DF.
Neglected Tropical Diseases ( NTDs ) have been the focus of increasing research efforts in recent decades, yet significant gaps remain in diagnostic and treatment tools. To better understand the global research landscape, we conducted a bibliometric analysis of NTD research with a focus on German contributions. We searched the SCOPUS database for articles published between 2002 and 2012 with German author affiliations, and extracted metadata to build co-authorship research networks. We identified 1, 187 publications with at least one German author affiliation out of 26, 833 worldwide publications on 11 NTDs, and processed 972 publications for the five most published-about diseases. We extracted 4, 007 individual authors and 863 research institutions to construct co-author networks. The majority of co-authors outside Germany were from high-income countries and Brazil. We identified strong performers on an individual level by using classic parameters ( number of publications, h-index ) and social network analysis parameters ( betweenness centrality ). The research network characteristics varied strongly between diseases. We found that the share of NTD publications with German affiliations is approximately half of its share in other fields of medical research, underlining the need to identify barriers and expand Germany’s research activities towards NTDs.
Lymphatic filariasis (LF) and soil-transmitted helminths (STH) have been targeted in Haiti since 2000 with a strong mass drug administration (MDA) program led by the Ministry of Public Health and Population and its international partners. By 2012, Haiti’s neglected tropical disease (NTD) program had reached full national scale and was able to stop treatment for LF throughout almost all of the country. The success of the program can be attributed to several key programmatic elements, including strong community awareness through a multi-channel communication and education campaign facilitated by voluntary drug distributors, community trust of the drug distributors, directly observed treatment, easy access to treatment through numerous distribution posts and a strong drug supply chain, and quality data collection to guide MDA strategies. As a result, Haiti achieved 100% geographical coverage in 2012, with almost all districts consistently achieving well above the epidemiological coverage targets of 65% for LF and 75% for STH. The program also resulted in a significant reduction in the burden of infection, with 45 communes reaching the target threshold for stopping treatment for LF. By taking advantage of sustained international financial and technical support, Haiti’s MDA campaign resulted in steady progress toward LF elimination and the development of a strong foundation for ongoing STH control.
Alphaproteobacteria, such as Sinorhizobium meliloti, require tight regulation of the cell cycle to coordinate genome replication, segregation, and cell division. During symbiosis with legume hosts, S. meliloti undergoes cellular differentiation, resulting in massive genome amplification, cell branching and/or elongation, and loss of reproductive capacity. The master regulator CtrA has been shown to play a key role in cell cycle regulation in Caulobacter crescentus, and recent research suggests that CtrA may also be important in S. meliloti. Here, we investigated the regulation and function of CtrA in S. meliloti. We found that depletion of CtrA causes cell elongation, branching, and genome amplification, similar to that observed in nitrogen-fixing bacteroids. We also showed that the cell cycle regulated proteolytic degradation of CtrA is essential in S. meliloti, suggesting a possible mechanism of CtrA depletion in differentiated bacteroids. Using ChIP-Seq and gene expression microarray analysis, we found that S. meliloti CtrA regulates similar processes as C. crescentus CtrA, but does so through different target genes. For example, S. meliloti CtrA negatively regulates the septum-inhibiting Min system, whereas C. crescentus CtrA regulates the expression of the Fts complex to control the timing of cell division.
Francisella tularensis is a highly infectious bacterium that causes tularemia, a zoonotic disease. The ability of F. tularensis to multiply and survive in macrophages is critical for its virulence. We identified a mutant strain of the F. tularensis live vaccine strain ( LVS ) that was unable to multiply intracellularly and was strongly attenuated for virulence in mice. This mutant had a transposon insertion in a gene encoding a putative γ-glutamyl transpeptidase ( GGT ), which we designated ggt. We demonstrated that the GGT activity of F. tularensis allows the bacterium to utilize glutathione ( GSH ) and γ-glutamyl-cysteine dipeptide as sources of cysteine to ensure intracellular growth. GSH is the most abundant source of cysteine in the host cytosol, and the ability of F. tularensis to utilize it as a source of cysteine constitutes a paradigm of bacteria–host adaptation. We showed that the ggt mutant was unable to utilize GSH and γ-glutamyl-cysteine dipeptide as sources of cysteine, and that only the addition of free cysteine could compensate for its enzymatic deficiency. We also demonstrated that the F. tularensis GGT can functionally complement an E. coli GGT-deficient strain, and that it can cleave the γ-glutamyl-cysteine bond of the dipeptide γ-Glu-Leu.
Leishmania amazonensis and Leishmania major are protozoan parasites that alternate between flagellated promastigotes in insect vectors and amastigotes enclosed in phagolysosome-like Parasitophorous Vacuoles ( PVs ) of infected mammalian host cells. To determine if PVs of these Leishmania species can fuse with each other, mouse macrophages in culture were infected with non-fluorescent L. amazonensis amastigotes and then superinfected with fluorescent L. major amastigotes or promastigotes. Live imaging of infected cells revealed that PVs containing L. amazonensis amastigotes did not fuse with PVs containing L. major amastigotes. However, PVs containing L. major promastigotes did fuse with pre-established L. amazonensis PVs. In these chimeric vacuoles, L. major promastigotes remained motile and multiplied, but did not differentiate into amastigotes. In contrast, within their own PVs, L. major promastigotes differentiated into proliferating amastigotes. The results indicate that PVs, presumably customized by L. major amastigotes or promastigotes, differ in their ability to fuse with L. amazonensis PVs. Additionally, a species-specific PV was required for L. major destruction or differentiation.
Eliciting broadly neutralizing antibodies ( bnAbs ) is a major goal of HIV-1 vaccine research. Here, we show that native, membrane-expressed HIV-1 Env trimers can elicit potent neutralizing antibodies ( nAbs ) that bind to quaternary epitopes involving glycan-deficient patches proximal to the CD4 binding site. Two of eight rabbits immunized with virus-like particles ( VLPs ) expressing trimers and one of twenty rabbits immunized with DNA expressing native Env trimer, followed by a protein boost, developed unusually potent nAb titers. All three sera neutralized via quaternary epitopes and exploited natural gaps in the glycan defenses of the second conserved region of JR-FL gp120. Specifically, trimer VLP sera took advantage of the unusual absence of a glycan at residue 197, while the neutralizing DNA trimer serum targeted the absence of a glycan at residue 230, also proximal to the CD4 binding site. Our data show that strain-specific holes in the glycan fence can allow the development of tier 2 neutralizing antibodies to native spikes and that cross-neutralization can occur in the absence of protecting glycan.
Buruli ulcer ( BU ) is a chronic skin and subcutaneous tissue infection caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans. While antibiotic treatment with a combination of oral rifampicin and intramuscular streptomycin has improved treatment outcomes and reduced recurrence rates, wound healing is often delayed in a proportion of patients. To better understand the wound healing process in BU patients, we have performed immunohistochemical investigations on tissue specimens from eight BU patients with plaque lesions collected before, during and after antibiotic treatment. We have identified a set of markers that allow monitoring wound healing in BU lesions by immunohistochemistry. These markers include α-smooth muscle actin ( αSMA ) positive myofibroblasts, which produce extracellular matrix ( ECM ) proteins such as pro-collagen 1 and tenascin, and are found in fibronectin rich areas. We have also identified ribosomal protein S6 phosphorylation, a marker for translation initiation, in many cells, including myofibroblasts, after antibiotic treatment. In addition, we have observed dermal tissue remodeling by apoptosis and increased cytokeratin 16 ( CK16 ) expression in the epidermis in healing wounds. We have also found that the mTor pathway is activated in myofibroblasts emerging in antibiotic treated BU lesions, which may help to discriminate between healing and non-healing wounds in BU.
Mitochondrial trafficking in adult mammalian peripheral axons has been shown to increase in response to impulse conduction in vivo. Using confocal imaging of saphenous nerves in anaesthetised mice, we found that electrical stimulation of myelinated and unmyelinated axons increased anterograde and retrograde mitochondrial traffic in comparison to silent axons. Higher frequency conduction ( 50 Hz ) further increased anterograde, but not retrograde, mitochondrial traffic by rapidly increasing the number of mobile mitochondria and gradually increasing their velocity. Similarly, topical application of capsaicin to skin innervated by the saphenous nerve increased mitochondrial traffic in both myelinated and unmyelinated axons. We also found that stationary mitochondria in axons conducting at higher frequency became shorter, suggesting that they may supply additional mitochondria to the trafficking population through enhanced fission. Mitochondria recruited to the mobile population did not accumulate near Nodes of Ranvier, but continued to travel anterogradely. This pattern of mitochondrial redistribution suggests that the peripheral terminals of sensory axons represent sites of particularly high metabolic demand during physiological high frequency conduction.
Spondylocarpotarsal synostosis ( SCT ) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by loss of function mutations in Filamin B ( FLNB ) and characterized by progressive vertebral fusions. FLNB acts as a signaling scaffold by linking the actin cytoskeleton to signal transduction systems, yet the disease mechanisms for SCT remain unclear. Employing a Flnb knockout mouse, we found that the intervertebral discs ( IVDs ) of Flnb–/–mice undergo rapid and progressive degeneration during postnatal development as a result of abnormal cell fate changes in the IVD, particularly the annulus fibrosus ( AF ). The AF cells lose their typical fibroblast-like characteristics and acquire the molecular and phenotypic signature of hypertrophic chondrocytes. This change is characterized by hallmarks of endochondral-like ossification including alterations in collagen matrix, expression of Collagen X, increased apoptosis, and inappropriate ossification of the disc tissue. We show that conversion of the AF cells into chondrocytes is coincident with upregulated TGFβ signaling via Smad2/3 and BMP induced p38 signaling as well as sustained activation of canonical and noncanonical target genes p21 and Ctgf.
Viruses, such as the orthomyxovirus Thogoto virus ( THOV ), have evolved mechanisms to target host antiviral responses. Here, we report that THOV targets the general transcription factor TFIIB by re-localizing it into the cytoplasm, generating a TFIIB depleted nuclear environment. Our data indicate that TFIIB is critical for the de novo recruitment of RNA polymerase II ( Pol II ) to promoter start sites, but is not required for regulated gene expression from paused promoters. Since many immune genes require de novo recruitment of Pol II, targeting of TFIIB by THOV represents a mechanism to affect immune responses while keeping other cellular transcriptional activities intact. Thus, interference with TFIIB activity may be a favourable site for therapeutic intervention to control undesirable inflammation.
Human parvovirus B19 ( B19V ) infection of primary human erythroid progenitor cells ( EPCs ) causes cell cycle arrest at both late S-phase and G2-phase, characterized by a 4N DNA content. The viral NS1 protein is a key factor in disrupting the cell cycle, and a putative C-terminal transactivation domain ( TAD2 ) within NS1 is responsible for cell cycle arrest at G2-phase. The TAD2 domain plays a pivotal role in G2-phase arrest by activating the ATR ( ataxia-telangiectasia mutated and Rad3-related ) pathway. Activated ATR phosphorylates CDC25C at serine 216, which in turn inactivates the cyclin B/CDK1 complex without affecting nuclear import of the complex. The ATR-CHK1-CDC25C-CDK1 pathway is activated during B19V infection of EPCs, and ATR activation plays an important role in B19V infection-induced G2-phase arrest. Importantly, the DNA damage response ( DDR ) induced by B19V infection is essential for viral DNA replication but is dispensable for cell cycle arrest at G2-phase.
Dengue virus ( DENV ) is a medically important mosquito-borne virus that causes disease ranging from uncomplicated dengue to life-threatening dengue hemorrhagic fever ( DHF ) and dengue shock syndrome ( DSS ), characterized by endothelial dysfunction and vascular leakage. DENV nonstructural protein 1 ( NS1 ) has been shown to induce endothelial hyperpermeability in a systemic mouse model and human pulmonary endothelial cells, where it disrupts the endothelial glycocalyx-like layer. Here, we investigated the relative contributions of inflammatory mediators and endothelial cell-intrinsic pathways to DENV NS1-induced vascular leak. In vivo, we demonstrated that DENV NS1 triggers localized vascular leak in the dorsal dermis of wild-type C57BL/6 mice, but not in mice deficient in TLR4 or TNF-α receptor. In vitro, we showed that human dermal endothelial cells exposed to DENV NS1 do not produce inflammatory cytokines ( TNF-α, IL-6, IL-8 ) and that blocking these cytokines does not affect DENV NS1-induced endothelial hyperpermeability. Finally, we demonstrated that DENV NS1-induced vascular leak in vivo can be blocked using inhibitors targeting molecules involved in glycocalyx disruption. Taken together, these data indicate that DENV NS1-induced endothelial cell-intrinsic vascular leak is independent of inflammatory cytokines but dependent on endothelial glycocalyx components.
In budding yeast, the integrity of the septin ring at the bud neck is crucial for cytokinesis, proper spindle positioning, and the spindle position checkpoint ( SPOC ). The SPOC delays mitotic exit and cytokinesis as long as the anaphase spindle does not properly align with the division axis. Here, we show that the redundant ubiquitin-ligases Dma1 and Dma2 control septin dynamics and the SPOC by promoting the efficient recruitment of the Elm1 kinase to the bud neck. Indeed, dma1 dma2 mutant cells show reduced levels of Elm1 at the bud neck and Elm1-dependent activation of Kin4. Artificial recruitment of Elm1 to the bud neck of the same cells is sufficient to re-establish a normal septin ring, proper spindle positioning, and a proficient SPOC response in dma1 dma2 cells. Our data indicate that septin dynamics and SPOC function are intimately linked and support the idea that integrity of the bud neck is crucial for SPOC signalling. We propose a model for SPOC signalling where Dma1 and Dma2 regulate both septin ring dynamics and the SPOC by promoting the efficient recruitment of Elm1 to the bud neck.
Humans have evolved to survive and thrive in a wide range of environments, and natural selection has likely played a central role in this adaptation. Here, we present the results of a genome-wide scan for evidence of positive selection in response to climatic variation. We find that SNPs with the strongest correlations between allele frequencies and climate across 61 worldwide populations are enriched for genic and nonsynonymous SNPs relative to non-genic SNPs. Among the most extreme signals, several overlap with those from genome-wide association studies ( GWAS ), including SNPs associated with pigmentation and autoimmune diseases. We also find an enrichment of strong signals in gene sets related to UV radiation, infection and immunity, and cancer. Our results imply that adaptations to climate have shaped the spatial distribution of variation in humans.
Short QT syndrome ( SQTS ) is a genetically heterogeneous condition characterised by an abbreviated QT interval and an increased susceptibility to arrhythmia and sudden death. The N588K mutation in the rapid-delayed rectifier K+ current ( IKr ) -linked SQT1 variant of SQTS was studied using Markov chain ( MC ) and Hodgkin-Huxley ( HH ) models. MC models were found to be superior in reproducing experimental data regarding the effects of the N588K mutation on KCNH2-encoded hERG. These ionic channel models were incorporated into human ventricular action potential ( AP ) models and into 1D and 2D idealised and realistic transmural ventricular tissue simulations and into a 3D anatomical model. In single cell models, the N588K mutation abbreviated ventricular cell AP duration at 90% repolarization ( APD90 ) and decreased the maximal transmural voltage heterogeneity ( δV ) during APs. This resulted in decreased transmural heterogeneity of APD90 and of the effective refractory period ( ERP ). However, with consideration of transmural heterogeneity of IKr density in the intact tissue model, not only did the N588K mutation lead to QT-shortening and increases in T-wave amplitude, but δV was found to be augmented in some local regions of ventricle tissue, resulting in increased tissue vulnerability for uni-directional conduction block and predisposing to formation of re-entrant excitation waves. In 2D and 3D tissue models, the N588K mutation facilitated and maintained re-entrant excitation waves due to the reduced substrate size necessary for sustaining re-entry. Thus, in SQT1 the N588K-hERG mutation facilitates initiation and maintenance of ventricular re-entry, increasing the lifespan of re-entrant spiral waves and the stability of scroll waves in 3D tissue.
Collective motion in groups of animals is a complex phenomenon that has been studied using a variety of simple models. However, these models may lack important elements necessary to predict the motion of each individual in the collective. Here, we report that deep attention networks can obtain a model of collective behaviour that is simultaneously predictive and insightful thanks to an organization in modules. Using simulated trajectories, the model recovers the ground-truth interaction rule used to generate them, as well as the number of interacting neighbours. For experimental trajectories of large groups of 60-100 zebrafish, the model obtains that interactions between pairs can be described as repulsive, attractive or as alignment, but only when moving slowly. At high velocities, interactions correspond only to alignment or alignment mixed with repulsion at close distances. The model also shows that each zebrafish decides where to move by aggregating information from the group as a weighted average over neighbours. The weights are higher for neighbours that are close, in a collision path or moving faster in frontal and lateral locations. The network also extracts that the number of interacting individuals is dynamical and typically in the range 8–22, with 1–10 more important ones.
HIV-1 drug resistance is a major threat to the long-term efficacy of antiretroviral treatment, with around 10% of ART-naïve patients in Europe infected with drug-resistant HIV type 1. To understand the dynamics of transmitted drug resistance evolution, we employ a phylodynamic approach to quantify the fitness costs of major resistance mutations in the Swiss HIV cohort. We model the viral phylogeny using stochastic birth–death–sampling processes with two types: hosts infected by a sensitive or resistant strain. This allows us to quantify fitness cost as the ratio between transmission rates of hosts infected by drug resistant strains and transmission rates of hosts infected by drug sensitive strains. We consider eight resistance mutations in the reverse transcriptase and one mutation in the protease gene. Among the considered resistance mutations, only the 90M mutation in the protease gene was found to have significantly higher fitness than the drug sensitive strains. The following mutations associated with resistance to reverse transcriptase inhibitors were found to be less fit than the sensitive strains: 67N, 70R, 184V, 219Q. The remaining resistance mutations did not have a significant effect on viral transmissibility within the Swiss HIV cohort. These patterns are consistent with alternative measures of the fitness cost of resistance mutations. Overall, we have developed and validated a novel phylodynamic approach to estimate the transmission fitness cost of drug resistance mutations.
The Elongator complex, which includes the histone acetyl transferase Sin3/Elp3, has been shown to play a role in the modification of certain tRNAs. In this study, we show that the fission yeast Sin3/Elp3 is important for oxidative stress survival and that cells lacking Sin3/Elp3 are unable to modify the uridine wobble nucleoside of certain tRNAs. We also show that other tRNA modifying activities, such as Ctu1-Ctu2, are essential for normal tolerance to H2O2. We demonstrate that the main H2O2-dependent genes, including those coding for the transcription factors Atf1 and Pcr1, are highly expressed mRNAs containing a biased number of lysine-coding codons AAA versus AAG. These mRNAs are poorly translated after stress in cells lacking Sin3/Elp3 or Ctu2, whereas a mutated atf1 transcript with AAA-to-AAG lysine codons is efficiently translated in all strain backgrounds. Our results suggest that the lack of a functional Elongator complex results in stress phenotypes due to its contribution to tRNA modification and subsequent translation inefficiency of certain stress-induced, highly expressed mRNAs.
Nef is a viral protein required for sustained HIV-1 replication in vivo and is associated with accelerated progression to AIDS. In this study, we investigated the mechanism by which Nef increases the infectivity of cell-free virions. We found that Nef renders HIV-1 virions refractory to the broadly-neutralizing antibodies 2F5 and 4E10, which target the membrane-proximal external region ( MPER ) of TMgp41. Nef conferred as much as 50-fold resistance to 2F5 and 4E10, but had no effect on neutralization by MPER-specific nAb Z13e1, the peptide inhibitor T20, nor by a panel of nAbs and other reagents targeting gp120. This effect was observed with Nef from a diverse range of HIV-1 and SIV isolates, as well as with HIV-1 virions bearing Env from CCR5- and CXCR4-tropic viruses, clade B and C viruses, or primary isolates. We found that this activity requires Nef myristoylation, but is genetically separable from other Nef functions such as the ability to enhance virus infectivity and to downregulate CD4. We also found that glycosylated-Gag from MoMLV substituted for Nef in conferring resistance to 2F5 and 4E10, indicating that this activity is conserved in a retrovirus that does not encode Nef.
Bithynia siamensis goniomphalos, the snail intermediate host of the carcinogenic liver fluke Opisthorchis viverrini, is the leading cause of cholangiocarcinoma ( CCA ) in the Greater Mekong sub-region of Thailand. Despite the severe public health impact of Opisthorchis-induced CCA, little is known about the molecular interactions occurring between the parasite and its snail intermediate host. To address this knowledge gap, we characterized the transcriptomes of uninfected and O. viverrini-infected B. siamensis goniomphalos using high-throughput ( Illumina ) sequencing and extensive bioinformatic analyses. We identified 7, 655 differentially expressed genes ( DEGs ), associated with 43 distinct biological pathways, including immune defense mechanisms against parasites. Amongst the DEGs with immune functions, transcripts encoding distinct proteases displayed the highest down-regulation in Bithynia specimens infected by O. viverrini; conversely, transcription of genes encoding heat-shock proteins and actins was significantly up-regulated in parasite-infected snails when compared to the uninfected counterparts. The present study lays the foundation for functional studies of genes and gene products potentially involved in immune-molecular mechanisms implicated in the ability of the parasite to successfully colonize its snail intermediate host.
Complement receptor 1 ( CR1, CD35 ) has been identified as a mediator of Mycobacterium leprae entry into phagocytes. We investigated the role of CR1 polymorphisms, gene expression, and soluble CR1 ( sCR1 ) levels in susceptibility to leprosy in a case-control study with Brazilian leprosy patients. Nine CR1 polymorphisms were haplotyped in 213 leprosy patients ( 47% multibacillary ) and 297 controls. We found that individuals with the most common recombinant haplotype harboring rs3849266*T in intron 21 and rs3737002*T in exon 26 presented twice higher susceptibility to leprosy ( OR = 2. 43, p = 0. 017 ). Paucibacillary patients with these variants presented lower sCR1 levels, thus reducing the anti-inflammatory response ( p = 0. 040 and p = 0. 046, respectively ). Furthermore, the most ancient haplotype increased susceptibility to the multibacillary clinical form ( OR = 3. 04, p = 0. 01 ) and presented the intronic rs12034383*G allele, which was associated with higher gene expression ( p = 0. 043 ). We also found an inverse correlation between sCR1 levels and mannose-binding lectin ( initiator molecule of the lectin pathway of complement, recognized by CR1 ) ( R = -0. 52, p = 0. 007 ). Our results suggest a regulatory role for CR1 polymorphisms on mRNA and sCR1 levels, with haplotype-specific effects increasing susceptibility to leprosy, probably by enhancing parasite phagocytosis and inflammation.
Metabolomic profiling and whole-genome genetic association data have been used to comprehensively explore gene regulatory networks and investigate the effects of genetic variation at the molecular level. We investigated sex-specific differences of serum metabolite concentrations and their underlying genetic determination in more than 3, 300 independent individuals from the KORA F3 and F4 cohorts. Metabolite concentrations were measured for 131 metabolites, including amino acids, phosphatidylcholines, sphingomyelins, acylcarnitines, and C6-sugars. A linear regression approach revealed significant concentration differences between males and females for 102 out of 131 metabolites ( p-values<3. 8×10−4; Bonferroni-corrected threshold ). Furthermore, sex-specific genome-wide association studies ( GWAS ) showed genome-wide significant differences in beta-estimates for SNPs in the CPS1 locus ( carbamoyl-phosphate synthase 1, significance level: p<3. 8×10−10; Bonferroni-corrected threshold ) for glycine. Our study provides new important insights into sex-specific differences of cell regulatory processes and underscores that studies should consider sex-specific effects in design and interpretation.
Genome-scale metabolic networks are widely used for modeling genotype-phenotype relationships through flux simulations. However, the solution space for the metabolic flux state of the cell is typically very large, and optimization-based approaches are necessary for predicting the active metabolic state under specific environmental conditions. The objective function used in such optimization algorithms is directly linked with the biological hypothesis underlying the model and is therefore one of the most relevant parameters for successful modeling. We show that the resulting optimization problem is sensitive towards stoichiometry representation of the metabolic network, leading to different simulation results when using numerically different but biochemically equivalent stoichiometry representations. This sensitivity makes biological interpretation intrinsically subjective and ambiguous. We propose a new method, Minimization of Metabolites Balance ( MiMBl ), which decouples the artifacts of stoichiometry representation from the formulation of the desired objective functions. MiMBl casts objective functions using metabolite turnovers rather than fluxes. We demonstrate that the use of stoichiometry representation independent algorithms is fundamental for unambiguously linking modeling results with biological interpretation. MiMBl allowed us to expand the scope of metabolic modeling in elucidating the mechanistic basis of several genetic interactions in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.
Plague is a highly virulent, re-emerging disease in Madagascar, and the ecology of which has been scarcely studied in Africa. We investigated the relationship between plague distribution and the population genetic structure of the black rat, Rattus rattus, the main reservoir of plague in Madagascar. We conducted a comparative study of plague seroprevalence and genetic structure in rat populations from four geographic areas differing in topology, each covering about 150–200 km2 within the Madagascan plague focus. The seroprevalence levels in the rat populations mimicked those previously reported for humans. As expected, rat populations displayed a more marked genetic structure with increasing relief. However, the relationship between seroprevalence data and genetic structure differs between areas, suggesting that plague distribution is not related everywhere to the effective dispersal of rats. Genetic diversity estimates suggested that plague epizootics had only a weak impact on rat population sizes. In the highlands of Madagascar, plague dissemination cannot be accounted for solely by the effective dispersal of the reservoir. Human social activities may also be involved in spreading the disease in rat and human populations.
Schistosoma mansoni is a parasitic flatworm that causes schistosomiasis, a disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The parasite's ability to maintain a long-term intravascular residence in its definitive host is due in part to the presence of a heptalaminate-covered, syncytial tegument on its surface. This surface layer is composed of a number of proteins, including members of the Ly6 family, which have been shown to induce protective immunity in experimental models. Here, we present a comprehensive reanalysis of the Schistosoma mansoni Ly6 family ( SmLy6A-K ), which extends the number of members to eleven, including three novel proteins. We show that the previously identified vaccine candidate Sm29 ( renamed SmLy6D ) is a unique double uPAR/Ly6 domain-containing representative and that all SmLy6 proteins are likely to be cell surface-bound due to the presence of canonical cysteine residues, signal peptides, and GPI-anchor sites. Using a cohort of S. mansoni-infected Ugandan males, we report IgG1 ( as well as IgG4 and IgE ) responses against two surface-bound representatives ( SmLy6A and SmLy6B ) before and after praziquantel treatment. We show that IgG1 levels against SmLy6A and SmLy6B drop significantly after treatment, while IgG1 levels against a sub-surface tegumental antigen, SmTAL1, rise.
Cells in the Drosophila retina have well-defined morphologies that are attained during tissue morphogenesis. We present a computer simulation of the epithelial tissue in which the global interfacial energy between cells is minimized. Experimental data for both normal cells and mutant cells either lacking or misexpressing the adhesion protein N-cadherin can be explained by a simple model incorporating salient features of morphogenesis that include the timing of N-cadherin expression in cells and its temporal relationship to the remodeling of cell-cell contacts. The simulations reproduce the geometries of wild-type and mutant cells, distinguish features of cadherin dynamics, and emphasize the importance of adhesion protein biogenesis and its timing with respect to cell remodeling. The simulations also indicate that N-cadherin protein is recycled from inactive interfaces to active interfaces, thereby modulating adhesion strengths between cells. We demonstrate that the model describes characteristic shape changes in such mutants, distinguishes between different mechanisms of how cadherin levels are attained and controlled, and incorporates important dynamical features in morphogenesis, such as the temporal sequence of cadherin expression and cell-cell contact remodeling.
MT1-MMP is a membrane protease that plays a central role in the degradation of the extracellular matrix (ECM) at invadopodia, which are membrane protrusions involved in cancer cell invasion. Previous studies have suggested that a continuous supply of MT1-MMP is required for ECM degradation, but the turnover rate of MT1-MMP and its contribution to ECM degradation at invadopodia have not been clarified. To address this problem, we performed FRAP (Fluorescence Recovery after Photobleaching) experiments with fluorescence-tagged MT1-MMP on a single invadopodium and found that the recovery depended primarily on vesicle transport, with time constants of 26 s and 259 s. We then constructed a computational model based on the observed kinetics of the FRAP experiments and found that it successfully reproduced the experimental results. Next, we inhibited the vesicle transport both experimentally and in simulation, and found that it blocked ECM degradation. The degree of the reduction in ECM degradation depended on the degree of the reduction in the MT1-MMP turnover. Our experiments and simulations have established the role of the rapid turnover of MT1-MMP in ECM degradation at invadopodia, and our computational model provides a new tool to design and evaluate intervention strategies in cancer cell invasion.
HIV-1 drug resistance is a major obstacle in the treatment of HIV-1 infection. However, the process by which drug-resistant HIV-1 arises and spreads spatially within an infected individual is poorly understood. In this study, we used a simian immunodeficiency virus encoding HIV-1 reverse transcriptase ( RT-SHIVmne027 ) to examine how drug resistance spreads within a host and how spatial structure impacts its emergence. Four macaques were infected with RT-SHIVmne027 and treated with RT inhibitors to induce the emergence of two of the most prevalent drug resistance mutations ( DRMs ) in HIV-1 reverse transcriptase ( RT ) : K103N and M184V. We obtained comprehensive single-genome sequence ( SGS ) data from four different compartments ( peripheral blood mononuclear cells, lymph node, vagina, and gut ) and the blood at four time points. The resulting sequences reveal a dynamic system in which viral RNA ( vRNA ) rapidly acquires drug resistance concomitantly across compartments through multiple independent mutations. The blood and lymph nodes were found to be compartmentalized rarely, while both the blood and lymph node were more frequently different from mucosal tissues. Our findings suggest that even oft-sampled blood does not fully capture the viral dynamics in other parts of the body, especially the gut where vRNA turnover was faster than the plasma and vDNA retained fewer wild-type viruses than other sampled compartments.
Morphogenesis is the process by which tissues and organs acquire their shape and form. Here we show that feedback regulation of stem or progenitor cell self-renewal can lead to growth bistability or bimodality, with ultrasensitive switching between high and low ( or zero ) growth states. A necessary condition for such behavior is the simultaneous presence of saturable positive and negative feedback. We mathematically define the conditions required for underlying phenomena such as bistability, ultrasensitivity and spatial self-organization to arise in such systems, and show how they can be used to drive the formation of induced or spontaneous bulges, buds and fingers, which are the basic building blocks of many types of morphogenesis. We further show that even though such phenomena arise out of the opposing interactions of diffusible factors, the patterns that arise are not Turing patterns. We explore the effects of mixed feedback in final-state systems, which may be inherently better representations of lineage dynamics during morphogenesis, even in self-renewing tissues.
Myopia, or nearsightedness, is the most common eye disorder, resulting primarily from excess elongation of the eye. We report the largest ever genome-wide association study on myopia in Europeans, with 45, 771 participants. We performed a survival analysis on age of myopia onset and identified 22 significant associations, two of which are replications of earlier associations with refractive error. Ten of the 20 novel associations identified replicate in a separate cohort of 8, 323 participants who reported if they had developed myopia before age 10. These 22 associations explain 2. 9% of the variance in myopia age of onset and point toward a number of different mechanisms behind the development of myopia. One association is in the gene PRSS56, which has previously been linked to abnormally small eyes; one is in a gene that forms part of the extracellular matrix ( LAMA2 ) ; two are in or near genes involved in the regeneration of 11-cis-retinal ( RGR and RDH5 ) ; two are near genes known to be involved in the growth and guidance of retinal ganglion cells ( ZIC2, SFRP1 ) ; and five are in or near genes involved in neuronal signaling or development. These novel findings point toward multiple genetic factors involved in the development of myopia and suggest that complex interactions between extracellular matrix remodeling, neuronal development, and visual signals from the retina may underlie the development of myopia in humans.
The role of curvature feedback in the energetics and dynamics of lamprey swimming has been investigated using a closed-loop model. The lamprey has a central pattern generator ( CPG ) circuit that activates muscles for locomotion and adjusts the activity in response to sensory inputs from the environment. The CPG is modeled as chains of coupled oscillators, with pairs of phase oscillators representing the left and right sides of segments along the lamprey body. The emergent curvature of the body serves as an input to the CPG oscillators, closing the loop. We consider two forms of curvature-based feedback: directional feedback, which excites or inhibits oscillators on the same side depending on the sign of a chosen gain parameter, and magnitude feedback, which provides a symmetric excitatory or inhibitory effect to oscillators on both sides. We find that directional feedback does not affect beat frequency, but changes the duration of muscle activity. In contrast, magnitude feedback tends to increase beat frequency and reduces the energetic cost to the lamprey when the gain is high and positive. These results indicate that the same magnitude of curvature-based feedback on the CPG with different functional forms can cause distinct differences in swimming performance.
The global phylogeography of HIV is characterized by compartmentalized local epidemics dominated by a single subtype, indicating strong founder effects. We hypothesized that the competition of viral strains at the epidemic level may involve an advantage of the resident strain that was the first to colonize a population. To test this hypothesis, we developed a stochastic modelling framework to simulate HIV epidemics over dynamic contact networks. We simulated epidemics in which the second strain was introduced into a population where the first strain had established a steady-state epidemic, and assessed whether, and on what time scale, the second strain was able to spread in the population. We found that the spread of the second strain occurred on a much slower time scale compared with the initial expansion of the first strain. With strains of equal transmission efficiency, the second strain was unable to invade on a time scale relevant for the history of the HIV pandemic. To become dominant over a time scale of decades, the second strain needed a considerable ( >25% ) advantage in transmission efficiency over the resident strain. The inhibition effect was weaker if the second strain was introduced while the first strain was still in its growth phase. Our simulations confirmed a strong first comer advantage in the competition dynamics of HIV at the population level, which may explain the global phylogeography of the virus and may influence the future evolution of the pandemic.
The organization of muscle structure and function is a complex process that spans multiple length scales, from the sarcomere to the muscle bundle. We hypothesized that boundary conditions in the extracellular space potentiate the organization of cytoskeletal scaffolds for directed sarcomeregenesis. To test this hypothesis, we developed a quantitative model of how the cytoskeleton of neonatal rat ventricular myocytes organizes with respect to geometric cues in the extracellular matrix. Our results indicate that distinct cytoskeletal architectures arise from two temporally-ordered, organizational processes: the interaction between actin fibers, premyofibrils and focal adhesions, as well as cooperative alignment and parallel bundling of nascent myofibrils. Our results suggest that a hierarchy of mechanisms regulate the self-organization of the contractile cytoskeleton and that a positive feedback loop is responsible for initiating the break in symmetry, potentiated by extracellular boundary conditions, is required to polarize the contractile cytoskeleton. Our model recapitulates the elegant protein choreography of the sarcomere assembly, where an ensemble of proteins assembles repetitively along the length of the actin fiber template.
Wolbachia, a symbiotic bacterium, is being trialled as a biocontrol agent to reduce dengue transmission by infecting Aedes aegypti mosquitoes. We examined the invasive potential of the wMel Wolbachia strain in Brazilian Aedes aegypti mosquitoes in the laboratory and in the field. In the laboratory, we found that the wMel strain causes strong cytoplasmic incompatibility, a high rate of maternal transmission, and no evident detrimental effect on host fecundity or fertility. Next, we performed mark-release-recapture experiments in two areas of Rio de Janeiro where Wolbachia will be deployed in the future. We characterized the mosquito populations in relation to the socio-demographic conditions at these sites, and at three other future release areas. We constructed mathematical models using both the laboratory and field data, and used these to describe the influence of urban environmental conditions on the likelihood that the Wolbachia infection frequency could reach 100% following mosquito release. Our results suggest that the wMel strain of Wolbachia will likely be able to successfully invade five distinct field sites around the city of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. We found that the most important factor influencing the spread of Wolbachia at any of the field sites was local mosquito abundance. Our results provide a useful framework for the ongoing field-releases of wMel-infected Ae. aegypti in Brazil, and will likely hold similar utility for future releases of these mosquitoes in other similarly heterogeneous urban landscapes.
Histone H3 lysine 4 methylation ( H3K4me ) is an important epigenetic modification that regulates chromatin structure and gene expression in plants. In this work, we identified a JmjC domain-containing protein, JMJ703, as a histone lysine demethylase that specifically reverses all three forms of H3K4me in rice. Loss-of-function mutation of the JMJ703 gene affected stem elongation and plant growth, which may be related to increased expression of cytokinin oxidase ( CKX ) genes in the mutant. Analysis of the crystal structure of the catalytic core domain ( c-JMJ703 ) of the protein revealed a general structural similarity with mammalian and yeast JMJD2 proteins that are H3K9 and H3K36 demethylases. However, several specific features were observed in the structure of c-JMJ703. Key residues that interact with cofactors Fe ( II ) and N-oxalylglycine and the methylated H3K4 substrate peptide were identified and were shown to be essential for the demethylase activity in vivo. These residues are conserved in known H3K4 demethylases, suggesting that they may be involved in the specificity for H3K4 demethylation. Our results demonstrate that JMJ703 is essential for plant cell division and stem elongation and specifically demethylates mono-, di-, and trimethylated H3K4 in vivo and in vitro.
The HIV-1 capsid is a critical component of the virus that plays a central role in all infectious steps, from reverse transcription to integration site selection. The capsid is the target of multiple host cell and pharmacologic ligands, but the mechanistic basis for how these ligands influence infection is not well understood. Here we show that a multi-subunit interface formed exclusively within CA hexamers mediates binding to linear epitopes within cellular cofactors NUP153 and CPSF6, and is competed for by the antiretroviral compounds PF74 and BI-2. Each ligand is anchored via a shared phenylalanine-glycine ( FG ) motif to a pocket within the N-terminal domain of one monomer, and all but BI-2 also make essential interactions across the N-terminal domain: C-terminal domain ( NTD:CTD ) interface to a second monomer. Dissociation of hexamer into CA monomers prevents high affinity interaction with CPSF6 and PF74, and abolishes binding to NUP153. The second interface is conformationally dynamic, but binding of NUP153 or CPSF6 peptides is accommodated by only one conformation. NUP153 and CPSF6 have overlapping binding sites, but each makes unique CA interactions that, when mutated selectively, perturb cofactor dependency. These results reveal that multiple ligands share an overlapping interface in HIV-1 capsid that is lost upon viral disassembly.
Dengue, yellow fever, and chikungunya viruses are transmitted by the mosquito Aedes aegypti, which has a large and poorly assembled genome. The current genome assembly contains 4, 758 scaffolds, few of which have been assigned to a chromosome. To improve the genome assembly, we scored a large number of SNPs in recombinant progeny from a cross between two strains of Ae. aegypti and generated a genetic map. This revealed a high rate of misassemblies in the current genome, where sequences from different chromosomes were found on the same scaffold. We corrected these errors and were able to assign 60% of the genome sequence to chromosomes and approximately order the scaffolds along the chromosome. We found that there are large regions of suppressed recombination around the centromeres, which can extend to as much as 47% of the chromosome. To illustrate the utility of this new genome assembly, we mapped a gene that makes Ae. aegypti resistant to the human parasite Brugia malayi, and generated a list of candidate genes that could be affecting the trait.
Aedes aegypti, the primary vector of dengue, chikungunya, and yellow fever viruses, is a major target of vector control programs in tropical countries. Despite the availability of new trapping devices, most mosquito surveillance programs are still based on traditional household larval surveys. We report the results of a multicentric entomological survey using four types of traps ( ovitrap, MosquiTRAP, Adultrap, and BioGent-Sentinel ) to compare the entomological indices generated by these different surveillance tools in terms of their sensitivity to detect mosquito density variation. The study was conducted in five mid-sized cities representing variations of tropical climate regimens. Surveillance schemes using traps for adults or eggs were applied monthly to three 1 km2 areas per city. Simultaneously, larval surveys were performed. The House Index was consistently low in most cities, with median always 0. Traps rarely produced null indices, pointing to their greater sensitivity in detecting the presence of Ae. aegypti in comparison to the larval survey. All investigated traps performed better than the House Index in measuring the seasonal variation in mosquito abundance and should be considered as complements or alternatives to larval surveys. Ideally, traps should be used in combination with vector control strategies to improve our response to dengue and other diseases transmitted by Ae. aegypti.
APOBEC3G ( A3G ) is a potent inhibitor of retroviruses, including HIV-1, and is able to deaminate cytidines to uridines in single-stranded DNA replication intermediates. A3G contains two canonical cytidine deaminase domains ( CDAs ), of which only the C-terminal one is known to mediate cytidine deamination. By exploiting the crystal structure of the related tetrameric APOBEC2 ( A2 ) protein, we identified residues within A3G that have the potential to mediate oligomerization of the protein. Using yeast two-hybrid assays, co-immunoprecipitation, and chemical crosslinking, we show that tyrosine-124 and tryptophan-127 within the enzymatically inactive N-terminal CDA domain mediate A3G oligomerization, and this coincides with packaging into HIV-1 virions. In addition to the importance of specific residues in A3G, oligomerization is also shown to be RNA-dependent. Homology modelling of A3G onto the A2 template structure indicates an accumulation of positive charge in a pocket formed by a putative dimer interface. Substitution of arginine residues at positions 24, 30, and 136 within this pocket resulted in reduced virus inhibition, virion packaging, and oligomerization. We propose that occupation of the positively charged pocket by RNA promotes A3G oligomerization, packaging into virions and antiviral function.
The bric-a-brac locus in Drosophila melanogaster is a major-effect quantitative trait locus (QTL) responsible for variation in cuticular pigmentation. Here, we show that natural bric-a-brac alleles with large effects on cuticular pigmentation reflect a cumulative impact of polymorphisms that affect three functional regions: a promoter, a tissue-specific enhancer, and a Polycomb response element. These polymorphisms modulate transcription at the cis-regulatory level, as confirmed by analysis of allele-specific expression at the bric-a-brac locus. Our results establish that a single QTL can act through a confluence of multiple molecular mechanisms and that sequence variation in regions flanking experimentally validated functional elements can have significant quantitative effects on transcriptional activity and phenotype. The bric-a-brac locus is composed of two anciently duplicated paralogs, bab1 and bab2, which are involved in patterning the adult abdomen, legs, and ovaries. Evolutionary changes in bric-a-brac regulation have played a central role in the macroevolutionary diversification of Drosophila color patterns.
Streptococcus pneumoniae ( pneumococcus ) is a persistent cause of invasive and mucosal disease in humans despite the widespread use of antibiotics and vaccines. Its ability to adapt through the uptake and incorporation of new genetic material from the surrounding microbial community is a key factor in its persistence. This adaptation is controlled by a tightly regulated quorum sensing system that is triggered by the extracellular accumulation of competence stimulating peptide ( CSP ). We demonstrate that CSP can stimulate the production of a diverse array of blp bacteriocins. This cross stimulation occurs through increased production and secretion of the bacteriocin pheromone, BlpC, and requires a functional competence regulatory system. We show that a highly conserved motif in the promoter of the operon encoding BlpC and its transporter mediates the upregulation by CSP. The accumulation of BlpC following CSP stimulation results in augmented activation of the entire blp locus. Using biofilm-grown organisms as a model for competition and genetic exchange on the mucosal surface, we demonstrate that DNA exchange is enhanced by bacteriocin secretion, suggesting that co-stimulation of bacteriocins with competence provides an adaptive advantage. The blp and com regulatory pathways are believed to have diverged and specialized in a remote ancestor of pneumococcus, but have maintained a regulatory connection that promotes competition and adaptation by targeting for lysis a wide array of potential competitors while simultaneously providing the means for incorporation of their DNA.
Poliovirus IRES-mediated translation is dependent on the recruitment of ribosomes to the viral RNA. The interaction between cellular proteins PCBP2 and SRp20 has been shown to function synergistically in viral translation. Here, we demonstrate that SRp20 dramatically re-localizes from the nucleus to the cytoplasm of poliovirus-infected neuroblastoma cells during the course of infection. SRp20 partially co-localizes with PCBP2 in the cytoplasm of infected cells and is associated with PCBP2 bound to poliovirus RNA, indicating that this interaction occurs on the viral RNA. We generated a mutated version of SRp20 lacking the RNA recognition motif ( SRp20ΔRRM ) and found that this protein is localized similar to the full length SRp20 and partially co-localizes with PCBP2 during poliovirus infection. Expression of this mutated version of SRp20 results in a ∼100 fold decrease in virus yield for poliovirus when compared to expression of wild type SRp20, possibly via a dominant negative effect. These results are consistent with a model in which SRp20 interacts with PCBP2 bound to the viral RNA, and this interaction functions to recruit ribosomes to the viral RNA in a direct or indirect manner. The co-sedimentation of SRp20 and PCBP2 with 40S ribosomal subunits in extracts from poliovirus-infected cells is consistent with these proteins functioning in translation initiation complex formation for poliovirus IRES-mediated translation.
The neural crest ( NC ) is a population of embryonic stem cells that gives rise to various cell types, including neurons, glia, and melanocytes. Mutations in genes and pathways regulating NC development lead to neurocristopathies, a spectrum of human developmental disorders. To identify molecular pathways regulating NC development, we established an N-ethyl-N-nitrosourea ( ENU ) mutagenesis screen in a mouse model sensitized for NC defects, Sox10LacZ/+. Out of 71 pedigrees analyzed, we identified and mapped four heritable loci, called modifier of Sox10 expression pattern 1–4 ( msp1–4 ), which show altered NC patterning. The msp1 locus was identified as a new allele of the receptor tyrosine kinase Erbb3, Erbb3msp1, carrying a single amino acid substitution in the extracellular region of the protein. Biochemical analysis of the mutant protein showed that ERBB3 is expressed on the cell surface, but its ligand-induced phosphorylation is dramatically reduced by the msp1 mutation. These findings highlight the importance of the mutated residue for ERBB3 receptor function and activation. This study underscores the utility of using an ENU mutagenesis screen to identify genetic pathways regulating NC development and to dissect the roles of discrete protein domains.
Schistosomiasis mansoni is a parasitic disease caused by Schistosoma mansoni that affects millions of people worldwide. In this study, we investigated the factors that influence susceptibility to reinfection with S. mansoni in a rural Ugandan fishing community. We used data from a multi-disciplinary longitudinal reinfection study to examine the influence of age, sex, and ethnic background on susceptibility to reinfection after anti-helminth drug treatment. We also investigated whether schistosome-specific IgE and IgG4 immune responses could account for any remaining variations in susceptibility to reinfection. We found that observed ethnic- and sex-related variations in S. mansoni reinfection were due to variations in cercarial exposure, as opposed to biological differences in susceptibility to infection. However, age-related differences in reinfection were not explained by exposure and appeared linked to the balance of IgE and IgG4 to the tegumental antigen SmTAL1, which itself was significantly related to resistance to reinfection. This study highlights the importance of taking a multidisciplinary approach in complex field settings to understand the ecology of a population and make more robust conclusions.
Clonorchiasis is a parasitic infection caused by the liver fluke Clonorchis sinensis. The number of eggs per gram of feces ( EPGs ) is the best method to estimate worm burden in infected humans. The present study investigated the correlation between EPGs and worm burden in human clonorchiasis. A total of 60 residents, 50 egg-positive and 10 egg-negative, from Sancheong-gun, Korea, participated in the study between 2006 and 2009. They were diagnosed by egg positivity in feces using the Kato-Katz method. After administration of praziquantel, they were purged with cathartics on the next day, and then discharged adult worms were collected from their feces. A positive correlation between EPGs and numbers of worms was demonstrated ( r = 0. 681, P<0. 001 ). Worm recovery rates were 9. 7% in cases of EPGs 1–1, 000 and 73. 7% in those of EPGs over 1, 000. No worms were detected from egg-negative subjects. The numbers of the worms are significantly correlated with the egg counts in human clonorchiasis. It is estimated that at least 110 worms are infected in a human body with EPGs around 3, 000, and egg productivity of a worm per day is around 4, 000.
Fluconazole resistance in Candida glabrata, a human fungal pathogen, is often mediated by gain-of-function mutations in the PDR1 gene. To identify novel targets for combination therapy, we performed an unbiased genome-wide screen in Saccharomyces cerevisiae expressing a C. glabrata PDR1+ gain-of-function allele. Eighteen synthetically lethal S. cerevisiae genetic mutants were identified, one of which was the histone acetyltransferase Gcn5. Deletion or drug-mediated inhibition of Gcn5 caused a lethal phenotype in C. glabrata cells expressing PDR1+ alleles. Moreover, deletion or drug-mediated inactivation of Gcn5 inhibited the emergence of fluconazole-resistant C. glabrata isolates in evolution experiments. We confirmed that loss of Gcn5 function is lethal in C. glabrata cells expressing the PDR1+L280F fluconazole resistant allele and demonstrated that chemically inhibiting Gcn5 renders both S. cerevisiae and the orthologous C. glabrata mutant inviable. These data demonstrate that targeting Gcn5, a synthetically lethal interacting partner of PDR1L280F, offers a new paradigm for the treatment of drug-resistant infection.
Poliovirus ( PV ) infection induces the formation of distinct membranous organelles that are involved in genome replication and virus assembly. The spatiotemporal dynamics of phosphatidylinositol-4-phosphate ( PI4P ) and membranous structures during PV infection have been studied in this work. Two PV mutants, termed EG and GG, which exhibit aberrant proteolytic processing of the P3 precursor, were used to illuminate the pathway of formation of PV-induced membranous structures. Genome replication and/or virus assembly were substantially delayed in these mutants. Changes to the PI4P pool were observed as early as 30 min post-infection in wild-type PV. PI4P remodeling occurred even in the presence of guanidine hydrochloride, a replication inhibitor, and was accompanied by formation of membrane tubules throughout the cytoplasm. Vesicular clusters appeared in the perinuclear region of the cell at 3 h post-infection, a time too slow for these structures to be responsible for genome replication. Our results are consistent with PV inducing temporally distinct membranous structures for genome replication ( tubules ) and virus assembly ( vesicular clusters ). We suggest that the pace of formation, spatiotemporal dynamics, and the efficiency of the replication-to-assembly-organelle conversion may be set by both the rate of P3 polyprotein processing and the capacity for P3 processing to yield 3AB and/or 3CD proteins.
Chagas disease is a neglected trypanosomiasis with enormous social and economic impact in most countries of Latin America. In order to develop new and more effective drugs with fewer side effects than the currently available chemotherapy, a multi-step cascade strategy was developed to identify new molecular classes of cruzain inhibitors by focusing on non-peptidic non-covalent ligands. We carried out virtual screening of the ZINC Database using ligand- and target-based virtual screening methods, followed by enzymatic assays, X-ray crystallography and structure-activity relationship ( SAR ) studies of the most promising hits. This approach led to the identification of 12 non-covalent binding cruzain inhibitors with affinity values in the low micromolar range ( 3–60 µM ) acting through a competitive inhibition mechanism. The most potent cruzain inhibitors were assayed against T. cruzi-infected cells and two compounds were found to have trypanocidal activity. Using compound Nequimed42 as precursor, an SAR was established in which the 2-acetamidothiophene-3-carboxamide group was identified as essential for enzyme and parasite inhibition activities. The IC50 value for compound Nequimed42 acting against the trypomastigote form of the Tulahuen lacZ strain was found to be 10. 6±0. 1 µM, tenfold lower than that obtained for benznidazole, which was taken as positive control.
Yellow fever ( YF ) remains a significant source of morbidity and mortality in tropical areas of the world. The only available vaccine against YF is the attenuated YF virus 17D/17DD vaccine, which generates both long-lasting neutralizing antibodies and strong T-cell responses. However, this vaccine has toxic side effects that can be fatal on rare occasions. This study presents the development and evaluation of two non-viral DNA-based antigen formulations against YF. The two formulations consist of DNA encoding the full-length envelope protein ( p/YFE ) or the full-length envelope protein fused to the lysosomal-associated membrane protein signal, LAMP-1 ( pL/YFE ). The immune responses triggered by these formulations were evaluated in H2b and H2d backgrounds, corresponding to the C57Bl/6 and BALB/c mice strains, respectively. Both DNA constructs were able to induce very strong T-cell responses of similar magnitude against almost all epitopes that are also generated by the YF 17DD vaccine. The pL/YFE formulation performed best overall. In addition to the T-cell response, it was also able to stimulate high titers of anti-YF neutralizing antibodies comparable to the levels elicited by the 17DD vaccine. More importantly, the pL/YFE vaccine conferred 100% protection against the YF virus in intracerebrally challenged mice. These results indicate that pL/YFE DNA is an excellent vaccine candidate and should be considered for further developmental studies.
The nucleoid occlusion protein SlmA has been identified as a direct transcriptional activator of the chitobiose utilization genes in Vibrio cholerae. Chitobiose is a chitin disaccharide that is required for the persistence and evolution of V. cholerae in the marine environment. The chb operon encodes genes involved in the uptake and catabolism of chitobiose, and is regulated by the orphan sensor kinase ChiS. However, the mechanisms downstream of ChiS activation that result in expression of the chb operon are poorly understood. Using an unbiased transposon mutant screen, we found that SlmA is a regulator of the chb operon. SlmA is a member of the TetR family of proteins, which are generally transcriptional repressors. However, we found that SlmA binds directly to the chb operon promoter and is required for transcriptional activation of this locus and for chitobiose utilization. We also found that DNA-binding, but not nucleoid occlusion, is critical for transcriptional activation. This study identifies a novel role for SlmA as a transcriptional regulator in V. cholerae in addition to its established role as a cell division licensing factor.
We present a novel nonlinear programming ( NLP ) framework for solving computationally challenging parameter estimation problems that arise in dynamic modeling of biological systems. Such problems involve highly nonlinear and stiff differential equations as well as many experimental data sets and parameters. The proposed framework is computationally efficient, robust, and easy-to-use. It uses a time discretization approach that avoids repetitive simulations of the dynamic model, enables fully algebraic model implementations and computation of derivatives, and enables the use of computationally efficient nonlinear interior point solvers that exploit sparse and structured linear algebra techniques. We demonstrate the capabilities of the proposed framework by solving estimation problems for synthetic human gut microbiome community models. We show that an instance with 156 parameters, 144 differential equations, and 1, 704 experimental data points can be solved in less than 3 minutes, while an off-the-shelf simulation-based solution framework requires over 7 hours. We also create large instances to show that the proposed framework is scalable and can solve problems with up to 2, 352 parameters, 2, 304 differential equations, and 20, 352 data points in less than 15 minutes. The proposed framework is flexible and can be broadly applied to dynamic models of biological systems, enabling the implementation of sophisticated estimation techniques to quantify parameter uncertainty, diagnose observability/uniqueness issues, perform model selection, and handle outliers.
West Nile virus ( WNV ) dissemination and the inflammatory response against WNV in the outbred Swiss Webster ( SW ) mouse model were evaluated using the nCounter, a high throughput digital gene expression system.
