The nCounter Mouse Inflammation gene expression kit containing 179 inflammation related genes was used to analyze gene expression changes in multiple tissues over a nine day course of infection in SW mice following intraperitoneal injection with WNV. Expression analysis of spleen, lung, liver, kidney and brain of SW mice infected with WNV revealed that Cxcl10 and Il12b are differentially expressed in all tissues tested except kidney. Data stratification of positively confirmed infected ( WNV ( + ) ) versus non-infected ( WNV ( − ) tissues allowed differentiation of the systemic inflammatory gene response from tissue-specific responses arising from WNV infection. Significant changes in gene expression were found in WNV ( − ) spleen, lung, liver and brain tissues. In WNV ( + ) livers, Stat1, Tlr2, chemokines Cxcl1, Cxcl3, Cxcl9, Cxcl10, cytokines Il6, Il18, cytokine-related gene Il1r and cytokine agonist Ilrn were significantly upregulated. In WNV ( − ) brain tissues, Csf2 and Cxcl10 were significantly upregulated. Similar gene and protein expression kinetics were found for Ccl2, Ccl3, Ccl4 and Ccl5 and correlated with the presence of infectious virus.
During an outbreak of rabies in Maputo and Matola cities, Mozambique in 2014, we investigated the epidemiology, clinical features and risk factors of human rabies and animal bites. We reviewed cases of human rabies and animal bites from April to July 2014 and conducted a community investigation in July and August in the neighborhoods where cases of human rabies resided. We detected 14 cases of human rabies, all of whom had a recent history of dog bite, and 819 cases of animal bites, of which 97. 8% were caused by dogs. Only one of the 14 rabid dogs had been immunized. Factors significantly associated with human rabies were: age <15 years, bite by stray dog, deep wound, bite in the head, bite by unimmunized dog, no use of soap and water, and no post-exposure prophylaxis. We found that implementation of control measures for rabies is poor in Maputo and Matola cities, where cases of human rabies were strongly associated with bites by stray and unvaccinated dogs and irregular implementation of post-exposure measures.
The SCN9A gene, which encodes the Nav1. 7 subunit of the voltage-gated sodium channel, has been identified as a potential cause of febrile seizures ( FS ) in a large Utah family. A highly conserved amino acid mutation, p. N641Y, in the SCN9A gene was found in 21 affected family members and was absent in 586 ethnically matched population control chromosomes. To establish a functional role for this mutation in seizure susceptibility, we introduced the orthologous mutation into the murine Scn9a ortholog using targeted homologous recombination. Homozygous Scn9aN641Y/N641Y knockin mice exhibited significantly reduced thresholds to electrically induced clonic and tonic-clonic seizures, and increased corneal kindling acquisition rates compared to wild-type mice. These data strongly support the SCN9A p. N641Y mutation as disease-causing in this family. In addition, we analyzed a collection of 92 unrelated FS patients and identified additional highly conserved Nav1. 7 missense variants in 5% of the patients. Furthermore, we sequenced the SCN1A gene in a child with FS who later developed Dravet syndrome and identified a heterozygous frameshift mutation. Subsequent analysis of 109 Dravet syndrome patients yielded nine Nav1. 7 missense variants ( 8% of the patients ), all in highly conserved amino acids. This study provides evidence for a role of SCN9A in human epilepsies, both as a cause of FS and as a partner with SCN1A mutations.
Morphogenesis, the process by which complex tissue shapes arise through growth, has been a long-standing problem in biology. Here we present the Growing Polarised Tissue ( GPT ) framework, a polarity-based system that can generate a wide range of biological forms through combinatorial interactions between tissue polarity and growth. Tissue is treated as a continuous material within which regionally expressed factors under genetic control may interact and propagate. Polarity is established by signals that propagate through the tissue and is anchored in regions termed tissue polarity organisers that are also under genetic control. Rates of growth parallel or perpendicular to the local polarity may then be specified through a regulatory network. The resulting growth depends on how specified growth patterns interact within the constraints of mechanically connected tissue. This constraint leads to the emergence of features such as curvature that were not directly specified by the regulatory networks. We illustrate the value of the GPT-framework for understanding morphogenesis by applying it to a growing Snapdragon flower and indicate how the underlying hypotheses may be tested by computational simulation. We propose that combinatorial interactions between orientations and rates of growth, which are a key feature of polarity-based systems, have been exploited during evolution to generate a range of observed biological shapes.
During early HIV infection, multiple CD8+ T cell responses are elicited almost simultaneously, exerting strong selective pressures on different parts of the virus’s genome and selecting for mutations that escape recognition and are beneficial to the virus. These escape mutations can emerge at different times, and it has been observed that the later they emerge, the more slowly they go to fixation. This pattern of escape rate decrease ( ERD ) can arise by distinct mechanisms, including interference among different escape strains. In this study, we investigated how interference between these concurrent escape mutations affects their escape rates in systems with multiple epitopes, and whether it could be a source of the ERD pattern. We developed a multilocus Wright-Fisher model of HIV dynamics with selection, mutation and recombination, as well as an interference-free null model assuming initial neutral evolution before immune response elicitation. We found that interference between several equally selectively advantageous mutations can generate the observed ERD pattern, and that the number of loci and recombination rates substantially affect ERD. We also found that the observed ERD pattern in HIV infected individuals is consistent with both independent, interference-free mutations as well as interference effects. Our results confirm that interference effects should be considered when analyzing HIV escape mutations, and that accounting for the stochastic nature of competition between mutations demands novel estimation methodologies based on the analysis of HIV strains, rather than mutation frequencies.
Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients with resectable disease require effective preoperative chemotherapy to eliminate micrometastasis and improve operability. In this study, we developed a mechanistic model of cancer response to treatment to estimate the cell killing efficacy of various cisplatin-based doublet regimens in NSCLC. The model takes into account the cancer-related mechanisms of uncontrolled proliferation, population heterogeneity, hypoxia, and treatment resistance. We applied the model to the retrospective data of 13 patients with NSCLC who received cisplatin in combination with gemcitabine, vinorelbine, or docetaxel in the neoadjuvant context. The selection of model input values was guided by a comprehensive literature survey on cancer-specific proliferation kinetics. A Latin hypercube sampling approach was used to compensate for patient-specific uncertainties. Our results show that the volume growth rate and growth fraction at diagnosis are key features for more accurate estimates of cell killing efficacy. We estimated a range of plausible values for the cell killing efficacy of various cisplatin-based doublet regimens, expressed as the sum of cell kill rates of the two drugs considered. Our methodology provides a quantitative framework for the estimation of in vivo cell killing ability of various chemotherapies, which could serve as a basis for reliable personalized predictions.
Bacteria growing in biofilms are known to exhibit high levels of antibiotic tolerance, which is distinct from inherited antibiotic resistance. In this study, we used random transposon mutagenesis to identify biofilm-specific tolerant mutants in Escherichia coli. We found that biofilms formed by amino acid auxotroph mutants are highly tolerant to the fluoroquinolone antibiotic ofloxacin. Furthermore, we demonstrated that amino acid starvation significantly increases the tolerance of biofilm bacteria to ofloxacin. We also showed that the biofilm-specific tolerance to ofloxacin is fully dependent on a functional SOS response upon starvation to both amino acids and carbon source, and partially dependent on the stringent response upon leucine starvation. However, the biofilm-specific ofloxacin tolerance does not involve any of the SOS-induced toxin–antitoxin systems previously associated with the formation of highly tolerant persisters. We further demonstrated that ofloxacin tolerance is induced as a function of biofilm age, which is dependent on the SOS response.
Plasmodium falciparum merozoites invade human erythrocytes to initiate the intra-erythrocytic stage of the parasite life cycle, which is responsible for all pathogenesis and death associated with P. falciparum malaria. Invasion of erythrocytes by P. falciparum merozoites is a complex multi-step process mediated by specific molecular interactions between red cell surface receptors and parasite protein ligands that reside in apical membrane-bound organelles known as micronemes and rhoptries. Timely secretion of these parasite ligands to the merozoite surface is critical for successful invasion. Here, we identify cAMP as a key regulator that triggers the timely secretion of microneme proteins enabling receptor-engagement and invasion. We demonstrate that exposure of merozoites to a low K+ environment, typical of blood plasma, activates a bicarbonate-sensitive cytoplasmic adenylyl cyclase to raise cytosolic cAMP levels and activate protein kinase A, which regulates microneme secretion. We also show that cAMP regulates merozoite cytosolic Ca2+ levels via induction of an Epac pathway and demonstrate that increases in both cAMP and Ca2+ are essential to trigger microneme secretion.
Strongyloides stercoralis, a soil-transmitted nematode, is one of the most neglected among the neglected tropical diseases ( NTDs ). We conducted a systematic literature review of 354 studies from 78 countries to obtain country-specific prevalence estimates of S. stercoralis infection in the general population and to assess the association between S. stercoralis prevalence and different risk groups. A Bayesian meta-analysis was carried out to compare disease odds ratios in different risk groups taking into account the sensitivities of the diagnostic methods applied. The meta-analysis showed an association between HIV-infection and S. stercoralis infection ( OR: 2. 17; 95% CI: 1. 18–4. 01 ), and between alcoholism and S. stercoralis infection ( OR: 6. 69; 95% CI: 1. 47–33. 8 ). Our findings show high infection prevalence rates in the general population in selected countries and geographical regions. S. stercoralis infection is prominent in several risk groups, including refugees, immigrants, tourists, and military personnel returning from deployment in endemic areas. In developed countries, S. stercoralis remains an issue for immigrants, tourists, and military personnel returning from deployment in endemic areas, and may call for systematic screening after visits to endemic countries and before initiation of immuno-suppressive treatment.
Stochastic noise at the cellular level plays a fundamental role in circadian oscillations, influencing how groups of cells entrain to external cues and generating cell-autonomous rhythms. However, few studies have investigated how clock perturbations affect stochastic noise. In this study, we show that the damping rate of population-level bioluminescence recordings can serve as an accurate measure of overall stochastic noise. Using cell-autonomous fibroblast data, we demonstrate that higher noise at the single-cell level results in faster damping at the population level. We also show that the damping rate of cultured cells can be changed in a dose-dependent fashion by small molecule modulators, and confirm that such a change can be explained by single-cell noise using a mathematical model. We further demonstrate the insights that can be gained by applying our method to a genome-wide siRNA screen, revealing that stochastic noise is altered independently from period, amplitude, and phase. Finally, we hypothesize that the unperturbed clock is highly optimized for robust rhythms, as very few gene perturbations are capable of simultaneously increasing amplitude and lowering stochastic noise.
FtsZ is an essential protein in bacterial cell division that has been identified as a promising target for the development of new antimicrobial drugs to combat the increasing problem of antibiotic resistance in pathogenic bacteria. Recent studies have shown that the allosteric inhibitor PC190723 has in vitro activity against Staphylococcus aureus FtsZ and in vivo antimicrobial activity. However, the mechanism of drug action and its effect on FtsZ in other bacterial species are unclear. Here, we examine the structural environment of the PC190723 binding pocket in FtsZ from different bacterial species using a statistical method called PocketFEATURE and molecular dynamics ( MD ) simulations. Our results show that species and nucleotide-binding state have significant impacts on the structural properties of the binding site, with substantially disparate microenvironments for bacterial species not from the Staphylococcus genus. We predict that PC190723 strongly prefers to bind Staphylococcus FtsZ in the nucleotide-bound state and that polymerization of FtsZ may enhance PC190723 binding. Our results demonstrate that a drug-binding pocket can vary significantly across species, genetic perturbations, and in different polymerization states, yielding important information for the further development of FtsZ inhibitors.
Lentiviral integrase ( IN ) is a protein that plays a critical role in the integration of viral DNA into the host genome. The cellular protein lens epithelium derived growth factor ( LEDGF ), also known as PC4 and SFRS1 interacting protein 1 ( PSIP1 ) and transcriptional co-activator p75, is the cellular binding partner of lentiviral IN proteins and is required for efficient viral replication. We now present the crystal structure of the N-terminal and catalytic core domains ( NTD and CCD ) of HIV-2 IN in complex with the IN binding domain ( IBD ) of LEDGF. The structure reveals primarily charge–charge interactions between the NTD of IN and the IBD of LEDGF. A constellation of acidic residues on the NTD is characteristic of lentiviral INs, and mutations of the positively charged residues on the IBD severely affect interaction with all lentiviral INs tested. We show that the novel NTD–IBD contacts are critical for stimulation of concerted lentiviral DNA integration by LEDGF in vitro and for its function during the early steps of HIV-1 replication. Furthermore, the new structural details enabled us to engineer a mutant of HIV-1 IN that primarily functions only when presented with a complementary LEDGF mutant. These findings provide a structural basis for the high affinity lentiviral IN–LEDGF interaction and pave the way for the development of LEDGF-based targeting technologies for gene therapy.
Cancer stem cells are a subpopulation of cells within a tumor that have the ability to initiate and sustain tumor growth. These cells have an intrinsic set of kinetics that dictate their behavior, including cell migration, proliferation potential, spontaneous cell death, and symmetric cancer stem cell division. We have developed a cellular automaton model that tracks the temporal evolution of cancer stem cells to investigate the emerging intratumoral heterogeneity and determine the evolutionary trajectories of the combination of cell-intrinsic kinetics that yield aggressive tumor growth. Our study suggests that cell proliferation potential is the strongest modulator of tumor growth. Early increase in proliferation potential yields larger populations of non-stem cancer cells that compete with cancer stem cells and thus inhibit cancer stem cell division, while a reduction in proliferation potential loosens such inhibition and facilitates frequent cancer stem cell division. The sub-population of cancer stem cells in itself becomes highly heterogeneous, dictating population level dynamics that vary from long-term dormancy to aggressive progression. We have identified a set of orthogonal cell kinetics that include cell migration rate, proliferation potential, spontaneous cell death, and symmetric cancer stem cell division. Our study suggests that the clonal diversity that is captured in single tumor biopsy samples represents only a small proportion of the total number of phenotypes.
Many zoonotic, novel infectious diseases in humans appear as sporadic infections with spatially and temporally restricted outbreaks, as seen with influenza A ( H5N1 ). Here we use simple mathematical models to describe different adaptation scenarios with particular reference to spatial heterogeneity within the human population. We present analytical expressions for the probability of emergence per introduction, as well as the waiting time to a successful emergence event. Furthermore, we derive general analytical results for the statistical properties of emergence events, including the probability distribution of outbreak sizes. Our results suggest that, for typical connection strengths between communities, spatial heterogeneity has only a weak effect on outbreak size distributions, and on the risk of emergence per introduction. For example, if or larger, any village connected to a large city by just ten commuters a day is, effectively, just a part of the city when considering the chances of emergence and the outbreak size distribution. We present empirical data on commuting patterns and show that the vast majority of communities for which such data are available are at least this well interconnected. For plausible parameter ranges, the effects of spatial heterogeneity are likely to be dominated by the evolutionary biology of host adaptation.
Influenza A virus ( AIV ) migration and persistence in North American wild birds have been poorly understood, hampering the prediction of viral spread and the formulation of preparedness plans. We analyzed 287 newly sequenced AIV samples collected over a 34-year period from North American migratory birds. Using a Bayesian statistical framework, we tested hypotheses of viral migration, population structure and patterns of genetic reassortment. Our results show that despite the high prevalence of Charadriiformes infected in Delaware Bay, this host population does not appear to significantly contribute to the North American AIV diversity sampled in Anseriformes. In contrast, influenza viruses sampled from Anseriformes in Alberta are representative of the AIV diversity circulating in North American Anseriformes. We found that while AIV may be restricted to specific migratory flyways over short time frames, the long-term persistence of AIV is independent of bird flyways, with migration between populations occurring throughout North America. Our analysis of long-term surveillance data provides vital insights for developing predictive models critical for pandemic preparedness and livestock protection.
Influenza A viruses are classified into 16 antigenically distinct subtypes based on their hemagglutinin ( HA ) surface glycoproteins. Most neutralizing antibodies are specific to a particular HA subtype and do not cross-react with other subtypes. However, a novel monoclonal antibody ( MAb ), MAb S139/1, has been generated that shows heterosubtypic cross-reactive neutralization and hemagglutination inhibition of influenza A viruses. MAb S139/1 was found to react with HA subtypes H1, H2, H3, H5, H9, and H13 in enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays ( ELISA ) and showed neutralization and hemagglutination-inhibition activities against particular strains of H1, H2, H3, and H13 subtypes. Mutant viruses that escaped neutralization by MAb S139/1 were selected from the A/Aichi/2/68 ( H3N2 ), A/Adachi/2/57 ( H2N2 ), and A/WSN/33 ( H1N1 ) strains, and sequence analysis of the HA genes of these escape mutants revealed amino acid substitutions at positions 156, 158, and 193. A molecular modeling study showed that these amino acids were located on the globular head of the HA and formed a novel conformational epitope adjacent to the receptor-binding domain of HA. Furthermore, passive immunization of mice with MAb S139/1 provided heterosubtypic protection.
Strongyloides stercoralis, a parasitic worm, is a major public health concern in remote Aboriginal communities of northern Australia, with prevalence rates as high as 30–40%. A three-year cohort study was conducted to assess the effectiveness of ivermectin treatment in controlling S. stercoralis infection in an Australian Aboriginal population. The study included 259 adult Aboriginals living in a remote community in northern Australia. S. stercoralis infection was diagnosed using a commercial ELISA kit with a lower threshold for treatment than recommended. Follow-up was conducted at 6 months and 3 years following ivermectin treatment. The results showed that treatment with ivermectin was highly effective in reducing the prevalence of S. stercoralis infection, from 35. 3% at baseline to 5. 8% at 3 years ( McNemar’s chi2 = 56. 5, p<0. 001 ). The study also suggested that using a lower ELISA threshold for treatment was valid in this setting. However, a small group of subjects had persistently positive ELISA serology despite repeated treatment. The study provides evidence that control of chronic S. stercoralis infection in an adult Aboriginal population may be achieved through a process of case finding and treatment, using the current best practice guidelines for treatment.
Prion diseases are caused by a misfolded isoform of the prion protein, PrPSc. Prion strains are hypothesized to be encoded by strain-specific conformations of PrPSc and can interfere with each other when a long-incubation period strain ( blocking strain ) inhibits the conversion of a short-incubation period strain ( non-blocking strain ). However, it is unknown if two long-incubation period strains can interfere with each other. Here, we show that co-infection of animals with combinations of long-incubation period strains failed to identify evidence of strain interference. To exclude the possibility that this inability of strains to interfere in vivo was due to a failure to infect common populations of neurons, we used protein misfolding cyclic amplification strain interference ( PMCAsi ). Consistent with the animal bioassay studies, PMCAsi indicated that both co-infecting strains were amplifying independently, suggesting that the lack of strain interference is not due to a failure to target the same cells but is an inherent property of the strains involved. Importantly, PMCA reactions seeded with long incubation-period strains contained relatively higher levels of remaining PrPC compared to reactions seeded with a short-incubation period strain. We hypothesize that the abundance of PrPC is not limiting in vivo or in vitro, resulting in prion strains with relatively low prion conversion efficiency to amplify independently.
Allosteric regulation is an important mechanism by which proteins control their activity in response to ligand binding. Intrinsically disordered proteins/regions ( IDPs/IDRs ) are prevalent in allosteric regulation, and it was previously thought that intrinsic disorder is favorable for maximizing the allosteric coupling. Here, we propose a comprehensive ensemble model to compare the roles of both order-order transition and disorder-order transition in allosteric effect. Our model reveals that the MWC pathway ( order-order transition ) has a higher probability than the EAM pathway ( disorder-order transition ) in allostery, suggesting a complicated role of IDPs/IDRs in regulatory proteins. We also obtain an analytic formula for the maximal allosteric coupling response, which shows that too stable or too unstable states are unfavorable to endow allostery. Our results suggest that the reasons for the prevalence of IDPs/IDRs in allosteric regulation are more complicated than previously thought. We propose that IDPs/IDRs can implement allosteric effect under the lack of ordered structures by stabilizing specific states and shifting the conformational ensemble. The prevalence of IDPs/IDRs in allosteric regulation is determined by all their advantages, but not only by their capacity in endowing allostery.
Prostate cancer is a major cause of male death in the Western world, but few frequent genetic alterations that drive prostate cancer initiation and progression have been identified. β-Catenin is essential for many developmental processes and has been implicated in tumorigenesis in many tissues, including prostate cancer. We have used in vivo genetic studies in the embryo and adult to extend our understanding of the role of β-Catenin in the normal and neoplastic prostate. Our gene deletion analysis revealed that prostate epithelial β-Catenin is required for embryonic prostate growth and branching but is dispensable in the normal adult organ. During development, β-Catenin controls the number of progenitors in the epithelial buds and regulates a discrete network of genes, including c-Myc and Nkx3. 1. β-Catenin overexpression in combination with Pten loss was able to drive progression to invasive carcinoma together with squamous metaplasia. These studies demonstrate that β-Catenin is essential for prostate development and that an inherent property of high levels of this protein in prostate epithelia is to drive squamous fate differentiation. In addition, they show that β-Catenin overexpression can promote invasive prostate cancer in a clinically relevant model of this disease.
Informed consent is a critical component of biomedical research, particularly in developing countries where disease burden is high. However, there is a need to tailor the consent process to the social and cultural context of the community and potential research participants. We conducted a qualitative study in southern Ethiopia to assess determinants of and approaches to gaining informed consent for a genetic study on podoconiosis ( non-filarial elephantiasis ). The study involved focus-group discussions and in-depth interviews with podoconiosis patients, non-patients, fieldworkers, researchers, local NGO staff, and community leaders. We found that the extent of use of everyday language, the degree to which expectations of potential participants were addressed, and the techniques of presentation of information had a considerable impact on comprehension of information provided about the research. Approaching podoconiosis patients via locally trusted individuals and preceding individual consent with community sensitization were considered the optimal means of communication. We also found that prevailing poverty among podoconiosis patients, the absence of alternative treatment facilities, and participants' trust in the local NGO were potential barriers for obtaining genuine informed consent.
T cell proliferation in the immune system is a complex process that involves cell proliferation, differentiation, selection, death, and migration of lymphocytes from the thymus to peripheral tissues. Quantifying cell proliferation dynamics requires specific experimental methods and mathematical modelling. Here, we investigate the impact of genetics and aging on the immune system by examining the proliferation dynamics of T lymphocytes across their differentiation stages in the thymus and spleen of mice. We use single-cell multicolour flow cytometry analysis and a generic mathematical model based on Ordinary Differential Equations ( ODEs ) to simulate the evolution of single cell behaviour during various durations of labelling. Our model allows us to fit our data, deduce proliferation rates, and estimate cell cycle durations in sub-populations. Our results reveal that T cell proliferation is highly heterogeneous and depends on genetic origins, cell differentiation stages in the thymus and spleen, and is altered with age. Our model allows us to infer proliferation rates and cell cycle phase durations from complex experimental data, revealing T cell proliferation heterogeneity and specific signatures.
Mitochondrial DNA ( mtDNA ) mutations are a common cause of human disease, and about half of these mutations occur in tRNA genes. We report the generation and characterization of the first mitochondrial tRNA pathological mutation in mouse cells, an m. 3739G>A transition in the mitochondrial mt-Ti gene. This mutation recapitulates the molecular hallmarks of a disease-causing mutation described in humans, an m. 4290T>C transition affecting also the human mt-Ti gene. We demonstrate that the pathogenic molecular mechanism induced by both the mouse and human mutations is a high frequency of abnormal folding of the tRNAIle that cannot be charged with isoleucine. We also show that the cells harboring the mouse or human mutant tRNA have exacerbated mitochondrial biogenesis triggered by an increase in mitochondrial ROS production as a compensatory response. This compensatory mechanism can explain the penetrance pattern of this mutation. We propose that the nature of the pathogenic mechanism combined with the existence of a compensatory mechanism can allow a scenario for the evolution of mitochondrial tRNAs in which the fixation of two alleles that are individually deleterious can proceed in two steps and not require the simultaneous mutation of both.
Human triploid cells, which have three sets of chromosomes instead of the normal two, have been found to have an unbalanced expression of X-linked genes compared to autosomal genes. In triploid cells with two active X chromosomes, the expression of X-linked genes is approximately doubled compared to diploid cells. However, in triploid cells with only one active X chromosome, the expression of X-linked genes is further increased, suggesting an epigenetic adjustment in response to the ratio between the number of active X chromosomes and autosomal sets. The expression of autosomal genes, on the other hand, is similar in triploid and diploid cells and is strictly proportional to the number of autosomal sets. We found that a small subset of X-linked genes ( ∼7% ) has expression levels that are proportional to the number of autosomal sets, suggesting that they are regulated in a dosage-sensitive manner. These genes are preferentially located on the short arm of the human X chromosome. Overall, our results indicate that the expression of X-linked genes in triploid cells does not strictly respond to an autosomal counting factor and is instead adjusted by an epigenetic mechanism that senses the ratio between the number of active X chromosomes and autosomal sets.
The dN/dS ratio is a widely used measure to quantify evolutionary pressures on proteins by comparing substitution rates at non-synonymous and synonymous sites. However, this measure was originally developed for application to distantly diverged sequences, where differences represent substitutions that have fixed along independent lineages. Here, we study the expected dN/dS ratio for samples drawn from a single population, where differences represent segregating polymorphisms. We find that in this context, dN/dS is relatively insensitive to the selection coefficient, and the hallmark signature of positive selection over divergent lineages, dN/dS>1, is violated within a population. Moreover, the relationship between selection and dN/dS does not follow a monotonic function, and so it may be impossible to infer selection pressures from dN/dS measurements among population-genetic samples. Our results have significant implications for the interpretation of dN/dS measurements among population-genetic samples, as standard tests for selection based on dN/dS are extremely sensitive to violation of the assumption of divergent lineages.
The effect of natural selection on linked neutral divergence between closely and distantly related species has been a long-standing issue in evolutionary biology. Here we show that natural selection can indirectly affect linked neutral divergence between both closely and distantly related species. We find that neutral divergence between closely related species ( e. g. human-primate ) is negatively correlated with functional content and positively correlated with human recombination rate. We also find that neutral divergence between distantly related species ( e. g. human-rodent ) is negatively correlated with functional content and positively correlated with estimates of background selection from primates. These patterns persist after accounting for confounding factors such as hypermutable CpG sites, GC content, and biased gene conversion. Coalescent models indicate that even when the contribution of ancestral polymorphism to divergence is small, background selection in the ancestral population can still explain a large proportion of the variance in divergence across the genome.
Circadian oscillations in Drosophila are governed by a transcriptional-translational negative feedback loop in which the CLOCK ( CLK ) and CYCLE ( CYC ) bHLH-PAS domain transcription factors activate the expression of the period ( per ) and timeless ( tim ) genes. CLK is the key rhythmic component of the circadian activator in Drosophila, with its DNA-binding and transcriptional activity showing a robust oscillation with an evening peak. In this study, we investigated the role of the CK2 kinase in the control of CLK phosphorylation and function. We show that CK2 phosphorylates and stabilizes CLK, while reducing its transcriptional activity. Downregulation of the catalytic α subunit of CK2 induces CLK degradation, even in the absence of PER and TIM. Unexpectedly, the regulatory β subunit of the CK2 holoenzyme is not required for the regulation of CLK stability. In addition, downregulation of CK2α activity decreases CLK phosphorylation and increases per and tim transcription. These results indicate that CK2 inhibits CLK degradation while reducing its activity. Since the CK1 kinase promotes CLK degradation, we suggest that CLK stability and transcriptional activity result from counteracting effects of CK1 and CK2.
Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas' disease, interacts with the invertebrate host Rhodnius prolixus during its life cycle. We investigated the role of cruzipain, a cysteine peptidase, in this interaction. We treated T. cruzi epimastigotes with anti-cruzipain antibodies or a panel of cysteine peptidase inhibitors ( cystatin, antipain, E-64, leupeptin, iodocetamide or CA-074-OMe ) and analyzed their effect on parasite adhesion to R. prolixus posterior midgut ex vivo. All treatments, except CA074-OMe, significantly decreased parasite adhesion to R. prolixus midgut. Cystatin presented a dose-dependent reduction on the adhesion. We compared the adhesion rate among several T. cruzi isolates and found that the G isolate, which naturally possesses low levels of active cruzipain, adhered to a lesser extent in comparison to Dm28c, Y and CL Brener isolates. Transgenic epimastigotes overexpressing an endogenous cruzipain inhibitor, chagasin, and that have reduced levels of active cruzipain adhered to the insect gut 73% less than the wild-type parasites. The adhesion of pCHAG parasites was partially restored by the addition of exogenous cruzipain. In vivo colonization experiments revealed low levels of pCHAG parasites in comparison to wild-type. Parasites isolated after passage in the insect presented a drastic enhancement in the expression of surface cruzipain.
Cytoplasmic dynein is a microtubule-dependent motor protein that plays a crucial role in various cellular processes during mitosis, including centrosome separation, metaphase chromosome congression, anaphase spindle elongation, and chromosome segregation, as well as during interphase for vesicle transport and organelle positioning. However, the mechanisms that target and regulate cytoplasmic dynein remain largely unknown. To identify potential regulators of cytoplasmic dynein, we conducted a genome-wide screen for modifiers of dynein function in Caenorhabditis elegans using a sensitized genetic background. We isolated and characterized twenty dynein-specific suppressor genes that, when reduced in function, suppress cytoplasmic dynein heavy chain mutants but not other conditionally mutant loci. Twelve of these suppressor genes do not exhibit sterile or lethal phenotypes when their function is reduced in wild-type worms. We also identified four putative dynein accessory chains that, when reduced in function, suppress cytoplasmic dynein heavy chain mutants, suggesting that some accessory chains negatively regulate heavy chain function. Furthermore, we identified 29 additional genes that, when reduced in function, suppress not only cytoplasmic dynein but also loci required for unrelated essential processes.
During programmed genome rearrangements ( PGR ) in the ciliate Paramecium tetraurelia, physiological DNA double-strand breaks ( DSBs ) drive the elimination of at least 45, 000 germline sequences ( Internal Eliminated Sequences, IESs ) from the somatic nucleus. This process involves a domesticated transposase, PiggyMac, for DNA cleavage, and the Ligase IV component of the non-homologous end-joining ( NHEJ ) pathway for DSB repair at excision sites. To understand how DNA cleavage and DSB repair are coordinated during PGR, we have focused on Ku, the earliest actor of NHEJ-mediated repair. We show that the development-specific Ku70/Ku80c heterodimer is essential for the recovery of a functional somatic nucleus, and that PiggyMac-dependent DNA cleavage is abolished at IES boundaries in cells depleted for Ku80c, resulting in IES retention in the somatic genome. We conclude that Ku has been integrated in the Paramecium DNA cleavage factory, enabling tight coupling between DSB introduction and repair during PGR. Our findings point to the participation of the development-specific Ku70-Ku80c heterodimer in Pgm-dependent DNA cleavage, upstream of its likely function in C-NHEJ-mediated DSB repair.
Prion diseases are characterized by a long pre-clinical incubation period during which time the infectious prion particle and infectivity steadily propagate in the brain. However, the molecular events that accompany early neuronal damage and ultimately conclude with neuronal death remain obscure. In this study, we used laser capture microdissection to isolate hippocampal CA1 neurons and determined their pre-clinical transcriptional response during prion infection. We found that gene expression within these neurons is dynamic and characterized by distinct phases of activity. A major cluster of genes is altered during pre-clinical disease after which expression either returns to basal levels, or alternatively undergoes a direct reversal during clinical disease. This cluster contains a signature highly reminiscent of synaptic N-methyl-D-aspartic acid ( NMDA ) receptor signaling and the activation of neuroprotective pathways. Additionally, genes involved in neuronal projection and dendrite development were also altered throughout the disease, culminating in a general decline of gene expression for synaptic proteins. Deregulated miRNAs such as miR-132-3p, miR-124a-3p, miR-16-5p, miR-26a-5p, miR-29a-3p and miR-140-5p follow concomitant patterns of expression. Our findings suggest that prion replication results in the persistent stimulation of a programmed response that is mediated, at least in part, by synaptic NMDA receptor activity that initially promotes cell survival and neurite remodelling.
Leishmania donovani is a protozoan parasite that causes experimental visceral leishmaniasis in mice, characterized by the formation of granulomas in the liver. To better understand granuloma formation and function, we have developed an in silico Petri net model that simulates granuloma development throughout the course of infection. The model was extensively validated by comparison with data from experimental studies in mice and robustness was assessed by sensitivity analysis. The model recapitulated the progression of disease seen during experimental infection and predicted changes in cellular composition within granulomas over time. By conducting in silico experiments, we have identified a previously unappreciated level of inter-granuloma diversity in terms of anti-leishmanial activity. Our data suggest that IL-10 produced by infected Kupffer cells at the core of the granuloma plays a dominant local regulatory role. The model only simulates events within the granuloma that lead to control of parasite load and does not take into account possible regulatory effects of IL-10 outside this environment.
Transcriptional regulation can be viewed as a computational device, with transcription factor concentrations as inputs and expression level as the output. We show that different parameterizations of a simple chemical kinetic model of transcriptional regulation are able to approximate all four standard arithmetic operations: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division, as well as various equality and inequality operations. This is in contrast to other studies that emphasize logical or digital notions of computation in biological networks. We analyze the accuracy and precision of these approximations, showing that they depend on different sets of parameters, and are thus independently tunable. We demonstrate that networks of these “arithmetic” genes can be combined to accomplish yet more complicated computations by designing and simulating a network that detects statistically significant elevations in a time-varying signal. We also consider the problem of approximating analytic functions, showing that this can be achieved by allowing multiple transcription factor binding sites on the promoter. These observations are important for the interpretation of naturally occurring networks and imply new possibilities for the design of synthetic networks.
Chikungunya virus ( CHIKV ) is an RNA virus transmitted by mosquitoes in both sylvatic and urban cycles. CHIKV infection leads to a febrile illness, Chikungunya fever ( CHIKF ), commonly associated with more intense and debilitating outcomes. In Brazil, CHIKV arrived in 2014 through two independent introductions: the Asian/Caribbean genotype entered through the North region and the African ECSA genotype was imported through the Northeast region. Following their initial introduction, both genotypes established their urban cycle among large naive human populations, causing several outbreaks in the Americas. We sequenced CHIKV genomes from a recent outbreak in the Northeast region of Brazil, employing an in-house developed Next-Generation Sequencing ( NGS ) protocol capable of directly detecting multiple known CHIKV genotypes from clinical positive samples. Our results demonstrate that both Asian/Caribbean and ECSA genotypes expanded their ranges, reaching cocirculation in the Northeast region of Brazil. In addition, our NGS data supports the findings of simultaneous infection by these two genotypes, suggesting that coinfection might be more common than previously thought in highly endemic areas.
Horizontal gene transfer ( HGT ) is a process by which bacteria acquire new genes from their environment, increasing their genetic diversity and ability to colonize new niches, including the human host. H-NS is a global modulator that targets both core genome and HGT genes, silencing gene expression in response to external stimuli. Here, we show that H-NS discriminates and differentially modulates core and HGT DNA. As an example, the plasmid R27-encoded H-NS protein selectively silences HGT genes and does not interfere with core genome regulation. In contrast, chromosomally-encoded H-NS requires a helper protein, Hha, to differentially modulate HGT and core genes. H-NS-Hha complexes silence HGT DNA, while H-NS homoligomers modulate core genes. The presence of Hha-like proteins is restricted to the Enterobacteriaceae family, and conjugative plasmids encoding H-NS variants have been isolated only from members of this family. The H-NS system in enteric bacteria presents unique evolutionary features. The capacity to selectively discriminate between core and HGT DNA may help to maintain horizontally transmitted DNA in a silent form, giving these bacteria a competitive advantage in adapting to new environments, including host colonization.
Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by Leishmania parasites, which are transmitted by sandflies and cause a range of disease phenotypes in the host. Genome sequencing of three Leishmania species, L. major, L. infantum, and L. braziliensis, has revealed a highly conserved gene content and synteny across the genus, with only a small number of genes differentially distributed between the species. We have used customised oligonucleotide microarrays to confirm that all of the differentially distributed genes are expressed in the disease-promoting intracellular amastigotes of these species, with only a few subject to regulation at the RNA level. In the first large-scale study of gene expression in L. braziliensis, we show that only ∼9% of the genes analysed are regulated in their RNA expression during the L. braziliensis life cycle. Comparing amastigote gene expression profiles between species confirms that Leishmania transcriptomes undergo little regulation, but also identifies conserved genes that are regulated differently between species in the host. We have also investigated whether host immune competence influences parasite gene expression, by comparing RNA expression profiles in L. major amastigotes derived from either wild-type ( BALB/c ) or immunologically compromised ( Rag2−/− γc−/− ) mice. While parasite dissemination from the site of infection is enhanced in the Rag2−/− γc−/− genetic background, parasite RNA expression profiles are unperturbed. These findings support the hypothesis that Leishmania amastigotes are pre-adapted for intracellular survival and undergo little dynamic modulation of gene expression at the RNA level.
Amphimeriasis, a fish-borne disease caused by the liver fluke Amphimerus spp., has recently been reported as endemic in the tropical Pacific side of Ecuador with a high prevalence in humans and domestic animals. The diagnosis of amphimeriasis is currently based on stool examination to identify parasite eggs, but this method lacks sensitivity and the morphology of the eggs may be confounded with other liver and intestinal flukes. No immunological or molecular methods have been developed to date. Here, we report the development and evaluation of a novel loop-mediated isothermal amplification ( LAMP ) assay, named LAMPhimerus, for detecting Amphimerus sp. DNA in human stool samples. The LAMP assay was designed to target a sequence of the Amphimerus sp. internal transcribed spacer 2 region and was optimized using DNA obtained from adult worms recovered from animals. The sensitivity and specificity of the LAMP assay were evaluated and found to be 76. 67% and 80. 77%, respectively, when tested with 44 human stool samples collected from localities where the fluke is endemic. The LAMP assay was shown to be highly specific for Amphimerus sp. DNA and had a detection limit of 1 pg of genomic DNA. The LAMPhimerus assay has the potential to be adapted for field diagnosis and disease surveillance in amphimeriasis-endemic areas.
Autophagosome-lysosome fusion is a critical step in autophagy, the process by which cells recycle damaged organelles and proteins. In Drosophila, the SNARE protein Syntaxin17 ( Syx17 ) forms a complex with Snap29 and Vamp7/8 to promote autophagosome-lysosome fusion. Here, we show that another SNARE protein, Ykt6, is also required for autophagosome clearance in Drosophila. We find that loss of Ykt6 leads to large-scale accumulation of autophagosomes that are unable to fuse with lysosomes to form autolysosomes. Ykt6 localizes to lysosomes and autolysosomes and forms a SNARE complex with Syx17 and Snap29. However, Ykt6 can be outcompeted from this complex by Vamp7, and overexpression of Vamp7 rescues the fusion defect of Ykt6 loss-of-function cells. We also show that a point mutant form of Ykt6 that is thought to be important for fusion-competent SNARE complex assembly retains normal autophagic activity and restores full viability in mutant animals. These data suggest that Ykt6 acts as a non-conventional, regulatory SNARE in autophagosome-lysosome fusion and that Vamp7 is directly involved in membrane fusion.
Nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae ( NTHI ), a commensal inhabitant of the human nasopharyngeal mucosa, is commonly associated with opportunistic infections of the upper and lower respiratory tracts. NTHI is able to avert the bactericidal effects of host-derived antimicrobial peptides ( AMPs ), which are a critical component of the host innate immune defense. The Sap ( sensitivity to antimicrobial peptides ) ABC transporter equips NTHI to resist AMPs, but the mechanism of this resistance has remained undefined. We previously demonstrated that the periplasmic binding protein SapA is required for NTHI virulence in vivo. Here, we show that SapA functions to directly counter AMP lethality during NTHI infection by delivering AMPs to the Sap inner membrane complex for transport into the bacterial cytoplasm. We observed that AMPs localize to the bacterial cytoplasm of the parental NTHI strain and are susceptible to cytoplasmic peptidase activity. In contrast, AMPs accumulated in the periplasm of bacteria lacking a functional Sap permease complex. These data support a mechanism of Sap mediated import of AMPs, a novel strategy to reduce periplasmic and inner membrane accumulation of these host defense peptides. This is the first direct evidence that SapA contributes to bacterial virulence by conferring protection from AMP lethality in vivo.
Active degradation of the multiple antibiotic resistance activator ( MarA ) in Escherichia coli controls the coordination of its downstream targets. MarA has a short half-life of 1–3 minutes due to Lon protease activity and regulates over 60 downstream targets involved in antibiotic resistance and stress response. We show that modifying MarA’s half-life either by knocking down the protease that targets it via CRISPRi or by engineering MarA to protect it from degradation impacts both the rate of coordination and the maximum coordination that downstream genes can achieve. In the context of multi-gene regulation, trade-offs between these properties show that perfect information fidelity and instantaneous coordination cannot coexist. Increasing MarA’s half-life increases the maximum coordinated diversity between downstream genes, but the rate at which the wild type and MarA fusion generate coordination between downstream genes is different. This suggests that active degradation may allow for a more responsive and agile signaling network. Alternatively, the capacity of a degraded activator to generate phenotypic diversity rapidly may be useful for a few remaining cells to regenerate diversity following antibiotic challenge.
Leishmania major is a protozoan parasite that causes cutaneous leishmaniasis. In this study, we investigated the role of MAP kinase phosphatase 2 ( MKP-2 ) in the immune response to L. major infection in C57BL/6 mice. We have previously shown that MKP-2 deficient mice are unable to control infection with Leishmania mexicana. However, in the present study, we found that MKP-2 deficient mice were able to control L. major infection with a healing response similar to wild-type mice. Despite this, we observed a reduced TH1 response in MKP-2 deficient mice with lower levels of IFN-γ and TNF-α producing CD4+ and CD8+ T cells and lower antigen stimulated spleen cell IFN-γ production. We also found that MKP-2 deficient macrophages were more permissive to L. major infection than wild-type macrophages due to increased Arginase-1 expression and reduced iNOS activity. However, LPS/IFN-γ activation was equally effective at controlling parasite growth in MKP-2 deficient and wild-type macrophages. Consequently, the overall TH1/TH2 balance was unaltered in MKP-2 deficient mice and no significant change in disease phenotype was observed.
The development of the ductal network in the mammalian pancreas is a poorly understood process. The pancreas is a branched organ that does not exhibit stereotypic branching patterns and contains a network of ducts that undergo a transition from unconnected microlumens to a mesh of interconnected ducts and finally to a treelike structure. Here, we show that the pancreatic network exhibits stereotypic traits at each developmental stage and changes systematically as the pancreas matures. Using in silico modeling, we deconstruct the main steps of network development into a set of simple rules likely to be conserved for many other glands. The early stage of the network is explained by noisy, redundant duct connection as new microlumens form. The later transition is attributed to pruning of the network based on the flux of fluid running through the pancreatic network into the duodenum. We show that the pancreatic ductal system has stereotypic traits at each stage and that its remodeling can be quantified by standard network measures. Our analysis reveals that although the branches of the pancreas are different between individual mice, the pancreatic network structure is stereotypic at each stage and changes systematically as the pancreas matures.
Kinesin motor proteins drive intracellular transport by coupling ATP hydrolysis to conformational changes that mediate directed movement along microtubules. Here, we report a comprehensive analysis of the structural and dynamical features of the kinesin motor domain. We analyzed 114 experimental structures and the results of conventional and accelerated molecular dynamics simulations to map the structural dynamics of the kinesin motor domain. We found that all experimental structures reside in one of three distinct conformational clusters: ATP-like, ADP-like and Eg5 inhibitor-bound. These groups differ in the orientation of key functional elements, most notably the microtubule binding α4–α5, loop8 subdomain and α2b-β4-β6-β7 motor domain tip. However, group membership does not correlate with the nature of the bound nucleotide in a given structure. Instead, groupings are coincident with distinct neck-linker orientations. Accelerated molecular dynamics simulations of ATP, ADP and nucleotide free Eg5 indicate that all three nucleotide states can sample the major crystallographically observed conformations. Our results indicate that the reported ATP and ADP-like conformations of kinesin are intrinsically accessible regardless of nucleotide state and support a model where neck-linker docking leads to a tighter coupling of the microtubule and nucleotide binding regions. Furthermore, simulations highlight sites critical for large-scale conformational changes and the allosteric coupling between distal functional sites.
Bioluminescent reporter systems based on the bacterial Lux system are widely used to measure gene expression. However, the relationship between bioluminescence and gene expression is not straightforward, as bioluminescence is influenced by nonlinear molecular and enzyme dynamics of the Lux system. To address this limitation, we have developed a new mathematical model that relates gene expression to light output in Lux promoter assays. The model includes newly discovered experimental evidence for product inhibition of the LuxAB reaction by FMNH2 and shows a nonlinear relationship between gene expression and light output. We have used the model to provide a method to infer gene expression from light output that can be generally applied to experiments using Lux reporter assays. The model associates changes in bioluminescence with promoter activity rather than viability, so it is important to ensure that there is minimal loss of viability due to experimental conditions in order to correctly interpret the model output. We show examples where a decrease in bioluminescence would be better interpreted as a switching off of the promoter, or where an increase in bioluminescence would be better interpreted as a longer period of gene expression. This approach could benefit all users of Lux technology.
Enterovirus 71 ( EV71 ) and coxsackievirus A16 ( CVA16 ) are the major causes of hand, foot and mouth disease ( HFMD ) in children. The capsid binder GPP3 has been shown to inhibit the replication of these viruses. Here, we present the crystal structure of CVA16 in complex with GPP3, which reveals the key residues involved in interactions with the inhibitor. Based on this model, we performed in silico docking to investigate the interactions with two next-generation capsid binders, NLD and ALD, which we show to be potent inhibitors of a panel of enteroviruses with potentially interesting pharmacological properties. A meta-analysis was performed using the available structural information to obtain a deeper insight into those structural features required for capsid binders to interact effectively and also those that confer broad-spectrum anti-enterovirus activity.
Necrotic is a serine proteinase inhibitor in Drosophila melanogaster that regulates the Toll-mediated immune response to fungal and Gram-positive bacterial infections. Following immune-challenge, a proteolytic cascade is activated which signals through the Toll receptor, resulting in the synthesis of antibiotic peptides in the fat-body and their export to the haemolymph. Necrotic is synthesised in the fat-body, but its site of degradation has been unclear. We demonstrate that Necrotic is removed from the haemolymph in two groups of giant cells: the garland and pericardial athrocytes. The serpin is processed through multi-vesicular bodies and delivered to the lysosome, where it co-localises with the ubiquitin-binding protein, HRS. Mutations which block late endosome/lysosome fusion cause accumulation of Necrotic-positive endosomes, even in the absence of infection. We identify the Lipophorin Receptor-1 ( LpR1 ) as an enhancer of the immune response and show that uptake of Necrotic from the haemolymph is blocked by a chromosomal deletion of LpR1. In conclusion, we identify the cells and the receptor molecule responsible for the uptake and degradation of the Necrotic serpin in Drosophila melanogaster. The scavenging of serpin/proteinase complexes may be a critical step in the regulation of proteolytic cascades.
In the sea urchin larva, left–right ( LR ) asymmetry is established by opposing Nodal and BMP signals. Nodal signaling prevents the formation of the rudiment on the right side, but the opposing pathway to Nodal signaling during LR axis establishment is not clear. Here, we show that BMP signaling is activated in the left coelomic pouch, specifically in the veg2 lineage, but not in the small micromeres. By perturbing BMP activities, we demonstrated that BMP signaling is required for activating the expression of the left-sided genes and the formation of the left-sided structures. On the other hand, Nodal signals on the right side inhibit BMP signaling and control LR asymmetric separation and apoptosis of the small micromeres. Our findings show that BMP signaling is the positive signal for left-sided development in sea urchins, suggesting that the opposing roles of Nodal and BMP signals in establishing LR asymmetry are conserved in deuterostomes.
Human cytomegalovirus ( HCMV ) lytic infection is strictly synchronized with the host cell cycle. We show that the block to viral immediate early ( IE ) gene expression during S and G2 phases of the cell cycle can be overcome by both genotoxic stress and chemical inhibitors of cellular DNA replication, pointing to the involvement of checkpoint-dependent signaling pathways in controlling IE gene repression. Checkpoint-dependent rescue of IE expression strictly requires p53 and is mimicked by proteasomal inhibition in a p53 dependent manner. Requirement for the cyclin dependent kinase ( CDK ) inhibitor p21 downstream of p53 suggests a pivotal role for CDKs in controlling IE gene repression in S/G2. Treatment of S/G2 cells with the CDK inhibitor roscovitine alleviates IE repression independently of p53. Importantly, CDK inhibition also overcomes the block to IE expression during quiescent infection of NTera2 ( NT2 ) cells. Thus, a timely block to CDK activity not only secures phase specificity of the cell cycle dependent HCMV IE gene expression program, but in addition plays a hitherto unrecognized role in preventing the establishment of a latent-like state.
HIV-1 elite controllers ( EC ) are a small subgroup of patients who control HIV-1 replication in the absence of antiretroviral therapy. These patients are characterized by highly functional HIV-1-specific T cell responses. However, the mechanisms supporting the evolution of effective HIV-1-specific T cell immunity in these patients remain undefined. Here, we show that exposure of conventional dendritic cells ( cDCs ) from EC to HIV-1 leads to a rapid and sustained production of type I interferons and upregulation of several interferon-stimulated effector genes. These cell-intrinsic immune responses are associated with a reduced induction of SAMHD1 and LEDGF/p75, and an accumulation of viral reverse transcripts. Importantly, improved cell-intrinsic immune recognition of HIV-1 in cDCs from elite controllers translates into stronger abilities to stimulate and expand HIV-1-specific CD8 T cell responses. Our data suggest that cell-intrinsic type I interferon secretion in dendritic cells plays an important role in the induction of effective HIV-1-specific CD8 T cells, and may be helpful for eliciting functional T cell immunity against HIV-1 for preventative or therapeutic clinical purposes.
We have developed a simple buoyancy-based screening method for identifying Drosophila larvae with increased levels of stored fat. Using this approach, we have identified 66 genes that when mutated increase organismal fat levels. Among these was a sirtuin family member, Sir2. We show that knockdown of Sir2 in the larval fat body results in increased fat levels and that Sir2 restricts fat accumulation in individual cells of the fat body in a cell-autonomous manner. Consistent with this function, changes in the expression of metabolic enzymes in Sir2 mutants point to a shift away from catabolism. Surprisingly, although Sir2 is typically upregulated under conditions of starvation, Sir2 mutant larvae survive better than wild type under conditions of amino-acid starvation as long as sugars are provided. Our findings point to a Sir2-mediated pathway that activates a catabolic response to amino-acid starvation irrespective of the sugar content of the diet.
Asymmetric cell division is essential for generating cellular diversity in many animal species. In this study, we investigated the evolution of mitotic spindle behavior during the first asymmetric embryonic division of nematodes. We recorded the first embryonic division of 42 species of nematodes closely related to Caenorhabditis elegans, which is an excellent model system to study the biophysical properties of asymmetric spindle positioning. Our collection of 128 strains from 27 Caenorhabditis and 15 non-Caenorhabditis species constitutes a powerful collection of subcellular phenotypes to study the evolution of various cellular processes across species. Although all species underwent an asymmetric first cell division, they exhibited large intra- and inter-species variations in the degree of cell asymmetry and in several parameters controlling spindle movement, including spindle oscillation, elongation, and displacement. Notably, these parameters changed frequently during evolution with no apparent directionality in the species phylogeny, with the exception of spindle transverse oscillations, which were an evolutionary innovation at the base of the Caenorhabditis genus. Importantly, spindle elongation, displacement, and oscillation each evolved independently. This finding contrasts starkly with expectations based on C. elegans studies and reveals previously unrecognized evolutionary changes in spindle mechanics.
Salmonella Typhimurium ( S. Typhimurium ) and Escherichia coli ( E. coli ) have identical OmpR proteins, which are DNA binding proteins that regulate gene expression in response to environmental changes. However, despite their identical amino acid sequences, the OmpR regulons of S. Typhimurium and E. coli are largely divergent. In S. Typhimurium, OmpR expression is induced by acid pH, whereas in E. coli, it is not. This difference is due to species-specific differences in the promoter regions of the ompR genes and the EnvZ sensor kinase. The ompR gene in S. Typhimurium has an acid-inducible promoter and is positively autoregulated by EnvZ following acid shock. In contrast, the ompR gene in E. coli does not have an acid-inducible promoter and is not autoregulated by EnvZ. The OmpR regulon in S. Typhimurium overlaps with that of E. coli at only 15 genes and includes many horizontally acquired genes, including virulence genes, that are not present in E. coli. We found that OmpR binds to its genomic targets in higher abundance when the DNA is relaxed, which occurs in S. Typhimurium as a result of acid stress and is a requirement for optimal expression of its virulence genes.
Chlamydia trachomatis, a strict intracellular pathogen, secretes a novel effector protein called NUE ( Nuclear Effector ) via a type III secretion mechanism. NUE is a histone methyltransferase that targets histones H2B, H3, and H4, as well as itself ( automethylation ). This is the first description of a bacterial effector that directly targets mammalian histones. NUE is secreted by Chlamydia and translocates to the host cell nucleus, where it associates with chromatin. In vitro methylation assays confirmed NUE's enzymatic activity as a histone methyltransferase. Mutants deficient in automethylation demonstrated diminished activity towards histones, suggesting that automethylation functions to enhance enzymatic activity. We propose to designate CT737 and its homologs in other chlamydiae genomes as NUE, as it is the first nuclear effector identified in chlamydiae. NUE has a preference for mammalian histones over chlamydial Hc1 when used at equal concentrations. Automethylation of NUE may enhance its methyltransferase activity by increasing its affinity for target substrates.
Human height is a highly heritable complex trait, with 80%–90% of variation explained by genetic factors. Genome-wide association studies ( GWAS ) have identified many common additive variants influencing height, but little attention has been given to the potential role of recessive genetic effects. Here, we investigated genome-wide recessive effects on adult height in over 35, 000 people from 21 different population samples. We found a highly significant inverse association between height and genome-wide homozygosity, equivalent to a height reduction of up to 3 cm in the offspring of first cousins compared with the offspring of unrelated individuals. This effect remained after controlling for socio-economic status, an important confounder. However, there was a high degree of heterogeneity among populations: the direction of the effect was consistent across most population samples, but the effect size differed significantly among populations. These results predict that multiple, rare, recessive variants influence human height.
Plasmodium falciparum malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In this study, we investigated the phenotype and function of blood monocytes ( MO ) in patients with acute uncomplicated malaria and healthy malaria-exposed individuals. We hypothesized that discrete MO subpopulations are induced during malaria infection and are associated with anti-parasitic activity. We characterized the phenotype of blood MO by flow cytometry and evaluated MO defense function by an in vitro antibody dependent cellular inhibition ( ADCI ) assay. We found that the percentages and absolute numbers of CD16+ MO and CCR2+CX3CR1+ MO were high in a majority of patients with acute uncomplicated malaria. We also found that expression of CCR2 and CX3CR1 on the CD14high ( hi ) MO subset defined two subgroups of patients that differed significantly in their functional ability to limit parasite growth through the ADCI mechanism. Patients with the highest percentages and absolute numbers of CD14hiCCR2+CX3CR1+ MO and the highest mean levels of ADCI activity had lower blood parasitemias than patients with low numbers of CD14hiCCR2+CX3CR1+ MO. These results suggest that some patients' MO can exert a strong ADCI activity during a malaria attack and that discrete MO subpopulations are induced during malaria infection and are associated with anti-parasitic activity.
Schistosoma mansoni infection is associated with an increased frequency of highly HIV-susceptible CD4 T cell subsets in the blood of HIV-uninfected Ugandan men, but not in the foreskin, according to a cross-sectional study of 34 HIV- and malaria-uninfected men who volunteered for elective circumcision. The study found that S. mansoni-infected men had a higher frequency of Th1, Th17, and Th22 cells in the blood compared to uninfected men. Additionally, Th17 cells in the blood of S. mansoni-infected men demonstrated enhanced function, producing multiple cytokines. However, these immune alterations were not observed in the foreskin tissue of S. mansoni-infected men. The study suggests that S. mansoni infection is associated with an increased frequency of highly HIV-susceptible T cell subsets in the blood, but these immune changes do not extend to the foreskin, which is the primary site of HIV acquisition in heterosexual Ugandan men.
Filarial nematodes, the causative agents of filarial diseases, maintain a mutualistic relationship with the endosymbiont Wolbachia. Depletion of Wolbachia has been shown to produce profound defects in nematode development, fertility, and viability, making it a promising approach for treating filarial diseases. Here, we demonstrate that depletion of Wolbachia from filarial nematodes leads to extensive apoptosis in adult germline cells, embryos, and somatic cells of microfilariae and fourth-stage larvae ( L4 ). Using whole mount confocal microscopy, we show that apoptosis occurs in the majority of embryonic cells that had not been infected with Wolbachia prior to antibiotic treatment, suggesting that the effects of Wolbachia depletion on apoptosis are non-cell autonomous. The pattern of apoptosis correlates closely with the nematode tissues and processes initially perturbed following depletion of Wolbachia, including embryogenesis and long-term sterilization, which are sustained for several months until the premature death of the adult worms. Our observations provide a cellular mechanism to account for the sustained reductions in microfilarial loads and interruption of transmission that occurs prior to macrofilaricidal activity following antibiotic therapy of filarial nematodes.
Plasmodium falciparum, the parasite responsible for the deadliest form of malaria, requires extracellular pantothenate to proliferate during the blood stage of its life cycle. Pantothenate is converted into coenzyme A ( CoA ) via a series of five enzymes, with pantothenate kinase ( PfPanK ) being the first enzyme in this pathway. Antiplasmodial pantothenate analogues, such as pantothenol and CJ-15, 801, have been shown to kill the parasite by targeting CoA biosynthesis or utilisation. However, the exact mechanism of action of these analogues has not been elucidated. Here, we show that continuous drug-pressuring with pantothenol or CJ-15, 801 selects for mutations in one of the two putative PanK genes of P. falciparum, Pfpank1. These mutations significantly alter PfPanK activity, with some conferring a fitness cost, consistent with Pfpank1 coding for a functional PanK that is essential for normal growth. The mutants exhibit a different sensitivity profile to recently-described antiplasmodial pantothenate analogues, with one line being hypersensitive. We provide evidence consistent with different pantothenate analogue classes having different mechanisms of action: some inhibit CoA biosynthesis while others inhibit CoA-utilising enzymes.
Genome-wide association ( GWA ) studies were performed to identify genetic variants associated with the PR interval, a measure of atrial and atrioventricular nodal conduction time, in African American individuals from four cohorts ( n = 6, 247 ). Genotyping was performed using the Affymetrix 6. 0 microarray, and imputation was performed for 2. 8 million single nucleotide polymorphisms ( SNPs ) using combined YRI and CEU HapMap phase II panels. We observed a genome-wide significant association ( p<2. 5×10−8 ) between the PR interval and a SNP ( rs3922844 ) within the gene encoding the cardiac sodium channel ( SCN5A ) in two of the four cohorts and in the meta-analysis. The signal explained 2% of PR interval variability in African Americans ( beta = 5. 1 msec per minor allele, 95% CI = 4. 1–6. 1, p = 3×10−23 ). This SNP was also associated with PR interval in individuals of European ancestry ( n = 14, 042 ), but with a smaller effect size ( p for heterogeneity <0. 001 ) and variability explained ( 0. 5% ). Further meta-analysis of the four cohorts identified genome-wide significant associations with SNPs in SCN10A ( rs6798015 ), MEIS1 ( rs10865355 ), and TBX5 ( rs7312625 ) that were highly correlated with SNPs identified in European and Asian GWA studies.
Tomato mosaic virus ( ToMV ) is a positive-strand RNA virus that replicates its genomic RNA in replication complexes formed on intracellular membranes. Previous studies have shown that a host seven-pass transmembrane protein TOM1 is necessary for efficient ToMV multiplication. In this study, we show that a small GTP-binding protein ARL8, along with TOM1, is co-purified with the ToMV 180K replication protein from solubilized membranes of ToMV-infected tobacco ( Nicotiana tabacum ) cells. This suggests that a complex containing ToMV replication proteins, TOM1, and ARL8 is formed on membranes in infected cells. In Arabidopsis thaliana, ARL8 consists of four family members, and simultaneous mutations in two specific ARL8 genes completely inhibited tobamovirus multiplication. In an in vitro ToMV RNA translation-replication system, the lack of either TOM1 or ARL8 proteins inhibited the production of replicative-form RNA, indicating that TOM1 and ARL8 are required for efficient negative-strand RNA synthesis.
In the locust olfactory system, two types of inhibitory motifs, feed-forward ( FF ) and feedback ( FB ) inhibition, have been proposed to shape the firing patterns of Kenyon cells ( KCs ) in the mushroom body ( MB ). FF inhibition was previously thought to be mediated by a population of inhibitory cells in the lateral horn ( LH ), while FB inhibition is mediated by a single inhibitory cell, the giant GABAergic neuron ( GGN ). We developed two models of the locust olfactory system to compare the properties of FF and FB inhibition. We found that both inhibitory motifs were able to maintain sparse KC responses and provide optimal odor discrimination. However, only FB inhibition was able to create a phase response consistent with data recorded in vivo. Our results suggest that GGN is potentially capable of providing the primary source of inhibition to the KCs. We also found that GGN-mediated inhibition affects both KCs and lateral horn interneurons ( LHNs ), although both classes of neurons respond differently to odor presentations. Our findings describe general rules for FF versus FB inhibition and provide a better understanding of how inhibitory motifs impact post-synaptic neuronal activity. This knowledge could be used to reveal unknown inhibitory structures within biological networks.
The definitive diagnosis of lyssavirus infection, including rabies, is based on laboratory confirmation. Molecular techniques, such as polymerase chain reaction ( PCR ) based methods, are increasingly used for diagnosing rabies in humans and for epidemiological analyses. However, it remains a key challenge to obtain relevant specificity and sensitivity with these techniques while ensuring that the genetic diversity of lyssaviruses does not compromise detection. We developed a dual combined real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction ( combo RT-qPCR ) method for pan-lyssavirus detection. This method is based on two complementary technologies: a probe-based ( TaqMan ) RT-qPCR for detecting the RABV species ( pan-RABV RT-qPCR ) and a second reaction using an intercalating dye ( SYBR Green ) to detect other lyssavirus species ( pan-lyssa RT-qPCR ). The performance parameters of this combined assay were evaluated with a large panel of primary animal samples covering almost all the genetic variability encountered at the viral species level, and they extended to almost all lyssavirus species characterized to date. This method was also evaluated for the diagnosis of human rabies on 211 biological samples ( positive n = 76 and negative n = 135 ) including saliva, skin and brain biopsies. It detected all 41 human cases of rabies tested and confirmed the sensitivity and the interest of skin biopsy ( 91. 5% ) and saliva ( 54% ) samples for intra-vitam diagnosis of human rabies. Finally, this method was successfully implemented in two rabies reference laboratories in enzootic countries ( Cambodia and Morocco ).
Trypanosomiasis, a disease transmitted by tsetse flies, resulted in more than 50% losses of domestic pigs in the Eastern Region of Ghana in 2007. A control trial was conducted from May 2007 to October 2007 to assess the efficacy of insecticide-treated mosquito nets to control tsetse flies and subsequently reduce the risk of trypanosomiasis in pigs. Two villages were selected, one serving as a control and the other as an experimental village where 24 pigsties were protected with insecticide-treated mosquito nets. The nets were 100 cm high, 150 denier polyester fences with 100 mg/m2 deltamethrin and a UV protector attached to timber poles and planks. Bi-monthly monitoring of tsetse fly densities showed a reduction of more than 90% in the protected village within two months, with further reductions exceeding 95% in subsequent months. In contrast, the tsetse fly population in the control village was not affected, only displaying seasonal variations. The trypanosome prevalence in pigs was also significantly reduced in the protected village, decreasing from 76% to 8% after six months, compared to 60% in the control village.
Reproducibility and transparency in the biomedical literature are major concerns in the scientific community. In this study, we assessed the current status of reproducibility and transparency in a random sample of 441 biomedical journal articles published between 2000 and 2014.
