Only one study provided a full protocol and none made all raw data directly available. Replication studies were rare ( n = 4 ), and only 16 studies had their data included in a subsequent systematic review or meta-analysis. The majority of studies did not mention anything about funding or conflicts of interest. However, the percentage of articles with no statement of conflict decreased substantially between 2000 and 2014 ( 94. 4% in 2000 to 34. 6% in 2014 ), while the percentage of articles reporting statements of conflicts ( 0% in 2000, 15. 4% in 2014 ) or no conflicts ( 5. 6% in 2000, 50. 0% in 2014 ) increased. Articles published in journals in the clinical medicine category were almost twice as likely to not include any information on funding and to have private funding.
Yersinia pestis, the causative agent of primary pneumonic plague, targets alveolar macrophages and neutrophils in the lung during the pre-inflammatory phase of the disease. Using a FRET-based probe, we show that Y. pestis targets alveolar macrophages early during infection of mice, followed by a switch in host cell preference to neutrophils. We also demonstrate that neutrophil influx is unable to limit bacterial growth in the lung and is ultimately responsible for the severe inflammation during the lethal pro-inflammatory phase. The ability of Y. pestis to create a localized protective environment in the lung early during pneumonic plague suggests that it deactivates host innate immune responses. Depletion of roughly 92% of alveolar macrophages had little or no effect on bacterial burden in the lung, indicating that macrophages are not involved in limiting Yersinia survival in the lung. We show that the Y. pestis type III secretion system primarily targets macrophages and neutrophils early during the pre-inflammatory phase of disease.
Visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ), caused by Leishmania ( Leishmania ) infantum in Brazil, is difficult to diagnose in asymptomatic carriers. The aim of this study was to evaluate the performance of serology to identify asymptomatic VL infection in a cohort of 136 participants from an urban area in the Southeast of Brazil. Blood samples were collected in 2001 and tested by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay ( ELISA ) using three different antigens: L. infantum and L. amazonensis crude antigens, and rK39 recombinant protein. Molecular biology techniques ( PCR with Leishmania-generic primer followed by hybridization using L. infantum probe, and PCR with specific primer to L. donovani complex ) were used as reference tests. The presence of Leishmania was confirmed in all kala-azar patients and in 117 ( 86% ) of the cohort participants. Kala-azar patients showed high reactivity in ELISAs, whereas asymptomatic individuals presented low reactivity against the antigens tested. The rK39 antigen showed higher specificity ( 73. 7% ) than L. amazonensis ( 52. 6% ) and L. infantum antigens ( 36. 8% ), but lower sensitivity ( 26. 5% ) than L. amazonensis ( 49. 6% ) and L. infantum ( 41. 0% ). There was low agreement among the different antigens used ( kappa<0. 10 ). Serological tests were inaccurate for diagnosing asymptomatic infections compared to molecular methods, which could lead to misclassification bias in population studies.
Retrotransposons are highly abundant in mammalian genomes and can amplify in pluripotent cells or developing germ cells. However, the mechanisms that silence retrotransposons in germ cells and pluripotent cells are not well understood. Here, we show that cryptic repetitive element probes present in Illumina and Affymetrix gene expression microarray platforms can be used to monitor retrotransposon expression. This computational approach has allowed us to identify the histone deacetylase Hdac1 as a component of the retrotransposon silencing machinery in mouse embryonic stem cells, and to determine the retrotransposon targets of Hdac1 in these cells. We have also identified retrotransposons that are targets of other silencing mechanisms such as DNA methylation, Eset-mediated histone modification, and Ring1B/Eed-containing polycomb repressive complexes in mouse embryonic stem cells. Furthermore, our analysis suggests that multiple silencing mechanisms are independently targeted to retrotransposons in embryonic stem cells, and that different genomic copies of the same retrotransposon can be differentially sensitive to these silencing mechanisms.
Cryptochrome 2 ( CRY2 ) mediates light control of flowering time in Arabidopsis thaliana. CRY2 interacts with CRY2-interacting bHLH 1 ( CIB1 ) in response to blue light to activate the transcription of Flowering Locus T ( FT ). In vitro, CIB1 binds to the canonical E-box ( CACGTG ) with much higher affinity than to non-canonical E-box ( CANNTG ) DNA sequences. However, in vivo, CIB1 binds to the chromatin region of the FT promoter, which only contains non-canonical E-box sequences. We show that CRY2 also interacts with at least CIB5 in response to blue light, but not in darkness or in response to other wavelengths of light. CIB1, CIB2, CIB4, and CIB5 act redundantly to activate the transcription of FT and are positive regulators of CRY2-mediated flowering. CIB1 and other CIB proteins form heterodimers, and some of the heterodimers have a higher binding affinity than the CIB homodimers to the non-canonical E-box in vitro. This explains why CIB1 and other CIBs bind to the canonical E-box with a higher affinity in vitro, whereas they are associated with the non-canonical E-boxes at the FT promoter in vivo.
Intestinal parasites such as hookworm, Trichuris trichuria, Ascaris lumbricoides, and Strongyloides stercoralis are rare in the United States but common in countries from which U. S. -bound refugees travel. These infections may be underdiagnosed or misdiagnosed, leading to potentially serious consequences. We evaluated the costs and benefits of overseas presumptive treatment of parasitic diseases vs. domestic screening/treating vs. no program for an annual cohort of 27, 700 U. S. -bound Asian refugees. We developed an economic decision tree model terminating in Markov processes to estimate the cost and health impacts of four interventions: 1 ) “No Program, ” 2 ) U. S. “Domestic Screening and Treatment, ” 3 ) “Overseas Albendazole and Ivermectin” presumptive treatment, and 4 ) “Overseas Albendazole and Domestic Screening for Strongyloides”. According to the model outcomes, the most effective treatment option is “Overseas Albendazole and Ivermectin, ” which reduces outpatient cases, deaths and hospitalization by around 80% at an estimated net cost of $458, 718 per death averted, or $2, 219/$24, 036 per QALY/life year gained relative to “No Program”. Overseas presumptive treatment for U. S. -bound refugees is a cost-effective intervention that is less expensive and at least as effective as domestic screening and treatment programs. The addition of ivermectin to albendazole reduces the prevalence of chronic strongyloidiasis and the probability of rare, but potentially fatal, disseminated strongyloidiasis.
Nematocida displodere is a new species of microsporidian parasite that infects the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. Unlike other microsporidian parasites of C. elegans, N. displodere has a broad tissue tropism and can infect and replicate in multiple host tissues, including the epidermis, muscle, neurons, intestine, coelomocytes, and seam cells. This is in contrast to Nematocida parisii and Nematocida sp. 1, which exclusively infect and replicate in the intestine. N. displodere is the earliest diverging species of the Nematocida genus and has over 10% of its proteins encoded by a single species-specific family of RING-domain containing proteins of unknown function. These proteins may mediate interactions with the host. N. displodere infection is dependent on C. elegans feeding and is consistent with other invertebrate-infecting microsporidia that display two major pathways for infection, either through ingestion of spores or transovum/transovarial passage. N. displodere is the first pathogen with the capacity to infect the neurons, muscle, or coelomocytes of C. elegans. The discovery and characterization of N. displodere presents a unique model system in C. elegans to study the mechanistic and evolutionary bases of pathogen tissue tropism.
The Cockayne syndrome complementation group B ( CSB ) protein is a member of the SWI2/SNF2 ATP–dependent chromatin remodeler family and is essential for transcription-coupled DNA repair. Mutations in CSB are associated with Cockayne syndrome, a devastating disease characterized by premature aging, sun sensitivity, and neurological and developmental defects. Here, we show that CSB repositions nucleosomes in an ATP–dependent manner in vitro and that this activity is greatly enhanced by the NAP1-like histone chaperones, which we identify as new CSB–binding partners. By mapping functional domains and analyzing CSB derivatives, we demonstrate that chromatin remodeling by the combined activities of CSB and the NAP1-like chaperones is required for efficient transcription-coupled DNA repair. Moreover, we show that chromatin remodeling and repair protein recruitment mediated by CSB are separable activities. The collaboration between CSB and the NAP1-like histone chaperones adds a new dimension to our understanding of the ways in which ATP–dependent chromatin remodelers and histone chaperones can regulate chromatin structure.
Epigenetic variation in the form of DNA methylation has been mapped in five purified human cell types, revealing hundreds of genomic loci with high inter-individual variation. These loci, termed Variably Methylated Regions ( VMRs ), are enriched for functional genomic features such as enhancers and 3’ UTRs. While most VMRs have high heritability, a subset shows highly correlated variation in trans, forming co-regulated networks with low heritability that differ between cell types. These networks are enriched for specific transcription factor binding sites and biological pathways relevant to each tissue. For example, in T cells, a network of 95 co-regulated VMRs is enriched for genes involved in T-cell activation, while in fibroblasts, a network of 34 co-regulated VMRs comprises all four HOX gene clusters and is enriched for control of tissue growth. In neurons, a network of 18 VMRs is enriched for roles in synaptic signaling. We experimentally demonstrated that some VMR networks are responsive to environmental conditions, with methylation levels at these loci changing in a coordinated fashion in trans. These environmentally-responsive VMRs are enriched for imprinted loci, suggesting that they are particularly sensitive to environmental conditions.
Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral disease that can be difficult to diagnose in the early stages of infection. Serological tests for IgM and IgG are commonly used in clinical laboratories to diagnose dengue and differentiate between primary and secondary infections. However, these tests can be less sensitive in the early stages of infection. Dengue virus non-structural protein 1 ( NS1 ) has been identified as an early marker for acute dengue and is typically present between days 1–9 post-onset of illness. We evaluated the performance of a newly developed Panbio Dengue Early Rapid test for NS1 in combination with a commercial IgM/IgG rapid test to determine if it can improve diagnostic sensitivity. The test was evaluated in a retrospective study in Vietnam with 198 acute laboratory-confirmed positive and 100 negative samples, and in Malaysia with 263 laboratory-confirmed positive and 30 negative samples. The sensitivity and specificity of the test were 69. 2% and 96% respectively in Vietnam, and 68. 9% and 96. 7% respectively in Malaysia. Importantly, when the Dengue Early Rapid test was used in combination with the IgM/IgG test, the sensitivity increased to 93. 0%. This study highlights that using dengue NS1 antigen detection in combination with anti-glycoprotein E IgM and IgG serology can significantly increase the sensitivity of acute dengue diagnosis and extends the possible window of detection to include very early acute samples.
Transat is a new computational method for detecting the conserved helices of functional RNA structures, including transient, pseudo-knotted, and alternative structures. Unlike existing RNA structure prediction methods, which assume a unique functional RNA structure and do not predict functional features required for in vivo folding, Transat detects conserved helices of high statistical significance. We have evaluated the performance of Transat and shown that it is able to predict the structural features of known reference structures, including pseudo-knotted ones, as well as those of known alternative structural configurations. Transat can also identify unstructured sub-sequences bound by other molecules and provides evidence for new helices which may define folding pathways. This supports the notion that homologous RNA sequences not only assume a similar reference RNA structure, but also fold similarly in vivo. Unlike existing methods for predicting folding pathways, Transat works in a comparative way, highlighting conserved features and not requiring a detailed knowledge of the cellular environment.
Plant immunity in Arabidopsis is mediated by a highly buffered biological network that controls inducible immunity. This network is comprised of four sub-networks: the salicylate ( SA ), jasmonate ( JA ), ethylene ( ET ), and phytoalexin-deficient 4 ( PAD4 ) signaling sectors. These sectors interact with one another to compensate for loss of function in individual components, conferring resilience against pathogen effectors that target and disable plant immune signaling proteins. Through a network reconstitution strategy, we have resolved systems-level regulatory mechanisms underlying the Arabidopsis transcriptome response to the immune stimulant flagellin-22 ( flg22 ). These mechanisms show widespread evidence of interactions among major sub-networks in the flg22-responsive transcriptome. Many of these interactions result in network buffering, which conceals the identity of network components. We demonstrate that many of the regulatory mechanisms we resolved are not detectable by the traditional genetic approach of single-gene null-mutant analysis. Similar to potential pathogenic perturbations, null-mutant effects on immune signaling can be buffered by the network. Our work shows that high-order perturbation at the scale of signaling sectors and dynamic transcriptional profiling together can help in deciphering the regulation of a complex network, the plant immune signaling network.
Neuroepithelial patterning is a critical step in the development of the central nervous system. In Drosophila, neuroepithelial patterning of the embryonic optic placode gives rise to the larval eye primordium and the optic lobe primordium. We have identified a genetic network that regulates the balance between larval eye and optic lobe precursors, as well as between primary and secondary photoreceptor ( PR ) precursors. The proneural factor Atonal ( Ato ) specifies larval eye precursors, while the orphan nuclear receptor Tailless ( Tll ) is crucial for the specification of optic lobe precursors. The Hedgehog and Notch signaling pathways act upstream of Ato and Tll to coordinate neural precursor specification in a timely manner. The correct spatial placement of the boundary between Ato and Tll is required to control the precise number of primary and secondary PR precursors. Notch signaling also controls a binary cell fate decision, thus acting at the top of a cascade of transcription factor interactions to define PR subtype identity.
Human ß-defensin 1 ( hBD1 ) is a ubiquitously expressed endogenous antimicrobial peptide that exhibits distinct antimicrobial activities depending on its redox state. Here, we show that the reduced form of hBD1 ( hBD1red ) forms a net-like structure that entraps bacteria and prevents their transmigration, independent of bacterial killing. In contrast, the oxidized form of hBD1 ( hBD1ox ) does not form such a structure. Using electron microscopy, we detected a net-like structure surrounding bacteria treated with hBD1red, but not with hBD1ox. A transmigration assay demonstrated that hBD1-derived nets capture bacteria and inhibit their transmigration, independent of bacterial killing. These nets are stable in the presence of human duodenal secretion with a high amount of proteases and can completely prevent migration of hBD1-resistant pathogens. In contrast to other defensins, such as Paneth cell-derived human α-defensin 6 ( HD6 ), cysteins are necessary for net formation by hBD1red. This redox-dependent function serves as an additional mechanism of action for hBD1 and differs from net formation by other defensins. While hBD1red and hBD1ox have distinct antimicrobial profiles and functions, only the reduced form provides additional host protection by entrapping bacteria in extracellular net structures preventing bacterial invasion.
Deficiency of the Lowe syndrome protein OCRL1 causes a defect in endocytosis in the zebrafish pronephric tubule, a model for the mammalian renal tubule. This coincides with a reduction in levels of the scavenger receptor megalin and its accumulation in endocytic compartments, consistent with reduced recycling within the endocytic pathway. We also observe reduced numbers of early endocytic compartments and enlarged vacuolar endosomes in the sub-apical region of pronephric cells. Cell polarity within the pronephric tubule is unaffected in mutant embryos. The OCRL1-deficient embryos exhibit a mild ciliogenesis defect, but this cannot account for the observed impairment of endocytosis. Catalytic activity of OCRL1 is required for renal tubular endocytosis and the endocytic defect can be rescued by suppression of PIP5K. These results indicate that OCRL1 is required for endocytic trafficking in vivo, and strongly support the hypothesis that endocytic defects are responsible for the renal tubulopathy in Lowe syndrome and Dent-2 disease. Moreover, our results reveal PIP5K as a potential therapeutic target for Lowe syndrome and Dent-2 disease.
Rift Valley fever ( RVF ) is a mosquito-borne viral zoonosis that affects both livestock and wild ruminants. The disease is known to occur in cycles of 5–15 years in the Eastern Africa region and the Horn of Africa, following unusual high precipitations that lead to sustained flooding. In recent years, evidence of RVF transmission during the inter-epidemic periods in some parts of the African continent has increasingly been reported. We investigated the presence of and the determinants for inter-epidemic RVF transmission in an area experiencing annual flooding in southern Tanzania. A cross-sectional sero-survey was conducted in randomly selected cattle, sheep and goats in the Kilombero river valley from May to August 2011, approximately four years after the 2006/07 RVF outbreak in Tanzania. An overall seroprevalence of 11. 3% ( n = 1680 ) was recorded; 5. 5% in animals born after the 2006/07 RVF outbreak and 22. 7% in animals present during the outbreak. There was a linear increase in prevalence in the post-epidemic annual cohorts. The spatial distribution of seroprevalence exhibited a few hotspots. Animals living >15 km from the flood plain were more likely to have antibodies than those living <5 km ( OR 1. 92; 95% CI 1. 04–3. 56 ). These findings indicate post-epidemic transmission of RVFV in the study area. The linear increase in seroprevalence in the post-epidemic annual cohorts implies a constant exposure and presence of active foci transmission preceding the survey.
Trypanosoma cruzi, the etiologic agent of Chagas disease, possesses a contractile vacuole complex ( CVC ) that plays a role in osmoregulation. In addition to its role in osmoregulation, the CVC is also involved in the trafficking of glycosylphosphatidylinositol ( GPI ) -anchored proteins to the plasma membrane of the parasite. Here, we show that T. cruzi Rab11 ( TcRab11 ) regulates the trafficking of GPI-anchored trans-sialidase ( TcTS ) to the plasma membrane through the CVC. TcTS is an abundant GPI-anchored protein present in the cell surface of trypomastigotes, where it catalyzes the transfer of sialic acid from host proteins to parasite mucins. We found that TcRab11 localizes to the CVC and that a dominant negative mutant of TcRab11 prevents TcTS from reaching the plasma membrane, resulting in reduced infectivity of the parasite. We also found that TcTS is trafficked to the plasma membrane of T. cruzi by an unconventional pathway involving the CVC and that the CVC is enriched in lipid rafts. Expression of the dominant negative form of TcRab11 makes epimastigotes less responsive to hyposmotic and hyperosmotic stresses.
Rabies post-exposure prophylaxis ( PEP ) regimens were compared in a phase III clinical trial to assess the immunogenicity and safety of a purified chick-embryo cell rabies vaccine ( PCECV ) administered according to a 4-site/1-week intradermal ( ID ) regimen versus the currently recommended 2-site/Thai Red Cross ( TRC ) regimen. A total of 443 participants received the 4-site/1-week regimen and 442 participants received the 2-site/TRC regimen. All participants achieved adequate rabies virus neutralizing antibody ( RVNA ) concentrations by day ( D ) 14. At D49, the percentage of participants with adequate RVNA concentrations was non-inferior in the 4-site/1-week group compared to the 2-site/TRC group, with a difference of -1% ( 95% confidence interval: -2. 4–0. 0 ). The 4-site/1-week regimen had similar safety profiles to the 2-site/TRC regimen, with no vaccination-related serious adverse events reported. The elicited immune responses peaked at D14 and subsequently declined up to D365. RVNA concentrations were consistently lower in participants with concomitant human rabies immunoglobulin ( HRIG ) administration compared to those without. The results suggest that the 4-site/1-week regimen might be an alternative to current recommendations, with potential benefits in terms of improved cost-efficiency and compliance to vaccination.
The salience network ( SN ) plays a crucial role in the human brain's ability to detect and attend to goal-relevant events in a flexible manner. We investigated the dynamic spatiotemporal organization of the SN using high temporal-resolution fMRI data from the Human Connectome Project and novel graph-theoretical techniques. We found that the SN is characterized by several distinctive and robust properties, including the highest levels of flexibility in time-varying connectivity with other brain networks, such as the frontoparietal network ( FPN ), the cingulate–opercular network ( CON ), and the ventral and dorsal attention networks ( VAN and DAN ). We also found that dynamic functional interactions of the SN were among the most spatially varied in the brain, and that SN nodes maintained a consistently high level of network centrality over time, indicating that this network is a hub for facilitating flexible cross-network interactions. Importantly, time-varying connectivity profiles of the SN were distinct from all other prefrontal control systems, and temporal flexibility of the SN uniquely predicted individual differences in cognitive flexibility. These results were also observed in a second retest dataset, demonstrating the robustness of our findings.
The SV40 virus is a nonenveloped virus that must be released from the host cell without being encapsulated by cellular membranes. This process is poorly understood and involves the insertion of viral proteins into host cellular membranes to render them permeable to large molecules. VP4 is a newly identified SV40 gene product that is expressed at late times during the viral life cycle, corresponding to the time of cell lysis. We investigated the role of VP4 in viral release by expressing and purifying it as a GST fusion protein from bacteria. Purified VP4 was found to efficiently bind biological membranes and support their disruption. VP4 perforated membranes by directly interacting with the membrane bilayer as demonstrated by flotation assays and the release of fluorescent markers encapsulated into large unilamellar vesicles or liposomes. The central hydrophobic domain of VP4 was essential for membrane binding and disruption. VP4 displayed a preference for membranes comprised of lipids that replicated the composition of the plasma membranes over that of nuclear membranes. Phosphatidylethanolamine, a lipid found at high levels in bacterial membranes, was inhibitory against the membrane perforation activity of VP4. The disruption of membranes by VP4 involved the formation of pores of ∼3 nm inner diameter in mammalian cells including permissive SV40 host cells. Altogether, these results support a central role of VP4 acting as a viroporin in the perforation of cellular membranes to trigger SV40 viral release.
Dengue virus ( DENV ) is a major public health problem in tropical and subtropical regions of the world, with an estimated half of the world's population at risk of infection. The immune response against DENV is not yet fully understood and a better knowledge of it is now recognized as one of the main challenges for vaccine development. We previously reported that a DNA vaccine containing the DENV2 NS1 gene ( pcTPANS1 ) induced protection against dengue in mice. Here, we aimed to elucidate the contribution of cellular and humoral responses elicited by this vaccine candidate for protective immunity. We observed that pcTPANS1 induced considerable levels of anti-NS1 antibodies and T cell responses. Passive immunization with anti-NS1 antibodies conferred partial protection in mice infected with low virus load, which was abrogated with the increase of viral dose. pcTPANS1 also induced activation of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. We detected production of IFN-γ and a cytotoxic activity by CD8+ T lymphocytes induced by this vaccine, although its contribution in the protection was not so evident when compared to CD4+ cells. Depletion of CD4+ cells in immunized mice completely abolished protection. Furthermore, transfer experiments revealed that animals receiving CD4+ T cells combined with anti-NS1 antiserum, both obtained from vaccinated mice, survived virus infection with survival rates not significantly different from pcTPANS1-immunized animals.
Streptococcal cell-to-cell communication mainly relies on extracellular signaling peptides that elicit a response either indirectly by triggering a two-component phosphorelay or directly by binding to cytoplasmic effectors. The RNPP family of proteins, which includes Rgg, Rap, NprR, PrgX, and PlcR, regulates important bacterial processes such as sporulation, conjugation, and virulence. Here, we elucidate the structure-function relationship of ComR, a new member of the RNPP family, which positively controls competence for natural DNA transformation in streptococci. ComR is directly activated by the binding of its associated pheromone XIP, the mature form of the comX/sigX-inducing-peptide ComS. The crystal structure analysis of ComR from Streptococcus thermophilus combined with mutational analysis and in vivo assays reveals that XIP-binding induces release of the sequestered HTH domain and ComR dimerization to allow DNA binding. Importantly, we bring evidence that this activation mechanism is conserved and specific to ComR orthologues, demonstrating that ComR is not an Rgg protein as initially proposed, but instead constitutes a new member of the RNPP family. The identification of XIP and ComR residues important for competence activation constitutes a crucial step towards the design of antagonistic strategies to control gene exchanges among streptococci.
Ligand activation of the prokaryotic pentameric ligand-gated ion channel ELIC has been investigated by electrophysiology and X-ray crystallography. ELIC is activated by a class of primary amines that include the neurotransmitter GABA at high micro- to millimolar concentrations. The ligands bind to a conserved site and evoke currents that slowly desensitize over time. The protein forms cation selective channels with properties that resemble the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor. The high single channel conductance and the comparably simple functional behavior make ELIC an attractive model system to study general mechanisms of ion conduction and gating in this important family of neurotransmitter receptors. ELIC is activated by a set of primary amines that include alkylamines, aminothiols, aminoalcohols, bromoamines, diamines, and the neurotransmitter GABA. The pentameric ligand-gated ion channels ( pLGICs ) constitute a large family of ionotropic neurotransmitter receptors that are ubiquitously expressed in the animal kingdom. All family members share a conserved molecular architecture and a similar functional behavior. With known agonists, ELIC has now become amenable for detailed structural and functional investigations.
Skin-derived thymic stromal lymphopoietin ( TSLP ) has been identified as the systemic driver of the progression from eczema/atopic dermatitis ( AD ) to asthma. We show that mice with skin-barrier defects develop AD-like skin inflammation and are susceptible to allergic asthma, similar to humans with AD. TSLP, overexpressed by skin keratinocytes, is the systemic driver of this bronchial hyper-responsiveness. In mice with keratinocyte-specific deletion of RBP-j that sustained high systemic levels of TSLP, antigen-induced allergic challenge to the lung airways resulted in a severe asthmatic phenotype not seen in similarly treated wild-type littermates. Elimination of TSLP signaling in these animals blocked the atopic march, demonstrating that high serum TSLP levels were required to sensitize the lung to allergic inflammation. Importantly, we show that epidermal-derived TSLP was sufficient to trigger the atopic march, sensitizing the lung airways to inhaled allergens in the absence of epicutaneous sensitization. These findings suggest that in addition to early treatment of the primary skin-barrier defects, selective inhibition of systemic TSLP may be the key to blocking the development of asthma in AD patients.
The genome of Thermotoga maritima, a hyperthermophilic bacterium, has been characterized using a multi-omics approach that integrates genomic, transcriptomic, and proteomic data with bioinformatics tools. This approach revealed several distinctive properties of the T. maritima genome relative to other bacteria. The T. maritima genome has a high number of genes per transcription unit ( 3. 3 ), a low number of putative non-coding RNAs ( 12 ), and few transcription units with multiple transcription start sites ( 3. 7% ). The promoters and ribosome binding sites of T. maritima are highly conserved relative to other bacteria. The 5′ untranslated regions ( UTRs ) of T. maritima follow an atypical bimodal length distribution, consisting of “Short” 5′UTRs ( 11–17 nt ) and “Common” 5′UTRs ( 26–32 nt ). Transcriptional regulation in T. maritima is limited by a lack of intergenic space for the majority of transcription units. Furthermore, a high fraction of annotated genes in T. maritima are expressed independently of growth state, and there is a linear correlation between mRNA and protein abundance ( Pearson r = 0. 63, p<2. 2×10−16 t-test ).
Visual object recognition and sensitivity to image features are largely influenced by contextual inputs. We study the influence of contextual bars on the bias to perceive or infer the presence of a target bar, rather than on the sensitivity to image features. Human observers judged whether a target bar of a known orientation and shape is present at the center of a display, given a weak or missing input contrast at the target location with or without a context of other bars. Observers are more likely to perceive a target when the context has a weaker rather than stronger contrast. When the context can perceptually group well with the would-be target, weak contrast contextual bars bias the observers to perceive a target relative to the condition without contexts, as if to fill in the target. Meanwhile, high-contrast contextual bars, regardless of whether they group well with the target, bias the observers to perceive no target. A Bayesian model of visual inference is shown to account for the data well, illustrating that the context influences the perception in two ways: ( 1 ) biasing observers' prior belief that a target should be present according to visual grouping principles, and ( 2 ) biasing observers' internal model of the likely input contrasts caused by a target bar. According to this model, our data suggest that the context does not influence the perceived target contrast despite its influence on the bias to perceive the target's presence, thereby suggesting that cortical areas beyond the primary visual cortex are responsible for the visual inferences.
Defectors can sometimes create conditions that rescue cooperation from defector-induced destruction. This is counterintuitive because cooperation is vulnerable to exploitation by defectors, which enjoy a fitness advantage by consuming the common good without contributing fairly. However, in a structured population, defectors can increase the heterogeneity in population collapse dynamics, reducing the chances that all populations go extinct simultaneously. When defectors are initially present, they occasionally go extinct before cooperators by chance, allowing cooperator-only but not defector-only populations to grow. Additionally, defectors cause population extinction, which creates empty locations that support cooperator but not defector migrants. This leads to the counterintuitive result that the initial presence of defectors in a population can sometimes improve the survival of cooperators. Furthermore, resource limitation, which can be precipitated by defectors, selects for rare cooperator and defector mutants adapted to this resource limitation. When these mutants are initially present at low levels or continuously generated at a moderate rate, they can favor cooperation by further reducing local population size. We predict that in a structured population, small population sizes precipitated by defectors provide a “built-in” mechanism for the persistence of cooperation.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an opportunistic pathogen that causes infections only in patients with altered epithelial barriers. In this study, we show that P. aeruginosa adheres almost exclusively to sites of multi-cellular junctions in a polarized epithelium, where it binds to extruded apoptotic cells or apoptotic bodies. This dead cell tropism is independent of the type of cell death, as P. aeruginosa also binds to necrotic cells. We further show that P. aeruginosa is internalized through efferocytosis, a process in which surrounding epithelial cells engulf and dispose of extruded apoptotic cells. Intracellularly, along with apoptotic cell debris, P. aeruginosa inhabits an efferocytic phagosome that acquires lysosomal features and is finally killed. We propose that elimination of P. aeruginosa through efferocytosis is part of a host defense mechanism. Our findings could be relevant for the study of cystic fibrosis, which is characterized by an exacerbated number of apoptotic cells and ineffective efferocytosis.
During Drosophila embryonic development, primordial germ cells ( PGCs ) and somatic gonadal precursor cells ( SGPs ) assemble to form the embryonic gonad. PGCs must migrate through the mesoderm to reach the SGPs, a process guided by local repulsive cues and attractive signals from the SGPs. We investigated the role of the hedgehog ( hh ) pathway gene shifted ( shf ) in directing PGC migration. shf encodes a secreted protein that facilitates long distance transmission of Hh through the proteoglycan matrix. shf is expressed in the gonadal mesoderm and is required for PGC migration, as demonstrated by loss- and gain-of-function experiments. The hmgcr-dependent isoprenoid biosynthetic pathway plays a crucial role in generating the PGC attractant produced by the SGPs and other tissues. We show that production of this attractant depends on shf as well as the hh pathway gene gγ1. Ectopic expression of hmgcr in the nervous system promotes the release/transmission of the Hh ligand from these cells into the underlying mesodermal cell layer, where Hh can contact migrating PGCs. Potentiation of Hh by hmgcr appears to depend on cholesterol modification.
Recombinant adenovirus serotype 5 ( Ad5 ) HIV-1 vaccine primes HIV-specific CD8+ T-cells for modest cytotoxic capacity that is most pronounced in individuals carrying protective HLA class I alleles. In this study, we examined the cytotoxic capacity of HIV-specific CD8+ T-cells in response to primary autologous HIV-infected CD4+ T-cell targets in samples from HIV-negative individuals vaccinated with a replication-incompetent Ad5/HIV vaccine. We observed readily detectable HIV-specific CD8+ T-cell recall cytotoxic responses in vaccinees at a median of 331 days following the last immunization. The magnitude of these responses was not related to the number of vaccinations, nor did it correlate with the percentages of cytokine-secreting T-cells determined by ICS assays. Although the recall cytotoxic capacity of the CD8+ T-cells of the vaccinee group was significantly less than that of long-term nonprogressors ( LTNP ) and overlapped with that of progressors, we observed significantly higher cytotoxic responses in vaccine recipients carrying the HLA class I alleles B*27, B*57 or B*58, which have been associated with immune control over HIV replication in chronic infection. These findings suggest that protective HLA class I alleles might lead to better outcomes in both chronic infection and following immunization due to more efficient priming of HIV-specific CD8+ T-cell cytotoxic responses.
The evolution of modern human cognition is hypothesized to have been catalyzed by the development of jointly intentional modes of behavior. This is known as the shared intentionality hypothesis, which suggests that a high degree of collaborative behavior amongst early hominins relative to other great apes aided the development of the rich cognitive abilities found in modern humans. Here, we formally model the coevolution of jointly intentional behavior and cumulative culture, showing that rapid techno-cultural advance goes hand in hand with the emergence of the ability to participate in jointly intentional behavior. Conversely, in the absence of opportunities for significant techno-cultural improvement, the ability to undertake jointly intentional behavior is selected against. We provide a unified mechanism for the suppression or emergence of shared intentions and collaborative behavior in humans, as well as a potential cause of inter-species diversity in the prevalence of such behavior. The emergence of shared intentions at a time of significant technological advance is consistent with evidence that composite tool manufacture may have evolved roughly contemporaneously with grammatical language, the primary application of which is the facilitation of jointly intentional behavior.
Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia, the leading cause of male sub/infertility in humans, is characterized by low sperm count, poor sperm motility, and abnormal sperm morphology. We found that the miR-34b/c and miR-449 loci, members of the miR-34 family, are specifically and highly expressed in post-mitotic male germ cells and play a critical role in spermatogenesis. Deletion of both miR-34b/c and miR-449 loci in mice resulted in oligoasthenoteratozoospermia, characterized by low sperm count, aberrant sperm morphology, and poor sperm motility. Our results indicate that miR-34bc/449-deficiency impairs both meiosis and the final stages of spermatozoa maturation. Analysis of miR-34bc−/−;449−/− pachytene spermatocytes revealed a small cohort of genes deregulated that were highly enriched for miR-34 family target genes. Our study identifies the miR-34 family as the first functionally important miRNAs for spermatogenesis whose deregulation is causal to oligoasthenoteratozoospermia and infertility.
Escherichia coli Nissle 1917 ( EcN ) has been used therapeutically for over a century, but the determinants of its probiotic properties remain unknown. EcN produces two siderophore-microcins ( Mcc ) and the genotoxin colibactin encoded by the pks island. Colibactin is a virulence factor and a putative pro-carcinogenic compound. We aimed to decouple the antagonistic activity of EcN from its genotoxic activity. We demonstrated that ClbP, the peptidase that activates colibactin, is required for the antagonistic activity of EcN. The analysis of ClbP mutants revealed that this activity is linked to the transmembrane helices of ClbP and not the periplasmic peptidase domain. A single amino acid substitution in ClbP inactivates the genotoxic activity but maintains the antagonistic activity. In an in vivo salmonellosis model, this point mutant reduced the clinical signs and the fecal shedding of Salmonella similarly to the wild type strain. The ClbP-dependent antibacterial effect was also observed in vitro with other E. coli strains that carry both a truncated form of the Mcc gene cluster and the pks island. This interplay between colibactin, salmochelin, and siderophore-Mcc biosynthetic pathways suggests that these genomic islands were co-selected and played a role in the evolution of E. coli from phylogroup B2. Decoupling the antagonistic from the genotoxic activity by specifically inactivating ClbP peptidase domain opens the way to the safe use of EcN.
Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungal pathogen responsible for hundreds of thousands of deaths annually. It is the leading cause of fungal meningitis worldwide. Cryptococcal glycans are required for fungal survival in the host and for pathogenesis. These glycans are made in the secretory pathway, although the activated precursors for their synthesis, nucleotide sugars, are made primarily in the cytosol. Nucleotide sugar transporters ( NSTs ) are membrane proteins that exchange nucleotide sugars for the corresponding nucleoside phosphates. The major virulence factor of C. neoformans is an anti-phagocytic polysaccharide capsule that is displayed on the cell surface; capsule polysaccharides are also shed from the cell and impede the host immune response. Here we show that Uxt1 and Uxt2 are both transporters specific for the xylose donor, UDP-xylose, although they exhibit distinct subcellular localization, expression patterns, and kinetic parameters. Both proteins also transport the galactofuranose donor, UDP-galactofuranose. We further show that Uxt1 and Uxt2 are required for xylose incorporation into capsule and protein; they are also necessary for C. neoformans to cause disease in mice, although surprisingly not for fungal viability in the context of infection. These findings provide a starting point for deciphering the substrate specificity of an important class of transporters, elucidate a synthetic pathway that may be productively targeted for therapy, and contribute to our understanding of fundamental glycobiology.
Neglected tropical diseases ( NTDs ) are a major public health burden in developing countries, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa. Disease risk estimates are a key feature to target control interventions and serve as a benchmark for monitoring and evaluation. However, a georeferenced global database for NTDs providing open-access to the available survey data is currently missing. We describe the development of such a database that can be employed for spatial disease risk modeling and control of NTDs. We systematically searched the literature and contacted Ministries of Health and research institutions in schistosomiasis-endemic countries for location-specific prevalence data and survey details. The data were extracted, georeferenced, and stored in a MySQL database with a web interface allowing free database access and data management. At the beginning of 2011, our database contained more than 12, 000 georeferenced schistosomiasis survey locations from 35 African countries. The database is currently expanded to a global repository, including a host of other NTDs, e. g. soil-transmitted helminthiasis and leishmaniasis. An open-access, spatially explicit NTD database offers unique opportunities for disease risk modeling, targeting control interventions, disease monitoring, and surveillance.
Chronic helminth infection does not exacerbate Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( MTB ) infection in cotton rats, a natural host for the filarial nematode Litomosoides sigmodontis and an excellent model for human MTB infection. We hypothesized that chronic helminth infections may worsen the course of MTB by inducing a Th2 immune shift and establishing an immunoregulatory milieu that suppresses Th1 immunity, which is necessary for MTB control. However, the results of this study demonstrate that chronic filarial infection does not alter control of MTB in cotton rats. Histological examinations and quantitative MTB cultures from two independent experiments clearly demonstrated equivalent or reduced mycobacterial burden in co-infected animals compared to those infected with only MTB. In contrast to our hypothesis, MTB loads and the occurrence and size of lung granulomas were not increased in co-infected animals. These findings suggest that chronic filaria infections do not exacerbate MTB infection in the cotton rat model.
In Drosophila melanogaster, ppk23, a member of the DEG/ENaC family of ion channels, is expressed in a subpopulation of sexually dimorphic gustatory-like chemosensory bristles that are distinct from those expressing feeding-related gustatory receptors. We found that disrupting ppk23 or inhibiting activity of ppk23-expressing neurons did not alter gustatory responses, but instead delayed the initiation and reduced the intensity of male courtship. Furthermore, mutations in ppk23 altered the behavioral response of males to the female-specific aphrodisiac pheromone 7, 11 ( Z ), 11 ( Z ) -Heptacosadiene. These data indicate that ppk23 and the cells expressing it play an important role in the peripheral sensory system that determines sexual behavior in Drosophila. Our data suggest that DEG/ENaC signaling contributes to sensory functions underlying sex-related behaviors, and indicate a novel physiological function for this important family of ion channels.
Mitochondrial tRNAs are imported from the cytosol in order to ensure proper mitochondrial translation in a wide range of organisms, including protozoa, fungi, higher plants, and humans. In the unicellular green alga Chlamydomonas, we found a precise correlation between the mitochondrial codon usage and the nature and amount of imported tRNAs. This led to the hypothesis that tRNA import might be a dynamic process able to adapt to the mitochondrial genome content. To test this hypothesis, we manipulated the Chlamydomonas mitochondrial genome by introducing point mutations to modify its codon usage. We found that the codon usage modification resulted in reduced levels of mitochondrial translation as well as decreased levels and activities of respiratory complexes. These effects were linked to the consequential limitations of the pool of tRNAs in mitochondria. Our results indicate that tRNA mitochondrial import cannot be rapidly regulated in response to a novel genetic context and thus does not appear to be a dynamic process. Instead, the steady-state levels of imported tRNAs in mitochondria result from a co-evolutive adaptation between the tRNA import mechanism and the requirements of the mitochondrial translation machinery.
Glucose dysregulation, a hallmark of diabetes and prediabetes, is more prevalent and heterogeneous than previously thought. Current methods for quantifying blood glucose dysregulation are limited by reliance on single-time-point measurements or average measures of overall glycemia, neglecting glucose dynamics. We used continuous glucose monitoring ( CGM ) to evaluate the frequency and patterns of postprandial glucose elevations in individuals given an identical nutrient challenge. We developed an analytical framework to group individuals according to specific patterns of glycemic responses called “glucotypes” that reveal subphenotypes within traditional diagnostic categories of glucose regulation. We found that even individuals considered normoglycemic by standard measures exhibit high glucose variability using CGM, with glucose levels reaching prediabetic and diabetic ranges 15% and 2% of the time, respectively. The interindividual variability in glycemic responses to standardized meals highlights the personal nature of glucose regulation. We developed a model for identifying potential mechanisms of personal glucose dysregulation and built a webtool for visualizing a user-uploaded CGM profile and classifying individualized glucose patterns into glucotypes. Our results suggest that an increase in glucose variability might precede the currently used measures defining abnormal glucose levels and thus represent an earlier stage of “prediabetes. ”
EDR1 negatively regulates the MKK4/MKK5-MPK3/MPK6 kinase cascade in Arabidopsis to modulate plant innate immunity. We found that edr1 mutants have highly activated MPK3/MPK6 kinase activity and higher levels of MPK3/MPK6 proteins than wild type. EDR1 physically interacts with MKK4 and MKK5, and this interaction requires the N-terminal domain of EDR1. EDR1 also negatively affects MKK4/MKK5 protein levels. In addition, the mpk3, mkk4 and mkk5 mutations suppress edr1-mediated resistance, and over-expression of MKK4 or MKK5 causes edr1-like resistance and mildew-induced cell death. Our data indicate that EDR1 physically associates with MKK4/MKK5 and negatively regulates the MAPK cascade to fine-tune plant innate immunity.
In this study, we developed a computational framework based on Gaussian processes to perform spatiotemporal prediction of infectious diseases. We exploited the special structure of similarity matrices in our formulation to obtain a very efficient implementation. We then tested our framework on the problem of modeling Crimean–Congo hemorrhagic fever cases between 2004 and 2015 in Turkey. Our results showed that our Gaussian process formulation obtained better results than two frequently used standard machine learning algorithms ( i. e., random forests and boosted regression trees ) under temporal, spatial, and spatiotemporal prediction scenarios. We proposed a computational framework that uses Gaussian processes as the basic building block to perform spatial, temporal, or spatiotemporal prediction of infectious diseases. We combined two similarity matrices to obtain a larger similarity matrix between location and time period pairs. Using the combined similarity matrix and reported cases counts, we trained a Gaussian process regression model to make predictions under three different scenarios: temporal prediction, spatial prediction, and spatiotemporal prediction.
Rift Valley fever ( RVF ) is an important mosquito-borne viral zoonosis in Africa and the Middle East that causes human deaths and significant economic losses. We propose an almost periodic three-patch model to investigate the transmission dynamics of RVF virus ( RVFV ) among ruminants with spatial movements. Our findings indicate that human activities, including those associated with the Eid al Adha feast, along with a combination of climatic factors such as rainfall level and hydrological variations, contribute to the transmission and dispersal of the disease pathogen in Northeastern Africa. We show that sporadic outbreaks may occur when the two events occur together: 1 ) abundant livestock are recruited into areas at risk from RVF due to the demand for the religious festival and 2 ) abundant numbers of mosquitoes emerge. Our numerical results present the transmission dynamics of the disease pathogen over both short and long periods of time, particularly during the festival time. We investigate the impact on patterns of disease outbreaks in each patch brought by festival- and seasonal-driven factors, such as the number of livestock imported daily, the animal transportation speed from patch to patch, and the death rate induced by ceremonial sacrifices. Our simulations show that when the time for festival preparation starts earlier than usual, the risk of massive disease outbreaks rises, particularly in patch 3 ( the place where the religious ceremony will be held ).
Anthrax is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium Bacillus anthracis that affects both humans and animals. In Azerbaijan, the incidence of human anthrax has undergone significant changes since the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991. We analyzed data from 1984 to 2010 on livestock anthrax outbreaks, vaccination efforts, and human anthrax incidence during the Soviet, post-Soviet, and preemptive livestock vaccination eras. Our results indicate that the incidence of human anthrax increased by 11. 95% from 1984 to 1995, followed by a decline of 35. 24% after the initiation of livestock vaccination in 1996. We also found that the geographic distribution of human anthrax shifted from the west to the east during the study period. The incidence of human cutaneous anthrax was primarily concentrated in the west and south during the Soviet era, but shifted eastward towards the capital Baku in the mid-1990s. During the preemptive livestock vaccination period, the burden of disease remained primarily concentrated in eastern and northern Azerbaijan. Our findings highlight the need for an integrated “One Health” approach that takes into account the changing geographic distribution of the disease. Continued control measures in livestock are needed to mitigate the occurrence of human anthrax in Azerbaijan.
Polyunsaturated fatty acids ( PUFAs ) have been found to modulate the activity of the Shaker voltage-gated potassium ( KV ) channel by shifting the voltage dependence of the channel to enable channel activation. PUFAs are essential components of cell membrane phospholipids in heart cells and neurons and have been extensively studied for their effects on voltage-gated ion channels. However, the molecular mechanism by which PUFAs modulate channel functioning remains an open question. In this study, we report on the interactions between the Shaker KV channel in open and closed states and a PUFA-enriched lipid bilayer using microsecond molecular dynamics simulations. We determined a putative PUFA binding site in the open state of the channel located at the protein-lipid interface in the vicinity of the extracellular halves of the S3 and S4 helices of the voltage-sensor domain ( VSD ). In particular, the lipophilic PUFA tail covered a wide range of non-specific hydrophobic interactions in the hydrophobic central core of the protein-lipid interface, while the carboxylic head group displayed more specific interactions to polar/charged residues at the extracellular regions of the S3 and S4 helices, encompassing the S3-S4 linker. Moreover, our study confirmed an increased conformational flexibility in the polyunsaturated carbon tails compared to saturated carbon chains, which may explain the specificity of PUFA action on channel proteins.
Cryptosporidiosis, a disease caused by the protozoan parasite Cryptosporidium parvum, results in significant morbidity among children in developing countries and severe enteritis in immunocompromised patients. Current drugs lack efficacy in treating these conditions, and the development of novel anti-cryptosporidial therapeutics has been hampered by the poor experimental tractability of this pathogen. We have developed a pipeline of tools to accelerate the in vivo screening of inhibitors of C. parvum inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase ( IMPDH ). We have genetically engineered the related parasite Toxoplasma gondii to serve as a model of C. parvum infection, providing a rapid assessment of anti-parasitic potential and a quantitative read of target specificity. We have also developed a fluorescence-based assay of host cell proliferation and a C. parvum growth assay that utilizes automated high-content imaging analysis for enhanced throughput. We have used these assays to evaluate C. parvum IMPDH inhibitors emerging from our ongoing medicinal chemistry effort and have identified a subset of 1, 2, 3-triazole ethers that exhibit excellent in vivo selectivity in the T. gondii model and improved anti-cryptosporidial activity. These compounds are >100× more potent than paromomycin, the current standard for anticryptosporidial activity.
Tooth development is a highly heritable process that interacts with the development of the entire craniofacial complex. We performed a genome-wide association study of time to first tooth eruption and number of teeth at one year in 4, 564 individuals from the 1966 Northern Finland Birth Cohort ( NFBC1966 ) and 1, 518 individuals from the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children ( ALSPAC ). We identified 5 loci at P<5×10−8, and 5 with suggestive association ( P<5×10−6 ). The loci included several genes with links to tooth and other organ development ( KCNJ2, EDA, HOXB2, RAD51L1, IGF2BP1, HMGA2, MSRB3 ). Genes at four of the identified loci are implicated in the development of cancer. A variant within the HOXB gene cluster associated with occlusion defects requiring orthodontic treatment by age 31 years.
Down syndrome ( DS ) is the most common viable human aneuploidy caused by the trisomy of human chromosome 21 ( Hsa21 ). In contrast, the complete monosomy of Hsa21 is lethal, and only partial monosomy or mosaic monosomy of Hsa21 is seen. Both conditions lead to variable physiological abnormalities with constant intellectual disability, locomotor deficits, and altered muscle tone. To search for dosage-sensitive genes involved in DS and monosomy 21 phenotypes, we created two new mouse models: the Ts3Yah carrying a tandem duplication and the Ms3Yah carrying a deletion of the Hspa13-App interval syntenic with 21q11. 2-q21. 3. Here we report that the trisomy and the monosomy of this region alter locomotion, muscle strength, mass, and energetic balance. The expression profiling of skeletal muscles revealed global changes in the regulation of genes implicated in energetic metabolism, mitochondrial activity, and biogenesis. These genes are downregulated in Ts3Yah mice and upregulated in Ms3Yah mice. The shift in skeletal muscle metabolism correlates with a change in mitochondrial proliferation without an alteration in the respiratory function. However, the reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) production from mitochondrial complex I decreased in Ms3Yah mice, while the membrane permeability of Ts3Yah mitochondria slightly increased. Thus, we demonstrated how the Hspa13-App interval controls metabolic and mitochondrial phenotypes in muscles certainly as a consequence of change in dose of Gabpa, Nrip1, and Atp5j. Our results indicate that the copy number variation in the Hspa13-App region has a peripheral impact on locomotor activity by altering muscle function.
G protein-gated K+ channels ( GIRK; Kir3 ), activated by Gβγ subunits derived from Gi/o proteins, regulate heartbeat and neuronal excitability and plasticity. Both neurotransmitter-evoked ( Ievoked ) and neurotransmitter-independent basal ( Ibasal ) GIRK activities are physiologically important, but mechanisms of Ibasal and its relation to Ievoked are unclear. We have previously shown for heterologously expressed neuronal GIRK1/2, and now show for native GIRK in hippocampal neurons, that Ibasal and Ievoked are interrelated: the extent of activation by neurotransmitter ( activation index, Ra ) is inversely related to Ibasal. To unveil the underlying mechanisms, we have developed a quantitative model of GIRK1/2 function. We characterized single-channel and macroscopic GIRK1/2 currents, and surface densities of GIRK1/2 and Gβγ expressed in Xenopus oocytes. Based on experimental results, we constructed a mathematical model of GIRK1/2 activity under steady-state conditions before and after activation by neurotransmitter. Our model accurately recapitulates Ibasal and Ievoked in Xenopus oocytes, HEK293 cells and hippocampal neurons; correctly predicts the dose-dependent activation of GIRK1/2 by coexpressed Gβγ and fully accounts for the inverse Ibasal-Ra correlation. Modeling indicates that, under all conditions and at different channel expression levels, between 3 and 4 Gβγ dimers are available for each GIRK1/2 channel. In contrast, available Gαi/o decreases from ~2 to less than one Gα per channel as GIRK1/2's density increases.
Plant-pathogenic Xanthomonas bacteria secrete transcription activator-like effectors ( TALEs ) into host cells, where they act as transcriptional activators on plant target genes to support bacterial virulence. TALEs have a unique modular DNA-binding domain composed of tandem repeats. We propose a novel approach for TALE target prediction, termed PrediTALE, to identify potential virulence targets. PrediTALE accounts for recent findings concerning TALE targeting, including frame-shift binding by repeats of aberrant lengths and the flexible strand orientation of target boxes relative to the transcription start of the downstream target gene. We benchmark PrediTALE using RNA-seq data after Xanthomonas infection in rice and find an overall improvement of prediction performance compared with previous approaches. Using PrediTALE, we are able to predict several novel putative virulence targets. However, we also observe that no target genes are predicted by any prediction tool for several TALEs, which we term orphan TALEs. We postulate that one explanation for orphan TALEs are incomplete gene annotations and propose to replace promoterome-wide by genome-wide scans for target boxes. We demonstrate that known targets from promoterome-wide scans may be recovered by genome-wide scans, whereas the latter, combined with RNA-seq data, are able to detect putative targets independent of existing gene annotations.
Mitochondrial non-synonymous genome variations are potentially pathogenic amino acid changes affecting the human mitochondrial DNA. However, only a small subset has been functionally evaluated with certainty, while the pathogenicity of the vast majority has been assessed in-silico by software predictors. These tools have been shown to be rather incongruent. To address this issue, we have designed and implemented APOGEE, a machine-learning algorithm that outperforms existing prediction methods in estimating the harmfulness of mitochondrial non-synonymous genome variations. APOGEE was built on a training set of 864 known mitochondrial variants and a test set of 100 variants drawn randomly with replacement. We calculated an array of performance metrics for APOGEE and aggregated individual predictors, which were reported in Table 1. We also calculated the frequency of coevolving amino acids and the mean MI Z-score for each amino acid site. These scores were computed for all 24, 189 non-synonymous amino acid changes potentially affecting the human mitochondrial DNA and made freely available from MitImpact. The APOGEE classifier is based on the Logistic Model Tree ( LMT ) and feeds third-party predictors with features strictly related to the 13 mitochondrial proteins. Its reasoning strategy was tuned on finely curated, non-overlapping, training sets of variations, and its predicting model was based on decision tree learning to provide investigable rules of pathogenicity.
Dengue virus ( DENV ) nonstructural protein 1 ( NS1 ) can cause thrombocytopenia and hemorrhage by activating platelets via Toll-like receptor 4 ( TLR4 ). We first demonstrated that DENV but not Zika virus cell culture supernatant could induce P-selectin expression and phosphatidylserine ( PS ) exposure in human platelets, both of which were abolished when NS1 was depleted from the DENV supernatant. Similar results were found using recombinant NS1 from all four serotypes of DENV, and those effects were blocked in the presence of anti-NS1 F ( ab’ ) 2, anti-TLR4 antibody, a TLR4 antagonist ( Rhodobacter sphaeroides lipopolysaccharide, LPS-Rs ) and a TLR4 signaling inhibitor ( TAK242 ), but not polymyxin B ( an LPS inhibitor ). The activation of platelets by DENV NS1 promoted subthreshold concentrations of adenosine diphosphate ( ADP ) -induced platelet aggregation and enhanced platelet adhesion to endothelial cells and phagocytosis by macrophages. Finally, we demonstrated that DENV-induced thrombocytopenia and hemorrhage were attenuated in TLR4 knockout and wild-type mice when NS1 was depleted from DENV supernatant. These results suggest that the binding of DENV NS1 to TLR4 on platelets can trigger its activation, which may contribute to thrombocytopenia and hemorrhage during dengue infection.
Vasomotor tone, blood volume, and mean arterial pressure are regulated by dynamic control loops involving the arginine vasopressin ( AVP ) system, the atrial natriuretic peptide system ( ANP ), and the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system ( RAAS ). We performed a loop analysis of the AVP-ANP-RAAS system and found that it can be split into two coexisting dynamic systems, which contain alternatively the vascular smooth muscle ( VSM ) and the distal tubular cells ( DTC ) functional agents, thereby exerting their effects on blood pressure and blood volume, respectively. The AVP-ANP-RAAS endocrine control of body fluids and blood pressure was therefore analysed using mathematical tools, to highlight the loop arrangement and its dynamic function. Our results suggest that the physiological mechanisms regulating long-term homeostasis of blood hydraulic parameters are arranged into a complex of equivalent loop systems, consisting of candidate oscillators with a single equilibrium point. The AVP-ANP-VSM subsystem, which includes ANP and AVP stimulation of vascular smooth muscle cells, turns out to be a candidate oscillator composed of a monotone system with multiple negative feedback loops, and its oscillatory potential is higher when the delays along all feedback loops are comparable.
Thromboembolic disease is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The formation of a fibrin network, also known as a fibrin cap, on the surface of a thrombus has been identified as a novel mechanism that limits thrombus growth. In this study, the transport of proteins through the fibrin network was studied by integrating experiments with model simulations. The results show that the permeability of the fibrin network and the diffusivity of proteins are important factors that determine the transport of proteins through the fibrin network. The formation of a fibrin cap prevents small thrombi from developing into life-threatening events by limiting the exposure of platelets on the thrombus surface to thrombin. The fibrin cap also restricts the approach of resting platelets in the flowing blood to the thrombus core, thus preventing platelet activation and limiting thrombus growth.
Invariant natural killer T ( iNKT ) cells are known to be activated during Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( Mtb ) infection, but the mechanisms by which they control Mtb growth are not well understood. In this study, we investigated how iNKT cells suppress intracellular Mtb replication. We found that iNKT cell activation, as measured by CD25 upregulation and IFNγ production, was primarily driven by IL-12 and IL-18 produced by infected macrophages. In contrast, iNKT cell control of Mtb growth was CD1d-dependent and did not require IL-12, IL-18, or IFNγ. This suggests that conventional activation markers do not correlate with iNKT cell effector function during Mtb infection. We also found that iNKT cell control of Mtb replication was independent of TNF and cell-mediated cytotoxicity. Instead, we identified GM-CSF as a novel mediator of iNKT cell antimicrobial activity. iNKT cells produced GM-CSF in vitro and in vivo in a CD1d-dependent manner during Mtb infection, and GM-CSF was both necessary and sufficient to control Mtb growth. These findings demonstrate that GM-CSF production is a novel iNKT cell antimicrobial effector function and suggest a potential role for GM-CSF in T cell immunity against Mtb.
Candida albicans, an opportunistic fungal pathogen, is a common component of human intestinal flora. To gain insight into C. albicans colonization, genes expressed by fungi grown within a host were studied. The EFH1 gene, encoding a putative transcription factor, was highly expressed during growth of C. albicans in the intestinal tract. Unexpectedly, an efh1 null mutant exhibited increased colonization of the murine intestinal tract, whereas an EFH1 overexpressing strain exhibited reduced colonization of the intestinal tract and of the oral cavity of athymic mice. When inoculated into the bloodstream of mice, both efh1 null and EFH1 overexpressing strains caused lethal infections. In contrast, other mutants are attenuated in virulence following intravenous inoculation but exhibited normal levels of intestinal colonization. These results show that expression of EFH1 regulates the level of colonizing fungi, favoring commensalism as opposed to candidiasis. Expression of several genes is dependent on transcription factor Efg1p during laboratory growth, but Efg1p-independent expression of these genes was observed during growth within the murine intestinal tract.
Immunization with irradiated Plasmodium sporozoites is the most effective vaccine strategy against liver stages of malaria parasites. However, the mechanisms underpinning the success of this approach are unknown. Here, we show that the complete development of protective CD8+ T cell responses requires prolonged antigen presentation. Using TCR transgenic cells specific for the malaria circumsporozoite protein, we found that sporozoite antigen persists for over 8 weeks after immunization. The persisting antigen was detected in lymphoid organs and depends on the presence of CD11c+ cells. Prolonged antigen presentation enhanced the magnitude of the CD8+ T cell response in several ways. Firstly, reducing the time primed CD8+ T cells were exposed to antigen in vivo severely reduced the final size of the developing memory population. Secondly, fully developed memory cells expanded in previously immunized mice but not when transferred to naïve animals. Finally, persisting antigen was able to prime naïve cells, including recent thymic emigrants, to become functional effector cells capable of eliminating parasites in the liver. Together, these data show that the optimal development of protective CD8+ T cell immunity against malaria liver stages is dependent upon the prolonged presentation of sporozoite-derived antigen.
Leishmanicidal and antimicrobial potential of biodegradable nanocarriers coated with polymyxin B ( PBCAnp-polB ) was evaluated in this study. PBCAnp-polB were fabricated by anionic polymerization and presented an adequate size of 261. 5 ± 25. 9 nm, low polydispersity index ( PDI ), and ζ potential of 1. 79 ± 0. 17 mV. The 50% drug release from PBCAnp-polB was 6–7 times slower than the free polB, which favors a prolonged and desired release profile. In vitro evaluations showed that polB alone reduced in vitro amastigote infection of macrophages without complete parasite elimination, even at higher concentrations. The nanocarrier PBCAnp also presented leishmanicidal effect and surpassed polB activity; however, no antimicrobial activity was detected. PolB maintained its activity against E. coli, Pseudomonas, and Klebsiella, adding antimicrobial properties to the nanoparticles. The IC50 value found for free polB was 77. 1 μg/mL ( 59. 2 μM ). PBCAnp-polB presented a coating of approximately 2. 4 x 105 molecules of polB per unit, with a sustained release profile. The optimal PBCAnp in pharmaceutics aspects presented antileishmanial activity by itself, superposing polB activity.
Visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) is a severe form of leishmaniasis, a disease caused by the intracellular protozoan parasite Leishmania infantum. In Brazil, VL is a major public health problem with high mortality rates. This study aimed to investigate the prognostic factors for death from VL in Belo Horizonte, Brazil. We analyzed data from the Reportable Disease Information System-SINAN ( Brazilian Ministry of Health ) relating to the clinical manifestations of the disease from 2002 to 2009. Two multivariate logistic regression models were developed to identify variables associated with death from VL. Model 1 included variables present in both SINAN versions ( 2002–2009; 111 deaths from VL and 777 cured patients ), and Model 2 included variables common to both SINAN versions plus additional variables included in the Net version ( 2007–2009; 49 deaths from VL and 327 cured patients ). In Model 1, the variables significantly associated with a greater risk of death from VL were weakness ( OR 2. 9; 95%CI 1. 3–6. 4 ), Leishmania-HIV co-infection ( OR 2. 4; 95%CI 1. 2–4. 8 ) and age ≥60 years ( OR 2. 5; 95%CI 1. 5–4. 3 ). In Model 2, the variables associated with death from VL were bleeding ( OR 3. 5; 95%CI 1. 2–10. 3 ), other associated infections ( OR 3. 2; 95%CI 1. 3–7. 8 ), jaundice ( OR 10. 1; 95%CI 3. 7–27. 2 ) and age ≥60 years ( OR 3. 1; 95%CI 1. 4–7. 1 ).
The Arabidopsis regulatory leucine-rich repeat receptor-like kinase ( LRR-RLK ) BAK1 plays a central role in plant growth, cell death, and innate immunity. Here, we describe a novel allele of BAK1, bak1-5, which differentially regulates three BAK1-dependent signaling pathways. bak1-5 mutant plants are severely impaired in innate immune signaling mediated by the BAK1-dependent receptor kinases FLS2 and EFR, but not in BR signaling or cell death control. In contrast to the RD kinase BRI1, FLS2 and EFR have very low kinase activity and are unable to trans-phosphorylate BAK1 in vitro. Furthermore, kinase activity is dispensable for the ligand-induced heteromerization of FLS2 or EFR with BAK1 in planta. However, the specific suppression of FLS2- and EFR-dependent signaling in bak1-5 requires BAK1-5 kinase activity. Overall, our results demonstrate a phosphorylation-dependent differential control of plant growth, innate immunity, and cell death by BAK1, which may reveal key differences in the molecular mechanisms underlying the regulation of ligand-binding RD and non-RD receptor kinases.
The cell cycle response to anticancer treatment is a complex process that extends over several cell generations and cannot be fully captured by current methods. A new experimental/computational approach combines time-lapse live cell microscopy and flow cytometric data to render the proliferative process through the cell cycle and subsequent generations during and after treatment. The approach models the effects of treatments with modules describing the functional activity of the main pathways causing arrest, repair, and cell death in each phase of the cell cycle. A framework modelling environment was created to apply different types of modules in each phase and test models at the complexity level justified by the available data. The method was challenged with time-course measures taken in parallel with flow cytometry and time-lapse live cell microscopy in X-ray-treated human ovarian cancer cells, spanning a wide range of doses. The most suitable model of the treatment, including the dose-response of each effect, was progressively built by combining modules with a rational strategy and fitting simultaneously all data of different doses and platforms. The final model gave the first complete rendering in silico of the cycling process following X-ray exposure, providing separate and quantitative measures of the dose-dependence of G1, S, and G2/M checkpoint activities in subsequent generations.
Coenzyme Q ( CoQ ) is an essential electron carrier in the respiratory chain whose deficiency has been implicated in a wide variety of human mitochondrial disease manifestations. We now show that a presumed autoimmune kidney disease in mice with the missense Pdss2kd/kd genotype can be attributed to a mitochondrial CoQ biosynthetic defect. Levels of CoQ9 and CoQ10 in kidney homogenates from B6. Pdss2kd/kd mutants were significantly lower than those in B6 control mice. Disease manifestations originate specifically in glomerular podocytes, as renal disease is seen in Podocin/cre, Pdss2loxP/loxP knockout mice but not in conditional knockouts targeted to renal tubular epithelium, monocytes, or hepatocytes. Liver-conditional B6. Alb/cre, Pdss2loxP/loxP knockout mice have no overt disease despite demonstration that their livers have undetectable CoQ9 levels, impaired respiratory capacity, and significantly altered intermediary metabolism as evidenced by transcriptional profiling and amino acid quantitation. These data suggest that disease manifestations of CoQ deficiency relate to tissue-specific respiratory capacity thresholds, with glomerular podocytes displaying the greatest sensitivity to Pdss2 impairment.
Phenotypic robustness is an important characteristic of life, but its underlying mechanisms and evolutionary origins are not well understood. Here, we report that determinative developmental cell lineages of two protostomes and one deuterostome are robust to environmental and genetic perturbations, such as necrosis and cell division program failure. Our computational analysis of these cell lineages reveals that several features, including their shallowness, topology, early ontogenic appearances of rare cells, and non-clonality of most cell types, underlie this robustness. These features allow the resulting cellular compositions of the organisms to be only modestly affected by cell deaths. We propose that the observed robustness arose as an adaptation in the face of random cell deaths in development. Our findings reveal a new mechanism of phenotypic robustness that manifests at the supracellular level and is a unique feature of multicellular organisms. This mechanism complements subcellular and cellular mechanisms of robustness to form a multi-layer defense system against environmental and genetic perturbations. Our study provides a novel explanation of the contribution of ontogenesis to phenotypic robustness and opens the door toward characterizing systemic properties of complex cell lineages.
Here, we present EmbryoPhenomics, an open-source high-throughput platform for phenomics in aquatic embryos. The platform consists of an Open-source Video Microscope ( OpenVIM ) and a Python package Embryo Computer Vision ( EmbryoCV ). OpenVIM produces high-resolution videos of multiple embryos under tightly controlled environmental conditions, while EmbryoCV extracts phenomic data for morphological, physiological, behavioural, and proxy traits during embryonic development. We demonstrate the broad-scale applicability of EmbryoPhenomics in a series of experiments assessing chronic, acute, and multistressor responses to environmental change ( temperature and salinity ) in >30 million images of >600 embryos of two species with markedly different patterns of development—the pond snail Radix balthica and the marine amphipod Orchestia gammarellus. EmbryoPhenomics can acquire and process data capturing functional, temporal, and spatial responses in the earliest, most dynamic life stages. We demonstrate the capability of OpenVIM to document the development of large numbers of aquatic embryos in experimental treatments ranging from long- ( >240 h ) to short-term ( 24 h ) exposures.
