EmbryoCV successfully extracted phenome-level data from 95% of the >30 million images acquired, producing high-dimensional data describing morphological, physiological, and behavioural embryo responses.
Malaria parasites ( Plasmodium spp. ) undergo dramatic changes in metabolism during their complex life cycles in the mosquito and human hosts. We have used stable isotope labelling, targeted metabolomics and reverse genetics to map stage-specific changes in Plasmodium berghei carbon metabolism and determine the functional significance of these changes on parasite survival in the blood and mosquito stages. We show that glutamine serves as the predominant input into tricarboxylic acid ( TCA ) metabolism in both asexual and sexual blood stages and is important for complete male gametogenesis. Glutamine catabolism, as well as key reactions in intermediary metabolism and CoA synthesis, are also essential for ookinete to oocyst transition in the mosquito. These data extend our knowledge of Plasmodium metabolism and point towards possible targets for transmission-blocking intervention strategies. Furthermore, they highlight significant metabolic differences between Plasmodium species which are not easily anticipated based on genomics or transcriptomics studies and underline the importance of integration of metabolomics data with other platforms in order to better inform drug discovery and design.
Incoherent feedforward loops ( IFFLs ) are a common motif found in many biological signaling pathways. These networks are able to differentiate between pulsatile and sustained signals in the regulation of downstream gene expression. IFFLs consist of an input that simultaneously activates an output and an inhibitor of the output, and can exhibit temporal adaptation, where the system is desensitized to a sustained input. This property allows IFFLs to distinguish input signals with varying temporal profiles. Here, we use quantitative modeling to examine the ability of IFFLs to process oscillatory signals. Our results indicate that the system’s ability to translate pulsatile dynamics is limited by two constraints. The kinetics of the IFFL components dictate the input range for which the network is able to decode pulsatile dynamics. In addition, a match between the network parameters and input signal characteristics is required for optimal “counting” of oscillatory signals.
Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is an obligate intracellular Gram-negative bacterium transmitted to humans by the bite of a Leptotrombidium mite. Despite being a leading cause of serious febrile illness in rural Southeast Asia, research into the basic mechanisms of cell biology and pathogenicity of O. tsutsugamushi has lagged behind that of other important human pathogens. One reason for this is that O. tsutsugamushi is an obligate intracellular bacterium that can only be cultured in mammalian cells and requires specific methodologies for propagation and analysis. Here, we present a body of work designed to improve methods for quantification, propagation, purification and long-term storage of O. tsutsugamushi. A clinical isolate of O. tsutsugamushi was grown in cultured mouse embryonic fibroblast ( L929 ) cells and bacterial growth was measured using an O. tsutsugamushi-specific qPCR assay. We present a standardised method for comparing the viability of O. tsutsugamushi after purification, treatment and propagation under various conditions. Our results will be useful to other researchers working on O. tsutsugamushi and other obligate intracellular pathogens such as those in the Rickettsiales and Chlamydiales families.
Schistosoma haematobium is a parasitic worm that causes schistosomiasis, a major cause of morbidity worldwide. The antihelminthic drug praziquantel ( PZQ ) is currently used to control schistosomiasis, but its safety and efficacy in children aged 1–5 years have not been well established. This study investigated the safety and efficacy of PZQ treatment in 104 Zimbabwean children aged 1–5 years who were naturally exposed to S. haematobium infection. The children were treated with PZQ tablets and side effects were assessed through questionnaires completed by their caregivers within 24 hours of treatment. Six weeks after treatment, schistosome egg counts in urine were used to determine treatment efficacy. The results showed that PZQ treatment significantly reduced schistosome infection levels in 1–5 year olds with an egg reduction rate ( ERR ) of 99% and a cure rate ( CR ) of 92%. This was comparable to the efficacy of PZQ in 6–10 year olds, where ERR was 96% and CR was 67%. Only 3. 8% of the children reported side effects within 24 hours of treatment, which included stomach ache, loss of appetite, lethargy, and inflammation of the face and body. These findings suggest that PZQ treatment is as safe and efficacious in children aged 1–5 years as it is in older children.
A genome-wide RNA interference ( RNAi ) screen in Drosophila melanogaster has been used to identify novel genes involved in Ras-driven epithelial tumorigenesis. Ras is a small GTPase that is mutated in ~30% of human cancers. However, Ras mutations alone are not sufficient for tumorigenesis, and therefore, it is necessary to identify cooperating cancer-relevant signaling pathways. We have identified multiple novel, evolutionarily conserved pathways controlling Ras-driven epithelial tumorigenesis in Drosophila. The top 100 candidate tumor suppressor genes were validated in secondary Drosophila assays, identifying many known cancer genes and multiple novel candidate genes that cooperate with Ras-driven tumorigenesis. Among the novel top 80 candidate cancer genes, we have mechanistically characterized the function of the top hit, Tetraspanin 29Fb ( Tsp29Fb ). Tsp29Fb regulates EGFR signaling, epithelial architecture, and restrains tumor growth and invasion in Drosophila. The mammalian orthologs of the fly hits were significantly downregulated in thousands of primary tumors, revealing novel prognostic markers for human epithelial tumors. Low expression of the confirmed hits significantly correlated with the KRASG12 mutation status and poor prognosis in pancreatic cancer.
Meiotic drivers are selfish alleles that increase their transmission into progeny by subverting gametogenesis. They impose a fitness cost on the genome, leading to the evolution of suppressors. Here, we investigate the wtf gene family from Schizosaccharomyces pombe, previously shown to contain meiotic drivers in wild isolates. We demonstrate that wtf13 is a meiotic driver that kills spores that do not inherit it by generating a diffusible poison and a spore-specific antidote. We also show that wtf13 is suppressed by another wtf gene, wtf18-2, which arose spontaneously in the lab and encodes only an antidote. wtf18-2 rescues only the spores that inherit it, selfishly gaining a transmission advantage while dampening the drive of wtf13. This establishes a novel paradigm for meiotic drive suppressors and provides insight into the mechanisms and evolution of drive systems. Our results are consistent with the idea that an ancestral wtf gene was a dual-transcript poison-antidote meiotic driver, and that novel duplications of this ancestral driver could have been selected based on their abilities to cause drive and protect spores from the poison of the ancestral driver.
Gene expression variation among human individuals plays a key role in the susceptibility to different diseases and phenotypes. A major goal is to predict gene expression changes among individuals based on their genetic sequence variation. Here, we present an algorithm that predicts the expression of genes of unseen individuals given only their genotype in the local genomic vicinity of the predicted gene. The algorithm is remarkably robust and agrees well between the training and test sets, even when the training and test sets consist of individuals from distinct populations. We also present an extension that incorporates heterogeneous types of genomic annotations to differentially weigh the importance of the various genetic variants. Assigning higher weights to variants with particular annotations such as proximity to genes and high regional G/C content can further improve the predictions. We show that genes that are successfully predicted have, on average, higher expression and more variability across individuals, providing insight into the characteristics of the types of genes that can be predicted from their cis genetic variation. Notably, a subset of genes are predicted better by our algorithm when incorporating information from populations other than that of the predicted individuals, suggesting that part of the predictive sequence variation is shared across different populations and may be hard to distill using only individuals from the same population.
Malarial parasites are genetically diverse, leading to competitive interactions between strains. To understand the evolution of virulence and drug resistance, we need a quantitative understanding of the competition between strains. In this study, we investigated the cause of competitive suppression of an avirulent clone of Plasmodium chabaudi ( AS ) by a virulent clone ( AJ ) in immuno-deficient and competent mice. We used dynamical-model based Bayesian inference to test whether competitive suppression is caused by clone-specific differences in adaptive immune clearance of merozoites and parasitised red blood cells ( RBCs ), background loss of merozoites and parasitised RBCs, RBC age preference, RBC infection rate, burst size, and within-RBC interference. We found that just one parameter, the ratio of background loss rate of merozoites to invasion rate of mature RBCs, needed to be clone-specific to predict the data. This parameter was the same for both clones in single-clone infections, but different between the clones in mixed infections. The size of this difference was largest in immuno-competent mice and smallest in immuno-deficient mice. This explains why competitive suppression was alleviated in immuno-deficient mice. We found that competitive suppression acts early in infection, even before the day of peak parasitaemia. Our results suggest that the innate immune response clearing merozoites is the most likely mediator of competitive interactions between virulent and avirulent clones.
Origin-Dependent Inverted-Repeat Amplification ( ODIRA ) is a model proposed to explain the generation of interstitial, inverted triplications, a type of copy number variation ( CNV ). This model proposes that a replication error at pre-existing short, interrupted, inverted repeats in genomic sequences generates an extrachromosomal, inverted dimeric, autonomously replicating intermediate. This intermediate subsequently integrates into the genome by homologous recombination, creating an inverted triplication without loss of distal chromosomal sequences. We show that the proposed replication error—the ligation of leading and lagging nascent strands to create “closed” forks—can occur in vitro at short, interrupted inverted repeats. The removal of molecules with two closed forks results in a hairpin-capped linear duplex that replicates in vivo to create an inverted, dimeric plasmid. This plasmid subsequently integrates into the genome by homologous recombination, creating an inverted triplication. Our tests of key features of ODIRA lend support to this mechanism and suggest that it can also explain the generation of human, de novo, inverted amplicons that have a 2:1 mixture of sequences from both homologues of a single parent.
Influenza virus infection alters the sites of translation initiation in mammalian cells, potentially leading to the production of novel immune epitopes. Here, we systematically investigate the extent and impact of alternate translation initiation in cells infected with influenza virus. We first perform evolutionary analyses that suggest selection against non-canonical initiation at CUG codons in influenza virus lineages that have adapted to mammalian hosts. We then use ribosome profiling with the initiation inhibitor lactimidomycin to experimentally delineate translation initiation sites in a human lung epithelial cell line infected with influenza virus. We identify several candidate sites of alternate initiation in influenza mRNAs, all of which occur at AUG codons that are downstream of canonical initiation codons. One of these candidate downstream start sites truncates 14 amino acids from the N-terminus of the N1 neuraminidase protein, resulting in loss of its cytoplasmic tail and a portion of the transmembrane domain. This truncated neuraminidase protein is expressed on the cell surface during influenza virus infection, is enzymatically active, and is conserved in most N1 viral lineages. We do not detect globally higher levels of alternate translation initiation on host transcripts upon influenza infection or during the anti-viral response, but the subset of host transcripts induced by the anti-viral response is enriched for alternate initiation sites.
Enteric bacterial pathogens, such as enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli ( EHEC ), cause an enormous economic and health burden. EHEC causes a severe bloody diarrhea and a potentially fatal kidney disease ( hemolytic uremic syndrome ) for which there is no effective treatment or prophylaxis. EHEC and other enteric pathogens utilize a type III secretion system ( T3SS ) to inject virulence proteins ( effectors ) into host cells. In this study, we present evidence that the E. coli O157:H7 nleH1 and nleH2 genes encode T3SS effectors that bind to the human ribosomal protein S3 ( RPS3 ), a subunit of nuclear factor kappa-light-chain-enhancer of activated B cells ( NF-κB ) transcriptional complexes. NleH1 and NleH2 co-localized with RPS3 in the cytoplasm, but not in cell nuclei. The N-terminal region of both NleH1 and NleH2 was required for binding to the N-terminus of RPS3. NleH1 and NleH2 are autophosphorylated Ser/Thr protein kinases, but their binding to RPS3 is independent of kinase activity. NleH1, but not NleH2, reduced the nuclear abundance of RPS3 without altering the p50 or p65 NF-κB subunits or affecting the phosphorylation state or abundance of the inhibitory NF-κB chaperone IκBα. NleH1 repressed the transcription of a RPS3/NF-κB-dependent reporter plasmid, but did not inhibit the transcription of RPS3-independent reporters. In contrast, NleH2 stimulated RPS3-dependent transcription, as well as an AP-1-dependent reporter.
Transcription factor ( TF ) binding to its DNA target site is a fundamental regulatory interaction. The most common model used to represent TF binding specificities is the position specific scoring matrix ( PSSM ), which assumes independence between binding positions. However, in many cases, this simplifying assumption does not hold. Here, we present feature motif models ( FMMs ), a novel probabilistic method for modeling TF–DNA interactions, based on log-linear models. Our approach uses sequence features to represent TF binding specificities, where each feature may span multiple positions. We develop the mathematical formulation of our model and devise an algorithm for learning its structural features from binding site data. We also developed a discriminative motif finder, which discovers de novo FMMs that are enriched in target sets of sequences compared to background sets. We evaluate our approach on synthetic data and on the widely used TF chromatin immunoprecipitation ( ChIP ) dataset of Harbison et al. We then apply our algorithm to high-throughput TF ChIP data from mouse and human, revealing sequence features that are present in the binding specificities of mouse and human TFs, and show that FMMs explain TF binding significantly better than PSSMs.
Sympathetic nervous activity in humans and chimpanzees is regulated by the adrenergic α2C receptor ( ADRA2C ), an inhibitory modulator of the sympathetic nervous system. We find that the neuronal expression of ADRA2C is lower in humans and chimpanzees than in other primates. We identified a cis-regulatory region whose DNA sequences have been significantly accelerated in humans and chimpanzees. This region contains two neuron-restrictive silencer factor ( NRSF ) binding motifs, each of which harbours a polymorphism. Our genotyping and analysis of population genome data indicate that at both polymorphic sites, the derived allele has reached fixation in humans and chimpanzees but not in bonobos, whereas only the ancestral allele is present among macaques. Our CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing and reporter assays show that both derived nucleotides repress ADRA2C, most likely by increasing NRSF binding. In addition, we detected signatures of recent positive selection for lower neuronal ADRA2C expression in humans. Our findings indicate that there has been selective pressure for enhanced sympathetic nervous activity in the evolution of humans and chimpanzees.
C4 photosynthesis represents one of the most remarkable examples of convergent evolution, with at least 60 independent origins in both monocotyledons and dicotyledons. This highly complex trait is associated with an increase in productivity by ∼50% in tropical and subtropical areas. We developed a new informatics framework to enable deep evolutionary comparison of gene expression in species lacking reference genomes. We compared gene expression in two independent C4 lineages, Cleome gynandra and Zea mays, whose last common ancestor diverged ∼140 million years ago. We defined a cohort of 3, 335 genes that represent conserved components of leaf and photosynthetic development in these species. We show that genes encoding proteins of the C4 cycle are recruited into networks defined by photosynthesis-related genes. Despite the wide evolutionary separation and independent origins of the C4 phenotype, we report that these species use homologous transcription factors to both induce C4 photosynthesis and to maintain the cell specific gene expression required for the pathway to operate. We define a core molecular signature associated with leaf and photosynthetic maturation that is likely shared by angiosperm species derived from the last common ancestor of the monocotyledons and dicotyledons.
Ebola virus ( EBOV ) was the cause of an unprecedented epidemic in West Africa from 2013 to 2016, which spread to Europe and North America, infecting several Health Care Workers ( HCW ). To develop new countermeasures and understand the pathways of human-to-human transmission, we need a better understanding of EBOV infection patterns in different body compartments. We longitudinally explored the persistence of EBOV-specific negative sense genomic RNA ( neg-RNA ) and the presence of positive sense RNA ( pos-RNA ), including replication intermediate ( antigenomic-RNA ) and messenger RNA ( mRNA ) molecules, in the upper and lower respiratory tract, as compared to plasma, in a HCW infected with EBOV in Sierra Leone, who was hospitalized in Rome, Italy. We observed persistence of pos-RNA and neg-RNAs in the lower respiratory tract even after viral clearance from plasma, suggesting possible local replication. This study aims to enhance the knowledge on the biological features of EBOV that can contribute to the human-to-human transmissibility and to develop effective intervention strategies.
New World arenaviruses, such as Machupo virus ( MACV ) and Junin virus ( JUNV ), cause hemorrhagic fever diseases in humans in South America. We previously reported that a recombinant, chimeric MACV ( rMACV/Cd#1-GPC ) expressing glycoprotein from the Candid#1 ( Cd#1 ) vaccine strain of JUNV is completely attenuated in a murine model and protects animals from lethal challenge with MACV. To investigate the role of different domains of Cd#1 GPC in the attenuation of MACV, we rescued several rMACVs expressing the ectodomain of GPC from Cd#1 either alone ( MCg1 ), along with the transmembrane domain ( TMD ) F438I substitution ( MCg2 ), or with the TMD of Cd#1 ( MCg3 ). All rMACVs exhibited similar growth curves in cultured cells. In mice, the MCg1 displayed significant reduction in lethality as compared with rMACV. The MCg1 was detected in brains and spleens of MCg1-infected mice and the infection was associated with tissue inflammation. On the other hand, all animals survived MCg2 and MCg3 infection without detectable levels of virus in various organs while producing neutralizing antibody against Cd#1. Our data suggest the indispensable role of each GPC domain in the full attenuation and immunogenicity of rMACV/Cd#1 GPC.
Mutations in the centromeric histone 3 variant ( CENH3 ) induce post-zygotic incompatibility and uniparental inheritance in Arabidopsis. The CENH3 histone is essential for the proper segregation of sister chromatids during mitosis and meiosis. To better understand the functional constraints of CENH3, we complemented a null allele in Arabidopsis with a variety of mutant alleles, each inducing a single amino acid change in conserved residues of the histone fold domain. We found that many of these transgenic missense lines displayed wild-type growth and fertility on self-pollination, but exhibited frequent post-zygotic death and uniparental inheritance when crossed with wild-type plants. The failure of centromeres marked by these missense mutations in the histone fold domain of CENH3 reproduces the genome elimination syndromes described with chimeric CENH3 and CENH3 from diverged species. We also found that a single point mutation is sufficient to generate a haploid inducer, providing a simple one-step method for the identification of non-transgenic haploid inducers in existing mutagenized collections of crop species.
Human embryonic stem cells ( hESCs ) have the ability to differentiate into various cell types, including cardiac precursors. However, the role of alternative splicing ( AS ) in this process is not well understood. In this study, hESCs were modified to allow selection of pluripotent cells by neomycin resistance and cardiac precursors by puromycin resistance. Exon-level microarray expression data from undifferentiated hESCs and cardiac and neural precursors were used to identify splice isoforms with cardiac-restricted or common cardiac/neural differentiation expression patterns. These isoforms corresponded to genes involved in cytoskeletal remodeling, RNA splicing, muscle specification, and cell cycle checkpoint control, as well as genes with serine/threonine kinase and helicase activity. Using a new program called AltAnalyze, we identified novel changes in protein domain and microRNA binding site architecture that were predicted to affect protein function and expression. These changes included an enrichment of splice isoforms that oppose cell-cycle arrest in hESCs and that promote calcium signaling and cardiac development in cardiac precursors. Our data suggest that AS may influence lineage commitment and hESC maintenance at the level of specific splice isoforms and microRNA regulation.
Trehalose-6-phosphate ( T6P ) synthase OtsA and T6P phosphatase OtsB2 are key enzymes in the biosynthesis of trehalose in Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( M. tuberculosis ). Trehalose biosynthesis is considered an attractive target for the development of antimicrobials against M. tuberculosis. To assess the drug target potential of T6P phosphatase, we generated a conditional mutant of M. tuberculosis allowing the regulated gene silencing of the otsB2 gene. We found that otsB2 is essential for the growth of M. tuberculosis in vitro and for the acute infection phase in mice following aerosol infection. However, otsB2 is not essential for the chronic infection phase in mice, highlighting the substantial remodelling of trehalose metabolism during infection by M. tuberculosis. We found that blocking OtsB2 resulted in the accumulation of its substrate T6P, which appears to be toxic, leading to the self-poisoning of cells. T6P accumulation elicited a global upregulation of more than 800 genes, which might result from an increase in RNA stability implied by the enhanced neutralization of toxins exhibiting ribonuclease activity. Our data conclusively show that essentiality of OtsB2 relies on direct or indirect toxic effects associated with OtsA-mediated T6P accumulation.
Chagas' disease, caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi ( T. cruzi ), is a life-threatening illness affecting 11–18 million people worldwide. Current treatments are limited and have poor efficacy and safety profiles. Recent studies have identified T. cruzi proline racemase ( TcPR ) as an attractive candidate for improved chemotherapeutic intervention. TcPR is believed to expose critical residues that elicit a host mitogenic B-cell response, a process contributing to parasite persistence and immune system evasion. However, characterization of the conformational states of TcPR requires access to long-time-scale motions that are currently inaccessible by standard molecular dynamics simulations. Here, we describe advanced accelerated molecular dynamics simulations that extend the effective simulation time and capture large-scale motions of functional relevance. Our results indicate that the mitogenic properties of TcPR are likely associated with the exposure of conserved conformational epitopes located around previously unidentified binding pockets. We show for the first time a model for the open form of TcPR obtained through the application of state of the art molecular dynamic simulation. Our results provide new insights for future structure-based drug discovery and constitute an important step toward the rationalization of the molecular basis behind the mitogenic B-cell response of TcPR.
We report the development of an inducible and reversible gene knockout ( iKO ) system in mice. The iKO system is based on a binary approach combining two genetically modified mouse lines: a knockout ( KO ) line with a tetracycline-dependent transactivator replacing the endogenous target gene, and a line with a tetracycline-inducible cDNA of the target gene inserted into a tightly regulated ( TIGRE ) genomic locus. The TIGRE locus provides for low basal expression and high inducibility of the target gene. We have developed a method to easily introduce genes into the TIGRE site of mouse embryonic stem ( ES ) cells by recombinase-mediated insertion. The iKO system allows for the efficient production of reversible and inducible gene knockout and rescue in mice. The system can be turned on and off at will by treating the mice with doxycycline. As a proof of concept, we have created iKO mice in the apolipoprotein E ( ApoE ) gene, which allows for sensitive and quantitative phenotypic analyses. The results demonstrated reversible switching of ApoE transcription, plasma cholesterol levels, and atherosclerosis progression and regression. The iKO system shows stringent regulation and is a versatile genetic system that can easily incorporate other techniques and adapt to a wide range of applications.
Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, can be transmitted from mother to child through congenital infection. However, little is known about the genetic response of the placental environment to T. cruzi infection. In this study, we used a murine model to investigate the genetic response of the placenta to infection by two different T. cruzi strains: K98, a clone of the non-lethal myotropic CA-I strain ( TcI ), and VD ( TcVI ), isolated from a human case of congenital infection. We used functional genomics by microarray analysis to compare the gene expression profiles of placentas from uninfected mice and mice infected with either K98 or VD. Our results showed that both infected groups had down-regulation of the “Secretory Granule” pathway, whereas the “Innate Immune Response” and “Response to Interferon-gamma” pathways were up-regulated in VD-infected mice but not in K98-infected mice. We also found that metabolic processes, transcription, and macromolecular transport were down-regulated in infected placentas, and that some pathways related to cascade signaling had opposite regulation in VD and K98-infected mice. Furthermore, we detected a stronger tropism of the VD strain to the placental organ by detecting parasite DNA and RNA. Our study is the first to describe the genetic response of the placental environment to T. cruzi infection in a murine model.
Sindbis virus ( SINV ), also known as Ockelbo disease in Sweden and Pogosta disease in Finland, is a mosquito-borne virus that mainly occurs in tropical and sub-tropical countries. In northern Europe, SINV is suggested to cause regularly reoccurring outbreaks, with a hypothesised seven-year cycle of outbreaks based on reported human cases. We evaluated mosquito abundance and SINV prevalence in vector mosquitoes from an endemic area in central Sweden to find a more objective outbreak signal. Mosquitoes were collected in the River Dalälven floodplains during the years before, during, and after the hypothesised 2002 outbreak year and assayed for virus on cell culture. The obtained isolates were partially sequenced, and the nucleotide sequences were analysed using Bayesian maximum clade credibility and median joining network analysis. Our findings suggest that increased SINV-I prevalence in vector mosquitoes constitutes the most valuable outbreak marker for further scrutinising the hypothesised seven-year cycle of SINV-I outbreaks. In 2002, the Maximum Likelihood Estimated infection rates were 10. 0/1000 in the enzootic vectors Culex torrentium/pipiens, and 0. 62/1000 in the bridge-vector Aedes cinereus, compared to 4. 9/1000 and 0. 0/1000 in 2001 and 0. 0/1000 and 0. 32/1000 in 2003. The genetic analysis revealed local maintenance of four SINV-I clades in the River Dalälven floodplains over the years.
The locust olfactory system is a well-studied preparation for investigating the interaction of multiple coding mechanisms. In this system, the antennal lobe ( AL ) transforms dense, transiently synchronized spike trains across ensembles of neurons into a sparse representation in the mushroom body ( MB ), a region associated with memory. Recordings made in vivo from the locust MB demonstrated highly specific responses to odors in Kenyon cells ( KCs ). Typically, only a few KCs from the recorded population of neurons responded reliably when a specific odor was presented. Different odors induced responses in different KCs. Here, we explored the possibility that plasticity may control and tune synaptic weights of inputs to the mushroom body to ensure the specificity of KCs' responses to familiar or meaningful odors. We found that plasticity at the synapses between the AL and the MB efficiently regulated the delicate tuning necessary to selectively filter the intense AL oscillatory output and condense it to a sparse representation in the MB. Activity-dependent plasticity drove the observed specificity, reliability, and expected persistence of odor representations, suggesting a role for plasticity in information processing and making a testable prediction about synaptic plasticity at AL-MB synapses.
The Stockholm Atherosclerosis Gene Expression ( STAGE ) study aimed to identify functionally associated genes important for the development of coronary artery disease ( CAD ). The study analyzed 278 transcriptional profiles from liver, skeletal muscle, visceral fat, and atherosclerotic and unaffected arterial wall tissues isolated from CAD patients during coronary artery bypass surgery. Using two-way clustering, the study identified 60 tissue clusters, of which one cluster in atherosclerotic arterial wall and one in visceral fat segregated patients into two groups differing in the extent of coronary stenosis ( P = 0. 008 and P = 0. 00015, respectively ). The associations of these clusters with coronary atherosclerosis were validated by analyzing carotid atherosclerosis expression profiles. The study found that genes in the transendothelial migration of leukocytes ( TEML ) pathway were overrepresented in all three clusters, referred to as the atherosclerosis module ( A-module ). The A-module was found to be genetically enriched with CAD risk by 1. 8-fold ( P<0. 004 ). The transcription co-factor LIM domain binding 2 ( LDB2 ) was identified as a potential high-hierarchy regulator of the A-module, supported by subnetwork analysis, cellular and lesion expression of LDB2, and expression of 13 TEML genes in Ldb2–deficient arterial wall.
The circadian clock of the cyanobacterium Synechococcus is regulated by the KaiC protein, which runs through different phospho-states during a 24-hour cycle. The regulation of the kaiBC gene, which encodes the KaiB and KaiC proteins, plays a key role in the circadian clockwork. However, it has remained unclear which phospho-state of KaiC is involved in transcriptional activation and which in transcriptional suppression of kaiBC expression. To address this question, we systematically analyzed various combinations of positive and negative transcriptional feedback regulation by introducing a combined transcriptional/translational feedback loop ( TTFL ) and post-translational oscillator ( PTO ) model. Only a particular two-loop feedback mechanism was able to reproduce existing experimental observations, including the effects of knockout or overexpression of kai genes. Our model suggests that threonine and double phosphorylated KaiC hexamers activate kaiBC transcription, while unphosphorylated KaiC hexamers suppress it. We propose that the peak expression ratio of the positive and negative components of kaiBC expression is the main factor for how the different two-loop feedback models respond to removal or overexpression of kai genes.
HIV-2 infection is characterized by low pathogenicity and replicative potential. We investigated the distribution of HIV-2 reservoirs in antiretroviral-naive HIV-2 infected individuals. We found that HIV-2 DNA was undetectable in monocytes from all individuals and was quantifiable in transitional-memory CD4 T-cells ( TTM ) from 4 individuals, but in central-memory CD4 T-cells ( TCM ) from only 1 individual. HIV-2 DNA levels in peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMCs ) positively correlated with those in TTM but not TCM. HIV-2 reactivation was observed in cells from only 3 individuals. We also found that TCM had a lower expression of CXCR6 transcripts and a higher expression of TRIM5 transcripts compared to TTM. These findings suggest that HIV-2 reservoirs differ from HIV-1 reservoirs by the lack of monocytic infection and a limited infection of TCM associated with a lower expression of a potential alternative HIV-2 co-receptor, CXCR6, and a higher expression of a restriction factor, TRIM5. These findings shed new light on the low pathogenicity of HIV-2 infection and suggest mechanisms similar to those reported in other models of attenuated HIV/SIV infection.
The Attentional Routing Circuit ( ARC ) is a spiking neuron model that provides a mechanistic description of selective attentional processing in cortex. The model is implemented at the level of individual spiking neurons, with computations for performing selective attentional processing mapped to specific neuron types and laminar circuitry. The ARC is shown to quantitatively match several observed forms of attentional modulation, including shifting and shrinking of receptive fields, increases in responses without changes in selectivity for non-spatial features ( i. e. response gain ), and the effect on contrast-response functions being better explained as a response-gain effect than as contrast-gain. Unlike past models, the ARC embodies a single mechanism that unifies the above forms of attentional modulation, is consistent with a wide array of available data, and makes several specific and quantifiable predictions. The ARC's mechanisms for selective routing predict that spatial attention only affects neural spatial selectivity, without altering selectivity for other feature dimensions. The model further predicts that the seemingly different forms of attentional modulation are consequences of a single mechanism for selective attentional routing, and that an increasing proportion of neurons at each higher cortical level will show attentional modulation as a result of neurons switching from their default routing state to a selective routing state during attentionally demanding tasks.
Atrial fibrillation ( AF ) is a common and heritable arrhythmia associated with substantial morbidity. We examined the contribution of coding genetic variation to AF susceptibility in a large community-based sample of 1, 734 individuals with AF and 9, 423 without AF from the Framingham Heart Study, Cardiovascular Health Study, Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities Study, and NHLBI-GO Exome Sequencing Project. None of the 99, 404 common variants evaluated was significantly associated with AF after adjusting for multiple testing. Among the most significantly associated variants was a common missense variant in SYNPO2L ( rs3812629, p. Pro707Leu, odds ratio 1. 27, 95% confidence interval 1. 13–1. 43, P = 6. 6x10-5 ), which lies at a known AF susceptibility locus and is in linkage disequilibrium with a top marker from prior analyses at the locus. We did not observe significant associations between rare variants and AF in gene-based tests. Individuals with AF did not display any statistically significant enrichment for common or rare coding variation in previously implicated AF genes. These findings suggest that large-effect coding variation is not the predominant mechanism underlying AF.
Alveolar echinococcosis ( AE ), caused by the larval stage of Echinococcus multilocularis, is an emerging disease in Poland. Between 1990 and 2011, a total of 121 human cases of AE were detected, with 83 confirmed, 16 probable, and 22 possible cases. The majority of cases ( 76% ) were diagnosed in an advanced stage of the disease. The liver was the primary location of AE in all cases, and in 24. 8% of patients, the disease spread to other organs. The majority of patients ( 94% ) were treated with albendazole, and 60% underwent a surgical operation, including 15 liver transplantations. Unfortunately, the disease was fatal in 19% of patients, with a mean age at death of 54. 1 years. The majority of cases ( 68. 6% ) occurred in the north-eastern part of Poland, where a family agglomeration of AE was found in 4 foci involving 9 patients. The mean age of patients at the time of diagnosis was 47. 7 years, and the sex ratio was 0. 86/1. 0 ( male/female ).
Metalloregulatory proteins, such as the zinc-sensing zinc uptake regulator ( Zur ) protein, play a crucial role in regulating gene expression in response to changes in metal availability. In this study, we investigated the molecular mechanism of Zur at each of the known Zur-regulated genes in Escherichia coli. We solved the structure of zinc-loaded Zur bound to the PznuABC promoter and found that this metalloregulatory protein represses gene expression by a highly cooperative binding of two adjacent dimers to essentially encircle the core element of each of the Zur-regulated promoters. Cooperativity in these protein-DNA interactions requires a pair of asymmetric salt bridges between Arg52 and Asp49′ that connect otherwise independent dimers. We also discovered a new member of the Zur-regulon, pliG, which is directly regulated by Zur in a zinc responsive manner. The pliG promoter forms stable complexes with either one or two Zur dimers with significantly less protein-DNA cooperativity than observed at other Zur-regulon promoters. We found that the number of ferric uptake regulator ( Fur )-family dimers that bind within any given promoter varies significantly and that the thermodynamic profile of the Zur-DNA interactions directly correlates with the physiological response at different promoters. These findings open the door to understanding how zinc availability and partial metal occupancy at a subset of the eight zinc binding sites in the repressor complex can fine tune stress responsive gene expression across a range of promoters.
Rift Valley fever ( RVF ) is a vector-borne zoonotic disease that causes high morbidity and mortality in ruminants. In 2008–2009, a RVF outbreak affected the whole Madagascar island, including the Anjozorobe district located in Madagascar highlands. An entomological survey showed the absence of Aedes among the potential RVF virus ( RVFV ) vector species identified in this area, and an overall low abundance of mosquitoes due to unfavorable climatic conditions during winter. No serological nor virological sign of infection was observed in wild terrestrial mammals of the area, suggesting an absence of wild RVF virus ( RVFV ) reservoir. However, a three years serological and virological follow-up in cattle showed a recurrent RVFV circulation. To understand the key determinants of this unexpected recurrent transmission, a spatial deterministic discrete-time metapopulation model combined with cattle trade network was designed and parameterized to reproduce the local conditions using observational data collected in the area. Three scenarios that could explain the RVFV recurrent circulation in the area were analyzed: ( i ) RVFV overwintering thanks to a direct transmission between cattle when viraemic cows calve, vectors being absent during the winter, ( ii ) a low level vector-based circulation during winter thanks to a residual vector population, without direct transmission between cattle, ( iii ) combination of both above mentioned mechanisms. Multi-model inference methods resulted in a model incorporating both a low level RVFV winter vector-borne transmission and a direct transmission between animals when viraemic cows calve. Predictions satisfactorily reproduced field observations, 84% of cattle infections being attributed to vector-borne transmission, and 16% to direct transmission.
The Asian tiger mosquito, Aedes albopictus, is a highly invasive and aggressive daytime-biting mosquito that is a major public health threat throughout its expanding range. We used 13 nuclear microsatellite loci and mitochondrial COI sequences to investigate the historical and contemporary movements of Ae. albopictus in the Indo-Pacific region and to characterize its population structure. Our results show that Ae. albopictus was most likely introduced to New Guinea via mainland Southeast Asia, before colonizing the Solomon Islands via either Papua New Guinea or Southeast Asia. We also found that the recent incursion into northern Australia’s Torres Strait Islands was seeded chiefly from Indonesia. For the first time, we provide evidence of a recently colonized population ( the Torres Strait Islands ) that has undergone rapid temporal changes in its genetic makeup, which could be the result of genetic drift or represent a secondary invasion from an unknown source. The species’ genetic structure in the region tends to favour a dispersal pattern driven mostly by human movements. Our study provides a more widespread sampling distribution of the species’ native range, revealing more spatial population structure than previously shown.
Infection with Schistosoma mansoni has been shown to have a negative impact on the quality of life of schoolchildren in Mwanza Region, North-Western Tanzania. A cross-sectional study of 572 schoolchildren aged 7–8 years found that 58. 7% were infected with S. mansoni, with 56. 5% having light infections and 16. 4% having heavy infections. The prevalence of anaemia was 30. 1% and stunting and wasting were found in less than 10% of the population. However, there was no association between S. mansoni infection and anthropometry, anaemia, liver or spleen pathology. In contrast, S. mansoni infection was found to have a significant effect on the emotional dimension of quality of life, as measured by the PedsQL tool. Children with S. mansoni infection had a lower score in emotional PedsQL compared to uninfected children. However, there was no association between S. mansoni infection and physical fitness, as measured by VO2 max. In multivariable linear regression analyses, age, S. mansoni infection, haemoglobin and VO2 max were significant predictors for emotional PedsQL, while physical PedsQL, height, age and haemoglobin were significant predictors for VO2 max.
Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by the spirochete Leptospira, with wild rodents, such as the brown rat ( Rattus norvegicus ), serving as the main reservoir. Experimental studies of Leptospira infection in rats have traditionally used an intraperitoneal inoculation route, which is not a natural route of infection. We investigated the effects of subcutaneous and mucosal inoculation routes compared to the intraperitoneal route on Leptospira infection in adult rats. Leptospira infection was asymptomatic and caused similar antibody production regardless of the inoculation route. The observed renal colonization rates were 8 out of 8 rats, 5 out of 8 rats, and 1 out of 8 rats for the intraperitoneal, mucosal, and subcutaneous inoculation routes, respectively. Among the natural infection routes studied, mucosal inoculation was more efficient for renal colonization associated with urinary excretion than the subcutaneous route and induced a slower-progressing infection than the intraperitoneal route. These results can facilitate understanding of the infection modalities in rats, unlike the epidemiological studies conducted in wild rats.
Sepsis is a life-threatening disease characterized by excessive inflammatory responses, severe tissue injury, organ dysfunction, and ultimately, mortality. In this study, we identify a novel role for Annexin A2 ( AnxA2 ) in modulating the inflammatory response during polymicrobial sepsis. AnxA2 is a multi-compartmental protein involved in diverse cellular processes, including regulation of innate immunity, endosome function, and inflammation. We show that AnxA2 functions as a putative reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) inhibitor in sepsis progression, and that cysteine 9 of AnxA2 is the most important amino acid for oxidation regulation. In sepsis models, AnxA2 deficient mice ( anxa2-/- ) manifested increased pro-inflammatory cytokines, neutrophil infiltration, decreased bacterial clearance, and impaired survival. Furthermore, AnxA2 deficiency led to increased levels of ROS and IL-17A, a pro-inflammatory cytokine. We found that ROS is responsible for elevated IL-17A levels and subsequently exaggerated inflammatory response. Depletion of IL-17 via CRISPR/Cas9 KO strategy down-regulated inflammation and conferred protection against sepsis in anxa2-/- mice. Our findings reveal a previously undemonstrated function for AnxA2 in inflammatory response in polymicrobial sepsis models via an AnxA2-ROS-IL-17 axis, providing insight into the regulation of pathophysiology of sepsis.
HIV-1 infection of macrophages plays a key role in viral pathogenesis and progression to AIDS. Polyinosine-polycytidylic acid ( poly ( I∶C ) ), a synthetic analog of dsRNA, and bacterial lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ), the ligands for Toll-like receptors ( TLR ) TLR3 and TLR4, respectively, are known to decrease HIV-1 infection in monocyte-derived macrophages ( MDMs ). We found that poly ( I∶C ) - and LPS-stimulation of MDMs abrogated infection by CCR5-using, macrophage-tropic HIV-1, and by vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein-pseudotyped HIV-1 virions. Suppression of infection did not correlate with differential effects on CD4 or CCR5 expression, type I interferon induction, or production of pro-inflammatory cytokines or β-chemokines. Using microarray analysis and quantitative reverse transcription ( RT ) -PCR, we found increased microRNA ( miR ) -155 levels in MDMs upon TLR3/4- but not TLR7-stimulation, and a miR-155 specific inhibitor partially restored infectivity in poly ( I∶C ) -stimulated MDMs. Ectopic miR-155 expression remarkably diminished HIV-1 infection in primary MDMs and cell lines. Our findings provide evidence that miR-155 exerts an anti-HIV-1 effect by targeting several HIV-1 dependency factors involved in post-entry, pre-integration events, leading to severely diminished HIV-1 infection.
Most organisms use daily light/dark cycles as timing cues to control many essential physiological processes. In plants, growth rates of the embryonic stem ( hypocotyl ) are maximal at different times of day, depending on external photoperiod and the internal circadian clock. To determine the transcriptional component associated with the rhythmic control of growth, we applied temporal analysis of the Arabidopsis thaliana seedling transcriptome under multiple growth conditions and mutant backgrounds using DNA microarrays. We show that a group of plant hormone-associated genes are coexpressed at the time of day when hypocotyl growth rate is maximal. This expression correlates with overrepresentation of a cis-acting element ( CACATG ) in phytohormone gene promoters, which is sufficient to confer the predicted diurnal and circadian expression patterns in vivo. Using circadian clock and light signaling mutants, we show that both internal coincidence of phytohormone signaling capacity and external coincidence with darkness are required to coordinate wild-type growth. We argue that the circadian clock indirectly controls growth by permissive gating of light-mediated phytohormone transcript levels to the proper time of day. This temporal integration of hormone pathways allows plants to fine tune phytohormone responses for seasonal and shade-appropriate growth regulation.
Rhodnius prolixus, the primary vector of Chagas disease, can be controlled by modifying its gut microbiota to induce systemic RNA interference ( RNAi ). Here, we show that feeding R. prolixus nymphs and adults with Escherichia coli HT115 ( DE3 ) expressing double-stranded RNA ( dsRNA ) for the Rhodnius heme-binding protein ( RHBP ) and catalase ( CAT ) results in systemic and temporal RNAi effects. RHBP is an egg protein and CAT is an antioxidant enzyme expressed in all tissues by all developmental stages. We found that concentrations of E. coli HT115 ( DE3 ) above 3. 35 × 107 CFU/mL produced a significant RHBP and CAT gene knockdown in nymphs and adults. RHBP expression in the fat body was reduced by 99% three days after feeding, returning to normal levels 10 days after feeding. CAT expression was reduced by 99% and 96% in the ovary and the posterior midgut, respectively, five days after ingestion. We also found that feeding females 105 CFU/mL of the natural symbiont, Rhodococcus rhodnii, transformed to express RHBP-specific hairpin RNA reduced RHBP expression by 89% and reduced oviposition. These results suggest that modifying the insect microbiota to induce systemic RNAi in R. prolixus may result in a paratransgenic strategy for sustainable vector control.
Malaria remains the leading cause of fever in pregnant women on the Thai-Burmese border, accounting for 55. 5% of all febrile illnesses in a cohort of 409 pregnant women. Arthropod-borne diseases, including malaria, rickettsial infections, and dengue, as well as zoonotic diseases, such as leptospirosis, accounted for nearly half of all febrile illnesses in pregnant women. Pyelonephritis was also a common cause of fever, occurring in 19. 7% of febrile women. Scrub and murine typhus were associated with poor pregnancy outcomes, including stillbirth and low birth weight. Fever in pregnancy increases the risk of maternal death and infant morbidity and mortality, and is associated with poor pregnancy outcomes, including miscarriage, stillbirth, and premature delivery. Despite the marked reduction in malaria incidence on the western border of Thailand, malaria remains the leading cause of fever in pregnancy in this low transmission area.
The relationship between maternal age and recombination rate in humans has been examined in a study of 69 French-Canadian pedigrees. Using over 600, 000 genotyped markers, we localized recombination events in 195 maternal meioses and observed a significant decrease in recombination rates with advancing maternal age. This effect appears to be localized in the middle section of chromosomal arms and near subtelomeric regions, and is likely driven by chromosome-specific effects. We propose a model that reconciles our findings with reported associations between maternal age and recombination in cases of trisomies. The most important factor linked to chromosomal aneuploidy in women is advancing maternal age, and it remains important to establish associations between patterns of recombination and maternal age in normal meioses. Our results support the hypothesis that chromosome-specific effects may be critical determinants of the complex relationship between maternal age and recombination in humans. The decay in crossovers with maternal age appears to be localized in specific portions of chromosomal arms, with a significant reduction in recombination rates observed for older mothers in the middle section of chromosomal arms and near subtelomeric regions.
Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that causes severe disease in immunocompromised patients. Developing vaccines against this pathogen is challenging, as patients most at risk of developing disease are deficient in aspects of the adaptive immune system. Here, we present a novel approach to induce innate memory in macrophages in vivo, which provides complete protection against secondary challenge in the absence of adaptive immune cells. Macrophages were primed in vivo with Cryptococcus neoformans and interferon-γ ( IFN-γ ), resulting in a rapid up-regulation of IFN-γ and STAT1 signaling pathways following secondary challenge. The enhanced cytokine recall responses were pathogen-specific, dependent on changes in histone methylation and acetylation, and correlated with increased STAT1 binding to promoter regions of genes associated with protective anti-fungal immunity. Thus, we demonstrate an alternative mechanism to induce macrophage innate memory in vivo that facilitates pathogen-specific vaccine-mediated immune responses. This concept suggests that immunization strategies that drive memory-like innate immune responses may provide a novel and effective mechanism for inducing vaccine-mediated protection in immunocompromised patients. Our data show that in vivo IFN-γ priming of macrophages can extend the memory-like phenotype for weeks, providing protection against subsequent infection.
Polycomb repressive complexes ( PRCs ) play a crucial role in transcriptional repression and developmental regulation in both plants and animals. In Arabidopsis, depletion of different members of PRCs causes both overlapping and unique phenotypic defects. Here, we show that CURLY LEAF ( CLF ), a major catalytic subunit of PRC2, coordinates with different members of PRC1 in suppression of distinct plant developmental programs. We found that expression of flower development genes is repressed in seedlings preferentially via non-redundant role of CLF, which specifically associates with LIKE HETEROCHROMATIN PROTEIN1 ( LHP1 ). In contrast, expression of embryo development genes is repressed by PRC1-catalytic core subunits AtBMI1 and AtRING1 in common with PRC2-catalytic enzymes CLF or SWINGER ( SWN ). This context-dependent role of CLF corresponds well with the change in H3K27me3 profiles, and is remarkably associated with differential co-occupancy of binding motifs of transcription factors ( TFs ), including MADS box and ABA-related factors. We propose that different combinations of PRC members distinctively regulate different developmental programs, and their target specificity is modulated by specific TFs.
RNA polymerase II is a multisubunit enzyme responsible for transcription in eukaryotic cells. Its active site contains a “trigger loop” ( TL ) that plays a crucial role in substrate selection, catalysis, and translocation. To understand the function of the TL, we have quantitatively phenotyped nearly all TL single variants of the Saccharomyces cerevisiae RNA polymerase II at individual-residue resolution. We have identified three mutant classes with distinct distributions among TL residues that are linked to transcription defects or various stresses. Mutations disrupting an intra-TL hydrophobic pocket confer phenotypes consistent with pocket disruption and increased catalysis. Furthermore, we have identified allele-specific genetic interactions among TL and TL-proximal domain residues that support the contribution of the funnel and bridge helices ( BH ) to TL dynamics. Our structural genetics approach incorporates structural and phenotypic data for high-resolution dissection of transcription mechanisms and their evolution. This approach is readily applicable to other essential yeast proteins and expands the current scope of existing deep mutational scanning studies. Our data indicate that both intra-TL interactions and TL interactions with nearby domains are critical for TL function. We have identified many more predicted gain-of-function and loss-of-function TL variants, some of which are predicted to confer epistatic interactions.
Rabies virus ( RV ) is the causative agent of a fatal central nervous system ( CNS ) disease in mammals. The virus is usually transmitted by bites or scratches from rabid animals, resulting in the dissemination of virions into skin and muscle tissue. In this study, we aimed to elucidate the pathogenetic relevance of hematogenous RV spread. We infected mice intramuscularly ( i. m. ) or intravenously ( i. v. ) with the dog-associated RV strain DOG4 or the silver-haired bat-associated RV strain SB to determine whether certain RV variants might have the capacity to invade the CNS from the periphery via hematogenous spread. In contrast to i. m. infection where both variants caused a lethal encephalopathy, only i. v. infection with SB resulted in the development of a lethal infection. Our data suggest that hematogenous spread of SB can lead to a fatal encephalopathy through direct retrograde invasion of the CNS at the neurovascular interface of the hypothalamus-hypophysis system. Immunohistochemical analysis showed that only i. v. administered SB directly infected the forebrain, with the earliest affected regions being those hypothalamic nuclei connected by neurosecretory fibers to the circumventricular organs neurohypophysis and median eminence. This alternative mode of virus spread has implications for the post-exposure prophylaxis of rabies, particularly with silver-haired bat-associated RV.
Since 1918, the H1N1 subtype of influenza A virus has caused significant morbidity and mortality in humans. The evolutionary history of the A/H1N1 virus is not well understood, particularly the virological basis for several notable epidemics of unusual severity in the 1940s and 1950s. Using a data set of 71 representative complete genome sequences sampled between 1918 and 2006, we show that segmental reassortment has played an important role in the genomic evolution of A/H1N1 since 1918. Specifically, we demonstrate that an A/H1N1 isolate from the 1947 epidemic acquired novel PB2 and HA genes through intra-subtype reassortment, which may explain the abrupt antigenic evolution of this virus. Similarly, the 1951 influenza epidemic may also have been associated with reassortant A/H1N1 viruses. Intra-subtype reassortment appears to be a more important process in the evolution and epidemiology of H1N1 influenza A virus than previously realized.
Nicotine exerts its reinforcing action by stimulating nicotinic acetylcholine receptors ( nAChRs ) and boosting dopamine ( DA ) output from the ventral tegmental area ( VTA ). Recent data have led to a debate about the principal pathway of nicotine action: direct stimulation of the DAergic cells through nAChR activation, or disinhibition mediated through desensitization of nAChRs on GABAergic interneurons. We use a computational model of the VTA circuitry and nAChR function to shed light on this issue. Our model illustrates that the α4β2-containing nAChRs either on DA or GABA cells can mediate the acute effects of nicotine. We account for in vitro as well as in vivo data, and predict the conditions necessary for either direct stimulation or disinhibition to be at the origin of DA activity increases. We propose key experiments to disentangle the contribution of both mechanisms. We show that the rate of endogenous acetylcholine input crucially determines the evoked DA response for both mechanisms. Together our results delineate the mechanisms by which the VTA mediates the acute rewarding properties of nicotine and suggest an acetylcholine dependence hypothesis for nicotine reinforcement.
Cutaneous leishmaniasis ( CL ) is a chronic skin disease caused by Leishmania parasites transmitted by sand fly vectors. In Afghanistan, Leishmania ( L. ) major and L. tropica are the principal causative species. A randomized, double-blinded, phase IIa trial was conducted in Kabul from 2004 to 2008 to evaluate a novel therapeutic concept to prevent superinfections, accelerate wound closure, and improve the cosmetic outcome of CL. Patients suffering from L. tropica CL were treated with bipolar high-frequency electrocauterization ( EC ) followed by daily moist-wound-treatment ( MWT ) with polyacrylate hydrogel with ( group I ) or without ( group II ) pharmaceutical sodium chlorite ( DAC N-055 ). Patients below age 5, with facial lesions, pregnancy, or serious comorbidities were excluded. The primary outcome was the time needed for complete lesion epithelialization. The mean duration for complete wound closure was 43. 1 days in group I and 42 days in group II ( p = 0. 83 ). In patients with Leishmania-positive 2nd biopsies, DAC N-055 caused a more rapid wound epithelialization ( 37. 2 days vs. 58. 3 days; p = 0. 08 ). Superinfections occurred in both groups at the same rate ( 8. 8% ). In vitro, DAC N-055 showed a leishmanicidal effect on pro- and amastigotes. Compared to previous results with intralesional antimony injections, the EC plus MWT protocol led to more rapid wound closure.
RAS is one of the most prevalent oncogenes, and the RAF-MEK-MAPK module is the main conduit through which RAS transmits proliferative signals in normal and cancer cells. To obtain a comprehensive view of the elements functionally linked to the RAS/MAPK cascade, we used a quantitative assay in Drosophila S2 cells to conduct a genome-wide RNAi screen for factors impacting RAS-mediated MAPK activation. The screen led to the identification of 101 validated hits, including most of the previously known factors associated with this pathway. Epistasis experiments were carried out on individual candidates to determine their position relative to core pathway components. We found that most hits unexpectedly work downstream of MEK and specifically influence MAPK expression. These hits mainly consist of constitutive splicing factors and suggest that splicing plays a specific role in establishing MAPK levels. We further characterized two representative members of this group and found that they act by regulating mapk alternative splicing. This study provides an unprecedented assessment of the factors modulating RAS/MAPK signaling in Drosophila.
Cryptococcus neoformans and Cryptococcus gattii are two species of the Cryptococcus neoformans/C. gattii species complex that cause cryptococcosis in humans and animals. A retrospective study of 498 isolates from clinical, environmental, and veterinary sources in Thailand was conducted to gain a more detailed picture of cryptococcosis in the country. The majority of the isolates ( 68. 9% ) were from males with a mean age of 37. 97 years, and 88. 5% of Cryptococcus neoformans and 37. 5% of Cryptococcus gattii isolates were from HIV patients. The majority of the isolates ( 94. 8% ) were Cryptococcus neoformans molecular type VNI, regardless of their source. Multilocus Sequence Type ( MLST ) analysis identified a total of 20 sequence types ( ST ) in Thailand, with ST30 for Cryptococcus gattii and ST82, ST83, ST137, ST141, ST172, and ST173 for Cryptococcus neoformans being unique to Thailand. Most of the Cryptococcus gattii isolates were ST7 = VGIIb, which is identical to the less virulent minor Vancouver island outbreak genotype, indicating Thailand as a stepping stone in the global spread of this outbreak strain. The current study revealed a greater genetic diversity and a wider range of major molecular types being present amongst Thai cryptococcal isolates than previously reported.
The evolution of transcriptional regulatory networks is a major source of phenotypic variation across organisms. While changes to cis-regulatory elements are thought to be the predominant means by which regulatory networks evolve, examples of regulatory network divergence due to transcription factor ( TF ) variation have also been observed. We analyzed the evolution of the largest class of metazoan TFs, Cys2-His2 zinc finger ( C2H2-ZF ) TFs, across 12 Drosophila species spanning ~45 million years of evolution. We found that a significant fraction of all C2H2-ZF 1-to-1 orthologs in flies exhibit variations that can affect their DNA-binding specificities. In addition to loss and recruitment of C2H2-ZF domains, we found diverging DNA-contacting residues in ~44% of domains shared between D. melanogaster and the other fly species. These variations were rarely found as polymorphisms within a population of D. melanogaster flies, indicating their rapid fixation. The predicted specificities of these dynamic domains gradually change across phylogenetic distances, suggesting stepwise evolutionary trajectories for TF divergence. Our work suggests that a subset of highly dynamic and largely unstudied TFs are a likely source of regulatory variation in Drosophila and other metazoans.
Salmonella enterica serotypes Typhi and Paratyphi A are the causative agents of typhoid and paratyphoid fevers. The development of serotype-specific PCR ( polymerase chain reaction ) assays is required to accelerate diagnosis and overcome the lack of typing sera and the need for culture in some situations. However, the sensitivity and specificity of such assays must be demonstrated on large collections of strains representative of the targeted serotypes and all other bacterial populations producing similar clinical symptoms. Here, we describe the development of serotype-specific PCR assays for serotypes Typhi and Paratyphi A using a new family of repeated DNA sequences, CRISPR ( clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats ), as a serotype-specific target. We developed a conventional multiplex PCR assay for the detection and differentiation of serotypes Typhi and Paratyphi A from cultured isolates, as well as EvaGreen-based real-time singleplex PCR assays with the same two sets of primers. We achieved 100% sensitivity and specificity for each protocol after validation of the assays on 188 serotype Typhi and 74 serotype Paratyphi A strains from diverse genetic groups, geographic origins and time periods, and on 70 strains of bacteria frequently encountered in bloodstream infections, including 29 other Salmonella serotypes and 42 strains from 38 other bacterial species. Our serotype-specific PCR assays should facilitate the rapid and accurate identification of these two major serotypes in a large range of clinical and public health laboratories with access to PCR technology.
Leishmania major is an intracellular protozoan parasite that causes cutaneous leishmaniasis. The protective immune response to this parasite involves the differentiation of IFNγ-secreting CD4+ T helper 1 ( Th1 ) cells. Notch receptors are known to regulate cell differentiation during development, but their role in the polarization of peripheral CD4+ T helper 1 cells is not well understood. Here, we investigated the role of Notch signaling in Th1 cell differentiation following infection with L. major. Mice with T cell-specific gene ablation of Notch1 ( N1 ), Notch2 ( N2 ), or both ( N1N2ΔCD4Cre ) were infected with L. major. Mice lacking both N1 and N2 ( N1N2ΔCD4Cre ) developed unhealing lesions and uncontrolled parasitemia. In contrast, mice with single inactivation of N1 or N2 ( N1ΔCD4Cre or N2ΔCD4Cre ) were resistant to infection and developed a protective Th1 immune response. We show that Notch signaling through either N1 and/or N2 induces the secretion of IFNγ by CD4+ Th1 cells. This effect is independent of CSL/RBP-Jκ, the major effector of Notch receptors, since L. major-infected mice with a RBP-Jκ deletion in their T cells were able to develop IFNγ-secreting Th1 cells.
Schistosoma mansoni infection significantly increases susceptibility to systemic SHIV clade C infection in rhesus macaques after mucosal virus exposure. This is the first direct evidence showing that helminth infection increases host susceptibility to mucosal AIDS virus transmission in primates. Systemic infection of S. mansoni-infected rhesus macaques was established by low doses of virus that remained sub-infectious in parasite-free hosts. The 50% animal infectious ( AID50 ) SHIV-C dose was 17-fold lower in parasitized animals compared to controls ( P<0. 001 ). Coinfected animals also had significantly higher peak viral RNA loads than controls ( P<0. 001 ), as well as increased viral replication in CD4+ central memory cells ( P = 0. 03 ). This increased susceptibility to mucosal immunodeficiency virus transmission, elevated viral replication in coinfected hosts, and accelerated loss of memory T cells have profound public health implications for areas of the world where both parasitic worms and HIV-1 are endemic. Our data support the suggestion that better control of helminth infections may favorably impact efforts to reduce the spread of HIV/AIDS.
Acetylcholine ( ACh ) is a neurotransmitter that plays a key role in regulating neural excitability and sleep-wake states. In the cortex, ACh modulates neural excitability by reducing spike-frequency adaptation ( SFA ) and shifting the phase response curve ( PRC ). We present a biophysical model of a cortical network composed of Hodgkin-Huxley type neurons with a M-current regulated by ACh. Our results show that changes in neural excitability and network structure interact to create three distinct functional regimes: localized asynchronous, traveling asynchronous, and traveling synchronous patterns of activity. These regimes are qualitatively consistent with experimental observations of cortical activity during slow wave sleep ( SWS ), REM sleep, and waking states. During SWS, traveling patterns of activity occur in the cortex, while in other states, stationary patterns are observed. We show that the level of ACh determines how sensitive network activity is to synaptic heterogeneity and that ACh induced changes in SFA level and PRC shape occur over differing values of gKs¯. Our results indicate that ACh mediated SFA can induce large scale spatio-temporal dynamics and that neural networks composed of highly excitable cells will be more responsive to synaptic heterogeneities.
Esophageal adenocarcinoma ( EAC ) develops in an inflammatory microenvironment with reduced microbial diversity. We investigated the role of mutations in the Toll-like receptor ( TLR ) signaling pathway in the development of EAC. We interrogated whole genome sequencing data from 171 EAC patients and found that non-synonymous mutations affected the TLR pathway in 25/171 ( 14. 6% ) tumors. TLR mutant cases were associated with more proximal tumors and metastatic disease. We validated our findings in an external EAC dataset with non-synonymous TLR pathway mutations in 33/149 ( 22. 1% ) tumors. TLR4 was the most frequently mutated gene with eleven mutations in 10/171 ( 5. 8% ) of EAC tumors. The TLR4 mutants E439G, S570I, F703C and R787H were confirmed to have impaired reactivity to bacterial lipopolysaccharide with marked reductions in signaling by luciferase reporter assays. In addition to EAC, TLR pathway mutations were frequently observed in solid tumors arising in body sites exposed to microbiota, including colorectal adenocarcinoma, stomach adenocarcinoma, cutaneous melanoma, uterine endometrioid carcinoma and lung adenocarcinoma. Overall, our findings show that TLR pathway genes are recurrently mutated in EAC, and TLR4 mutations have decreased responsiveness to bacterial lipopolysaccharide and may play a role in disease pathogenesis in a subset of patients.
Taste cell differentiation is a critical process in the development of the sense of taste, which is essential for animal survival. Although the mechanisms of taste signal transduction are well understood, the ontogeny of taste cells remains largely unknown. We used a novel approach to investigate the molecular regulation of taste system development in mice by combining in silico and in vivo analyses. We discovered that taste receptor calcium signaling molecules ( TRCSMs ) colocalized within developing circumvallate papillae ( CVP ), and used computational analysis to investigate the possibility of a common regulatory network for TRCSM transcription. We identified Hes1 as a likely common regulatory factor and examined its function in vivo. Expression profile analyses revealed that decreased expression of nuclear HES1 correlated with expression of type II taste cell markers. After stage E18, the CVP of Hes1−/− mutants displayed over 5-fold more TRCSM-immunoreactive cells than did the CVP of their wild-type littermates. Thus, according to our composite analyses, Hes1 is likely to play a role in orchestrating taste cell differentiation in developing taste buds.
Ethylene and auxin play important roles in regulating root growth and development in plants. In Arabidopsis, ethylene and auxin act synergistically to inhibit root elongation. However, the interaction between ethylene and auxin in rice is still unclear. Here, we report that the transcriptional activation of OsEIL1 on the expression of YUC8/REIN7 and indole-3-pyruvic acid ( IPA ) -dependent auxin biosynthesis is required for ethylene-inhibited root elongation in rice. We showed that ethylene-inhibited primary root elongation is dependent on YUC-based auxin biosynthesis. We identified a rice ethylene-insensitive mutant, rein7-1, in which YUC8/REIN7 is truncated at its C-terminus. Mutation in YUC8/REIN7 reduced auxin biosynthesis in rice, while YUC8/REIN7 overexpression enhanced ethylene sensitivity in the roots. Moreover, YUC8/REIN7 catalyzed the conversion of IPA to indole-3-acetic acid ( IAA ), and a truncated version of YUC8/REIN7 resulted in significant reduction of enzymatic activity. We further showed that ethylene induced YUC8/REIN7 expression and promoted auxin accumulation in roots. Addition of low concentrations of IAA rescued the ethylene response in the rein7-1, strongly demonstrating that ethylene-inhibited root elongation depends on IPA-dependent auxin biosynthesis.
The first nationwide epidemiological study on non-tuberculous mycobacterial ( NTM ) diseases in Saudi Arabia was conducted to investigate the current epidemiologic situation in the country. A total of 527 NTM isolates with clinical and demographical data were collected over a period of 24 months. Primary species identification was carried out by line probe assays followed by sequencing of 16S rRNA, 16S-23S ITS region, rpoB and hsp65 genes. The study revealed a higher proportion of Saudi citizens ( 76. 5% ), elderly ( >60 years ) patients ( 34. 2% ), and male gender ( 65. 3% ). Overall, 75. 1% of the isolates were of pulmonary origin with a proven clinical significance of 44. 7%. A total of 34 NTM species, including 17 rare species, were identified, in addition to 8 ‘undefined’ isolates. M. simiae ( 22. 6% ), M. fortuitum ( 18. 1% ) and M. abscessus ( 17. 8% ) were the predominant species. Interestingly, 27 new cases of clinically relevant M. riyadhense were identified. The study also revealed rare clinical events such as mycobacteremia, cecum abscess, peritonitis and ascites caused by M. wolinskyi, M. holsaticum, M. duvalii and M. monacence respectively. Diabetes mellitus and previous history of tuberculosis were identified as independent risk factors associated with NTM diseases.
Quiescence entry and chronological lifespan ( CLS ) extension in yeast are dependent on the accumulation of storage carbohydrates mediated by the kinases Yak1, Mck1 and Rim15. Upon starvation for glucose or other macronutrients, yeast cells exit the mitotic cell cycle and acquire characteristics specific to quiescent cells to ensure longevity. We screened a subset of the yeast deletion library representing genes encoding ‘signaling’ proteins and found that Rim15, Mck1 and Yak1 kinases, the SNF1/AMPK complex, the cell wall integrity pathway and cell cycle regulators are necessary for proper quiescence establishment and CLS extension. The CLS of these signaling mutants correlates well with the amount of storage carbohydrates but poorly with transition-phase cell cycle status. The combined removal of glycogen and trehalose biosynthetic genes severely reduces CLS, while overexpression of these genes or supplementation of trehalose to the growth medium rescues the defects of quiescence exit exhibited by the signaling mutants.
Influenza A virus hemagglutinin glycosylation has been found to compensate for fitness costs resulting from escape from anti-hemagglutinin ( HA ) neutralizing antibodies. Using the primerID method of error-correcting viral population sequencing, we reveal that the addition of N-linked glycans to the HA globular domain can modulate receptor binding avidity and increase the fitness of antigenic escape variants in the absence of antibody selective pressure. This finding expands our understanding of the viral mechanisms that maintain fitness during antigenic evolution and sheds light on the unique mutational plasticity of influenza HA. Our results indicate that glycosylation can play an important role in compensating for the fitness costs imposed by escape substitutions elsewhere on HA, thus increasing the viability and emergence potential of antibody-escape variants. Furthermore, we show that glycosylation can also play the opposite role during antigenic drift, increasing the fitness of antigenic escape variants by restoring optimal HA receptor interactions. This raises the possibility that both mechanisms contribute to the steady evolutionary accretion of N-linked glycans within the globular domain observed during human circulation of H1 and H3 viruses. Our findings highlight the power of virus population sequencing for uncovering novel mechanisms of viral adaptation through high-definition forward genetics screening.
Reverse rate dependence is a problematic property of antiarrhythmic drugs that prolong the cardiac action potential ( AP ). This property results in reduced arrhythmia suppression at fast heart rates and increased arrhythmia risk at slow heart rates. We have addressed the possibility of forward rate dependence by performing a comprehensive analysis of 13 ventricular myocyte models. By simulating populations of myocytes with varying properties and analyzing population results statistically, we simultaneously predicted the rate-dependent effects of changes in multiple model parameters. An average of 40 parameters were tested in each model, and effects on AP duration were assessed at slow ( 0. 2 Hz ) and fast ( 2 Hz ) rates. The analysis identified a variety of forward rate dependent ( FRD ) ionic current perturbations and generated specific predictions regarding their mechanisms.
