For instance, an increase in L-type calcium current is FRD when this is accompanied by indirect, rate-dependent changes in slow delayed rectifier potassium current. A comparison of predictions across models identified inward rectifier potassium current and the sodium-potassium pump as the two targets most likely to produce FRD AP prolongation. Finally, a statistical analysis of results from the 13 models demonstrated that models displaying minimal rate-dependent changes in AP shape have little capacity for FRD perturbations, whereas models with large shape changes have considerable FRD potential.
Phenome-Wide Association Studies ( PheWAS ) are used to investigate whether genetic polymorphisms associated with a phenotype are also associated with other diagnoses. In this study, we have developed new methods to perform a PheWAS based on ICD-10 codes and biological test results, and to use a quantitative trait as the selection criterion. We tested our approach on thiopurine S-methyltransferase ( TPMT ) activity in patients treated by thiopurine drugs. We developed two aggregation methods for the ICD-10 codes: an ICD-10 hierarchy and a mapping to existing ICD-9-CM based PheWAS codes. We also analyzed eleven biological test results using discretization algorithms. We applied these methods in patients having a TPMT activity assessment from the clinical data warehouse of a French academic hospital between January 2000 and July 2013. A total of 442 patient records were analyzed representing 10, 252 ICD-10 codes and 72, 711 biological test results. The results from the ICD-9-CM based PheWAS codes and ICD-10 hierarchy codes were concordant. Cross-validation with the biological test results allowed us to validate the ICD phenotypes. Iron-deficiency anemia and diabetes mellitus were associated with a very high TPMT activity. We describe here an original method to perform PheWAS on a quantitative trait using both ICD-10 diagnosis codes and biological test results to identify associated phenotypes. In the field of pharmacogenomics, PheWAS allow for the identification of new subgroups of patients who require personalized clinical and therapeutic management.
Spinal cord injury ( SCI ) is a devastating condition for which no treatments are currently available. Stem cells offer some promise in the restoration of neurological function. We conducted a systematic review, meta-analysis, and meta-regression to study the impact of stem cell biology and experimental design on motor and sensory outcomes following stem cell treatments in animal models of SCI. We found that allogeneic stem cell treatment appears to improve both motor ( effect size, 27. 2%, 95% CI, 25. 0%–29. 4%, 312 comparisons in 5, 628 animals ) and sensory ( effect size, 26. 3%, 95% CI, 7. 9%–44. 7%, 23 comparisons in 473 animals ) outcomes. For sensory outcome, most heterogeneity between experiments was accounted for by facets of stem cell biology. Differentiation before implantation and intravenous route of delivery favoured better outcome. However, stem cell implantation did not appear to improve sensory outcome in female animals and appeared to be enhanced by isoflurane anaesthesia. For motor outcome, facets of stem cell biology had little detectable effect. Instead, most heterogeneity could be explained by the experimental modelling and the outcome measure used. The location of injury, method of injury induction, and presence of immunosuppression all had an impact.
Soil-transmitted helminth ( STH ) infections, including Ascaris lumbricoides, hookworm, and Trichuris trichiura, affect more than a billion people worldwide. Preventive chemotherapy, which involves repeated administration of anthelmintic drugs to at-risk populations, is the mainstay of control. However, this strategy does not prevent reinfection. We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis to assess the patterns and dynamics of STH reinfection after drug treatment. We analyzed data from 51 studies and found that at 3, 6, and 12 months posttreatment, the prevalence of A. lumbricoides reinfection reached 26%, 68%, and 94% of pretreatment levels, respectively. For T. trichiura, the respective reinfection prevalence were 36%, 67%, and 82%, and for hookworm, 30%, 55%, and 57%. We also found that the prevalence and intensity of reinfection were positively correlated with pretreatment infection status. Our results suggest that STH reinfections occur rapidly after treatment, particularly for A. lumbricoides and T. trichiura. Therefore, there is a need for frequent anthelmintic drug administrations to maximize the benefit of preventive chemotherapy.
Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease ( NAFLD ) is a spectrum of metabolic syndromes ranging from simple steatosis to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. To understand the deregulation of metabolic processes that give rise to these phenotypes, we propose a method called Minimum Network Enrichment Analysis ( MiNEA ). MiNEA is applied to genome-scale metabolic networks ( GEMs ) to generate all possible alternative minimal networks ( MiNs ) that can synthesize a target metabolite. We applied MiNEA to investigate deregulated MiNs and identify key regulators in different NAFLD phenotypes, such as fatty liver and liver inflammation, in both humans and mice by integrating condition-specific transcriptomics data from liver samples. We identified key deregulations in the synthesis of cholesteryl esters, cholesterol, and hexadecanoate in both humans and mice, and found that key regulators of the hydrogen peroxide synthesis network were regulated differently in humans and mice. We further identified which MiNs demonstrate the general and specific characteristics of the different NAFLD phenotypes. MiNEA is applicable to any GEM and to any desired target metabolite, making it flexible enough to study condition-specific metabolism for any given disease or organism.
The olfactory system faces the challenge of identifying an enormous variety of odors independent of their intensity. We show that primacy coding, where the odor identity is encoded by the receptor types that respond earliest, provides a compact and informative representation that can be interpreted efficiently by the brain. We analyze the information transmitted by a simple model of primacy coding using numerical simulations and statistical descriptions. We show that the encoded information depends strongly on the number of receptor types included in the primacy representation, but only weakly on the size of the receptor repertoire. The representation is independent of the odor intensity and the transmitted information is useful to perform typical olfactory tasks with close to experimentally measured performance. Interestingly, we find situations in which a smaller receptor repertoire is advantageous for discriminating odors. We show that primacy coding provides a robust and compact representation of the odor identity over a wide range of odors, independent of the odor intensity, and that it outperforms other simple coding schemes. Our results suggest that the primacy code formed in the olfactory bulb is more useful to identify odors in the subsequent olfactory cortex than simple alternatives.
HIV broadly neutralizing monoclonal antibodies ( bnMAbs ) have been shown to occasionally display non-sigmoidal neutralization curves that plateau at less than 100% neutralization. In this study, we investigated the extent of non-sigmoidal slopes and plateaus at less than 100% for HIV bnMAbs targeting the four best-studied regions of the Env spike involved in broad neutralization. Using a panel of 278 pseudoviruses in a CD4 T-cell assay and a panel of 117 viruses in the TZM-bl assay, we found that bnMAbs targeting the V2 apex of Env and gp41 were most likely to show neutralization curves that plateaued at less than 100%. Conversely, bnMAbs targeting the high-mannose patch epitopes were less likely to show such behavior. We also found that two CD4 binding site ( CD4bs ) Abs showed this behavior relatively infrequently. The phenomenon of incomplete neutralization was also observed in a large peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) -grown molecular virus clone panel derived from patient viral swarms. In addition, five bnMAbs were compared against an 18-virus panel of molecular clones produced in 293T cells and PBMCs and assayed in TZM-bl cells, and examples of plateaus at less than 90% were seen with both types of virus production.
Cancer cells exhibit several metabolic traits, including aerobic production of lactate from glucose ( Warburg effect ), extensive glutamine utilization, and impaired mitochondrial electron flow. To understand how these metabolic rearrangements contribute to cancer cell proliferation, we performed systematic constraint-based simulations of a model of human central metabolism. We sampled the feasible flux space to obtain a large number of randomly mutated cells simulated at different glutamine and glucose uptake rates. We observed that, in the limited subset of proliferating cells, most displayed fermentation of glucose to lactate in the presence of oxygen. At high utilization rates of glutamine, oxidative utilization of glucose was decreased, while the production of lactate from glutamine was enhanced. This emergent phenotype was observed only when the available carbon exceeded the amount that could be fully oxidized by the available oxygen. Under these conditions, Flux Balance Analysis indicated that this metabolic pattern is optimal to maximize biomass and ATP production. It requires the activity of a branched TCA cycle, in which glutamine-dependent reductive carboxylation cooperates to the production of lipids and proteins, and is sustained by a variety of redox-controlled metabolic reactions.
Cellular prion protein ( PrPC ) and its mammalian paralogs, Doppel ( Prnd ) and Shadoo ( Sprn ), were investigated in a cell culture model permissive to prion replication. A quantitative investigation of the PrPC interactome was conducted in neuroblastoma cells and extended to Prnd and Sprn to facilitate recognition of relevant interactors. The study established a similar physiological environment for the three prion protein family members in neuroblastoma cells and suggested direct interactions amongst them. Multiple interactions between PrPC and the neural cell adhesion molecule, the laminin receptor precursor, Na/K ATPases and protein disulfide isomerases ( PDI ) were confirmed. Subsequent validation experiments established that interactions of PrPC with PDIs may extend beyond the endoplasmic reticulum and may play a hitherto unrecognized role in the accumulation of PrPSc. A simple hypothesis was presented which accounts for the majority of interactions observed in uninfected cells and suggests that PrPC organizes its molecular environment on account of its ability to bind to adhesion molecules harboring immunoglobulin-like domains, which in turn recognize oligomannose-bearing membrane proteins. The study suggests that members of the mammalian prion protein family may be embedded in specialized membrane domains characterized by an extended molecular network which supports functions in adhesion control, lactate metabolism and cell fusion events.
Respiratory virus infections, such as influenza, typically induce a robust type I immune response. However, the production of type 2 cytokines, such as interleukin ( IL ) -5, has been observed. IL-5 is a prototypical type 2 cytokine that is essential for eosinophil maturation and egress out of the bone marrow. Using a mouse model of influenza virus infection, we found a robust transient release of IL-5 into infected airways along with a significant and progressive accumulation of eosinophils into the lungs, particularly during the recovery phase of infection. The cellular source of the IL-5 was group 2 innate lymphoid cells ( ILC2 ) infiltrating the infected lungs. Interestingly, the progressive accumulation of eosinophils following virus clearance is reflected in the rapid expansion of c-kit+ IL-5 producing ILC2. We further demonstrate that the enhanced capacity for IL-5 production by ILC2 during recovery is concomitant with the enhanced expression of the IL-33 receptor subunit, ST2, by ILC2. Lastly, we show that NKT cells, as well as alveolar macrophages ( AM ), are endogenous sources of IL-33 that enhance IL-5 production from ILC2. Collectively, these results reveal that c-kit+ ILC2 interaction with IL-33 producing NKT and AM leads to abundant production of IL-5 by ILC2 and accounts for the accumulation of eosinophils observed during the recovery phase of influenza infection.
Invasive non-typhoidal Salmonella (iNTS) infections are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in children and HIV-infected adults in sub-Saharan Africa. However, the epidemiology and clinical manifestations of iNTS disease in Asia are not well documented. This study retrospectively identified 102 cases of iNTS infections in an infectious disease hospital in southern Vietnam between 2008 and 2013. The majority of patients ( 71% ) were HIV-infected, >90% were adults, 71% were male, and 33% reported intravenous drug use. The most commonly identified serovars were S. Enteritidis ( ST11 ) and S. Typhimurium ( STs 19, 34 and 1544 ), which were responsible for 43% and 30% of all cases, respectively. S. Typhimurium was identified more frequently in HIV-infected patients ( p = 0. 003 ). HIV infection was significantly associated with death ( p = 0. 039 ), with a mortality rate of 28%. Isolates from HIV-infected patients were more likely to exhibit reduced susceptibility against trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole than HIV-negative patients ( p = 0. 037 ). We conclude that iNTS disease is a severe infection in Vietnam with a high mortality rate.
Bacteriophages are viruses that infect bacteria and play a crucial role in the survival and pathogenicity of their hosts, as well as in nutrient redistribution via cell lysis and lysogenic conversion factors. However, over 70% of phage open reading frames ( ORFs ) are dissimilar to any genes with annotated functions in GenBank, making their identification challenging. To address this issue, we have developed a computational method to predict phage structural protein sequences using Artificial Neural Networks ( ANNs ). We first trained ANNs to classify viral structural proteins using amino acid frequency, which correctly classified a large fraction of test cases with a high degree of specificity and sensitivity. We then added estimates of protein isoelectric points as a feature to ANNs that classify specialized families of proteins, namely major capsid and tail proteins. These more specialized ANNs were more accurate than the structural ANNs. We experimentally validated the ANN predictions by examining several ORFs with no significant similarities to known sequences that were predicted to be structural proteins by transmission electron microscopy. Some of these ORFs self-assembled into structures strongly resembling virion structures. Our ANNs are new tools for identifying phage and potential prophage structural proteins that are difficult or impossible to detect by other bioinformatic analysis.
Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus ( KSHV ) is one of the few oncogenic human viruses known to date. KSHV ORF20 is a member of the herpesviral core UL24 family, but the function of ORF20 and its role in the viral life cycle is not well understood. Here, we show that ORF20 interacts with the interferon-stimulated gene product ( ISG ) oligoadenylate synthetase-like protein ( OASL ). This interaction is conserved among all ORF20 isoforms and multiple ORF20 homologs of the UL24 family in other herpesviruses. Characterization of OASL interacting partners by quantitative affinity purification coupled to mass spectrometry ( q-AP-MS ) identified a very similar interactome to that of ORF20. Both ORF20 and OASL copurified with 40S and 60S ribosomal subunits, and when they were co-expressed, they associated with polysomes. Although ORF20 did not have a global effect on translation, ORF20 enhanced RIG-I induced expression of endogenous OASL in an IRF3-dependent but IFNAR-independent manner. OASL has been characterized as an ISG with antiviral activity against some viruses, but its role for gammaherpesviruses was unknown. We show that OASL and ORF20 mRNA expression were induced early after reactivation of latently infected HuARLT-rKSHV. 219 cells. Intriguingly, we found that OASL enhanced infection of KSHV. During infection with a KSHV ORF20stop mutant, however, OASL-dependent enhancement of infectivity was lost. Our data have characterized the interaction of ORF20 with OASL and suggest ORF20 usurps the function of OASL to benefit KSHV infection.
Lassa virus disease ( LVD ) is an important cause of fever, including undifferentiated fever, in children in endemic areas of Nigeria. However, it is not significantly associated with convulsions in febrile children. This study aimed to determine the prevalence and presentation of LVD in febrile children with and without convulsions in an endemic area of Nigeria. We conducted a prospective study of consecutive febrile children aged ≥1 month–15 years admitted to the Children’s Emergency Room of Irrua Specialist Teaching Hospital over a period of 1 year. The overall prevalence of LVD was 13/373 ( 3. 5% ) in febrile admissions, 3/108 ( 2. 8% ) in children with convulsions, and 10/265 ( 3. 8% ) in children without convulsions. Only vomiting and bleeding were significantly associated with an increased prevalence of LVD. The prevalence of LVD and its lack of clinical differentiation on presentation underscore the importance of a high index of suspicion in diagnosis. Screening of febrile children with undifferentiated fever in endemic areas for LVD could be an important medical and public health control measure.
Arabidopsis thaliana, a model organism for plant biology, has been used to identify new factors that regulate drought resistance. We found that mutations in the KARRIKIN INSENSITIVE2 ( KAI2 ) gene, which encodes the proposed karrikin receptor, result in hypersensitivity to water deprivation. This suggests that KAI2 plays a positive role in regulating drought resistance in Arabidopsis. We performed transcriptomic, physiological, and biochemical analyses of kai2 mutants to understand the basis for KAI2-regulated drought resistance. We found that kai2 mutants have increased rates of water loss, drought-induced cell membrane damage, enlarged stomatal apertures, and higher cuticular permeability. In addition, kai2 plants have reduced anthocyanin biosynthesis during drought and are hyposensitive to abscisic acid ( ABA ) in stomatal closure and cotyledon opening assays. We identified genes that are likely associated with the observed physiological and biochemical changes through a genome-wide transcriptome analysis of kai2 under both well-watered and dehydration conditions. These data provide evidence for crosstalk between ABA- and KAI2-dependent signaling pathways in regulating plant responses to drought. Our findings suggest that chemical or genetic manipulation of KAI2 signaling may provide novel ways to improve drought resistance.
Schistosoma japonicum, the causative agent of zoonotic schistosomiasis japonica in China and the Philippines, exploits host insulin for growth and development. To further investigate the importance of insulin signaling in schistosomes, we have focused on the insulin receptors ( SjIRs ) of S. japonicum. We have shown that human insulin can bind the L1 subdomains of recombinant SjIR1 and SjIR2, and that RNA interference ( RNAi ) knockdown of the SjIRs in adult S. japonicum in vitro results in reduced transcription of the SjIRs and other important downstream genes within the insulin pathway. These genes are associated with glucose metabolism and schistosome fecundity. In addition, we observed a significant decrease in glucose uptake in SjIR-knockdown worms compared with luciferase controls. In vaccine/challenge experiments, we found that recombinant SjLD1 and SjLD2 depressed female growth, intestinal granuloma density, and faecal egg production in S. japonicum in mice presented with a low dose challenge infection. These data re-emphasize the potential of the SjIRs as veterinary transmission blocking vaccine candidates against zoonotic schistosomiasis japonica.
Lymphatic filariasis ( LF ) is a leading cause of disability in the South Pacific, where >96% of the 1. 7 million population are at risk of LF infection. Current mass drug administration ( MDA ) efforts have effectively reduced LF prevalence, but the goal of LF elimination cannot be attained via MDA alone in some regions. The primary vector of LF in the South Pacific is Aedes polynesiensis, which is difficult to control using existing methods. Here, we demonstrate that interspecific hybridization and introgression results in an A. polynesiensis strain ( ‘CP’ strain ) that is stably infected with the endosymbiotic Wolbachia bacteria from Aedes riversi. The CP strain is bi-directionally incompatible with naturally infected mosquitoes, resulting in female sterility. Laboratory assays demonstrate that CP males are equally competitive, resulting in population elimination when CP males are introduced into wild type A. polynesiensis populations. These findings support the feasibility of a vector elimination strategy as a supplement to ongoing MDA efforts. The strategy involves inundative releases of bi-directionally incompatible males that induce sterility in A. polynesiensis females, resulting in vector population elimination.
Human African trypanosomiasis (HAT), also known as Rhodesiense sleeping sickness, is a vector-borne disease that is always fatal if left untreated. In Tanzania, HAT is highly focalized and of major socio-economic and public health importance in affected communities. This study aimed to estimate the public health burden of rhodesiense HAT in terms of Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) and financial costs in a highly disease-endemic area of Tanzania. The study used hospital records from 143 patients admitted in 2004 for treatment for HAT at Kaliua Health Centre, Urambo District. The direct medical and other indirect costs incurred by individual patients and by the health services were calculated, and DALYs were estimated using methods recommended by the Global Burden of Disease Project. The estimated DALYs for HAT in Urambo District were 215. 7 ( 95% CI: 155. 3–287. 5 ) and 281. 6 ( 95% CI: 209. 1–362. 6 ) without and with age-weighting, respectively. When 45% under-reporting was included, the results were 622. 5 ( 95% CI: 155. 3–1098. 9 ) and 978. 9 ( 95% CI: 201. 1–1870. 8 ), respectively. The costs of treating 143 patients were estimated at US$ 15, 514, of which patients themselves paid US$ 3, 673 and the health services US$ 11, 841. The burden in terms of indirect non-medical costs for the 143 patients was estimated at US$ 9, 781.
NGLY1 is a cytoplasmic de-N-glycosylating enzyme that is highly conserved among eukaryotes. Mice with a knockout of the Ngly1 gene ( Ngly1−/− ) are embryonic lethal in a C57BL/6 background. However, the lethality of Ngly1−/− mice is partially rescued by the additional deletion of the Engase gene, which encodes another cytoplasmic de-N-glycosylating enzyme that leaves a single GlcNAc at glycosylated Asn residues. The lethality of Ngly1−/− mice is also partially rescued by changing the genetic background from C57BL/6 to a C57BL/6 and ICR mixed background. Despite the rescue of lethality, Ngly1−/−;Engase−/− mice and Ngly1−/− mice in the C57BL/6 and ICR mixed background exhibit recognizable phenotypes that are reminiscent of the symptoms observed in human subjects with NGLY1-deficiency. These phenotypes are strongly suppressed by the additional deletion of Engase in both Ngly1−/−;Engase−/− mice and Ngly1−/− mice in the C57BL/6 and ICR mixed background. These observations suggest that Ngly1−/− mice and Ngly1−/−;Engase−/− mice could serve as valuable animal models for studying the pathogenesis of NGLY1-deficiency.
In Drosophila segmentation, the hunchback ( hb ) gene is activated by the Bicoid ( Bcd ) protein gradient. However, gene regulation is subject to intrinsic noise, which must be constrained to produce reproducible and coordinated developmental events. We investigated how noise is controlled during hb gene expression by characterizing the dependence of hb mRNA and protein output noise on hb promoter structure and transcriptional dynamics. We used a stochastic model of the hb promoter in which the number and strength of Bcd and Hb binding sites can be varied. The model was fit to data from wild-type embryos, the self-regulation mutant hb14F, and lacZ reporter constructs using different portions of the hb promoter. The results indicate that wild-type Hb output noise is predominantly dependent on the transcription and translation dynamics of its own expression, rather than on Bcd fluctuations. In contrast, the constructs and mutant lacking self-regulation indicate that the multiple Bcd binding sites in the hb promoter play a role in buffering noise. The model is robust to the variation in Bcd binding site number across a number of fly species.
Introgression of Neanderthal alleles into modern human populations has resulted in a low level of Neanderthal ancestry scattered across the genomes of many modern-day humans. After hybridization, on average, selection appears to have removed Neanderthal alleles from the human population. Here, we develop a novel method for estimating the genome-wide average strength of selection and the density of selected sites using estimates of Neanderthal allele frequency along the genomes of modern-day humans. We confirm that East Asians had somewhat higher initial levels of Neanderthal ancestry than Europeans even after accounting for selection. We find that the bulk of purifying selection against Neanderthal ancestry is best understood as acting on many weakly deleterious alleles. We propose that the majority of these alleles were effectively neutral—and segregating at high frequency—in Neanderthals, but became selected against after entering human populations of much larger effective size. This work suggests that differences in effective population size may play a far more important role in shaping levels of introgression than previously thought.
The HIV-1 promoter within the viral long terminal repeat ( LTR ) plays a central role in the regulation of viral gene expression, replication, and the establishment of a latent state. After viral integration into the host genome, stochastic fluctuations in viral gene expression, amplified by the Tat positive feedback loop, can contribute to the formation of either a productive, transactivated state or an inactive state. In a significant fraction of cells harboring an integrated copy of the HIV-1 model provirus, this bimodal gene expression profile is dynamic, as cells spontaneously and continuously flip between active ( Bright ) and inactive ( Off ) expression modes. The HIV-1 promoter contains cis-acting Sp1 and NF-κB elements that regulate gene expression via the recruitment of both activating and repressing complexes. We show that interplay in the recruitment of such positive and negative factors modulates the stability of the Bright and Off modes and thereby alters the sensitivity of viral gene expression to stochastic fluctuations in the Tat feedback loop. Using model lentivirus variants with mutations introduced in the Sp1 and NF-κB elements, we reveal significant functional differences in contributions of each site to viral gene regulation. The Sp1 sites apparently stabilize both the Bright and the Off states, such that their mutation promotes noisy gene expression and reduction in the regulation of histone acetylation and deacetylation. The NF-κB sites exhibit distinct properties, with κB site I serving a stronger activating role than κB site II. Finally, analysis of 362 clonal cell populations infected with the viral variants revealed that mutations in any of the Sp1 sites yield a 6-fold higher frequency of clonal bifurcation compared to that of the wild-type promoter.
Orthologs are genes in different species that evolved from a common ancestral gene. Accurate identification of orthologs is a central problem in comparative genomics, and several orthology identification projects have been developed in recent years. However, only a few reports have compared the accuracy of these projects, and several recent efforts have not been systematically evaluated. We compared the results of nine leading orthology projects and methods ( COG, KOG, Inparanoid, OrthoMCL, Ensembl Compara, Homologene, RoundUp, EggNOG, and OMA ) and two standard methods ( bidirectional best-hit and reciprocal smallest distance ) with respect to both phylogeny and function. We found that OMA and Homologene perform best in phylogenetic analysis and functional analysis where high specificity is required. At lower functional specificity but higher coverage, OrthoMCL outperforms Ensembl Compara, and to a lesser extent Inparanoid. EggNOG provides the largest coverage for coarse-grained functional categories, but is not specific enough for phylogenetic or detailed function analyses. We also found that standard bidirectional best-hit often outperforms projects with more complex algorithms. Our study provides guidance for the broad community of orthology data users as to which database best suits their needs, introduces new methodology to verify orthology, and sets performance standards for current and future approaches.
Schistosomiasis, a parasitic infection of the tropics and sub-tropics, is an important neglected tropical disease for which a single 40-year old drug, praziquantel, is the only available treatment. However, its use in mass drug administration is leading to signs of drug-resistance emerging. To address this challenge, we developed a computational drug repurposing pipeline supported by phenotypic screening to identify new schistosomicidal agents. This approach highlighted several protein kinases as interesting new biological targets for schistosomiasis, as they play an essential role in the parasite’s biological processes. We also elucidated the kinome of Schistosoma japonicum, as well as updated the kinomes of S. mansoni and S. haematobium. By comparing these kinomes with the human kinome, we identified potential targets of existing inhibitors that are unique to Schistosoma species, allowing us to identify novel targets and suggest approved drugs that might inhibit them. These include previously suggested schistosomicidal agents such as bosutinib, dasatinib, and imatinib, as well as new inhibitors such as vandetanib, saracatinib, tideglusib, alvocidib, dinaciclib, and 22 newly identified targets such as CHK1, CDC2, WEE, PAKA, and MEK1.
Transcription factors are central components of the intracellular regulatory networks that control gene expression. Here, we study the folding and binding of the pKID domain of the transcription factor CREB to the KIX domain of the co-activator CBP. Our simulations of a topology-based Gō-type model predict a coupled folding and binding mechanism, and the existence of partially bound intermediates. We find that the binding transition state resembles the unstructured state in solution, implying that CREB becomes structured only after committing to binding. This contrasts with models in which binding occurs to pre-structured conformations that exist in the unbound state at equilibrium. Interestingly, increasing the amount of structure in the unbound pKID reduces the rate of binding, suggesting a “fly-casting”-like process. We also find that the inclusion of attractive non-native interactions results in the formation of non-specific encounter complexes that enhance the on-rate of binding, but do not significantly change the binding mechanism. Our study helps explain how being unstructured can confer an advantage in protein target recognition.
Schistosomiasis is a major public health problem in Latin America and the Caribbean ( LAC ). In 2012, the World Health Assembly adopted a resolution calling for increased investment in schistosomiasis control and support for countries to initiate elimination programs. This systematic review aimed to analyze the prevalence and intensity of Schistosoma mansoni infection in children in LAC countries and territories. A total of 132 articles published between 1942 and 2014 were included in the review, providing 1, 242 prevalence and 199 intensity of infection data points. The majority of the studies were conducted in Brazil ( 69. 7% ), where several ‘hot spots’ with high prevalence were identified. Countries such as Brazil, Venezuela, Suriname, and Saint Lucia need to update their epidemiological status of schistosomiasis to re-design their national programs and target the elimination of Schistosoma mansoni transmission by 2020. In contrast, countries such as Antigua and Barbuda, Dominican Republic, Guadeloupe, Martinique, Montserrat, and Puerto Rico may have interrupted schistosomiasis transmission, but require follow-up surveys to verify this status.
Heterosexual transmission of HIV-1 is characterized by a genetic bottleneck that selects a single viral variant, the transmitted/founder ( TF ), during most transmission events. To assess viral characteristics influencing HIV-1 transmission, we sequenced 167 near full-length viral genomes and generated 40 infectious molecular clones ( IMC ) including TF variants and multiple non-transmitted ( NT ) HIV-1 subtype C variants from six linked heterosexual transmission pairs near the time of transmission. We found that consensus-like genomes sensitive to donor antibodies were selected for during transmission in these six transmission pairs. However, TF variants did not demonstrate increased viral fitness in terms of particle infectivity or viral replicative capacity in activated peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) and monocyte-derived dendritic cells ( MDDC ). In addition, resistance of the TF variant to the antiviral effects of interferon-α ( IFN-α ) was not significantly different from that of non-transmitted variants from the same transmission pair. Thus, neither in vitro viral replicative capacity nor IFN-α resistance discriminated the transmission potential of viruses in the quasispecies of these chronically infected individuals.
Lymphatic filariasis is a disease caused by filarial parasites that can lead to lymphedema and elephantiasis in humans. Even in the absence of an adaptive immune system, lymphatic dilatation and dysfunction can occur in filarial infections. However, severe irreversible lymphedema and elephantiasis appear to require an intact adaptive immune response. To understand how filarial parasites directly influence the lymphatic system, human lymphatic endothelial cells ( LEC ) were exposed to filarial antigens, live parasites, or serum from infected patients. We found that live filarial parasites or filarial antigens induced significant proliferation and differentiation of LEC into tube-like structures in vitro. Moreover, serum from patients with patent filarial infections and those with chronic lymphatic obstruction induced significantly increased LEC proliferation compared to serum from uninfected individuals. The differentiation of LEC into tube-like networks was associated with increased levels of matrix metalloproteases and inhibition of their tissue inhibitors. We also found that filarial parasites altered the expression of genes involved in cellular organization and development, as well as those associated with junction adherence pathways, which in turn decreased trans-endothelial transport. These findings suggest that filarial parasites directly induce lymphangiogenesis and lymphatic differentiation and provide insight into the mechanisms underlying the pathology seen in lymphatic filariasis.
Single-cell genome amplification is a powerful tool for the study of microbial ecology and evolution, as the majority of microorganisms cannot be obtained in pure culture. Multiple Displacement Amplification ( MDA ) is a method that enables genome amplification from single cells isolated by FACS flow cytometry, serial dilution, or micromanipulation methods. In this study, we used a microfluidic device to isolate individual Escherichia coli cells and amplify genomic DNA by MDA in 60-nl reactions. Our results show that reducing the MDA reaction volume from microliters to nanoliters lowers nonspecific synthesis resulting from contaminant DNA templates and unfavourable interaction between primers. The quality of the genome amplification was assessed by qPCR and compared favourably to single-cell amplifications performed in standard 50-μl volumes. Amplification bias was greatly reduced in nanoliter volumes, thereby providing a more even representation of all sequences. Single-cell amplicons from both microliter and nanoliter volumes provided high-quality sequence data by high-throughput pyrosequencing, thereby demonstrating a straightforward route to sequencing genomes from single cells.
Hantavirus host assemblages and human disease in the Atlantic Forest are influenced by landscape structure and local small mammal diversity. We analyzed 283 rodent capture records from the Atlantic Forest and found that hantavirus host proportions were more positively influenced by landscape diversity than by a particular habitat or agricultural matrix type. Local small mammal diversity also positively influenced known pathogenic hantavirus host proportions, indicating that a plasticity to habitat quality may be more important for these hosts than competition with native forest dwelling species. We found a consistent positive effect of sugarcane and tree plantation on the proportion of rodent hosts, whereas defaunation intensity did not correlate with the proportion of hosts of potentially pathogenic hantavirus genotypes in the community. The spatial match between host hotspots and human disease vulnerability was 17%, while coldspots matched 20%. Overall, we discovered strong spatial and land use change influences on hantavirus hosts at the landscape level across the Atlantic Forest. Our findings suggest that disease surveillance must be reinforced in the southern and southeastern regions of the biome where the highest predicted hantavirus host proportion and levels of vulnerability spatially match. Importantly, our analyses suggest there may be more complex rodent community dynamics and interactions with human disease than currently hypothesized.
Infection with flaviviruses, such as Japanese encephalitis virus, Dengue virus, and Zika virus, requires the pro-survival BCL2 protein BCLXL for the survival of infected cells. BCL2 family proteins play a crucial role in maintaining cell homeostasis by controlling mitochondria-mediated apoptosis. Upon infection with flaviviruses, the expression of MCL1, another pro-survival BCL2 protein, is suppressed, leading to the activation of BAX/BAK-dependent apoptosis. However, the continued expression of BCLXL delays apoptosis in infected cells, allowing the virus to disseminate to neighbouring cells and leading to high pathogenicity. Treatment with BCLXL inhibitors, as well as deficiency of the BCLXL gene, induces BAX/BAK-dependent apoptosis in flavivirus-infected cells. Furthermore, inhibition of BCLXL increases phagocytosis of virus-infected cells by macrophages, thereby suppressing viral dissemination and chemokine production. In vivo, haploinsufficiency of the BCLXL gene, as well as administration of BH3 mimetic compounds, increases the survival rate after challenge with Japanese encephalitis virus infection and suppresses inflammation. These results suggest that BCLXL plays a crucial role in the survival of cells infected with flaviviruses, and that BCLXL may provide a novel antiviral target to suppress the propagation of flaviviruses.
Canine rabies is a significant public health problem in Viet Nam. The economic burden of canine rabies in Viet Nam over a ten year period ( 2005–2014 ) was estimated to be over $719 million USD. The largest portion of this burden ( 92% ) was comprised of costs associated with post-exposure prophylaxis ( PEP ), while dog vaccination efforts accounted for only 6% of the costs. Canine rabies resulted in between 36, 560 and 45, 700 disability adjusted life years ( DALYs ), measured in years of life lost ( YLL ), and a total of 914 human deaths were reported over the study period. The cost per dog vaccinated was estimated to be $1. 75 USD. Our results indicate that canine rabies impacts in Viet Nam are consistent with the burden elsewhere reported in Asia, with large expenditures on PEP and very small investments in dog vaccination.
The Type II Secretion System ( T2SS ) is a molecular machine that drives the secretion of fully-folded protein substrates across the bacterial outer membrane. A key element in the machinery is the secretin: an integral, multimeric outer membrane protein that forms the secretion pore. We show that three distinct forms of T2SSs can be distinguished based on the sequence characteristics of their secretin pores. Two of these forms, the Klebsiella-type and Vibrio-type, are further distinguished by the pilotin that mediates their transport and assembly into the outer membrane. We have determined the crystal structure of the novel pilotin AspS from Vibrio cholerae, which is functionally equivalent and yet structurally unrelated to the pilotins found in Klebsiella and other bacteria. AspS binds to a specific targeting sequence in the Vibrio-type secretins, enhances the kinetics of secretin assembly, and homologs of AspS are found in all species of Vibrio as well as those few strains of Escherichia and Shigella that have acquired a Vibrio-type T2SS.
Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by pathogenic Leptospira spp. that can be transmitted to a susceptible host through skin abrasions or mucous membranes. The ability of leptospires to adhere to cell surface and extracellular matrix components is a crucial step for dissemination and colonization of host tissues. In this study, we investigated the functional roles of transmembrane outer membrane proteins OmpL36, OmpL37, and OmpL47, which we recently identified on the leptospiral surface. We determined the capacity of these proteins to bind to host tissue components by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. We found that OmpL37 binds elastin preferentially, exhibiting dose-dependent, saturating binding to human skin and aortic elastin. OmpL37 also binds fibrinogen, fibrinogen fragment D, plasma fibronectin, and murine laminin. The binding to human skin elastin by both recombinant OmpL37 and live Leptospira interrogans is specifically enhanced by rabbit antiserum for OmpL37, suggesting the involvement of OmpL37 in leptospiral binding to elastin. We also demonstrate that OmpL37 is recognized by acute and convalescent leptospirosis patient sera and by Leptospira-infected hamster sera. Finally, we found that OmpL37 protein is detected in pathogenic Leptospira serovars and not in saprophytic Leptospira. Thus, OmpL37 is a novel elastin-binding protein of pathogenic Leptospira that may be promoting attachment of Leptospira to host tissues.
Broadly neutralizing antibodies 4E10 and 2F5, isolated from HIV-1 infected individuals, recognize epitopes in the membrane proximal external region ( MPER ) of gp41 that are transiently exposed during viral entry. These antibodies are polyreactive, binding to the viral membrane and their epitopes in the MPER. We present a model to calculate the probability that during the pre-hairpin intermediate, the transient period when the epitopes are first exposed, a bound antibody will disable a trivalent gp41 before fusion is complete. The model predicts that for these antibodies to be effective at neutralization, the time to disable an epitope must be shorter than the time the antibody remains bound in this conformation, about five minutes or less for 4E10 and 2F5. We investigate the role of avidity in neutralization and show that 2F5 IgG, but not 4E10, is much more effective at neutralization than its Fab fragment. We attribute this to 2F5 interacting more stably than 4E10 with the viral membrane. We use the model to elucidate the parameters that determine the ability of these antibodies to disable epitopes and propose an extension of the model to analyze neutralization data. The extended model predicts the dependencies of neutralization on the rate constants that characterize antibody binding, the rate of fusion of gp41, and the number of gp41 bridging the virus and target cell at the start of the pre-hairpin intermediate.
Onchocerciasis, a disease caused by the parasite Onchocerca volvulus and transmitted by blackflies, is a major public health problem in Africa. A study was conducted in three hyperendemic foci in Mali and Senegal to assess whether annual or six-monthly treatment with ivermectin for 15 to 17 years could interrupt transmission and eliminate the parasite. The study evaluated infection and transmission levels up to 5 years after the last treatment. A total of 29, 753 people were examined and 492, 600 blackflies were analyzed for the presence of Onchocerca volvulus larvae. The results showed a declining trend in infection and transmission levels after the last treatment. In two sites, the prevalence of microfilariae and vector infectivity rate were zero 3 to 4 years after the last treatment. In the third site, where infection levels were high before stopping treatment, there was a consistent decline in infection and transmission to very low levels 3 to 5 years after stopping treatment. All infection and transmission indicators were below postulated thresholds for elimination. The study has established the proof of principle that onchocerciasis elimination with ivermectin treatment is feasible in at least some endemic foci in Africa.
Human rhinovirus, a frequent cause of the common cold, is a non-enveloped virus of the picornavirus family, which also includes other significant pathogens such as poliovirus and foot-and-mouth disease virus. During cell entry, the small myristoylated capsid protein VP4 is released from the virus, interacts with the cell membrane and is implicated in the delivery of the viral RNA genome into the cytoplasm to initiate replication. In this study, we have produced recombinant C-terminal histidine-tagged human rhinovirus VP4 and shown it can induce membrane permeability in liposome model membranes. Dextran size-exclusion studies, chemical crosslinking and electron microscopy demonstrated that VP4 forms a multimeric membrane pore, with a channel size consistent with transfer of the single-stranded RNA genome. The membrane permeability induced by recombinant VP4 was influenced by pH and was comparable to permeability induced by infectious virions. These findings present a molecular mechanism for the involvement of VP4 in cell entry and provide a model system which will facilitate exploration of VP4 as a novel antiviral target for the picornavirus family.
Francisella tularensis ( Ft ) is a highly infectious Gram-negative bacterium and the causative agent of tularemia, a disease designated as a class A select agent by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Francisella novicida ( Fn ), a pathogen of mice, has a similar lipid A structure to human clinical isolates of Ft. We identified three enzymes required for Fn lipid A carbohydrate modifications: flmF1 ( mannose ), flmF2 ( galactosamine ), and flmK ( galactosamine/mannose ). Mutants lacking either galactosamine ( flmF2 ) or galactosamine/mannose ( flmK ) addition to their lipid A were attenuated in mice by both pulmonary and subcutaneous routes of infection. In addition, aerosolization of the mutants ( flmF2 and flmK ) provided protection against challenge with wild-type ( WT ) Fn, whereas subcutaneous administration of only the flmK mutant provided protection from challenge with WT Fn. Infection of an alveolar macrophage cell line by the flmK mutant induced higher levels of tumor necrosis factor-α ( TNF-α ) and macrophage inhibitory protein-2 ( MIP-2 ) compared to infection with WT Fn. Bone marrow–derived macrophages ( BMMø ) from Toll-like receptor 4 ( TLR4 ) and TLR2/4 knockout mice infected with the flmK mutant produced significantly higher amounts of interleukin-6 ( IL-6 ) and MIP-2 than BMMø infected with WT Fn. However, production of IL-6 and MIP-2 was undetectable in BMMø from MyD88−/− mice infected with either strain. We hypothesize that the ability of the flmK mutant to activate pro-inflammatory cytokine/chemokine production and innate immune responses mediated by the MyD88 signaling pathway may be responsible for its attenuation, leading to the induction of protective immunity by this mutant.
E. coli, act as molecular switches to coordinate ribosome assembly. Here we show that Era is not essential in S. aureus but is important for 30S ribosomal subunit assembly. Protein interaction studies reveal that Era interacts with the 16S rRNA endonuclease YbeY and the DEAD-box RNA helicase CshA. We determine that both Era and CshA are required for growth at suboptimal temperatures and rRNA processing. Era and CshA also form direct interactions with the ( p ) ppGpp synthetase RelSau, with RelSau positively impacting the GTPase activity of Era but negatively affecting the helicase activity of CshA. We propose that in its GTP-bound form, Era acts as a hub protein on the ribosome to direct enzymes involved in rRNA processing/degradation and ribosome subunit assembly to their site of action. This activity is impeded by multiple components of the stringent response, contributing to the slowed growth phenotype synonymous with this stress response pathway.
Anthrax lethal toxin ( LT ) is known to induce vascular insufficiency in experimental animals, but the underlying mechanisms are unknown. In this study, we show that mice lacking neuronal nitric oxide synthase ( nNOS ) are strikingly more sensitive to LT than mice lacking the other two NOS enzymes, endothelial NOS ( eNOS ) or inducible NOS ( iNOS ). The increased sensitivity of nNOS−/− mice was independent of macrophage sensitivity to toxin or cytokine responses, and could be replicated in wild-type ( WT ) mice through pharmacological inhibition of nNOS with 7-nitroindazole. Histopathological analyses revealed that LT induced architectural changes in the hearts of nNOS−/− mice, with rapid appearance of novel inter-fiber spaces, but no associated apoptosis of cardiomyocytes. Electron microscopic analyses revealed pathological changes in the hearts of both nNOS−/− and WT mice, including endothelial/capillary necrosis and degeneration, inter-myocyte edema, myofilament and mitochondrial degeneration, and altered sarcoplasmic reticulum cisternae. Multiple biomarkers of cardiac injury were elevated in LT-treated mice, including myoglobin, cardiac troponin-I, and heart fatty acid binding protein. Echocardiography indicated an average reduction in ejection fraction following LT treatment in both nNOS−/− and WT mice, indicative of decreased contractile function in the heart. We report the heart as an early target of LT in mice and discuss a protective role for nNOS against LT-mediated cardiac damage.
Parasitic nematodes cause some of the most common neglected tropical diseases and infect over 1 billion people worldwide. However, our understanding of their biology has been limited by the lack of tools for genetic intervention. Here, we report the development of a method for introducing CRISPR-Cas9-mediated gene disruptions in the human-parasitic threadworm Strongyloides stercoralis. We disrupted the S. stercoralis twitchin gene unc-22, resulting in nematodes with severe motility defects. Ss-unc-22 mutations were resolved by homology-directed repair when a repair template was provided. Omission of a repair template resulted in deletions at the target locus. Ss-unc-22 mutations were heritable; we passed Ss-unc-22 mutants through a host and successfully recovered mutant progeny. Using a similar approach, we also disrupted the unc-22 gene of the rat-parasitic nematode Strongyloides ratti. Our results demonstrate the applicability of CRISPR-Cas9 to parasitic nematodes, and thereby enable future studies of gene function in these medically relevant but previously genetically intractable parasites.
Ribosome drop-off is a well established phenomenon that plays a crucial role in translational accuracy and nutrient starvation responses during protein translation. When cells are under stress conditions, such as amino acid starvation or high level recombinant protein expression, ribosome drop-off can substantially affect the efficiency of protein expression. Here, we introduce a mathematical model that describes the effects of ribosome drop-off on the ribosome density along the mRNA and on the concomitant protein synthesis rate. Our results show that ribosome premature termination may lead to non-intuitive ribosome density profiles, such as a ribosome density that increases from the 5’ to the 3’ end. Importantly, the model predicts that the effects of ribosome drop-off on the translation rate are mRNA-specific, and we quantify their resilience to drop-off, showing that mRNAs which present ribosome queues are much less affected by ribosome drop-off than those which do not. Moreover, among those mRNAs that do not present ribosome queues, resilience to drop-off correlates positively with the elongation rate, so that sequences using fast codons are expected to be less affected by ribosome drop-off. This result is consistent with a genome-wide analysis of S. cerevisiae, which reveals that under favourable growth conditions mRNAs coding for proteins involved in the translation machinery are highly resilient to ribosome drop-off.
Soil-transmitted helminth ( STH ) infections are a major public health problem in many developing countries. The World Health Organization recommends routine deworming of school and pre-school aged children to control morbidity. However, transmission continues to occur due to persistent reservoirs of infection in untreated individuals and the environment. To accelerate the interruption of transmission, alternative strategies of mass drug administration ( MDA ) are being explored. The DeWorm3 trial is currently ongoing to test the feasibility of interrupting STH transmission using MDA. In this study, we investigate whether criteria to determine whether transmission interruption is unlikely can be defined at earlier timepoints. We employed a stochastic, individual-based simulation model to simulate core aspects of the DeWorm3 community-based cluster-randomized trial. We evaluated a range of threshold prevalences measured at six months after the last round of MDA and the impact of MDA coverage levels to see if the likelihood of bounce-back or elimination could reliably be assessed at that point. The analyses suggest that all clusters should be assessed for transmission interruption after two years of surveillance, unless transmission interruption can be effectively ruled out through evidence of low treatment coverage.
Serogroup specificity in Vibrio cholerae is determined by the O-specific polysaccharide ( OSP ) of lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ). Here we report the evaluation of a conjugate vaccine for cholera ( OSP:TThc ) made from V. cholerae O1 Ogawa O-Specific Polysaccharide–core ( OSP ) and recombinant tetanus toxoid heavy chain fragment ( TThc ). We immunized mice intramuscularly on days 0, 21, and 42 with OSP:TThc or OSP only, with or without dmLT, a non-toxigenic immunoadjuvant derived from heat labile toxin of Escherichia coli. We detected significant serum IgG antibody responses targeting OSP following a single immunization in mice receiving OSP:TThc with or without adjuvant. Anti-LPS IgG responses were detected following a second immunization in these cohorts. No anti-OSP or anti-LPS IgG responses were detected at any time in animals receiving un-conjugated OSP with or without immunoadjuvant, and in animals receiving immunoadjuvant alone. Responses were highest following immunization with adjuvant. Serum anti-OSP IgM responses were detected in mice receiving OSP:TThc with or without immunoadjuvant, and in mice receiving unconjugated OSP. Serum anti-LPS IgM and vibriocidal responses were detected in all vaccine cohorts except in mice receiving immunoadjuvant alone. No significant IgA anti-OSP or anti-LPS responses developed in any group. Administration of OSP:TThc and adjuvant also induced memory B cell responses targeting OSP and resulted in 95% protective efficacy in a mouse lethality cholera challenge model.
Candida albicans inhibits the virulence of the bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa by suppressing the expression of pyochelin and pyoverdine genes, which play a critical role in iron acquisition and virulence. In a neutropenic mouse model of microbial gastrointestinal colonization and dissemination, we show that C. albicans secreted proteins directly suppress P. aeruginosa pyoverdine and pyochelin expression and inhibit P. aeruginosa virulence in mice. Interestingly, suppression or deletion of pyochelin and pyoverdine genes has no effect on P. aeruginosa’s ability to colonize the GI tract but does decrease P. aeruginosa’s cytotoxic effect on cultured colonocytes. Oral iron supplementation restores P. aeruginosa virulence in P. aeruginosa and C. albicans colonized mice. Our findings provide insight into how a bacterial-fungal interaction can modulate bacterial virulence in the intestine and validate the use of a mammalian model system to explore the complexities of polymicrobial, polykingdom infections in order to identify new therapeutic targets for preventing microbial disease.
The rate and timing of reversion to wild-type ( WT ) virus from escape mutant ( EM ) virus is highly variable following infection with HIV-1 or Simian Immunodeficiency Virus ( SIV ). EM virus evades CD8+ T cell recognition and is often less replicatively fit compared to WT virus. However, the rate and timing of reversion to WT virus determines the outcome of infection. Infection with mixes of EM and WT virus containing ≥10% WT virus results in rapid outgrowth of WT virus at SIV Gag CD8 T cell epitopes within 7 days of infection in pigtail macaques. In contrast, infection with biologically passaged SHIVmn229 viruses with much smaller proportions of WT sequence or a molecular clone of pure EM SIVmac239 results in a delayed or slow pattern of reversion. WT virus is not detectable until ≥8 days after inoculation and takes ≥8 weeks to become the dominant quasispecies. A delayed pattern of reversion is associated with significantly lower viral loads. The diversity of the infecting inoculum determines the timing of reversion to WT virus, which in turn predicts the outcome of infection. The delay in reversion of fitness-reducing CD8 T cell escape mutations in some scenarios suggests opportunities to reduce the pathogenicity of HIV during very early infection.
Yeast strains collected from Evolution Canyon ( EC ), Israel, exhibit an extremely high tolerance to the heavy metal cadmium. We found that cadmium resistance is primarily caused by an enhanced function of a metal efflux pump, PCA1. Molecular analyses demonstrate that this enhancement can be largely attributed to mutations in the PCA1 promoter sequence, while mutations in the coding region have a minor effect. Reconstruction experiments show that three single nucleotide substitutions in the PCA1 promoter quantitatively increase its activity and thus enhance the cells' cadmium resistance. The critical nucleotides found in EC strains are conserved and functionally important for cadmium resistance in other yeast species, suggesting that they represent an ancestral type. However, these nucleotides had diverged in most Saccharomyces cerevisiae populations, which gave cells growth advantages under conditions where cadmium is low or absent. Our results provide a rare example of a selective sweep in yeast populations driven by a tradeoff in metal resistance.
Gastric cancer, the second leading cause of global cancer mortality, is a molecularly heterogeneous disease characterized by deregulation of multiple oncogenic pathways. We sought to identify major oncogenic pathways in gastric cancer with significant relationships to patient survival. Using gene expression signatures, we devised an in silico strategy to map patterns of oncogenic pathway activation in 301 primary gastric cancers. We identified three oncogenic pathways ( proliferation/stem cell, NF-κB, and Wnt/β-catenin ) deregulated in the majority ( >70% ) of gastric cancers. We functionally validated these pathway predictions in a panel of gastric cancer cell lines. Patient stratification by oncogenic pathway combinations showed reproducible and significant survival differences in multiple cohorts, suggesting that pathway interactions may play an important role in influencing disease behavior. Individual gastric cancers can be successfully taxonomized by oncogenic pathway activity into biologically and clinically relevant subgroups. Predicting pathway activity by expression signatures thus permits the study of multiple cancer-related pathways interacting simultaneously in primary cancers, at a scale not currently achievable by other platforms.
Superhelical Destabilization in Regulatory Regions of Stress Response Genes. We show that strongly destabilized sites in the E. coli K12 genome are statistically significantly overrepresented in the upstream regions of genes encoding transcriptional regulators. These genes include transcriptional activators, repressors, and two-component systems that play important regulatory functions in gene expression. In particular, the upstream regions of genes that directly respond to physiological and environmental stimuli are more destabilized than are those regions of genes that are not involved in these responses. Moreover, if a pathway is controlled by a transcriptional regulator whose gene has a destabilized 5′ flank, then the genes ( operons ) in that pathway also usually contain strongly destabilized SIDD sites in their 5′ flanks. We observe this statistically significant association of SIDD sites with upstream regions of genes functioning in transcription in 38 of 43 genomes of free-living bacteria, but in only four of 18 genomes of endosymbionts or obligate parasitic bacteria. These results suggest that strong SIDD sites 5′ to participating genes may be involved in transcriptional responses to environmental changes, which are known to transiently alter superhelicity. We propose that these SIDD sites are active and necessary participants in superhelically mediated regulatory mechanisms governing changes in the global pattern of gene expression in prokaryotes in response to physiological or environmental changes.
Sexual reproduction in the fungus Podospora anserina is regulated by a network of high-mobility group ( HMG )-box transcription factors. We identified 12 HMG-box genes in P. anserina, of which 11 are involved in the sexual cycle. PaHMG5, an ortholog of SpSte11 from Schizosaccharomyces pombe, is a pivotal activator of mating-type genes in P. anserina. PaHMG9 is a repressor of several phenomena specific to the stationary phase, most notably hyphal anastomoses. PaHMG5 is at the hub of a network of several HMG-box factors that regulate mating-type genes and mating-type target genes. This network also controls fertility genes that are not regulated by mating-type transcription factors. PaHMG5 and SpSte11 are conserved transcriptional regulators of mating-type genes, although P. anserina and S. pombe diverged 550 million years ago. The P. anserina and S. pombe mating-type genes and their upstream regulatory factor form a module of HMG-box genes analogous to the SRY/SOX9 module, revealing a commonality of sex regulation in animals and fungi.
During the 2013–2016 West African Ebola virus disease ( EVD ) epidemic, there was an urgent need to determine the persistence of Ebola virus ( EBOV ) in survivors’ body fluids and the potential risk of transmission. An observational cohort study was implemented in Sierra Leone to investigate the presence of EBOV in semen and other body fluids of EVD survivors. The study was conducted in two phases. The first phase assessed the persistence of EBOV in semen of 100 adult men within five months of initial protocol discussions. The second phase assessed the persistence of virus in multiple body fluids ( semen, vaginal fluid, menstrual blood, breast milk, urine, rectal fluid, sweat, saliva, and tears ) of 120 men and 120 women. The study demonstrated the need to implement semen testing programs among EVD survivors and informed national and global guidelines in real time. Strong community engagement helped rapidly implement the study during the epidemic, and the lessons learned and study tools developed accelerated the implementation of such programs in EVD affected countries. The study also informed studies examining the persistence of Zika virus.
Chemotactic bacteria, such as Escherichia coli, are able to detect and migrate in chemical gradients of nutrients and toxins. To predict the chemical environments these bacteria typically encounter in their natural habitat, we reevaluate the phenomenological Weber's law and its generalizations to the Weber-Fechner law and fold-change detection. We use quantitative dose-response curves from in vivo fluorescence resonance energy transfer ( FRET ) measurements of the chemotactic sensory pathway, information theory, as well as measurements and simulations of swimming bacteria. We show that maximizing mutual information implies maximizing the alignment of cell trajectories with the gradient ( chemotactic index ), and hence the drift velocity of cells swimming up the gradient. Our results indicate that chemotactic E. coli typically encounters exponential gradients in its natural habitat, since its pathway has evolved to maintain perception in these. To fully characterize the chemical environment of chemotactic bacteria in terms of distributions, we expect a matching between the statistical properties of typical stimuli and the corresponding cellular responses assuming certain optimization criteria. Our model is able to connect a large number of phenomenological laws with information theory at the molecular level, and provides a first step towards deciphering the chemical nature of complex, experimentally inaccessible cellular microenvironments, such as the human intestine.
Hematopoietic stem cells ( HSCs ) are responsible for the life-long supply of blood cells and are characterized by their multi-potency and self-renewal capacity. HSCs were thought to have indefinite lifespans due to their self-renewal capacity, but there is increasing evidence that genetically identical HSCs differ in lifespan and that the lifespan of a HSC is predetermined and HSC-intrinsic. We present a new model based on reliability theory to account for the diversity of lifespans of HSCs. Using clonal repopulation experiments and computational-mathematical modeling, we found that the best fit of the experimental data is provided by a model where the repopulation failure kinetics of each HSC are largely anti-persistent, or mean-reverting, processes. This means that failure rates repeatedly increase during population-wide division events and are counteracted and decreased by repair processes. In the long-run, a crossover from anti-persistent to persistent behavior occurs due to a slow increase in the mean failure rate of self-renewal, leading to rapid clonal extinction. We show that the lifespan of each HSC depends on the amplitudes and frequencies of fluctuations in the failure rate kinetics, and that shorter and longer lived HSCs differ significantly in their pre-programmed ability to dissipate perturbations.
Antibodies play a crucial role in providing protective immunity against chronic helminth infections, which affect approximately one-third of the world's population. However, the mechanisms by which antibodies target these large multi-cellular parasites have remained obscure. We demonstrate that helminth-specific antibodies induce the rapid trapping of tissue migrating helminth larvae and prevent tissue necrosis following challenge infection with the natural murine parasite Heligmosomoides polygyrus bakeri ( Hp ). Antibodies induce the expression of Arginase-1 in macrophages, which directly impairs larval motility. This novel mechanism of alternative macrophage activation is antibody-dependent and IL-4Rα-independent. In the presence of helminth antigens, antibodies elicit a novel subtype of IL-4Rα-independent alternatively activated macrophages, which we refer to as helminth-antibody activated macrophages ( HAAM ). We show that HAAM upregulate Arginase-1 and immobilize infective and tissue-dwelling larvae. In addition, we demonstrate that antibodies mediate the activation of macrophages resulting in Arginase-1 expression and immobilization of tissue invasive helminth larvae. Our data indicate that antibodies form a previously unrecognized component of macrophage regulation during type 2 immune responses and provide a novel effector function of antibodies in activating macrophages to modulate the expression of genes normally associated with the alternatively activated phenotype.
DNA double-strand breaks ( DSBs ) are a major threat to genome integrity and cell survival. The most accurate way to repair DSBs is through homologous recombination ( HR ) with an intact copy of the broken locus. However, the early steps of HR, such as resection from DSB ends that generates recombinogenic single strands, are difficult to visualize in living cells. We have developed a new, non-intrusive method that uses protein oligomerization rather than operator multiplicity to form visible foci. We applied this method to the HO cleavage of the MAT locus on Saccharomyces cerevisiae chromosome III and monitored the dynamics of a chromatin locus next to a DSB in single living cells. We observed transient confinement of the damaged chromatin region during the very early steps of resection, consistent with the need to keep DNA ends in contact. In addition, we found that resection in a yku70 mutant began ∼10 min earlier than in wild type, defining this as the period of commitment to homology-dependent repair. Our new DNA-labelling and -targeting method will be widely applicable to fine-scale analysis of genome organization, dynamics and function in normal and pathological contexts.
Chagas disease, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, is a major public health problem in Latin America. People living in areas with active vector-borne transmission have multiple contacts with T. cruzi, and reinfections are possible. However, there is little quantitative knowledge about the frequency and timing of parasite re-inoculation in humans. We developed stochastic agent-based models to estimate the rate of re-inoculation in humans and assess the frequency of reinfections during the acute and chronic stages of the disease. We used a hybrid genetic algorithm to fit the models to epidemiological data from Argentinean rural villages where mixed infections by different genotypes of T. cruzi reach 56% in humans. The best model predicted 0. 032 ( 0. 008–0. 042 ) annual reinfections per individual with 98. 4% of them occurring in the chronic phase. The parasite escapes the adaptive immune response mounted after the primary infection in at least 20% of the events of re-inoculation. With these low annual rates, the risks of reinfection during the typically long chronic stage of the disease stand around 14% ( 4%–18% ) and 60% ( 21%–70% ) after 5 and 30 years, with most individuals being re-infected 1–3 times overall. These low rates are better explained by the weak efficiency of the stercorarian mode of transmission than a highly efficient adaptive immune response.
Dengue virus ( DENV ) infection can lead to a range of outcomes, from asymptomatic or subclinical infection to classical dengue fever ( DF ), dengue hemorrhagic fever ( DHF ), or dengue shock syndrome ( DSS ). While the majority of DENV infections result in subclinical outcomes, epidemiologic studies suggest that type-cross-reactive immunity can influence disease outcome in subsequent infections. However, the mechanisms controlling these differential clinical outcomes remain poorly defined. In this study, blood samples were collected from a cohort of school-aged Thai children who subsequently experienced a subclinical DENV infection or developed dengue illness. PBMC collected prior to infection were stimulated in vitro with DENV and the secretion of 30 cytokines was measured using a multiplexed, bead-based array. Significant differences were found in cytokine production based on both the type of DENV used for stimulation and the occurrence of clinical illness. Higher levels of IL-15, MCP-1, and IL-6 were found in subjects who later developed symptomatic DENV infection, while lower levels of IL-12, IL-2R, MIP-1α, RANTES, GM-CSF, and TNFα were found in subjects with symptomatic infection. These data demonstrate significant differences in pre-existing immune responses to DENV associated with the clinical outcome of subsequent infection, supporting the existence of both protective and pathologic immune profiles.
In the Drosophila wing imaginal disc, Hedgehog ( Hh ) forms an extracellular gradient that organizes patterning along the anterior–posterior axis and specifies at least three different domains of gene expression. However, a direct correspondence between the borders of these patterns and Hh concentration thresholds has not been demonstrated. Here, we provide evidence that the interpretation of Hh signaling depends on the history of exposure to Hh and propose that a single concentration threshold is sufficient to support multiple outputs. Using mathematical modeling, we predict that at steady state, only two domains can be defined in response to Hh, suggesting that the boundaries of two or more gene expression patterns cannot be specified by a static Hh gradient. Computer simulations suggest that a spatial “overshoot” of the Hh gradient occurs, i. e., a transient state in which the Hh profile is expanded compared to the Hh steady-state gradient. Through a temporal examination of Hh target gene expression, we observe that the patterns initially expand anteriorly and then refine, providing in vivo evidence for the overshoot. The Hh gene network architecture suggests this overshoot results from the Hh-dependent up-regulation of the receptor, Patched ( Ptc ). In fact, when the network structure was altered such that the ptc gene is no longer up-regulated in response to Hh-signaling activation, we found that the patterns of gene expression, which have distinct borders in wild-type discs, now overlap. Our results support a model in which Hh gradient dynamics, resulting from Ptc up-regulation, play an instructional role in the establishment of patterns of gene expression.
Ethanol and inhaled anesthetics influence the nervous system, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here we describe a new mouse mutation, Lightweight ( Lwt ), isolated in an N-ethyl-N-nitrosourea ( ENU ) forward mutagenesis screen for animals with enhanced locomotor activity. Lwt results from a nonsense mutation in the mouse homolog of the Caenorhabditis elegans ( C. elegans ) unc-79 gene. While Lwt/Lwt homozygotes are perinatal lethal, Lwt/+ heterozygotes are dramatically hypersensitive to acute ethanol exposure. Experiments in C. elegans demonstrate a conserved hypersensitivity to ethanol in unc-79 mutants and extend this observation to the related unc-80 mutant and nca-1;nca-2 double mutants. Lwt/+ heterozygotes also exhibit an altered response to the anesthetic isoflurane, reminiscent of unc-79 invertebrate mutant phenotypes. In addition, Lwt/+ heterozygotes are mildly hyperactive when exposed to a novel environment and are smaller than wild-type animals. They also exhibit increased food consumption yet have a leaner body composition. Interestingly, Lwt/+ heterozygotes voluntarily consume more ethanol than wild-type littermates. The acute hypersensitivity to and increased voluntary consumption of ethanol observed in Lwt/+ heterozygous mice in combination with the observed hypersensitivity to ethanol in C. elegans unc-79, unc-80, and nca-1;nca-2 double mutants suggests a novel conserved pathway that might influence alcohol-related behaviors in humans.
Plasmodium falciparum, the etiological agent of human malaria, has been identified as a target of the Anopheles gambiae immune response. The Imd pathway, a conserved immune signaling pathway, has been shown to have potent anti-P. falciparum activity. Silencing the expression of caspar, a negative regulator of the Imd pathway, or over-expressing rel2, an Imd pathway-controlled NFkappaB transcription factor, confers a resistant phenotype on A. gambiae mosquitoes that involves an array of immune effector genes. Using RNA interference, we have identified genes participating in the anti-Plasmodium signaling module regulated by Caspar, each of which represents a potential target to achieve over-activation of the pathway. The Imd pathway is most potent against the parasite's ookinete stage, yet also has reasonable activity against early oocysts and lesser activity against late oocysts. We further demonstrated that caspar silencing alone is sufficient to induce a robust anti-P. falciparum response even in the relative absence of resident gut microbiota. Finally, we established the relevance of the Imd pathway components and regulated effectors TEP1, APL1, and LRIM1 in parasite infection intensity-dependent defense.
Paracoccidioidomycosis is a fungal infection caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis that can lead to pulmonary fibrosis. In this study, we investigated the anti-fibrotic potential of bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells ( BMMSCs ) in a mouse model of pulmonary paracoccidioidomycosis. BMMSCs have been proposed as a promising therapy for fibrotic diseases. We found that BMMSCs did not have an anti-fibrotic effect in mice infected with P. brasiliensis. Instead, we observed an increase in granulomatous inflammatory areas, fibrocytes count, soluble collagen, and collagen-3α1, TGF-β3, MMP-8, and MMP-15 gene expression in the lungs of mice treated with BMMSCs. This suggests that BMMSCs may exacerbate pulmonary fibrosis in this model. Interestingly, when BMMSCs were combined with itraconazole ( ITC ), a drug used to treat fungal infections, we observed a decrease in TIMP-1 and MMP-13 gene expression. We also found that lung supernatants from infected and BMMSCs-treated mice induced a higher expression of collagen I in human fibroblasts. Our results suggest that BMMSCs may not be effective in treating pulmonary fibrosis caused by P. brasiliensis, and that their interaction with the fungus may promote collagen expression and tissue remodeling.
Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by the parasite Leishmania infantum, transmitted by phlebotomine sand flies in the Mediterranean subregion. Climate change has led to the geographical expansion of these sand fly vectors. To understand the seasonal dynamics of these vectors, a consortium of partners from eight Mediterranean countries carried out entomological investigations in sites where L. infantum transmission was recently reported.
