From 2011 to 2013, a total of 99, 000 sand fly specimens were collected and analyzed, resulting in the description of seasonal dynamics of 56, 000 sand flies belonging to six L. infantum vector species. The study found that the time of sand fly appearance/disappearance differed between sites, and seasonal densities showed variations in each site. Significant correlations were found between latitude/mean annual temperature of sites and the first month of sand fly appearance, which ranged from early April to the first half of June, and the type of density trend, varying from a single peak in July/August to multiple peaks increasing in magnitude from May through September. The period of potential exposure to L. infantum in the Mediterranean subregion was associated with a regular bell-shaped density curve having a wide peak center encompassing the July-September period, and falling between early May to late October for more than 99% of values.
Scrub typhus is a public health problem in the Asia-Pacific region caused by the obligate intracellular bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi. In addition to infecting endothelial cells, O. tsutsugamushi was found to replicate in monocytes isolated from healthy donors and alter the expression of more than 4, 500 genes, as demonstrated by microarray analysis. The expression of type I interferon, interferon-stimulated genes, and genes associated with the M1 polarization of macrophages was significantly upregulated. O. tsutsugamushi also induced the expression of apoptosis-related genes and promoted cell death in a small percentage of monocytes. Live organisms were indispensable to the type I interferon response and apoptosis, and enhanced the expression of M1-associated cytokines. These data were related to the transcriptional changes detected in mononuclear cells isolated from patients with scrub typhus. The microarray analyses revealed the upregulation of 613 genes, including interferon-related genes, and some features of M1 polarization were observed in these patients, similar to what was observed in O. tsutsugamushi-stimulated monocytes in vitro. This is the first report demonstrating that monocytes are clearly polarized in vitro and ex vivo following exposure to O. tsutsugamushi.
Insects, such as ants, use visual memory to navigate through complex environments, but it is unknown how their small brains implement this capability. The mushroom body neuropils have been identified as a crucial memory circuit in the insect brain, but their function has mostly been explored for simple olfactory association tasks. We show that a spiking neural model of the mushroom body circuit, originally developed to describe fruitfly olfactory association, can also account for the ability of desert ants to rapidly learn visual routes through complex natural environments. We further demonstrate that abstracting the key computational principles of this circuit, including one-shot learning of sparse codes, enables the theoretical storage capacity of the ant mushroom body to be estimated at hundreds of independent images. We have shown that the neural architecture of the insect mushroom body can implement the ‘familiarity’ algorithm for ant route following. In our simulation, the mushroom body learns over 80 on-route images, reconstructed from real ant viewpoints in their natural habitat, and reliably distinguishes them from the highly similar images obtained when looking off-route. The network which was originally developed for modelling simple olfactory associative learning in flies required almost no modification other than increased size to perform the apparently much more complex function of supporting navigation under realistic conditions.
Plants have evolved unique defense mechanisms to protect themselves from disease. One such mechanism is pathogen-triggered leaf abscission, where infected leaves are shed to prevent the spread of disease. We developed a system to study pathogen-triggered leaf abscission in Arabidopsis by infecting cauline leaves with the bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas syringae. We found that Pseudomonas syringae lacking a functional type III secretion system fail to elicit an abscission response, suggesting that the abscission response is a novel form of immunity triggered by bacterial effectors. We identified several genes required for pathogen-triggered leaf abscission, including HAESA/HAESA-like 2, INFLORESCENCE DEFICIENT IN ABSCISSION, and NEVERSHED. We also found that salicylic acid is necessary for full pathogen-triggered leaf abscission to occur, as well as for drought-triggered leaf abscission. Plants with mutations in genes necessary for bacterial defense and salicylic acid signaling, such as phytoalexin deficient 4, enhanced disease susceptibility 1, and salicylic acid induction-deficient 2, fail to abscise cauline leaves normally. We propose a threshold model regulating cauline leaf defense where minor infections are handled by limiting bacterial growth, but when an infection is deemed out of control, cauline leaves are shed.
Retinal starburst amacrine cells ( SACs ) play a major role in the detection of image motion direction. To study the mechanisms underlying the computation of direction selectivity ( DS ) in SAC dendrites, we measured electrical responses to expanding and contracting circular wave visual stimuli via somatic whole-cell recordings and quantified them using Fourier analysis. We found that fundamental and, especially, harmonic frequency components were larger for expanding stimuli. This direction selectivity persists in the presence of GABA and glycine receptor antagonists, suggesting that inhibitory network interactions are not essential. The presence of harmonics indicates nonlinearity, which is likely due to the activation of voltage-gated channels. We also found that the distal dendrite is tonically depolarized relative to the soma, due in part to resting currents mediated by tonic glutamatergic synaptic input, and that high-voltage–activated Ca2+ channels are active at rest. Using compartmental modeling, we conclude that dendritic DS in SACs can be computed by the dendrites themselves, relying on voltage-gated channels and a dendritic voltage gradient, which provides the spatial asymmetry necessary for direction discrimination. Optical recordings of visual stimulus-evoked Ca2+ signals also showed that dendritic sectors can be activated independently and that the strongest [Ca2+] increases are in the distal portions of the dendrites, near the output synapses.
The number of pathogens required to infect a host, termed the infective dose, varies dramatically across pathogen species. It has been predicted that infective dose will depend upon the mode of action of the molecules that pathogens use to facilitate their infection. Specifically, pathogens that use locally acting molecules will require a lower infective dose than pathogens that use distantly acting molecules. Furthermore, it has also been predicted that pathogens with distantly acting immune modulators may be more virulent because they have a large number of cells in the inoculum, which will cause more harm to host cells. Here, we formally test these predictions using data on 43 different human pathogens from a range of taxonomic groups with diverse life-histories. We found that pathogens using local action do have lower infective doses, but are not less virulent than those using distant action. Instead, we found that virulence was negatively correlated with infective dose, and higher in pathogens infecting wounded skin compared with those ingested or inhaled.
Schistosoma mansoni is a parasitic helminth that causes schistosomiasis, a disease affecting approximately 200 million people, primarily in underprivileged regions of the world. Schistosoma mansoni is the most experimentally tractable schistosome species due to its ease of propagation in the laboratory and the high quality of its genome assembly and annotation. In this study, we investigated the role of microRNAs ( miRNAs ) in the development of S. mansoni from juvenile to adult stages. We used a bioinformatics tool called Sylamer to analyse the 3’-untranslated regions ( 3’-UTRs ) of transcripts differentially expressed between the juvenile and adult stages. We found that the miR-277/4989 family target sequence is the only one significantly enriched in the transition from juvenile to adult worms. We also identified a novel miRNA, sma-miR-4989, and proposed hairpin folds for both sma-miR-277 and sma-miR-4989 that are compatible with the miRNA pathway. Our results indicate that sma-miR-277/4989 may play a dominant role in post-transcriptional regulation during the development of juvenile worms and suggest an important role in the sexual development of female schistosomes.
SARS-related coronaviruses ( SARSr-CoV ) have been detected in multiple species of horseshoe bats in China since 2005. However, these bat SARSr-CoVs show genetic differences from SARS-CoV and are considered unlikely to represent the direct progenitor of SARS-CoV. Here, we report the findings of our 5-year surveillance of SARSr-CoVs in a cave inhabited by multiple species of horseshoe bats in Yunnan Province, China. The full-length genomes of 11 newly discovered SARSr-CoV strains, together with our previous findings, reveal that the SARSr-CoVs circulating in this single location are highly diverse in the S gene, ORF3 and ORF8. Importantly, strains with high genetic similarity to SARS-CoV in the hypervariable N-terminal domain ( NTD ) and receptor-binding domain ( RBD ) of the S1 gene, the ORF3 and ORF8 region, respectively, were all discovered in this cave. Recombination analysis shows evidence of frequent recombination events within the S gene and around the ORF8 between these SARSr-CoVs. We hypothesize that the direct progenitor of SARS-CoV may have originated after sequential recombination events between the precursors of these SARSr-CoVs. Cell entry studies demonstrated that three newly identified SARSr-CoVs with different S protein sequences are all able to use human ACE2 as the receptor, further exhibiting the close relationship between strains in this cave and SARS-CoV.
Human soil-transmitted helminth ( STH ) infections are controlled by periodic mass treatment with benzimidazole and imidothiazole drugs. However, high levels of resistance to these drugs have developed in roundworms of livestock, necessitating the need to monitor drug efficacy in human STHs. The faecal egg count reduction test ( FECRT ), which measures faecal egg output pre- and post-drug treatment, is being examined by WHO as a means of detecting the emergence of resistance. We have investigated the potential impact of density dependent fecundity on FECRT data. Density dependent fecundity refers to the phenomenon where the number of eggs produced by female worms increases as their population density decreases. This phenomenon has been observed in canine hookworms and is likely to apply to human STHs as well. The relaxation of density dependent constraints on egg production may lead to an increase in egg output by female worms that survive drug treatment, resulting in an underestimation of drug efficacy in the FECRT. The degree of underestimation will depend on the ability of worms to increase their egg output, which in turn depends on the extent to which their egg output is constrained prior to drug treatment.
Epithelial heparan sulfate ( HS ) plays a critical role in lung development by regulating the Sonic Hedgehog ( SHH ) signaling pathway. We show that epithelial deletion of HS synthetase Ext1 results in expanded branching tips and reduced branching number in the lung, associated with several mesenchymal developmental defects. We further demonstrate an expanded Fgf10 expression and increased FGF signaling activity in Ext1 mutant lungs, suggesting a cell non-autonomous mechanism. Consistent with this, we observed reduced levels of SHH signaling, which is responsible for suppressing Fgf10 expression. Moreover, reactivating SHH signaling in mutant lungs rescued the tip dilation phenotype and attenuated FGF signaling. Importantly, the reduced SHH signaling activity did not appear to be caused by decreased Shh expression or protein stability; instead, biologically active form of SHH proteins were reduced in both the Ext1 mutant epithelium and surrounding wild type mesenchymal cells. Together, our study highlights the epithelial HS as a key player for dictating SHH signaling critical for lung morphogenesis.
Paired-end sequencing has emerged as a key technique for detecting genome rearrangements and structural variation on a genome-wide scale. This technique is particularly useful for detecting copy-neutral rearrangements, such as inversions and translocations, which are common in cancer and can produce novel fusion genes. We address the question of how much sequencing is required to detect rearrangement breakpoints and to localize them precisely using both theoretical models and simulation. We derive a formula for the probability that a fusion gene exists in a cancer genome given a collection of paired-end sequences from this genome. We use this formula to compute fusion gene probabilities in several breast cancer samples, and we find that we are able to accurately predict fusion genes in these samples with a relatively small number of fragments of large size. We further demonstrate how the ability to detect fusion genes depends on the distribution of gene lengths, and we evaluate how different parameters of a sequencing strategy impact breakpoint detection, breakpoint localization, and fusion gene detection, even in the presence of errors that suggest false rearrangements. These results will be useful in calibrating future cancer sequencing efforts, particularly large-scale studies of many cancer genomes that are enabled by next-generation sequencing technologies.
Chemotaxis, the ability of cells to sense the direction of chemical gradients and respond by polarizing and migrating toward attractants, involves the coordinated action of separable but interrelated processes: motility, gradient sensing, and polarization. Here, we describe a mathematical model that recreates the behaviors of chemotactic cells by implementing these processes in terms of reaction-diffusion equations and a mechanical model of the cell cortex implemented in the level set framework. The central module is an excitable network that accounts for random migration, while the response to combinations of uniform stimuli and gradients is mediated by a local excitation, global inhibition module that biases the direction in which excitability is directed. A polarization module linked to the excitable network through the cytoskeleton allows unstimulated cells to move persistently and, for cells in gradients, to gradually acquire distinct sensitivity between front and back. By varying the strengths of various feedback loops in the model, we obtain cellular behaviors that mirror those of genetically altered cell lines.
Tudor containing protein 6 ( TDRD6 ) is a male germ line-specific protein that is essential for the structure of the chromatoid body ( ChB ), elongated spermatid development, and male fertility. In this study, we show that TDRD6 interacts with the protein arginine methyl transferase PRMT5 in meiotic prophase I spermatocytes, which supports splicing. TDRD6 also associates with the spliceosomal core protein SmB in the absence of RNA and in an arginine methylation dependent manner. In TDRD6-deficient diplotene spermatocytes, PRMT5 association with SmB and arginine dimethylation of SmB are much reduced. As a result, TDRD6 deficiency impairs the assembly of spliceosomes, which feature 3. 5-fold increased levels of U5 snRNPs. In the nucleus, these deficiencies in spliceosome maturation correlate with decreased numbers of SMN-positive bodies and Cajal bodies involved in nuclear snRNP maturation. Transcriptome analysis of TDRD6-deficient diplotene spermatocytes revealed high numbers of splicing defects such as aberrant usage of introns and exons as well as aberrant representation of splice junctions.
Bacterial populations that colonize a host can play important roles in host health, including serving as a reservoir that transmits to other hosts and from which invasive strains emerge. Understanding rates of acquisition and clearance of colonizing populations is therefore important. Previous studies of colonization dynamics have been based on assessment of whether serial samples represent a single population or distinct colonization events. However, these studies often rely on a fixed genetic distance threshold below which isolates are considered to represent the same strain. This approach is often inadequate to account for the diversity of the underlying within-host evolving population, the time intervals between consecutive measurements, and the uncertainty in the estimated acquisition and clearance rates. Here, we present a fully Bayesian model that provides probabilities of whether two strains should be considered the same, allowing us to determine bacterial clearance and acquisition from genomes sampled over time. Our method explicitly models the within-host variation using population genetic simulation, and the inference is done using a combination of Approximate Bayesian Computation ( ABC ) and Markov Chain Monte Carlo ( MCMC ). We validate the method with multiple carefully conducted simulations and demonstrate its use in practice by analyzing a collection of methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus ( MRSA ) isolates from a large recently completed longitudinal clinical study.
The shoot apical meristem ( SAM ) is responsible for initiating leaves, flowers, and lateral meristems in a highly ordered pattern via phyllotaxis. The active transport of the plant hormone auxin plays a major role in this process. Current hypotheses propose that cellular hormone transporters of the PIN family create local auxin maxima at precise positions, which in turn lead to organ initiation. However, different concepts have been proposed to explain how auxin transporters create hormone fluxes to distinct regions within the plant. The canalization hypothesis proposes that auxin transporters amplify and stabilize existing fluxes, which could be initiated by local diffusion. In contrast, a second hypothesis proposes that auxin is systematically transported towards areas with the highest concentrations. We show that a flux-based polarization hypothesis is able to explain auxin transport at the shoot meristem, thus providing a unifying concept for the control of auxin distribution in the plant. Auxin is actively transported throughout the plant from cell to cell by carriers located at the cell plasma membranes. PIN proteins facilitate auxin efflux, while AUX/LAX family proteins facilitate auxin import. We propose that both regimes correspond to different states of the same flux sensing mechanism, and that the flux-based hypothesis remains a potential unifying mechanism for auxin transport throughout the plant.
Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by Leishmania parasites transmitted by sandflies. Visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) is the most severe form of the disease and requires improved point-of-care diagnostic tests for early case detection and surveillance. Previous studies have shown that IgG1 is a potential biomarker for monitoring clinical status in rapid diagnostic tests ( RDTs ). However, using a crude lysate antigen ( CLA ) as a capturing antigen in RDTs may not lead to robust results. Here, we employed in silico searches to reduce the number of wet lab experiments, focusing on promising candidates containing selected protein features. Immunoblots revealed L. donovani protein bands detected by IgG1 from VL patients, which were then identified by mass spectrometry ( MS ). We searched for evidence of constitutive protein expression and presence of antigenic domains or high accessibility to B-cells. Multiple high-scoring predicted epitopes from the shortlisted proteins were screened in peptide arrays. The most promising candidate was tested in RDT prototypes using VL and nonendemic healthy control ( NEHC ) patient sera. Over 90% of the proteins identified from the immunoblots did not satisfy the selection criteria and were excluded from the downstream epitope mapping. Screening of predicted epitope peptides from the shortlisted proteins identified the most reactive, for which the sensitivity for IgG1 was 84% ( 95% CI 60–97% ) with Sudanese VL sera on RDT prototypes. None of the sera from NEHCs were positive.
Cutaneous leishmaniasis ( CL ) is a disease caused by the Leishmania parasite, which is transmitted by the bite of an infected sandfly. In this study, a multiregional cohort of 317 patients with CL from six countries ( Syria, Pakistan, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia, Ethiopia, and Iran ) was reviewed to document the incidence of caseating granulomas, a type of granuloma often associated with mycobacterial infections such as tuberculosis ( TB ). The study found that caseating granulomas were present in 195 ( 61. 5% ) cases of CL and were divided into three types: caseating ( 25. 2% ), suppurative ( 4. 6% ), and tuberculoid without necrosis ( 70. 2% ). Caseating and tuberculoid granuloma groups were significantly different in terms of geographical source, with more cases harboring caseating granulomas in Saudi Arabia ( p<0. 0001 ). Histologically, both groups were different in the distribution of their Ridley's pattern ( p<0. 0001 ) with a doubling Ridley's pattern 3 in caseating granulomas ( 31% vs. 15% ) as opposed to doubling of Ridley's pattern 5 in tuberculoid granuloma group ( 38% vs. 19% ). The time needed to achieve healing ( Ridley's pattern 5 ) was notably shorter in tuberculoid vs. caseating group ( 4. 0 vs. 6. 2 months ). The study also found that 18. 2% of all CL cases harbored caseating granulomas, suggesting that CL should be considered part of the differential diagnosis for cases with caseating granulomas in endemic regions.
Type 2 diabetes in mice is associated with obesity and results from a combination of adipogenic and diabetogenic alleles. Here, we report the identification of a candidate gene for the diabetogenic effect of a QTL ( Nidd/SJL, Nidd1 ) contributed by the SJL, NON, and NZB strains in outcross populations with New Zealand Obese ( NZO ) mice. A critical interval of distal chromosome 4 ( 2. 1 Mbp ) conferring the diabetic phenotype was identified by interval-specific congenic introgression of SJL into diabetes-resistant C57BL/6J, and subsequent reporter cross with NZO. Analysis of the 10 genes in the critical interval by sequencing, qRT–PCR, and RACE–PCR revealed a striking allelic variance of Zfp69 encoding zinc finger domain transcription factor 69. In NZO and C57BL/6J, a retrotransposon ( IAPLTR1a ) in intron 3 disrupted the gene by formation of a truncated mRNA that lacked the coding sequence for the KRAB ( Krüppel-associated box ) and Znf-C2H2 domains of Zfp69, whereas the diabetogenic SJL, NON, and NZB alleles generated a normal mRNA. When combined with the B6. V-Lepob background, the diabetogenic Zfp69SJL allele produced hyperglycaemia, reduced gonadal fat, and increased plasma and liver triglycerides. We conclude that Zfp69 is the most likely candidate for the diabetogenic effect of Nidd/SJL, and that retrotransposon IAPLTR1a contributes substantially to the genetic heterogeneity of mouse strains.
Alternative cell differentiation pathways are believed to arise from the concerted action of signalling pathways and transcriptional regulatory networks. However, the prediction of mammalian cell differentiation from the knowledge of the presence of specific signals and transcriptional factors is currently a daunting challenge. In this respect, the vertebrate hematopoietic system, with its many branching differentiation pathways and cell types, is a compelling case study. We propose an integrated, comprehensive model of the regulatory network and signalling pathways controlling Th cell differentiation. As most available data are qualitative, we rely on a logical formalism to perform extensive dynamical analyses. To cope with the size and complexity of the resulting network, we use an original model reduction approach together with a stable state identification algorithm. We have identified stable states corresponding to canonical Th1, Th2, Th17 and Treg subtypes, as well as transient hybrid cell types that co-express combinations of Th1, Th2, Treg and Th17 markers in an environment-dependent fashion. Our logical analysis highlights the nature of these cell types and their relationships with canonical Th subtypes. Finally, our logical model can be used to explore novel differentiation pathways in silico.
Genome-wide patterns of transcription factor binding during early Drosophila development have been studied using a thermodynamic model of transcription factor binding. The model was used to evaluate the contribution of different biophysical forces to the binding of five regulators of early embryonic anterior-posterior patterning in Drosophila melanogaster. Predictions based on DNA sequence and in vitro protein-DNA affinities alone achieved a correlation of ∼0. 4 with experimental measurements of in vivo binding. Incorporating cooperativity and competition among the five factors, and accounting for spatial patterning by modeling binding in every nucleus independently, had little effect on prediction accuracy. However, incorporating experimental measurements of genome-wide DNA accessibility into the model dramatically improved predictions to a correlation of 0. 6–0. 9 for various factors across known target genes. Our results show that, in regions of open chromatin, binding can be predicted almost exclusively by the sequence specificity of individual factors, with a minimal role for protein interactions. We suggest that a combination of experimentally determined chromatin accessibility data and simple computational models of transcription factor binding may be used to predict the binding landscape of any animal transcription factor with significant precision.
Daughterless ( Da ) and Extramacrochaetae ( Emc ), members of the basic helix-loop helix ( bHLH ) transcription factor family, control cell proliferation in Drosophila imaginal discs by regulating the activity of the Cdc25 phosphatase, string. Through a genetic analysis, we show that Emc controls the G2/M transition, and hence cell proliferation, by downregulating Da, which in turn transcriptionally represses string. The ectopic expression of string in cells with reduced levels of Emc or high levels of Da is sufficient to rescue the proliferative defects seen in these mutant cells. Moreover, we present evidence demonstrating that Da acts as a transcriptional repressor of string. These findings define a mechanism through which Emc controls cell proliferation by regulating the activity of Da. In Drosophila, Da and Emc are the only representatives of classes I and V bHLH factors, respectively, thereby facilitating functional studies. The interaction between these proteins and with other bHLH proteins is a determinant of cell fate decisions in different developmental contexts. Our data indicate that at least in Drosophila, E proteins can also control the G2/M transition in conjunction with Id factors, and thus we have described the first mechanism through which interacting class I and class V bHLHs intercede in this cell cycle transition.
Yeast filamentous growth is a complex biological process regulated by multiple signaling networks. However, few of these networks have been completely delineated. Here, we propose a comprehensive quantitative analysis pipeline for phosphoproteome data from interventional experiments to identify key proteins in specific pathways, discover protein-protein interactions, and infer signaling networks. The pipeline includes phosphopeptide meta-analysis, correlation network analysis, and causal relationship discovery. We applied this pipeline to yeast phosphoproteome data generated using SILAC ( Stable Isotope Labeling with Amino acids in Cell culture ) technique with interventional experiments ( kinase-dead mutations ). We identified 5 high-confidence proteins from meta-analysis and 19 hub proteins from correlation analysis, all of which are involved in stress responses. Nine of these proteins have direct or indirect evidence of involvement in filamentous growth. We tested four of our predicted proteins by interventional phenotypic experiments and all of them presented differential invasive growth, providing prospective validation of our approach. Our pipeline presents a systematic way for discovering signaling networks using interventional phosphoproteome data and can suggest candidate proteins for further investigation.
The regulation of the Drosophila X chromosome in the male germline has been the subject of much debate. Here we report three new findings concerning gene expression from the X in Drosophila testes. First, we show that X chromosome-wide dosage compensation appears to be absent from most of the Drosophila male germline. Second, microarray analysis provides no evidence for X chromosome-specific inactivation during meiosis. Third, we confirm the previous discovery that the expression of transgene reporters driven by autosomal spermatogenesis-specific promoters is strongly reduced when inserted on the X chromosome versus the autosomes, but we show that this chromosomal difference in expression is established in premeiotic cells and persists in meiotic cells. The magnitude of the X-autosome difference in transgene expression cannot be explained by the absence of dosage compensation, suggesting that a previously unrecognized mechanism limits expression from the X during spermatogenesis in Drosophila. These findings help to resolve several previously conflicting reports and have implications for patterns of genome evolution and speciation in Drosophila.
The pathogenesis of Citrobacter rodentium, a mouse model for the human diarrheal infection caused by enteropathogenic E. coli ( EPEC ) and enterohemorrhagic E. coli ( EHEC ), depends on the formation of epithelium-adherent microcolonies, also known as “attachment/effacement” ( A/E ) lesions. These microcolonies must be dynamic and able to self-renew by continuous re-infection of the rapidly regenerating epithelium. We show here that all colonic epithelial A/E microcolonies are clonal bacterial populations, and thus depend on local clonal growth to persist. In wild-type mice, microcolonies are established exclusively within the first 18 hours of infection. These early events shape the ongoing intestinal geography and severity of infection despite the continuous presence of phenotypically virulent luminal bacteria. Mechanistically, induced resistance to A/E lesion de-novo formation is mediated by TLR-MyD88/Trif-dependent signaling and is induced specifically by virulent C. rodentium in a virulence gene-dependent manner. Our data demonstrate that the establishment phase of C. rodentium pathogenesis in vivo is restricted to a very short window of opportunity that determines both disease geography and severity. We show that the development of colonic C. rodentium A/E pathogenesis is critically dependent on very early bacteria-host interactions. The characteristic A/E lesions that determine the severity of infection originate from a limiting number of single-bacterial epithelial infection events that need to occur within the first 18 hours of infection.
Measuring the overlap between two populations, such as species, taxonomical units, or gene variants, is in principle straightforward when both populations are fully sampled. However, in practice, only a fraction of each population’s objects are likely to be sampled due to stochastic data collection or sequencing techniques. Existing methods for quantifying population overlap under subsampled conditions are biased and their uncertainty cannot be quantified. Here, we derive and validate a method to rigorously estimate the population overlap from incomplete samples when the total number of objects in each population is known. This method, based on Bayesian inference, takes into account the rates of subsampling and produces unbiased and Bayes-optimal estimates of overlap. It also provides a natural framework for computing the uncertainty of its estimates, and can be used prospectively in study planning by quantifying the tradeoff between sampling effort and uncertainty. This method is particularly relevant in the ecology and genomic epidemiology of malaria.
Eukaryotic protein kinases play a central role in regulating most cellular functions by phosphorylating targeted protein substrates through a highly conserved catalytic core. In the active state, the catalytic core oscillates between open, intermediate, and closed conformations. However, the intramolecular interactions that regulate the active state mechanics are not well understood. Using cAMP-dependent protein kinase as a representative model, we define a set of highly conserved electrostatic and hydrophobic interactions that regulate the active state mechanics. These interactions include a salt bridge between a lysine from the β3-strand and a glutamate from the αC-helix as well as an electrostatic interaction between the phosphorylated activation loop and αC-helix and an ensemble of hydrophobic residues of the Regulatory spine and Shell. We show that the highly conserved β3-lysine is not required for phosphoryl transfer but is essential for the active state mechanics. The β3-lysine is a structural ATP sensor that facilitates the active state mechanics by coordinating the transition of the β-sheet region of the N-lobe and linking this region with the αC-helix. The active state mechanics can be regulated through the R-spine and Shell in the absence of the salt bridge and the electrostatic interaction between the activation loop and the αC-helix.
American Samoa conducted seven rounds of mass drug administration ( MDA ) for lymphatic filariasis ( LF ) from 2000 to 2006 under the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis. In 2016, we compared the effectiveness of two survey designs for post-MDA surveillance: a school-based survey of children aged 6–7 years and a community-based survey of people aged ≥8 years. We conducted a systematic school-based Transmission Assessment Survey ( TAS ) in all elementary schools ( N = 29 ) and a cluster survey in 28 villages on the two main islands of American Samoa. We collected information on demographics and risk factors for infection using electronic questionnaires, and recorded geo-locations of schools and households. Blood samples were collected to test for circulating filarial antigen ( CFA ) using the Alere Filariasis Test Strip. The school-based TAS identified nine antigen-positive children and found an overall adjusted CFA prevalence of 0. 7% ( 95% CI: 0. 3–1. 8 ). The community-based survey identified 102 antigen-positive people and estimated an overall adjusted CFA prevalence of 6. 2% ( 95% CI: 4. 5–8. 6 ). CFA prevalence increased with age and was higher in males. The school-based TAS had limited sensitivity and negative predictive value but high specificity and positive predictive value for identifying villages with ongoing transmission. The community-based survey identified antigen-positive individuals of all ages and foci of high antigen prevalence. Both surveys confirmed recrudescence of LF transmission in American Samoa 10 years after the last round of MDA.
Female sex determination in zebrafish is a complex process influenced by multiple genetic and environmental factors. In this study, we investigated the role of two oocyte-expressed signaling molecules, Gdf9 and Bmp15, in female sex determination and maintenance of the female sexual phenotype in zebrafish. We generated targeted mutations in the genes for Gdf9 and Bmp15 and found that females deficient in Bmp15 begin development normally but switch sex during the mid- to late-juvenile stage and become fertile males. In contrast, females deficient in Gdf9 did not exhibit a sex reversal phenotype. Our results provide the first mechanistic insights into how oocytes regulate the maintenance of sex in zebrafish. We propose that the outcome of the oocyte-somatic gonad interaction is the stabilization of cyp19a1a expression and thus estrogen production by the somatic gonad. Consistent with this, we have shown that the somatic gonad expresses probable receptors for Bmp15. We have also shown that estrogen production is necessary for female development and that the function of Bmp15 in female sex maintenance is likely linked to the regulation of estrogen biosynthesis via promoting the development of estrogen-producing granulosa cells in the oocyte follicle. Our results establish the framework of a genetic pathway required for female sexual development and maintenance in zebrafish that is likely conserved in other fish species.
Hox proteins play a fundamental role in controlling morphogenetic diversity in animals by regulating distinct sets of target genes along the anterior–posterior body axis. To achieve high-regulatory specificity, it has been postulated that Hox proteins co-operate with other transcription factors to activate or repress their target genes in a highly context-specific manner in vivo. Here, we analyze the regulation of the cell death gene reaper ( rpr ) by the Hox protein Deformed ( Dfd ) and suggest that local activation of rpr expression in the anterior part of the maxillary segment is achieved through a combinatorial interaction of Dfd with at least eight functionally diverse transcriptional regulators on a minimal enhancer. We have shown that eight transcriptional regulators, Apt, Gcm, Ems, En, Slp1, Brk, Doc1 and Disco, are required in addition to the Hox protein Dfd to properly regulate the expression of the apoptosis gene reaper in a specific subset of cells of the maxillary segment. Our findings suggest that proper spatio-temporal Hox target gene regulation is achieved by the combined action of multiple transcriptional regulators: the Hox proteins themselves and a large number of structurally diverse transcription factors.
Plants recognize and respond to pathogen attack by detecting pathogen-specific molecules at the cell surface and inside the cell. Pathogen effectors are monitored by intracellular nucleotide-binding leucine-rich repeat ( NB-LRR ) sensor proteins in plants and mammals. Here, we study the genetic requirements for defense responses of an autoactive mutant of ADR1-L2, an Arabidopsis coiled-coil ( CC ) -NB-LRR protein. ADR1-L2 functions upstream of salicylic acid ( SA ) accumulation in several defense contexts, and it can act as a “helper” to transduce specific microbial activation signals from “sensor” NB-LRRs. We generated an autoactive missense mutation, ADR1-L2D484V, in a small homology motif termed MHD. Expression of ADR1-L2D484V leads to dwarfed plants that exhibit increased disease resistance and constitutively high SA levels. We used ADR1-L2D484V to define genetic requirements for signaling. Signaling from ADR1-L2D484V does not require NADPH oxidase and is negatively regulated by EDS1 and AtMC1. Transcriptional regulation of ADR1-L2D484V is correlated with its phenotypic outputs; these outputs are both SA–dependent and –independent. The genetic requirements for ADR1-L2D484V activity resemble those that regulate an SA–gradient-dependent signal amplification of defense and cell death signaling initially observed in the absence of LSD1. Importantly, ADR1-L2D484V autoactivation signaling is controlled by both EDS1 and SA in separable, but linked pathways.
MORC6 is a protein that mediates transcriptional silencing in Arabidopsis through heterochromatin condensation. Previous studies have shown that MORC6 physically interacts with SUVH9, a component of the RNA-directed DNA methylation ( RdDM ) pathway. However, how MORC6 mediates transcriptional silencing remains to be determined. In this study, we demonstrate that SUVH2 and SUVH9 can either act in the same pathway as MORC6 or act synergistically with MORC6 to mediate transcriptional silencing. Moreover, we show that IDN2, a double-stranded RNA-binding protein, interacts with MORC6 and mediates the silencing of a subset of MORC6 target loci. We also demonstrate that other RdDM components, including Pol IV, Pol V, RDR2, and DRM2, are required for transcriptional silencing at a subset of MORC6 target loci. Furthermore, we show that the SWI/SNF chromatin-remodeling complex components SWI3B, SWI3C, and SWI3D interact with MORC6 and mediate transcriptional silencing. These results suggest that the RdDM components are involved not only in DNA methylation but also in MORC6-mediated heterochromatin condensation.
Heat shock protein 90 ( Hsp90 ) is a molecular chaperone that plays a critical role in the development of vertebrates. In this study, we used zebrafish as a vertebrate model to investigate the role of Hsp90 in phenotype modification. We found that mild perturbation of Hsp90 function at critical developmental stages may underpin the variable penetrance and expressivity of many developmental anomalies. We defined Hsp90 inhibitor levels that did not induce a heat shock response or perturb phenotype in wild-type zebrafish strains. Using these conditions, we found that Hsp90 inhibition increased the severity of the recessive eye phenotype in sunrise, caused by a pax6b mutation, and decreased the severity of the recessive eye phenotype in dreumes, caused by a sufu mutation. In another strain, we uncovered a previously unobserved spectrum of severe structural eye malformations, reminiscent of anophthalmia, microphthalmia, and nanophthalmia complex in humans. Inbreeding of offspring from selected unaffected carrier parents led to significantly elevated malformation frequencies and revealed the oligogenic nature of this phenotype. We also found that Hsp90 inhibition can decrease developmental stability in zebrafish, as indicated by increased asymmetric presentation of anophthalmia, microphthalmia, and nanophthalmia and sunrise phenotypes.
N-terminal acetylation is a common protein modification found throughout the tree of life, where the N-terminus of a nascent polypeptide chain becomes co-translationally acetylated after the removal of the initiating methionine residue. In this study, we analyzed the amino-terminal peptides from proteins extracted from Drosophila Kc167 cells and detected more than 1, 200 mature protein N-termini. We found that N-terminal acetylation occurs in insects with a similar frequency as in humans and that the sequence requirements that promote N-terminal acetylation are similar to those in other eukaryotes. We identified the ( X ) PX rule as the sole true determinant for N-terminal acetylation, which indicates the prevention of acetylation under all circumstances. This rule can be used to genetically engineer a protein to study the biological relevance of the presence or absence of an acetyl group, thereby generating a generic assay to probe the functional importance of N-terminal acetylation. We applied this assay by expressing mutated proteins as transgenes in cell lines and in flies and propose that the ( X ) PX rule can be used to study the function of N-terminal acetylation in all species.
The ability of RNA polymerase III ( RNAP III ) to efficiently recycle from termination to reinitiation is critical for the production of abundant tRNA during cellular proliferation, development, and cancer. However, the unique termination mechanisms used by RNAP III and their link to high transcription output are incompletely understood. We used two tRNA-mediated suppression systems to screen for RNAP III mutants with gain- and loss-of-termination phenotypes in Schizosaccharomyces pombe. We identified 122 point mutations that cluster in the active center bridge helix and trigger loop, as well as the pore and funnel of the RNAP III elongation complex. These mutants exhibit increased elongation rate and increased transcription levels in vivo. Our data strongly support a kinetic coupling model in which elongation rate is inversely related to termination efficiency. We show that the mobile elements of the RNAP III active center, including the C11 subunit, are key determinants of termination and that some of the mutations activate RNAP III for overall transcription.
We have developed a method to predict SH2-mediated protein-protein interactions using the structure of SH2-phosphopeptide complexes and the FoldX algorithm. Our approach is based on the idea that the structure of SH2-phosphopeptide complexes can be used to predict the binding specificity of SH2 domains. We have shown that our method performs similarly to experimentally derived consensus sequences and substitution matrices at predicting known in vitro and in vivo targets of SH2 domains. We have used our method to provide a set of high-confidence interactions for human SH2 domains with known structure filtered on secondary structure and phosphorylation state. We have validated our predictions using literature-derived SH2 interactions and a probabilistic score obtained from a naive Bayes integration of information on coexpression, conservation of the interaction in other species, shared interaction partners, and functions. We have also used FoldX to predict in vivo protein-protein interactions for nine SH2 domain-containing proteins and annotated the predicted interactions with supporting information. Our results show that FoldX performs as well as experimentally derived consensus sequences or position-specific substitution matrices in the prediction of in vitro SH2-phosphopeptide binding and in vivo SH2-mediated protein-protein interactions. We propose that the FoldX algorithm is a useful alternative to peptide library experiments for the prediction of SH2-mediated protein-protein interactions.
Human cyclophilin 40 ( CyP40 ) is a cis/trans peptidyl-prolyl isomerase ( PPIase ) that has been shown to dissolve tau amyloids in vitro and in a mouse model of tau accumulation. Tau is a microtubule associating protein that accumulates into toxic oligomers and amyloid deposits in tauopathies, the most common of which is Alzheimer’s disease ( AD ). CyP40 was found to interact with tau at sites rich in proline residues and was able to disaggregate other aggregating proteins that contain prolines. Moreover, CyP40 lacking PPIase activity was unable to disaggregate amyloids in vitro, indicating that its disaggregation activity is dependent on its PPIase activity. In a mouse model of tau accumulation, transduction of CyP40 reduced tau oligomers and tangles, improved neuronal health, and preserved cognitive function. These data implicate CyP40 as a potential therapeutic intervention for tauopathies and other amyloidogenic disorders. Furthermore, we describe a unique structural property of CyP40 that may enable it to disaggregate amyloids in an energy-independent manner.
Heterocyst pattern formation in cyanobacteria filaments is one of the simplest examples of cellular differentiation and pattern formation in multicellular organisms. However, there is still a theoretical gap connecting the macroscopic and microscopic processes underlying heterocyst pattern formation. Here, we present an integrative approach for modeling and simulation of heterocyst pattern formation in cyanobacteria filaments under the paradigm of systems biology. We formulate the essential dynamical ingredients of the genetic circuit of a single cyanobacterium into a set of differential equations describing the time evolution of the concentrations of the relevant molecular products. We study the behavior of a single cyanobacterium under different external conditions, emulating nitrogen deprivation, and simulate the dynamics of cyanobacteria filaments by coupling their respective genetic circuits via molecular diffusion. Our results show that by including both diffusion and noisy external conditions in the computational model, it is possible to reproduce the main features of the formation and sustainment of heterocyst patterns in cyanobacteria filaments as observed experimentally. Our model connects the diffusion of combined nitrogen along the filament with the dynamical properties of the underlying genetic circuit of each single cyanobacterium, capturing both the development of heterocyst patterns and their maintenance.
Onchocerciasis prevalence remains above the non-transmission threshold in Cameroon, despite more than 15 years of mass treatment with the Community Directed Treatment with Ivermectin ( CDTI ) program. A cross-sectional survey was conducted in three Cameroonian health districts to explore the association between people’s beliefs/perceptions of onchocerciasis and the CDTI program, and their adherence to ivermectin. The study found that adherence to ivermectin was comparable between Bafang and Bafia ( 55. 0% and 48. 8%, respectively ), but lower in Yabassi ( 40. 7% ). Perceptions of the CDTI program were the most determinant factor in adherence to ivermectin. People who had a “not positive” opinion of ivermectin distribution campaigns were less compliant than those who had a positive opinion ( 40% vs 55% in Bafang, and 48% vs 62% in Bafia, p<0. 01 ), as well as those who had a negative appreciation of community drug distributors’ commitment ( 22% vs 53% in Bafang, 33% vs 59% in Bafia, 27% vs 47% in Yabassi; p<0. 01 ). The most common misconception about onchocerciasis transmission was the lack of hygiene, especially in Bafia and Yabassi. In Bafang, high proportions of people believed that onchocerciasis was due to high consumption of sugar ( 31% vs less than 5% in Bafia and Yabassi, p<0. 001 ).
The relative contribution of DNA methylation and genetic variants on protein biomarkers for human diseases has been investigated in this study. We combined DNA methylation and SNP data with measurements of protein biomarkers for cancer, inflammation, and cardiovascular disease. We identified 124 and 45 loci with effect sizes up to 0. 22 standard units’ change per 1% change in DNA methylation levels and up to four standard units’ change per copy of the effective allele in the epigenome-wide association study ( EWAS ) and genome-wide association study ( GWAS ) respectively. Most GWAS loci were cis-regulatory, whereas most EWAS loci were located in trans. Eleven EWAS loci were associated with multiple biomarkers, including one in NLRC5 associated with CXCL11, CXCL9, IL-12, and IL-18 levels. We found that all EWAS signals that overlapped with a GWAS locus were driven by underlying genetic variants, and three EWAS signals were confounded by smoking. While some cis-regulatory SNPs for biomarkers appeared to have an effect also on DNA methylation levels, cis-regulatory SNPs for DNA methylation were not observed to affect biomarker levels. We present associations between protein biomarker and DNA methylation levels at numerous loci in the genome. The associations are likely to reflect the underlying pattern of genetic variants, specific environmental exposures, or represent secondary effects to the pathogenesis of disease.
Varicella zoster virus ( VZV ) potently impairs the ability of human natural killer ( NK ) cells to respond to target cell stimulation in vitro, leading to a loss of both cytotoxic and cytokine responses. NK cells are important anti-viral immune effectors in VZV infection, yet it is unknown how VZV can directly affect NK cell function. We demonstrate that VZV can productively infect NK cells, and that VZV infected NK cells are affected, as well as VZV antigen negative NK cells that were exposed to virus in culture. The impairment of NK cell function is dependent on direct contact between NK cells and VZV infected inoculum cells. Profiling of the NK cell surface receptor phenotype revealed that functional receptor expression is predominantly stable, and inhibited NK cells were still capable of releasing cytotoxic granules when the stimulation signal bypassed receptor/ligand interactions and early signalling. In addition to inhibiting degranulation, IFN-γ and TNF production were also repressed by VZV co-culture, which was most strongly regulated in VZV infected NK cells. Interestingly, the closely related virus, herpes simplex virus type 1 ( HSV-1 ), was also capable of efficiently infecting NK cells in a cell-associated manner, and demonstrated a similar capacity to render NK cells unresponsive to target cell stimulation, however HSV-1 differentially targeted cytokine production compared to VZV.
Apparent motion ( AM ) is a phenomenon in which two stimuli alternately presented at different locations can evoke a percept of a stimulus continuously moving between the two locations. The neural mechanism underlying AM is thought to be increased activation of primary visual cortex ( V1 ) neurons tuned to locations along the AM path. However, evidence remains inconclusive. AM masking, which refers to the reduced detectability of stimuli along the AM path, has been taken as evidence for AM-related V1 activation. However, AM masking can also be explained by predictive coding models, which predict that responses to stimuli presented on the AM path are suppressed when they match the spatio-temporal prediction of a stimulus moving along the path. We find that AM has a distinct effect on the detection of target gratings, limiting the maximum performance at high contrast levels. This masking is strongest when the target orientation is identical to the orientation of the inducers. We developed a V1-like population code model of early visual processing and find that AM-related activation in early visual cortex is too small to either cause masking or to be perceived as motion. Our model instead predicts strong suppression of early sensory responses during AM, consistent with the theoretical framework of predictive coding.
Human T-lymphotropic virus 1 (HTLV-1) is a retrovirus that causes adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATL) and tropical spastic paraparesis/HTLV-1 associated myelopathy (TSP/HAM). The HTLV-1 oncoprotein Tax plays a key role in the transformation of CD4+ T cells by promoting cell proliferation and survival, mainly through the permanent activation of the NF-κB pathway and induction of NF-κB target genes. However, the underlying molecular mechanism of Tax-induced NF-κB activation is still not fully understood. In this study, we elucidated the biochemical mechanism of Tax-induced NF-κB activation by reconstituting Tax-stimulated NF-κB activation in a cell-free system. We found that Tax functions as a putative E3 ubiquitin ligase, which catalyzes the assembly of free mixed-linkage polyubiquitin chains. These free mixed-linkage polyubiquitin chains are then responsible for direct activation of the IKK complex by binding to the NEMO subunit of IKK. Our studies revealed the biochemical function of Tax in the process of IKK activation, which utilizes the minimal cellular ubiquitination components for NF-κB activation. This study clarifies the confusion on HTLV-1-induced IKK-NF-κB activation, reveals the essential cellular factors hijacked by HTLV-1, and might shed light on potential development of therapeutics for ATL and TSP/HAM.
The relationship between the number of individuals introduced to found a population ( propagule pressure ) and the establishment success of alien species has been evaluated for a broad range of taxa and life histories, including invertebrates, herbaceous plants and long-lived trees, and terrestrial and aquatic vertebrates. Using Bayesian meta-analytical methods, we found a positive mean effect of propagule pressure on establishment success to be a feature of every hypothesis we tested. However, establishment success most critically depended on propagule pressures in the range of 10–100 individuals. Heterogeneity in effect size was associated primarily with different analytical approaches, with some evidence of larger effect sizes in animal rather than plant introductions. Conversely, no variation was accounted for in any analysis by the scale of study ( field to global ) or methodology ( observational, experimental, or proxy ) used. Our analyses reveal remarkable consistency in the form of the relationship between propagule pressure and alien population establishment success.
Interleukin 17A ( IL-17 ) is a cytokine that plays a role in chronic and severe inflammatory diseases by enhancing the production of pro-inflammatory mediators. Here, we show that IL-17 attenuates the degradation of mRNAs encoding these mediators by changing the cooperation between AU-binding proteins ( AUBps ) and microRNA16 ( miR16 ). AUBps target AU-rich elements in the 3′-untranslated region of mRNAs and can either facilitate mRNA decay or stabilization. In the presence of miR16, AUBps and the target mRNA assemble in a novel ribonucleoprotein complex that leads to mRNA degradation. However, IL-17 attenuates miR16 expression and promotes the binding of stabilizing AUBps over destabilizing AUBps, resulting in reduced mRNA degradation. These findings indicate that miR16 directs the competition between degrading and stabilizing AUBps for target mRNAs independently of a seed sequence. Since AUBps affect the expression of about 8% of the human transcriptome and miR16 is ubiquitously expressed, IL-17 may affect many other cellular processes in addition to inflammation.
Sleeping sickness, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense ( T. b. rhodesiense ), is a zoonotic disease that affects both humans and animals. In Uganda, the disease has been spreading rapidly from its traditional focus in southeast Uganda to new districts. Cattle act as long-term reservoirs of human infective T. b. rhodesiense, showing few signs of morbidity, yet posing a significant risk to human health. In this study, we examined the relationship between human T. b. rhodesiense infection and human infective and non-human T. brucei s. l. circulating in cattle at village level in Kaberamaido and Dokolo Districts, Uganda. We compared T. brucei s. l. prevalence and presence or absence of T. b. rhodesiense in cattle between villages that had reported a case of sleeping sickness ( defined as case villages ) and those that had never reported a case ( defined as non-case villages ). We found that the sleeping sickness status of a village had a significant effect on the likelihood of T. brucei s. l. infection in cattle, with higher odds of infection in case villages than in non-case villages. We also found that village human sleeping sickness status had a significant effect on the detection of T. b. rhodesiense in the village cattle herd, with significantly higher likelihood of T. b. rhodesiense in the village cattle of case villages.
In Drosophila melanogaster, the NSL complex, which contains the histone H4 lysine 16-specific ( H4K16 ) acetyltransferase MOF, plays a major role in the regulation of housekeeping genes. Here, we report a comprehensive ChIP–seq analysis of four NSL complex members ( NSL1, NSL3, MBD-R2, and MCRS2 ) throughout the Drosophila genome. We find that the majority ( 85. 5% ) of NSL-bound genes are constitutively expressed across different cell types. These genes are characterized by an increased abundance of the histone modifications H4K16ac, H3K4me2, H3K4me3, and H3K9ac in gene promoter regions, as well as a well-defined nucleosome free region and broad transcription initiation patterns. Furthermore, we show that both NSL1 and NSL3 are required for efficient recruitment of RNA polymerase II ( Pol II ) to NSL target gene promoters, and that genes that undergo the most dramatic loss of Pol II upon NSL knockdowns tend to be enriched in DNA Replication–related Element ( DRE ). Our findings suggest that the NSL complex acts as a major regulator of housekeeping genes in flies by modulating initiation of Pol II transcription.
Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy (FSHD) is a progressive muscular dystrophy caused by decreased epigenetic repression of the D4Z4 macrosatellite repeats and ectopic expression of DUX4, a retrogene encoding a germline transcription factor. We have generated transgenic mice carrying D4Z4 arrays from an FSHD1 allele and from a control allele. These mice recapitulate important epigenetic and DUX4 expression attributes seen in patients and controls, including high DUX4 expression levels in the germline, ( incomplete ) epigenetic repression in somatic tissue, and FSHD–specific variegated DUX4 expression in sporadic muscle nuclei associated with D4Z4 chromatin relaxation. Our data suggest that somatic epigenetic silencing of DUX4 is an evolutionary conserved mechanism and that contracted D4Z4 repeat arrays are silenced less efficiently, leading to a variegated expression pattern of DUX4 protein in skeletal muscle nuclei. ChIP and DNA methylation analyses indicate a relative chromatin relaxation of the D4Z4 repeats in D4Z4-2. 5 mice compared to D4Z4-12. 5 mice, concordant with the observed DUX4 expression pattern. These transgenic mice therefore represent a valuable animal model for FSHD and will be a useful resource to study the molecular mechanisms underlying FSHD and to test new therapeutic intervention strategies.
Malaria vaccine candidate Apical Membrane Antigen-1 ( AMA1 ) induces protection, but only against parasite strains that are closely related to the vaccine. To overcome the AMA1 diversity problem, we need to understand the structural basis of cross-strain invasion inhibition. A vaccine containing four diverse AMA1 allelic proteins ( AMA1 Quadvax or QV ) elicited polyclonal rabbit antibodies that inhibited the invasion of four vaccine and 22 non-vaccine strains of Plasmodium falciparum. We compared polyclonal anti-QV with antibodies against a strain-specific, monovalent, 3D7 AMA1 vaccine and found that QV induced higher levels of broadly inhibitory antibodies. These antibodies were associated with increased conserved face and domain-3 responses and reduced domain-2 response. Inhibitory monoclonal antibodies ( mAb ) raised against QV reacted with a novel cross-reactive epitope at the rim of the hydrophobic trough on domain-1. This epitope mapped to the conserved face of AMA1 and encompassed the 1e-loop. MAbs binding to the 1e-loop region were ∼10-fold more potent than previously characterized AMA1-inhibitory mAbs and inhibited AMA1 binding to its ligand RON2. Another novel mAb, 1E10, which bound to domain-3, was broadly inhibitory and blocked the proteolytic processing of AMA1. These novel inhibition susceptible regions and epitopes can form the basis for improving the antigenic breadth and inhibitory response of AMA1 vaccines. Vaccination with a few diverse antigenic proteins could provide universal coverage by redirecting the immune response towards conserved epitopes.
Mitotic spindle displacement to one side of a cell is important for many cells to divide unequally, but little is known about how spindle displacement is precisely timed. Here we show that a conserved mitotic progression mechanism, involving the anaphase-promoting complex ( APC ), its activator Cdc20/Fizzy, its degradation target cyclin, and cyclin-dependent kinase ( CDK ), comprises a previously unrecognized timer for spindle displacement. In the Caenorhabditis elegans zygote, mitotic spindle displacement begins at a precise time, soon after chromosomes congress to the metaphase plate. We found that reducing the function of the proteasome, the APC, or Cdc20/Fizzy delayed spindle displacement. Conversely, inactivating CDK in prometaphase caused the spindle to displace early. The consequence of experimentally unlinking spindle displacement from this timing mechanism was the premature displacement of incompletely assembled components of the mitotic spindle. We conclude that in this system, asymmetric positioning of the mitotic spindle is normally delayed for a short time until the APC inactivates CDK, and that this delay ensures that the spindle does not begin to move until it is fully assembled. This link between the cell cycle and asymmetric cell division might be evolutionarily conserved, because the mitotic spindle is displaced at a similar stage of mitosis during asymmetric cell divisions in diverse systems.
High-altitude hypoxia exerts severe physiological stress on the human body. Populations living in high-altitude regions, such as the Andean Altiplano and the Tibetan Plateau, have developed unique circulatory, respiratory, and hematological adaptations to life at high altitude. However, the underlying genetic basis of these adaptations remains unknown. We performed a genome scan to identify genes showing evidence of adaptation to hypoxia in Andeans and Tibetans. We looked across each chromosome to identify genomic regions with previously unknown function with respect to altitude phenotypes. We also examined groups of genes functioning in oxygen metabolism and sensing to test the hypothesis that particular pathways have been involved in genetic adaptation to altitude. Applying four population genetic statistics commonly used for detecting signatures of natural selection, we identified selection-nominated candidate genes and gene regions in these two populations separately. Our results indicate that several key HIF-regulatory and targeted genes are responsible for adaptation to high altitude in Andeans and Tibetans, and several different chromosomal regions are implicated in the putative response to selection. Interestingly, one gene previously known to be important in cellular oxygen sensing, EGLN1 ( also known as PHD2 ), shows evidence of positive selection in both Tibetans and Andeans, but the pattern of variation for this gene differs between the two populations.
Double-strand DNA breaks ( DSBs ) are a major source of genetic instability that can result from environmental assaults or the collapse of DNA replication. The efficient and precise repair of DSBs is essential for cell survival, but faulty repair can lead to genetic instability. Here, we report that inverted DNA repeats ( IRs ) placed near a DSB can channel its repair from an accurate pathway that leads to gene conversion to a break-induced replication ( BIR ) pathway that leads to genetic instability. IRs can form unusual DNA structures when present in single-strand DNA ( ssDNA ) that is formed by DSB resection. We demonstrate that IRs can form two types of unusual DNA structures, and the choice between these structures depends on the length of the spacer separating IRs. IRs separated by a long ( 1-kb ) spacer are predominantly involved in inter-molecular single-strand annealing ( SSA ) leading to the formation of inverted dimers; IRs separated by a short ( 12-bp ) spacer participate in intra-molecular SSA, leading to the formation of fold-back ( FB ) structures. Both of these structures interfere with an accurate DSB repair by gene conversion and channel DSB repair into BIR, which promotes genomic destabilization. We also report that different protein complexes participate in the processing of FBs containing short ( 12-bp ) versus long ( 1-kb ) ssDNA loops. Overall, our studies uncover the mechanisms of genomic destabilization resulting from re-routing DSB repair into unusual pathways by IRs.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an opportunistic pathogen that causes both acute and chronic infections in susceptible hosts. Chronic P. aeruginosa infections are thought to be caused by bacterial biofilms, which are highly structured, multicellular communities encased in an extracellular matrix that enable long-term survival in the host. To study P. aeruginosa biofilm infections in vivo, we developed an animal model using Drosophila melanogaster as the host. At 24 h post oral infection of Drosophila, P. aeruginosa biofilms localized to and were visualized in dissected Drosophila crops. These biofilms had a characteristic aggregate structure and an extracellular matrix composed of DNA and exopolysaccharide. P. aeruginosa cells recovered from in vivo grown biofilms had increased antibiotic resistance relative to planktonically grown cells. Biofilm formation was dependent on expression of the pel exopolysaccharide genes, as a pelB::lux mutant failed to form biofilms. The pelB::lux mutant was significantly more virulent than PAO1, while a hyperbiofilm strain ( PAZHI3 ) demonstrated significantly less virulence than PAO1. Biofilm formation by strains PAO1 and PAZHI3 in the crop was associated with induction of diptericin, cecropin A1 and drosomycin antimicrobial peptide gene expression 24 h postinfection. In contrast, infection with the non-biofilm forming strain pelB::lux resulted in decreased AMP gene expression in the fly.
Vasopressin receptor 1a ( Avpr1a ) is a gene responsible for mediating differences in vasopressin-mediated social behaviors between and within species. However, the genomic mechanisms that contribute to these differences are not well understood. Previous studies have suggested that both the proximal 5′ flanking region and a polymorphic microsatellite element within that region of the vole Avpr1a gene are associated with variation in V1a receptor ( V1aR ) distribution and behavior. Using homologous recombination in mice, we reveal that the proximal 5′ flanking sequences contribute modestly to species differences in V1aR distribution, and that variation in V1aR distribution impacts stress-coping in the forced swim test. We also demonstrate that the vole Avpr1a microsatellite structure contributes to Avpr1a expression in the amygdala, thalamus, and hippocampus, mirroring a subset of the inter- and intra-species differences observed in central V1aR patterns in voles. This is the first direct evidence that polymorphic microsatellite elements near behaviorally relevant genes can contribute to diversity in brain gene expression profiles, providing a mechanism for generating behavioral diversity both at the individual and species level.
Activation Induced Cytidine Deaminase ( AID ) induces double-strand breaks ( DSBs ) at immunoglobulin switch ( S ) regions and the c-MYC oncogene in yeast THO mutants, which are impaired in messenger RNA ( mRNP ) biogenesis. Such DSBs lead to chromosomal translocations via Non-Homologous End Joining ( NHEJ ). AID-mediated deamination of cytosines at S sequences in yeast is channeled by the Ung1 activity into DSBs as occurs in mammalian B cells, which are then repaired by NHEJ. The c-MYC oncogene, which shares features of S sequences, also acts as a hotspot of recombination in yeast THO mutants. Our study provides new clues to understand the role of mRNP biogenesis in preventing genome rearrangements and the mechanism of AID-mediated genome instability. We show that yeast cells, as mammalian B cells, have the factors and pathways required to channel AID-mediated DNA lesions into DSBs responsible for NHEJ-dependent genome rearrangements and Class Switch Recombination ( CSR ).
In Escherichia coli, coordination between cell division and chromosome replication is essential for the production of viable progeny. However, cells lacking proper positioning of their cell division planes can still successfully propagate. Here, we characterize how these cells partition their chromosomes into daughters during asymmetric divisions. Using quantitative time-lapse imaging, we show that DNA translocase, FtsK, can pump as much as 80% of the chromosome ( 3. 7 Mb ) between daughters at an average rate of 1700±800 bp/s. Pauses in DNA translocation are rare, and in no occasions did we observe reversals at experimental time scales of a few minutes. The majority of DNA movement occurs at the latest stages of cell division when the cell division protein ZipA has already dissociated from the septum, and the septum has closed to a narrow channel with a diameter much smaller than the resolution limit of the microscope ( ~250 nm ). Our data suggest that the narrow constriction is necessary for effective translocation of DNA by FtsK.
Epitope-based vaccines ( EVs ) have a wide range of applications, including therapeutic and prophylactic approaches for infectious diseases and cancer. The development of an EV is based on the knowledge of target-specific antigens from which immunogenic peptides, so-called epitopes, are derived. However, due to regulatory, economic, and practical concerns, the number of epitopes that can be included in an EV is limited. Furthermore, the major histocompatibility complex ( MHC ) binding these epitopes is highly polymorphic, making the optimal selection of these epitopes an important and interesting optimization problem. In this work, we present a mathematical framework based on integer linear programming ( ILP ) that allows the formulation of various flavors of the vaccine design problem and the efficient identification of optimal sets of epitopes. The framework selects the set with the maximum likelihood of eliciting a broad and potent immune response from a user-defined set of predicted or experimentally determined epitopes. Our ILP approach allows an elegant and flexible formulation of numerous variants of the EV design problem, including common immunological requirements such as coverage of epitopes from each antigen, coverage of all MHC alleles in a set, or avoidance of epitopes with high mutation rates.
HIV-1 transmission to the cervico-vaginal mucosa is the most common route of HIV-1 infection in women. Semen is not only a carrier of HIV-1 but also contains biological factors, including cytokines, that may affect HIV-1 transmission. Interleukin-7 ( IL-7 ) is one of the most prominent cytokines in semen of healthy individuals and is further increased in semen of HIV-1-infected men. Here, we investigated the role of IL-7 in HIV-1 vaginal transmission in an ex vivo system of human cervico-vaginal tissue. We simulated an in vivo situation by depositing HIV-1 on cervico-vaginal tissue in combination with IL-7 at concentrations comparable with those measured in semen of HIV-1-infected individuals. We found that IL-7 significantly enhanced HIV-1 replication in ex vivo infected cervico-vaginal tissue and lymphoid tissue explants. Analysis of T cells isolated from infected tissues showed that IL-7 reduced CD4+ T cell depletion by preventing apoptosis and increased the fraction of cycling CD4+ T cells. Our results suggest that high levels of seminal IL-7 in vivo may be relevant to the survival of the founder pool of HIV-1-infected cells in the cervico-vaginal mucosa at the initial stage of infection, promoting local expansion and dissemination of HIV infection.
Zika virus ( ZIKV ) infection of Aedes aegypti mosquito cells induces the production of both virus-specific small interfering RNAs ( siRNAs ) and PIWI-interacting RNAs ( piRNAs ). The siRNAs are 21 nucleotides in length and are loaded into the exogenous siRNA pathway effector protein Argonaute 2 ( Ago2 ). However, silencing of Ago2 does not enhance ZIKV replication, suggesting that the exo-siRNA pathway is not the primary antiviral response mechanism. In contrast, enhanced ZIKV replication is observed in a Dicer 2 ( Dcr2 )-knockout cell line, indicating that the exo-siRNA pathway is involved in the antiviral response. Although ZIKV-specific piRNA-sized small RNAs are detected, they lack the characteristic piRNA ping-pong signature motif and are bound to Ago3 but not Piwi5 or Piwi6. Silencing of Ago3, Piwi5, or Piwi6 does not enhance ZIKV replication. However, silencing of Piwi4 results in enhanced ZIKV replication, suggesting that Piwi4 has antiviral activity. We also report that the expression of ZIKV capsid ( C ) protein amplifies the replication of a reporter alphavirus, but unlike yellow fever virus C protein, it does not inhibit the exo-siRNA pathway.
Sporotrichosis is a fungal infection caused by species of the genus Sporothrix. In Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, a cross-sectional study was conducted to determine the association between Sporothrix species and clinical manifestations of sporotrichosis. A total of 50 patients with different clinical manifestations of sporotrichosis were included in the study, and their Sporothrix isolates were analyzed by phenotypic and genotypic methods. The results showed that Sporothrix brasiliensis was associated with disseminated cutaneous infection without underlying disease, hypersensitivity reactions, and mucosal infection, whereas patients infected with Sporothrix schenckii sensu stricto presented with less severe and more localized disease. Interestingly, patients infected with S. brasiliensis required shorter durations of itraconazole treatment compared to those infected with S. schenckii. These findings suggest that Sporothrix species are linked to different clinical manifestations of sporotrichosis and that S. brasiliensis is effectively treated with oral itraconazole. This study is the first to demonstrate an association between genotypic identification of Sporothrix species and several clinical aspects of human sporotrichosis, and it supports the careful speciation of Sporothrix isolates to guide clinical care.
Most “dark matter” transcripts in the mammalian genome are associated with known genes. This conclusion is based on a comprehensive analysis of RNA sequencing ( RNA-Seq ) and tiling array data from human and mouse tissues. While previous studies have suggested that a large portion of the genome is transcribed, our results indicate that the majority of these transcripts are either fragments of pre-mRNAs, alternative cleavage and polyadenylation site usage, promoter- and terminator-associated transcripts, or new alternative exons. Indeed, we identified 4, 544 new exons affecting 3, 554 genes. Most of the remaining intergenic transcripts are present at low levels and display characteristics of random sampling from a low-level background. We also found that tiling arrays are ill-suited to accurately detect transcripts expressed at low levels. In contrast to previous reports, we found relatively few transcripts in intergenic regions, with only 16, 268 seqfrags expressed above background levels in human and 11, 533 in mouse. A genome-wide analysis of “de novo” splice junctions revealed 2, 789 previously uncharacterized transcript fragments that have no overlap with exons of known gene annotations, 1, 259 of which map to intergenic regions. Overall, our results suggest that while there are bona fide new intergenic transcripts, their number and abundance is generally low in comparison to known exons, and the genome is not as pervasively transcribed as previously reported.
Protein thermostability is crucial for the development of novel protein bioreagents. In this work, a combined computational and experimental method was developed to increase the thermostability of the flavin mononucleotide based fluorescent protein Bacillus Subtilis YtvA LOV domain. The method includes five steps: single mutant computer screening to identify thermostable mutant candidates, experimental evaluation to confirm the positive selections, computational redesign around the thermostable mutation regions, experimental reevaluation, and multiple mutations combination. The method is simple and effective, and can be applied to other important proteins where other methods have difficulties. The thermostability of the YtvA LOV domain was increased by 31°C, thus extending its applicability in thermophilic systems. The success rate of the computational screening was 62%, highlighting the effectiveness of the method. The thermostable sites were mainly located at the dimeric interface, suggesting that forging stronger interactions between subunits is an effective way to increase thermostability.
