Leishmaniasis, a protozoan disease transmitted by sand flies of the genus Lutzomyia, is endemic in the Panama Canal watershed and poses a health threat to residents, tourists, and the international research community. Here, we report the results of a study on the diversity of Lutzomyia sand fly species and their infection rates by Leishmania and Wolbachia in the tropical forest of Barro Colorado Island, Panama. We used DNA sequences to determine the diversity and phylogenetic relationships of the Phlebotominae occurring in the understory of the island. We detected Leishmania DNA in 43. 3% of Lu. trapidoi, 26. 3% of Lu. gomezi individuals, and in 0% of the other 18 sand fly species. The Leishmania infecting Lu. trapidoi and Lu. gomezi was identified as Leishmania ( viannia ) naiffi, a species previously unknown in Panama but recognized as a type of cutaneous leishmaniasis vectored broadly across northern and central South America. We also detected distinct strains of Wolbachia in three of 20 sand fly species, including Lu. trapidoi, in which it frequently co-occurred with Leishmania. Our results suggest that Lu. trapidoi and Lu. gomezi are likely vectors of leishmaniasis to humans or other mammal species, and that Le. naiffi has recently expanded its range to include the Isthmus of Panama.
The reactivation of human cytomegalovirus ( HCMV ) from latency in dendritic cells ( DCs ) is dependent on the mitogen and stress activated kinase ( MSK ) family and the transcription factor CREB ( cAMP response element binding protein ). CREB binding to the viral major immediate early promoter ( MIEP ) is necessary for the recruitment of MSK kinase activity to initiate chromatin remodelling at the MIEP required for reactivation. MSK mediated phosphorylation of histone H3 is required to promote histone de-methylation and the subsequent exit of HCMV from latency. The interaction between CREB and MSKs is important for promoting chromatin modifications conducive for viral gene expression as well as acting as a classical transcription factor. Inhibition of this interaction between CREB and MSKs could provide a strategy for therapeutic intervention against HCMV reactivation. Using an adenovirus vector approach, we have shown that IE gene expression from latency in DCs is acutely sensitive to MSK chemical inhibition and that reactivation of HCMV involves the phosphorylation of histones bound to the latent MIEP. Furthermore, MSK mediated phosphorylation of these histones is highly dependent on concomitant CREB binding to the MIEP.
Ribosome biogenesis factor Nol11 is required for optimal rDNA transcription and craniofacial development in Xenopus. Nol11 is strongly expressed in the developing cranial neural crest ( CNC ) of both amphibians and mammals. Knockdown of Xenopus nol11 results in impaired pre-rRNA transcription and processing, increased apoptosis, and abnormal development of the craniofacial cartilages. Inhibition of p53 rescues this skeletal phenotype, but not the underlying ribosome biogenesis defect, demonstrating an evolutionarily conserved control mechanism through which ribosome-impaired craniofacial cells are removed. Excessive activation of this mechanism impairs craniofacial development. Our findings reveal a novel requirement for Nol11 in craniofacial development and provide further insight into the evolutionarily conserved relationship between specific ribosome biogenesis factors and the control mechanisms that regulate CNC survival and development.
Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium Leptospira interrogans serovar Copenhageni. The lack of an adequate laboratory test for leptospirosis is a major barrier for diagnosis, especially during the early stages of illness when antibiotic therapy is most effective. In order to identify new targets that could be used as diagnostic markers for leptospirosis, we constructed a protein microarray chip comprising 61% of the Leptospira interrogans proteome and investigated the IgG response from 274 individuals, including 80 acute-phase, 80 convalescent-phase patients and 114 healthy control subjects from regions with endemic, high endemic, and no endemic transmission of leptospirosis. We found 16 antigens that can discriminate between acute cases and healthy individuals from a region with high endemic transmission of leptospirosis, and 18 antigens that distinguish convalescent cases. Some of the antigens identified in this study, such as LipL32, the non-identical domains of the Lig proteins, GroEL, and Loa22, are already known to be recognized by sera from human patients. We also identified several novel antigens, including the hypothetical protein LIC10215, which showed good sensitivity and specificity rates for both acute- and convalescent-phase patients. Our study is the first large-scale evaluation of immunodominant antigens associated with naturally acquired leptospiral infection.
Melanization, a potent immune effector mechanism of arthropods, plays an important role in mosquito defense against the entomopathogenic fungus Beauveria bassiana. In this study, we used the malaria vector Anopheles gambiae as a model to investigate the role of melanization in mosquito defense against B. bassiana using in vivo functional genetic analysis and confocal microscopy. We found that melanin eventually formed on all stages of B. bassiana, including conidia, germ tubes and hyphae, except the single cell hyphal bodies. However, melanin rarely aborted the growth of any of these stages and the mycelium continued growing despite being melanized. Silencing TEP1 and CLIPA8, key positive regulators of Plasmodium and bacterial melanization in A. gambiae, abolished completely melanin formation on hyphae but not on germinating conidia or germ tubes. Our results suggest that melanization of early fungal stages is cell-mediated while that of late stages is a humoral response dependent on TEP1 and CLIPA8. Finally, we found that fungal proliferation was more rapid in TEP1 and CLIPA8 knockdown mosquitoes which exhibited increased sensitivity to natural B. bassiana infections.
Dengue virus host factors ( DENV HFs ) that are essential for the completion of the infection cycle in the mosquito vector Aedes aegypti and vertebrate host represent potent targets for transmission blocking. Here, we investigated whether known mammalian DENV HF inhibitors could influence virus infection in A. aegypti. We evaluated the potency of bafilomycin ( BAF; inhibitor of vacuolar H+-ATPase ), mycophenolic acid ( MPA; inhibitor of inosine-5′-monophosphate dehydrogenase ), castanospermine ( CAS; inhibitor of glucosidase ), and deoxynojirimycin ( DNJ; inhibitor of glucosidase ) in blocking DENV infection of the mosquito midgut. We found that injection of BAF ( 5 µM ) and MPA ( 25 µM ) prior to feeding on virus-infected blood inhibited DENV titers in the midgut at 7 days post-infection by 56% and 60%, and in the salivary gland at 14 days post-infection by 90% and 83%, respectively. Ingestion of BAF and MPA through a sugar meal or together with an infectious blood meal also resulted in various degrees of virus inhibition. RNAi-mediated silencing of several vATPase subunit genes and the IMPDH gene resulted in a reduced DENV infection, thereby indicating that BAF- and MPA-mediated virus inhibition in adult mosquitoes most likely occurred through the inhibition of these DENV HFs.
Seizures, spreading depression, and anoxic depolarization are pathological states of the brain characterized by excessive neuronal depolarization. These states are associated with major rearrangements of ions across the cell membrane and neuronal microenvironment. In this study, we investigated the role of cell volume in the dynamics of these pathological states. By incorporating cell swelling, dynamic ion concentrations, and oxygen supply into Hodgkin-Huxley type spiking dynamics, we demonstrated the spontaneous transition between seizure and spreading depression states as the cell swells and contracts in response to changes in osmotic pressure. Our results revealed a dynamical definition for the physiological ceiling that separates seizure from spreading depression, as well as a second ceiling that demarcates spreading depression from anoxic depolarization. Our model highlights the neuroprotective role of glial K buffering against seizures and spreading depression, and provides novel insights into anoxic depolarization and the relevant cell swelling during ischemia. We argue that the dynamics of seizures, spreading depression, and anoxic depolarization lie along a continuum of the repertoire of the neuron membrane that can be understood only when the dynamic ion concentrations, oxygen homeostasis, and cell swelling in response to osmotic pressure are taken into consideration.
Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is the causative agent of paracoccidioidomycosis, the most prevalent systemic mycosis in Latin America. In this study, we investigated the role of the NLRP3 inflammasome in host defense against P. brasiliensis infection. We found that murine bone marrow-derived dendritic cells responded to P. brasiliensis yeast cells infection by releasing the pro-inflammatory cytokine IL-1β in a spleen tyrosine kinase ( Syk ), caspase-1 and NLR family member NLRP3 dependent manner. In addition, P. brasiliensis-induced NLRP3 inflammasome activation was dependent on potassium ( K+ ) efflux, reactive oxygen species production, phagolysosomal acidification and cathepsin B release. Using mice lacking the IL-1 receptor, we demonstrated that IL-1β signaling has an important role in killing P. brasiliensis by murine macrophages. Our results demonstrate that the NLRP3 inflammasome senses and responds to P. brasiliensis yeast cells infection and plays an important role in host defense against this fungus.
Toxoplasma gondii is a brain-tropic parasite capable of infecting most nucleated cells in the central nervous system ( CNS ), including neurons and astrocytes. However, in vivo, Toxoplasma is primarily found in neurons. In vitro studies have shown that interferon-γ-stimulated astrocytes, but not neurons, are able to clear intracellular parasites, suggesting that neurons are persistently infected in vivo because they lack the ability to clear intracellular parasites. To test this theory, we used a novel Toxoplasma-mouse model capable of marking and tracking host cells that directly interact with parasites, even if the interaction is transient. We found that Toxoplasma shows a strong predilection for interacting with neurons throughout CNS infection. This predilection remains in the setting of IFN-γ depletion; infection with parasites resistant to the major mechanism by which murine astrocytes clear parasites; or when directly injecting parasites into the brain. These findings suggest that neurons are not incidentally infected, but rather they are Toxoplasma’s primary in vivo target.
Actin-myosin contractility plays a crucial role in the motility of cells undergoing lamellipodial motility. A minimal free-boundary model of actin-myosin contractility has been systematically explored to understand the mechanical states of the simplest motile cell. The model accounts for isotropic contraction proportional to myosin density, viscous stresses in the actin network, and constant-strength viscous-like adhesion. The contraction generates a spatially graded centripetal actin flow, which in turn reinforces the contraction via myosin redistribution and causes retraction of the lamellipodial boundary. Actin protrusion at the boundary counters the retraction, and the balance of protrusion and retraction shapes the lamellipodium. The model analysis shows that initiation of motility critically depends on three dimensionless parameter combinations, which represent myosin-dependent contractility, a characteristic viscosity-adhesion length, and a rate of actin protrusion. When the contractility is sufficiently strong, cells break symmetry and move steadily along either straight or circular trajectories, and the motile behavior is sensitive to conditions at the cell boundary.
Understanding protein-protein interaction ( PPI ) networks is a major challenge in the post-genomic era. High-throughput methods such as yeast-2-hybrid ( Y2H ), tandem affinity purification ( TAP ), and mass spectrometric protein complex identification ( HMS-PCI ) have generated large amounts of PPI data. However, these data have high levels of noise and incompleteness. For example, Y2H screens have a false positive rate of up to 64% and a false negative rate of 43%–71%, while TAP experiments have comparable levels of noise. We present a novel technique to assess the confidence levels of interactions in PPI networks and predict new interactions. Our approach is based on geometric graphs, the best fitting network model for PPI networks, and achieves specificity of 85% and sensitivity of 90%. We apply our technique to the human PPI network and predict 251 interactions, a statistically significant fraction of which correspond to protein pairs sharing common GO terms. We validate a statistically significant portion of our predicted interactions in the HPRD database and the newer release of BioGRID.
Myotonic dystrophy type 1 ( DM1 ) is a human neurodegenerative disease caused by non-coding CTG repeat expansions in the DMPK gene. In addition to the sense expanded-repeat transcript, anti-sense expanded-repeat transcripts may also contribute to disease pathogenesis. We established a Drosophila model for DM1 to investigate the role of interactions between expanded CTG and CAG repeat transcripts. We found that co-expression of CTG and CAG expanded repeats resulted in dramatically enhanced toxicity in flies. This toxicity was accompanied by the generation of dcr-2 and ago2-dependent 21-nt triplet repeat-derived siRNAs. These small RNAs targeted the expression of CAG-containing genes, such as Ataxin-2 and TATA binding protein ( TBP ), which bear long CAG repeats in both fly and man. These findings indicate that the generation of triplet repeat-derived siRNAs may dramatically enhance toxicity in human repeat expansion diseases in which anti-sense transcription occurs.
Pectobacterium wasabiae SCC3193 is a model soft rot phytopathogen that was originally isolated from a diseased potato stem in Finland in the early 1980s and was previously classified as Pectobacterium carotovorum. However, our study reveals that SCC3193 can now be more accurately classified as Pectobacterium wasabiae based on genomic and proteomic comparisons with other sequenced soft rot bacteria. Our phylogenetic analysis indicates that P. wasabiae has been present in potato fields worldwide, including Europe and possibly North America, for a long time. We identified novel virulence determinants of P. wasabiae, including a putative transcriptional regulator SirB, two partially redundant type VI secretion systems, and two horizontally acquired clusters ( Vic1 and Vic2 ) that contain predicted virulence genes. We also found that P. wasabiae lacks a type III secretion system that contributes to virulence in other soft rot species. Our study provides a solid basis for further investigation of the virulence, distribution, and phylogeny of soft rot bacteria.
Mitochondrial protein expression is known to vary depending on the cellular state. However, little is known about how nuclear-encoded mitochondrial proteins ( mt proteome ) change in response to mitochondrial DNA ( mtDNA ) depletion. In this study, we investigated the systemic alterations of mtDNA-depleted ( ρ0 ) mitochondria by using network analysis of gene expression data. We discovered that up-regulated and down-regulated proteins were organized into two predominant subnetworks that exhibited distinct biological processes. The down-regulated network modules are involved in typical mitochondrial functions, while up-regulated proteins are responsible for mtDNA repair and regulation of mt protein expression and transport. Furthermore, comparisons of proteome and transcriptome data revealed that ρ0 cells attempted to compensate for mtDNA depletion by modulating the coordinated expression/transport of mt proteins. Our results demonstrate that mt protein composition changed to remodel the functional organization of mitochondrial protein networks in response to dysfunctional cellular states.
In this study, we develop a method to deduce the kinetics of protein synthesis in vivo from the transition rates measured in vitro. We introduce the kinetic distance, a new concept that quantitatively compares the kinetics of a multistep process in different environments. The kinetic distance depends logarithmically on the transition rates and can be interpreted in terms of the underlying free energy barriers. We then minimize the kinetic distance between the in-vitro and in-vivo process, imposing the constraint that the deduced rates reproduce a known global property such as the overall in-vivo speed. We apply this method to protein synthesis by ribosomes, a key process of gene expression. We describe the process by a codon-specific Markov model with three reaction pathways, corresponding to the initial binding of cognate, near-cognate, and non-cognate tRNA. We determine all individual transition rates in vitro and predict the in-vivo rates by the constrained minimization procedure. We validate these rates by three independent sets of in-vivo data, obtained for codon-dependent translation speeds, codon-specific translation dynamics, and missense error frequencies. We find good agreement between theory and experiment without adjusting any fit parameter. The deduced in-vivo rates lead to smaller error frequencies than the known in-vitro rates, primarily by an improved initial selection of tRNA.
Helicobacter pylori is a bacterium that infects the stomach lining of humans and causes chronic gastritis, peptic ulcers, and gastric cancer. In this study, we estimated the short-term rates of mutation and recombination in H. pylori by sequencing an average of 39, 300 bp in 78 gene fragments from 97 isolates. These isolates included 34 pairs of sequential samples, which were sampled at intervals of 0. 25 to 10. 2 years, as well as single isolates from 29 individuals ( average age: 45 years ) from 10 families. We used Approximate Bayesian Computation to estimate the rates of mutation, recombination, mean length of recombination tracts, and average diversity in those tracts. Our results indicate that the short-term mutation rate is 1. 4×10−6 to 4. 5×10−6 per nucleotide per year and that three times as many substitutions are introduced by recombination as by mutation. The long-term mutation rate over millennia is 5–17-fold lower, partly due to the removal of non-synonymous mutations due to purifying selection.
Melanopsin, a photopigment found in a subset of retinal ganglion cells ( mRGCs ), is known to drive reflex light responses such as circadian photoentrainment and pupillomotor movements. However, until now, there has been no direct assessment of its contribution to conventional visual pathways. Using new reporter lines, we show that mRGC projections are much more extensive than previously thought and extend across the dorsal lateral geniculate nucleus ( dLGN ), the origin of thalamo-cortical projection neurons. We demonstrate that this input supports extensive physiological light responses in the dLGN and visual cortex in mice lacking rods and cones, a model of advanced retinal degeneration. Moreover, using chromatic stimuli to isolate melanopsin-derived responses in mice with an intact visual system, we reveal strong melanopsin input to the ∼40% of neurons in the LGN that show sustained activation to a light step. We show that this melanopsin input supports irradiance-dependent increases in the firing rate of these neurons. The implication that melanopsin is required to accurately encode stimulus irradiance is confirmed using melanopsin knockout mice. Our data establish melanopsin-based photoreception as a significant source of sensory input to the thalamo-cortical visual system, providing unique irradiance information and allowing visual responses to be retained even in the absence of rods and cones.
HIV-1 infection is associated with an early and profound depletion of mucosal memory CD4+ T cells, which play a crucial role in the regulation of isotype switching and transepithelial transport of antibodies. In this study, we investigated whether the depletion of CD4+ T cells in HIV-1-infected individuals results in altered humoral responses specific to antigens encountered at mucosal surfaces. We found that antiretroviral therapy-treated HIV-1-infected individuals exhibited elevated levels of total and antigen-specific IgM in intestinal secretions, reduced IgG/IgM and IgA/IgM ratios of antibodies specific to microbial and food antigens in intestinal secretions, and reduced IgG levels to antigens derived from Proteobacteria and Firmicutes in plasma. These findings indicate reduced competence of mucosal B cells for class switch recombination from IgM to other isotypes, limiting their capacity to react to changing antigenic variety in the gut lumen. The reduced availability of microbiota-specific IgA and IgG may be an important factor contributing to the translocation of microbial antigens across the intestinal mucosal barrier and their systemic dissemination that drives chronic inflammation in HIV-1-infected individuals. Furthermore, we found that HIV-1-infected individuals with low CD4+ T cell counts exhibited reduced levels of plasma IgG specific to antigens derived from Proteobacteria and Firmicutes.
Populations of species in ecosystems are often constrained by the availability of resources within their environment, leading to a balance between the growth of one population and the decline of others. Here, we propose and model a redistribution mechanism driven by abrupt and severe reduction in the size of a single species, freeing up resources for the remaining ones. This mechanism may be relevant for communities of bacteria, with strain-specific collapses caused by invading bacteriophages, or for other ecosystems where infectious diseases play an important role. The emergent dynamics of our system is characterized by cyclic ‘‘diversity waves’’ triggered by collapses of globally dominating populations. The population diversity peaks at the beginning of each wave and exponentially decreases afterwards. Species abundances have a bimodal time-aggregated distribution with the lower peak formed by populations of recently collapsed or newly introduced species and the upper peak formed by species that have not yet collapsed in the current wave. This self-organized hierarchical peak structure has a long-term memory transmitted across several waves, giving rise to a scale-free tail of the time-aggregated population distribution with a universal exponent of 1. 7. We show that diversity wave dynamics is robust with respect to variations in the rules of our model such as diffusion between multiple environments, species-specific growth and extinction rates, and bet-hedging strategies.
Chemotactic movement of Escherichia coli is one of the most well-studied paradigms of simple behavior. Bacteria follow gradients by performing temporal comparisons of chemoeffector concentrations along their runs, a strategy which is most efficient given their size and swimming speed. The chemotaxis system is expected to be strongly optimized due to the significant competitive advantage it confers and the high evolution rates in bacteria. The regulation of tumble probability is commonly assumed to be the only navigation mechanism of chemotactic E. coli. However, we predict the existence of an additional mechanism of gradient navigation in E. coli using computer simulations. We suggest that not only the tumbling probability but also the degree of reorientation during a tumble depend on the swimming direction along the gradient. The difference in mean tumbling angles up and down the gradient is small, but it results in a dramatic enhancement of the cellular drift velocity along the gradient. We thus demonstrate a new level of optimization in E. coli chemotaxis, which arises from the switching of several flagellar motors and a resulting fine tuning of tumbling angle. Similar strategy is likely to be used by other peritrichously flagellated bacteria, and indicates yet another level of evolutionary development of bacterial chemotaxis.
Thymic medullary epithelial cells ( mTECs ) play a crucial role in establishing central tolerance by expressing self-peptides that delete autoreactive thymocytes or divert them into the regulatory T cell lineage. In addition to the NFκB signaling pathway, we show that Stat3-mediated signaling also plays a key role in mTEC development and homeostasis. We demonstrate that Stat3 activation promotes mTEC survival and is essential for optimal medullary region development and homeostasis. In contrast, conditional deletion of Stat3 disrupts medullary region architecture and reduces mTEC cellularity. Stat3 signaling does not affect mTEC proliferation, but rather promotes survival of immature MHCIIloCD80lo mTEC precursors. We show that targeting a constitutively active Stat3 transgene to the mTEC compartment increases mTEC cellularity and expands the thymic medulla. Conversely, conditional deletion of Stat3 in mTECs reduces mTEC cellularity and impairs medullary region formation. These results demonstrate that in addition to the NFκB pathway, Stat3-mediated signals play an essential role in regulating mTEC cellularity and medullary region homeostasis.
Clostridium difficile is an emergent pathogen and the most common cause of nosocomial diarrhea. In an effort to understand the role of small noncoding RNAs ( sRNAs ) in C. difficile physiology and pathogenesis, we used an in silico approach to identify 511 sRNA candidates in both intergenic and coding regions. RNA–seq and differential 5′-end RNA–seq were used for global identification of C. difficile sRNAs and their transcriptional start sites at three different growth conditions ( exponential growth phase, stationary phase, and starvation ). This approach identified 251 putative regulatory sRNAs, including 94 potential trans riboregulators, 91 cis-antisense RNAs, and 66 riboswitches. Expression of 35 sRNAs was confirmed by gene-specific experimental approaches. Some sRNAs showed growth phase-dependent expression profiles, including an antisense RNA that may be involved in control of C. difficile autolytic activity. Expression of 16 predicted c-di-GMP-responsive riboswitches was observed, and experimental evidence for their regulatory role in coordinated control of motility and biofilm formation was obtained. We also detected abundant sRNAs encoded by multiple C. difficile CRISPR loci, which may be important for C. difficile survival in bacteriophage-rich gut communities.
Hepatitis C virus ( HCV ) core protein downregulates the abundance of the liver-specific microRNA miR-122 by promoting its destabilization via the inhibition of GLD-2, a non-canonical cytoplasmic poly ( A ) polymerase. The decrease in miR-122 expression results in the dysregulation of its known functions, including its proviral activity for HCV. We found that the 22-nucleotide ( nt ) prototype miR-122 is modified at its 3′ end by 3′-terminal non-templated and templated nucleotide additions. The proportion of miR-122 isomers bearing a single nucleotide tail of any ribonucleotide decreases in liver specimens from patients with HCV. These single-nucleotide-tailed miR-122 isomers display increased miRNA activity and stability over the 22-nt prototype miR-122 and are catalyzed by the unique terminal nucleotidyl transferase activity of GLD-2. The HCV core protein specifically inhibits GLD-2, and its interaction with GLD-2 in the cytoplasm is responsible for miR-122 downregulation. Inhibition of GLD-2 by the HCV core protein affects multiple miRNAs in addition to miR-122 by decreasing the proportion of mono-adenylated isomers.
Trypanosomes cause disease in humans and livestock in sub-Saharan Africa, but there has been no evidence of acquired immunity to natural infections until now. We discovered a peak and decrease in age prevalence of Trypanosoma brucei s. l. infection in wild African lions that is consistent with an exposure-dependent increase in cross-immunity following infections with the more genetically diverse species, Trypanosoma congolense s. l. The causative agent of human sleeping sickness, Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense, disappears by 6 years of age apparently in response to cross-immunity from other trypanosomes, including the non-pathogenic subspecies, Trypanosoma brucei brucei. This is the first epidemiological evidence consistent with the development of acquired immunity to trypanosomes in any host species. It is unlikely that some hitherto unknown aspect of innate immunity is responsible for the peak and drop in age-prevalence, because this pattern is only seen in Trypanosoma brucei and not in Trypanosoma congolense. Instead, our observations are consistent with acquired immunity being mounted against Trypanosoma congolense s. l., which allows lions to clear most infections of Trypanosoma brucei s. l. by 3–5 years of age and to eliminate all infections of Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense by the age of 6 years.
The role of mechanistic mathematical modeling and systems biology in molecular medicine and clinical development remains uncertain. In this study, we used mathematical modeling and sensitivity analysis to explore the hypothesis that mechanistic models of human cascades, despite model uncertainty, can be computationally screened for points of fragility, and that these sensitive mechanisms could serve as therapeutic targets. We developed and validated a model of the coagulation cascade, composed of 92 proteins and 148 protein–protein interactions, using 21 published datasets generated from two different quiescent in vitro coagulation models. Simulated platelet activation and thrombin generation profiles in the presence and absence of natural anticoagulants were consistent with measured values, with a mean correlation of 0. 87 across all trials. Overall state sensitivity coefficients, which measure the robustness or fragility of a given mechanism, were calculated using a Monte Carlo strategy. In the absence of anticoagulants, fluid and surface phase factor X/activated factor X ( fX/FXa ) activity and thrombin-mediated platelet activation were found to be fragile, while fIX/FIXa and fVIII/FVIIIa activation and activity were robust. These results support our hypothesis that computationally derived points of fragility of human relevant cascades could be used as a rational basis for target selection despite model uncertainty.
Bacteriophages are viruses that infect bacteria and have been proposed as antimicrobial agents for the control of pathogenic and other problem bacteria. However, successful application of phage therapy requires a good understanding of the non-linear kinetics of phage–bacteria interactions. Here, we combine experimental and modelling approaches to make a detailed examination of such kinetics for the important food-borne pathogen Campylobacter jejuni and a suitable virulent phage in an in vitro system. We find that phage-insensitive populations of C. jejuni arise readily and that even a simple model fits the data surprisingly well. We confirm that the so-called inundation and proliferation thresholds are likely to be of considerable practical importance to phage therapy. We fit the model to time series data in order to estimate thresholds and rate constants directly. A comparison of the fit for each culture reveals density-dependent features of phage infectivity that are worthy of further investigation. Our results illustrate how insight from empirical studies can be greatly enhanced by the use of kinetic models: such combined studies of in vitro systems are likely to be an essential precursor to building a meaningful picture of the kinetic properties of in vivo phage therapy.
Schistosomiasis is a devastating disease caused by parasitic flatworms of the genus Schistosoma that affects over 260 million people worldwide, especially in tropical and sub-tropical regions. The snail Biomphalaria glabrata acts as an obligate intermediate host for Schistosoma mansoni, the causative agent of intestinal schistosomiasis in Africa and South America. Here, we report the first functional characterization of a snail Toll-like receptor, BgTLR, which plays an important role in the cellular immune response of B. glabrata following challenge with S. mansoni. BgTLR was identified as part of a peptide screen of snail immune cell surface proteins that differed in abundance between B. glabrata snails that differ in their compatibility phenotype to challenge by S. mansoni. The S. mansoni-resistant strain of B. glabrata ( BS-90 ) displayed higher levels of BgTLR compared to the susceptible ( M-line ) strain. Transcript expression of BgTLR was found to be very responsive in BS-90 snails when challenged with S. mansoni, increasing 27 fold relative to β-actin. Knockdown of BgTLR in BS-90 snails via targeted siRNA oligonucleotides resulted in a significant alteration of the resistant phenotype, yielding patent infections in 43% of the normally resistant snails.
Aedes aegypti and Aedes polynesiensis mosquitoes are major vectors of infectious diseases in French Polynesia, including dengue, chikungunya, Zika, and Bancroftian filariasis. To assess the risk of disease transmission and evaluate the efficacy of vector control programmes, we developed an ELISA test to detect and quantify the presence of immunoglobulin G ( IgG ) directed against proteins from salivary gland extracts ( SGE ) of Ae. aegypti and Ae. polynesiensis in human populations. We conducted a cross-sectional study in Tahiti and Moorea islands, where both mosquito species are present, and found that 98% and 68% of individuals have developed IgG directed against Ae. aegypti and Ae. polynesiensis SGE, respectively. In contrast, 97% of individuals from metropolitan France, not exposed to these Aedes mosquitoes, had no IgG directed against SGE of either mosquito species. We also found no ELISA IgG cross-reactivity between Ae. aegypti and Ae. polynesiensis SGE, indicating that the IgG response to salivary gland extracts is a valid and specific biomarker of human exposure to the bites of Ae. aegypti and Ae. polynesiensis. This new immuno-epidemiological tool will enhance our understanding of human exposure to mosquito bites, facilitate the identification of areas where disease transmission risk is high, and permit the evaluation of the efficacy of novel vector control strategies in Pacific islands and other tropical settings.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( Mtb ) pathogenicity is linked to its ability to adapt to the intracellular environment of human macrophages. We investigated how Mtb infection influences the metabolic pathways of the host macrophage by examining time-dependent modulations in macrophage metabolism after infection with mycobacterial strains of varying virulence. Our results show that Mtb pathogenicity is intimately linked to its capacity to regulate host cell metabolism, and that this process is controlled at the level of host cell metabolism. We identified a core subset of host reactions that are targeted by Mtb, and found that the goal of regulation is to integrate pathways that facilitate macrophage survival with those that promote mycobacterial sustenance. This integration of host- and pathogen-derived factors defines determinants of pathogenicity. We also found that the requirement for macrophage survival sensitizes TB susceptibility to the glycemic status of the individual, and that mediation by the pathogen ensures that the virulence properties of the infecting strain contribute to the resulting pathology.
Crossover recombination and the formation of chiasmata are essential for the proper segregation of homologous chromosomes during the first meiotic division. We show that ZHP-3, the Caenorhabditis elegans ortholog of the budding yeast ZIP3 gene, is required for crossover recombination. ZHP-3 protein localization is highly dynamic and shifts from along the length of the synaptonemal complex ( SC ) to an asymmetric localization on the SC and eventually becomes restricted to foci that mark crossover recombination events. A zhp-3::gfp transgene partially complements a null mutation and reveals a separation of function; although the fusion protein can promote nearly wild-type levels of recombination, aneuploidy among the progeny is high, indicating defects in meiotic chromosome segregation. The structure of bivalents is perturbed in this mutant, suggesting that the chromosome segregation defect results from an inability to properly remodel chromosomes in response to crossovers. We propose that coordination of crossover recombination with SC disassembly and bivalent formation reflects a conserved role of Zip3/ZHP-3 in coupling recombination with SC morphogenesis.
Aedes albopictus, a tropical mosquito species, has become a public health concern in temperate regions of Europe and the US due to its ability to transmit exotic arboviruses and cause severe nuisance problems. In this study, we investigated the effects of eco-climatic factors on the abundance and dynamics of Ae. albopictus in metropolitan and sub-urban/rural sites in Rome, Italy, which was colonized in 1997 and is now one of the most infested metropolitan areas in Southern Europe. We conducted longitudinal adult mosquito monitoring along a 70 km transect across and beyond the metropolitan area and analyzed the effect of climatic and socio-environmental variables on Ae. albopictus abundance and dynamics using two fine scale spatiotemporal datasets. Our results showed that Ae. albopictus abundance was associated with highly anthropized habitats in both metropolitan and sub-urban/rural areas, with “small green islands” corresponding to hot spots of abundance in the metropolitan areas only. We also found a bimodal seasonal dynamics with a second peak of abundance in autumn, due to heavy rains occurring in the preceding weeks in association with permissive temperatures.
Phthiocerol dimycocerosates ( DIM ), major virulence factors of Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( Mtb ), play a key role in the early step of infection when Mtb encounters host macrophages. Using Mtb mutants deleted for genes involved in DIM biosynthesis, we demonstrated that DIM participate both in the receptor-dependent phagocytosis of Mtb and the prevention of phagosomal acidification. The effects of DIM required a state of the membrane fluidity, as demonstrated by experiments conducted with cholesterol-depleting drugs that abolished the differences in phagocytosis efficiency and phagosome acidification observed between wild-type and mutant strains. The insertion of a new cholesterol-pyrene probe in living cells demonstrated that the polarity of the membrane hydrophobic core changed upon contact with Mtb, whereas the lateral diffusion of cholesterol was unaffected. This effect was dependent on DIM and was consistent with the effect observed following DIM insertion in model membranes. Therefore, we propose that DIM control the invasion of macrophages by Mtb by targeting lipid organisation in the host membrane, thereby modifying its biophysical properties. The DIM-induced changes in lipid ordering favour the efficiency of receptor-mediated phagocytosis of Mtb and contribute to the control of phagosomal pH driving bacilli in a protective niche.
The mean-field approximation is a powerful tool for studying large neural networks, but it fails to describe the behavior of small networks composed of a few tens of neurons. Here, we develop a novel systematic analysis of the dynamics of arbitrarily small networks composed of homogeneous populations of excitatory and inhibitory firing-rate neurons. We study the local bifurcations of their neural activity with an approach that is largely analytically tractable, and we numerically determine the global bifurcations. We find that for strong inhibition, these networks give rise to very complex dynamics, caused by the formation of multiple branching solutions of the neural dynamics equations that emerge through spontaneous symmetry-breaking. This qualitative change of the neural dynamics is a finite-size effect of the network, revealing qualitative and previously unexplored differences between mesoscopic cortical circuits and their mean-field approximation. The most important consequence of spontaneous symmetry-breaking is the ability of mesoscopic networks to regulate their degree of functional heterogeneity, which is thought to help reducing the detrimental effect of noise correlations on cortical information processing.
Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by the parasite Leishmania, transmitted by the bite of an infected sandfly. In this study, we investigated the presence of Leishmania in extralesional tissues of patients with active dermal leishmaniasis. Extralesional tissues include blood monocytes, tonsils, and normal skin, which are not directly affected by the disease. We used a molecular marker called Leishmania 7SLRNA to determine the viability and burden of Leishmania in these tissues. Our results show that viable parasites are present in extralesional tissues, including blood monocytes, tonsils, and normal skin of dermal leishmaniasis patients. We detected Leishmania 7SLRNA genes or transcripts in 100% and 73% of patients, respectively, in one or more extralesional tissues. The copy number of 7SLRNA transcripts was correlated with the dose and time dependent reduction of parasite viability in response to the drug Glucantime, substantiating the validity of this target as a marker of viability. We also detected 7SLRNA transcripts in 68% of monocyte samples, 42% of tonsil swabs, 36% of normal skin aspirates, and 88% of lesions. These results demonstrate that Leishmania 7SLRNA is an informative target for clinical and epidemiologic investigations of human leishmaniasis.
Chromatin features, such as histone modifications ( HMs ) and chromatin binding proteins ( CBPs ), play a fundamental role in regulating DNA replication timing in metazoans. However, no individual HM is strictly indispensable for origin function, suggesting that HMs may act combinatorially in analogy to the histone code hypothesis for transcriptional regulation. Here, we investigated the combinatorial potential of HMs and CBPs for predicting DNA replication timing in Drosophila using quantitative statistical models. We found that while combinations of CBPs exhibit moderate predictive power for replication timing, pairwise interactions between HMs lead to accurate predictions genome-wide that can be locally further improved by CBPs. We developed a simplified, biologically interpretable model of the relationship between chromatin landscape and replication timing that reaches 80% of the full model accuracy using six model terms. We also show that pairwise combinations of HMs are able to predict differential DNA replication timing across different cell types. Our results provide support to the existence of combinatorial HM patterns for DNA replication and reveal cell-type independent key elements thereof, whose experimental investigation might contribute to elucidate the regulatory mode of this fundamental cellular process.
Dengue virus serotypes 1–3 are responsible for 390 million infections and at least 25, 000 deaths annually, with the largest disease burden in tropical and subtropical regions. In Brazil, we investigated the spatial dynamics of DENV-1, DENV-2 and DENV-3 by applying a statistical framework to complete genome sequences. We estimated that new lineages of all three serotypes were introduced within 7 to 10-year intervals, and were most likely to be imported from the Caribbean region to the North and Northeast regions of Brazil, then dispersing at a rate of approximately 0. 5 km/day. Joint statistical analysis of evolutionary, epidemiological and ecological data indicates that aerial transportation of humans and/or vector mosquitoes, rather than Aedes aegypti infestation rates or geographical distances, determines dengue virus spread in Brazil. We characterized the introduction, establishment and drivers of dengue virus spread in Brazil using a combination of genetic and epidemiological data. By applying a flexible phylogeographic approach to full genome sequences, our analyses strongly support a human role for the spread of DENV through aerial transportation of humans and/or mosquito vectors. Our investigation of DENV serotypes 1 to 3 spatiotemporal dispersal indicates distinct introductions and co-circulation of distinct serotypes and genotypes, highlights the impact of air traffic fluxes in the spatial spread of DENV within Brazil and shows that the introduction of new lineages is followed by epizootic amplifications in 7 to 10 year cycles.
Understanding how neural populations encode sensory information remains an important problem in neuroscience. Here we investigated how differences in the antagonistic center-surround receptive field ( RF ) organization across three parallel sensory maps in weakly electric fish influence correlations between the activities of electrosensory pyramidal neurons. Using a model based on known anatomical differences in RF center size and overlap, we initially predicted large differences in correlated activity across the maps. However, in vivo electrophysiological recordings showed that electrosensory pyramidal neurons across all three segments displayed nearly identical correlations. To explain this surprising result, we incorporated the effects of RF surround in our model. By systematically varying both the RF surround gain and size relative to that of the RF center, we found that multiple RF structures gave rise to similar levels of correlation. In particular, incorporating known physiological differences in RF structure between the three maps in our model gave rise to similar levels of correlation. Our results show that RF center overlap alone does not determine correlations, which has important implications for understanding how RF structure influences correlated neural activity.
In this paper, we investigate how noise correlations between pairs of neurons impact the population's ability to encode a stimulus. We consider a general mathematical setup in which we vary noise correlations while keeping all other aspects of the problem fixed. Our results provide general insights into the problem of population coding. We show that if noise correlations between pairs of neurons have opposite signs compared to their signal correlations, then coding performance will improve compared to the independent case. This holds for three different metrics of coding performance, and for arbitrary tuning curves and levels of heterogeneity. We dub this the “sign rule” ( SR ). However, we also show that the SR does not provide a necessary condition for good coding, and that a diverse set of correlation structures can improve coding. Many of these correlation structures violate the SR, as do experimentally observed correlations. We prove that the optimal correlation structures must lie on boundaries of the possible set of noise correlations. Finally, we provide a novel set of necessary and sufficient conditions under which the coding performance will be as good as it would be if there were no noise present at all.
Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa frequently co-infect patients, leading to treatment failure and significant morbidity and mortality. However, the impact of P. aeruginosa on S. aureus antibiotic susceptibility remains poorly understood. In this study, we demonstrate that P. aeruginosa alters S. aureus susceptibility to bactericidal antibiotics in a variable, strain-dependent manner. We find that P. aeruginosa LasA endopeptidase potentiates lysis of S. aureus by vancomycin, rhamnolipids facilitate proton-motive force-independent tobramycin uptake, and 2-heptyl-4-hydroxyquinoline N-oxide ( HQNO ) induces multidrug tolerance in S. aureus through respiratory inhibition and reduction of cellular ATP. The production of each of these factors varies between clinical isolates and corresponds to the capacity of each isolate to alter S. aureus antibiotic susceptibility. Furthermore, we demonstrate that vancomycin treatment of a S. aureus mouse burn infection is potentiated by the presence of a LasA-producing P. aeruginosa population. These findings demonstrate that antibiotic susceptibility is complex and dependent not only upon the genotype of the pathogen being targeted, but also on interactions with other microorganisms in the infection environment.
Dengue virus ( DENV ) infection is associated with thrombocytopenia and platelet dysfunction, which may contribute to complications such as bleeding and plasma leakage. We investigated the mechanisms of platelet clearance in patients with dengue and their relationship with thrombocytopenia and platelet reactivity. In two observational cohort studies in Indonesia, we found that patients with dengue had higher plasma concentrations of von Willebrand factor ( VWF ) antigen and active VWF, and that circulating platelets had bound more VWF to their membrane. The amount of platelet-VWF binding correlated well with platelet count. Furthermore, sialic acid levels in dengue patients were significantly reduced as assessed by the binding of Sambucus nigra lectin ( SNA ) and Maackia amurensis lectin II ( MAL-II ) to platelets. Platelet sialylation was also not altered by in vitro exposure of platelets to DENV nonstructural protein 1 or cultured DENV. In contrast, induction of binding of VWF to glycoprotein 1b on platelets using the VWF-activating protein ristocetin resulted in the removal of platelet sialic acid by translocation of platelet neuraminidase to the platelet surface. The neuraminidase inhibitor oseltamivir reduced VWF-induced platelet desialylation. Our data demonstrate that excessive binding of VWF to platelets in dengue results in neuraminidase-mediated platelet desialylation and platelet clearance, and that oseltamivir might be a novel treatment option for severe thrombocytopenia in dengue infection.
In this study, we identified the most complete collection of human transcripts under the control of bidirectional promoters using a database of spliced-expressed sequence tags ( ESTs ). A bidirectional promoter is a regulatory region between two adjacent genes whose transcription start sites are directed away from each other. These promoters are often associated with genes that function in DNA repair and have the potential to participate in the development of cancer. We show that there is a highly significant enrichment of bidirectional promoters in genes implicated in somatic cancer, including a substantial number of genes implicated in breast and ovarian cancers. Using microarray expression data from 79 human tissues, we verified regulatory networks among genes controlled by bidirectional promoters. We found that subsets of these promoters contain similar combinations of transcription factor binding sites, including evolutionarily conserved ETS factor binding sites in ERBB2, FANCD2, and BRCA2. This suggests that bidirectional promoters could regulate co-expression patterns among groups of genes. We also show that a subset of these promoters, which regulate genes implicated in breast and ovarian cancers, contain transcription factor binding sites in common.
Diptera, the order of flies that includes the model organism Drosophila melanogaster, generally have a conserved karyotype consisting of six chromosomal arms. However, our analysis of 37 fly species belonging to 22 different families of Diptera reveals tremendous hidden diversity in sex chromosome karyotypes. We identify over a dozen different sex chromosome configurations, including species with undifferentiated sex chromosomes, species in which a different chromosome replaced the dot as a sex chromosome, and species in which up to three chromosomal elements became incorporated into the sex chromosomes. We also identify species with female heterogamety ( ZW sex chromosomes ). Transcriptome analysis shows that dosage compensation has evolved multiple times in flies, consistently through up-regulation of the single X in males. We find that X chromosomes generally show a deficiency of genes with male-biased expression, possibly reflecting sex-specific selective pressures. Our data suggest that sex chromosomes have been lost, gained, rearranged or replaced multiple times over the course of Diptera evolution.
Zika virus ( ZIKV ) is an emerging mosquito-borne pathogen that has been linked to severe fetal abnormalities, including microcephaly, spontaneous abortion, stillbirth, and hydranencephaly. Between 2009 and 2012, we investigated the presence of ZIKV IgM and IgG antibodies in archived blood samples from six mothers who gave birth to babies with microcephaly and 12 mothers who gave birth to healthy babies in Hawaii. We used commercially available human ZIKV IgM and IgG ELISA kits to test for the presence of ZIKV antibodies. We found that blood from one mother who delivered a baby with microcephaly tested positive for ZIKV IgM antibody ( 16. 6% ) and blood from three mothers tested positive for ZIKV IgG antibody ( 50% ). ZIKV IgG antibody positive mothers were more likely to deliver babies with microcephaly than mothers who were negative for ZIKV IgG antibodies ( Odds ratio [OR] = 11. 0, 95% confidence interval [CI] = 0. 8–147. 9, p = 0. 083 ). Similarly, ZIKV IgM antibody positive mothers were also more likely to deliver babies with microcephaly than mothers who were negative for ZIKV IgM antibody ( OR = 6. 8, 95% CI = 0. 2–195. 1, p = 0. 333 ). These data provide further evidence of a link between ZIKV infection and microcephaly and suggest the presence of ZIKV positive cases and associated microcephaly in the United States as early as 2009.
Mycobacterium ulcerans ( MU ) is the causative agent of Buruli ulcer ( BU ), a disease endemic in the Ashanti region of Ghana. In this study, we used Variable Number Tandem Repeat ( VNTR ) typing to source-track MU infections to specific water bodies. We collected environmental samples from 10 water bodies in four BU endemic communities in the Ashanti region, Ghana, and compared them to MU isolates from 14 confirmed BU patients within the same study area. Four VNTR loci in the MU Agy99 genome were used to genotype environmental MU ecovars and those from human samples. Length polymorphism was confirmed with sequencing. We found that MU was present in different types of water bodies, but significantly higher in biofilm samples. Four MU genotypes, designated W, X, Y, and Z, were typed in both human and environmental samples. Other reported genotypes were only found in water bodies. Our findings suggest that patients may have been infected from community-associated water bodies. We also present evidence that small mammals within endemic communities could be susceptible to MU infections.
The global distribution and drivers of alien bird species richness remain poorly understood. Here, we present the first global analysis of the determinants of alien species richness that takes into account colonisation pressure. Our study uses a database of 27, 723 distribution records for 971 alien bird species worldwide. We show that the locations of origin and introduction of alien birds, and their identities, were initially driven largely by European ( mainly British ) colonialism. However, recent introductions are a wider phenomenon, involving more species and countries, and driven in part by increasing economic activity. We find that, globally, alien bird species richness is currently highest at midlatitudes and is strongly determined by anthropogenic effects, most notably the number of species introduced ( i. e., “colonisation pressure” ). Nevertheless, environmental drivers are also important, with native and alien species richness being strongly and consistently positively associated. Our results demonstrate that colonisation pressure is key to understanding alien species richness, show that areas of high native species richness are not resistant to colonisation by alien species at the global scale, and emphasise the likely ongoing threats to global environments from introductions of species.
Upstream Binding Factor ( UBF ) is a multi-HMGB-box protein involved in RNA polymerase I ( RPI/PolI ) transcription of ribosomal RNA ( rRNA ) genes. We show that UBF is essential for rRNA gene transcription and defines the active chromatin conformation of both gene and enhancer sequences. UBF is required for the formation of the SL1/TIF1B pre-initiation complex and recruitment of the RPI-Rrn3/TIF1A complex. Loss of UBF is accompanied by recruitment of H3K9me3, canonical histone H1 and HP1α, but not by de novo DNA methylation. Genes retain penta-acetyl H4 and H2A. Z, suggesting that even in the absence of UBF the rRNA genes can maintain a potentially active state. In contrast to canonical histone H1, binding of H1. 4 is dependent on UBF. Unexpectedly, arrest of rRNA synthesis does not suppress transcription of the 5S, tRNA or snRNA genes, nor expression of the several hundred mRNA genes implicated in ribosome biogenesis. Loss of UBF also induces the formation of a large sub-nuclear structure resembling the nucleolar precursor body ( NPB ) of oocytes and early embryos. These somatic NPBs contain rRNA synthesis and processing factors but do not associate with the rRNA gene loci ( NORs ).
Wingless/Wnt signaling plays a critical role in tissue patterning and cell fate specification in metazoans. In the adult Drosophila intestine, Wingless ( Wg ) signaling gradients coincide with all major boundaries between compartments. We find that the critical roles of Wg during adult intestinal development, including regulation of target gene activation, boundary formation, stem cell proliferation, epithelial cell fate specification, muscle differentiation, gut folding, and signaling crosstalk with the Decapentaplegic ( Dpp ) pathway, are all disrupted by Wg tethering. This indicates that Wg secretion and movement are critical for proper Wg pathway activation during adult gut development. In contrast to the larval wing disc, the adult gut forms through distinct developmental mechanisms that arise during metamorphosis, and faces different functional demands throughout life, including the ability of its epithelium to continuously turnover during homeostasis and to regenerate following injury. Our findings provide new evidence that supports the requirement for the direct, long-range action of Wg in tissue patterning, with relevance for animal development, tissue homeostasis, and Wnt-driven disease.
Streptococcus pyogenes (GAS) is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The ability of GAS to accumulate plasmin at the cell surface is a key process in invasive disease initiation. However, the role of host activators of plasminogen in this process is poorly understood. Here, we demonstrate that the urokinase-type plasminogen activator (uPA) contributes to plasmin recruitment and subsequent invasive disease initiation in vivo. In the absence of a source of host plasminogen activators, streptokinase was required to facilitate cell surface plasmin acquisition by GAS. However, in the absence of streptokinase, host activators were sufficient to promote cell surface plasmin acquisition by GAS strain 5448 during incubation with plasminogen or human plasma. Furthermore, GAS were able to mediate a significant increase in the activation of zymogen pro-uPA in human plasma. In order to assess the contribution of uPA to invasive GAS disease, a previously undescribed transgenic mouse model of infection was employed. Both C57/black 6J and AlbPLG1 mice expressing the human plasminogen transgene were significantly more susceptible to invasive GAS disease than uPA−/− mice. The observed decrease in virulence in uPA−/− mice was found to correlate directly with a decrease in bacterial dissemination and reduced cell surface plasmin accumulation by GAS. These findings have significant implications for our understanding of GAS pathogenesis, and research aimed at therapeutic targeting of plasminogen activation in invasive bacterial infections.
Helicobacter pylori exploits a unique repertoire of type IV secretion system ( T4SS ) components for pilus assembly at the bacteria-host cell interface. The cag pathogenicity island ( cag PAI ) of H. pylori encodes components of a T4SS that translocates the bacterial oncoprotein CagA into gastric epithelial cells, and CagL is a specialized component of the cag T4SS that binds the host receptor α5β1 integrin. We utilized a mass spectrometry-based approach to reveal co-purification of CagL, CagI ( another integrin-binding protein ), and CagH ( a protein with weak sequence similarity to CagL ). These three proteins are encoded by contiguous genes in the cag PAI, and are detectable on the bacterial surface. All three proteins are required for CagA translocation into host cells and H. pylori-induced IL-8 secretion by gastric epithelial cells. Scanning electron microscopy analysis reveals that these proteins are involved in the formation of pili at the interface between H. pylori and gastric epithelial cells. A conserved C-terminal hexapeptide motif is present in CagH, CagI, and CagL. Deletion of these motifs results in abrogation of CagA translocation and IL-8 induction, and the C-terminal motifs of CagI and CagL are required for formation of pili.
Bovine tuberculosis ( bTB ) is a chronic disease of cattle caused by Mycobacterium bovis, a member of the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex group of bacteria. Vaccination of cattle might offer a long-term solution for controlling the disease. In this study, calves were vaccinated with BCG or with a heterologous BCG prime adenovirally vectored subunit boosting protocol and challenged with M. bovis to determine protective efficacy. RNA was prepared from PPD-stimulated PBMC from vaccinated-protected, vaccinated-unprotected and unvaccinated control cattle and global gene expression was determined by RNA-seq. A total of 668 genes were differentially expressed in vaccinated-protected cattle compared with vaccinated-unprotected and unvaccinated control cattle. Cytokine-cytokine receptor interaction was the most significant pathway related to this dataset with IL-22 expression identified as the dominant surrogate of protection besides INF-γ. The expression of these candidate genes was evaluated by RT-qPCR in an independent set of PBMC samples from BCG vaccinated and unvaccinated calves, confirming the importance of IL-22 as a predictor of vaccine efficacy.
γ-TuRC and AIR-1 are essential for microtubule nucleation at the centrosome in Caenorhabditis elegans, but their role at non-centrosomal microtubule organizing centers ( ncMTOCs ) is largely unknown. We used a tissue-specific degradation system to test the role of γ-TuRC and AIR-1 at the apical ncMTOC in C. elegans embryonic intestinal epithelial cells. We found that GIP-1, a core component of γ-TuRC, is required to recruit other γ-TuRC components, including MZT-1, to the apical ncMTOC. In contrast, AIR-1 and MZT-1 are specifically required to recruit γ-TuRC to the centrosome, but not to centrioles or to the apical ncMTOC. Surprisingly, microtubules remain robustly organized at the apical ncMTOC upon γ-TuRC and AIR-1 co-depletion, and upon depletion of other known microtubule regulators. However, loss of GIP-1 removes a subset of dynamic microtubules, and the remaining dynamic microtubules grow faster. These results suggest that different microtubule organizing centers use discrete proteins for their function, and that the apical ncMTOC is composed of distinct populations of γ-TuRC-dependent and -independent microtubules that compete for a limited pool of resources.
Genome phasing is the process of determining the parental origin of the two copies of each chromosome in a diploid human genome. Most human sequencing initiatives do not directly delineate the nucleotide content of the maternal and paternal copies of the 23 chromosomes individuals possess. We compared 11 different widely-used approaches to phasing human genomes using the publicly available ‘Genome-In-A-Bottle’ ( GIAB ) phased version of the NA12878 genome as a gold standard. The approaches included laboratory-based assays that prepare DNA in unique ways to facilitate phasing as well as purely computational approaches that seek to reconstruct phase information from general sequencing reads and constructs or population-level haplotype frequency information obtained through a reference panel of haplotypes. We found that a hybrid or combined approach that leverages population-based phasing using the SHAPEIT software suite, genome-wide sequencing read data, and a large reference panel of variant and haplotype frequencies provides a fast and efficient way to produce highly accurate phase-resolved individual human genomes. We also found that the inclusion of parental genotype data within a population-based phasing strategy can provide as much as a ten-fold reduction in phasing errors. Finally, we identified DNA sequence signatures associated with the genomic regions harboring phasing switch errors, which included regions of low polymorphism or SNV density.
Type-III protein secretion systems are used by gram-negative pathogens to secrete proteins into host cells. The flagellar type-III secretion apparatus utilizes both the proton motive force and ATP hydrolysis to energize substrate unfolding and translocation. However, we report that functional flagella can be formed in the absence of type-III ATPase activity by mutations that increase the proton motive force and flagellar substrate levels. We also show that increased proton motive force can bypass the requirement of the Salmonella pathogenicity island 1 virulence-associated type-III ATPase for secretion. Our data support a role for type-III ATPases in enhancing secretion efficiency under limited secretion substrate concentrations and reveal the dispensability of ATPase activity in the type-III protein export process. We demonstrate that type-III protein secretion can efficiently occur in the absence of ATPase activity in both flagellar and virulence-associated type-III secretion systems. We propose that the function of the T3SS-associated ATPase complex is to deliver secretion substrates to the export apparatus and ensure efficient substrate unfolding. Our findings have important implications for the evolution of the bacterial flagellum and type-III secretion systems.
Bistability plays a central role in the gene regulatory networks ( GRNs ) controlling many essential biological functions, including cellular differentiation and cell cycle control. However, establishing the network topologies that can exhibit bistability remains a challenge. To address this problem, we employed chemical reaction network theory in a comprehensive in silico survey to determine the capacity for bistability of more than 40, 000 simple networks that can be formed by two transcription factor-coding genes and their associated proteins. We find that there exist reaction rate constants leading to bistability in ∼90% of these GRN models, including several circuits that do not contain any of the TF cooperativity commonly associated with bistable systems. A topological sorting of the two-gene family of networks based on the presence or absence of biochemical reactions reveals eleven minimal bistable networks. The large number of previously unknown bistable network topologies suggests that the capacity for switch-like behavior in GRNs arises with relative ease and is not easily lost through network evolution. To highlight the relevance of the systematic application of CRNT to bistable network identification in real biological systems, we integrated publicly available protein-protein interaction, protein-DNA interaction, and gene expression data from Saccharomyces cerevisiae, and identified several GRNs predicted to behave in a bistable fashion.
Mutations in the HYAL2 gene, which encodes the enzyme hyaluronidase 2, have been identified as a cause of orofacial clefting and cor triatriatum sinister in humans and mice. Hyaluronidase 2 is responsible for degrading extracellular hyaluronan, a critical component of the developing heart and palatal shelf matrix. Mutations in the HYAL2 gene were found to destabilize the enzyme and dramatically reduce protein levels, leading to craniofacial abnormalities, including submucosal cleft palate and cor triatriatum sinister, in affected individuals and mice. In humans, orofacial clefting was identified in all but one affected individual, and craniofacial dysmorphism was a consistent finding. Conductive hearing loss was observed in most affected human subjects, while one individual had profound sensorineural hearing loss. In mice, cor triatriatum sinister and hearing loss were identified as incompletely penetrant features. Our findings highlight the importance of hyaluronidase enzymes for normal human and mouse development and reveal a previously unrecognized pathway involved in the pathogenesis of orofacial clefting, myopia, and cor triatriatum sinister in humans.
Hair cells in the inner ear are responsible for sound detection, and their mechanosensory function is mediated by tip links that interconnect stereocilia and convey force to transduction channels. Current models suggest that tip links have a static composition of protocadherin 15 ( PCDH15 ) at the lower end and cadherin 23 ( CDH23 ) at the upper end. However, we show that functional tip links have at least two molecular compositions: PCDH15/CDH23 and PCDH15/PCDH15. During regeneration, shorter tip links containing nearly equal amounts of PCDH15 at both ends appear first and mediate mechanotransduction currents of normal amplitude but abnormal Ca2+-dependent decay ( adaptation ). The mature PCDH15/CDH23 tip link composition is re-established later, concomitant with complete recovery of adaptation. Our findings provide a molecular mechanism for regeneration and maintenance of mechanosensory function in postmitotic auditory hair cells and could help identify elusive components of the mechanotransduction machinery.
Dengue virus ( DENV ) is the most prevalent arbovirus, causing an estimated 100 million symptomatic dengue infections every year. DENV can cause a spectrum of clinical manifestations, ranging from mild dengue fever ( DF ) to more life threatening forms such as dengue hemorrhagic fever ( DHF ). The mechanisms that trigger the transition from DF to DHF are not well understood. We performed a mass spectrometry-based metabolomic profiling of sera from adult DF and DHF patients at the critical and recovery phases of infection. We identified 29 differentially expressed metabolites between DF and DHF at the critical phase, including bile acids, purines, acylcarnitines, phospholipids, and amino acids. Bile acids were up to 5 fold higher in DHF patients compared to DF patients and correlated with liver injury. Uric acid, the most abundant antioxidant in the blood, was 1. 5 fold lower in DHF patients compared to DF patients. This could result in decreased capacity of endogenous antioxidant defense and elevated oxidative stress among DHF patients. In the recovery phase, the levels of eight metabolites were still significantly higher or lower among DHF patients, including chenodeoxyglycocholic acid, one of the bile acids observed at the critical phase. Our study identified altered metabolic pathways linked to DHF in the critical and recovery phases of dengue infection and provided insights into the different host and DENV interactions between DF and DHF.
Trypanosoma brucei, a causative protozoan parasite of African trypanosomiasis, has a unique guanosine 5’-monophosphate reductase ( GMPR ) that catalyzes the deamination of guanosine 5’-monophosphate ( GMP ) to inosine 5’-monophosphate ( IMP ). We identified the GMPR in T. brucei and characterized its recombinant protein to investigate the enzymatic differences between GMPRs of T. brucei and its host animals. We found that T. brucei GMPR has an insertion of a tandem repeat of the cystathionine β-synthase ( CBS ) domain, which is absent in mammalian and bacterial GMPRs. The recombinant protein of T. brucei GMPR catalyzed the conversion of GMP to IMP in the presence of NADPH, and showed apparent affinities for both GMP and NADPH different from those of its mammalian counterparts. Interestingly, the addition of monovalent cations such as K+ and NH4+ to the enzymatic reaction increased the GMPR activity of T. brucei, whereas none of the mammalian GMPR’s was affected by these cations. The monophosphate form of the purine nucleoside analog ribavirin inhibited T. brucei GMPR activity, though mammalian GMPRs showed no or only a little inhibition by it. These results suggest that the mechanism of the GMPR reaction in T. brucei is distinct from that in the host organisms. Finally, we demonstrated the inhibitory effect of ribavirin on the proliferation of trypanosomes in a dose-dependent manner, suggesting the availability of ribavirin to develop a new therapeutic agent against African trypanosomiasis.
Voltage-gated sodium channels are transmembrane proteins that initiate action potentials in excitable cells by allowing the rapid influx of sodium ions into the cell. Mutations and aberrant expression of sodium channels are responsible for a range of diseases including neuropathic pain, cardiac arrhythmia, and epilepsy. Sodium channel blockers are used to control electrical excitability in cells as a treatment for these diseases. To develop the next generation of drugs that can selectively target one of the nine types of voltage-gated sodium channels expressed in the body, a better understanding of how current channel blockers work is required. Here, we use molecular dynamics simulations to examine the route of entry and mechanism of binding in the bacterial voltage-gated sodium channel NavAb of two channel-blocking drugs: benzocaine and phenytoin. We show that both drugs have two likely binding sites in the pore characterised by nonspecific, hydrophobic interactions: one just above the activation gate, and one at the entrance to the lateral lipid-filled fenestrations. Our simulations highlight the importance of a number of residues in directing drugs into and through the fenestration, and in forming the drug binding sites. We also show that both drugs can pass through the fenestrations into the lipid with only small energy barriers, suggesting that this can represent the long posited hydrophobic entrance route for neutral drugs.
MyD88 signaling plays a critical role in the induction of protective host responses upon intestinal infection with the pathogen C. rodentium. Although MyD88-deficient mice are highly susceptible to infection, the cell type-specific contribution of MyD88 in protecting the host against intestinal bacterial infection has been poorly understood. We employed a novel murine knock-in model for MyD88 that enables the cell type-specific reactivation of functional MyD88 expression in otherwise MyD88-deficient mice to investigate the importance of MyD88 in specific immune and nonimmune cell types during intestinal infection. We found that functional MyD88 signaling in CD11c+ cells was sufficient to activate intestinal dendritic cells ( DC ) and to induce the early group 3 innate lymphoid cell ( ILC3 ) response as well as the development of colonic Th17/Th1 cells in response to infection with C. rodentium. In contrast, restricting MyD88 signaling to several other cell types, including macrophages ( MO ), T cells or ILC3 did not induce efficient intestinal immune responses upon infection. However, we observed that the functional expression of MyD88 in intestinal epithelial cells ( IEC ) also partially protected the mice during intestinal infection, which was associated with enhanced epithelial barrier integrity and increased expression of the antimicrobial peptide RegIIIγ and the acute phase protein SAA1 by epithelial cells. Together, our data suggest that MyD88 signaling in DC and IEC is both essential and sufficient to induce a full spectrum of host responses upon intestinal infection with C. rodentium.
Onchocerciasis is targeted for elimination in Africa through annual or biannual ivermectin mass drug administration ( MDA ). An immunodiagnostic test, based on the detection of human IgG4 antibodies in the blood to the Onchocerca volvulus-specific antigen Ov16, is one of the recommended tools for determining whether transmission is interrupted and mass treatment can stop. Mathematical modelling was used to explore the relationship between post-MDA Ov16 antibody prevalence in children ( measured 1 year after the last round of MDA ) and the duration and coverage of MDA, the mf prevalence in the population, and the probability that onchocerciasis is eventually eliminated. The ONCHOSIM model was extended with new output on the Ov16 antibody serostatus of individuals. Seroconversion was assumed to be triggered by the first worm establishing in the host, with seroconversion occurring either before maturation, after maturation or only after the start of mf production. We are mainly interested in seroconversion rates in children, and for now ignore the possibility of seroreversion to simplify the model. The results show that both the microfiladermia prevalence in the population aged 5 years and above and the Ov16 antibody prevalence in children under 10 declined with increasing duration of MDA. The association between either of these indicators and the model-predicted probability of elimination was not influenced much by the assumed treatment coverage levels, but was found to depend on baseline endemicity levels, assumptions regarding the trigger of seroconversion, and diagnostic test characteristics ( sensitivity and specificity ).
Prions are infectious proteins that can change their properties when propagated in different environments. When prions are grown in cells in the presence of an inhibitory drug, they can become resistant to the drug, and in some cases, they can even become dependent on the drug for propagation. This is because prions are composed of a range of variants with different properties, from which the fittest are selected in a particular environment. When prions are grown in cells in the presence of the drug swainsonine ( swa ), they can become resistant to the drug, and in some cases, they can even become dependent on the drug for propagation. For example, when swainsonine-sensitive 22L prions were grown in PK1 cells in the presence of swa, they became swainsonine-resistant. Similarly, when swainsonine-sensitive RML prions were grown in PK1 cells in the presence of swa, they became swainsonine-resistant and even swainsonine-dependent. The misfolded prion protein ( PrPSc ) associated with swainsonine-dependent variants was less rapidly cleared in PK1 cells than that associated with their drug-sensitive counterparts, indicating that structural differences of the misfolded PrP underlie the properties of the prions. These adaptations are most likely due to conformational changes of the abnormal prion protein.
Metabolism is one of the most ancient and fundamental evolving systems, sustaining life by extracting energy from extracellular nutrients.
