Here we study metabolism’s potential for innovation by analyzing an exhaustive genotype-phenotype map for a space of 1015 metabolisms that encodes all possible subsets of 51 reactions in central carbon metabolism. Using flux balance analysis, we predict the viability of these metabolisms on 10 different carbon sources which give rise to 1024 potential metabolic phenotypes. We find that although viable metabolisms with any one phenotype comprise a tiny fraction of genotype space, their absolute numbers exceed 109 for some phenotypes. Metabolisms with any one phenotype typically form a single network of genotypes that extends far or all the way through metabolic genotype space, where any two genotypes can be reached from each other through a series of single reaction changes. The minimal distance of genotype networks associated with different phenotypes is small, such that one can reach metabolisms with novel phenotypes – viable on new carbon sources – through one or few genotypic changes.
Trypanosoma cruzi is the causative agent of Chagas disease, a major public health problem in the Neotropics. Triatoma dimidiata is one of the main vectors of T. cruzi in Mexico. This study analyzed the genetic variation and phylogeography of T. dimidiata haplogroups across the Mexican Neotropics. We analyzed two contiguous fragments of the ND4 gene and found that the lowest genetic diversity of T. dimidiata occurs where there is greatest historical anthropic modification, and where T. cruzi infection prevalence is highest. T. cruzi prevalence was significantly higher than expected in haplogroups 1 and 3, while lower than expected in haplogroup 2. There was also a significant difference of DTUI and DTUVI infection frequencies in both haplogroups 1 and 3, while no difference of either in haplogroup 2. All haplogroups from the Mexican Neotropics had moderate to high haplotype diversity, while greatest genetic differentiation was between haplogroups 1 and 3 ( above FST = 0. 868, p < 0. 0001 ). Divergence of the complex from the MRCA was estimated between 0. 97 MYA ( 95% HPD interval = 0. 55–1. 53 MYA ) and 0. 85 MYA ( 95% HPD interval = 0. 42–1. 5 MYA ) for ND4A and both concatenated fragments, respectively, with primary divergence from the MRCA of haplogroups 2 and 3. This study supports previous ecological niche evidence for the complex´s origin surrounding the Tehuantepec Isthmus, and provides evidence for recent divergence of three primary dimidiata haplogroups, with differential T. cruzi infection frequency and DTU specificity, important components of vector capacity.
Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome ( HFRS ) is a rodent-borne infectious disease caused mainly by two hantaviruses in China: Hantaan virus ( HTNV ) and Seoul virus ( SEOV ). HFRS is clinically characterized by fever, hemorrhage, headache, back pain, abdominal pain, and acute kidney damage. The main hosts for SEOV are Rattus norvegicus, Rattus flavipectus, and Mus musculus, whereas Apodemus agrarius is the host for HTNV. Transmission of hantavirus to humans occurs via inhalation of aerosolized viral particles present in the urine, feces, and saliva excreted into the environment by rodents infected with it. In China, Hunan Province is one of the areas where HFRS is most highly endemic, with 6, 237 cases of HFRS diagnosed during 2006–2015. Chenzhou, a city with a subtropical climate in Hunan Province, is a typical hotspot for hantavirus infections.
Activating mutations in codon 12/13 of the HRAS proto-oncogene can cause Costello syndrome ( CS ), a congenital disease characterized by postnatal growth retardation, short stature, tumor predisposition, developmental delay, and abnormalities of the heart, skin, and skeletal muscles. The majority of CS cases ( 75% ) are caused by heterozygous c. 34G>A ( p. Gly12Ser ) activating mutations in HRAS. We identified a new germline p. Gly12Val mutation, c. 35_36GC>TG, in a 12-year-old boy with attenuated CS. Analysis of his HRAS cDNA showed high levels of exon 2 skipping. Using wild type and mutant HRAS minigenes, we confirmed that c. 35_36GC>TG results in exon 2 skipping by simultaneously disrupting the function of a critical Exonic Splicing Enhancer ( ESE ) and creating an Exonic Splicing Silencer ( ESS ). We show that this vulnerability of HRAS exon 2 is caused by a weak 3’ splice site, which makes exon 2 inclusion dependent on binding of splicing stimulatory proteins, like SRSF2, to the critical ESE. We demonstrate that the phenotype in CS and somatic cancers is not only determined by the different transforming potentials of mutant HRAS proteins, but also by the efficiency of exon 2 inclusion resulting from the different HRAS mutations. Finally, we show that a splice switching oligonucleotide ( SSO ) that blocks access to the critical ESE causes exon 2 skipping and halts proliferation of cancer cells.
Methyltransferase-like 3 ( METTL3 ) is a key factor in the formation of N6-methyladenosine ( m6A ) RNA methylation, the most abundant modification on mRNAs. Here, we show that specific inactivation of Mettl3 in the mouse nervous system causes severe developmental defects in the brain. Mettl3 conditional knockout ( cKO ) mice manifest cerebellar hypoplasia caused by drastically enhanced apoptosis of newborn cerebellar granule cells ( CGCs ) in the external granular layer ( EGL ). We found that METTL3 depletion–induced loss of m6A modification causes extended RNA half-lives and aberrant splicing events, leading to dysregulation of transcriptome-wide gene expression and premature CGC death. Our findings reveal a critical role of METTL3-mediated m6A in regulating the development of the mammalian cerebellum. We conclude that METTL3 is an essential regulator of cerebellar neurogenesis and development. Transcriptome-wide gene expression dysregulation induced by m6A depletion in the absence of METTL3 results in CGCs apoptosis and cerebellum hypoplasia.
Oct4, Sox2 and Nanog are transcription factors that are essential for maintaining the ability of embryonic stem ( ES ) cells to differentiate into any cell type of the developing embryo. In this study, we show that combinatorial binding of Oct4, Sox2 and Nanog is strongly associated with co-localization of the transcriptional co-activator Mediator, H3K27ac and increased expression of nearby genes in ES cells. We observe that the same loci bound by Oct4, Nanog and Sox2 in ES cells frequently drive expression in early embryonic development. Comparison of mouse and human ES cells shows that less than 5% of individual binding events for Oct4, Sox2 and Nanog are shared between species. However, about 15% of combinatorial binding events and 53% to 63% of combinatorial binding events at enhancers active in early development are conserved. Our data suggests that the combination of Oct4, Sox2 and Nanog binding is critical for transcription in ES cells and likely plays an important role for embryogenesis by binding at conserved early developmental enhancers.
Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is initiated by the AML1/ETO oncogenic transcription factor, which is generated by a reciprocal translocation involving chromosomes 8 and 21. AML1/ETO recruits co-repressor complexes to DNA and interferes with the function of its wild-type counterpart, AML1, by directly targeting AML1 binding sites. However, AML1/ETO also interacts with other transcription factors, such as E-proteins, and may target other sites on DNA. Genome-wide chromatin immunoprecipitation and expression profiling were used to identify AML1/ETO-dependent transcriptional regulation. AML1/ETO was found to co-localize with AML1 and the E-protein HEB on many of its regulated targets. Furthermore, the level of HEB protein was increased in both primary cells and cell lines expressing AML1/ETO. Our results suggest that the functional interaction of AML1/ETO with AML1 and HEB plays a major role in transcriptional regulation determined by the fusion protein.
Leishmania donovani HAT2 is a constitutively nuclear histone acetyltransferase that acetylates histone H4 at lysine 10 ( H4K10 ) in vitro and in vivo. Depletion of HAT2 in Leishmania donovani cells results in growth and cell cycle defects, as well as poor survival in host cells. We found that HAT2 is essential for the expression of cyclins CYC4 and CYC9, which are involved in S phase and G2/M progression, respectively. CYC4 and CYC9 have their own specific promoters, which are activated in a cell cycle-dependent manner. HAT2-dependent H4K10 acetylation of these promoters is required for their activation, and depletion of HAT2 results in downregulation of CYC4 and CYC9 expression. This downregulation is responsible for the cell cycle defects observed in HAT2-depleted cells. We also found that transcription of polycistronic units in Leishmania donovani primarily initiates at divergent strand switch regions ( dSSRs ), which are enriched in H4K10 acetylation and H3K4 trimethylation. However, the role of H4K10 acetylation in transcriptional activation from dSSRs in Leishmania donovani is unclear, as a 50% decrease in H4K10 acetylation at dSSRs did not have an impact on gene expression.
Inferring on others' intentions is a fundamental problem during many social transactions. To investigate the underlying mechanisms, we applied computational modeling to behavioral data from an economic game in which 16 pairs of volunteers interacted. The game was structured such that the adviser's incentives to provide helpful or misleading information varied in time. Using a meta-Bayesian modeling framework, we found that the players' behavior was best explained by the deployment of hierarchical learning: they inferred upon the volatility of the advisers' intentions in order to optimize their predictions about the validity of their advice. Beyond learning, volatility estimates also affected the trial-by-trial variability of decisions: participants were more likely to rely on their estimates of advice accuracy for making choices when they believed that the adviser's intentions were presently stable. Our model of the players' inference predicted the players' interpersonal reactivity index ( IRI ) scores, explicit ratings of the advisers' helpfulness and the advisers' self-reports on their chosen strategy. Overall, our results suggest that humans employ hierarchical generative models to infer on the changing intentions of others, use volatility estimates to inform decision-making in social interactions, and integrate estimates of advice accuracy with non-social sources of information.
Scrub typhus, an endemic disease in Asia, has traditionally been considered a rural disease. However, indigenous urban cases have been observed in Seoul, South Korea. We investigated the status of indigenous urban scrub typhus and its clinical characteristics in Seoul. Using national notifiable disease data from 2010 to 2013, we identified 88 cases of urban scrub typhus in Seoul. The possible sites of infection were mountainous areas, city parks, the vicinity of one’s own residence, and riversides. Eighty-seven chigger mites were collected in Gwanak mountain, one of the suspected infection sites in southern Seoul, and 76 ( 87. 4% ) of them were identified as Helenicula miyagawai and 8 ( 9. 2% ) as Leptotrombidium scutellare. Pooled DNA extracted from H. miyagawai mites yielded O. tsutsugamushi Boryong strain. Twenty-six patients from one hospital showed low APACHE II score, low complication rate, and no hypokalemia. We identified the presence of indigenous urban scrub typhus in Seoul, and a subgroup of them had mild clinical features. The chigger mite H. miyagawai infected with O. tsutsugamushi within the city was found. In endemic areas, urban scrub typhus needs to be considered as one of the differential febrile diseases and a target for prevention.
C. elegans HEN1 homolog, HENN-1, plays a role in the stability of small RNA ( sRNA ) molecules in the germline. HENN-1 mediates methylation of the 3′ ends of sRNA molecules, which is important for their stability. We investigated the effects of HENN-1 on two endogenous sRNA classes in C. elegans, 26G and 21U RNAs, which are involved in RNA interference ( RNAi ) pathways. We found that HENN-1 has differential effects on these two pathways. In the germline, the stability of 21U RNAs is only mildly affected by loss of methylation, and introduction of artificial 21U target RNA does not further destabilize non-methylated 21U RNAs. In contrast, most 26G RNAs display reduced stability and respond to loss of HENN-1 by displaying increased 3′-uridylation frequencies. Within the 26G RNA class, we found that specifically ERGO-1–bound 26G RNAs are modified by HENN-1, while ALG-3/ALG-4–bound 26G RNAs are not. Our data suggest that HENN-1 has a stabilizing effect on ERGO-1-bound 26G RNAs and prevents non-templated uridylation. We also found that loss of HENN-1 results in mild effects on global gene expression in the germline, including down-regulation of many germline-expressed genes.
The first genome-wide association study ( GWAS ) of the human N-glycome has identified a novel role for the transcription factor Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 1α ( HNF1α ) as a master regulator of plasma protein fucosylation. HNF1α and its downstream target HNF4α regulate the expression of genes involved in fucosyltransferase and fucose biosynthesis. We show that HNF1α is both necessary and sufficient to drive the expression of these genes in hepatic cells. This mechanism has implications for the regulation of immunity, embryonic development, and protein folding, as well as for our understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying cancer, coronary heart disease, and metabolic and inflammatory disorders.
Centromeres are the attachment points between the genome and the cytoskeleton, where kinetochores bind to spindles and move chromosomes. Paradoxically, the DNA sequence of centromeres has little or no role in perpetuating kinetochores, suggesting that kinetochore assembly is an epigenetic process. We show that maize CENPC, a key inner kinetochore protein, has a DNA-binding domain that is exquisitely sensitive to single-stranded RNA. Long, single-stranded nucleic acids strongly promote the binding of CENPC to DNA, and the types of RNAs that stabilize DNA binding match in size and character the RNAs present on kinetochores in vivo. Our data suggest that centromeric RNA helps to recruit CENPC to the inner kinetochore by altering its DNA binding characteristics. We propose that CENPC is first recruited to kinetochores by protein-protein contacts and then converted to a functional DNA binding protein by centromeric RNA. Our findings are consistent with recent studies showing that RNA facilitates or stabilizes the association of kinetochore proteins with centromeric DNA, and implicate CENPC as a primary target of this activity. In maize, the available data suggest that centromeric DNA does not function to recruit kinetochores until it is combined with specific epigenetic marks.
GWAS have identified genetic variants associated with birth weight ( BW ), childhood obesity ( CO ), and childhood body mass index ( CBMI ). The placenta plays a critical role in fetal development and postnatal health. We examined the role of the placental transcriptome and expression quantitative trait loci ( eQTLs ) in mediating the genetic causes of BW, CO, and CBMI. We found that GWAS loci associated with BW, CO, and CBMI were substantially enriched for placental eQTLs ( 6. 76, 4. 83, and 2. 26 folds, respectively ). Importantly, compared to eQTLs of adult tissues, only placental eQTLs contributed significantly to both anthropometric outcomes at birth ( BW ) and childhood phenotypes ( CO/CBMI ). We identified eight, six, and one transcripts that colocalized with BW, CO, and CBMI risk loci, respectively. Our study reveals that placental transcription in utero likely plays a key role in determining postnatal body size, and may hold new possibilities for therapeutic interventions to prevent childhood obesity.
Post Kala-azar Dermal Leishmaniasis ( PKDL ) is a chronic but not life-threatening disease that is highly relevant in the context of Visceral Leishmaniasis ( VL ) elimination. PKDL occurs in approximately 10–20% of successfully treated VL cases in India and 50–60% of such cases in Sudan. PKDL is characterized by macular, maculopapular or nodular skin lesions caused by Leishmania donovani. In the present study conducted in Malda district, West Bengal, India, the prevalence of PKDL was determined to be 27. 5% among antileishmanial antibody positive cases. A total of 26 PKDL cases were detected and treated with either sodium stibogluconate ( SSG ) or oral miltefosine. The sensitivity of species-specific PCR on slit skin smear was 93. 8%, but it has not been applied for routine diagnostic purposes. In this study, the sensitivity of primary PCR was 65. 4%, which increased to 88. 5% in nested PCR. Parasite DNA was detected by PCR in 23 cases with a sensitivity rate of 88. 46%. The rK-39 strip test was positive in all 26 patients, but it is not conclusive for PKDL diagnosis due to the persistence of anti-leishmanial antibodies after L. donovani infections. The study highlights the need for active mass surveys in endemic areas to attain the ultimate goal of eliminating Kala-azar.
Competence is an inducible genetic program in bacteria that enables horizontal gene transfer. In Streptococcus pneumoniae, competence development in liquid cultures is synchronized within the whole cell population and is known to depend on an exported signaling peptide called Competence Stimulating Peptide ( CSP ). However, it is unclear how this CSP-dependent population switch is coordinated. We have found that competence shift in the population relies on a self-activated cell fraction that arises via a growth time-dependent mechanism. This mechanism involves the propagation of competence by contact between activated and quiescent cells. We have demonstrated that CSP remains bound to cells during this event and that the rate of competence development corresponds to the propagation of competence by contact between activated and quiescent cells. We propose that competence initiator cells originate stochastically in response to stress, to form a distinct subpopulation that then transmits the CSP by cell-cell contact. We have validated this two-step cell-contact sensing mechanism by measuring competence development during co-cultivation of strains with altered capacity to produce or respond to CSP. We have also found that the membrane protein ComD retains the CSP, limiting its free diffusion in the medium.
Translocation of the human papillomavirus type 16 (HPV16) L2/viral DNA (vDNA) complex from the trans-Golgi network (TGN) to the nucleus requires the onset of mitosis. The L2 protein acts as a chaperone to ensure that the vDNA traffics from endosomes to the TGN and eventually the nucleus, where HPV replication occurs. We have developed a system based on subcellular compartmentalization of the enzyme BirA and its cognate substrate to detect membrane translocation of L2-BirA from incoming virions. We find that L2 translocation requires transport to the TGN and is strictly dependent on entry into mitosis, coinciding with mitotic entry in synchronized cells. Cell cycle arrest causes retention of L2/vDNA at the TGN; only release and progression past G2/M enables translocation across the limiting membrane and subsequent infection. Microscopy of EdU-labeled vDNA reveals a rapid and dramatic shift in vDNA localization during early mitosis. At late G2/early prophase vDNA egresses from the TGN to a pericentriolar location, accumulating there through prometaphase where it begins to associate with condensed chromosomes. By metaphase and throughout anaphase the vDNA is seen bound to the mitotic chromosomes, ensuring distribution into both daughter nuclei. Mutations in a newly defined chromatin binding region of L2 potently blocked translocation, suggesting that translocation is dependent on chromatin binding during prometaphase.
We present a mathematical framework for estimating the relative transmissibility of one strain of a pathogen compared to another. The method is applied to data from competitive mixtures experiments in which animals are co-infected with a mixture of two strains. We use data from influenza experiments in ferrets to demonstrate the approach. The relative transmissibility of one strain of influenza compared to another is important in at least three contexts: seasonal/seasonal interactions, seasonal/pandemic interactions, and NAI-resistant/NAI-sensitive interactions. The mathematical framework introduced here also provides an estimate for the size of the transmitted inoculum. We demonstrate the framework's behaviour using data from ferret transmission studies, and through simulation suggest how to optimise experimental design for assessment of transmissibility. The method introduced here for assessment of mixed transmission events has applicability beyond influenza, to other viral and bacterial pathogens.
The integration of light and abscisic acid ( ABA ) signaling pathways is crucial for plant adaptation and survival. In this study, we show that BBX21, a B-box protein involved in seedling photomorphogenesis, also plays a role in ABA signaling. Our genetic data indicate that BBX21 may act upstream of several ABA INSENSITIVE ( ABI ) genes and ELONGATED HYPOCOTYL 5 ( HY5 ) in ABA control of seed germination. We further demonstrate that BBX21 negatively regulates ABI5 expression by interfering with HY5 binding to the ABI5 promoter. In addition, we show that ABI5 directly activates its own expression, and that BBX21 negatively regulates this activity by directly interacting with ABI5. Together, these findings indicate that BBX21 coordinates with HY5 and ABI5 on the ABI5 promoter and that these transcriptional regulators work in concert to integrate light and ABA signaling in Arabidopsis thaliana.
The Mediator complex is an essential co-regulator of RNA polymerase II that is conserved throughout eukaryotes. Here we present the first study of Mediator in the pathogenic fungus Candida albicans. We focused on the Middle domain subunit Med31, the Head domain subunit Med20, and Srb9/Med13 from the Kinase domain. The C. albicans Mediator shares some roles with model yeasts Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Schizosaccharomyces pombe, such as functions in the response to certain stresses and the role of Med31 in the expression of genes regulated by the activator Ace2. The C. albicans Mediator also has additional roles in the transcription of genes associated with virulence, for example genes related to morphogenesis and gene families enriched in pathogens, such as the ALS adhesins. Consistently, Med31, Med20, and Srb9/Med13 contribute to key virulence attributes of C. albicans, filamentation, and biofilm formation; and ALS1 is a biologically relevant target of Med31 for development of biofilms. Furthermore, Med31 affects virulence of C. albicans in the worm infection model. We present evidence that the roles of Med31 and Srb9/Med13 in the expression of the genes encoding cell wall adhesins are different between S. cerevisiae and C. albicans: they are repressors of the FLO genes in S. cerevisiae and are activators of the ALS genes in C. albicans.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilms have been shown to exhibit higher antibiotic tolerance than their planktonic counterparts. However, the degree to which the biofilm-specific cellular state and its constituent genetic determinants contribute to this hyper-tolerant phenotype is not well understood. To address this question, we used genome-wide functional profiling of a complex, heterogeneous mutant population of P. aeruginosa MPAO1 in biofilm and planktonic growth conditions with and without tobramycin to systematically quantify the contribution of each locus to antibiotic tolerance under these two states. We identified large sets of mutations that contribute to antibiotic tolerance predominantly in the biofilm or planktonic setting only, offering global insights into the differences and similarities between biofilm and planktonic antibiotic tolerance. Our mixed population-based experimental design recapitulated the complexity of natural biofilms and, unlike previous studies, revealed clinically observed behaviors including the emergence of quorum sensing-deficient mutants. Our study revealed a substantial contribution of the cellular state to the antibiotic tolerance of biofilms, providing a rational foundation for the development of novel therapeutics against P. aeruginosa biofilm-associated infections.
Complex biological systems are difficult to analyse due to the multitude of interacting components and the lack of information about the essential dynamics. Model selection algorithms that evaluate the performance of a multitude of different models against experimental data provide a useful tool to identify appropriate model structures. However, many algorithms addressing the analysis of complex dynamical systems compare a preselected number of models or rely on exhaustive searches of the total model space, which might be unfeasible. Therefore, we developed a Flexible and dynamic Algorithm for Model Selection ( FAMoS ) that is able to perform model selection on complex systems and searches large model spaces in a dynamical way. Our algorithm includes local and newly developed non-local search methods that can prevent the algorithm from ending up in local minima of the model space by accounting for structurally similar processes. We tested and validated the algorithm based on simulated data and showed its flexibility for handling different model structures. We also used the algorithm to analyse experimental data on the cell proliferation dynamics of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells that were cultured under different conditions. Our analyses indicated dynamical changes within the proliferation potential of cells that was reduced within tissue-like 3D ex vivo cultures compared to suspension. Due to the flexibility in handling various model structures, the algorithm is applicable to a large variety of different biological problems and represents a useful tool for the data-oriented evaluation of complex model spaces.
Chagas disease, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, is a major public health problem in Bolivia. In 2006, the National Program for Chagas disease was implemented in Bolivia, resulting in a significant decrease in the number of infections through vector control. Subsequently, a treatment regimen of benznidazole ( BNZ ) was started in seropositive school-age children living in certified vector control areas. We conducted a 12-month follow-up study to evaluate the efficacy of BNZ treatment in seropositive children. Blood samples were taken during and after treatment, and serology, conventional diagnostic PCR ( cPCR ), and quantitative Real-time PCR ( qPCR ) were performed. Plasma Th1/Th2/Th17 cytokines levels were also determined. Among 57 children who completed follow-up, 6 ( 11% ) showed both cPCR ( + ) and qPCR ( + ) ( non reactive ), 24 ( 42% ) cPCR ( - ) but qPCR ( + ) ( ambiguous ), and 27 ( 47% ) cPCR ( - ) and qPCR ( - ) ( reactive ). IL-17A levels were significantly higher in seropositive children before treatment compared to age-matched seronegative children and decreased to normal levels one year after treatment. Moreover, IL-17A levels were positively correlated with parasite counts detected by qPCR. At the 12 months’ time point, IL-17A levels of non-reactive subjects were significantly higher than those of reactive or ambiguous subjects, suggesting that IL-17A might be useful to determine the reactivity to BNZ treatment.
Neisseria meningitidis, the primary causative agent of bacterial meningitis, has a genome rich in repetitive DNA, with almost 2% occupied by a diminutive transposon called the Correia element ( CE ). Here, we report a bioinformatic analysis defining eight subtypes of the CE with four distinct types of ends. Transcriptional analysis using PCR and a lacZ reporter system revealed that two ends in particular encode strong promoters. The activity of the strongest promoter is dictated by a recurrent polymorphism ( Y128 ) at the right end of the element. We show that CEs can drive transcription of adjacent genes and may express small non-coding RNAs. Pair-wise comparisons between three meningococcal genomes revealed that no more than two-thirds of CEs maintain their subtype at any particular locus, due to recombinational class switching between elements in a single strain. This process may represent a hitherto unrecognized mechanism for phase variation in the meningococcus. We conclude that the strain-to-strain variability of the CEs, and the large number of strong promoters encoded by them, allows for potentially widespread effects within the population as a whole.
Cochliobolus heterostrophus is a maize pathogen that produces a wealth of secondary metabolites, including the host selective toxin T-toxin. T-toxin is produced by race T and promotes high virulence to maize carrying Texas male sterile cytoplasm ( T-cms ). T-toxin production is significantly increased in the dark in wild type ( WT ), whereas Chvel1 and Chlae1 mutant toxin levels are much reduced in the dark compared to WT. Correspondingly, expression of T-toxin biosynthetic genes ( Tox1 ) is up-regulated in the dark in WT, while dark-induced expression is much reduced/minimal in Chvel1 and Chlae1 mutants. Toxin production and Tox1 gene expression are increased in ChVEL1 overexpression ( OE ) strains grown in the dark and in ChLAE1 strains grown in either light or dark, compared to WT. These observations establish ChLae1 and ChVel1 as the first factors known to regulate host selective toxin production. ChLae1 and ChVel1 positively regulate T-toxin biosynthesis, pathogenicity and super virulence, oxidative stress responses, sexual development, and aerial hyphal growth, and negatively control melanin biosynthesis and asexual differentiation.
Bacterial Nav channels have been characterized as functionally asymmetric, and the mechanism of this asymmetry has not been clearly understood. To address this question, we combined non-equilibrium simulation data with two-dimensional equilibrium unperturbed landscapes generated by umbrella sampling and Weighted Histogram Analysis Methods for multiple ions traversing the selectivity filter of bacterial NavAb channel. The non-equilibrium simulations indicate that two or three extracellular K+ ions can block the entrance to the selectivity filter of NavAb in the presence of applied forces in the inward direction, but not in the outward direction. The block state occurs in an unstable local minimum of the equilibrium unperturbed free-energy landscape of two K+ ions that can be ‘locked’ in place by modest applied forces. In contrast, three Na+ ions move favorably through the selectivity filter together as a unit in a loose “knock-on” mechanism of permeation in both inward and outward directions, and there is no similar local minimum in the two-dimensional free-energy landscape of two Na+ ions for a block state. The useful work predicted by the non-equilibrium simulations that is required to break the K+ block is equivalent to large applied potentials experimentally measured for two bacterial Nav channels to induce inward currents of K+ ions. These results illustrate how inclusion of non-equilibrium factors in the simulations can provide detailed information about mechanisms of ion selectivity that is missing from mechanisms derived from either crystal structures or equilibrium unperturbed free-energy landscapes.
Rabies virus spreads more slowly in the paralytic form of canine rabies compared to the furious form. This is evident from the amount of rabies viral antigen present in the cell processes of the brain and spinal cord. In the furious form, rabies virus rapidly colonizes the cerebral hemispheres, as measured by viral antigen within neuronal cell bodies and viral RNA levels. In contrast, in the paralytic form, there is a delay in cell process involvement following cell body involvement, consistent with replication occurring in the cell body region and subsequent transport out to cell processes. The amount of rabies viral antigen in cell processes decreases in a rostral direction, following the pattern for the amount of rabies viral antigen in neuronal cell bodies and the percentage of involved cell bodies. However, the amount of antigen in cell processes is greater in dogs with the furious form compared to the paralytic form, at all anatomic levels examined. This suggests that intracellular transport of the virus may be slower in the paralytic form, resulting in slower viral propagation. Possible mechanisms might involve host-specific differences in intracellular virus transport, which could be cytokine-mediated, since previous studies have documented greater inflammation in the paralytic form.
CTCF (CCCTC-binding factor) is a zinc-finger protein that plays an important role in the regulation of transcription by preventing inappropriate interactions between enhancers and promoters. In vertebrates, CTCF is well characterised as an enhancer-blocking factor, but its function in Drosophila has only recently been characterised. To date, only one endogenous binding location for CTCF has been identified in the Drosophila genome, the Fab-8 insulator in the Bithorax complex ( BX-C ). We used chromatin immunopurification coupled with genomic microarray analysis to identify CTCF binding sites within representative regions of the Drosophila genome, including the 3-Mb Adh region, the BX-C, and the Antennapedia complex. We identified CTCF binding sites in the BX-C that map precisely to the known insulator elements Mcp, Fab-6, and Fab-8. We also identified three additional presumptive insulator elements; “Fab-2, ” “Fab-3, ” and “Fab-4. ” Our data indicate that CTCF is directly associated with all known or predicted insulators in the BX-C, suggesting that the functioning of these insulators involves a common CTCF-dependent mechanism.
Peptide deformylase ( PDF ) is a metal cation-dependent enzyme that catalyzes the removal of the N-formyl group from the N-terminus of nascent polypeptide chains. Here, we provide a detailed mechanism for the induced-fit process that occurs during the binding of a slow, tight-binding inhibitor, actinonin, to PDF. We solved the crystal structures of the initial open state and final closed state of the enzyme-inhibitor complex, as well as several intermediate mimics captured during the binding process. Our results show that the binding of actinonin induces a conformational change in the enzyme, resulting in the closure of the active site. This closure is driven by the ligand-induced reshaping of a hydrophobic pocket and is further stabilized by additional binding interactions. Together with biochemical analyses, these data allow us to reconstruct the sequence of events leading from the encounter complex to the key-lock binding state of the enzyme.
The thalamus acts as the primary gateway for relaying sensory information to the cerebral cortex. However, the influence of the functional loop between the thalamus and cortex remains largely unexplored during sensory processing. Using dynamic-clamp techniques in thalamic slices in vitro, we implemented a hybrid retino-thalamo-cortical pathway combining biological cells and simulated circuits. We mimicked the synaptic bombardment of cortical origin through the injection of a stochastic mixture of excitatory and inhibitory conductances, resulting in a gradable correlation level of afferent activity shared by thalamic cells. Our results show that the transfer efficiency of sensory input transmission depends on three key features: i ) the number of thalamocortical cells involved in the many-to-one convergence from thalamus to cortex, ii ) the statistics of the corticothalamic synaptic bombardment and iii ) the level of correlation imposed between converging thalamic relay cells. Counterintuitively, our results demonstrate that the retinocortical signal transfer efficiency increases when the level of correlation across thalamic cells decreases. This suggests that the transfer efficiency of relay cells could be selectively amplified when they become simultaneously desynchronized by the cortical feedback. We propose that active decorrelation of background synaptic activity in the thalamic layer provides a powerful optimization mechanism controlling the efficiency of the retinocortical signal transfer.
The putative DNA demethylase NMAD-1 plays a critical role in regulating DNA replication and repair during meiosis in the Caenorhabditis elegans germline. NMAD-1 mutants have reduced fertility and show defects in prophase I of meiosis, which leads to reduced embryo production and an increased incidence of males due to defective chromosomal segregation. In nmad-1 mutant worms, nuclear staging beginning at the leptotene and zygotene stages is disorganized, the cohesin complex is mislocalized at the diplotene and diakinesis stages, and chromosomes are improperly condensed, fused, or lost by the end of diakinesis. RNA sequencing of the nmad-1 germline revealed reduced induction of DNA replication and DNA damage response genes during meiosis, which was coupled with delayed DNA replication, impaired DNA repair, and increased apoptosis of maturing oocytes. NMAD-1 binds to multiple proteins that regulate DNA repair and replication, including topoisomerase TOP-2, and co-localizes with TOP-2 on chromatin. Moreover, the majority of TOP-2 binding to chromatin depends on NMAD-1. These results suggest that NMAD-1 functions at DNA replication sites to regulate DNA replication and repair during meiosis.
Human cytomegalovirus ( HCMV ) is a ubiquitous pathogen that can cause disease in newborns and immunocompromised patients. HCMV has a large genome and can infect a wide range of human cells, but the mechanism of HCMV infection remains a mystery. Here, we report the identification of adipocyte plasma membrane-associated protein ( APMAP ) as a novel modulator of HCMV infection. APMAP is necessary for HCMV infection in both epithelial cells and fibroblasts; knockdown of APMAP expression significantly reduced HCMV infection of these cells. Interestingly, ectopic expression of human APMAP in cells refractory to HCMV infection, such as canine MDCK and murine NIH/3T3 cells, promoted HCMV infection. Furthermore, reduction in viral immediate early ( IE ) gene transcription at 6 h post infection and delayed nucleus translocation of tegument delivered pp65 at 4 h post infection were detected in APMAP-deficient cells but not in wildtype cells. These results suggest that APMAP plays a role in the early stage of HCMV infection. Biochemical studies of APMAP and HCMV proteins suggest that APMAP could participate in HCMV infection through interaction with gH/gL containing glycoprotein complexes at low pH and mediate nucleus translocation of tegument pp65. Taken together, our results suggest that APMAP functions as a modulator promoting HCMV infection in multiple cell types and is an important player in the complex HCMV infection mechanism.
Hematopoiesis is the process by which blood cells are produced from hematopoietic progenitor cells. Lineage commitment during hematopoiesis is the process by which a progenitor cell commits to a specific lineage of blood cells, such as erythrocytes, granulocytes, or megakaryocytes. Lineage commitment can be influenced by both intrinsic and extrinsic factors. Intrinsic factors include the differential expression of lineage-specific transcription factors, which are proteins that regulate gene expression. Extrinsic factors, on the other hand, include cytokines, which are signaling molecules produced by other cells that can influence the behavior of hematopoietic progenitor cells. Here, we present a mathematical model of lineage commitment that combines both intrinsic and extrinsic factors. Our model suggests that cytokine-mediated positive receptor feedback can induce a “switch-like” response to external stimuli during multilineage differentiation, providing robustness to both bipotent and committed states while protecting progenitors from noise-induced differentiation or decommitment. The model further suggests that cell fates are ultimately driven by lineage-specific transcription factors, but cytokine signaling can strongly bias lineage commitment by regulating these inherently noisy cell-fate decisions. Our model also shows good agreement with lineage-specific receptor expression kinetics from microarray experiments and provides a computational framework that can integrate both classical and alternative commitment paths in hematopoiesis that have been observed experimentally.
Orthobunyaviruses are an expanding group of emerging viruses that pose a threat to human and animal health. Despite their medical importance, little is known about their structure, which is essential for understanding virus assembly and entry into host cells. Here, we report the ultrastructure of Bunyamwera virus, the prototypic member of this genus, using electron cryo-tomography. We show that Bunyamwera virions are pleomorphic in shape and display a locally ordered lattice of glycoprotein spikes. Each spike protrudes 18 nm from the viral membrane and becomes disordered upon introduction to an acidic environment. Using sub-tomogram averaging, we derived a three-dimensional model of the trimeric pre-fusion glycoprotein spike to 3-nm resolution. The glycoprotein spike consists mainly of the putative class-II fusion glycoprotein and exhibits a unique tripod-like arrangement. Protein–protein contacts between neighbouring spikes occur at membrane-proximal regions and intra-spike contacts at membrane-distal regions. This trimeric assembly deviates from previously observed fusion glycoprotein arrangements, suggesting a greater than anticipated repertoire of viral fusion glycoprotein oligomerization. Our study provides evidence of a pH-dependent conformational change that occurs during orthobunyaviral entry into host cells and a blueprint for the structure of this group of emerging pathogens.
Primary angle closure glaucoma ( PACG ) is a major cause of irreversible blindness, particularly in Asian countries. We conducted a genome-wide association study ( GWAS ) on a total of 5, 308 population-based individuals of Asian descent to identify novel genes associated with PACG. We discovered that a sequence variant within the ABCC5 gene ( rs1401999 ) is associated with a decrease in anterior chamber depth ( ACD ) of 0. 045 mm ( P = 8. 17×10−9 ). This locus was also associated with an increase in risk of PACG in a separate case-control study of 4, 276 cases and 18, 801 controls ( per-allele OR = 1. 13 [95% CI: 1. 06–1. 22], P = 0. 00046 ). The association was strengthened when a sub-group of controls with open angles were included in the analysis ( per-allele OR = 1. 30, P = 7. 45×10−9; 3, 458 cases vs. 3, 831 controls ). Our findings suggest that the increase in PACG risk could in part be mediated by genetic sequence variants influencing anterior chamber dimensions.
Deuterostomes and protostomes are two clades of bilaterian animals that share a common developmental toolkit, including conserved transcription factors and signaling pathways. However, previous studies have found no regulatory sequence conserved between the two clades. Here, we describe the first examples of developmental enhancers conserved between deuterostomes and protostomes, which we call bilaterian conserved regulatory elements ( Bicores ). Bicores show conservation of sequence and gene synteny, and sequence conservation reflects conserved patterns of transcription factor binding sites. We predict that Bicores act as response elements to signaling pathways, and we show that Bicores are developmental enhancers that drive expression of transcriptional repressors in the vertebrate central nervous system.
Influenza virus diversity and antigenic drift have been well characterized on a global scale, but the factors that influence the virus’ rapid evolution within and between human hosts are less clear. We used next generation sequencing of patient-derived viruses from a randomized, placebo-controlled trial of vaccine efficacy to characterize the diversity of influenza A virus and to define the impact of vaccine-induced immunity on within-host populations. We identified 166 cases of H3N2 influenza over 3 seasons and 5119 person-years, and obtained whole genome sequence data for 119 samples. Phylogenetic analysis of consensus hemagglutinin and neuraminidase sequences showed no stratification by pre-season hemagglutination inhibition and neuraminidase inhibition titers, respectively. We found that the vast majority of intrahost single nucleotide variants were rare and that very few were found in more than one individual. Most samples had fewer than 15 single nucleotide variants across the entire genome, and the level of diversity did not significantly vary with day of sampling, vaccination status, or pre-season antibody titer. Our data indicate that seasonal influenza vaccination has little impact on intrahost diversity in natural infection and that vaccine-induced immunity may be only a minor contributor to antigenic drift at local scales.
Visceral leishmaniasis is a severe disease caused by the protozoan parasite Leishmania donovani. In this study, we investigated the efficacy of live attenuated L. donovani parasites ( LdCen-/- ) in inducing a protective immune response in young and aged mice. We previously showed that LdCen-/- parasites induce a strong protective immune response in young mice. In this study, we analyzed the immune response in aged mice ( 18 months ) and compared it to young mice ( 2 months ). We found that LdCen-/- infection significantly enhanced the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines ( IL-12, IL-6, IFN-γ, and TNF ) and down-regulated anti-inflammatory cytokines ( IL-10 ) in bone marrow derived dendritic cells ( BMDCs ) from both young and aged mice. We also found that LdCen-/- immunization induced higher IgG2a antibodies, lymphoproliferative response, pro- and anti-inflammatory cytokine responses, and stimulated splenocytes for heightened leishmanicidal activity associated with nitric oxide production in young and aged mice. Upon challenge with virulent L. donovani parasites, LdCen-/- immunized mice from both age groups displayed multifunctional Th1-type CD4 and cytotoxic CD8 T cells correlating to a significantly reduced parasite burden in the spleen and liver compared to naïve mice.
Enteric and respiratory enteroviruses ( EVs ) have distinct biophysical properties and cause a wide range of human pathologies despite their genetic similarities. We generated chimeras at the capsid level between EV-D68 ( a respiratory EV ) and EV-D94 ( an enteric EV ) to investigate the underlying cause of these differences. We found that capsid proteins determine acid sensitivity and tropism in cell lines and in respiratory, intestinal and neural tissues. Additionally, capsid genes also participate in determining the optimal growth temperature, since EV-D94 temperature adaptation relied on single mutations in VP1, while constructs with EV-D68 capsid could not adapt to higher temperatures. We also demonstrated that EV-D68 maintains residual binding capacity after acid treatment despite a loss of infectivity. In contrast, non-structural proteins modulate the innate immune response in tissues.
Herpes Simplex Virus 1 ( HSV-1 ) glycoprotein gE-gI is a transmembrane Fc receptor found on the surface of infected cells and virions that binds human immunoglobulin G ( hIgG ). gE-gI can also participate in antibody bipolar bridging ( ABB ), a process by which the antigen-binding fragments ( Fabs ) of the IgG bind a viral antigen while the Fc binds to gE-gI. The fate of viral antigens associated with gE-gI–bound IgG had been unknown: they could remain at the cell surface or be endocytosed with IgG. Here, we developed an in vitro model system for ABB and investigated the trafficking of ABB complexes using 4-D confocal fluorescence imaging of ABB complexes with transferrin or epidermal growth factor, well-characterized intracellular trafficking markers. Our data showed that cells expressing gE-gI and the viral antigen HSV-1 gD endocytosed anti-gD IgG and gD in a gE-gI–dependent process, resulting in lysosomal localization. These results suggest that gE-gI can mediate clearance of infected cell surfaces of anti-viral host IgG and viral antigens to evade IgG-mediated responses, representing a general mechanism for viral Fc receptors in immune evasion and viral pathogenesis.
Echinococcus granulosus is the causative agent of cystic hydatid disease ( CHD ), which affects humans and domestic animals worldwide. The larval stages of the parasite, including the protoscoleces ( PSCs ), can interact with both definitive and intermediate hosts. However, our understanding of how PSCs subvert the immune response of hosts and maintain metabolic adaptation remains unclear. In this study, we used Roche 454 sequencing technology and in silico secretome analysis to explore the transcriptome profiles of E. granulosus PSCs and elucidate the potential functions of the excretory-secretory proteins ( ESPs ) released by the parasite. We generated 26, 514 nonredundant sequences, of which 22, 910 ( 86. 4% ) were mapped to the newly published E. granulosus genome and 17, 705 ( 66. 8% ) were distributed within the coding sequence ( CDS ) regions. We predicted 2, 280 ESPs, of which 138 were involved in carbohydrate metabolism and 124 were involved in protein metabolism. Eleven ESPs were identified as intracellular enzymes that regulate glycolysis/gluconeogenesis ( GL/GN ) pathways, while 44 antigenic proteins, 25 molecular chaperones and four proteases were highly represented. Many proteins were also found to be significantly enriched in development-related signaling pathways, such as the TGF-β receptor pathways and insulin pathways. This study provides valuable information on the metabolic adaptation of parasites to their hosts that can be used to aid the development of novel intervention targets for hydatid treatment and control.
Nitrate assimilation is a tightly regulated process in microorganisms and plants. In Aspergillus nidulans, the transcription factor NirA plays a key role in the transcriptional activation of nitrate assimilatory genes. The interaction between NirA and the exportin KapK/CRM1 is disrupted in the presence of nitrate, leading to rapid nuclear accumulation and transcriptional activity of NirA. We found that in the absence of nitrate, when NirA is inactive and predominantly cytosolic, methionine 169 in the nuclear export sequence ( NES ) is oxidized to methionine sulfoxide ( Metox169 ). This oxidation is dependent on FmoB, a flavin-containing monooxygenase, and is independent of thioredoxin and classical methionine sulfoxide reductases. In the presence of nitrate, NirA-Metox169 is rapidly reduced to Met169. Replacement of Met169 with isoleucine, a sterically similar but not oxidizable residue, led to partial loss of NirA activity and insensitivity to FmoB-mediated nuclear export. In contrast, replacement of Met169 with alanine transformed the protein into a permanently nuclear and active transcription factor. We propose that in the presence of nitrate, the activation domain of NirA is exposed, but the NES is masked by a central portion of the protein ( termed nitrate responsive domain, NiRD ), thus restricting active NirA molecules to the nucleus. In the absence of nitrate, Met169 oxidation leads to loss of protection by the NiRD, NES exposure, and relocation of the inactive NirA to the cytosol.
Voltage-gated sodium channels are essential for the propagation of action potentials in mammalian cells. Mathematical models have suggested that sodium channel properties need to be tightly constrained for an action potential to propagate. There are nine mammalian genes encoding voltage-gated sodium channels, many of which are more than 90% identical by sequence. This sequence similarity presumably corresponds to similarity of function, consistent with the idea that these properties must be tightly constrained. However, the multiplicity of genes encoding sodium channels raises the question of why there are so many. We demonstrate that the simplest theoretical constraints bounding sodium channel diversity—the requirements of membrane excitability and the uniqueness of the resting potential—act directly on constraining sodium channel properties. We compare the predicted constraints with functional data on mammalian sodium channel properties collected from the literature, including 172 different sets of measurements from 40 publications, wild-type and mutant, under a variety of conditions. The data from all channel types, including mutants, obeys the excitability constraint; on the other hand, channels expressed in muscle tend to obey the constraint of a unique resting potential, while channels expressed in neuronal tissue do not. The excitability properties alone distinguish the nine sodium channels into four different groups that are consistent with phylogenetic analysis.
Influenza virus polymerase is an attractive target for antiviral drugs because it is essential for viral transcription and replication. The endonuclease domain of the PA subunit of the heterotrimeric polymerase has been identified as a good target for drug development, as its inhibition could directly stop viral replication at an early stage. Here, we report high resolution X-ray co-crystal structures of the 2009 pandemic H1N1 ( pH1N1 ) PA endonuclease domain with a series of specific inhibitors, including four diketo compounds and a green tea catechin, all of which chelate the two critical manganese ions in the active site of the enzyme. Our results show that different substituent groups on the basic metal binding scaffold can be orientated to bind in distinct sub-pockets within the active site cavity, and that certain structural elements of the active site cavity are plastic and result in induced fit binding. These findings will be important in optimising the design of more potent inhibitors targeting the cap-snatching endonuclease activity of influenza virus polymerase.
The aim of the present study was to develop an effective immunization protocol for the production of potent polyspecific antisera against the medically important vipers of Thailand and its neighboring countries, namely Calloselasma rhodostoma, Cryptelytrops albolabris and Daboia siamensis. Four horses were immunized with a mixture of the 3 viper venoms using the ‘low dose, low volume multi-site’ immunization protocol. The antisera showed rapid rise in ELISA titers against the 3 venoms and reached plateau at about the 8th week post-immunization. The in vivo neutralization potency of the antisera against CA, CR and DS venoms was 10. 40, 2. 42 and 0. 76 mg/ml, respectively, and was much higher than the minimal potency limits set by Queen Soavabha Memorial Institute ( QSMI ). The corresponding potency values for the QSMI monospecific antisera against CA, CR and DS venoms were 7. 28, 3. 12 and 1. 50 mg/ml, respectively. The polyspecific antisera also effectively neutralized the procoagulant, hemorrhagic, necrotic and nephrotoxic activities of the viper venoms. This effective immunization protocol should be useful in the production of potent polyspecific antisera against snake venoms, and equine antisera against tetanus, diphtheria or rabies.
Salmonella typhimurium, a host-adapted strain of Salmonella enterica, causes systemic infections that can persist for long periods of time despite the presence of a robust immune response. We show that the bacterial effector protein SseI, translocated into host cells by the Salmonella Pathogenicity Island 2 ( SPI2 ) type III secretion system ( T3SS ), is required for Salmonella typhimurium to maintain a long-term chronic systemic infection in mice. SseI inhibits normal cell migration of primary macrophages and dendritic cells ( DC ) in vitro, and such inhibition requires the host factor IQ motif containing GTPase activating protein 1 ( IQGAP1 ). SseI binds directly to IQGAP1 and co-localizes with this factor at the cell periphery. The C-terminal domain of SseI is similar to PMT/ToxA, a bacterial toxin that contains a cysteine residue ( C1165 ) that is critical for activity. Mutation of the corresponding residue in SseI ( C178A ) eliminates SseI function in vitro and in vivo, but not binding to IQGAP1. In addition, infection with wild-type ( WT ) S. typhimurium suppressed DC migration to the spleen in vivo in an SseI-dependent manner. Correspondingly, examination of spleens from mice infected with WT S. typhimurium revealed fewer DC and CD4+ T lymphocytes compared to mice infected with ΔsseI S. typhimurium.
Community acquired-methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus ( CA-MRSA ) is more virulent than hospital associated-MRSA ( HA-MRSA ) and causes severe disease in healthy individuals. The underlying mechanism for the high virulence of CA-MRSA is not known. Here, we report that the transcription product of the psm-mec gene, located in the mobile genetic element SCCmec of HA-MRSA, but not CA-MRSA, suppresses the expression of phenol-soluble modulin α ( PSMα ), a cytolytic toxin of S. aureus. We found that psm-mec RNA inhibits translation of the agrA gene encoding a positive transcription factor for the PSMα gene via specific binding to agrA mRNA. Furthermore, 25% of 325 clinical MRSA isolates had a mutation in the psm-mec promoter that attenuated transcription, and 9% of the strains had no psm-mec. In most of these psm-mec-mutated or psm-mec-deleted HA-MRSAs, PSMα expression was increased compared with strains carrying intact psm-mec, and some mutated strains produced high amounts of PSMα comparable with that of CA-MRSA. Deletion of psm-mec from HA-MRSA strains carrying intact psm-mec increased the expression of AgrA protein and PSMα, and virulence in mice. Thus, psm-mec RNA suppresses MRSA virulence via inhibition of agrA translation and the absence of psm-mec function in CA-MRSA causes its high virulence property.
Dengue virus ( DENV ) infection can lead to severe disease in individuals who have previously been infected with a different DENV serotype, a phenomenon known as antibody-mediated disease enhancement ( ADE ). ADE occurs when heterologous or sub-neutralizing homologous antibodies bind to DENV particles but fail to neutralize them, allowing Fc-receptor mediated entry of the virus-antibody complexes into host cells. This results in enhanced viral replication and heightened inflammatory responses. Here, we report a novel mouse model of ADE that is mediated by maternal antibodies in type I interferon receptor-deficient A129 mice. We show that 5-week old A129 mice born to DENV1-immune mothers succumbed to a DENV2 infection within 4 days that was sub-lethal in mice born to naïve mothers. Clinical manifestations included extensive hepatocyte vacuolation, moderate vascular leakage, lymphopenia, and thrombocytopenia. Anti-TNFα therapy totally protected the mice and correlated with healthy hepatocytes. In contrast, blocking IL-6 did not impact the virus titers or disease outcome. This A129 mouse model of ADE may help dissect the mechanisms involved in dengue pathogenesis and evaluate the efficacy of vaccine and therapeutic candidates.
Visceral leishmaniasis, a disease caused by the parasite Leishmania infantum, is a major public health concern in the Americas. A systematic review and meta-analysis of 51 studies was conducted to identify factors associated with the disease in humans in the Americas. The results showed that male sex was associated with visceral leishmaniasis in studies that used the leishmanin skin test for diagnosis and in those where the outcome was the clinical disease. In contrast, younger individuals were less frequently infected than adults, but were more prone to illness. The presence of dogs at home, higher dog seropositivity in nearby areas, lower socioeconomic status, and highly vegetated areas were also associated with L. infantum infection. However, the presence of chickens in the house and nutritional status were not associated with the disease. Ecological studies showed consistent evidence that dog seropositivity is associated with human visceral leishmaniasis, emphasizing the relevance of dogs as a marker of disease occurrence.
Francisella tularensis, the causative agent of tularemia, is a highly virulent bacterium that causes acute and fatal pneumonia following inhalation of as few as 10 colony forming units ( cfu ) of the highly virulent SchuS4 strain. In contrast, the less virulent LVS strain requires higher bacterial numbers to cause lethal infection. The mechanisms underlying acute pathogenesis and death in pulmonary tularemia remain unknown. Here, we show that an overt innate cellular response to Francisella tularensis, rather than overwhelming bacterial burden or cytokine production, drives tissue pathology and host mortality. This response is characterized by the recruitment of large numbers of immature myeloid cells ( IMC ) and myeloid-derived suppressor cells ( MDSC ) to the lungs and spleen. These cells fail to mature and die, leading to necrotic lung damage, loss of pulmonary function, and host death that is partially dependent upon immature Ly6G+ cells. In contrast, during sub-lethal infection with Francisella tularensis LVS, the pulmonary cellular response is characterized by a predominance of mature neutrophils and monocytes required for protection. This study reveals that the nature of the myeloid cell response may be the primary determinant of host mortality versus survival following Francisella infection.
Aedes albopictus, also known as the Asian tiger mosquito, is a vector of medically important arboviruses such as chikungunya ( CHIKV ), dengue ( DENV ), and Zika ( ZIKV ). This mosquito is an invasive species that has spread rapidly across the globe, raising concerns about the potential for infectious disease transmission. In order to mitigate its spread and the associated disease risks, it is essential to understand the complex colonization pattern of Aedes albopictus. In this study, we combined classical population genetics analyses and Approximate Bayesian Computation ( ABC ) approaches to reconstruct the demographic history of Aedes albopictus populations from representative countries in the Southeast Asian native range and in the more recently colonized areas. Our results indicate that, in the native range, populations from China, Thailand, and Japan maintain high genetic connectivity, revealing their ancestral common origin. In contrast, the invasion process outside of Southeast Asia is primarily supported by a chaotic propagule distribution mediated by human activity, resulting in a relatively high genetic diversity within the adventive populations. Our data suggest that independent and trans-continental introductions of Aedes albopictus may have facilitated the rapid establishment of adventive populations through admixture of unrelated genomes.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an opportunistic pathogen that can cause chronic infections in humans, particularly in wounds. While much is known about the pathogenesis of acute infections, the understanding of chronic infections has lagged. Here we sought to identify the genes and functions that mediate the fitness of P. aeruginosa in chronic wound infections, and to better understand the selective environment in wounds. We found that clinical isolates from chronic human wounds were frequently defective in virulence functions and biofilm formation, and that many virulence and biofilm formation genes were not required for bacterial fitness in experimental mouse wounds. In contrast, genes involved in anaerobic growth, some metabolic and energy pathways, and membrane integrity were critical. We also found that the fitness characteristics of some wound-impaired mutants could be represented by anaerobic, oxidative, and membrane-stress conditions ex vivo, and more comprehensively by high-density bacterial growth conditions, in the absence of a host. These data shed light on the bacterial functions needed in chronic wound infections, the nature of stresses applied to bacteria at chronic infection sites, and suggest therapeutic targets that might compromise wound infection pathogenesis.
Hydrocele is the most common clinical manifestation of bancroftian filariasis, an endemic disease in 80 countries. In a prospective study, we evaluated the occurrence of intrascrotal lymphangiectasia, testicular morphology and consistency, and hydrocele recurrence in patients living in a bancroftian filariasis endemic area who underwent hydrocelectomy at the Center for Teaching, Research and Tertiary Referral for Bancroftian Filariasis ( NEPAF ). A total of 1, 186 patients with uni- or bilateral filarial hydrocele ( Group-1 ) and a Comparison Group ( CG ) of 218 patients from the same area who already had undergone hydrocele-sac-sparing hydrocelectomy elsewhere were enrolled at NEPAF. The hydrocele recurrence rates in Group-1 and in the Comparison Group were 0. 3% and 19. 3%, respectively ( p<0. 001 ). There was no hydrocele recurrence in patients who underwent complete excision of the hydrocele sac ( Group-2 ). Per surgically leaking or leak-prone dilated lymphatic vessels were seen in the inner or outer surface of the hydrocele sac wall or in surrounding tissue, particularly in the retrotesticular area, in 30. 9% and 46. 3% of patients in Group-1 and Group-2, respectively ( p = 0. 081 ). The testicles were abnormal in shape, volume, and consistency in 203/1, 186 ( 18% ) and 10/28 ( 35. 7% ) of patients from Group-1 and Group-2, respectively ( p = 0. 025 ).
Trichinella spiralis is a zoonotic parasitic nematode that causes trichinellosis, a disease found on all continents except Antarctica. During chronic infection, T. spiralis larvae infect skeletal myofibres, severely disrupting their differentiation state. To identify deubiquitinating enzymes ( DUBs ) in T. spiralis, an activity-based probe, HA-Ub-VME, was used to identify DUB activity in lysate of T. spiralis L1 larvae. Immuno-blot and immuno-precipitation analyses identified a number of potential DUBs, including a putative UCH-L5 homologue, TsUCH37. The predicted gene encoding TsUCH37 was cloned and recombinant protein was expressed and purified. The deubiquitinating activity of this enzyme was verified by Ub-AMC assay. Co-precipitation of recombinant TsUCH37 showed that the protein associates with putative T. spiralis proteasome components, including the yeast Rpn13 homologue ADRM1. Furthermore, the UCH inhibitor LDN-57444 exhibited specific inhibition of recombinant TsUCH37 and reduced the viability of cultured L1 larvae. This study reports the identification of the first T. spiralis DUB, a cysteine protease that is putatively orthologous to the human protein, hUCH-L5.
Chagas disease is caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi and is a major public health problem in the Americas. Cysteine protease cruzipain is considered a validated target for therapeutic intervention in the treatment of Chagas disease. In this study, we investigated the anti-trypanosomal activity of non-peptidic nitrile-based cysteine protease inhibitors against the CL Brener strain of T. cruzi. Three nitrile-based cysteine protease inhibitors based on two scaffolds known to be associated with cathepsin K inhibition showed anti-trypanosomal activity in the 0. 1 μM to 1 μM range. The two most potent compounds had EC50 values of 0. 12 μM and 0. 25 μM, which were an order of magnitude lower than the corresponding Ki values measured against cruzain, a recombinant form of cruzipain, in an enzyme inhibition assay. This suggests that the anti-trypanosomal activity of these compounds may not be explained solely by the inhibition of cruzain, thereby triggering a putative polypharmacological profile towards cysteine proteases. In addition, we observed that the anti-trypanosomal activity of two cathepsin K inhibitors based on a cyclohexane dicarboxamide scaffold was significantly greater than what would be expected on the basis of their cruzain inhibitory activity.
Maize ( Zea mays L. ) is one of the most important cereal crops and a model for the study of genetics, evolution, and domestication. To better understand maize genome organization, we constructed a sequence-ready fingerprinted contig-based physical map that covers 93. 5% of the genome, of which 86. 1% is aligned to the genetic map. The fingerprinted contig map contains 25, 908 genic markers that enabled us to align nearly 73% of the anchored maize genome to the rice genome. The distribution pattern of expressed sequence tags correlates to that of recombination. In collinear regions, 1 kb in rice corresponds to an average of 3. 2 kb in maize, yet maize has a 6-fold genome size expansion. This can be explained by the fact that most rice regions correspond to two regions in maize as a result of its recent polyploid origin. Inversions account for the majority of chromosome structural variations during subsequent maize diploidization. We also find clear evidence of ancient genome duplication predating the divergence of the progenitors of maize and rice. Reconstructing the paleoethnobotany of the maize genome indicates that the progenitors of modern maize contained ten chromosomes.
Transmissible spongiform encephalopathies ( TSEs ) are a group of neurodegenerative diseases caused by prions, infectious agents composed of a misfolded version of the prion protein ( PrPSc ) that replicates in the absence of nucleic acids by inducing the misfolding of the cellular prion protein ( PrPC ). The most common form of human prion disease is sporadic, which appears to originate from a low frequency event of spontaneous misfolding to generate the first PrPSc particle that then propagates as in the infectious form of the disease. In this study, we attempted to mimic an early event in the etiology of sporadic disease by attempting de novo generation of infectious PrPSc in vitro using the protein misfolding cyclic amplification ( PMCA ) procedure. Under standard PMCA conditions, de novo generation of PrPSc was never observed, supporting the use of the technology for diagnostic applications. However, we report that PMCA can be modified to generate PrPSc in the absence of pre-existing PrPSc in different animal species at a low and variable rate. The de novo generated PrPSc was infectious when inoculated into wild type hamsters, producing a new disease phenotype with unique clinical, neuropathological and biochemical features.
We present a novel neurally based model for estimating angular velocity ( AV ) in the bee brain. The Angular Velocity Detector Unit ( AVDU ) is capable of quantitatively reproducing experimental observations of visual odometry and corridor-centering in free-flying honeybees, including previously unaccounted for manipulations of behaviour. The model is fitted using electrophysiological data and tested using behavioural data. We suggest that the AV response can be considered as an evolutionary extension to the optomotor response. The detector is tested behaviourally in silico with the corridor-centering paradigm, where bees navigate down a corridor with gratings ( square wave or sinusoidal ) on the walls. When combined with an existing flight control algorithm, the detector reproduces the invariance of the average flight path to the spatial frequency and contrast of the gratings, including deviations from perfect centering behaviour as found in the real bee’s behaviour. In addition, the summed response of the detector to a unit distance movement along the corridor is constant for a large range of grating spatial frequencies, demonstrating that the detector can be used as a visual odometer.
Sleeping sickness, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma brucei gambiense, has long been considered invariably fatal if left untreated. However, we report on a 15-year follow-up study of 50 untreated patients from the Ivory Coast, among whom 11 continued to refuse treatment after diagnosis. Using highly specific and sensitive diagnostic tools, we observed parasite clearance in 10 of the 11 patients who continued to refuse treatment, as well as a decrease in serological responses to trypanosome antigens in 7 of the 10 patients. We also observed two alternative natural progressions of the disease: an apparently aparasitaemic and asymptomatic infection associated with strong long-lasting serological responses, and an apparently spontaneous resolution of infection associated with a progressive drop in antibody titres, similar to that observed in treated cases. These findings demonstrate that trypanotolerance exists in humans, as it does in animals.
In this study, we investigated the role of irradiation in selecting for p53-deficient hematopoietic progenitors in vivo. We used mouse models to determine whether ionizing irradiation selects for p53-deficient cells in the hematopoietic system. We found that p53 disruption does not provide a clear selective advantage within an unstressed hematopoietic system or in previously irradiated bone marrow allowed to recover from irradiation. However, upon irradiation, p53 disruption confers a dramatic selective advantage, leading to long-term expansion of p53-deficient clones and increased lymphoma development. This selection for cells with disrupted p53 appears to be attributable to several factors, including protection from acute irradiation-induced ablation of progenitor cells, prevention of irradiation-induced loss of clonogenic capacity for stem and progenitor cells, improved long-term maintenance of progenitor cell fitness, and the disabling/elimination of competing p53 wild-type progenitors. Our results indicate that the carcinogenic effect of ionizing irradiation can in part be explained by increased selection for cells with p53 disruption, which protects progenitor cells both from immediate elimination and from long-term reductions in fitness following irradiation.
Schistosoma mansoni SmKI-1 is a serine protease inhibitor that plays a key role in the parasite's development and survival in its human host. SmKI-1 has been shown to inhibit neutrophil elastase ( NE ) and trypsin in vitro, and molecular docking studies suggest that the Kunitz domain of SmKI-1 binds to the active site of NE. This interaction impairs the ability of NE to kill schistosomula, the larval stage of S. mansoni. In addition, SmKI-1 has anti-inflammatory properties and has been shown to reduce neutrophil recruitment and elastase activity in different murine models of inflammatory diseases, including acetaminophen-mediated liver damage and gout arthritis. Furthermore, SmKI-1 has been shown to inhibit early events that trigger neutrophil recruitment in pleural cavities of mice in response to carrageenan. These results suggest that SmKI-1 is a key protein in S. mansoni survival and has the ability to inhibit neutrophil function as a potential therapeutic molecule against inflammatory diseases.
Eukaryotic transmembrane helical ( TMH ) proteins perform a wide variety of critical cellular functions, but their high-resolution structure prediction is currently hindered by the lack of close structural homologues. To address this problem, we present a novel and generic method for accurately modeling large TMH protein structures from distant homologues exhibiting distinct loop and TMH conformations. The method was stringently validated in two blind predictions and in a large benchmark consisting of pairs of membrane protein homologues with wide diversity in length, topology, and sequence identity. The method was able to improve most starting templates in the benchmark to reach near-atomic accuracy prediction in the TMH regions. The method was tested in two challenging blind predictions of membrane receptor structures, i. e. GPCR-DOCK 2008 for the adenosine receptor ( A2AR ) and GPCR-DOCK 2010 for the chemokine receptor ( CXCR4 ). The method should prove useful for the atom-level modeling and design of a large fraction of structurally uncharacterized TMH proteins from a wide range of structural homologues. The method should also be useful for rebuilding and refining X-ray structures of membrane receptors where functionally important loop regions have missing densities or are often deleted to facilitate crystallization.
Listeria monocytogenes is an intracellular bacterial pathogen that causes listeriosis, a foodborne disease that poses serious risks to fetuses, newborns, and immunocompromised adults. During infection, L. monocytogenes proliferates in the host cytosol and exploits the host actin polymerization machinery to spread from cell-to-cell and disseminate in the host. However, we report that during prolonged infection in human hepatocytes or trophoblast cells, L. monocytogenes switches from this active motile lifestyle to a stage of persistence in vacuoles. Upon intercellular spread, bacteria gradually stop producing the actin-nucleating protein ActA and become trapped in lysosome-like vacuoles termed Listeria-Containing Vacuoles ( LisCVs ). Subpopulations of bacteria resist degradation in LisCVs and enter a slow/non-replicative state. During the subculture of host cells harboring LisCVs, bacteria show a capacity to cycle between the vacuolar and the actin-based motility stages. When ActA is absent, such as in ΔactA mutants, vacuolar bacteria parasitize host cells in the so-called “viable but non-culturable” state ( VBNC ), preventing their detection by conventional colony counting methods.
Perceptual alternations between integrated and segregated percepts are a hallmark of auditory bistability in the ABA-triplet paradigm. In this study, we develop a neuromechanistic model of auditory streaming that accurately reproduces the dynamics of these alternations after the build up phase. Our model is motivated by physiological studies of auditory streaming and general models of perceptual bistability. It explicitly incorporates sound-evoked A1 responses as input to a competition network, where perceptual states are identified in the neuronal dynamics rather than pre-assigned to phenomenological units. The inclusion of NMDA-like synaptic dynamics enables temporal binding from one triplet to the next to deal with gaps in the periodic sound input. We predict that manipulations of the frequency difference between tones A and B should affect the dominance durations of the stronger percept more than those of the weaker percept. We confirm this prediction with psychoacoustic experiments and use the behavioral data to further constrain and improve the model, achieving quantitative agreement between experimental and modeling results. Our model provides a platform that can be extended to consider other stimulus conditions, including the effects of context and volition. The model parameters controlling the balance between adaptation and noise were tuned to match the statistics of perceptual durations in terms of mean durations and coefficient of variation, and A1 responses were interpreted in a statistical model using neurometric functions that mimic the time course of build up.
Schistosoma mansoni is a parasitic worm that causes schistosomiasis, a major public health problem in tropical and subtropical regions. Parasite-specific IgE is thought to correlate with protection against S. mansoni infection or re-infection.
