However, only a few molecular targets of the IgE response in S. mansoni infection have been characterised. To gain a better understanding of the basic mechanisms of anti-parasite immunity, a genome-wide characterisation of S. mansoni allergens is needed. This could lead to a better understanding of allergy and the development of safe and efficacious vaccinations against helminthic parasites. Here, we describe a complete medium- to high-throughput amenable workflow that enables the rapid translation of S. mansoni proteins using wheat germ lysate and subsequent assessment of potential allergenicity with a humanised Rat Basophilic Leukemia ( RBL ) reporter cell line. This method offers an accessible way for assessment of potential allergenicity of anti-helminthic vaccine candidates and is suitable for medium- to high-throughput studies using infected individual sera. We demonstrate the suitability of this system for characterization of novel S. mansoni allergens using well characterised plant and parasitic allergens such as Par j 2, SmTAL-1 and the IgE binding factor IPSE/alpha-1, expressed in wheat germ lysates and/or E. coli.
Hybrid dysgenic syndromes are a form of genomic incompatibility that can arise when the abundance of transposable elements ( TEs ) differs between two parents. When TEs inherited from the father are absent in the mother's genome, TEs can become activated in the progeny, causing germline damage and sterility. In Drosophila, dysgenesis can occur when TEs inherited paternally are not matched with a pool of corresponding TE silencing PIWI-interacting RNAs ( piRNAs ) provisioned by the female germline. Using the D. virilis syndrome of hybrid dysgenesis as a model, we show that divergence in the TE landscape is associated with persisting differences in germline TE expression when comparing genetically identical females of reciprocal crosses. These differences are transmitted to the next generation and coincide with increased levels of genic piRNAs associated with reduced gene expression. We further demonstrate that gene expression is idiosyncratically influenced by differences in the genic piRNA profile of the parents that arise through polymorphic TE insertions. Overall, these results support a model in which early germline events in dysgenesis establish a chronic, stable state of both TE and gene expression in the germline that is maintained through adulthood and transmitted to the next generation.
Fragile X Tremor Ataxia Syndrome ( FXTAS ) is a neurodegenerative disorder caused by expansion of a CGG trinucleotide repeat in the 5′UTR of the fragile X syndrome ( FXS ) gene, FMR1. The expanded CGG repeat is thought to induce toxicity as RNA, and in FXTAS patients, mRNA levels for FMR1 are markedly increased. Here, we show that overexpressing any of three histone deacetylases ( HDACs 3, 6, or 11 ) suppresses CGG repeat–induced neurodegeneration in a Drosophila model of FXTAS. This suppression results from selective transcriptional repression of the CGG repeat–containing transgene. We also show that in patient-derived lymphoblasts and fibroblasts, there is increased acetylation of histones at the FMR1 locus in pre-mutation carriers compared to control or FXS derived cell lines. These epigenetic changes correlate with elevated FMR1 mRNA expression in pre-mutation cell lines. Moreover, histone acetyltransferase ( HAT ) inhibitors repress FMR1 mRNA expression to control levels in pre-mutation carrier cell lines and extend lifespan in CGG repeat–expressing Drosophila. These findings support a disease model whereby the CGG repeat expansion in FXTAS promotes chromatin remodeling in cis, which in turn increases expression of the toxic FMR1 mRNA.
Lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus ( LCMV ) is a chronic viral infection that is controlled by CD8 T cell responses. However, CD8 T cell exhaustion can lead to viral persistence and immunopathology. In this study, we examined the role of host genetics in controlling CD8 T cell function and lethal immunopathology during chronic LCMV Cl-13 infection. We used F1 crosses of B10. D2 x B6 ( D2B6F1 ) and BALB. B x BALB/c ( BCF1 ) mice to examine the impact of MHC heterogeneity versus non-MHC host genetics on the development of chronic viral infection. Following chronic Cl-13 infection, both D2B6F1 and BCF1 mice demonstrated increased viral control compared to homozygous mice. Strikingly, D2B6F1 mice on a C57BL genetic background exhibited mortality following Cl-13 infection. CD8 T cell depletion prevented mortality in Cl-13-infected D2B6F1 mice, indicating that mortality was CD8 T-cell-dependent. D2B6F1 mice maintained more CD8 T cell effector cytokine production and exhibited reduced expression of the T cell exhaustion marker PD-1. In addition, D2B6F1 mice induced a larger Th1 response than BCF1 mice and Cl-13-induced mortality in D2B6F1 mice was also dependent on CD4 T-cell-mediated IFN-γ production.
Anthracis, the causative agent of anthrax, is an important zoonotic disease in China, especially in rural regions. In this study, we analyzed the genetic characteristics of Bacillus anthracis isolated from northwestern China from 1990 to 2016. We used canonical single-nucleotide polymorphism ( canSNP ) analysis and multilocus variable-number tandem repeat analysis ( MLVA ) with 15 markers to analyze 106 B. anthracis strains collected from six provinces in northwestern China. We identified five sublineages/subgroups, namely, A. Br. 001/002, A. Br. Vollum, A. Br. Aust94, A. Br. Ames, and A. Br. 008/009, using 13 canSNP sites. All of the sublineages were found in Xinjiang province, while one sublineage was found in Shaanxi, two in Gansu, three in Qinghai, and four in Inner Mongolia. However, the geographical distribution of the B. anthracis populations exhibited different canSNP characteristics from those of the strains isolated before 1990 in China. In contrast to previous data, the A. Br. Ames subgroup was also observed to be scattered from Inner Mongolia to other provinces. By canSNP analysis and MLVA, we found that the diversification of MLVA genotypes and the geographical distribution of B. anthracis populations is gradually becoming balanced across northwestern China. This study also provides preliminary survey results regarding the population diversity of B. anthracis in China, which will help promote the prevention and control of this important disease.
Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli and related food and waterborne pathogens cause severe diarrheal disease by infecting the apical surface of intestinal epithelial cells ( IECs ) and colonizing the intestinal luminal surface. To defend against these pathogens, hosts rely on immune-mediated changes in IECs, including goblet cells, which produce the mucin Muc2 and the goblet cell-derived mediator, Resistin-like Molecule ( RELM ) -β. RELM-β is strongly induced within goblet cells during infection with Citrobacter rodentium, a related mouse pathogen, and is detected in the stool and serum. Despite its dramatic induction, the role of RELM-β in host defense was unclear. Here, we show that RELM-β acts as a CD4+ T cell chemoattractant to recruit CD4+ T cells to the infected colon, where they drive a protective increase in IEC proliferation through the production of interleukin ( IL ) -22. Mice lacking the RELM-β gene ( Retnlb-/- ) suffered increased mortality and mucosal ulceration due to deep pathogen penetration of colonic crypts, and were impaired in infection-induced IEC hyper-proliferation. Enema delivery of RELM-β to Retnlb-/- mice restored CD4+ T cell recruitment, concurrently increasing IL-22 levels and IEC proliferation, while reducing mucosal pathology. These findings demonstrate that RELM-β and goblet cells play a critical role in recruiting CD4+ T cells to the colon to protect against enteric pathogens.
Noroviruses, a major cause of gastroenteritis in humans, have an unusual mechanism to initiate protein synthesis that relies on interactions between the VPg protein attached to the 5´-end of the viral RNA and eukaryotic initiation factors ( eIFs ) in the host cell. We have identified a conserved ~20 amino acid motif in the C terminus of norovirus VPg proteins that mediates direct and specific binding to the HEAT-1 domain within the 4GM fragment of eIF4G. This motif is conserved in all known noroviruses and binds to eIF4G HEAT-1 with micromolar affinity. Our results show that norovirus VPg serves as a proteinaceous ‘5´-cap’ that does not require a functional interaction with the cap-binding protein, eIF4E. We have used a combination of pull-down assays, fluorescence anisotropy, isothermal titration calorimetry ( ITC ), and NMR spectroscopy to define the VPg binding site on eIF4G HEAT-1, which is non-overlapping with the binding site for eIF4A on eIF4G HEAT-1. We have also shown that norovirus VPg can form ternary VPg-eIF4G-eIF4A complexes. The functional significance of the VPg-eIF4G interaction was demonstrated by the ability of fusion proteins containing the C-terminal peptide of MNV VPg to inhibit in vitro translation of norovirus RNA but not cap- or IRES-dependent translation.
The evolution of gene clusters in bacterial genomes has been a topic of interest in the field of evolutionary biology. Genes encoding proteins in a common pathway are often found near each other along bacterial chromosomes. Several explanations have been proposed to account for the evolution of these structures, including natural selection, the selfish operon model, and the persistence model. Here, we develop computational models to study the conditions under which gene clusters can evolve and persist. We examine the selfish operon model by re-implementing the simulation and running it under a wide range of conditions. We also introduce and study a Moran process in which there is natural selection for gene clustering and rearrangement occurs by genome inversion events. Finally, we develop and study a model that includes selection and inversion, which tracks the occurrence and fixation of rearrangements. Surprisingly, gene clusters fail to evolve under a wide range of conditions. However, factors that promote the evolution of gene clusters include a low number of genes in the pathway, a high population size, and in the case of the selfish operon model, a high horizontal transfer rate. The selfish operon model is still viable as an explanation for the evolution of gene clusters under these conditions.
Malaria, caused by the parasite Plasmodium falciparum, is responsible for significant morbidity, mortality, and economic losses in tropical regions. Pregnant women are particularly vulnerable to severe consequences of the infection due to the specific adhesion of parasite-infected erythrocytes in the placenta. This adhesion is mediated by a unique variant of PfEMP1, called VAR2CSA, which binds to chondroitin sulfate A on syncytiotrophoblasts in the intervillous space of placentas. VAR2CSA is only expressed in the presence of a placenta, suggesting that its expression is actively repressed in men, children, or non-pregnant women. However, the mechanism of repression is not understood. We show that the gene encoding VAR2CSA contains a small upstream open reading frame ( uORF ) that acts to repress translation of the resulting mRNA, revealing a novel form of gene regulation in malaria parasites. The mechanism underlying this translational repression is reversible, allowing high levels of protein translation upon selection, thus potentially enabling parasites to upregulate expression of this variant antigen in the presence of the appropriate host tissue.
Dengue virus ( DENV ) infection leads to a spectrum of disease outcomes, ranging from asymptomatic infection to hemorrhagic fever and shock. The pathophysiology of severe versus non-severe manifestations of DENV infection may be driven by host responses, which could be reflected in the transcriptional profiles of peripheral blood immune cells. We conducted genome-wide microarray analysis of whole blood RNA from 34 DENV-infected children in Nicaragua collected on days 3–6 of illness, with different disease manifestations. Gene expression analysis identified genes that are differentially regulated between clinical subgroups. The most striking transcriptional differences were observed between dengue patients with and without shock, especially in the expression of mitochondrial ribosomal proteins associated with protein biosynthesis. In the dengue hemorrhagic fever patients, one subset of differentially expressed genes encode neutrophil-derived anti-microbial peptides associated with innate immunity. A meta-analysis of our dataset in conjunction with previously published datasets confirmed that DENV infection in vivo is associated with large changes to protein and nucleic acid metabolism. Notably, whereas in vitro infection leads to an increased interferon signature, this was not consistently observed from in vivo patient samples, suggesting that the interferon response in vivo is relatively transient and was no longer observed by days 3–6 of illness.
Herpesviruses are ubiquitous pathogens that cause much disease and are difficult to clear from the host. To understand how herpesviruses enter the host, we need to know how they cross differentiated mucus-covered epithelia in vivo. We studied the host entry of Murid Herpesvirus-4 ( MuHV-4 ), a lymphotropic rhadinovirus related to the Kaposi's Sarcoma-associated Herpesvirus. We found that MuHV-4 targets the olfactory neuroepithelium for host entry. Like many herpesviruses, MuHV-4 binds to heparan sulfate ( HS ), and virions unable to bind HS show poor host entry. The olfactory neuroepithelium expresses HS on its apical neuronal cilia and is bound strongly by incoming virions. Incoming virions track down the neuronal cilia and either infect neurons or reach the underlying microvilli of the adjacent glial ( sustentacular ) cells and infect them. Thus, the olfactory neuroepithelium provides an important and complex site of HS-dependent herpesvirus uptake. MuHV-4 exploits neurons for host entry even though it is not classically neurotropic, suggesting that the olfactory neuroepithelium may provide many herpesviruses with an important entry portal.
Salmonella enterica invasion of epithelial cells requires the expression of genes located in the pathogenicity island I ( SPI-1 ). The expression of SPI-1 genes is tightly regulated and activated only under specific conditions. Here, we describe a new regulatory circuit involving CRP-cAMP, a widely established metabolic regulator, in silencing of SPI-1 genes under non-permissive conditions. CRP-cAMP-deficient Salmonella strains are unable to secrete SPI-1 T3SS effector proteins and are avirulent in a mouse model, suggesting a role for CRP-cAMP in the regulation of Salmonella virulence. CRP-cAMP indirectly regulates virulence by affecting the post-transcriptional regulation of hilD, the master regulator of Salmonella invasion. CRP-cAMP modulates the level of hilD at the post-transcriptional level and requires the presence of a newly identified regulatory motif within the hilD 3’UTR. We further demonstrate that the Hfq-dependent sRNA Spot 42 is under the transcriptional repression of CRP-cAMP and, when this repression is relieved, Spot 42 exerts a positive effect on hilD expression. In vivo and in vitro assays indicate that Spot 42 targets the 3’UTR of the hilD transcript. Together, our results highlight the biological relevance of the hilD 3’UTR as a hub for post-transcriptional control of Salmonella invasion gene expression.
Huntington's disease ( HD ) and myotonic dystrophy 1 are caused by the expansion of CAG/CTG repeats. These expansions are unstable in selective somatic tissues, which accelerates disease progression. We investigated the relationship between CAG instability, chromatin structure, and transcription at the HD locus in the R6/1 and R6/2 HD transgenic mouse lines. These mice express a similar transgene, albeit integrated at a different site, and recapitulate HD tissue-specific instability. We show that instability rates are increased in R6/2 tissues as compared to R6/1 matched-samples. High transgene expression levels and chromatin accessibility correlated with the increased CAG instability of R6/2 mice. Transgene mRNA and H3K4 trimethylation at the HD locus were increased, whereas H3K9 dimethylation was reduced in R6/2 tissues relative to R6/1 matched-tissues. However, the levels of transgene expression and these specific histone marks were similar in the striatum and cerebellum, two tissues showing very different CAG instability levels. Interestingly, the levels of elongating RNA Pol II at the HD locus, but not the initiating form of RNA Pol II, were tissue-specific and correlated with CAG instability levels. Similarly, H3K36 trimethylation, a mark associated with transcription elongation, was specifically increased at the HD locus in the striatum and not in the cerebellum.
Enterovirus 71 ( EV71 ) is one of the most virulent enteroviruses, but the specific molecular features that enhance its ability to disseminate in humans remain unknown. We analyzed the genomic features of EV71 in an immunocompromised host with disseminated disease and identified three nucleotide changes that occurred within a five-day period: a non-conservative amino acid change in VP1 located within the BC loop ( L97R ), a conservative amino acid substitution in protein 2B ( A38V ), and a silent mutation in protein 3D ( L175 ). Infectious clones were constructed using both BrCr ( lineage A ) and the clinical strain ( lineage C ) backgrounds containing either one or both non-synonymous mutations. In vitro cell tropism and competition assays revealed that the VP197 Leu to Arg substitution within the BC loop conferred a replicative advantage in SH-SY5Y cells of neuroblastoma origin. Interestingly, this mutation was frequently associated in vitro with a second non-conservative mutation ( E167G or E167A ) in the VP1 EF loop in neuroblastoma cells. Comparative models of these EV71 VP1 variants were built to determine how the substitutions might affect VP1 structure and/or interactions with host cells. Our results show that the VP1 BC loop region of EV71 plays a critical role in cell tropism independent of EV71 lineage and may have contributed to dissemination and neurotropism in the immunocompromised patient.
Streptococcus species are able to acquire new traits, such as antibiotic resistance, through the process of natural transformation, or competence. This process is regulated by quorum sensing ( QS ) mediated by peptide pheromones. One such system, ComRS, consists of a peptide ( ComS ) that is processed, secreted, and later imported into the cytoplasm, where it binds and activates the transcription factor ComR. ComR then engages in a positive feedback loop for the expression of ComS and the alternative sigma-factor SigX. Although ComRS are present in the majority of Streptococcus species, the sequence of both ComS/XIP and ComR diverge significantly, suggesting a mechanism for species-specific communication. We developed a ‘test-bed’ assay to measure the activity of different ComR proteins in response to cognate and heterologous XIP peptides in vivo, revealing distinct ComR classes of strict, intermediate, and promiscuous specificity among species. We then solved an X-ray crystal structure of ComR from S. suis to further understand the interaction with XIP and to search for structural features in ComR proteins that may explain XIP recognition. Our results provide a model for XIP recognition and specificity, and allow for the prediction of novel XIP peptides that induce ComR activity.
Eukaryotic centromeres are epigenetically maintained at specific chromosomal sites over many generations. In this study, we used the pathogenic yeast Candida albicans as a model organism to study the DNA replication properties of centromeric DNA. We discovered that each centromere is associated with a replication origin that is the first to fire on its respective chromosome, and that epigenetic formation of new ectopic centromeres ( neocentromeres ) is accompanied by shifts in replication timing, such that a neocentromere becomes the first to replicate and is associated with origin recognition complex ( ORC ) components. Furthermore, changing the level of the centromere-specific histone H3 isoform led to a concomitant change in levels of ORC association with centromere regions, further supporting the idea that centromere proteins determine origin activity. Analysis of centromere-associated DNA revealed a replication-dependent sequence pattern characteristic of constitutively active replication origins. This pattern is conserved, together with centromere position, among related strains and species, in a manner independent of primary DNA sequence. Thus, inheritance of centromere position is correlated with a constitutively active origin of replication that fires at a distinct early time.
Chronic back pain ( CBP ) is the leading cause of years lived with disability worldwide, yet little is known about the biological mechanisms underlying this symptom. We conducted a genome-wide association study ( GWAS ) meta-analysis of 158, 025 adults of European ancestry from 15 cohorts in the Cohorts for Heart and Aging Research in Genomic Epidemiology ( CHARGE ) consortium and the UK Biobank. CBP cases were defined as those reporting back pain present for ≥3–6 months; non-cases were included as controls. We found a genome-wide significant association for the intronic variant rs12310519 in SOX5 ( OR 1. 08, p = 7. 2×10−10 ), which was subsequently replicated in 283, 752 UK Biobank participants not included in the discovery sample ( OR 1. 06, p = 5. 3×10−11 ), and exceeded genome-wide significance in joint meta-analysis ( OR 1. 07, p = 4. 5×10−19 ). We also found suggestive associations at three other loci in the discovery sample, two of which exceeded genome-wide significance in joint meta-analysis: an intergenic variant, rs7833174, located between CCDC26 and GSDMC ( OR 1. 05, p = 4. 4×10−13 ), and an intronic variant, rs4384683, in DCC ( OR 0. 97, p = 2. 4×10−10 ).
Taenia solium cysticercosis is a neglected zoonotic disease that affects both humans and pigs in many developing countries. It is an important cause of epilepsy in regions where the parasite occurs, but it is largely underreported and there is a lack of data about the disease burden. This study aimed to calculate the impact of T. solium cysticercosis in Cameroon by applying both cost and Disability Adjusted Life Year ( DALY ) estimations. Based on a prevalence of epilepsy of 3. 6%, the number of people with neurocysticercosis-associated epilepsy was estimated at 50, 326 ( 95% CR 37, 299–65, 924 ), representing 1. 0% of the local population. The number of pigs diagnosed with cysticercosis was estimated at 15, 961 ( 95% CR 12, 320–20, 044 ), which corresponds to 5. 6% of the local pig population. The total annual costs due to T. solium cysticercosis in West Cameroon were estimated at 10, 255, 202 Euro ( 95% CR 6, 889, 048–14, 754, 044 ), of which 4. 7% were due to losses in pig husbandry and 95. 3% to direct and indirect losses caused by human cysticercosis. The monetary burden per case of cysticercosis amounts to 194 Euro ( 95% CR 147–253 ). The average number of DALYs lost was 9. 0 per thousand persons per year ( 95% CR 2. 8–20. 4 ).
Staphylococcus aureus produces a large number of non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs) for which the functions are poorly understood. We demonstrate that the Sigma B-dependent ncRNA RsaA represses the synthesis of the global transcriptional regulator MgrA by forming an imperfect duplex with the Shine and Dalgarno sequence and a loop-loop interaction within the coding region of the target mRNA. These two recognition sites are required for translation repression. Consequently, RsaA causes enhanced production of biofilm and a decreased synthesis of capsule formation in several strain backgrounds. These phenotypes led to a decreased protection of S. aureus against opsonophagocytic killing by polymorphonuclear leukocytes compared to the mutant strains lacking RsaA. Mice animal models showed that RsaA attenuates the severity of acute systemic infections and enhances chronic catheter infection. RsaA takes part in a regulatory network that contributes to the complex interactions of S. aureus with the host immune system to moderate invasiveness and favour chronic infections. It is the first example of a conserved small RNA in S. aureus functioning as a virulence suppressor of acute infections. We propose that RsaA has been positively selected through evolution to support commensalism and saprophytic interactions with the host.
HIV-1 uncoating is a critical step in establishing a life-long infection, yet it is poorly understood. Here, we report a novel strategy to visualize HIV-1 uncoating using a fluorescently tagged oligomeric form of a capsid-binding host protein, cyclophilin A ( CypA-DsRed ). CypA-DsRed is specifically packaged into virions through high-avidity binding to the HIV-1 capsid ( CA ). Single virus imaging reveals that CypA-DsRed remains associated with cores after permeabilization/removal of the viral membrane and is lost concomitantly with CA in vitro and in living cells. The rate of loss is modulated by core stability and is accelerated upon initiation of reverse transcription. We show that the majority of single cores lose CypA-DsRed shortly after viral fusion, while a small fraction remains intact for several hours. Single particle tracking at late times post-infection reveals a gradual loss of CypA-DsRed dependent on reverse transcription. Uncoating occurs both in the cytoplasm and at the nuclear membrane. Our novel imaging assay enables time-resolved visualization of single HIV-1 uncoating in living cells and reveals the previously unappreciated spatio-temporal features of this process.
Oligonucleotide usage in prokaryotic genomes can be linked to a number of properties, including codon usage, DNA base-stacking energy, and DNA structural conformation. We investigated how oligonucleotide frequencies differ in coding and non-coding regions, and how DNA sequence patterns change within and between prokaryotic organisms. Our results show that prokaryotic chromosomes can be described by hexanucleotide frequencies, suggesting that prokaryotic DNA is predominantly short range correlated, i. e., information in prokaryotic genomes is encoded in short oligonucleotides. Oligonucleotide usage varied more within AT-rich and host-associated genomes than in GC-rich and free-living genomes, and this variation was mainly located in non-coding regions. We found that bias in tetranucleotide usage correlated with GC content, and coding regions were more biased than non-coding regions. Non-coding regions were found to be approximately 5. 5% more AT-rich than coding regions, on average, in the 402 chromosomes examined. Pronounced DNA compositional differences were found both within and between AT-rich and GC-rich genomes. GC-rich genomes were more similar and biased in terms of tetranucleotide usage in non-coding regions than AT-rich genomes.
Meiotic recombination is a process that ensures the correct segregation of homologous chromosomes during gamete formation and contributes to DNA diversity through both large-scale reciprocal crossovers and very localised gene conversion events, also known as noncrossovers. While considerable progress has been made in understanding factors such as PRDM9 and SNP variants that influence the initiation of recombination at human hotspots, very little is known about factors acting downstream. To address this, we simultaneously analysed both types of recombinant molecules in sperm DNA at six highly active hotspots, and looked for disparity in the transmission of allelic variants indicative of any cis-acting influences. We identified a novel form of biased transmission that was exclusive to the noncrossover class of recombinant, and which presumably arises through differences between crossovers and noncrossovers in heteroduplex formation and biased mismatch repair. This form of biased gene conversion is not predicted to influence hotspot activity as previously noted for SNPs that affect recombination initiation, but does constitute a powerful and previously undetected source of recombination-driven meiotic drive that by extrapolation may affect thousands of recombination hotspots throughout the human genome.
Human health can be negatively affected by exposure to environmental chemicals and drugs. A better understanding of the molecular mechanisms of such compounds is needed to determine the risk. We present a high confidence human protein-protein association network built upon the integration of chemical toxicology and systems biology. This computational systems chemical biology model reveals uncharacterized connections between compounds and diseases, thus predicting which compounds may be risk factors for human health. The network can also be used to identify unexpected potential associations between chemicals and proteins. We propose an approach that integrates toxicogenomics data, chemical structures, protein-protein interaction data, disease information, and functional annotation to associate chemicals to disease and identify potential molecular targets. We downloaded the Comparative Toxicogenomics Database ( CTD ), which contains curated information combining drug and environmental chemical data associated with proteins. We selected 42, 194 associations between 2, 490 unique compounds and 6, 060 molecular targets known to be involved in human disease. We then analyzed selected clusters to identify new chemical-disease associations.
Auditory cortical neurons in the primary auditory cortex can be characterized by their spectrotemporal receptive fields ( STRFs ), which describe the spectral and temporal features of a sound that linearly drive a neuron. However, this characterization does not capture the complex nonlinear network in which the neuron is embedded. By fitting a nonlinear feedforward network model, called a network receptive field ( NRF ), to cortical responses to natural sounds, we reveal that primary auditory cortical neurons are sensitive over a substantially larger spectrotemporal domain than is seen in their standard STRFs. The NRF is a parsimonious network consisting of 1–7 sub-receptive fields that interact nonlinearly, and consistently better predicts neural responses to auditory stimuli than the standard STRFs. The NRF reveals separate excitatory and inhibitory sub-fields with different nonlinear properties, and interaction of the sub-fields gives rise to important operations such as gain control and conjunctive feature detection. The conjunctive effects, where neurons respond only if several specific features are present together, enable increased selectivity for particular complex spectrotemporal structures, and may constitute an important stage in sound recognition. We demonstrate that fitting auditory cortical neural responses with feedforward network models expands on simple linear receptive field models in a manner that yields substantially improved predictive power and reveals key nonlinear aspects of cortical processing.
The mammalian circadian clock is composed of clock genes that act in transcription-translation feedback loops to drive global rhythmic expression of the transcriptome and allow an organism to anticipate the momentum of the day. Using a novel clock-perturbing peptide, we established a pivotal role for casein kinase 2 ( CK2 ) -mediated circadian BMAL1-Ser90 phosphorylation ( BMAL1-P ) in regulating central and peripheral core clocks. Subsequent analysis of the underlying mechanism revealed a novel role of CRY as a repressor of CK2 protein kinase activity toward BMAL1-S90. CRY proteins have a dual function: in addition to their known role as repressors of BMAL1–CLOCK-driven transcription, we found a novel role of CRY proteins as a repressor of CK2 protein kinase activity toward BMAL1-S90. We propose a dual negative-feedback model in which a CRY-dependent CK2-driven posttranslational BMAL1–P-BMAL1 loop is an integral part of the core clock oscillator. The BMAL1 protein is hyperphosphorylated in CRY1/2-deficient mice, leading us to hypothesize that CRY proteins are involved in rhythmic BMAL1 modification. We established a circadian clock-controlling role of CK2 kinase, formerly thought to be a constitutively active kinase, in BMAL1 phosphorylation and uncovered a novel role of CRY as a regulator of cyclic CK2-mediated BMAL1 phosphorylation.
Salmonella enterica, a pathogenic bacterium, is able to survive in the presence of bile by employing multiple mechanisms of adaptation. We show that sublethal concentrations of the bile salt sodium deoxycholate ( DOC ) can adapt Salmonella to survive lethal concentrations of bile. This adaptation is associated with multiple changes in gene expression, including the upregulation of the RpoS-dependent general stress response and other stress responses. The general stress response plays a crucial role in adaptation to bile, as RpoS− mutants are unable to survive in the presence of lethal concentrations of bile. In addition to adaptation by gene expression, individual Salmonella cells can become bile-resistant without previous adaptation, and such cells are present in non-adapted cultures at frequencies between 10−6 and 10−7 per cell and generation. Fluctuation analysis indicates that these cells are present in the previous culture, and full genome sequencing of bile-resistant mutants shows that alteration of the lipopolysaccharide transport machinery is a frequent cause of mutational bile resistance. However, selection on lethal concentrations of bile also provides bile-resistant isolates that are not mutants, and we propose that such isolates derive from rare cells whose physiological state permitted survival upon encountering bile.
The E. coli chromosome is organized into 400–500 supercoiled domains by both active and passive mechanisms, such as transcription and DNA-protein association. We find that prophage Mu is organized as a stable domain bounded by the proximal location of Mu termini L and R, which are 37 kbp apart on the Mu genome. The formation/maintenance of the Mu ‘domain’ configuration is dependent on a strong gyrase site ( SGS ) at the center of Mu, the Mu L end and MuB protein, and the E. coli nucleoid proteins IHF, Fis and HU. The Mu domain was observed at two different chromosomal locations tested. By contrast, prophage λ does not form an independent domain. The establishment/maintenance of the Mu domain was promoted by low-level transcription from two phage promoters, one of which was domain dependent. We propose that the domain confers transposition readiness to Mu by fostering topological requirements of the reaction and the proximity of Mu ends. The potential benefits to the host cell from a subset of proteins expressed by the prophage may in turn help its long-term stability.
Plasmodium vivax ( Pv ) and Plasmodium falciparum ( Pf ) gametocyte carriage was studied in school-aged Papua New Guinean children who received radical cure treatment with chloroquine, artemether-lumefantrine plus either primaquine ( PQ ) or placebo. PQ is the only licensed antimalarial that prevents Pv relapses and clears mature Pf gametocytes. PQ treatment reduced the incidence of Pv gametocytes by 73%, which was comparable to its effect on incidence of blood-stage infections. 92% of Pv and 79% of Pf gametocyte-positive infections were asymptomatic. Pv and Pf gametocyte positivity and density were associated with high blood-stage parasite densities. Multivariate analysis revealed that the odds of gametocytes were significantly reduced in mixed-species infections compared to single-species infections for both species. No difference between the PQ and placebo treatment arms was observed in density of Pv gametocytes or in the proportion of Pv infections that carried gametocytes. First infections after blood-stage and placebo treatment were equally likely to carry gametocytes than first infections after PQ treatment. Pv relapses and new infections were associated with similar levels of gametocytaemia. Relapses thus contribute considerably to the Pv reservoir, highlighting the importance of effective anti-hypnozoite treatment for efficient control of Pv.
Rho GTPases are a family of proteins that control actin organization during various cellular processes such as cell migration, cytokinesis, and endocytosis. Although the primary members of this family ( RhoA, Rac, and Cdc42 ) have different downstream effects on actin remodeling, they share a common mechanism involving targeting to the plasma membrane and activation by GTP binding. We hypothesized that the details of GTPase cycling between the membrane and cytosol are key to the differential upstream regulation of these biochemical switches. We developed a modeling framework to analyze experimental data for these systems, which can reveal details of GDI-mediated cycling and help distinguish between GDI-dependent and -independent mechanisms, including vesicle trafficking and direct association-dissociation of GTPase with membrane molecules. Our analysis of experimental data for Rac membrane cycling reveals that the lower apparent affinity of GDI for RacGTP compared to RacGDP can be fully explained by the faster dissociation of the latter from the membrane. We present non-dimensional steady-state solutions for membrane fraction of GTPase in multidimensional charts, which can be used to illustrate the effects of GEFs/GAPs and regulated affinities between GTPases and membrane and/or GDI on the amount of membrane bound GTPase.
Schistosomiasis is a major public health problem for which the World Health Organization ( WHO ) aims to achieve morbidity control and elimination as a public health problem. Monitoring and evaluation ( M&E ) programmes are used to collect data to assess the impact of current interventions on schistosomiasis control. Typically, prevalence and intensity of infection data are collected from school-aged children ( SAC ) as they are relatively easy to sample and are thought to be most likely to be infected by schistosome parasites. However, adults are also likely to be infected. We investigated how the age distribution of infection impacts the mathematical model generated recommendations of the preventive chemotherapy coverage levels required to achieve the WHO goals for Schistosoma mansoni. We used three different age-intensity profiles of infection with low, moderate and high burdens of infection in adults. Our results show that for moderate prevalence regions, treating SAC only may achieve the WHO goals. However, for high prevalence regions with a high burden of infection in adults, adult treatment is required to meet the WHO goals. We highlight the importance of collecting prevalence and intensity of infection data from a broader age-range, specifically the inclusion of adult data at baseline and throughout the treatment programme, to accurately determine the treatment strategy for a defined region.
Temporal lobe epilepsy ( TLE ) is a common neurological disorder characterised by disruptive seizures. In drug resistant cases, resective surgery is often considered. However, this procedure is hampered by unpredictable success rates, with many patients continuing to have seizures even after surgery. In this study, we apply a computational model of epilepsy to patient specific structural connectivity derived from diffusion tensor imaging ( DTI ) of 22 individuals with left TLE and 39 healthy controls. We validate the model by examining patient-control differences in simulated seizure onset time and network location. We then investigate the potential of the model for surgery prediction by performing in silico surgical resections, removing nodes from patient networks and comparing seizure likelihood post-surgery to pre-surgery simulations. We find that patients tend to transit from non-epileptic to epileptic states more often than controls in the model. Regions in the left hemisphere, particularly within temporal and subcortical regions, are the most frequent starting points for seizures in patients in the model. Our analysis also implicates regions in the contralateral and frontal locations which may play a role in seizure spreading or surgery resistance. Finally, the model predicts that patient-specific surgery may lead to better outcomes than the currently used routine clinical procedure.
Human herpesvirus 8 ( HHV-8 ) encodes four viral interferon regulatory factors ( vIRFs 1–4 ), which interfere with the host's innate antiviral defenses by blocking interferon and apoptotic signaling. Here, we report that vIRF-1 directly targets and inactivates Bim, a pro-apoptotic Bcl-2 family member, via nuclear translocation. Bim is a key negative regulator of HHV-8 replication. vIRF-1-mediated relocalization of Bim was detected in transfected cells and in lytically infected endothelial cells. In vitro co-precipitation assays revealed a direct interaction between vIRF-1 and Bim, and Bim-binding residues of vIRF-1 were mapped by deletion and point mutagenesis. Generation of Bim-refractory vIRF-1 variants revealed the importance of vIRF-1:Bim interaction in vIRF-1's pro-replication and anti-apoptotic activity. Blocking the interaction with a cell-permeable peptide corresponding to the Bim-binding region of vIRF-1 confirmed the relevance of vIRF-1:Bim association to vIRF-1's pro-replication activity. This is the first report of an IRF protein that interacts with a Bcl-2 family member and of nuclear sequestration of Bim or any other member of the family as a means of inactivation.
The epithelial integrin αVβ6 plays a crucial role in regulating the amplitude of protective lung interferon ( IFN ) responses against multiple respiratory pathogens, including influenza virus, Sendai virus, and bacterial pneumonia. Mice lacking the β6 integrin ( β6 KO ) are protected from disease caused by influenza infection and develop less severe acute lung injury ( ALI ), characterized by reduced edema, inflammatory cytokine expression, and vascular permeability of the lung epithelium. β6 KO mice also have altered baseline homeostasis with high baseline CD11b+ CD11c+ macrophages. We show that the protection of β6 KO mice from influenza infection depends on the loss of β6-activated transforming growth factor-β ( TGF-β ) and elevated type I IFN signaling, while the phenotypic changes in lung macrophages are independent of the type I IFN pathway. Macrophages isolated from TGF-β1-treated β6 KO mice display decreased mRNA encoding levels of IFN-associated transcripts, highlighting that the loss of β6-activated TGF-β results in an altered lung macrophage population and increased type I IFN activation. Furthermore, β6 KO mice treated with TGF-β1 have increased numbers of CD11c+ CD11b- macrophages and are no longer protected from influenza infection, suggesting that the loss of β6-mediated TGF-β1 activation is important for both protection and the ‘activated’ macrophage phenotype.
Leishmania ( Viannia ) braziliensis is the most common cause of cutaneous and mucosal leishmaniasis in the Americas. Diagnosis of this disease is challenging due to the low parasite burden in lesions. The Leishmanin Skin Test ( LST ) is used as a complementary tool for diagnosis in endemic areas, based on delayed type hypersensitivity responses to Leishmania antigens injected intradermally. We performed a retrospective analysis of 733 cases of tegumentary leishmaniasis evaluated at a reference center in Argentina between 2006 and 2015 to assess the usefulness of LST as a diagnostic tool. We found that 65% of cases were confirmed through positive smears from skin or mucosal lesions, with only 6 cases having a negative LST. Among smear-negative cases, 190 were also negative by LST, but 69 cases had a positive LST. The sensitivity of LST was similar to that of smears across all age groups. We also found that lesions older than 21 days were more likely to have positive results for both smears and LST. These findings support the use of LST as a diagnostic complement for American Cutaneous Leishmaniasis across all age groups, even in endemic areas.
Coronary artery disease ( CAD ) is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Genome-wide association studies ( GWAS ) have identified over 40 loci that affect CAD risk, but the causal mechanisms at the majority of these loci are unknown. In this study, we used a combination of open chromatin mapping with formaldehyde-assisted isolation of regulatory elements ( FAIRE-seq ) and enhancer and transcription factor mapping using chromatin immuno-precipitation ( ChIP-seq ) in primary human macrophages before and after exposure to atherogenic oxidized low-density lipoprotein ( oxLDL ), with resultant foam cell formation. We found that oxLDL-induced foam cell formation was associated with changes in a subset of open chromatin and active enhancer sites that strongly correlated with expression changes of nearby genes. OxLDL-regulated enhancers were enriched for several transcription factors, including C/EBP-beta, which has no previously documented role in foam cell formation. We found that variants at CAD-associated loci were significantly and specifically enriched in the subset of chromatin sites altered by oxLDL exposure, including rs72664324 in an oxLDL-induced enhancer at the PPAP2B locus. OxLDL increased C/EBP beta binding to this site and C/EBP beta binding and enhancer activity were stronger with the protective A allele of rs72664324. In addition, expression of the PPAP2B protein product LPP3 was present in foam cells in human atherosclerotic plaques and oxLDL exposure up-regulated LPP3 in macrophages resulting in increased degradation of pro-inflammatory mediators.
One round of azithromycin mass drug administration (MDA) may be sufficient to interrupt transmission of trachoma in districts with a prevalence of trachomatous inflammation–follicular (TF) of 5. 0–9. 9% in 1–9-year-olds. In Malawi, eight districts with baseline TF prevalences of 5. 0–9. 9% were treated with one round of azithromycin MDA, achieving a mean coverage of ~80%. We report the results of impact surveys conducted at least 6 months after MDA in 18 evaluation units of the 8 treated districts. Each of the 18 evaluation units had a TF1-9 prevalence <5. 0%. The study demonstrates that one round of azithromycin MDA with ~80% coverage is associated with a reduction in TF prevalence to <5% in Malawi districts with TF of 5. 0–9. 9%. This approach may be a practical alternative to the World Health Organization ( WHO ) recommendation of three rounds of azithromycin treatment for districts with TF prevalence ≥10%. The study provides optimism that Malawi may be able to eliminate trachoma as a public health problem by 2020.
Plants have evolved a sophisticated innate immune system to defend against pathogen attacks. Nucleotide-binding domain leucine-rich repeat ( NLR ) protein complexes are intracellular immune sensors that recognize pathogen-encoded effectors to initiate complex immune responses, including a sustained increase in cytosolic Ca2+ concentration, transcriptional reprogramming, production of reactive oxygen species ( ROS ), and programmed cell death ( PCD ). In Arabidopsis thaliana, NLR proteins RPS2 and RPM1 initiate resistance upon recognition of pathogen effectors AvrRpt2 and AvrRpm1/AvrB, respectively. We identified six closely related Arabidopsis Ca2+-dependent protein kinases ( CPKs ) that mediate bifurcate immune responses activated by NLR proteins. The dynamics of differential CPK1/2 activation by pathogen effectors controls the onset of cell death. Sustained activation of CPK4/5/6/11 phosphorylates a specific subgroup of WRKY transcription factors, WRKY8/28/48, to synergistically regulate transcriptional reprogramming crucial for NLR-dependent restriction of pathogen growth. In contrast, CPK1/2/4/11 phosphorylate plasma membrane-resident NADPH oxidases for ROS production and contribute to PCD.
Schistosoma haematobium, a neglected tropical disease, imposes a significant burden on public health in developing countries, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa. In Mali, the incidence of S. haematobium is rising due to factors such as irrigation and hydro-electric projects, shifts from nomadic to sedentary existence, and ineffective control programs. To enhance management and control of this parasitic infection, public health programs could benefit from parsimonious forecasting and early warning systems. However, less than 0. 5% of Schistosoma sp. investigations have attempted to predict their spatial and temporal distributions. In this study, the S. haematobium time-series for the district of Niono, Mali, was fitted with general-purpose exponential smoothing methods to generate contemporaneous on-line forecasts. These methods, encapsulated within a state–space framework, accommodate seasonal and inter-annual time-series fluctuations. The exponential smoothing state–space framework employed herein produced reasonably accurate forecasts for this time-series, which reflects the incidence of S. haematobium–induced terminal hematuria. The framework obliquely captured prior non-linear interactions between disease dynamics and exogenous covariates, such as climate, irrigation, and public health interventions. Therefore, this framework could assist with managing and assessing S. haematobium transmission and intervention impact in the district of Niono, Mali, and potentially elsewhere in the Sahel.
Human cytomegalovirus ( HCMV ) has evolved an additional level of self-imposed restriction by the viral tegument protein pp150, which prevents the onset of viral gene expression in the S/G2 cell cycle phase of otherwise fully permissive cells. This restriction is mediated by a cyclin A-binding motif in pp150. We investigated the physiological relevance of this restriction during productive HCMV infection by employing a cyclin A-binding deficient pp150 mutant virus. One consequence of unrestricted viral gene expression in S/G2 was the induction of a G2/M arrest. G2-arrested but not mitotic cells supported viral replication. Cyclin A destabilization by the viral gene product pUL21a was required to maintain the virus-permissive G2-arrest. An HCMV double-point mutant where both pp150 and pUL21a are disabled in cyclin A interaction forced mitotic entry of the majority of infected cells, with a severe negative impact on cell viability and virus growth. Thus, pp150 and pUL21a functionally cooperate, together building a cell cycle synchronization strategy of cyclin A targeting and avoidance that is essential for productive HCMV infection.
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis ( ALS ) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease that results in progressive degeneration of motor neurons, ultimately leading to paralysis and death. Approximately 10% of ALS cases are familial, with the remaining 90% being sporadic. The cause of ALS in approximately 30% of familial cases and in the majority of sporadic cases remains unknown. We undertook a targeted sequencing approach of 169 known and candidate ALS disease genes in 242 sporadic ALS cases and 129 matched controls to try to identify novel variants linked to ALS. We found a significant enrichment in novel and rare variants in cases versus controls, indicating that we are likely identifying disease associated mutations. This study highlights the utility of next generation sequencing techniques combined with functional studies and rare variant analysis tools to provide insight into the genetic etiology of a heterogeneous sporadic disease. We found rare or novel variants in 144 of the 242 patients sequenced, suggesting that at minimum approximately 40% of the cases have no potential genetic cause for ALS that we could identify with our sequencing method and set of candidate genes. We identified new variants in known ALS disease genes, as well as in genes associated with ALS, and found no association between several previously identified SNPs and ALS in our population, with the exception of APOE.
Influenza-specific memory CD4+ T cells require interleukin-6 ( IL-6 ) for their development and function. IL-6 is an important regulator of T cell proliferation and survival, and it is abundant following infection with influenza virus. In this study, we analyzed the role of IL-6 in the development of T cell memory to influenza virus in wild type and IL-6 deficient mice. We found that CD4+ T cell memory, but not CD8+ T cell memory, is critically dependent on IL-6. IL-6 limits the activity of virus-specific CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cells ( Tregs ), thereby facilitating the activity of virus-specific memory CD4+ T cells. We demonstrated that influenza-induced IL-6 limits the activity of virus-specific Tregs, thereby facilitating the activity of virus-specific memory CD4+ T cells. In contrast, CD8+ T cell memory is unimpaired in IL-6 deficient mice, suggesting that CD4+ and CD8+ T cells differ in their susceptibility to suppression by Tregs. Our findings support the view that IL-6 has an inhibitory effect on the activity of virus-specific Tregs, thereby favoring pathogen clearance and survival of the host.
Cytosine-5 methyltransferases of the Dnmt2 family are known to function as DNA and tRNA methyltransferases. However, the role and biological significance of Dnmt2 are greatly hampered by a lack of knowledge about its protein interactions. In this report, we identify enolase as a Dnmt2-binding protein through a yeast two-hybrid screen. Enolase, a glycolytic enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate, has both cytoplasmatic and nuclear localization in the parasite Entamoeba histolytica. We show that enolase acts as a Dnmt2 inhibitor and that this inhibitory activity is antagonized by 2-phosphoglycerate, suggesting that glucose metabolism controls the non-glycolytic function of enolase. Interestingly, glucose starvation drives enolase to accumulate within the nucleus, leading to the formation of additional enolase-E. histolytica DNMT2 homolog ( Ehmeth ) complex, and to a significant reduction of the tRNAAsp methylation in the parasite. We also demonstrate that enolase is the first Dnmt2-interacting protein and highlight an unexpected role of a glycolytic enzyme in the modulation of Dnmt2 activity.
Chikungunya virus ( CHIKV ) is a mosquito-borne pathogen transmitted to humans via saliva during blood feeding. Mosquito saliva is a complex mixture of secretory factors that modulate the feeding site to enhance pathogen infection and establishment. Here, we report the discovery of exogenous microRNAs ( miRNAs ) in the saliva of two species of Aedes mosquitoes, Ae. aegypti and Ae. albopictus. MicroRNAs are small, non-coding RNAs that regulate gene expression and are generally found inside cells. However, circulating miRNAs have been identified in human serum and saliva. We used next generation sequencing to identify 103 exogenous miRNAs in mosquito saliva, of which 31 were previously unidentified and designated as novel. Several miRNAs were expressed only in CHIKV-infected mosquitoes. Five saliva miRNAs were tested for their potential to regulate CHIKV infection, and our results demonstrate their functional role in transmission and establishment of infection during blood feeding on the host. Inhibition of these miRNAs decreased viral replication, suggesting that they enhance CHIKV replication and dissemination in the host and at the site of infection.
Mitochondrial DNA ( mtDNA ) is an independently maintained genome that encodes proteins required for cellular respiration. Deletions in the mtDNA are associated with several maternally inherited diseases, certain cancers, and neurological disorders. These deletions are often flanked by short, repetitive sequences, suggesting that they may result from recombination events. Our current understanding of mtDNA maintenance and repair is limited compared to nuclear DNA repair. This study investigated the contribution of nuclear double-strand break repair ( DSBR ) proteins Rad51p, Rad52p, and Rad59p in mtDNA repair in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. We have determined that Rad51p and Rad59p are localized to the matrix of the mitochondria and that Rad51p binds directly to mitochondrial DNA. A mitochondrially-targeted restriction endonuclease was used to produce a unique double-strand break ( DSB ) in the mitochondrial genome, allowing direct analysis of DSB repair in vivo. We find that loss of Rad51p, Rad52p, and Rad59p significantly decreases the rate of spontaneous deletion events and the loss of Rad51p and Rad59p impairs the repair of induced mtDNA DSBs.
Acute rheumatic fever ( ARF ) and rheumatic heart disease ( RHD ) pose a major disease burden among disadvantaged populations worldwide. These conditions result from Group A Streptococcal ( GAS ) infection and are acknowledged as diseases of poverty. However, the role of specific social and environmental factors in GAS infection and progression to ARF/RHD is not well understood. We conducted a systematic review to determine the association between social determinants of health and GAS infection, ARF and RHD, and the effect of interventions targeting these factors. We identified 1, 164 publications, of which 90 met inclusion criteria, comprising 91 individual studies. The majority of studies reported a positive association between socioeconomic determinants and risk of GAS infection ( 57. 1% ) and ARF/RHD ( 50% ). Crowding was the most assessed factor ( 14 studies with GAS infection, 36 studies with ARF/RHD ), followed by socioeconomic status ( 6 and 36 respectively ). The majority of studies assessing crowding, dwelling characteristics, education and employment status of parents or cases, and nutrition reported a positive association with risk of GAS infection, ARF or RHD. Crowding and socioeconomic status satisfactorily met the criteria of a causal association.
In the PhoQ/PhoP bacterial signaling network, a single point mutation that abolishes the phosphatase activity of the sensor kinase PhoQ results in a striking change in phenotype. The mutant responds to stimulus in a bistable manner, as opposed to the wild-type, which has a graded response. Mutant cells in on and off states have different morphologies, and their state is inherited over many generations. Interestingly, external conditions that repress signaling in the wild-type drive the mutant to the on state. Mathematical modeling and experiments suggest that the bistability depends on positive autoregulation of the two key proteins in the circuit, PhoP and PhoP. The mutant has a lower fitness in stationary phase cultures in rich medium compared to the off state. However, due to the high inheritance of the on state, a population of on cells can be epigenetically trapped in a low-fitness state. Our results demonstrate the remarkable versatility of the prototypical two-component signaling architecture and highlight the tradeoffs in the particular case of the PhoQ/PhoP system.
Primary Amoebic Meningoencephalitis ( PAM ) is a rare but devastating infection caused by the free-living amoeba Naegleria fowleri. PAM is characterized by a high mortality rate and a lack of established success in treatment. In the absence of economic incentives to develop anti-PAM drugs, anti-PAM drug discovery largely relies on drug repurposing, a cost-effective strategy to apply known drugs for treatment of rare or neglected diseases. Similar to fungi, N. fowleri has an essential requirement for ergosterol, a building block of plasma and cell membranes. Disruption of sterol biosynthesis by small-molecule inhibitors is a validated interventional strategy against fungal pathogens of medical and agricultural importance. The N. fowleri genome encodes the sterol 14-demethylase ( CYP51 ) target, which shares ~35% sequence identity with fungal orthologues. This similarity raises the possibility of repurposing anti-mycotic drugs and optimizing their usage for the treatment of PAM. In this work, we systematically assessed the impact of anti-fungal azole drugs on sterol biosynthesis and viability of cultured N. fowleri trophozoites, identified the endogenous CYP51 substrate by mass spectrometry analysis of N. fowleri lipids, and analyzed the interactions between the recombinant CYP51 target and conazoles by UV-vis spectroscopy and x-ray crystallography. Collectively, the target-based and parasite-based data obtained in these studies validated CYP51 as a potentially ‘druggable’ target in N. fowleri, and conazole drugs as candidates for assessment in the animal model of PAM.
Nematode parasites trigger a host protective type 2 immune response via interleukin-4 receptor alpha ( IL-4Rα ). However, the role of IL-4Rα in maintaining host type 2 immune responses following polarization is not well understood. To determine the role of IL-4Rα after polarization, we used a recently established strain of rosaCreERT2-/+IL-4Rα-/Lox mice where il4rα gene deletion can be temporally controlled. We show that sustained expression of IL-4Rα is required for the maintenance of type 2 immune responses and protective immunity following interruption after polarization with Nippostrongylus brasiliensis primary infection. Moreover, we show by temporal deletion of IL-4Rα prior to secondary infection with N. brasiliensis that signaling via this receptor drives more efficient recall of type 2 immune responses and clearance of the parasites. Together, this study demonstrates that sustained IL-4Rα mediated signaling is required for the maintenance of anti-nematode type 2 immune responses, describing a novel function for IL-4Rα that is distinct from its role in immune polarization. Our studies elucidate previously unknown functions of IL-4Rα mediated signaling beyond its role in the establishment of Th2 immune responses during N. brasiliensis infection.
Bartonella is a genus of bacteria that causes numerous human infections and is prevalent in mammals. We analyzed the largest collection of Bartonella gltA genotypes to date, including 67 new genotypes, and found that this pathogenic genus likely originated as an environmental bacterium and insect commensal before infecting mammals. Rodents and domestic animals serve as the reservoirs or key proximate hosts for most Bartonella genotypes in humans. We also found evidence of exchange of Bartonella between phylogenetically distant domestic animals and wildlife, likely due to increased contact. Overall, our findings show that Bartonella is a rich system for examining the impacts of humans on patterns of infectious disease spread within species and between species, across landscapes and across the globe.
MALAT1 is a long noncoding RNA that is upregulated in cancer tissues and is associated with hyper-proliferation. We demonstrate that MALAT1 levels are regulated during normal cell cycle progression and is required for G1/S and mitotic progression. Genome-wide transcriptome analyses reveal that MALAT1 modulates the expression of cell cycle genes. Depletion of MALAT1 leads to activation of p53 and its target genes, and the cell cycle defects observed in MALAT1-depleted cells are sensitive to p53 levels. Furthermore, MALAT1-depleted cells display reduced expression of B-MYB, an oncogenic transcription factor involved in G2/M progression, due to altered binding of splicing factors on B-MYB pre-mRNA and aberrant alternative splicing. In human cells, MALAT1 promotes cellular proliferation by modulating the expression and/or pre-mRNA processing of cell cycle–regulated transcription factors. We propose that abnormal expression of MALAT1 in specific cell types or tissues results in aberrant alternative splicing leading to misexpression of genes that are involved in cell cycle progression and/or cell death, thereby contributing to tumor progression.
Juvenile hormone ( JH ) is a key regulator of insect development, reproduction, and metamorphosis. In locusts, JH acts independently of 20-hydroxyecdysone ( 20E ) to stimulate vitellogenesis and egg production in adult females. However, the molecular basis of JH action in promoting vitellogenesis has not been fully elucidated. We have now demonstrated that JH stimulates DNA replication and increases ploidy in preparation for vitellogenesis in migratory locusts. Using RNA interference ( RNAi ) to phenocopy a JH-deprived condition, we have shown that JH stimulates the expression of Mcm4 and Mcm7, two genes in the DNA replication pathway. Depletion of Mcm4 or Mcm7 inhibited de novo DNA synthesis and polyploidization, and resulted in the substantial reduction of vitellogenin mRNA levels as well as severely impaired oocyte maturation and ovarian growth. Furthermore, we have shown that the JH receptor, Met, directly regulates the transcription of Mcm4 and Mcm7 by binding to upstream consensus sequences with E-box or E-box-like motifs. Our results suggest that the JH-receptor complex acts on Mcm4 and Mcm7 to regulate DNA replication and polyploidy for vitellogenesis and oocyte maturation.
Leprosy patients with recent nerve function impairment ( NFI ) are commonly treated with prednisolone, but the optimal treatment duration has not yet been established. The “Treatment of Early Neuropathy in Leprosy” ( TENLEP ) trial aimed to determine whether a 32-week prednisolone course is more effective than a 20-week course in restoring and improving nerve function. In this multi-centre, triple-blind, randomized controlled trial, 868 leprosy patients who had recently developed clinical NFI ( <6 months ) were allocated to a prednisolone treatment regimen of either 20 weeks or 32 weeks. Prednisolone was started at either 45 or 60 mg/day, depending on the patient’s body weight, and was then tapered. Throughout follow up, NFI was assessed by voluntary muscle testing and monofilament testing. The primary outcome was the proportion of patients with improved or restored nerve function at week 78. At 78 weeks, the proportion of patients with improved or restored nerve function did not differ significantly between the groups: 78. 1% in the 20-week arm and 77. 5% in the 32-week arm ( p = 0. 821 ). The results suggest that a 20-week course of prednisolone is as effective as a 32-week course in improving and restoring recent clinical NFI in leprosy patients.
Male Rocky Mountain elk ( Cervus elaphus nelsoni ) and male European Red Deer ( Cervus elaphus scoticus ) produce different types of vocalizations during the mating season. Elk produce loud and high fundamental frequency bugles, while Red Deer produce loud and low fundamental frequency roaring calls. To understand the relationship between sound complexity and anatomy/physiology, we developed a finite element model of the larynx and a wave propagation model of the vocal tract based on the morphology and biomechanics of the elk. The model can produce a wide range of fundamental frequencies. We found that low fundamental frequencies require low vocal fold strain, but large lung pressure and large glottal flow to achieve high sound intensity levels. In contrast, high-frequency bugles require large muscular effort to strain the vocal ligament and high lung pressure to overcome phonation threshold pressure. However, high-frequency bugles can achieve at least 10 dB more intensity level than low-frequency calls. We also found that glottal efficiency, the ratio of radiated sound power to aerodynamic power at the glottis, is higher in elk, suggesting an advantage of high-pitched signaling. This advantage is based on two aspects: lower airflow required for aerodynamic power and an acoustic radiation advantage at higher frequencies.
Chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by high-throughput sequencing ( ChIP-seq ) has become the preferred approach for mapping transcription-factor binding sites and chromatin modifications. However, the state of the art for analyzing ChIP-seq data relies on using only reads that map uniquely to a relevant reference genome ( uni-reads ). This can lead to the omission of up to 30% of alignable reads. We describe a general approach for utilizing reads that map to multiple locations on the reference genome ( multi-reads ). Our approach is based on allocating multi-reads as fractional counts using a weighted alignment scheme. Using human STAT1 and mouse GATA1 ChIP-seq datasets, we illustrate that incorporation of multi-reads significantly increases sequencing depths, leads to detection of novel peaks that are not otherwise identifiable with uni-reads, and improves detection of peaks in mappable regions. Overall, peaks from multi-read analysis have similar characteristics to peaks that are identified by uni-reads except that the majority of them reside in segmental duplications. We further validate a number of GATA1 multi-read only peaks by independent quantitative real-time ChIP analysis and identify novel target genes of GATA1. These computational and experimental results establish that multi-reads can be of critical importance for studying transcription factor binding in highly repetitive regions of genomes with ChIP-seq experiments.
Neglected tropical diseases ( NTDs ) such as human African trypanosomiasis, leprosy, visceral leishmaniasis, and Chagas disease impose a significant economic burden on individuals, particularly in low- and middle-income countries ( LMICs ). The World Health Organization ( WHO ) has set targets to control or eliminate these diseases by 2020. We estimated the economic benefits to individuals of meeting these targets through innovative and intensified disease management ( IDM ). We combined information on productivity loss and out-of-pocket payments ( OPPs ) related to these NTDs with projections of the number of people suffering from each disease, country, and year for 2011–2020 and 2021–2030. We compared the ideal scenario in which the WHO’s 2020 targets are met with a counterfactual scenario in which the situation of 1990 stayed unaltered. The economic benefit equaled the difference between the two scenarios. We used probabilistic sensitivity analyses to quantify the degree of uncertainty around the base-case impact estimate. The total global productivity gained for the four IDM-NTDs was estimated to be I$ 23. 1 ( I$ 15. 9–I$ 34. 0 ) billion in 2011–2020 and I$ 35. 9 ( I$ 25. 0–I$ 51. 9 ) billion in 2021–2030. The reduction in OPPs was estimated to be I$ 14 billion ( US$ 6. 7 billion ) and I$ 18 billion ( US$ 10. 4 billion ) for the same periods.
The prevailing theory in neuroscience suggests that neurons with higher selectivity, i. e., responding to a narrower range of sensory inputs, carry more information about external sensory inputs. In the auditory cortex, neuronal responses are less selective immediately after the onset of a sound and then become highly selective in the following sustained response epoch. However, we found that the neural population conveys similar information about sound input across the 2 epochs in spite of the neuronal selectivity differences. The amount of information encoded turns out to be almost completely dependent upon the total number of population spikes in the read-out window for this system. Moreover, inhomogeneous Poisson spiking behavior is sufficient to account for this property. These results imply a novel principle of sensory encoding that is potentially shared widely among multiple sensory systems.
OX40 is a co-stimulatory molecule that plays a critical role in the maintenance of anti-viral T cell responses during chronic viral infections. In contrast to acute viral infections, where T cell responses are followed by a contraction of the anti-viral T cell compartment, chronic viral infections require sustained anti-viral T cell responses to control viral replication and prevent viral spreading. While much is known about the inhibitory signals that limit T cell activity during chronic viral infections, such as PD-1, little is known about the stimulatory signals that allow maintenance of anti-viral T cells. Here, we show that OX40 is a key factor in sustaining anti-viral T cell responses during persistent LCMV clone 13 infection. Anti-viral T cells express high levels of OX40 in the presence of their cognate antigen, and T cells lacking the OX40 receptor fail to accumulate sufficiently. Moreover, the emergence of T cell dependent germinal center responses and LCMV-specific antibodies are severely impaired in OX40-deficient mice. Consequently, OX40-deficient mice fail to control LCMV clone 13 infection over time, highlighting the importance of this signaling pathway during persistent viral infection.
Convergent evolution is the process by which different species evolve similar traits independently of a common ancestor. Here, we show that a mechanically optimal method of swimming with elongated fins has evolved independently at least eight times in both vertebrate and invertebrate swimmers across three different phyla. The optimal specific wavelength ( OSW ), which is the length of an undulation along an animal’s fin during swimming divided by the mean amplitude of undulations along the fin length, is consistently around twenty. This value maximizes the force generated by the body, which in turn maximizes swimming speed. We hypothesize a mechanical basis for this optimality and suggest reasons for its repeated emergence through evolution. Unlike the case of the convergently evolved wing, the evolved feature here is a pattern of movement that occurs across a morphologically diverse set of moving appendages on aquatic animals. These animals swim by undulating elongated fins while keeping their body relatively rigid. We hypothesize that regulation of the OSW, axial elongation, and fin elongation in the phyla in which we observe these traits may reflect the action of common genetic networks. This phenomenon unifies a vast diversity of swimming organisms, from invertebrates, like cuttlefish, to vertebrates, like cartilaginous and bony fish.
Condensins I and II are a class of evolutionarily conserved protein complexes that play a central role in chromosome assembly and segregation in eukaryotes. Here, we report the first comprehensive genetic study of mammalian condensins, demonstrating that both condensin I and II are essential for neural stem cell ( NSC ) divisions and survival in mice. Simultaneous depletion of both condensins leads to severe defects in chromosome assembly and segregation, causing DNA damage and triggering p53-induced apoptosis. Individual depletions of condensins I and II lead to slower loss of NSCs compared to simultaneous depletion, but display distinct mitotic defects: chromosome missegregation was observed more prominently in NSCs depleted of condensin II, whereas mitotic delays were detectable only in condensin I-depleted NSCs. Notably, NSCs depleted of condensin II display hyperclustering of pericentric heterochromatin and nucleoli, indicating that condensin II, but not condensin I, plays a critical role in establishing interphase nuclear architecture. Our results demonstrate that condensins I and II have overlapping and non-overlapping functions in NSCs, and also provide evolutionary insight into the intricate balancing acts of the two condensin complexes.
Schistosoma mansoni, a parasitic flatworm, is unusual among hermaphroditic trematodes because it has evolved gonochorism, where sex is determined by a female heterogametic system. However, phenotypic sexual dimorphism appears only after infection of the vertebrate definitive host, and the molecular mechanisms that trigger sexual differentiation remain unknown. To study the molecular basis of sex determination and sexual differentiation in schistosomes, we investigated the whole transcriptome of S. mansoni in a stage- and sex-comparative manner. We performed RNA-seq on males and females for five developmental stages: cercariae larvae, three in vivo schistosomulum stages, and adults. We detected 7, 168 genes differentially expressed between sexes in at least one of the developmental stages, and 4, 065 of them were functionally annotated. Our results suggest that sexual differentiation in S. mansoni is accompanied by distinct male and female transcriptional landscapes of known players of the host-parasite crosstalk, genetic determinants, and epigenetic regulators. We propose that such combination could lead to the optimized sexual dimorphism of this parasitic species.
We propose an approach for modeling disagreements among experts in large-scale annotation efforts. Our approach assigns a confidence value ( i. e., the posterior probability that an annotation is correct ) to each annotation. We developed two probabilistic models for performing this analysis and compared them using computer simulation and actual performance based on a large data set generated by human annotators. We show that our approach can significantly increase the probability of choosing the correct annotation, even in the worst-case scenario when all annotators disagree. We also make publicly available a corpus of 10, 000 sentences annotated according to several cardinal dimensions. The corpus was annotated by a group of eight experts, and a 1, 000-sentence subset was further annotated by five new experts. Our approach is general and can be applied to most data annotation studies. We suggest an internally consistent way to design annotation experiments and analyze curation data. We propose a holistic approach to quantify our certainty in individual annotations for a group of several annotators, which allows us to retain the complete dataset as a basis for training and testing machine learning methods.
Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome ( HPS ), caused by Andes virus ( ANDV ) and ANDV-like viruses, is responsible for most HPS cases in South America. Convalescent human plasma has shown promise as a possible treatment for HPS, but its availability is limited. We have explored the concept of using DNA vaccine technology to produce antiviral biologics, including polyclonal neutralizing antibodies, for use in humans. Geese were vaccinated with an ANDV DNA vaccine encoding the virus envelope glycoproteins and developed high-titer neutralizing antibodies after the second vaccination. These antibodies were purified from egg yolks and shown to be highly reactive to specific amino acid sequences of ANDV envelope glycoproteins. We examined the protective efficacy of the goose-derived antibody in the hamster model of lethal HPS. Hamsters were passively transferred with α-ANDV immune sera or IgY/IgYΔFc purified from eggs starting 5 days after an IM challenge with ANDV. Both immune sera and egg-derived purified IgY/IgYΔFc protected 8 of 8 and 7 of 8 hamsters, respectively. In contrast, all hamsters receiving IgY/IgYΔFc purified from normal geese or no treatment developed lethal HPS. These findings demonstrate that the DNA vaccine/goose platform can be used to produce a candidate antiviral biological product capable of preventing a lethal disease when administered post-exposure.
Dnmt3a is a DNA methyltransferase enzyme that plays an important role in the establishment of normal methylation patterns in the genome. We have used whole-genome bisulfite sequencing to comprehensively characterize the methylomes from Dnmt3a wildtype and Dnmt3a-deficient mouse lung tumors. Our results show that Dnmt3a wildtype tumors are characterized by large hypomethylated domains that correspond to nuclear lamina-associated domains. In contrast, Dnmt3a-deficient tumors show a uniformly hypomethylated genome.
